site_title: Japan aims for steady progress as automakers’ losses balloon, top negotiator says
summary: Japan's top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa aims for steady progress in US tariff negotiations, amid rising losses for the country's automakers, which are suffering a $1 million loss every hour. With no Japanese company having a margin large enough to absorb the 25% tariffs on auto exports, Akazawa emphasized the need for swift and steady progress. He is set to meet with US counterparts in Washington for the second round of negotiations.

site_title: Taiwan’s economy beats estimates on pre-tariff export rush
summary: Taiwan's economy expanded 5.37% in Q1, beating estimates, driven by a surge in exports ahead of looming US tariffs. The country's export-oriented economy has benefited from global demand for high-tech products, including those underpinning AI development. Exports reached a record $49.6 billion in March, with shipments to the US and Asean countries seeing new highs. The US tariff threat had prompted economists to lower their growth estimates, but Taiwan's central bank is expected to cut interest rates as early as September to mitigate the impact of uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Customer service, pricing and how much wafer allocation can be obtained are likely to influence a company’s decision about which chip manufacturer would be best.

site_title: TSMC starts building third Arizona plant as US tariffs loom
summary: TSMC, the world's most advanced chipmaker, has begun construction on its third chip plant in Arizona as the US government threatens further tariffs to entice manufacturing back home. The third plant will use advanced N2 and A16 process technologies, while the fifth and sixth plants will utilize even more advanced technologies. This expansion is part of the US government's effort to entice companies like TSMC to invest in the US, with Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick signaling that withholding subsidies may be a condition for federal semiconductor subsidies.

images.alt_text: Customer service, pricing and how much wafer allocation can be obtained are likely to influence a company’s decision about which chip manufacturer would be best.
TSMC has been spending billions of US dollars on new factories overseas, though it has said most manufacturing will remain in Taiwan.
In addition to AMD, both Apple and Nvidia have said that some of their chips are being produced at TSMC’s Arizona plant.
The main chipmaker for Apple and Nvidia reported revenue of NT$839.25 billion (S$34 billion) in the first three months of 2025.

site_title: Singapore’s F&B sector falls into contraction after year of growth, but bright spots remain: OCBC
summary: Singapore's food and beverage sector has contracted for the first time in four quarters, with a reading of 49.6 in the latest OCBC SME Index, down from 51.1 in Q4. The sector's decline reflects market saturation and challenging macroeconomic conditions, with 3,793 new brands entering the market in 2024, despite a 19-year high of 3,047 closures. Despite the contraction, bright spots remain, including a surge in tourism demand and the proliferation of new F&B establishments in mixed-development launches. Industry players are responding by refreshing menus, improving customer retention efforts, and boosting service levels to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: People visit a restaurant at the Marina Bay Sands shopping mall in Singapore on February 18, 2025. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Renald Yeo
The quarterly index, which tracks the business health and performance of SMEs, fell slightly from 50.7 to 49.9.
Popular Chinese hotpot chain Haidilao shuttered three restaurants earlier this year in Bedok (above), Pasir Ris and Punggol, after a period of rapid expansion.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.

site_title: Miu Miu’s momentum powers Prada sales growth
summary: Prada's net revenues rose 12.5% to 1.34 billion euros in the first quarter, driven by a 60% jump in retail sales at its smaller brand Miu Miu. This outperforms most peers, including LVMH and Kering, which posted declining sales. Miu Miu now accounts for 31% of total revenues, up from 22% last year. CEO Andrea Guerra attributed the positive start to the year to Prada's resilience against challenging quarterly comparisons, despite a complex backdrop.

REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Walmart is looking to better compete against Amazon.com and other rivals by adding more brands.

site_title: Rise in landed housing construction disputes – and a new fix
summary: Construction disputes involving landed housing in Singapore have increased, making up 40% of cases at the Singapore Mediation Centre. Disputes often stem from issues with workmanship or unclear contracts, fueled by poor communication and misinformation. To address this, the Micro Builders Association, Singapore (MBAS) launched the BuildTrust Construction Quality Assessment Scheme in April 2024, a quality assurance framework for smaller-scale developments. The scheme sets standards for finishes, workmanship, and installation and outlines how to rectify common defects.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei posts first monthly gain for the year on trade talk hopes
summary: Japan's Nikkei index rose 0.6% to 36,045.38, its highest close since March 28, marking its first monthly gain since December. The gain was driven by hopes of easing US-Japan trade tensions, with Japan's top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa aiming to make steady progress in tariff negotiations. The Nikkei has recouped all losses induced by early-April tariff announcements, gaining 1.2% for the month.

images.alt_text: Shares fell in Hong Kong and Shanghai on Wednesday.

site_title: 🗳️ Ready for GE2025 – A first-time voter’s guide
summary: Singapore is set to hold its General Election 2025, with 2.6 million eligible voters. Polls will open from 8 am to 8 pm, and voters must be at least 21 years old, a Singaporean citizen, and not disqualified from voting. Before voting, check your poll card, verify your details, and arrive on time to avoid missing the polling station. Bring required documents such as an NRIC or passport, and refrain from wearing attire or badges showing political party symbols. Voters can check their name on the voter rolls and register to vote online.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo
Election posters showing the People's Action Party and Workers' Party candidates for Tampines GRC.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said the ruling People’s Action Party offers the best team to take Singapore through global uncertainty, while some opposition parties proposed alternative solutions to cost-of-living woes.
First-timers everywhere

site_title: GE2025: What you need to know about the cooling-off period
summary: Singapore's Cooling-off Day, a 24-hour period before polling day, begins on May 2 and ends on May 3. During this time, campaigning activities, election advertising, and public events are prohibited. This period aims to allow voters to reflect on issues raised during the campaign period before casting their vote. Key restrictions include publishing new election ads, conducting house visits or walkabouts, wearing campaign propaganda, and holding election meetings. However, campaign materials already in place, news outlets publishing election-related articles, and private sharing of personal political views are allowed.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment’s total revenue falls 24% to S$496 million in Q1
summary: CapitaLand Investment reported a 24% decline in total revenue to S$496 million for Q1, primarily due to the deconsolidation of CapitaLand Ascott Trust. However, like-for-like revenue remained stable. The company's fee-income-related business revenue grew 3% to S$281 million, driven by increases in lodging management, commercial management, and listed funds management. Despite a cautious economic outlook, CLI attributed its performance as "largely stable" and plans to focus on strategic priorities, including investing in new markets and products.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
US President Donald Trump unveils reciprocal 'Liberation Day' tariffs at the White House on Apr 2, 2025.

site_title: Elite UK Reit posts 10.2% rise in Q1 2025 distributable income to £4.8 million
summary: Elite UK Reit posted a 10.2% year-over-year increase in distributable income to £4.8 million in Q1 2025, driven by better cash efficiency, lower interest expenses, and higher rentals. Net property income rose 24.4% to £10.4 million, while the net gearing ratio fell to 42.2%. The company's debt is in sustainability-linked loans, which will help optimize borrowing costs with improved energy performance.

images.alt_text: Great Western House, Birkenhead. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead (pictured), and a building in Newport Road,

site_title: A walkthrough of Singapore’s electoral journey
summary: Singapore's electoral journey is highlighted in the article, focusing on the country's electoral milestones and the upcoming General Election (GE2025). The article provides a brief overview of Singapore's electoral system, including the different types of electoral boundaries (GRCs and SMCs). No specific details about GE2025 are mentioned, but the article is intended to serve as a precursor to the upcoming election.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday, snapping four-day losing streak; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak, after a positive sentiment across most of Asia. Hongkong Land was the top gainer, rising 4% to US$4.89, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also closed higher. The broader market saw 288 gainers beat 177 decliners, with 971.8 million securities changing hands worth S$1.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
The Nikkei added 0.6 per cent to 36,045.38, its highest close since March 28.

site_title: Microsoft posts strong results fuelled by cloud sales growth
summary: Microsoft reported strong quarterly sales and profit growth, driven by cloud sales growth and its close partnership with ChatGPT maker OpenAI. Total revenue increased 13% to $70.1 billion, while adjusted profit was $3.46 a share, beating analyst estimates. The Azure cloud unit posted a 33% revenue gain, and Microsoft's stock rose 6% in extended trading after closing at $395.26. The company attributed 16 percentage points of Azure's growth to AI, indicating its efforts to capitalize on the trend.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is pulling back from the China market amid growing political and trade tensions between Washington and Beijing.
Copilot, Microsoft’s AI assistant, is gaining a host of new features to make it more proactive.
Investor scepticism about the hefty AI spending by US tech firms has increased due to slow payoffs and the rise of Chinese startup DeepSeek.

The new cloud region will generate US$10.9 billion in new revenues and create 37,575 jobs in Malaysia by 2028, including 5,700 skilled IT positions, projects Laurence Si, managing director of Microsoft Malaysia.

site_title: Oil settles lower, posts steepest monthly decline since 2021
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.76% to $63.12 a barrel, the largest monthly decline since 2021, due to Saudi Arabia's decision to produce more oil and expand its market share, as well as the ongoing global trade war. Brent crude futures fell 15% and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures dropped 18% for the month. Analysts warn of a prolonged oil price drop, with concerns over a potential production war and a weakening global economy.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell by US$1.61, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$64.25 per barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: UK student homes taking longer to fill on weaker overseas demand
summary: UK student dorms are experiencing a decline in leasing due to weaker overseas demand, with only 36% of available beds signed for the September academic year, down from 46% last year. The post-pandemic surge in leasing has proven temporary, according to StuRents, a company that tracks student accommodation data. The decline is attributed to a decrease in international students, particularly those from the European Union, and a rise in competition from other countries, as well as a cost of living crisis that has encouraged some domestic students to skip university.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 30)
summary: The US has significantly reduced its semiconductor imports from South-east Asia, with shipments from Cambodia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia plummeting over the past year. This comes amid a widening crackdown on trade circumvention. Meanwhile, Singapore's chip exports have not been directly affected, and investors are seeking diversification. In other news, Grab raised its full-year adjusted Ebitda guidance after posting a profit in Q1, and Far East Hospitality Trust's net property income fell 8.3% in Q1.

site_title: Barclays beats first-quarter forecasts as Trump turmoil supercharges trading
summary: Barclays reported a 19% increase in first-quarter profit to £2.7 billion, beating forecasts, driven by strong trading activity and progress in its domestic British lending business. The bank's investment bank income rose 16% and fixed-income trading rose 21%. Despite the positive results, Barclays set aside an additional £91 million charge against potential future losses due to trade tensions. The bank's CEO, Venkatakrishnan, reiterated its performance goals for the year, while Wall Street bank bosses warned that the outlook for the rest of the year is murkier due to trade tensions and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Barclays said total income in its investment bank reached £11.8 billion, just above analysts’ forecasts for £11.6 billion.
Barclays is one of the largest UK employers in India, with over 23,000 people spread across its banking, technology and shared services operations.
Barclays has enjoyed a strong year as activity in markets improved and chief executive officer CS Venkatakrishnan ploughed ahead with a multi-year plan to boost returns.
The investment bank has benefited from a surge in debt underwriting fees so far this year as well as a 17 per cent increase in equities trading revenue.

site_title: Vetting, contracts, warranty: HomeMatch introduces safeguards for homeowners
summary: HomeMatch, a Singapore-based platform, has introduced safeguards for homeowners in the renovation industry to address issues such as project delays, poor workmanship, and prepayment losses. The platform connects homeowners to CaseTrust-accredited renovators who undergo vetting, screenings, and have a minimum of four-star reviews. Homeowners can review contracts, track progress, and receive feedback on completed projects, with a 12-month workmanship warranty. HomeMatch aims to eliminate black sheep in the industry while promoting fair practices, and profits by charging renovators an upfront fee.

site_title: eBay announces CFO transition; sees quarterly revenue ahead of estimates
summary: eBay announces CFO Steve Priest's transition to Peggy Alford in May, with the company expecting revenue in the range of US$2.59 billion to US$2.66 billion for the second quarter, beating estimates. eBay's use of AI and improvements in search and targeted advertising are helping simplify selling and buying, with gross merchandise volume rising 1% to US$18.8 billion in the first quarter. Despite macro uncertainty, eBay views the guidance as solid, with adjusted earnings per share coming in higher than estimates.

site_title: Goldman sees central banks buying more renminbi, won, Singapore dollars
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts Asian currencies, particularly the renminbi, won, and Singapore dollar, will benefit from central banks diversifying their reserves away from the US dollar. China's trade linkages and Singapore's AAA rating make it a natural candidate for reserve re-allocations. The US dollar's dominance is expected to continue to ebb, with demand for alternative assets, such as gold, also rising. Central banks are accelerating searches for alternatives due to sanctions on Russia and US President Trump's policies, leading to a potential rotation to other global assets.

site_title: Morgan Stanley offers private equity fund to wider swath of millionaires
summary: Morgan Stanley is launching the North Haven Private Assets Fund, a private equity fund initially available to its clients, with plans to open it to a wider audience. The evergreen fund will offer exposure to lower middle-market co-investments and secondaries, with a potential fundraising target of $1-2 billion. This move follows similar efforts by other asset managers, such as Goldman Sachs, to develop more private equity offerings for individual investors. The fund aims to provide a user-friendly alternative to traditional private equity investments.

images.alt_text: Overseas investors have resumed selling onshore stocks in the new year as pessimism over the nation’s sluggish economic recovery deepens.

site_title: HKEX posts record quarterly profit on trading, listings boom
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, reported a record quarterly profit of HK$4.08 billion (S$687 million), beating estimates, driven by trading and listings boom fueled by global market volatility and China's support to the private sector. HKEX's trading and listings have increased since late 2024, with a total of 17 companies debuting on the exchange in the first quarter, and total fundraising surging. The exchange's shares have risen 16% this year, outperforming the Hang Seng Index.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing’s (HKEX) new office is located in the same retail centre in the city’s core business district that has housed its headquarters for over four decades.
The suggestion to set up an OTC market for delisted shares was first mentioned in a broader HKEX market consultation released in December.

Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing has boosted its derivatives offering over the last six months to meet the market’s growing demand as investors look to gain more exposure to Chinese assets in a way that helps lower their risk.

summary: Asian markets struggle as China's trade war hits factory activity, with China exempting US-made goods from 125% tariffs. Singapore investors bought the most gold since 2010, while Grab posted a US$24 million profit in Q1. Despite these market movements, the overall trend remains cautious due to the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: NTUC will collaborate with tripartite partners to protect all workers from tariff impact
summary: NTUC, in collaboration with tripartite partners, will work to protect all workers from the impact of global tariffs. The labour movement aims to support various groups, including platform workers, caregivers, and professionals, through initiatives such as mentorship and upskilling opportunities. NTUC has also pushed for the Workplace Fairness Act and the Platform Workers Act to ensure a level playing field for workers. The organization emphasizes its strong relationships with the Ministry of Manpower and the Singapore National Employers Federation to reinforce Singapore's stability and resilience.

site_title: S-Reits need to reveal clear strategies amid tariff uncertainty
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) face uncertainty amid US tariffs, which may impact their financial results. While many S-Reits acknowledged the potential drag from tariffs, few provided concrete details on how they will respond. Reit managers should offer specific strategies to mitigate the impact, including how they will address tenant behavior and portfolio mix adjustments. Investors need more clarity to instill confidence in Reit management, especially given the sector's recent rebound from an early April sell-off.

site_title: Meta launches standalone AI app to compete with ChatGPT
summary: Meta has launched a standalone AI app called Meta AI, built on its Llama large language model technology, to compete with popular chatbots like ChatGPT. The app provides a voice-focused digital assistant experience with personalization capabilities, leveraging data from Meta's social media platforms. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg sees the app as a tool for users to learn news or navigate personal issues, and it will also feature a social feed for users to share their AI experiences.

images.alt_text: Earlier this year, Meta cut roughly 5 per cent of staff – about 3,600 people – in what was described as performance-based terminations.

site_title: China creates list of US-made goods exempted from 125% tariffs: sources
summary: China has created a list of US-made products exempted from its 125% tariffs, allowing Beijing to ease the impact of its trade war with Washington while maintaining public messaging. The list, not publicly shared, includes products such as pharmaceuticals, microchips, and aircraft engines, and has been quietly notified to companies. The move appears to be growing, with China waiving tariffs on ethane imports from the US and surveying companies to gauge the impact of the tariff war. This private approach contrasts with China's public stance that it will fight until the US lifts its 145% tariffs.

images.alt_text: The ramp-up in domestic installations that’s supported demand in recent months is likely to meet dead air after a Jun 1 deadline.

Chinese President Xi Jinping said that Shanghai should strive to be at the forefront of artificial intelligence (AI) development and governance.

site_title: How the Singdollar fared in Trump’s first 100 days
summary: US President Donald Trump's 'will-they-won't-they' tango with tariffs has negatively impacted the Singapore dollar, causing a bumpy ride. On April 9, Trump paused sweeping reciprocal tariffs for 90 days, hours after they kicked in, affecting the Singapore dollar's value relative to the greenback. The Monetary Authority of Singapore operates a managed float regime, using the exchange rate as a monetary policy instrument, and the Singapore dollar has been influenced by Trump's trade policies.

site_title: Thai factory output falls 0.66% y/y in March; drop smaller than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index dropped 0.66% year-over-year in March, beating expectations. Exports surged 17.8% year-over-year, the highest in three years, while tourism and government stimulus measures contributed to the recovery. Despite a monthly increase of 9.2%, annual terms have contracted for eight consecutive months. The industry ministry urged monitoring US tariffs, which could impact Thailand if not reduced before a global moratorium expires in July.

site_title: GE2025: SM Lee, PM Wong visits show how WP brings competition to Tampines, says Faisal Manap
summary: Workers' Party (WP) candidates for Tampines GRC and Tampines Changkat SMC visited the constituency, receiving a warm reception from residents. WP vice-chairman Faisal Manap said the party's presence brings competition to the ruling party, with the goal of forcing them to improve their performance. WP candidates assured residents that they have experience in running town councils and will manage estates effectively if elected, with specific references to their past roles in Aljunied-Hougang Town Council.

Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh (centre) speaking to the media during a doorstop in Tampines on April 28.

site_title: Jardine C&C reports lower contributions across most business units in Q1 2025
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C) reported lower contributions across most business units in Q1 2025 due to uncertain macroeconomic environment. The company's Astra unit in Indonesia saw a decrease in underlying profit, while financial services, agribusiness, and infrastructure segments showed improved performance. Automotive and mobility, heavy equipment and mining business segments fell in earnings, driven by lower car sales and coal prices. JC&C is cautious of the knock-on effects of global trade tensions on currency rates and consumer sentiment.

Contributions from Cycle & Carriage rose 13 per cent to US$32 million, with increases in both new and used car sales in Singapore.

site_title: Thailand’s central bank cuts rate again; economy could face recession as US tariffs loom
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) cut its key interest rate by a quarter point to 1.75% for the second consecutive meeting, aiming to support an underperforming economy. The central bank reduced its growth forecast for 2025 to 2% and 1.8% for 2026, citing downside risks from US trade tariffs and a potential recession. The rate cut is seen as a response to the escalating trade tensions and a slowing global economy, with the BOT warning of a prolonged economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Record high gold prices are also boosting local assets as Thailand is a major trading hub for the precious metal in Asia.

Thailand is among South-east Asian nations hardest hit by US President Donald Trump’s proposed measures, facing a 36 per cent tariff if a reduction can’t be negotiated before a global moratorium expires in July.
The central bank estimates that the trade war could dock as much as half a percentage point from gross domestic product growth of slightly above 2.5 per cent this year.
The central bank has said the bar would be high for a further cut as the level is consistent with the current economic outlook.

site_title: Business council chief flags urgent need for S-E Asia to deepen integration amid rising protectionism
summary: Asean Business Advisory Council Malaysia chief Nazir Razak has urged South-east Asia to deepen regional integration to unlock the full potential of its 700-million-person market amid rising global protectionism. The region faces significant non-tariff barriers and uneven trade rule enforcement, hindering efforts to build a seamless market. Razak advocates greater flexibility for businesses, harmonized regulations, and lowered tariffs to turbocharge integration. He cites the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone as a model for closer cooperation, and Asean is set to launch initiatives such as a regional capital market framework and digital trade platforms to boost intra-Asean economic activity.

site_title: Sodexo, Insead partner Montfort Care to help seniors eat healthier meals
summary: Sodexo and Insead's SG60: Doing Good Through Food initiative partnered with Montfort Care to teach seniors in Singapore how to prepare healthy meals. The programme, launched at Goodlife Studio (Bukit Purmei), aimed to empower seniors through cooking skills and promote preventive healthcare. Over 60 seniors participated in a live cooking demonstration, learning to make simple and nutritious meals like soy chicken rice. The initiative is part of a broader effort to address social isolation and support seniors' independent living, as Singapore's ageing population continues to grow.

site_title: Maybank names Shafiq Abdul Jabbar as new group chief financial officer
summary: Maybank appoints Shafiq Abdul Jabbar as its new group chief financial officer, effective July 7. He replaces Khalijah Ismail, who was dismissed earlier this year following an internal inquiry. Shafiq will partner with the president and group CEO to drive value creation and strategic decision-making, leading transformation within the finance department and leveraging technology and data. With over 25 years of experience, Maybank's PGCEO Khairussaleh Ramli believes Shafiq's strong financial leadership will support the bank's strategy for sustainable growth and value creation.

Eco-Shop operates 350 stores across Malaysia and has a market share of 68 per cent in the country’s discount-store sector.

The value of buybacks by DBS Group Holdings, Singapore’s largest bank, accounts for nearly half of all the stock repurchases in Singapore from Apr 1 to Apr 23.

site_title: GE2025: PAP and WP play on football analogy; 11 rallies to come on final day of campaigning
summary: Singapore is set to head to the polls on Saturday for the 2025 general election, with 11 rallies taking place on the final day of campaigning. The People's Action Party (PAP) is holding five rallies, including one in Tampines GRC, which will see a four-way fight between the PAP, People's Power Party, Workers' Party, and others. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong used a football analogy to describe the PAP's reliance on key ministers, while Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh emphasized the need for renewal within the WP to bring in fresh candidates.

images.alt_text: Echoing a message from his electoral campaign, PM Wong stressed that the loss of key ministers cannot be treated as lightly as opposition parties do.
Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh hit back at the PAP's arguments against voting opposition MPs into Parliament, in the party's final rally.

site_title: Sasseur Reit CEO Cecilia Tan steps down
summary: Cecilia Tan, CEO of Sasseur Asset Management and manager of Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust, will step down on October 28 after over four years in the role. Tan is resigning to pursue other professional interests. The board is now searching for a suitable candidate to act as CEO, and the management staff will continue to manage the Reit with the board's support. Units of Sasseur Reit closed 0.8% higher on the news.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Trump should revise rules for AI chip exports, says Nvidia CEO
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang urged the Trump administration to revise US rules for exporting AI chip technology to accelerate its global diffusion. Huang cited China's growing technological prowess, particularly Huawei Technologies, as a significant rival. He emphasized the need for supportive policies to enable American businesses to capitalize on AI opportunities worldwide. China is "right behind" the US in AI development, and Huawei is expanding its AI chip design capabilities. Huang's comments come ahead of his trip to China, highlighting the importance of adapting US regulations to stay competitive.

site_title: GE2025: Voters should see the election as being about their future ‘in a very changed world’, says PM Wong
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong framed the general election as a choice between a secure future in a "very changed world" and serious challenges affecting jobs and cost of living. The election, he said, is about choosing trustworthy candidates, upholding ideals of racial and religious harmony, and securing a brighter future. The government faces concerns about slowing economic growth, graduate jobs, and retrenchments, with PM Wong warning of a "prolonged" economic storm.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
( L-R) Eileen Chong, Jimmy Tan，Faisal Manap，Kenneth Foo, Ong Lue Ping addressing the media during a doorstop at Tampines.
Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong's trade talks with the US can help save jobs in Singapore, said Minister for Law and Home Affairs K Shanmugam at the PAP's rally for Nee Soon GRC.

site_title: Australia’s core inflation slows to 3-year low in Q1, supports May rate cut
summary: Australia's core inflation slowed to a three-year low of 2.9% in Q1, supporting a potential rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia in May. The consumer price index rose 0.9% in the March quarter, driven by a 16.3% jump in electricity prices. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, increased by 0.7%, above forecasts. The benign inflation readings could benefit Prime Minister Anthony Albanese ahead of a federal election. Analysts expect a 25 basis point rate cut in May, citing downside risks to global growth and a softer near-term inflation profile.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar rose back to US$0.6429 from a Monday low of US$0.6369.

Anthony Albanese, Australia's prime minister, speaks during the Labor Party federal election campaign launch in Perth, Australia, on Sunday, April 13, 2025. A one-time tax cut and billions of dollars to build new houses for first home buyers will be on the table when Australia’s two major parties hold their 2025 election campaign launches within hours of each other on Sunday. Photographer: Matt Jelonek/Bloomberg
Australia is among just a handful of countries in the world to hold a AAA rating from all three agencies – S&P, Fitch Ratings and Moody’s Investors Service.

site_title: Tesla hiring over 1,000 workers to ramp up Semi truck production: report
summary: Tesla is hiring over 1,000 workers at its Nevada factory to ramp up production of its Semi trucks, which will have an annual capacity of 50,000 units. The factory's production is expected to begin by the end of 2025, with the company initially assigning fewer than 100 factory workers to the program. Tesla has been working to build a truck-making business for years, with production delays previously reported. The hiring move aims to support the mass production of the Semi, which was initially expected to be in production by 2019.

At US$750 billion, Tesla’s value is propped up not by car sales but by faith that Musk can work magic, and has the time to do so.
The company retreated from its 2025 guidance, citing unpredictability over trade policy and demand.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 clocks second consecutive monthly loss hit by tariff woes
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3% higher on Wednesday, despite marking its second consecutive monthly loss, due to a 1.3% rise in healthcare stocks. The benchmark index fell 1.3% in April, with energy being the worst-performing sub-index, down 10.2% due to uncertainty around global growth and US tariffs. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 has recouped more than half of its losses after tumbling nearly 18% earlier this month.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.36 per cent higher at 525.09 points on Tuesday, with the aerospace and defence index leading gains.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Q4 DPU flat at S$0.0336
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0336 for Q4, unchanged from the previous year, despite a 0.5% decline in revenue to S$177.8 million. Net property income (NPI) also fell 0.5% to S$131.2 million. The trust's DPU rose 1% to S$0.1357 for the year, driven by higher contributions from its data centre in Osaka and the newly acquired mixed-use facility in Tokyo.

site_title: Meta quarterly profit climbs despite big cloud spending
summary: Meta reported a quarterly profit of $16.6 billion, exceeding expectations, despite significant investments in cloud computing and AI. The company's advertising business remained strong, and shares rose 4% in after-market trades. Meta is putting AI to work across its platforms, including creating and targeting ads, and has unveiled a standalone AI assistant app. The company faces regulatory challenges and emerging competition, including Chinese startup DeepSeek's AI model, but is accelerating its AI-driven ad performance and targeting tools.

Prior to her appointment, Tan led Meta’s operations in Malaysia for nine years.

site_title: Raising standards for interior designers
summary: Singapore's interior design industry lacks professional standards, with many individuals marketing themselves as designers without formal education or experience. The Society of Interior Designers Singapore (Sids) has been working to raise standards, but a voluntary accreditation scheme has seen slow take-up. The industry's reputation suffers due to unscrupulous players, and established designers need to protect their craft and reputation. Sids aims to improve the industry's reputation and establish a unified set of standards for interior designers.

site_title: China adopts private economy promotion law
summary: China's top legislature passed a private economy promotion law, aiming to support the private sector amid trade tensions with the US. The law, effective May 20, includes provisions on fair competition, access to investment and financing, and rights protection. It aims to optimize the development environment for private businesses, promote fair market competition, and ensure the healthy growth of the private economy. The private sector contributes significantly to China's tax revenue, economic output, and tech innovation.

site_title: US economy contracts in the first quarter; tariffs unleash flood of imports
summary: The US economy contracted at a 0.3% annualized rate in the first quarter, driven by a surge in imports due to tariffs. Despite this, consumer spending continued to grow at a moderate pace, and inflation picked up last quarter. The contraction in GDP was likely overstated, with economists warning against placing too much weight on the data. The news reinforces Americans' growing disapproval of President Trump's handling of the economy, particularly inflation.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles at the open as US economy contracts in first quarter
summary: US stocks tumbled at the open on April 30, with the S&P 500 falling 1.10% to 5,499.44, following data showing the US economy contracted in the first quarter. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.59% to 40,290.41, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 2.07% to 17,099.977. The economic contraction amplified concerns over the economic impact of President Trump's tariff policies.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. Signs Donald Trump is rethinking the most-aggressive elements of his combative stances on trade and the Federal Reserve sent stocks to the first back-to-back gains since his tariff war escalated, while soothing volatility across asset classes. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese sovereign fund CIC to sell US$1 billion of US private equity investments: sources
summary: Chinese sovereign fund CIC plans to sell around $1 billion of its US private equity investments in the secondary market, citing market turmoil and uncertainty triggered by geopolitical tensions between Beijing and Washington. The sale is part of CIC's efforts to diversify its portfolio and is being advised by Evercore. The assets are held in funds managed by US firms such as Blackstone and Carlyle Group, and the sale is expected to be completed by the end of June.

site_title: Nomura’s China losses narrow as brokerage seeks turnaround
summary: Nomura Holdings reported a smaller loss at its Chinese joint venture, Nomura Orient International Securities, narrowing to 128.7 million yuan (S$23 million) in the year ended December 31. The venture has continued to lose money since its inception in 2019, but has shown improvement in the past two years. It expects China's economic growth to slow this year due to trade tensions and is seeking stable and positive returns from proprietary trading. The venture is undergoing an overhaul and is seeking a new CEO, with headcount having fallen to 208 employees from 246 last year.

images.alt_text: Signage for Nomura Securities Co., a unit of Nomura Holdings Inc., displayed on a glass door at one of the company's branches in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024. site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as trade war hits China factory activity
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday as China's factory activity contracted at its fastest pace in nearly two years due to the US trade war. Chinese exports surged 12% in the previous month, while the US has imposed tariffs of up to 145% on Chinese goods. Investors are uncertain about the outcome of trade talks between the US and China, with some warning that the real growth damage is just starting to unfold.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk in front of an electronic board showing the opening numbers on the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on April 11, 2025. site_title: Eurozone economy expands faster than forecast but faces trade war hit
summary: The eurozone economy expanded 0.4% in the first quarter, beating expectations of 0.2%, driven by quick growth in Spain. Despite this, policymakers warn of permanent damage from the US trade war, a surging euro, and deteriorating sentiment. Germany's largest economy, the US, and other European countries face temporary growth due to the trade tensions, which are likely to be offset by the bloc's overall weaker trend. Inflation appears to have slowed, with price growth in Germany and Italy near the ECB's 2% target.

images.alt_text: Consumer confidence is near five-year lows and business sentiment has tanked.

site_title: Singapore investors buy 2.5 tonnes of bullion in Q1, the highest since 2010
summary: Singapore investors purchased 2.5 tonnes of gold in Q1 2025, the highest since 2010, with demand rising 35% year-over-year. Global central banks added 243.7 tonnes of gold to their reserves in the same quarter, but demand fell 21% from the previous year. The World Gold Council forecasts weaker gold jewellery demand in 2025 due to record-high prices, but expects gold demand to stay resilient due to ongoing geopolitical tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: China’s factory activity falls sharply as Trump tariffs bite
summary: China's factory activity contracted at the fastest pace in 16 months in April, with the official purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 49.0, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. The decline was attributed to US President Donald Trump's tariffs, which snapped two months of recovery and put pressure on policymakers to address the economy's rebalancing. China's economy is expected to expand just 3.5% this year, and the government is stepping up fiscal support, but it is unlikely to fully offset the drag.

site_title: Salman Haider named head of Asean, CEO of Eastspring Singapore
summary: Eastspring Investments appointed Salman Haider as head of Asean and CEO of Eastspring Singapore, subject to regulatory approval. Haider will oversee the firm's growth strategy in Asean, focusing on delivering client-centric solutions, and will report to Bill Maldonado, CEO of Eastspring Investments Group. Haider brings over 25 years of experience in wealth management, retail banking, and corporate banking across Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.

site_title: Chinese set to spend record US$1 trillion in local travel boom
summary: China is expected to spend a record US$1 trillion on domestic and international travel this year, with domestic spending forecast to reach nearly US$968 billion, a 19% increase from 2024. International spending is also poised to outpace pre-Covid-19 levels, growing 13% from 2019. This boom is driven by China's efforts to boost consumption and attract foreign tourists, with the government announcing new plans to expand cultural and tourism events across the country.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts Q1 NPI slides 14.2% to S$30 million on lower revenue
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 14.2% decline in net property income (NPI) to S$30 million for Q1, driven by lower revenue from all markets except the UK and Japan. The Singapore market saw a 19.6% decline in NPI and 15.8% drop in RevPAR, while the UK and Japan markets experienced growth in NPI and RevPAR. The trust's gearing remains high at 41.8%, but its manager expects benefits from falling interest rates and will implement hedging strategies.

site_title: Short selling is simply part of normal market functioning
summary: Thailand banned short selling of stocks and tightened trading rules in April following the US tariff announcement, while Taiwan and South Korea also implemented curbs. Critics argue that short selling is morally objectionable and adds to market volatility, but proponents claim it's a routine and necessary part of market functioning, allowing for price discovery and risk management. The lifting of bans in South Korea and Singapore suggests that regulators recognize short selling as a normal market activity, rather than trying to curb it.

site_title: Office loan trouble signal problems ahead for a US$650 billion bond market
summary: The US commercial real estate market is facing significant problems due to defaults on commercial mortgage debt, with a $650 billion market impacted by rising interest rates and falling property values. Defaults on office buildings, such as the recent $135 million default by a Seattle developer, are leading to a backlog of unpaid loans, with special servicers overseeing 10% of mortgages, double the rate from two years ago. Experts warn that the situation may worsen, with projected losses on office loans potentially reaching 9% of total value, and concerns about economic stagflation or recession adding to the headwinds.

summary: US imports of semiconductor products, including solar panels and cells, from South-east Asia have plummeted, with shipments from Cambodia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia falling by 51%, 39%, 22%, and 8% respectively, between March 2024 and February 2025. New tariffs of up to 3,521% on solar imports threaten to further squeeze exports from the region. Analysts warn that South-east Asian countries must diversify their markets, with potential alternatives being the European Union and China, where demand for AI-powered chips continues to grow.

summary: A European Central Bank survey of 19,000 Eurozone consumers found they are willing to switch to non-US products if hit by tariffs, regardless of price increase. The median substitution score was 80, indicating a strong willingness to move away from US products. Higher-income households were more likely to substitute. The results suggest consumers' reactions to tariffs may deviate from standard consumption patterns.

site_title: Pop Mart holder sells US$101 million stake after shares hit record
summary: A Pop Mart International Group investor sold approximately 4.1 million shares at HK$192.95 apiece, raising US$101 million in a block trade. The shares have jumped over 470% in the last 12 months, making the company the top gainer in the MSCI China Index. The sale comes after the company reported a 100% profit increase last year due to the popularity of its Labubu dolls.

site_title: Restaurant fire kills 22 in north-east China’s Liaoning
summary: A restaurant fire in Liaoyang, northeast China's Liaoning Province, killed at least 22 people on Tuesday, with three injured. The cause of the fire is unknown, but President Xi Jinping called it a "deeply sobering lesson." This incident is the latest in a series of deadly fires in China, including a recent nursing home fire in Hebei Province that killed 20 people. Emergency services were deployed, and an investigation is underway to determine what triggered the blaze and hold those responsible accountable.

site_title: China asks drugmakers, hospitals to find US import substitutes
summary: China has asked state-owned drugmakers to study alternatives to US-made pharmaceutical products and raw materials due to the ongoing trade war, which has led to tariffs over 100% on each other's goods. Chinese hospitals and top medical facilities are also being told to assess the feasibility of replacing US-imported products with domestic or international alternatives. This effort aims to reduce reliance on the US for healthcare products and minimize the impact of tariffs on China's medical supply.

site_title: Navigating the new economic disorder: Decode, deepen, diversify
summary: Singapore faces a period of extreme uncertainty due to US President Donald Trump's tariffs and trade controls, threatening its role as an open trading hub. The US administration's priorities appear to be raising revenue, reindustrializing America, and deploying tariffs as a tool to deal with China. To survive, businesses must decode tariffs' impact, deepen transformation, and diversify markets. The government has introduced initiatives to support enterprise transformation and diversification of markets. Despite the challenges, Singapore's robust economic foundation and strong fiscal reserves give it agency to navigate the new economic order, and its businesses have a history of working closely with the government to overcome adversity.

site_title: Gold prices steady as investors await key US data, tariff updates
summary: Gold prices remain steady at US$3,318.79 per ounce, awaiting key US data and potential trade developments. Investors await US inflation data for clues on the Federal Reserve's policy path. US President Donald Trump signed orders to soften the blow of his auto tariffs, easing investor concerns. Meanwhile, US consumer confidence slumped to a nearly five-year low in April.

site_title: Samsung Electronics drops Q2 outlook due to trade uncertainties
summary: Samsung Electronics dropped its Q2 business outlook due to ongoing US tariff uncertainties, which may impact demand for key products such as smartphones and semiconductor chips. The company reported a 1.2% increase in operating profit to 6.7 trillion won, driven by strong mobile device sales. However, the chip division's operating profit slumped 42% due to US export controls on AI chips. Samsung also warned of potential risks from US tariff policies and considered relocating TV and home appliance production.

site_title: Chinese solar losses deepen even before worst of trump tariffs

The industry's self-discipline measures have not worked, and conditions will worsen if US tariffs on Chinese exports come into force, including levies as high as 3,521% on South-east Asian nations. Profitability is expected to improve in the second quarter but may be unsustainable due to a potential demand vacuum in the third quarter.

site_title: US consumer confidence slumps to an almost five-year low
summary: US consumer confidence plummeted to an almost five-year low in April, reaching a reading of 86, the weakest since May 2020. The decline was driven by growing pessimism about the economy and labor market due to tariffs, with expectations for business conditions and employment prospects deteriorating sharply. Corporate executives warn that the slump in confidence will filter through into weaker demand and higher prices.

site_title: Trump and the Federal Reserve’s independence
summary: US President Donald Trump recently escalated his criticism of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, accusing him of "playing politics" and wanting to fire him. However, Trump later backtracked, stating he does not intend to fire Powell. Such an attempt would test the Federal Reserve's independence and destabilize financial markets, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warning Trump about the potential consequences. The Fed's independence is crucial to maintaining economic stability, and any attempt to undermine it could have severe repercussions for the US economy.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s independence “is very widely understood and supported in Washington, in Congress, where it really matters,” Powell says.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell attends a press conference, following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy, in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard/File Photo
The US president repeatedly complained that the Fed was not cutting interest rates quickly enough.

site_title: Mark Carney: democracy’s unTrump
summary: Canada's Mark Carney, a former central banker and Goldman Sachs executive, has won the country's election as prime minister, defeating a populist candidate who was seen as a Trump-like figure. Carney's victory is attributed to his ability to distance himself from his predecessor Justin Trudeau and appeal to moderate voters. The article suggests that Carney's win serves as a model for Democrats in the US, highlighting the importance of rules-based internationalism and the dangers of Trump's populist style, which can be detrimental to one's own country and allies.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s Liberals secured control of Canada’s parliament but may fall just short of a majority.

Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks to the media after meeting with his cabinet to deal with the US auto tariffs on March 27, 2025 on Parliament Hill in Ottawa. The era of deep economic, security and military ties between Canada and the United States "is over," Prime Minister Mark Carney said, a day after US President Donald Trump announced steep auto tariffs. (Photo by Dave Chan / AFP)

site_title: Xi is trying to turn world against US as Trump cuts deals
summary: China is seeking to turn the world against the US as President Xi Jinping's diplomats promote Beijing as a champion of the rules-based order. The US has granted a 90-day reprieve to countries to strike trade deals without tariffs, but China is demanding removal of "reciprocal" tariffs and is approaching foreign governments as a group. China has devoted years to weaning its economy off US exports and has the world's largest military, while US allies are wary of moving closer to China due to military aggression and concerns over cheap goods.

images.alt_text: Trump says Americans should not be surprised by his tariff regime, saying the levies were necessary to address trade deficits and revive domestic manufacturing.
Chinese President Xi Jinping said that Shanghai should strive to be at the forefront of artificial intelligence (AI) development and governance.
China and the US have hiked levies on each other’s goods to over 100 per cent since US President Donald Trump took office in January, rattling global markets.
China is forecast to make up 20 per cent of global aircraft demand over the next two decades and in 2018, nearly a quarter of Boeing’s output ended up there.
Yuan weakness is providing an opportunity for exporters that were holding out of converting their US dollar proceeds to finally act.
Wang Yi’s call to the international community underscores China’s attempt to portray itself as the bastion of free trade as US tariffs threaten to reshape commerce globally.

site_title: Prudential’s quarterly new business profit rises on strong Hong Kong, China growth
summary: Prudential, a London and Hong Kong dual-listed insurer, reported a 12% rise in new business profit for the first quarter to US$608 million. The company's Hong Kong and China segments drove growth, with double-digit increases in both markets. Indonesia and Taiwan also saw double-digit profit growth, while Vietnam declined due to low consumer confidence. Prudential's CEO attributed the strong performance to its growth markets and other segments. The company's asset management arm reported funds under management of US$256.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the Prudential logo seen on Aug 13, 2020.
The insurer noted 14 markets achieved double-digit year-on-year growth in new business profit.
Hong Kong, one of AIA’s largest contributors in terms of profits, reported a 16 per cent annual increase in VONB for the reported quarter.

site_title: Japan factory output falls in sign of frailty before tariffs
summary: Japan's factory output fell 1.1% in March, exceeding economists' forecasts, amid uncertainties surrounding US President Donald Trump's tariff campaign. The decline was driven by a 1.3% predicted increase in output this month. The US tariffs, which include a 10% tax on all goods, are expected to significantly impact Japan's manufacturing base, particularly autos. The Bank of Japan may hold its policy settings steady, as authorities need more time to gauge the impact of the tariffs.

images.alt_text: Rather than dialling back trade, Tokyo is in the process of trying to get China to resume imports of seafood and beef from Japan after bans imposed over health concerns.
The data comes ahead of the BOJ policy meeting on Apr 30 to May 1, where the central bank is widely expected to keep short-term rates steady at 0.5 per cent.
Providing some support for a fragile economic recovery, the au Jibun Bank flash services PMI expanded to 52.2 in April, improving from 50 in March.
Price gains are still high by Japan’s standards after more than a decade of deflation.

site_title: TikTok plans to build 1b euro data centre in Finland
summary: TikTok plans to invest 1 billion euros to build its first data centre in Finland, marking a significant step in moving data storage for European users to the continent. The move aims to alleviate concerns over Chinese government access to user data. This investment follows TikTok's "Project Clover" initiative, which aims to invest 12 billion euros over 10 years. The data centre is part of Finland's growing attractiveness as a destination for data centres due to its low energy costs and availability of cheap, emission-free electricity.

images.alt_text: TikTok Shop, where users can run livestreams selling everything from sneakers to eyeshadow and earn a commission on sales, is known for discounted products.

site_title: China Vanke’s quarterly loss widens to 6.25 billion yuan after overhaul
summary: China Vanke, a property developer, reported a net loss of 6.25 billion yuan in its first quarter, widening from a 362 million yuan loss a year earlier. The loss stemmed from declines in home settlements and gross margins, with margins dropping to 6.1% from about 10% last year. The company has 26.3 billion yuan of onshore and offshore bonds maturing this year and plans to sell treasury shares to replenish liquidity. The government-led overhaul, which included the takeover of operations, aims to address the company's challenges.

images.alt_text: State-backed Vanke reported a record 49.5 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) loss last year, its first full-year loss since 1991.

site_title: UBS Q1 profit tops forecasts but Trump tariff shock clouds outlook
summary: UBS reported a net profit of $1.7 billion in Q1 2025, beating analyst estimates of $1.3 billion. However, the Swiss bank warned of an uncertain outlook due to US President Trump's tariffs, which raise concerns over global growth and inflation. UBS expects a decline in net interest income in its global wealth management business in Q2, and market uncertainty may delay corporate deals. The bank also reaffirmed its share repurchase program and confirmed its integration of Credit Suisse's business is on track.

images.alt_text: The value of buybacks by DBS Group Holdings, Singapore’s largest bank, accounts for nearly half of all the stock repurchases in Singapore from Apr 1 to Apr 23.

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% to two-week low as trade war concerns dampen demand outlook
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% to a two-week low on Tuesday, falling to $64.25 per barrel, amid concerns over a potential trade war between the US and China. The US trade deficit widened in March, and investors worry that President Trump's tariffs will slow demand for oil. Analysts have lowered their oil demand and price forecasts, citing a slowdown in trade between the two nations. Opec+ is expected to boost output, further weakening oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$65.86 a barrel, down US$1.01, or 1.51 per cent on Monday.
The agreement was signed by Sinopec, its unit Fujian Petroleum Chemical Industry Co, and Saudi Aramco’s Singaporean unit Aramco Asia Singapore (AAS).

site_title: Trump predicts China would ‘eat’ tariffs, lessening US impact
summary: US President Donald Trump predicted China would "eat" the tariffs imposed on their exports, reducing the impact on American consumers. Trump defended his 145% tariffs on Chinese goods, saying China "deserves" them due to their trade deficits and manufacturing practices. Despite the administration's efforts to repair relations and initiate trade negotiations, talks have not commenced. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned China could lose 10 million jobs due to the tariffs, but declined to discuss specific negotiations.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping said that Shanghai should strive to be at the forefront of artificial intelligence (AI) development and governance.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust Q1 net property income falls 8.3% to S$23 million
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a 8.3% decline in net property income to S$23 million for Q1 FY2025, mainly due to lower master lease revenue from hotels and serviced residences. Gross revenue fell 6.8% to S$25.2 million. The trust's hotels segment saw a 9.2% drop in revenue, while the commercial premises segment posted a 4.9% increase. FEHT's average occupancy for hotels decreased by 1.4 percentage points to 79%. The trust has a positive outlook for tourism recovery amid an uncertain macroeconomic environment.

The expanded scope is expected to give the trust access to a larger pool of reputable hospitality operators.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence falls in April amid tariff concerns
summary: New Zealand business confidence fell in April due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans. The ANZ Bank survey showed a 9-point decline in the headline measure, with a net 49.3% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the year ahead, down from 57.5% in March. Business confidence and plans to invest also decreased, with a net 47.7% of respondents expecting their own businesses to grow in the next 12 months, down from 48.6% last month.

site_title: AIA Group’s value of new business jumps on strong Hong Kong sales
summary: AIA Group reported a 13% rise in its first-quarter value of new business (VONB) due to strong demand from local customers and visitors from Mainland China. The insurer attributed the increase to its proprietary Premier Agency model, which generated 75% of its VONB. Hong Kong, one of AIA's largest contributors in terms of profits, saw a 16% annual increase in VONB. This growth is driven by Chinese investors seeking offshore insurance policies as an alternative investment vehicle, attracted by competitive premiums and higher potential returns.

images.alt_text: Insurance revenue rose 15 per cent year on year to S$27.3 from S$23.7 million.
Labour chief Ng Chee Meng apologised over the Allianz-Income deal at a PAP rally on Apr 27.

site_title: Grab raises full-year adjusted Ebitda guidance after posting US$24 million profit in Q1
summary: Grab, a Nasdaq-listed company, reported a net profit of US$24 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2025, reversing a US$104 million loss in the previous period. Revenue grew 18% to US$773 million, surpassing analyst estimates. Adjusted Ebitda for the quarter came in at US$106 million, up 71% from US$62 million. Grab raised its adjusted full-year Ebitda guidance to between US$460 million and US$480 million, representing a 47-53% on-year climb. The company attributed its turnaround to higher revenue across all segments, improved operating loss, and higher net finance income.

images.alt_text: Taxi cabs in front a Grab office in Singapore.

site_title: Visa earnings top estimates as spending on network stays strong
summary: Visa's fiscal second-quarter earnings beat estimates, with net income rising 6% to $5.44 billion. Payments volume came in at $3.34 trillion, slightly below expectations. The company expects value-added services to account for more than half of total revenue in coming years. Despite macroeconomic uncertainties, CEO Ryan McInerney stated that consumer spending remained resilient. Visa also authorized a $30 billion multiyear share-repurchase program and shares climbed 2.3% in late trading.

site_title: Kheng Leong launches ultra-luxury project 21 Anderson with prices from S$10 million
summary: Kheng Leong has launched its ultra-luxury project 21 Anderson in Singapore, with prices starting from S$10 million for two-bedroom units and S$22.5 million for four-bedroom units. Two four-bedroom units have already been sold for over S$20 million each, and five other units have been reserved. The project, which features 18 units, is expected to receive its temporary occupation permit later this year.

site_title: Starbucks says turnaround on track as sales decline persists
summary: Starbucks reported a 1% decline in same-store sales in the latest quarter, missing analyst expectations. Despite efforts to revive sales growth, including price increases, store renovations, and cost-cutting measures, the company's turnaround appears to be on track. CEO Brian Niccol expressed confidence in the company's progress, stating that the business will return to growth. The company's international business, particularly in China, performed better than expected, while North America saw a decline in transactions. Starbucks' stock has declined 7% so far this year.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as Trump tempers auto tariffs
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.8% higher at 40,527.62, following President Trump's move to ease tariffs on automakers. The S&P 500 advanced 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6%. Investors welcomed the decision, which includes limitations on tariffs and a measure to offset the levy for two years. Analysts predict the market could go higher, despite uncertainty, as the risk is to the upside. Automakers General Motors fell, Ford rose, and Stellantis gained.

site_title: GE2025: DPM Gan can help save jobs if he remains in government, says Shanmugam
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong's trade talks with the US could help save jobs in Singapore, according to Minister for Law and Home Affairs K Shanmugam. The US tariffs, which were announced earlier in April, contribute to job uncertainty and slow investments, Shanmugam said. The government has formed an inter-ministerial committee, led by DPM Gan, to tackle the issue. If Gan remains in government after May 3, he can play a role in saving jobs in Singapore, Shanmugam added.

site_title: US consumer spending surges in March, inflation cools
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.7% in March, beating expectations, after households boosted purchases of motor vehicles to avoid tariffs. The data, part of the first quarter GDP report, showed a 0.3% annualized contraction in GDP, weighed down by a record surge in imports. Despite the increase in spending, economists remain concerned about a period of tepid growth and high inflation, commonly referred to as stagflation, fueled by President Trump's tariffs.

site_title: Ferrari unveils 400,000 euro hybrid supercars for collectors
summary: Ferrari unveiled two new hybrid supercars, the 296 Speciale coupé and Speciale A convertible, priced at 407,000 euros and 462,000 euros respectively. The new models weigh about 60kg less and reach speeds of over 330km per hour. They feature mid-rear-mounted V6 engines and electric motors, producing 880 metric horsepower. Deliveries will begin in the first and second quarters of next year, marking a significant boost in performance and exclusivity for collectors.

images.alt_text: This 1988 Porsche 959 Sport is one prime example of the brand's innovative 1980s supercar. It's one of just 29 such examples built.

site_title: Coca-Cola results beat estimates on price hikes, demand surge
summary: Coca-Cola reported better-than-expected revenue and profit for the first quarter, driven by price hikes and strong demand for its sodas, juices, and milk offering Fairlife. The company maintained its full-year organic revenue and comparable profit forecasts, despite a difficult macroeconomic backdrop. Revenue fell marginally to $11.22 billion, with an average selling price increase of 5% and unit case volumes rising 2%. Shares rose 1.2% in premarket trading.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola’s fourth-quarter comparable net revenue rose 4.2 per cent to US$11.40 billion, while analysts had expected it to drop 2.47 per cent to US$10.68 billion.

site_title: Trump tempers auto tariffs, winning cautious praise from industry
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order to limit overlapping tariffs on automakers, giving them a two-year grace period to move supply chains back to the US. The move is seen as a cautious step to soften the impact of tariffs on the industry, with the American Automotive Policy Council welcoming the relief. Analysts had warned that tariffs could result in higher prices, denting US car sales and threatening jobs, but Trump's new policy aims to spur more domestic auto manufacturing.

site_title: GE2025: ‘Housing reset’ needed to give young couples confidence to stay, says RDU chair
summary: Red Dot United (RDU) chair David Foo proposed a "comprehensive housing reset" to address Singapore's affordability crisis, convincing young couples to stay in the country. The party's "citizen's dividend" scheme, which would fund a cash transfer, will be funded by reforming tax loopholes rather than the reserves. The scheme aims to create a permanent financial safety net for all, ensuring that young couples can afford to settle down without being priced out of their own lives.

site_title: France to tax small parcels from China amid tariff fallout fears
summary: France will impose a handling tax on small parcels sent from China, starting next year, with the aim of platforms paying rather than consumers. The tax, estimated to be a few euros or cents per article, will be used to finance inspections. The move follows international concerns that US tariffs could force more Chinese goods into European markets. France seeks to establish a European handling fee mechanism, which would replace the French tax once implemented.

images.alt_text: The higher costs illustrate the impact of President Trump’s tariffs, and they risk changing how Americans shop and disrupting shipments from the likes of Temu and Shein.

site_title: Electronic Arts lays off hundreds, cancels ‘Titanfall’ game
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) is laying off hundreds of workers and cancelling a "Titanfall" game in development at its Respawn Entertainment subsidiary. Between 300 and 400 positions were eliminated, including around 100 at Respawn. The cancelled project, R7, was an extraction shooter set in the "Titanfall" universe. Respawn, known for "Apex Legends" and "Star Wars Jedi" titles, will continue working on the next "Jedi" game and new seasons for "Apex Legends".

images.alt_text: The new title will mark a return to the modern-day setting, after three consecutive games set in different time periods.

site_title: South-east Asia may see most gas projects approved in a decade
summary: South-east Asia may see 13 new gas projects approved in 2025, boosting output by 18% and adding 20 billion cubic meters of annual production capacity. This would surpass the decade's highest number of final investment decisions. The region is likely to miss its renewable energy production goal of 23% by the end year, due to financial bottlenecks and wavering global commitment on climate change. Fossil fuel financing may be accelerating in the region, making it harder for countries to transition to cleaner energy sources.

site_title: Preventing trade shocks from igniting the next financial crisis
summary: A new financial crisis could be triggered by trade shocks, particularly in developing economies, due to vulnerabilities in trade finance and currency mismatches. Over 55% of cross-border bank lending to emerging markets is still in US dollars, making trade finance vulnerable to exchange rate volatility. The World Bank estimates a $100 billion trade finance gap in sub-Saharan Africa. To prevent this, financial sector supervisors must adopt a proactive, globally aware strategy, including real-time monitoring of trade-linked exposures, testing banks against severe trade and FX shock scenarios, and increased transparency. Preparedness, not prediction, is key.

site_title: GM pulls forecast due to tariffs as nervous consumers rush to buy
summary: General Motors has temporarily paused its share buyback activity due to uncertainty from US President Donald Trump's global trade war. The company pulled its annual forecast, citing significant potential impact from tariffs on automotive costs. GM's shares fell 2.6% in premarket trading after reporting strong quarterly results, with revenue up 2.3% and adjusted earnings per share exceeding analyst forecasts. The automaker attributed the strong demand for vehicles to customers rushing to buy before prices jumped due to tariffs.

images.alt_text: GM said its US sales jumped 17 per cent in the quarter from the same period a year ago, reporting 693,363 deliveries.

site_title: UPS profit beats estimates, to cut 20,000 jobs on economic worries
summary: UPS beats market estimates with a profit of $1.49 per share in Q1, but will cut 20,000 jobs due to economic uncertainty and weak volumes from largest customer Amazon. The company expects to save $3.5 billion in 2025 from job cuts and building closures, and will reduce costs through automation and asset sales. UPS did not provide full-year guidance due to economic uncertainty, and shares rose 2% before the bell.

images.alt_text: The company deploys fixed robotic arms and AI-driven software in its high-tech Velocity facilities.
The move to scale back business with Amazon.com by 50 per cent will allow UPS to focus on more profitable shipments.

site_title: ASM’s orders beat estimates on strong demand from China
summary: ASM International's first-quarter orders exceeded estimates, driven by strong demand for AI-linked chipmaking equipment in China and solid sales in the region. Orders rose 14% to 834 million euros, beating the average analyst estimate of 808 million euros. The firm attributes the growth to AI-related segments, particularly "gate-all-around" technology, while citing uncertainty surrounding US President Trump's tariffs and their impact on economic growth. ASM expects its gross margin to be at the upper half of its target range, excluding direct tariff impacts.

images.alt_text: Tightening US export curbs have in recent years made it harder for American chipmakers to tap the Chinese market, but the country remains a key source of revenue.

site_title: New wave of SME buyers mining for ‘diamonds in the rough’ in Singapore, Asean
summary: A new wave of small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) buyers is emerging in Singapore and Southeast Asia, focusing on micro to small buyouts and longer-term holds. These niche players, including Gen Capital Partners, Oneteam, and M3I, aim to partner with "operators" – individual entrepreneurs – to acquire profitable regional businesses. Unlike traditional private equity firms, they are open to smaller deals and have longer investment horizons. They also provide continuity, leadership, and operational capabilities to SMEs, helping to solve succession and exit challenges. These players intend to build a portfolio of companies and provide shared services, offering a new avenue for SME owners and employees.

site_title: UK sets out new rules for crypto as it aligns with US on approach
summary: Britain is introducing new rules for cryptocurrencies, aligning with the US approach of regulating digital assets as securities. The draft laws will bring crypto exchanges and dealers under compulsory regulation, supporting legitimate innovation while cracking down on bad actors. Stablecoin issuers will be subject to regulation if based in the UK. The government aims to finalize the legislation by the end of the year, following discussions with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.

site_title: ST Engineering unit to issue US$750 million 4.25% notes due 2030
summary: ST Engineering's wholly owned subsidiary, ST Engineering RHQ Ltd, has priced US$750 million in 4.25% fixed-rate notes due 2030. The notes will be issued on May 8 and listed on the Singapore Exchange on May 9. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings. The notes are issued under the S$5 billion global medium-term note programme, which is unconditionally guaranteed by ST Engineering. The move is expected to support the group's long-term strategy to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open lower as investors eye trade developments, earnings
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell at the open on Tuesday, April 29, as investors assessed mixed corporate earnings and US-China trade developments. The Dow Jones rose 6.4 points, or 0.02%, to 40,233.98. The S&P 500 fell 19.9 points, or 0.36%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 95.4 points, or 0.55%. Investors are monitoring trade developments and corporate earnings, despite a recent rally in US stocks.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up, rebounding from bad GDP report
summary: US stocks ended mostly up on Wednesday, rebounding from a poor GDP report that showed the US economy shrank by 0.3% in the first quarter. Despite worries about a recession, solid consumer spending data and a late-day surge lifted two of the three indices into positive territory. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% to 40,669.36, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.2% to 5,569.06.

site_title: War bunker-turned-art space: Why you should visit Fort Canning’s Battlebox
summary: The Battlebox, a secret World War II command centre in Singapore, has been transformed into an art space showcasing seven site-specific works by local artists. The exhibition, titled Portals, uses technology, sound art, and projection mapping to reframe history and explore the comfort and discomfort of wartime architecture. The artworks, including sculptures, installations, and interactive pieces, reflect on colonial power, addiction, exploitation, and the legacy of war, inviting visitors to engage with the space and its history. The exhibition runs until June and offers curator-led tours, artist talks, and workshops.

summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) held five election rallies on Wednesday, April 30, while the opposition parties Red Dot United (RDU) and Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) held one each. The PAP responded to the Progress Singapore Party's (PSP) claims on housing issues, with National Development Minister Desmond Lee rejecting the PSP's assertions that the government has failed to address concerns on public housing affordability and GST hikes. Lee assured Singaporeans that the government has addressed national housing issues and is committed to keeping housing affordable and accessible.

site_title: IMDA’s Ang Wee Keong named as new head of MPA
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has named Ang Wee Keong as its new chief executive, succeeding Teo Eng Dih. Ang will hold the position from June 16, concurrently with his role as assistant chief executive of international at the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), until June 15. Teo will be appointed as the Ministry of Transport's deputy secretary of special duties from June 16. Ang will oversee the upcoming Digital Infrastructure Act and strengthen the country's digital economy partnerships.
