site_title: GE2025: PAR proposes shrinking ‘bloated’ civil service to fund free education
summary: Opposition party People's Alliance for Reform (PAR) leader Lim Tean has proposed shrinking the "bloated" civil service to fund free education, school meals, and healthcare for Singaporean children. If elected, PAR plans to use the interest earned from investing citizens' CPF money to fund these programs. Lim also aims to cut the Prime Minister's pay by 70% and abolish the mayors' positions. The party's proposals aim to improve the country's low total fertility rate and reduce reliance on foreign workers.

images.alt_text: The goal of opposition parties is not always to have their proposals adopted wholesale, but to help shape policy outcomes through debate and advocacy, says WP's Tampines GRC candidate Michael Thng. PHOTO: TAY CHU YI, BT
On May 3, Singaporeans will cast their votes in a general election that will be fought against a backdrop of unprecedented global economic instability.

site_title: GE2025: PSP calls for affordable housing, more healthcare funding and caregiver support at rally
summary: The People's Front of Singapore (PSP) proposed several key policies at a rally in Bukit Gombak Stadium, including affordable housing, increased healthcare funding, and caregiver support. PSP candidates also called for a revamp of education policies, including allowing pupils to bypass the Primary School Leaving Examination. Additionally, the party proposed that MediShield Life be fully funded by the government and that the goods and services tax be lowered to 7%. The proposals were made in an effort to address issues such as the high cost of living and job insecurities.

images.alt_text: On May 3, Singaporeans will cast their votes in a general election that will be fought against a backdrop of unprecedented global economic instability.
PPP party secretary-general Goh Meng Seng urged people to stand up against what he termed the politics of fear.

site_title: Singapore investors behind regional peers on climate governance and disclosures: investor group
summary: Singapore investors ranked behind regional peers in climate governance and disclosures, with average scores of 28% and 28% respectively, according to a review by the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change. However, they excelled in recognizing climate risks and opportunities, conducting advanced climate scenario analysis, and setting policies on fossil fuels, with 89%, 72%, and 61% respectively. The review noted that while progress has been made, the real economy still needs to align portfolios with net-zero trajectories.

site_title: Singapore-headquartered Shein hikes US prices as much as 377% ahead of tariff spikes
summary: Shein, a Singapore-headquartered fast-fashion retailer, has raised US prices of its products by as much as 377% ahead of tariffs on small parcels from mainland China and Hong Kong. Most of the price hikes occurred on April 25, with markups significantly higher in beauty and health, home and kitchen, and women's clothing categories. The price increases reflect the impact of the US government's decision to end the "de minimis" exemption for small packages and the impending increase in postal fees.

site_title: GE2025: How to catch tonight’s rallies on Day 4 of campaigning
summary: Singapore is set to hold its general election on May 3, with seven parties holding nine rallies across the island on the fourth day of campaigning. The election comes amidst global economic instability, with the Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh reiterating that WP candidates represent all Singaporeans, not just their own communities. Meanwhile, Progress Singapore Party chairman Tan Cheng Bock celebrated his 85th birthday at a rally, and the People's Action Party (PAP) is also set to hold rallies tonight.

site_title: GE2025: PAP, SDP to hold rallies on Day 5 of campaigning; Five parties to take part in live forum at 8 pm
summary: The fifth day of Singapore's GE2025 election campaigning saw the People's Action Party (PAP) and Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) hold rallies, with the PAP and five other parties participating in a live forum. The election, set for May 3, will take place amidst global economic instability. The live forum, "Singapore Votes 2025: The Roundtable," will feature a 90-minute English Q&A session, while a Mandarin forum is scheduled for April 29.

site_title: US dollar poised for worst 1st 100 days of presidency since Nixon
summary: The US dollar index is on track for its worst performance during the first 100 days of a US presidency since 1973, with a 9% loss between January 20 and April 25. This is attributed to President Trump's tariff policy, which has led to investors piling into assets outside the US, weakening the dollar and lifting other currencies. Analysts warn of a structural shift in global asset allocation trends, with the US dollar's role in international trade and finance under threat. The Federal Reserve's independence is also at risk due to Trump's comments on Fed Chair Jerome Powell.

images.alt_text: U.S. dollar banknote and stock graph are seen in this illustration taken April 25, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Steady rises in wages and inflation were key to the BOJ’s decision to exit a massive stimulus last year and raise its short-term interest rate to 0.5 per cent in January.

site_title: GE2025: Parties should make it clear that mixing religion and politics is unacceptable: PM Wong
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned against mixing religion and politics, calling it unacceptable and a threat to national unity. He urged party leaders to reject foreign influence and endorse identity politics, saying it weakens Singapore and advances external interests. Wong emphasized that politics should be for Singaporeans alone to decide, and that addressing community needs through engagement is different from identity politics, which champions one group's interests over others.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The WP does not push any individual’s agenda in exchange for support, Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh said, reiterating the party's stance in an earlier statement that morning.

site_title: S-Reits rebound from early April sell-off
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have rebounded strongly over the past two weeks, with the iEdge S-Reit index climbing 5.9% since April 11. Top performers include S-Reits with international exposure and those holding hospitality assets. Mapletree Logistics Trust and Suntec Reit recorded positive rental reversions in all markets except China, while CapitaLand China Trust saw its units rise 11% over the same period. Institutional investors net sold S$36.6 million in S-Reits, but retail investors remain net buyers, with total net inflows of S$261.9 million for the year-to-date.

images.alt_text: In March, Singapore Reits outperformed the global Reit market.

site_title: China's Xi calls for self sufficiency in AI development amid US rivalry
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has called for self-sufficiency in AI development amid a rivalry with the US, pledging to leverage China's "new whole national system" to advance the field. Experts say China has narrowed the AI gap with the US over the past year, with notable advancements in infrastructure software engineering and a recent AI reasoning model launch by Chinese startup DeepSeek. Xi emphasized the need for comprehensive technological innovation, industrial development, and AI-empowered applications, with a focus on mastering core technologies and building an independent AI system.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping applauds during a signing ceremony with Azerbaijan's President Ilham Aliyev at the Great Hall of The People in Beijing on April 23, 2025. (Photo by Iori SAGISAWA / POOL / AFP)
This is as Beijing seeks to become a world leader in the rapidly developing industry.

site_title: China widens tax rebates for foreign tourists to boost spending
summary: China has widened tax rebates for foreign tourists, aiming to boost spending and offset the damage from the trade war. Tourists spending at least 200 yuan (S$36) at the same store will be eligible for a rebate of up to 20,000 yuan. The move is part of China's efforts to stimulate domestic demand and increase foreign tourist spending, which accounted for 0.5% of China's GDP last year. The government plans to expand eligible tax-refund stores and streamline procedures to make it easier for tourists to claim the rebate.

site_title: World military spending hits US$2.7 trillion in record 2024 surge
summary: The world's military spending reached a record $2.72 trillion in 2024, a 9.4% increase from 2023, driven by heightened geopolitical tensions in Europe and the Middle East. Russia's military expenditure surged to $149 billion, a 38% increase from 2023 and double the 2015 level. The US spent $997 billion, accounting for 66% of NATO spending and 37% of global military spending. Ukraine's military expenditure rose 2.9% to $64.7 billion, with the country bearing a significant military burden, allocating all its tax revenues to its military.

images.alt_text: Trump’s comments come as Washington intensifies its push for a deal to end Russia’s war in Ukraine, with the American president’s envoy Steve Witkoff holding talks with Putin on Friday.
It’s possible that Trump’s unorthodox ways of doing diplomacy, proposing a mix of threats and carrots, would make a deal involving Iran dismantling its nuclear programme more likely.

site_title: Santa Maria Maggiore basilica: Pope Francis's final resting place
summary: Pope Francis, who died on April 21 at 88, will be the first pontiff in over a century not to be entombed in St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican. Instead, he will be buried in the Santa Maria Maggiore basilica, a fifth-century church in Rome that already holds the tombs of seven popes. Francis had declared his desire to be buried in the basilica in 2023, citing his devotion to the Virgin Mary, whom he frequently prayed to before leaving on trips abroad.

images.alt_text: Throughout the day, vast crowds of people had packed the wide avenue leading to the basilica, pilgrims and tourists mingling with Italians enjoying a public holiday.

site_title: Developing countries should fast-track US trade deals: World Bank president
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga advises developing countries to quickly strike trade deals with the US, warning that delays hurt everyone. The US has imposed tariffs on most countries, with higher duties on China, causing financial market volatility and investor concern. Banga also defends the World Bank's stance on China, suggesting the country's status as a developing nation should not be taken lightly, and calls for a reduction in borrowing from the institution. The World Bank is pushing for energy efficiency and private sector job creation in developing countries.

images.alt_text: Many participants in the meetings have questions over the Trump administration’s support for the IMF and the World Bank.

site_title: Nissan to end vehicle production at Wuhan plant-Yomiuri
summary: Nissan will end vehicle production at its Wuhan plant in China by March 31, 2026, due to low production rates below 10% of capacity. The decision comes amid stiff competition from Chinese automakers. Nissan leased the 300,000 vehicle capacity plant from Dongfeng Motor since 2022. The Japanese carmaker also forecast a record net loss of 700 billion yen (S$6.4 billion) for the financial year ending in March. Nissan declined to comment on the report.

site_title: China Square Food Centre set to be redeveloped into hotel; more homes to be built in the CBD, Kallang and River Valley
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed amendments to redevelop several land parcels in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD), Kallang, and River Valley for residential use. China Square Food Centre may be redeveloped into a hotel, while a site along Cross Street will become a residential development with commercial use. The proposed amendments aim to introduce more accommodation options near key amenities and transport nodes, with an estimated 1,000 to 1,500 condominium units to be built. The changes are expected to support demand for housing and improve residents' accessibility to health and medical care amenities.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

The 54-storey V on Shenton (left) comprises 510 apartments. It is part of a mixed-use project by Singapore Land Group that also includes the adjacent 23-storey UIC Building, comprising mostly offices.

site_title: GE2025: PPP raises concerns over rising cost of living, job insecurities in rally
summary: The People's Power Party (PPP) held its second rally on April 26, raising concerns over the rising cost of living, affordability of healthcare, and job insecurities. PPP candidates criticized the PAP government on various topics, including the national Covid-19 vaccination drive and immigration policy. The party is contesting Ang Mo Kio and Tampines GRCs in the upcoming election, with its 10 candidates vying against the incumbent PAP team and other opposition parties. PPP secretary-general Goh Meng Seng urged people to stand up against the "politics of fear" that has hindered the party's volunteer recruitment.

images.alt_text: The PAP's Tampines GRC team arriving at Poi Ching School to submit their nomination papers.
SUP secretary-general Andy Zhu said his party is adamant about contesting the ward despite the presence of a “third party”. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

site_title: Napoleon’s sword to be sold at auction in Paris
summary: A sword commissioned by Napoleon in 1802 and kept throughout his reign is set to be auctioned in Paris on May 22 for an estimated 700,000 to 1 million euros. The sword, which was passed down to Napoleon's ally Emmanuel de Grouchy, has been in the family since 1815. A second identical copy is held at the Hermitage Museum in Russia. This is the latest in a series of Napoleon memorabilia to be sold at auction in France, following the sale of pistols and a bicorne hat in recent months.

site_title: GE2025: Once wary of being spotted as a WP volunteer, Michael Thng now champions political diversity
summary: Michael Thng, a 37-year-old chief operating officer and co-founder of tech startup Showdrop, is part of the Workers' Party's (WP) slate for Tampines GRC in Singapore's General Election 2025. Thng, who initially volunteered for the WP in 2011, now champions political diversity and change. He hopes to improve policies such as the Workfare Income Supplement scheme and increase support for early-stage startups. Thng believes that a multi-party Parliament can lead to better policy outcomes, as long as parties act in good faith and prioritize the country's interests.

The PAP's Tampines GRC team arriving at Poi Ching School to submit their nomination papers.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the following key market trends for the week of April 25, 2025:

- Capesize rates rose across all regions, driven by growing cargo volumes and increased miner activity, with the C5 index rising to $7.815.
- Panamax rates surged in the Atlantic basin, supported by strong demand for North Atlantic Trans-Atlantic grain, while the Asian market remained flat.
- Ultramax and Supramax rates were mixed, with the Asian arena seeing renewed interest, while the Atlantic was described as very slow.
- Handysize rates remained flat, with minimal visible activity across both basins.
- The LNG market showed a notable shift, with strong recovery in the Atlantic basin, while the Pacific was mixed.
- The LPG market has been relatively quiet, with fixing activity slowing noticeably and rates remaining below pre-tariff levels.
- The time charter market strengthened, with six-month charters rising by $3,200 to $31,050 per day, while one-year rates climbed by $1,325 to $34,400 per day.

An undated handout photograph shows Nippon Yusen K.K.'s dry-bulk ship, provided to the media on Friday, July 3, 2009. Nippon Yusen K.K. , the world's second-largest ship operator, predicted profit at its capesize division for shipping iron ore will be higher than originally forecast this fiscal year on demand for the steel ingredient from China. site_title: GE2025: WP candidates represent all Singaporeans, not just their communities: Pritam Singh
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh reiterated that the party's candidates represent all Singaporeans, not just their communities, in a statement. The WP's manifesto focuses on policies appealing to all Singaporeans, regardless of race, language, or religion. In contrast, the PAP has been criticized for its lack of policy proposals, particularly on housing affordability and caregiver support. The WP has proposed measures such as lease decay solutions and family care leave for caregivers of elderly parents. Singh warned that community-based politics could lead to the unnecessary politicization of public space.

site_title: Singapore blocks Facebook posts by 2 Malaysian politicians, ex-ISA detainee that attempt to influence election
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has blocked access to several Facebook posts by foreigners, including a former ISA detainee, attempting to influence the country's general election. The posts were made by Malaysian politicians and a Facebook user who renounced his Singapore citizenship, criticizing local Muslim MPs and urging voters to consider racial and religious lines. The government warned that such posts can fracture social harmony and undermine the secular state, and urged all parties to safeguard the country's harmony. The election is set to take place on May 3.

site_title: GE2025: Chee Soon Juan says Bukit Batok residents remain in his heart despite move to Sembawang West
summary: SDP chief Chee Soon Juan defended his move from the Bukit Batok to contest Sembawang West, accusing the PAP of personal attacks. He said residents of Bukit Batok remain in his heart, despite his move, and unveiled the SDP's plans for Sembawang GRC, including community storage facilities and microchip services for lost pets. Chee accused the PAP of repackaging existing national development plans as constituency-specific promises, and called for a focus on human-centric policies. The SDP's plans aim to engage residents' input in drawing up future plans for Sembawang GRC.

images.alt_text: In his speech, PM Lawrence Wong promised to continue to manage Singapore’s economy well and harness its resources effectively to stay ahead of changes.

site_title: Oil posts weekly fall on tariff worry and rising supplies
summary: Oil prices rose 32 US cents to $66.87 a barrel, but posted a weekly decline of 1.6% due to market concerns over oversupply and uncertain tariff talks between the US and China. China exempted some US imports from tariffs, but analysts say further price gains are unlikely in the short term. Supplies could swell if Opec+ accelerates production hikes in June and the war in Ukraine ends, allowing more Russian oil to reach global markets.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose 43 US cents, or 0.7 per cent, to settle at US$66.55 a barrel.

site_title: InnoTek conducts buybacks following robust FY2024
summary: InnoTek, a Singapore-based company, conducted a buyback of S$20.7 million worth of shares over four trading sessions from Apr 21 to 24, marking the company's first buyback since May 2013. InnoTek's FY2024 revenue increased by 15.8% to S$238 million, with attributable net profit rising 23.4% to S$5.8 million. Meanwhile, institutions sold S$14 million worth of Singapore stocks, bringing the net institutional outflow for the 2025 year to S$1.79 billion. Several companies, including Singtel, Singapore Exchange, and ST Engineering, led the net institutional inflow, while telecommunications and industrials sectors saw the highest net institutional inflow.

images.alt_text: Over the four trading sessions from Mar 28 to Apr 3, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional inflow of S$76 million.

site_title: All eyes on Asia: The next travel powerhouse reshaping travel spend
summary: Asia-Pacific contributed 51.2% of global passenger traffic growth in 2024, with travel spend in some markets on track to hit record highs. The region's middle class, driven by demographic shifts and emerging markets, is fueling this transformation. South-east Asia is emerging as a powerhouse, with countries like Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand outpacing the Asia-Pacific average. The region's increasing influence on global travel trends is expected to shape the next phase of travel spending growth, with intra-regional travel poised to become a stable engine for sustained travel spending.

images.alt_text: The swimming pool at Raffles Sentosa.
Shinichi Inoue (left), CEO of All Nippon Airways and Goh Choon Phong, CEO of Singapore Airlines. The two airlines will begin revenue-sharing flights between Singapore and Japan in September 2025.

Sean Lim rose from being a lowly-paid cook to a successful investor, car lover and property owner.

site_title: US pharma tariffs would raise US drug costs by US$51 billion annually, report finds
summary: A 25% US tariff on pharmaceutical imports would increase US drug costs by nearly $51 billion annually, boosting prices by up to 12.9% if passed on to consumers. The US imported $203 billion in pharmaceutical products in 2023, with 73% coming from Europe. The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) has argued that tariffs would undermine domestic manufacturing efforts, while the Trump administration has threatened a 25% tariff due to national security concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknote and medicines are seen in this illustration taken, June 27, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Of the 12,000 new positions, nearly 6,500 will be in construction and 1,000 at new and expanded facilities, Roche said.
Pharmaceuticals and semiconductors are exempt from those duties, but Trump has said they will face separate tariffs.
Novartis joins a growing number of multinational drug companies to announce investments in the US this year.
Trump has long bemoaned a lack of domestic pharmaceutical production and has repeatedly promised tariffs to bring more capacity into the country.

site_title: Conflicting US-China talks statements add to global trade confusion
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed that tariff negotiations with China are underway, despite China denying any talks. Trump stated that China should open its markets to US products to avoid tariffs, but China countered that the US should stop creating confusion. The US Trade Representative aims to streamline trade talks with 18 countries, while China has exempted some US imports from its tariffs. The back-and-forth adds to the uncertainty surrounding Trump's tariff policy, which has sparked global trade confusion and raised concerns about recession and global growth.

images.alt_text: The world’s two leading economies are locked in an escalating tit-for-tat trade battle triggered by Trump’s new levies on Chinese goods, which have reached 145 per cent on many products.

There are “no winners in trade wars” and China will remain open to the outside world and firmly support free trade and the multilateral trading system,  People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Pan Gongsheng said.

site_title: GE2025: Jobs, wages and prices are issues majority of Singaporeans concerned with: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized that jobs, wages, and prices are the top concerns for most Singaporeans, particularly in the current economic climate. He urged candidates to focus on these issues and proposed that the government help workers by redistributing the fruits of Singapore's growth, ensuring they have good jobs and growing income. Chan also responded to Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh's comments on the labor movement and PAP MPs, stating that every NTUC secretary-general and labor MPs must go through the NTUC's internal election to maintain their effectiveness in representing workers.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The WP does not push any individual’s agenda in exchange for support, Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh said, reiterating the party's stance in an earlier statement that morning.

site_title: Malaysia-US trade talks started ‘well enough,’ official says
summary: Malaysia's initial meeting with US officials on tariffs went well, according to Second Finance Minister Amir Hamzah Azizan. The talks aimed to frame the way forward and avoid 24% tariffs announced by President Donald Trump earlier this month. Malaysia is seeking to avoid the tariffs, which could impact its semiconductor exports, and is coordinating with other Asean bloc members to negotiate a trade agreement. The conversations are ongoing, with the US seeking to wrap up trade deals in the next three to four weeks.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Petronas Twin Towers (C) are pictured with others commercial buildings from the KL Tower in Kuala Lumpur on February 21, 2025. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)
Malaysia's Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz says: “Negotiation takes time, right? So, it is more to talk about how Malaysia can play an important role in the supply chain between Asia and the US.”

site_title: Xi says China must 'overcome' AI chip challenges: state media
summary: President Xi Jinping urged China to overcome challenges in developing core artificial intelligence technologies, including high-end chips. At a Politburo meeting, Xi emphasized the need for strengthened basic research and focus on overcoming core technologies to build an autonomous AI system. This comes as Beijing seeks to become a world leader in the rapidly developing AI industry.

site_title: The war on ‘woke’ universities will slow US innovation
summary: The US war on "woke" universities threatens to slow innovation, with some institutions facing billions of dollars in federal funding at risk if they comply with the Trump administration's demands. The ivory tower has been corroded by "woke mind virus" and administrative bloat, but universities are powerful engines of US prosperity, driving innovation and economic growth. The Trump administration's actions could damage the delicate balance between government, business, and academia, allowing countries like China to catch up in innovation and potentially erode America's lead.

images.alt_text: CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS - APRIL 17: People leave Harvard University on April 17, 2025 in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The Trump administration announced that it would block Harvard University from receiving $2.2 billion in federal grants and $60 million in contracts after the school refused demands to adopt new policies relating to student and faculty conduct, admissions, anti-semitism on campus and DEI.   Sophie Park/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Sophie Park / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
With Trump's trade tariffs clouding economic forecasts, indicators both leading and lagging are lacking in their ability to help us navigate the dense fog.

site_title: China’s Didi recruits ride-hailing drivers in Hong Kong push
summary: China's Didi Global is recruiting ride-hailing drivers in Hong Kong to expand its services beyond mainland China. The move comes as the company seeks to compete with Uber in a financial hub with still-unregulated ride-hailing services. Didi has been offering limited taxi services in Hong Kong but lacks a ride-share option. The company is using a subsidiary, KayGo, to recruit drivers, who will gradually provide their services to Didi users. This expansion is part of Didi's international growth strategy, which includes a planned listing on the Hong Kong stock exchange.

images.alt_text: The Didi Global Inc. offices in Hangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Didi’s autonomous driving unit operates a self-driving fleet of over 200 vehicles that have conducted trials in Beijing, Guangzhou and Shanghai.
Didi Global swung to a net income of 929 million yuan (S$172 million) for the September quarter, versus a year-ago loss.

site_title: Chinese tea hub branches into coffee as tastes change
summary: Chinese tea growers are expanding into coffee production as younger generations develop a taste for specialty coffee drinks. In Pu'er, Yunnan province, coffee plantations are thriving, with many family-owned farms, such as Xiaowazi, producing high-quality coffee. The region's unique climate and altitude make it well-suited for coffee cultivation, and local roasters and baristas are now experimenting with traditional and modern brewing methods. With China's coffee output rising dramatically, the government is promoting the sector through policies and tourism initiatives, offering new income streams for farmers like Yu Dun, who has seen her revenue increase tenfold since learning to process and roast her own coffee.

images.alt_text: A Birkin handbag on display at a Hermes boutique. Hermes reported 14.7 per cent global sales growth, though its Asia-Pacific growth slowed to 7 per cent from 19 per cent a year earlier.

site_title: GE2025: From ‘the best team’ to building democracy: parties’ first political broadcasts
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and opposition parties have delivered their first political broadcasts ahead of the General Election (GE2025). The speeches touched on global uncertainty, cost-of-living woes, and strengthening democracy. PAP Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a "best team" to navigate the challenges, while Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh proposed building a stable and sustainable opposition presence. Other parties, including Red Dot United and Progress Singapore Party, highlighted issues like inequality, housing affordability, and healthcare.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Sharon See
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong from the PAP, Gigene Wong from the SDP, and NSP candidates on their walkabouts on Apr 25 morning.

site_title: Six reasons to avoid hedge funds
summary: A financial expert advises against investing in hedge funds, citing six main reasons. Hedge funds often charge high fees, typically exceeding 1.5% on top of base fees, and have complex structures that can lead to asymmetric risk. Returns are generally mediocre, and diversification benefits are limited. Investors may pay higher rates than contracted performance fees when holding a diversified pool of hedge funds. The complexity of hedge funds can also exploit investors' cognitive biases. Additionally, predicting outperforming funds is difficult, and even successful funds may not accept new capital. Overall, the expert recommends sticking to traditional assets like stocks and bonds.

images.alt_text: The increasing number of ultra-high-net-worth families has spurred the need for modernised approaches to wealth management.

site_title: Yen, BOJ's rate policy may remain focus in Japan-US trade talks
summary: Japan and the US held bilateral finance talks on April 24, where Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato and US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent discussed issues such as exchange rates and trade. Despite no explicit discussion of yen targets, Kato stated that Japan and the US will continue close dialogue on exchange rates "in relation to the ongoing bilateral trade negotiations." The talks come as US President Donald Trump has expressed concerns about Japan's weak yen and its impact on US trade deficit, but the meeting appears to have averted direct pressure on Japan to strengthen the yen.

images.alt_text: Rather than dialling back trade, Tokyo is in the process of trying to get China to resume imports of seafood and beef from Japan after bans imposed over health concerns.

site_title: UK's Reeves talks trade with US's Bessent after stressing EU ties
summary: British finance minister Rachel Reeves met US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent to discuss a trade deal, focusing on easing the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs on British car and metals exporters. Reeves emphasized the importance of improving ties with the European Union, stating it is "arguably even more important" than the UK-US relationship. She also met with German Finance Minister Joerg Kukies and China's finance minister Lan Foan to discuss trade and economic cooperation, while ruling out concessions on food standards to secure a deal with Washington.

images.alt_text: British finance minister Rachel Reeves plans to advocate for a “more balanced global economic and trading system” at the upcoming International Monetary Fund meeting later this month.

site_title: Taiwan envoy to pope's funeral says he aims to chat with world leaders
summary: Taiwan's envoy to the Pope's funeral, former vice-president Chen Chien-jen, aims to use the opportunity to "have a good chat" with world leaders, particularly those friendly to Taipei. Chen, a devout Catholic, will attend the funeral alongside US President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron. Taiwan's President Lai Ching-te is not attending, instead sending Chen to boost international ties. Chen plans to "seize the opportunity" to increase friendly relations with like-minded countries, despite China's diplomatic isolation of Taiwan.

site_title: PSG lose unbeaten Ligue 1 record ahead of Arsenal showdown
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) lost their unbeaten Ligue 1 record with a 3-1 defeat to Nice on Friday, ending a 30-match winning streak. The team had been seeking to become the first to complete a French top-flight season without a loss. PSG coach Luis Enrique expressed acceptance of the result, focusing on the upcoming Champions League semi-final against Arsenal. Despite the setback, Enrique remains confident, stating he's not worried about the loss and believes his team will carry on in the Champions League.

images.alt_text: Liverpool's Conor Bradley (left) in action against PSV Eindhoven on Thursday in the final round of group games of this season's Champions League. Liverpool lost 3-2 but still topped the 36-team table.

site_title: Powell draws applause on independence at closed-door International Monetary Fund meeting
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell defended central bank independence at a closed-door IMF meeting, stating it's "very widely understood and supported in Washington." He emphasized that central banks must remain shielded from politics to focus on inflation stability and employment. Powell's remarks came after President Donald Trump publicly criticized him and expressed concerns about the Fed's independence. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates steady at its next meeting on May 6-7, amid Trump's tariff policy concerns. Powell reiterated that Fed officials are not influenced by politics and will make decisions strictly without consideration of extraneous factors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell attends a press conference, following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy, in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard/File Photo

site_title: BYD first-quarter profit soars, beating Tesla on another metric
summary: BYD's net income for the first quarter jumped to 9.15 billion yuan, beating analyst projections and surpassing Tesla's net income of $409 million. Despite US President Donald Trump's auto tariffs, analysts expect minimal impact on BYD due to strong orders from South America and Southeast Asia. BYD's car sales for the quarter reached 170.36 billion yuan, with just shy of one million units sold, putting the company on track to achieve full-year sales of 5.5 million units.

images.alt_text: A Wuling Motors car is transported to the National Exhibition and Convention Center to be displayed for Shanghai auto show this week.

In Q1 2025, BYD outsold Tesla in pure battery EVs for the second straight quarter. And years of being shut out of the US forced BYD to redirect its focus to every other major market, including in Europe where it now has factories.
India wants to be a global hub for electric vehicle production, but high entry barriers serve as a detriment.

site_title: What Singapore can do to be a global crypto leader
summary: Singapore has a unique opportunity to solidify its position as a global crypto leader by embracing its role in financial innovation. With a strong foundation in regulation and experimentation, the city-state can build on its momentum by launching a National Digital Asset Strategy, easing guardrails for onshore retail participation, doubling down on R&D and upskilling, establishing a RegLab for tokenisation, and considering strategic bitcoin positions. By taking a bold course forward, Singapore can unlock new capital, attract top-tier talent, and reinforce its leadership in financial innovation, ultimately ensuring the next decade of finance is built in the Lion City.

images.alt_text: The launch of Bitcoin perpetual futures on SGX is expected to have a profound impact on the global cryptocurrency market, with industry experts anticipating that it will reinforce the ongoing institutionalisation of digital assets.
A handful of ETFs already offer products with investment strategies that align with Trump’s policy objectives.
If Bitcoin continues to trade more like gold than a tech stock, the decoupling narrative will gather momentum.

site_title: Tencent Music in talks to buy Ximalaya for US$2.4 billion
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group is in talks to acquire Chinese podcasting startup Ximalaya for approximately $2.4 billion. The deal would accelerate Tencent Music's push to become China's answer to Spotify Technology. The acquisition would be funded by a combination of cash and shares. If agreed upon, the deal could be finalized in the coming weeks, according to sources. Ximalaya, which counts Tencent, Baidu, and Sony Group's music entertainment unit as backers, has 303 million monthly active users.

site_title: Former France captain Evra to make mixed martial arts debut
summary: Former France football captain Patrice Evra is set to make his mixed martial arts debut on May 23 in Paris. Evra, 43, has been training in combat sports since 2016 and has joked about facing former Uruguayan footballer Luis Suarez, whom he accuses of racially insulting him. The PFL announced Evra's fight on Friday, stating he's "ready for this" and will fulfill his dream of competing in an MMA bout. The name of his opponent will be announced shortly.

images.alt_text: PSG must now quickly put this defeat behind them as they head to London for the first leg of their Champions League last-four tie against Arsenal on Tuesday.

site_title: Trump says Russia and Ukraine are ‘very close to a deal’
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Russia and Ukraine are "very close" to a deal to end the war, following a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin's envoy Steve Witkoff. The two sides have agreed on major points, including stopping the bloodshed, and Trump is urging high-level talks to finalize the agreement. The US demands Ukraine maintain its army and defense industry, which would require Putin to give up his demand for the demilitarization of the country. Trump's comments come as he rushes to end the war before his 100th day in office.

images.alt_text: Trump maintains pressure on Zelensky to agree to a deal to give the US access to Ukraine’s resources.

site_title: Seatrium chief financial officer resigns, to be replaced by strategy EVP
summary: Seatrium appoints Stephen Lu as its new CFO, effective April 29, replacing Adrian Teng who is leaving to pursue personal interests. Lu, with over 15 years of experience in strategy and corporate finance, will continue to serve as EVP for strategy. The appointment is seen as a strategic move to support Seatrium's growth and transformation.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Seatrium has proposed a final dividend of S$0.015 per share. It will be paid on May 19, after the record date of May 7.

Representatives from Seatrium and International Maritime Industries (IMI) signed a contract (pictured). Under the agreement, the offshore and marine specialist will provide equipment and a license for the construction of Kingdom 3, a rig in the Middle East and North Africa region.
At 9.41 am the counter rose to S$2.45, up 6.5 per cent or S$0.15 from its closing price of S$2.30 on Wednesday.

site_title: US officials adopt ‘organised’ framework to handle trade talks
summary: US officials have adopted an 'organised' framework to handle trade talks, aiming to provide clarity for negotiations with major trading partners. The framework, developed by the US Trade Representative, outlines common areas of concern, including tariffs, digital trade, and economic security. US negotiators will host select countries each week to discuss tariff relief ahead of a mid-July deadline, with 18 countries expected to be involved in the talks. The effort aims to manage the flood of foreign governments seeking tariff relief and provide a clearer understanding of US objectives.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump during an executive order signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. Trump will sign an executive order to boost artificial intelligence education and workforce training, according to a senior White House official, highlighting a rapidly developing technology that is a top administration priority. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Sipa/Bloomberg
The world’s two leading economies are locked in an escalating tit-for-tat trade battle triggered by Trump’s new levies on Chinese goods, which have reached 145 per cent on many products.

US President Donald Trump during an executive order signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. Trump will sign an executive order to boost artificial intelligence education and workforce training, according to a senior White House official, highlighting a rapidly developing technology that is a top administration priority. site_title: Apple aims to build most iPhones for US in India by end-2026
summary: Apple plans to assemble most iPhones sold in the US in India by the end of 2026, aiming to double its annual production to over 80 million units. This shift is driven by US President Donald Trump's tariffs and Beijing-Washington tensions, prompting Apple to diversify its supply chain. The goal means Apple would source all US-sold iPhones from India, with the bulk of production assembled at Foxconn Technology Group's factory in southern India.

images.alt_text: Global smartphone shipments rose 1.5 per cent in the first quarter with Apple rushing to stockpile units to avoid tariffs imposed by US president Donald Trump.
Apple, these days, sells about 220 million to 230 million iPhones annually, with about a third of those going to the US.
While the ban was in place, the government had allowed iPhone 16 models to be brought into the country, provided they were not being traded commercially.
The details of the push provide an insight into Apple’s private strategy to navigate around the Trump tariffs and build up inventory of its popular iPhones in the US.
The estimate comes as US President Donald Trump zeros in on China for his trade fight.
Apple has rapidly expanded in India after strict Covid shutdowns paralysed manufacturing at its largest iPhone plant in China.
Apple’s latest flagship iPhone currently starts at US$999 – a level that has remained constant since 2017.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: A voters guide to GE2025
summary: Singapore is gearing up for its general election on May 3, 2025, with various issues dominating the discussion. Expert guests Dr. Felix Tan, Anthea Ong, and Nicholas Fang discussed pivotal issues such as GST hikes, housing woes, and the influence of social media on politics. The panelists highlighted the importance of integrity and values in candidates, particularly for younger voters, and the potential risks of fielding new candidates. The discussion also touched on the impact of external factors on local elections and the need for rejuvenation of leadership.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
(From left) Claressa Monteiro, Prof Walid Jumblatt Bin Abdullah and Dr Gillian Koh break down the unique traits of Singapore’s electoral system.

site_title: China flexes hard at the world’s biggest car expo
summary: China's home-grown car brands are making a bold move to expand globally, showcasing their technology and design vision at the Shanghai motor show. Avatr's 06 electric sedan and Zeekr's luxury SUV, 9X, are among the high-profile debuts, with Avatr aiming to enter 50 new markets by year's end. Other Chinese brands, including BYD, Zeekr, and Deepal, are also pushing into the premium segment, with BYD's Denza Z concept targeting Porsche's 911 and Deepal's S09 SUV starting at under $43,000. The show marks a turning point for Chinese carmakers, shifting from acquiring foreign brands to developing their own.

images.alt_text: Designed in Turin, the S07 is blessed with the sleek proportions and taut surface language you'd expect from Italy, with frameless windows for an extra dash of style.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, April 25, 2025
summary: China may exempt some US goods from tariffs as costs rise, while the IMF cut Singapore's GDP growth forecast for 2025 due to a tariff shock. Tensions in Kashmir dragged down Indian stocks and bonds. These market movements and news from Singapore and the region were discussed in the latest "Market Focus Daily" podcast.

images.alt_text: China is the world’s largest plastics manufacturer but some of its factories depend on ethane, which is mainly imported from the US.
Generic image of Singapore's CBD, financial district

site_title: Trump scraps US office on climate diplomacy
summary: The US has abolished its Office of Global Change, effectively ending US participation in UN climate diplomacy, as President Donald Trump's administration continues to prioritize climate skepticism. The move is expected to result in the US being absent from the November's COP30 summit in Brazil, a significant shift in global climate diplomacy. The office's closure is seen as a continuation of Trump's stance on climate change, which has been a subject of controversy since his return to office in January 2025.

images.alt_text: “Regardless of changes in the international landscape, China’s efforts to combat climate change will not slow down", said Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally as market eyes busy calendar next week
summary: US stocks rallied for a fourth consecutive session, with the S&P 500 finishing up 0.7% as markets await a busy calendar of earnings and economic data next week. President Trump's comments on tariffs and trade talks with China boosted sentiment, with analysts noting that any easing of the trade war would be welcomed by financial markets. Despite Trump's continued support for tariffs, reports suggest China may exempt some US goods from retaliatory tariffs, and markets are also benefiting from strong earnings reports, including Alphabet's beat on expectations.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 gained 2 per cent to 5,484.77, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.7 per cent to 17,166.04.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit three-week high as US-China trade tensions ease
summary: European shares reached a three-week high, closing 0.3% higher and up 2.7% for the week, driven by easing US-China trade tensions. China exempted some US imports from 125% tariffs, and the White House expressed willingness to negotiate with Beijing. This led to gains in basic resources and automobiles sub-indices, with copper prices benefiting from easing global trade tensions. European stocks rose across sectors, including defences, construction, and materials, with some companies, such as Safran and Siemens, seeing significant gains.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index erased earlier losses to close 0.4 per cent higher, building on this week’s rally.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly lower as China trade uncertainty lingers
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, April 25, as investors reacted to conflicting comments from US President Donald Trump and Beijing on the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones fell 47.7 points, or 0.12%, to 40,045.73, while the S&P 500 rose 5.0 points, or 0.09%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 16.1 points, or 0.09%. The uncertainty surrounding the trade tensions lingered, affecting market sentiment.

site_title: Issue 145: South-east Asia’s sunburn; favourable market greets Singapore green bond auction
summary: The US has imposed new solar tariffs on imports from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, with duties ranging from 34% to 3,521%. The tariffs aim to offset unfair subsidies given to these countries' solar manufacturers. The move is expected to impact the solar exporters in the four countries, who sold US$12.9 billion of solar equipment to the US in 2024. However, the tariffs could lead to short-term benefits for solar buyers elsewhere in the world. Singapore is set to issue S$1.8 billion of 30-year green bonds through an auction, which could lower the nation's blended cost of financing its decarbonisation strategy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 25)
summary: A significant number of legal professionals have stepped forward as candidates in the coming general election, across party lines. This marks a notable shift in Singapore's political landscape, with each candidate bringing specialized knowledge in different legal domains that could inform various aspects of legislation. Meanwhile, private home prices rose 0.8% and rents increased 0.4% in Q1, while HDB resale prices grew at a slower rate due to increased housing supply. The government must ensure sufficient resources to support an ageing population and address global economic challenges.

site_title: SM Lee receives top May Day award for ‘sterling contributions’ to workers
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong received the Distinguished Comrade of Labour award at the NTUC May Awards for his "sterling contributions" to workers, becoming the seventh recipient of the top award since 1963. The award recognizes individuals who have made unique and supreme contributions to the labour movement, and NTUC President K Thanaletchimi praised SM Lee for putting workers at the heart of Singapore's progress and shaping policies that uplifted workers and ensured no one was left behind.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

Acknowledging the uncertain times ahead, SkillsFuture Singapore chief executive Tan Kok Yam said that having “versatility and deployability across the labour force” is what will keep Singapore resilient as an economy. PHOTO: ST
Changes made to SkillsFuture schemes will ease logistical, administrative and cost burdens.
Under the SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme, applicants can take part in 13 types of job search activities — including career-related events — to meet their monthly points target. PHOTO: BT FILE
The 38-year-old mother of two was introduced on Apr 13 as a People’s Action Party (PAP) candidate for Workers’ Party-held Sengkang GRC.

site_title: Nasa administrator was once arrested, accused of passing bad checks to casinos
summary: NASA Administrator nominee Jared Isaacman was arrested in 2010 on fraud charges related to passing bad checks to casinos, totaling $2 million. The charges were resolved in 2011. Isaacman, a billionaire pilot and astronaut, has faced lawsuits in New Jersey and Connecticut over casino debts. Despite the controversy, Isaacman's nomination for NASA administrator is set for a Senate Commerce Committee vote.

images.alt_text: SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket has lifted off at 7.03 pm ET (2303 GMT) from Nasa’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida carrying four astronauts who will replace Wilmore and Williams.

site_title: Hup San Social Club is a love letter to Singapore’s early Chinese immigrants
summary: Hup San Social Club, a clandestine 12-seater speakeasy in Singapore, pays tribute to the city's early Chinese immigrants and their social clubs. The bar, located in the basement of a shophouse, offers a range of Asian-inspired cocktails, including a sweet-sour concoction named Achar, and serves small bites from sister restaurant Club Street Laundry. Co-owner June Baek hopes to recreate the convivial spirit of Singapore's past social clubs, bringing people together in a "friendly neighbourhood bar" for second-generation immigrants like herself.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Miss Samsui, a twist on the Manhattan, pays tribute to the samsui women, female Chinese immigrants in iconic red headscarves who played a vital role in building pre-war Singapore.

site_title: Huge crowds pack Vatican ahead of Pope's funeral
summary: Over 128,000 people have paid their last respects to Pope Francis, who will be buried at his favorite church after a funeral ceremony in St Peter's Square. The Vatican has placed the area under tight security, with drones blocked and snipers on rooftops. The funeral, attended by over 130 foreign delegations, including heads of state and monarchs, will take place on Saturday. Pope Francis, who defied doctors' orders to appear at Easter, will be remembered for his reformist policies and advocacy for the vulnerable.

images.alt_text: The lying in state began on Wednesday and instead of a planned closing at midnight, the basilica remained open until 5.30am (0330 GMT) on Thursday morning, before reopening at 7.00am.

site_title: Thailand woos rich European tourists as Chinese arrivals slump
summary: Thailand aims to attract more European tourists to boost its tourism industry, which has been impacted by a decline in Chinese arrivals due to safety concerns. The country plans to increase flights to European cities and launch new routes, with a surge in visitors from long-haul markets, including the UK, Italy, and Spain. This move is crucial to meet Thailand's goal of 39 million visitors and 2.23 trillion baht in revenue this year, as the tourism industry accounts for 13% of the country's GDP.

images.alt_text: Washington has put its deficit with Thailand at US$45.6 billion.
“As the situation changes, we have to adjust,” Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira says.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Friday; STI slides 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to 3,823.78 on Friday, as a smaller-than-expected 5.8% year-on-year gain in factory output outweighed improved sentiment on trade discussions. The index closed lower despite 309 gainers outnumbering 208 decliners, with Hongkong Land rising 10% and OCBC sliding 3.9%. Analysts expect Singapore's external demand to weaken amid US tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Malaysia has reaffirmed its decision not to retaliate against Washington, underscoring its willingness to work together in addressing the raised concerns.
Tokyo rose more than 1 per cent, while Sydney added 0.6 per cent and Shanghai 0.3 per cent.

site_title: Mexico president open to modifying telecoms bill after censorship accusations
summary: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum is open to modifying a contentious telecommunications bill that critics say could limit free speech and permit government censorship. The bill, which aims to prevent foreign governments from broadcasting propaganda in Mexico, has sparked controversy and criticism from human rights groups and opposition lawmakers. Sheinbaum has called for the bill's Article 109 to be clarified or removed, amid concerns that the legislation could grant the state control over the internet and social media. Debate on the bill will continue into the coming weeks and months.

images.alt_text: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's president, speaks during an event at Zocalo Plaza in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025. Sheinbaum, in a speech to crowds of supporters days before Donald Trump is sworn in as US head of state, vowed her country would not be subordinated by its northern neighbor. Photographer: Stephania Corpi/Bloomberg

Mexico's President Claudia Sheinbaum said she is confident her US counterpart Donald Trump won't impose reciprocal tariffs on her nation's exports next month as tensions between the top trading partners simmer.

site_title: Active fund management isn't dead just yet
summary: Nomura Holdings agreed to pay US$1.8 billion for the US and European asset management arm of Australian group Macquarie Group. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move in a challenging asset management landscape, where active fund management is under pressure from low-fee passive funds and high-charging alternative strategies. The deal is considered an oddity given the current market conditions, but may offer Nomura a competitive edge. The acquisition is expected to help Nomura navigate the industry's "barbell" problem and capitalize on dollar asset diversification in Asia.

images.alt_text: Nomura will acquire all relevant assets, investment teams and operating platforms.

site_title: Legal minds at the ballot box: What lawyers bring to Singapore’s political landscape
summary: A significant number of legal professionals have stepped forward as candidates in Singapore's 2025 General Election (GE2025), with lawyers from across party lines vying for seats. This trend reflects a tradition of legal expertise in politics, with many lawyers having served in government and contributing to governance. Lawyers bring distinct advantages to parliamentary service, including analytical thinking, ability to identify unforeseen consequences, and skills in balancing competing interests. Their participation in GE2025 signals a commitment to evidence-based policymaking and rigorous analysis, and reflects the importance of high-calibre legal thinking in addressing Singapore's challenges.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong from the PAP, Gigene Wong from the SDP, and NSP candidates on their walkabouts on Apr 25 morning.
Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC voters have a choice of two rallies tonight, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong kicking off the People's Action Party rally in Woodlands Stadium.

Speaking to reporters on Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong explained the thinking behind the redeployments, noting that he moved DPM Gan Kim Yong to Punggol as it was “really not easy to find a senior officeholder of a similar stature” to take over from SM Teo Chee Hean.

site_title: Toyota chairman proposes record buyout of its supplier at US$42 billion valuation
summary: Toyota Motor chairman Akio Toyoda has proposed a $42 billion buyout of supplier Toyota Industries, a 40% premium over its closing stock price. The deal would bolster Toyoda's stake and influence over the broader Toyota group, including suppliers and rival carmakers. The proposal comes months after a failed similar bid to take Japanese retailer Seven & i Holdings private and is part of a wave of merger and acquisition activity in Japan. Discussions are ongoing, and the deal may not proceed.

images.alt_text: Akio Toyoda, chairman of Toyota Motor Corp., during a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, June 3, 2024. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg
Toyoda, the grandson of the company’s founder, saw shareholder support drop to a record low of 85 per cent last year, then a further decline to 72 per cent in June.

site_title: Huge crowds pack Vatican for last day of Pope's lying in state
summary: Pope Francis's body was paid respects by over 250,000 people during his lying in state at St Peter's Basilica in Vatican City. The public viewing ended on Friday, with world leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, US President Donald Trump, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, gathering for his funeral. The Vatican has placed the area under tight security, with a white silk veil covering the pope's face and a bag of coins and medals in his coffin. Francis will be buried at Rome's papal basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore, with a conclave expected to choose his successor in May.

images.alt_text: More than 128,000 people have already paid their last respects to Francis.
The lying in state began on Wednesday and instead of a planned closing at midnight, the basilica remained open until 5.30am (0330 GMT) on Thursday morning, before reopening at 7.00am.

site_title: China vows to ready emergency plans, signals calm amid trade war
summary: China's Politburo has pledged to prepare emergency plans to mitigate the impact of a deepening trade war with the US, while signaling a patient approach to defending growth. The decision-making body has also vowed to introduce new monetary tools and policy financing instruments to boost technology, consumption, and trade. This move comes after China's stronger-than-expected growth in the first quarter, but the government is still considering additional economic stimulus. Beijing is waiting for clearer signs of progress in trade negotiations with the US before unveiling new measures, with the next Politburo meeting in July potentially bringing new stimulus.

images.alt_text: China is the world’s largest plastics manufacturer but some of its factories depend on ethane, which is mainly imported from the US.
Vietnam has said it would crackdown on fraudulent rules of origin as part of its fight against goods labelled as Vietnamese products.
The world’s two leading economies are locked in an escalating tit-for-tat trade battle triggered by Trump’s new levies on Chinese goods, which have reached 145 per cent on many products.

There are “no winners in trade wars” and China will remain open to the outside world and firmly support free trade and the multilateral trading system,  People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Pan Gongsheng said.
A 25 per cent tariff on all imports of foreign-made cars would remain in place and a 25 per cent tariff on car parts will still be imposed on May 3, the report says.
US President Donald Trump’s trade conflicts with China and other countries loom as a question mark for Boeing, a major US exporter, despite Wednesday’s solid results.
The plight of Chinese exporters mean US consumers could face rising prices and shortages of crucial goods in the coming months.
The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.
Trump’s comments come as US stocks and Treasuries have been battered since he rolled out sweeping tariffs on Apr 2, later announcing a 90-day reprieve for most nations.

site_title: Minister for Finance appoints new Iras board chairman Lai Chung Han
summary: Lai Chung Han, a 52-year-old Singaporean, has been appointed chairman of the board of the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras), effective May 1. He replaces Tan Ching Yee, who served as chairman since 2016. Lai has held various leadership roles in the Singapore Armed Forces and Ministry of Defence, including deputy secretary (policy) and Chief of Navy. He received the Public Administration Medal (Gold) in 2022. Under Tan's leadership, Iras expanded its services and participated in international platforms, including the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development Forum on Tax Administration.

images.alt_text: GIRO is a payment method in Singapore that allows individuals and businesses to automate recurring payments directly from their bank accounts.
XXXXX

site_title: Employee at telehealth firm WhiteCoat suspected of falsifying genetic test reports for Vietnam client
summary: A Singapore-based telehealth firm, WhiteCoat, has acknowledged an "isolated case" of employee misconduct, where allegedly falsified genetic screening reports were sent to a corporate client in Vietnam. The reports were generated by an unauthorized external service provider and bore the name of a partner firm, Gene Solutions. WhiteCoat has launched an internal investigation and reported the matter to the Vietnamese authorities. The company claims there is no impact on the medical treatment and health of the individuals involved, and has taken steps to remedy the situation and strengthen its internal controls.

images.alt_text: WhiteCoat founder and chief executive Bryan Koh (pictured left) says the company "will be seeking funding at the right time" to fuel its next phase of growth.
Vietnam's Gene Solutions boasts a portfolio of more than 30 genetic testing products in the fields of obstetrics, paediatrics, and oncology.

site_title: Seven & i’s new CEO aims aggressive investments in US stores
summary: Seven & i Holdings' new CEO, Stephen Dacus, plans to boost investments in US stores using cash from a planned listing of its American retail operations, aiming to deliver greater value to customers and improve shareholder value. The company, which operates over 13,000 convenience stores in North America, is also reviewing its global supply chain and plans to undertake a $18 billion share buyback. Dacus aims to expand its quick-service restaurants and revamp the company's board, following a restructuring to boost growth and address weak investor returns.

images.alt_text: The 7-Eleven operator’s profit has fallen in recent quarters as domestic convenience store operations underperformed competitors and its North American arm suffered from lower consumer spending against a backdrop of accelerating inflation.
Seven & i has more than 13,000 locations in the US and Canada under a variety of brands, including franchises and stores operated under license.
Seven & i has said it is engaging with Couche-Tard, but a core concern is that US competition authorities will not give the deal the green light given the overlap in the companies’ businesses.
Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc.'s founder Alain Bouchard speaks during a press conference on their bid for 7-Eleven convenience store operator Seven & i Holdings in Tokyo, Japan, March 13, 2025.

site_title: Potential slight downgrade in Q1 GDP growth after March factory output expansion misses: economists
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 5.8% year-over-year in March, but missed economists' forecasts of an 8.1% expansion. The sector's performance may lead to a possible one percentage point downgrade in Q1 GDP growth to 4% and a revised Q1 GDP growth estimate of 3.6%. Economists predict the manufacturing outlook will weaken, especially in the second half of the year, due to US tariff uncertainties and a favorable base effect. The electronics cluster recovered strongly, while the precision engineering and chemicals clusters showed signs of softening.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Feburary's manufacturing output data missed economists' expectation of a 7 per cent expansion.

site_title: Trump sees trade deals coming in three to four weeks
summary: US President Donald Trump expects to finalize trade deals with US partners within the next three to four weeks, despite giving conflicting signals about talks with China. Trump defended his trade policies, which have unnerved financial markets, and said he would consider adjustments to tariffs with countries that ask for them. However, he also claimed to have spoken with Chinese President Xi Jinping, contradicting Beijing's denial of negotiations. Trump's comments come after he paused tariff increases on 60 countries for three months to allow for negotiations, sparking a flurry of visits from foreign delegations.

images.alt_text: “Other countries that have done it have lost a lot of people. They lose their wealthy people. That will be bad because the wealthy people pay the tax.” said US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Are Singapore’s supermarkets ‘tariff-proof’?
summary: Singapore's supermarkets may face an uncertain economic outlook, with analysts predicting a defensive play for investors despite US tariffs. Despite this, analysts believe that supermarkets will remain a stable option for consumers, with lower prices and wider product offerings. Tariffs are unlikely to impact product prices directly, but supermarkets will need to adapt to increasing price-conscious consumers. To counter this, supermarkets are expected to expand their in-house brands, which are typically cheaper than external brands, and continue offering more products at competitive pricing.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales dropped 6.7 per cent year on year, compared with January’s 5.1 per cent growth.
Fresh produce at a FairPrice supermarket marked with a price freeze label. 2025 marks the third year that the group is freezing prices on popular fresh produce.
DFI announced the sale of its Cold Storage and Giant stores a fortnight after it said its Singapore food business had turned profitable in Q4 2024
Macrovalue's owners Gary Yap (left) and Andrew Lim (right) with Cold Storage managing director Lim Boon Cheong (centre) at CS Fresh in Great World City.
Cold Storage, Giant sold to Malaysian group for S$125 million.
Despite returning to the black, DFI expects its supermarket revenue in Singapore to remain stable at best under heavy competition.

site_title: Suntec Reit sees subdued retail sales, expects office, retail tenants to hold off expansion plans
summary: Suntec Reit's office and retail tenants are expected to delay expansion plans due to uncertainty over US tariffs, with tenants becoming more cautious about the impact. The Reit's convention centre portfolio remains stable, with no signs of weakening. Despite this, Suntec Reit's office rental reversion is projected to be between 1-5% and retail between 5-10% for the upcoming quarter. The Reit's distribution per unit rose 3.4% to S$0.01563 for Q1, driven by better performance and lower financing costs.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Q1 gross revenue of Suntec Reit was up 3.4 per cent to S$113.5 million for the quarter, from S$109.8 million in the year-ago period.
Analysts expect Frasers Centrepoint Trust, which counts Northpoint City as its asset, to post a higher DPU in its upcoming financial results.
凯德雅诗阁信托在收购位于美国南卡罗来纳州的学生宿舍Standard at Columbia的剩余10%股权后，完全收购了这套房地产，有助于信托提高收入韧性。（凯德雅诗阁信托提供）
An artist impression of the downtown Mice hub. The new venue will cater to the rising demand for events and serve delegates' changing needs.

site_title: IMF reaches agreement with Sri Lanka on US$344m loan payout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reached an agreement with Sri Lanka on a US$344 million loan payout, bringing the total disbursed under the current programme to around US$1.7 billion. The loan will support Sri Lanka's economic reforms, which have delivered commendable outcomes, including a five per cent post-crisis growth rebound and substantial fiscal reforms. The agreement comes as Sri Lanka continues to implement a reform process initiated by the previous government, which involved cutting subsidies and raising taxes to stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: The United States is Sri Lanka’s largest single market, accounting for almost a quarter of its US$12 billion in merchandise exports.
A general view of the main port in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

This handout photograph taken on September 25, 2024, and released by Sri Lanka's President Office shows the country's newly elected President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, as he addresses the nation in Colombo. Sri Lanka's new president called on September 25, for restarting talks with the IMF "immediately" over a $2.9 billion bailout that threw a lifeline to his bankrupt country but imposed painful austerity.
