site_title: Singapore Airlines, OpenAI link up to build AI solutions to raise efficiency, customer service
summary: Singapore Airlines has partnered with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, to develop AI solutions to boost efficiency and customer service. The collaboration will create tools to interpret text, audio, and videos, enhancing the airline's customer experience and operational efficiency. The AI virtual assistant on SIA's website will be upgraded to provide more personalized customer service, automate routine processes, and enable staff to make informed decisions. This is OpenAI's first partnership with a major carrier and follows its announcement to open a Singapore office as its Asia-Pacific hub.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed miniature model of Elon Musk and ChatGPT logo are seen in this illustration taken, February 11, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Therese Soh
Globally, more than 250 million people use ChatGPT weekly.

site_title: HSBC launches wealth centre at Star Vista, seeks to deepen local wealth banking network
summary: HSBC has launched its second wealth centre in Singapore, located at The Star Vista mall, providing bespoke advisory services to clients in the west of the city. The centre is part of the bank's strategy to deepen its physical wealth banking network, with a third location slated to open by end-2025. The new centre features personalized services, accessibility features, and curated spaces, as HSBC aims to lead in wealth-management services in an increasingly affluent local population.

images.alt_text: OCBC last month launched what it styled as an “integrated lifestyle and banking branch” at Wisma Atria, along the Orchard Road shopping belt.
Wong Kee Joo (left), CEO for HSBC Singapore, and Ashmita Acharya (right), head of wealth and personal banking at HSBC Singapore.

site_title: London gets a taste of New York’s cut-throat real estate culture
summary: London's luxury real estate market is adopting a "cut-throat" culture similar to New York's, with Sotheby's International Realty offering larger earnings packets to top agents. The company has recruited over 50 selling agents in two years, including top brokers from rival firms Knight Frank and Savills. Sotheby's agents earn a 20% net fee on deals, doubling to 40% once they reach £500,000 in fees per year. This shift is seen as a response to a market slump, with some sellers offering discounts of up to 30% and fewer high-end deals.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Stoneweg European Reit secures lease renewals with Motorola and Coolblue
summary: Stoneweg European Reit (Sert) has secured lease renewals with Motorola Solutions and Coolblue BV, covering approximately 27,000 square meters of office space in Rotterdam and Krakow. Motorola extended its lease at the Green Office in Krakow by five years, while Coolblue signed a new lease for its headquarters in Rotterdam. The leases are valued at about 5.5 million euros in combined annual rent, with Sert's office portfolio occupancy rates steadying at around 90% and retention rate at 85% in 2024.

images.alt_text: A logistics complex in Tilburg in the Netherlands, which is in Stoneweg E-Reit's portfolio. The stapled entity will be known as Stoneweg European Stapled Trust and will comprise Stoneweg E-Reit and Stoneweg European Business Trust.

site_title: GE2025: Desmond Lee refutes PSP proposal for return to 7% GST, cites Singapore’s ageing population
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee has refuted the Progress Singapore Party's (PSP) proposal to revert the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 7%, citing the need for government revenue to support Singapore's ageing population. Lee emphasized the importance of the GST system being "easy to operationalise" and highlighted the need for targeted measures to support lower and middle-income households. He also discussed the government's plans to enhance housing affordability and address concerns on job security and cost of living.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

Speaking to reporters on Wednesday afternoon, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong explained the thinking behind the redeployments, noting that he moved DPM Gan Kim Yong to Punggol as it was “really not easy to find a senior officeholder of a similar stature” to take over from SM Teo Chee Hean.

site_title: Samsung to invest US$117 million in southern Indian facility
summary: Samsung Electronics is investing US$117.09 million in its southern Indian facility, adding 100 new jobs. The investment comes after a recent labour dispute at the plant, where workers staged a sit-in over employee suspensions in February. The company has maintained it is compliant with all applicable laws, and the investment "reinforces their faith in the labour force of Tamil Nadu state," according to the state's industries minister.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s decision to pump more money into its key chips sector is designed to help companies cope with heavier costs as they compete globally, it says.

site_title: Sri Lanka to begin talks with India, UAE for new energy hub
summary: Sri Lanka plans to develop an energy hub with India and the UAE, involving a multi-product pipeline, bunkering facilities, and potentially a refinery, to leverage its strategic location and aid recovery from a financial crisis. The project was signed during a visit by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and will be discussed in late May by representatives from state-run Ceylon Petroleum, Indian Oil, and AD Ports. The hub aims to cement Sri Lanka's position as a major energy hub in the region.

images.alt_text: The Proceeds of Crime Bill was passed unanimously in parliament, where the leftist government of President Anura Dissanayake enjoys a two-thirds majority after elections last year.

site_title: iFast Q1 net profit rises 31.2% to S$19 million on continued growth in UK bank, wealth management platform business
summary: iFast's Q1 net profit rose 31.2% to S$19 million, driven by a turnaround in its UK bank and continued growth in its wealth management platform business. Revenue gained 24.4% to S$106.9 million, and assets under administration reached a record high of S$25.7 billion. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.016 per share and expects healthy progress for its various business segments in 2025, barring unforeseen circumstances.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
iFast's Singapore office. The company's core wealth management platform is steadily advancing with record-high assets under administration, said DBS Group Research.

site_title: Citi picks Goldman Sachs’ Christopher Chan to head Asia-North and South markets solutions for financial institutions
summary: Citi appoints Christopher Chan as head of Asia-North and South markets solutions for financial institutions, effective July. Chan, a former Goldman Sachs banker, will drive strategy in providing bespoke hedging, financing, and investment solutions for Citi's clients. This is the latest in a series of appointments for Citi's markets business, following previous hires at JP Morgan. Chan brings over 10 years of experience in fixed income clearing and equity distribution from Goldman Sachs and other banking roles.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: China’s Baidu says its Kunlun chip cluster can train DeepSeek-like models
summary: China's Baidu has successfully "illuminated" a 30,000-kunlun chip cluster, supporting the training of DeepSeek-like models with hundreds of billions of parameters. CEO Robin Li announced the development at the company's developer conference, highlighting the cluster's potential for fine-tuning models with billions of parameters simultaneously. Baidu also unveiled its latest AI model, Ernie 4.5 Turbo, which matched industry benchmarks in coding and linguistic comprehension, and launched a new reasoning model, Ernie X1 Turbo. The development comes amid heightened competition in China's AI market, where Baidu seeks to regain traction after its Ernie Bot struggled to gain traction.

images.alt_text: Baidu sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
Baidu’s reasoning model excels in areas such as daily dialogs, complex calculations and logical deduction, it says in a statement on Sunday.
Baidu has become just the latest in a string of companies making the most of a rally in Chinese stocks to raise cash.
Baidu aims to raise as much as 10 billion yuan in the sale.
The financings come at a time when major industry players on both sides of the Pacific have rolled out artificial intelligence models at a rapid clip, from OpenAI to Alibaba.

site_title: China’s investments in South-east Asia snarl US plans on supply chains
summary: China's investments in South-east Asia have surged, contributing to a growing US trade deficit in the region. According to a report by Rhodium Group, Chinese firms announced $10 billion in new manufacturing investments in 2024, more than double the official data from the Association of South-east Asian Nations. This increase is driven by China's economic ties with the region, including free-trade deals and efforts to avoid US tariffs. The US is preparing to press nations to curb trade with China, but China has warned of "reciprocal countermeasures" if its interests are undermined.

images.alt_text: European food and beverage (F&B), automotive, as well as machinery and industrial equipment manufacturers are more likely to seek opportunities in the region, as they are hardest hit by Trump's tariffs.

site_title: We may have already hit peak booze
summary: Alcohol consumption has reached a possible permanent decline, with global per-capita drinking falling from 5 litres in 2013 to 3.9 litres in 2023, according to market research firm IWSR. The decline is attributed to demographic shifts, increasing availability of non-alcoholic alternatives, and the COVID-19 pandemic's focus on health. The world's population is projected to reach 10.3 billion by the 2080s, but the hardest-drinking regions, such as Africa and South-east Asia, may not provide a significant boost to the industry. If consumption falls to 3.1 litres per adult per year, it will mark a monumental moment for humanity, potentially ending the long association between alcohol and civilization.

images.alt_text: Sales in China remain below pre-Covid-19 levels, despite a rebound since the pandemic.

site_title: Ossia CEO sold rare Pagani supercar to Ng Yu Zhi for S$7.3 million and invested over S$20 million in billion-dollar nickel scheme
summary: Ossia International CEO Steven Goh Ching Huat sold a rare Pagani Huayra Coupe to alleged scammer Ng Yu Zhi for S$7.3 million in 2020. Goh also invested over S$20 million in Ng's billion-dollar nickel trading scheme, losing S$11 million. The car is listed as one of Ng's assets in two money laundering charges. Goh testified in Ng's trial, stating he had sold the car at a higher price than his purchase price, but did not know about Ng's attempt to become Pagani's distributor in Singapore and Malaysia.

images.alt_text:
Finian Tan at the Supreme Court, on April 4, 2025.
Well-known venture capitalist Finian Tan told the High Court on April 3 that he was impressed by alleged fraudster Ng Yu Zhi, who was introduced to him as a successful nickel trader when they first met in August 2020.
He was taking the stand in the ongoing trial of Ng, 37, who is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted $1.45 billion from hundreds of investors over six years.
Ng is accused of cheating Dr Tan by getting him to deliver US$19.2 million (S$25.7 million) in fresh funds to Ng’s company, Envy Global Trading (EGT).
Ng faces 108 charges over offences including cheating, forgery, criminal breach of trust, money laundering and fraudulent trading.
Ng Yu Zhi is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted S$1.46 billion from 947 investors over six years.
Prosecutors alleged that Ng Yu Zhi’s Ponzi scheme, which promised attractive profits from nickel trading, was “pure fiction” that duped 947 investors of almost $1.5 billion.

Investigations show that Envysion's former chief executive officer and directors did not put in place appropriate risk management framework for a fund related to a nickel trading fraud case, says MAS.

site_title: IMF cuts Singapore’s GDP growth forecast for 2025 on tariff shock
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its GDP growth forecast for Singapore to 2% for 2025, citing the region's exposure to the US tariff hit and uncertainty from the fallout. This is a reduction from its previous forecast of 2.5% in October 2024. The IMF also lowered its forecast for the Asia-Pacific region to 3.9% for 2025, down from 4.6% in 2024, citing lower external demand and a soft tech cycle.

images.alt_text: The IMF projects global growth in 2025 will slow to 2.8 per cent – its poorest showing since the Covid-19 pandemic – from 3.3 per cent in 2024.

site_title: DBS downgrades Keppel Infrastructure Trust to ‘hold’, keeps Mapletree Logistics Trust at ‘buy’
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) to 'hold' and Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) to 'hold', with lowered target prices to S$1.55 for MLT and S$0.45 for KIT. Despite MLT's Q4 distribution per unit falling 11.6% to S$0.01955, analysts say it was anticipated by the market. KIT's leverage is at 40.7%, and analysts express concerns over the trust's ability to generate stable cash flows. However, they note that MLT's exposure to domestic demand and defensive sector exposure minimizes the impact of tariffs.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
The Mapletree logo on the facade of the Mapletree Business City building on 26 April 2021.
The trust manager did note that Q1 distributable income will decrease by 31.9 per cent on the year to S$45.4 million, after adjusting for one-off costs.

site_title: Indonesia wants ‘fair and square’ trade in US tariff talks
summary: Indonesia has proposed a "fair and square" trade relationship with the US, offering to increase imports from the US by up to $19 billion and reduce non-tariff barriers. The country also proposed tax cuts for US goods and has proposed reducing orders from other countries. Indonesia's delegation, led by Airlangga Hartarto and Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has been negotiating with US officials and businesses, aiming to strengthen bilateral relations. The proposal aims to avoid a "zero sum game" and promote mutual benefits, with Indonesia seeking to buy other products from countries affected by US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s financial markets have been hit by capital outflows since the US announcement of reciprocal tariffs in early April.
Indonesia has proposed increasing its imports from the US by up to US$19 billion, including around US$10 billion of energy imports.

site_title: GE2025: WP says to measure its candidates against PAP backbenchers, not ministers
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh said voters should compare the party's slate of candidates to the ruling People's Action Party's (PAP) backbenchers, not ministers, in the upcoming General Election (GE2025). Singh argued that this comparison is fair because the WP is not seeking to govern. He emphasized that the WP has a serious slate of candidates, and voters should carefully consider their choices. In contrast, PAP Prime Minister Lawrence Wong urged voters to apply the same standards to the opposition as they do to the PAP, highlighting the differing opinions on the evolution of the political system.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
“The reality is this: when you have an opposition in parliament, your alternative voice, your views are heard by the government,” said party secretary-general Pritam Singh.

In his speech, PM Lawrence Wong promised to continue to manage Singapore’s economy well and harness its resources effectively to stay ahead of changes.
Contrary to expectations, Senior Counsel Harpreet Singh (centre) was fielded in newly-formed Punggol GRC, with fellow newcomers (from left) Siti Alia, Alexis Dang, and Jackson Au.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda keeps rate-hike pledge but warns of US tariff impact
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda pledged to continue raising interest rates if Japan's underlying inflation converges to its 2% target, but warned of the potential economic impact of US tariffs. Ueda stated that tariffs affect trade activity, business sentiment, and market volatility, and will scrutinize this data when setting monetary policy. The BOJ is expected to keep interest rates steady at 0.5% and downgrade its growth forecasts at its next policy meeting, citing US tariffs as a major concern.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda speaks during a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on January 24, 2025. The Bank of Japan increased interest rates on January 24 to their highest in 17 years and signalled more hikes to come, sending the yen higher against the dollar. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
“US tariffs will likely put downward pressure on global and Japanese economies through various channels,” Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said on Monday.

The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its monetary policy settings steady as it bides its time for now, while a dissenter's proposed rate hike suggests momentum for another increase is building. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

Aside from the direct impact on global trade, Donald Trump’s tariffs, set at 24 per cent for Japanese goods, could affect corporate sentiment and market moves by heightening uncertainty over the economic outlook, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said.

site_title: GE2025: Candidates rebut rally comments on Day 3, with political broadcasts to come
summary: Singapore is gearing up for the 2025 General Election, with candidates from various parties participating in rallies and walkabouts. The People's Action Party (PAP) and Workers' Party (WP) teams are set to appear on national television and radio, with the first round of political broadcasts scheduled for tonight. The PAP has fielded candidates in every constituency, while the WP is focusing on backbenchers. Other parties, including the Progress Singapore Party, Singapore Democratic Party, and People's Alliance for Reform, are also participating in the election.

images.alt_text: GE2025: Singapore can return to ‘the road to democracy’ started in 2011: SDP’s Paul Tambyah
In his speech, PM Lawrence Wong promised to continue to manage Singapore’s economy well and harness its resources effectively to stay ahead of changes.
“The reality is this: when you have an opposition in parliament, your alternative voice, your views are heard by the government,” said party secretary-general Pritam Singh.

site_title: Southwest CEO says US airline industry is already in a recession
summary: Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan says the US airline industry is already in a recession due to a decline in domestic leisure travel demand. The company expects a 6% drop in second-quarter revenue, following a 3-point decline in the first quarter. Jordan attributes the decline to economic uncertainty, which causes consumers to pull back on spending. As the airline industry is heavily reliant on domestic leisure travel, this vulnerability makes it difficult to accurately forecast travel demand and pricing for the rest of 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO-An aircraft of the national flag carrier Vietnam Airlines taxis at Noi Bai airport in Hanoi, Vietnam December 23, 2020. Picture taken December 23, 2020. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Air India’s growth is also set to slow because of a retrofit programme that will temporarily remove some jets from its fleet, and a plan to phase out some Airbus models.
Malaysia Airlines has struggled to recover from two deadly disasters in 2014.
The Chinese maker’s C919 is a single-aisle jet designed to compete with the Airbus A320 and Boeing 737 families and has a capacity for 158 to 192 passengers.

site_title: China waives tariffs on some US goods, but denies Trump’s claim that talks are underway
summary: China has waived tariffs on some US goods, allowing US-made pharmaceuticals to enter the country without paying 125% duties. A list of 131 product categories under consideration for exemptions circulated among businesses and trade groups, including vaccines, chemicals, and jet engines. China denied US President Donald Trump's claim that talks are underway, contradicting Trump's statement that Chinese President Xi Jinping had called him. The move is seen as a sign that the trade war between the two economies may be easing, but analysts warn that tariffs could lead to higher prices for US consumers and increase the risk of recession.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has said it would crackdown on fraudulent rules of origin as part of its fight against goods labelled as Vietnamese products.
The world’s two leading economies are locked in an escalating tit-for-tat trade battle triggered by Trump’s new levies on Chinese goods, which have reached 145 per cent on many products.
A 25 per cent tariff on all imports of foreign-made cars would remain in place and a 25 per cent tariff on car parts will still be imposed on May 3, the report says.
Scott Bessent says talks with other countries were continuing, and that a deal with India was “very close”.

site_title: Malaysia open to negotiate with US on reducing trade deficit, non-tariff barriers
summary: Malaysia is open to negotiating with the US to reduce its trade deficit and address non-tariff barriers. The country has avoided retaliatory action against the US despite facing a 24% tariff rate in July for its goods exported to the US. Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz met with US officials to discuss key issues and ensure mutually beneficial trade flows between the two countries. Malaysia is willing to explore alternative solutions and a bilateral trade agreement to address US concerns.

images.alt_text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased to 134.1 points in March, up from 132.2 points in the same month last year.
The negative sentiment triggered 26 consecutive weeks of foreign outflows since last November, pulling the FBM KLCI down 7.3 per cent to 1,513.65 in the first quarter of 2025.

Malaysia's Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz says: “Negotiation takes time, right? So, it is more to talk about how Malaysia can play an important role in the supply chain between Asia and the US.”

site_title: Hongkong Land to sell 147,025 sq ft of One Exchange to HKEX, launch share buyback programme
summary: Hongkong Land is selling 147,025 sq ft of One Exchange Square to Hong Kong's stock exchange operator, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX), for HK$6.3 billion (S$1.1 billion). The sale proceeds will be used to fund enhancements to the space, debt reduction, and a share buyback programme worth US$200 million. The share buyback programme will run until Dec 31, 2025, returning capital to shareholders and reducing the group's share capital.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The group's revenue for FY2024 is US$2 billion, up from US$1.8 billion a year ago.

site_title: South-east Asia’s economic powerhouses seek talks with US to defuse tariff tensions
summary: Indonesia and Malaysia are seeking talks with the US to address rising trade tensions and avoid punitive tariffs on their key exports. The two South-east Asian nations have engaged in high-level talks with US counterparts, proposing solutions such as boosting US investments in critical minerals and streamlining import processes. Indonesia faces a 32% duty rate and Malaysia a 24% duty rate, which could hinder trade flows if not addressed. The US has offered a 90-day reprieve, and both countries have reaffirmed their willingness to work together to find a mutually beneficial resolution.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Elisa Valenta

In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.

site_title: MPACT struggles with leasing demand, cost of debt as Q4 DPU tumbles 14.8%
summary: MPACT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, reported a 14.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter ended March, due to slow leasing demand and higher debt costs. China remains a challenging market for the trust, with its committed portfolio occupancy rate falling to 89.6% from 96.1% in the previous year. The trust's manager attributed the decline to tenants being more cost-conscious and decision-making slowing down.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Chloe Lim
Gross revenue was down 7.4 per cent to S$223.7 million for the quarter, from S$241.6 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: JD.com’s delivery clash with Meituan may worsen US$70 billion rout
summary: JD.com and Meituan, two of China's largest internet companies, are engaged in a costly battle for market share in the food-delivery market. JD.com has launched a strategy to steal Meituan's market share, while Meituan has expanded into overseas food delivery through its Keeta app. The companies' Hong Kong-listed stocks have dropped 30% each, shedding around $70 billion in combined market value. Analysts predict a prolonged struggle that will hurt earnings for both companies, with some estimating that JD.com's food delivery platform could generate annualized losses of up to $3.2 billion.

images.alt_text: JD is pushing beyond online retailing to challenge Meituan in the lucrative food delivery market of the country of 1.4 billion people.
FILE PHOTO: JD.com logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 11, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
JD’s results follow Alibaba’s better-than-anticipated numbers last month, underpinning a more buoyant mood among Chinese tech companies after Beijing signalled renewed support for the private sector.
Now available in over three dozen cities in China, JD Takeaway is offering zero commission for some restaurants as it seeks to lure business.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, MPACT, Sats, Suntec Reit, OUE Reit, Clint
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 0.8% drop in net property income for Q1 FY2025, to S$291.5 million, due to the absence of income from 21 Collyer Quay. Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) posted a 14.8% decline in Q4 DPU to S$0.0195, with revenue and NPI falling 6.8% and 7.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of SATS logo on July 10, 2024.
Q1 gross revenue of Suntec Reit was up 3.4 per cent to S$113.5 million for the quarter, from S$109.8 million in the year-ago period.

The impact of US tariffs on the Indian economy could be beneficial in the medium term, the manager of CLINT said.

site_title: US bank regulators pull back guardrails on bank crypto activities
summary: US banking regulators have withdrawn guidance urging banks to exercise caution when engaging in cryptocurrency and related activities. The move marks the latest effort by the Trump administration to strike a more crypto-friendly stance. The Federal Reserve, along with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, are reviewing whether new guidance will support innovation in the crypto space. This decision comes after the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency also scrapped guidance on cautious engagement with crypto activities in March.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust NPI slips 0.8% on lower revenue
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 0.8% decline in net property income (NPI) to S$291.5 million for Q1 FY2025, due to the absence of income from the divested 21 Collyer Quay office building. Assuming no income from this property, CICT's revenue would have been 1.1% higher and NPI would have grown 1.4%. Despite this, the trust's portfolio occupancy remained healthy at 96.4% and its weighted average lease expiry was stable.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
By the time CICT completed the preferential offering to support its acquisition of Ion Orchard, the 10-year Treasury bond yield was beginning to shoot back up

site_title: US: S&P 500 edges higher with trade negotiations, earnings in focus
summary: The S&P 500 edged higher at the open on Thursday, April 24, due to mixed corporate results and developments in the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19% to 39,531.05, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.28% to 16,754.756. Investors are closely watching US-China trade negotiations and corporate earnings reports.

site_title: China warns G20 global economic growth ‘insufficient’, trade tensions weaken momentum
summary: China has warned that global economic growth is "insufficient" due to trade tensions and tariff disputes, calling for strengthened multilateral cooperation. At a G20 meeting in Washington, Finance Minister Lan Foan urged parties to settle disputes on an equal footing, while People's Bank of China governor Pan Gongsheng said economic fragmentation and trade tensions have disrupted supply chains. The US has raised tariffs on imports, prompting the International Monetary Fund to cut its growth forecasts for most countries.

images.alt_text: Given the stakes, the most effective way to restore global growth prospects would be for the US to reverse course and reassure the international community that the change is both genuine and lasting.
The IMF projects global growth in 2025 will slow to 2.8 per cent – its poorest showing since the Covid-19 pandemic – from 3.3 per cent in 2024.
Rebeca Grynspan, head of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, noted that the current uncertainty was weighing down the global economy.

site_title: HDB Q1 resale price growth slows to 1.6% on higher housing supply
summary: The pace of growth in Singapore's resale prices of public housing flats slowed to 1.6% in Q1 2025, the lowest since Q1 2024, due to a higher supply of units. Transaction volumes rose 2.6% to 6,590 units, but year-on-year, they decreased 6.8%. The slower growth is attributed to a higher supply of flats through public housing exercises and policy changes, such as the largest Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercise in February. Despite this, analysts expect prices to remain stable and moderate growth in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

Singapore’s public housing market is well-positioned to achieve a better equilibrium between demand and supply, with price increases expected to be moderated by the upcoming influx of supply and caution among buyers.
Generic photo of Singapore property landscape

site_title: Nomura weighs deeper foray into prime brokerage four years after Archegos
summary: Nomura Holdings is considering a deeper foray into prime brokerage four years after exiting the business following the Archegos implosion. The firm has hired Matias Bercun, a 17-year veteran of Barclays, to run the prime brokerage business globally. Nomura aims to generate over $1 billion in annual revenue from the business, more than three times its current earnings. This move is part of the firm's efforts to deepen its foothold in traditional Wall Street businesses, which have been buoyed by resurgent markets in Japan.

images.alt_text: Nomura will acquire all relevant assets, investment teams and operating platforms.
While Nomura’s struggles in China are shared by other global firms that have had to temper their initial exuberance, its prior losses have exceeded many of them.
Nomura has been on the hunt for new offices in Manhattan with plans to downsize its footprint.

Japan’s financial institutions have sought to develop their asset and wealth management businesses to generate income from the mammoth savings held by Japanese households, of which around half is currently held in cash and deposits.

site_title: Gold set for third straight weekly gain; US-China trade talks in focus
summary: Gold prices rose for a third consecutive week, reaching a record high of US$3,500.05 per ounce on Tuesday due to concerns over the US economy. Investors closely monitored US-China trade talks, with US President Donald Trump backing down from threats to fire the Federal Reserve chair. Despite this, spot gold firmed 0.2% to US$3,354.29 an ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.5% to US$3,365.90.

images.alt_text: Gold hit a record high of US$3,500.05 on Tuesday.

site_title: Google says will buy back US$70 billion in shares, posts earnings beat
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet, reported a first-quarter profit above Wall Street expectations, driven by steady growth in its digital advertising business. The company announced plans to buy back $70 billion in shares, boosting its market value. Revenue from Google's mainstay ad business rose 8.5% to $66.89 billion, beating analysts' expectations. Despite US President Donald Trump's trade policy triggering economic worries, Alphabet's results showed demand for digital ads remains robust, with shares of rival ad sellers also rising.

images.alt_text: Splitting up Google’s ad business won’t cripple the company.
The amount of money that Google pays to Samsung was not revealed in court.
The US Department of Justice is heading into trial after two major legal victories against Google, having won a ruling in August that Google monopolised search.
Google on Thursday laid off hundreds of employees in its platforms and devices unit, which works on Android software, Pixel phones and the Chrome browser.

site_title: GE2025: Singapore can return to ‘the road to democracy’ started in 2011: SDP’s Paul Tambyah
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) is urging voters to send a signal to the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) by voting for SDP, with the goal of allowing Singapore to "go back on the road to democracy" started in 2011. SDP chairman Paul Tambyah believes that with a stronger opposition presence, PAP MPs will work harder in Parliament, while opposition MPs will be able to block harmful legislation. The party's manifesto promises to tackle issues such as cost of living, healthcare costs, and housing affordability, and promises to reverse cost increases caused by the PAP, including lowering the GST rate.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
In his speech, PM Lawrence Wong promised to continue to manage Singapore’s economy well and harness its resources effectively to stay ahead of changes.
PSP chairman Dr Tan Cheng Bock (second from right) at Thursday's (Apr 24) rally.
“The reality is this: when you have an opposition in parliament, your alternative voice, your views are heard by the government,” said party secretary-general Pritam Singh.

site_title: GE2025: With MNCs wavering on whether to stay, Singapore needs a good team: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned that the country needs a good team to manage its economy well amidst the impact of US tariffs on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals. The US tariffs, threatened by President Donald Trump, may last for years and have a huge impact on the economy. Wong emphasized the importance of a good team to tackle the crisis, citing key ministers and praising their dedication. He also urged voters to remember that the real contest is not between the PAP and opposition, but between Singapore and the world.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
PSP chairman Dr Tan Cheng Bock (second from right) at Thursday's (Apr 24) rally.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says that while GE2025 is not the first general election amid challenging circumstances, with pandemic-era GE2020 being similar, today’s challenges are more severe.

site_title: Japan to resist Trump efforts to form trade bloc against China
summary: Japan is resisting US efforts to form a trade bloc against China, prioritizing its trade ties with Beijing. Despite US President Donald Trump's plans to bring countries together to maximize trade pressure on China, Japan is focusing on bilateral trade agreements with the US to address concerns over autos and agriculture. Japan is also trying to get China to resume imports of seafood and beef from Japan after health concerns led to bans. The country aims to finalize a deal before the current 90-day tariff reprieve expires in June, but may prioritize its own economic interests if the US seeks to curb economic ties with China.

images.alt_text: The data comes ahead of the BOJ policy meeting on Apr 30 to May 1, where the central bank is widely expected to keep short-term rates steady at 0.5 per cent.
Providing some support for a fragile economic recovery, the au Jibun Bank flash services PMI expanded to 52.2 in April, improving from 50 in March.
Price gains are still high by Japan’s standards after more than a decade of deflation.
US trade tariffs are shaking up Japan’s industrial supply chains, particularly for automobiles, the country’s biggest export item.

site_title: Old-school tempura at Ensei
summary: Tempura Ensei, a new Japanese restaurant in Singapore, offers high-priced fare with mixed results. Despite its promise of fine-dining quality and a hinoki-counter experience, the meal falls short, with overpriced and underwhelming dishes. The tempura batter is mostly light and floppy, with some satisfying crunch, but the real test of the dish is the execution, which falls short. The restaurant's prices, ranging from S$188 to S$288, are comparable to its competitors, but the quality does not justify the cost. Overall, the experience is akin to dining at a Tokyo shopping mall eatery.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio’s challenges bleed into its bond prices
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio is facing financial challenges, with its bond prices rising despite concerns over its financial health. The company's shares have declined 10% since January, and its expansion strategy in Europe is being recalibrated due to increasing competition. Nio has raised funds from external investors, including a recent HK$4 billion equity placement, but analysts say there is no clear positive earnings catalyst, and the debt repayment risk for its convertible bonds will intensify. The company's struggles highlight the intense competition in China's EV market, where BYD and Tesla also operate.

images.alt_text: A NIO EL8 electric vehicle at a showroom in Berlin, Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
Nio plans to seek more local partners to expand in Europe and will announce some deal signings with European partners during the show, Nio CEO William Li says.

In January, the company said it delivered a record 72,689 vehicles in Q4, with full-year delivery at 221,970.

site_title: Footwear brand Skechers pulls annual forecast on trade uncertainty, shares drop
summary: Skechers withdraws annual forecast due to trade uncertainty, shares drop 7% in extended trading. The company cites the Trump administration's erratic trade policies and tariffs on Chinese goods as a major factor. China production accounts for nearly 38% of US sales, and higher levies are expected to push up input costs and result in price increases for American consumers. Skechers also misses first-quarter sales estimates, with China sales sliding 16% in the quarter. The company plans to minimize production in "high-cost locations" and diversify its sourcing base.

images.alt_text: Nike works with over 100 apparel factories, footwear plants and equipment makers in Vietnam, the company has disclosed.

site_title: Vietnam ramps up bond sales, spending as export-led growth faces tariff risks
summary: Vietnam has increased government bond sales by nearly 30% this year, aiming to boost public spending and shield the economy from US tariffs, which could reduce growth by up to 3 percentage points. The country plans to raise 500 trillion dong (around 4% of GDP) in financing this year, with funds earmarked for infrastructure and domestic consumption. Vietnam has also kicked off trade talks with the US to persuade Washington to reduce or eliminate the new tariffs, which have been paused until July.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Hai Phong International Container Terminal, after U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause on tariffs for many countries, in Hai Phong, Vietnam, April 16, 2025. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Vietnam has repeatedly vowed to purchase more American goods such as LNG and aircraft, while offering to remove all tariffs on US imports.
Vietnam has no free trade deal with the United States.

Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh reiterated that Vietnamese goods do not compete with those of the US and that “bilateral trade relations so far have ultimately benefited US consumers while driving Vietnam’s export growth.”

site_title: GE2025: ‘Real pressure’ on PAP to act with opposition in Parliament, says WP’s Pritam Singh
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party (WP) candidates have urged voters to support capable MPs in the 2025 general election, emphasizing the importance of having alternative voices in Parliament to hold the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) accountable. WP Secretary-General Pritam Singh stated that the PAP faces "real pressure" to act if the opposition's views are shared by the majority of Singaporeans. The WP aims to bring a more rational and credible alternative to the PAP, with candidates vowing to provide checks and balances to prevent the PAP from taking away the dignity and self-respect of all Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
PSP chairman Dr Tan Cheng Bock (second from right) at Thursday's (Apr 24) rally.

site_title: Office rents in Singapore’s central region up 0.3% qoq in Q1 2025: URA
summary: Singapore's office rents rose 0.3% in Q1 2025, driven by occupiers renewing leases and some "flight-to-quality" movement amid economic uncertainties. The islandwide office vacancy rate increased to 11.7% as of Q1 2025, up from 10.6% at end-Q4 2024. The amount of available office space expanded by 1.05 million sq ft NLA, contrasting with a 10,764 sq ft decrease in occupied space. Retail rents fell 0.5% in Q1 2025, with the islandwide vacancy rate rising to 6.8% from 6.2% at end-Q4 2024.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Presently, landlords continue to prioritise building occupancies in a time of uncertainty that has been amplified by global tariffs.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse operator to shift headquarters in US$812 million deal
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) has agreed to a US$812 million deal to shift its headquarters to a new office in the same retail center in Hong Kong's core business district. The deal includes taking over the top nine floors of a building owned by Hongkong Land, with long-term cost savings expected. Hongkong Land also agreed to enhance the space for up to HK$400 million. The deal will be financed via proceeds from the transaction and other capital recycling activities.

site_title: Core inflation in Japan’s capital sharply accelerates in April
summary: Japan's core consumer prices in Tokyo rose 3.4% in April, the second straight month, surpassing a median market forecast of 3.2%. The increase, driven by price hikes for food and reduced government subsidies, complicates the Bank of Japan's decision on short-term rates ahead of its policy meeting on April 30. This accelerates the central bank's task of balancing risks from US tariffs and rising prices, potentially leading to a rate hike. The Tokyo core CPI has not exceeded 3% since July 2023.

images.alt_text: Providing some support for a fragile economic recovery, the au Jibun Bank flash services PMI expanded to 52.2 in April, improving from 50 in March.
Price gains are still high by Japan’s standards after more than a decade of deflation.
US trade tariffs are shaking up Japan’s industrial supply chains, particularly for automobiles, the country’s biggest export item.

Tourists walk past shops and restaurants up the hill leading to Kiyomizu-dera Temple in the city of Kyoto on January 13, 2025. Japan on January 15 will announce tourist figures for the year 2024, widely expected to break the record set in 2019. (Photo by PAUL MILLER / AFP)

site_title: Oil prices settle up on weaker US dollar, mixed economic news
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% to $66.55 a barrel as investors weighed a weaker US dollar and mixed economic news. Brent crude futures increased 43 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 52 US cents. A weaker US dollar makes dollar-priced commodities like oil less expensive for buyers using other currencies. Supply uncertainty, including potential Opec+ output increases and the Russia-Ukraine war, also influenced prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$1.32, or 1.96 per cent, at US$66.12 a barrel,

site_title: Why American tech stocks are newly vulnerable
summary: US tech stocks, including Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla, are vulnerable due to recent market turbulence. Their value is largely based on future earnings, making them sensitive to shocks. The VIX index, a measure of expected volatility, has fallen to a level last seen in 2022, indicating investors are preparing for a drawn-out slump. Since a peak in December, the share prices of these tech giants have fallen by 27%, with Tesla experiencing the largest decline. High valuations and the increasing costs of capital for these companies, which rely on technological innovation, further exacerbate their vulnerability.

images.alt_text: Fewer Chinese companies have listed in the US since Didi Global’s ill-fated share sale in 2021.

site_title: OUE Reit posts 11.9% fall in Q1 revenue to S$66 million
summary: OUE Reit's Q1 revenue fell 11.9% to S$66 million due to divestment of Lippo Plaza in Shanghai and lower hospitality segment contributions. Net property income declined 12.1% to S$53.2 million. The commercial segment saw a 2.2% increase in revenue and 32.3% in NPI, while hospitality revenue fell 13.3% and NPI declined 12.5%. Despite a cautious outlook, the manager expects retail rents to recover to pre-pandemic levels by 2025.
