site_title: Renault to cut costs as US tariffs lash car market
summary: French carmaker Renault plans to further cut costs amid US tariffs, despite maintaining its 2025 gross operating margin guidance of over 7%. The company reported a 2.9% increase in vehicles sold in the first quarter to 564,980, but revenue dipped 0.3% to 11.7 billion euros. Renault's cost reduction measures aim to enhance competitiveness in a volatile global car market.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor incoming Chief Executive Officer Ivan Espinosa wants to cut development for the first car in a family of cars to 37 months, while the second car or third car would take just 30 months.

site_title: Meta lays off more than 100 employees across Reality Labs unit
summary: Meta Platforms is laying off more than 100 employees across its Reality Labs division, focusing on virtual reality and wearable devices. The layoffs aim to streamline similar work across two teams within Reality Labs, with impacted staff eligible to apply for new roles. The move follows earlier job cuts, including a 5% reduction of about 3,600 staff in April, and affects Reality Labs staff working on VR experiences and hardware operations, including the Supernatural VR fitness app.

images.alt_text: Prior to her appointment, Tan led Meta’s operations in Malaysia for nine years.
Meta is applying AI across all of its businesses – an effort that affects how Instagram and Facebook target users with ads, and how content is ordered in people’s feeds.
Dan Neary, Meta’s vice-president for the region, assumed the role in 2013 and oversaw the rapid expansion of the company’s user base from Australia to Greater China and South-east Asia.

site_title: How one man made nude art possible in Singapore
summary: A tribute to Solamalay Namasivayam, also known as "Nama," is being held at Yeo Workshop in Singapore. Nama was a Colombo Plan scholar, art teacher, and founding member of Group 90 who fought to include life drawing in the local art syllabus, despite it being considered "indecent" at the time. His efforts led to life drawing being introduced at Lasalle College of the Arts in 1987. The exhibition "Points of Articulation" showcases Nama's figure studies and is accompanied by a 280-page monograph.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Portraits of artists who transcended their outsider status, showcased at National Gallery Singapore.

site_title: China’s central bank chief warns trade frictions threaten trust in world economy
summary: China's central bank governor Pan Gongsheng warned that trade frictions threaten trust in the world economy, urging countries to cooperate and prevent economic downturns. Pan stated that there are "no winners in trade wars" and China will remain open to the outside world, supporting free trade and the multilateral trading system. This comes as US President Donald Trump signals a shift towards de-escalating tensions, despite previously hiking tariffs on Chinese imports.

images.alt_text: The plight of Chinese exporters mean US consumers could face rising prices and shortages of crucial goods in the coming months.
The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.
That de-escalation will come in the very near future, Bessent says.
The latest round of issuance comes as Beijing looks to ramp up spending to defend the economy from the onslaught of 145 per cent US tariffs on Chinese goods.
A string of global investment banks have lowered their projections for China’s economic growth this year and expected more monetary easing measures to underpin the economy.
Chinese demand has been shored up by a pilot programme that allows insurance funds to invest in gold, as part of efforts to optimise their asset allocations.
The PBOC has been pushing for lower borrowing costs for businesses and households.

site_title: Trump’s tariff chaos could reverse 80 years of economic progress
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies, including tariffs, are threatening eight decades of economic progress, according to experts. Trump's erratic approach has created widespread uncertainty, with tariffs on Chinese imports raised to 145%, and on almost every country in the world. This chaos could lead to a fragmented world economy, slower growth, and greater instability. The US needs to reverse course and reassure the international community that the change is genuine and lasting to restore global growth prospects. Alternatively, other countries can form a new trade alliance to uphold WTO principles and reduce America's bargaining power.

images.alt_text: European food and beverage (F&B), automotive, as well as machinery and industrial equipment manufacturers are more likely to seek opportunities in the region, as they are hardest hit by Trump's tariffs.
Vietnam has repeatedly vowed to purchase more American goods such as LNG and aircraft, while offering to remove all tariffs on US imports.
A 25 per cent tariff on all imports of foreign-made cars would remain in place and a 25 per cent tariff on car parts will still be imposed on May 3, the report says.

site_title: US existing home sales fall more than expected in March
summary: US existing home sales fell 5.9% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.02 million units, exceeding expectations. Higher borrowing costs and growing concerns of an economic slowdown due to tariffs on imports are contributing to the decline. Existing home inventory increased 8.1% to 1.33 million units, and the median price rose 2.7% to $403,700. A four-to-seven-month supply of existing homes is considered a healthy balance between supply and demand.

images.alt_text: New home sales jumped 7.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 724,000 units last month, the highest level since September 2024.
Higher rates risk stifling sales during the typically busy spring market as broader economic uncertainty weighs on buyers.
New residential construction decreased 11.4 per cent to an annualised rate of 1.32 million last month, restrained largely by single-family homes.
Construction sites are photographed in Frankfurt, Germany, July 19, 2023. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/Files
A gauge of overall conditions from the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) and Wells Fargo rose one point to 40 in April, hovering near some of the lowest levels since late 2023.

site_title: GE2025: Danger of ‘inbreeding’ in PAP’s candidate selection process, says PSP’s Tan Cheng Bock
summary: Progress Singapore Party (PSP) chairman Dr. Tan Cheng Bock warned that the People's Action Party's (PAP) reliance on civil servants in its candidate selection process could lead to "group-thinking" and "inbreeding" in the party's decision-making. PSP is contesting 13 seats in GE2025, with Dr. Tan leading a team in the West Coast-Jurong West GRC, a rematch of his 2020 bid. The PSP has criticized the PAP's governance and the first-past-the-post system, with secretary-general Leong Mun Wai and NCMP Hazel Poa highlighting issues such as police data misuse and the dominance of the ruling party in the Group Representation Constituency model.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
PSP's West Coast-Jurong West team greeting a resident. From left: Leong Mun Wai, Sumarleki Amjah, Tan Cheng Bock, Sani Ismail and Hazel Poa.
The Progress Singapore Party's West Coast-Jurong West GRC team on nomination day at Nan Hua High.
PSP chairman Tan Cheng Bock leads the party's West Coast-Jurong West GRC team.
PM Lawrence Wong (front) leads the PAP's team for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC, which comprises Senior Minister of State for Defence and Manpower Zaqy Mohamad, Alex Yam, and Hany Soh.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 up as automakers, materials gain; Trump policy shifts in focus
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by gains in automakers and materials stocks, as investors digested mixed corporate earnings and evaluated shifting US trade rhetoric. The Stoxx 600 index recovered from earlier losses, with automobile and parts stocks leading the gains. The US White House hinted at reducing tariffs on China, and US President Donald Trump's comments on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell also boosted market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 1.8 per cent higher.

site_title: Nestle sales rise on price hikes for coffee, cocoa products
summary: Nestle's sales rose 2.8% on an organic basis in the first quarter, driven by price hikes for coffee and cocoa products to counter soaring costs. The company's revenue growth exceeded analysts' 2.6% average estimate. CEO Laurent Freixe aims to reignite growth by boosting advertising spending and investing in fewer but bigger product initiatives. Nestle has also implemented a 2.5 billion-Swiss franc cost-cutting plan to drive growth, and plans to lower prices in North America to regain lost market share.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Swiss national flag flies beside a flag of the canton of Bern in front of the logo of Nestle at a plant in Konolfingen, Switzerland September 28, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Rise in private home prices eases in Q1, up 0.8% as market finds new equilibrium
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.8% in Q1 2025, moderating from a 2.3% increase in the previous quarter. Non-landed properties grew 1% and landed properties 0.4%. Buying demand remained strong, particularly in the Outside Central Region, with take-up rates at several newly launched projects. Analysts attribute the moderation in price growth to a higher proportion of new sales and lower interest rates. New home sales fell slightly to 3,375 units in Q1, while unsold inventory decreased 6.6% to 18,125 units. Rental growth is expected to moderate between 1% and 3% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
A bird's eye view of Singapore's financial district.
HDB Q1 resale price growth slows to 1.6% on higher housing supply
Generic photo of properties for stories related to private housing, condos

site_title: This Malaysian actor is scoring the best Singapore roles
summary: Malaysian actor Ghafir Akbar is set to star in Singapore Repertory Theatre's production of Shakespeare's Macbeth, marking his biggest performance yet. Rehearsing for the role has taken a toll on his mental health, but he believes it's necessary to convey the character's tension and pressure. Akbar aims to make Macbeth feel human, rather than a villain, to connect with the audience. This production, directed by Guy Unsworth, is a semi-futuristic interpretation of the classic tragedy, exploring the complexities of Macbeth and Lady Macbeth's relationship.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Sean Lim rose from being a lowly-paid cook to a successful investor, car lover and property owner.

site_title: US: Stocks rise for 3rd straight day
summary: US stocks rose for the third consecutive day, with the S&P 500 gaining 2% to 5,484.77 and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.7% to 17,166.04. Despite mixed earnings and signs of delayed US trade deals with China and the European Union, stocks shrugged off concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.2% at 40,093.40. A "relief rally" is persisting, driven by Trump's more conciliatory tone towards the Federal Reserve and China.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.1 per cent at 39,606.57.

site_title: Binance billionaire Zhao guides regulators to relax crypto rules
summary: Crypto billionaire Changpeng Zhao, co-founder of Binance, advised Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim to relax crypto rules, citing the US's pro-crypto stance as a competitive factor. Zhao met with Ibrahim to discuss Malaysia's potential as a crypto hub, suggesting more relaxed regulations and the establishment of new agencies. He also highlighted the Middle East, particularly Dubai and Bahrain, as forward-thinking regulators. Zhao has been advising governments in Pakistan and Kyrgyzstan and has been pushing for a pardon in the US, where his former company Binance has a minority stake.

images.alt_text: Binance’s Zhao will guide Pakistan’s newly-formed Crypto Council on regulation, infrastructure, education and adoption as a strategic advisor.
The talks reportedly began when Binance approached Trump allies last year, offering a business deal with the family as part of a strategy to re-enter the US market.
Zhao Changpeng built Binance into the dominant crypto exchange while maintaining that it did not have a global headquarters.

The Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) alleged that Binance Australia Derivatives offered crypto derivative products to 505 retail investors, about 83 per cent of its local clientele, who were misclassified as wholesale clients between July 2022 and April 2023.
FTX was one of the largest cryptocurrency firms in the world before it collapsed in late 2022.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 24)
summary: Malaysia's stock market has seen a 7.3% decline in the first quarter of 2025, with 26 consecutive weeks of foreign outflows triggered by negative sentiment over US trade policy uncertainty. The FBM KLCI index fell to 1,513.65. This is attributed to concerns about sweeping new tariffs under a second Trump administration.

images.alt_text: Property developers, tech firms and companies focussed on Sarawak have emerged as top performers in Bursa Malaysia this year.

site_title: Huawei raises record 20 billion yuan in Chinese debt issuance spree
summary: Huawei has raised a record 20 billion yuan in debt through ultra-short-term commercial paper issuance in China, taking advantage of low borrowing costs amid the US-China trade war. The funds will be used to supplement operating funds for its headquarters and subsidiaries. This borrowing spree aligns with China's push to boost financial backing for tech innovation, as onshore rates near historic lows make local funding cheaper than offshore US dollar bonds or loans.

images.alt_text: Huawei’s insistence on maintaining control over its intelligent driving ecosystem also means that it’s unlikely to be able to sign up customers overseas.
Huawei Atlas 800 inference server is displayed at InnoEX Fair, in Hong Kong, China April 15, 2025. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
U Mobile chairman Vincent Tan said Huawei and ZTE were chosen as they had “a proven global deployment track record”.
The deal signed on Friday provides for Huawei and SAIC Motor to cooperate strategically on manufacturing, supply chain management and sales services.

site_title: Toyota inks deal for wholly owned Lexus factory in Shanghai
summary: Toyota Motor has agreed to build a wholly owned electric vehicle factory in Shanghai, China, with an initial annual production capacity of 100,000 units, starting in 2027. The $2 billion investment is expected to create around 1,000 new jobs and lower production costs by up to 20%. The move aims to maintain Lexus's strong customer base in China despite slowing economic growth and increasing competition from local EV makers.

images.alt_text: Toyota signage during the 2025 New York International Auto Show (NYIAS) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. The event, which first opened in November 1900, is North America's oldest and largest attended auto show. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg
Toyota Motor Asia Vice President Preston Tan
Toyota's global output increased 6 per cent to 779,790 vehicles year-on-year, with domestic production up 16 per cent and that in other countries growing less than 1 per cent last month.
The India research centre will be Toyota’s third R&D location in the Asia-Pacific region outside Japan, following similar investments in China and Thailand.
Toyota said it will launch three Toyota brand electric SUVs this year - new versions of the bZ4X, Urban Cruiser and C-HR+ - followed by three more in 2026.
Toyota's global output for January increased 6 per cent year-on-year to 781,729 vehicles, with domestic production up 22 per cent, offsetting an overseas production decline.
The batteries Toyota is buying from LG can be used in either EVs or hybrid vehicles.
Sales of Toyota’s parent-only vehicles fell 1.4 per cent from a year earlier in 2024 to 10.2 million vehicles due to a double-digit decline in Japan.
Factoring in parallel imports, Toyota was the top selling car brand in Singapore, but BYD was number one in authorised dealer sales.
Toyota’s strategy is in contrast to that of other global automakers, including Japanese ones, that are either scaling back or pulling out of China.

site_title: Singapore dealer for China’s Neta EV shuts down after cars fail to arrive for months: sources
summary: Singapore's Neta EV dealer, Evology Automobile, has shut down its showroom after months of delayed car deliveries. The company, which was appointed as the distributor and dealer for Neta in Singapore in October 2024, had initially received orders for 52 vehicles but none were delivered. Industry sources say the management decided to close operations after the initial shipment failed to arrive. This is not the first time concerns were raised about deliveries from the China carmaker, which has faced challenges since late 2023, including a reported bankruptcy attempt and mass layoffs.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The Neta showroom in Singapore, opened by distributor/dealer Evology Auto.
Hyundai cars on display at car show The Car Expo, October 2024 in Singapore.
Toyota Motor Asia Vice President Preston Tan
Li Sheng, MG’s overseas brand and marketing director, with the MG S5 electric vehicle that launches in Singapore on Wednesday (Apr 9).
A bungalow, owned by Komoco Holdings executive chairman Teo Hock Seng, will go under the hammer for at least S$36 million.
From left to right: Mercedes-Benz eVito, eCitan and eSprinter, in front of the Mercedes-Benz Centre at Alexandra in Singapore.

site_title: 🤷🏻 I’m a new investor but I have a fear of investing... What can I do?
summary: A new investor is hesitant to start due to a fear of investing. However, inaction can lead to greater losses in the long run due to compounding and inflation. To overcome this, it's essential to understand the "why" behind investing, do thorough research, and stay motivated. New investors should be cautious of investment scams and avoid making impulsive decisions based on emotions. Seeking help from a trusted and knowledgeable person, such as a financial adviser, can also be beneficial in making informed investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Vanessa Chew
BT
BT
BT

site_title: Norway US$1.7 trillion wealth fund reports tech-stock driven loss
summary: Norway's $1.7 trillion sovereign wealth fund reported a 0.6% loss, or $40 billion, in the first quarter due to significant market fluctuations, mainly caused by a drop in technology company values. The fund's performance was 0.16 percentage points better than its benchmark, with a 1.6% gain in fixed-income investments. CEO Nicolai Tangen attributed the loss to the tech sector, stating that the quarter was impacted by market volatility.

site_title: Nissan sees 750 billion yen loss as restructuring charges mount
summary: Nissan Motor reported a potential net loss of 750 billion yen (S$6.9 billion) for the fiscal year ending March, due to restructuring charges and a decline in sales. The company has an ageing lineup and has been discounting cars to avoid inventory buildup, eroding profits. Nissan's shares have declined 44% this year, and the company faces US$5.6 billion in debt obligations next year. New CEO Ivan Espinosa will need to reverse the company's fortunes by refreshing its outdated lineup and finding a new business partner.

images.alt_text: Nissan says it will debut the next-generation ProPilot system in the 2027 fiscal year.
Nissan Motor incoming Chief Executive Officer Ivan Espinosa wants to cut development for the first car in a family of cars to 37 months, while the second car or third car would take just 30 months.
Nissan will roll out a number of new and refreshed models in its next two fiscal years to arrest its financial free fall.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s next court date fixed for Jun 10
summary: Property tycoon Ong Beng Seng's next court date is set for June 10. He stepped down as HPL's managing director on April 29, citing his illness. Ong, 79, has been diagnosed with multiple myeloma and will travel abroad for medical treatment between April 28 and May 16. He faces two charges related to his dealings with former transport minister S Iswaran, including abetting an offence under Section 165 of the Penal Code and obstructing the course of justice.

images.alt_text:
Property tycoon, hotelier and Singapore GP head Ong Beng Seng  at State Courts on Oct 30, 2024.//

 Mr Ong, 78, made headlines in recent months because of his links to former minister S Iswaran. He was named in Iswaran's initial graft charges, which alleged that the then-transport minister had corruptly obtained from Mr Ong tickets to the 2022 Singapore Formula 1 Grand Prix, as well as flights and a hotel stay in Doha. Mr Ong is known as the man who brought F1 to Singapore in 2008 – the first night race in the sport’s history. He owns the rights to the Singapore Grand Prix.

 SC-907646-2024 PP v. Ong Beng Seng
Jessie Lim
Redeveloping voco Orchard Singapore, the Forum and HPL House might yield much benefit for Hotel Properties Limited's shareholders.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust Q1 total property income up 14% at 4.7 billion rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust reported a 14% increase in total property income to 4.7 billion rupees (S$74.6 million) for its first quarter ended March 31, 2025, driven by higher rental income and income from recent acquisitions. Net property income rose 14% to 3.5 billion rupees, with portfolio occupancy at 90% and a weighted average lease expiry of 3.4 years. The manager expects the US tariffs to have a minimal direct impact, but notes that India's large domestic market could benefit in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Navi Mumbai data centre.
Tan Nai Lun
Gauri Shankar Nagabhushanam, chief executive of the trustee-manager, noted that Bangalore had record leasing levels for Grade A office space in 2024.
CapitaLand India Trust saw its distributable income increase by 4 per cent in H2 FY2024 to S$47.4 million from S$45.7 million in H2 FY2023

CapitaLand India Trust's (Clint) Navi Mumbai data centre (pictured) is one of four facilities Clint is developing in India's key data centre corridors as demand for data centres in India is set to rise.

site_title: Millionaire tax would push wealthy to leave the US, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed concerns that a proposed 40% tax bracket for individuals earning over $1 million could lead to the country's wealthiest citizens leaving the US. Trump stated that other countries that have implemented similar taxes have lost their wealthy individuals, which could harm the tax base. This comes as some Republican lawmakers consider raising taxes on top earners to fund Trump's economic agenda, which includes proposals to end taxes on tips and overtime.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk’s work as an adviser to Trump and his embrace of right-wing politics in Europe have drawn widespread opposition, including protests and vandalism at Tesla showrooms.
The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.
A handful of ETFs already offer products with investment strategies that align with Trump’s policy objectives.
The US president repeatedly complained that the Fed was not cutting interest rates quickly enough.

CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS - APRIL 17: People leave Harvard University on April 17, 2025 in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The Trump administration announced that it would block Harvard University from receiving $2.2 billion in federal grants and $60 million in contracts after the school refused demands to adopt new policies relating to student and faculty conduct, admissions, anti-semitism on campus and DEI.   Sophie Park/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Sophie Park / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

US President Donald Trump in his social media post said Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell was “always too late and wrong”, and critiqued the speech Powell made on Wednesday, calling it “another, and typical, complete mess!”
FILE PHOTO: Students walk on the campus of Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., April 15, 2025.   REUTERS/Faith Ninivaggi/File Photo

site_title: South Korea’s economy shrinks in first quarter as trade war hits exports
summary: South Korea's economy contracted 0.1% in the first quarter of 2025 due to the impact of US President Donald Trump's threatened 25% "reciprocal" tariffs on export-dependent South Korea. The country is also emerging from a political crisis triggered by former president Yoon Suk-yeol's attempt to suspend civilian rule. The economy is expected to rebound in the second quarter, but the recovery will remain fragile as elevated US tariffs weigh on external demand.

images.alt_text: US ally South Korea is due to hold trade talks in Washington on Thursday after the US introduced 10 per cent blanket tariffs and 25 per cent auto and steel tariffs.
The Korea Customs Service has launched a special task force to prevent illegal export attempts and plans to come up with more specific response measures to protect domestic companies.
South Korea is the US’s sixth-biggest trading partner, with the Asian country’s surplus jumping about 25 per cent in 2024 from the previous year to about US$55.7 billion.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 3.4% rise in Q1 DPU to S$0.01563
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 3.4% increase in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01563, driven by strong operating performances in its Singapore office, retail, and convention portfolios. Revenue rose 3.4% to S$113.5 million, while net property income increased 5% to S$77.1 million. The distribution will be paid out on May 30. CEO Chong Kee Hiong attributed the improvement to better property performance and lower financing costs, amid global macroeconomic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Analysts expect Frasers Centrepoint Trust, which counts Northpoint City as its asset, to post a higher DPU in its upcoming financial results.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.
Property tycoon Gordon Tang and wife’s stake in Suntec Reit stands at 35.5 per cent, or about 1 billion units, after returning the offer units to the unitholders who accepted the offer.
Suntec Reit's distributable income in H2 FY2024 slipped 13.2 per cent.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines signs funding deal with Vietcombank for 50 narrow-body planes
summary: Vietnam Airlines has signed a funding deal with Vietcombank for 50 narrow-body planes as part of its fleet development strategy for the next decade. The deal aims to expand the airline's short and medium-haul network in key markets, particularly in Southeast Asia and Northeast Asia. The funding comes after previous agreements with Citibank and potential sales of 10 E190 jets from Embraer. The move is seen as crucial to reducing Vietnam's trade surplus with the US and follows efforts to secure US plane deliveries, which have been hampered by Boeing's struggles.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO-An aircraft of the national flag carrier Vietnam Airlines taxis at Noi Bai airport in Hanoi, Vietnam December 23, 2020. Picture taken December 23, 2020. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Vietnam has repeatedly vowed to purchase more American goods such as LNG and aircraft, while offering to remove all tariffs on US imports.
Vietnam Airlines is working to move ahead with a US$10 billion 2023 commitment to buy 50 Boeing 737 Max aircraft, Le Duc Canh says.

site_title: BNP looks past tariff slowdown fears after investment bank boost in Q1
summary: BNP Paribas reported first-quarter earnings in line with expectations, with its investment bank division seeing a 12.5% increase in sales. The bank's group net income fell 4.9% year-over-year to 2.95 billion euros, but CEO Jean-Laurent Bonnafe said BNP is well-positioned to benefit from increased corporate activity due to Germany's and the EU's fiscal spending plans. The bank maintained its 2024-2026 profit forecasts despite a deteriorating economic outlook.

images.alt_text: A BNP Paribas SA sign at one of the company's bank branch in Paris, France, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. French President Emmanuel Macron is adamant that the EU shouldn’t shy away from a strong response to US tariffs. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg
The European Union’s banking giant, BNP Paribas, stood out for its stable profit growth in FY24 amid changing macroeconomic conditions.

site_title: Companies are renting bigger London offices, undoing Covid cuts
summary: Companies in London are reversing post-pandemic office cuts, with 70% of businesses leasing additional space in 2024, totaling 4.1 million square feet. This marks a 75% increase from the previous year, with businesses focusing on central and connected areas. Office vacancy rates in the UK have fallen to 8.6% in March, the first time since 2020, as companies reassess their office footprints and prioritize proximity to previous locations.

images.alt_text: London values, which have barely grown over the past year, are now exposed to the fallout from Trump’s sweeping tariff announcements since Apr 2.
London remains the least affordable UK region, with 90 per cent of local authorities recording house prices equal to over 12 times annual earnings.

A sign for stamp duty savings outside newly completed homes in Chelmsford, UK, on Thursday, March 13, 2025. Interest-rate cuts, wage growth and stagnant home prices have begun to marginally improve affordability, boosting confidence that housing output will start to recover from the plunge offset by the end of the cheap-money era. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Revolut Singapore in the black, targets South-east Asia
summary: Revolut Singapore has achieved its first year of profitability, with a net profit margin of 15%, driven by revenue growth of 72% to S$5.3 billion in FY2024. The fintech company plans to expand into 10 other markets in South-east Asia, targeting new customers and increasing its headcount by 50% in Singapore. Revolut will leverage its UK banking licence to enter new markets, with CEO Raymond Ng stating that the company will "find ways" to enter markets where it doesn't have a banking licence.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The firm currently has more than 800,000 UK trading customers.
Revolut co-founder Nikolay Storonsky recently flagged that backers will want an initial public offering “sooner or later”, and that the US looks a preferable listing destination.
The London-headquartered firm is now Europe’s most valuable fintech.

site_title: Vietnam kicks off trade talks with US as plane deal takes shape
summary: Vietnam and the US have begun trade talks, aiming to address a 46% tariff threat and resolve concerns over goods origin and smuggling. Vietnam has offered to remove all tariffs on US imports and purchase more American goods, including LNG and aircraft. A provisional deal to finance 50 aircraft purchases has been signed, potentially paving the way for a trade deal. Other South-east Asian nations, including Malaysia and Thailand, are also seeking to avert high tariffs, with talks underway.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has no free trade deal with the United States.

Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh reiterated that Vietnamese goods do not compete with those of the US and that “bilateral trade relations so far have ultimately benefited US consumers while driving Vietnam’s export growth.”
Vietnam has been slapped by the Trump administration with 46 per cent “reciprocal” tariffs, currently paused until July.

site_title: IBS: Moving more can help you ‘move’ more easily
summary: Regular physical activity can help alleviate symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) by improving mood, reducing stress and anxiety, and promoting regular bowel movements. Exercise, such as aerobic activities like brisk walking or cycling, and resistance training like yoga or bodyweight exercises, can stimulate the digestive system and reduce constipation. While exercise does not treat IBS, it can be a complementary approach to managing the condition, improving quality of life and reducing symptoms.

site_title: Thousands gather for second day to view pope
summary: Thousands gathered in St Peter's Square to view Pope Francis' body on the second day of public tributes, with 48,600 people passing by the coffin as of Thursday morning. The lying in state began on Wednesday and remained open until 5:30am, before reopening at 7:00am. World leaders, including US President Donald Trump and Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky, are expected to attend the funeral on Saturday. A massive security operation is underway, with Italy estimating up to 170 foreign delegations and several hundred thousand people in Rome for the funeral. The conclave to choose Francis' successor will begin no fewer than 15 days after his death, with cardinals from around the world returning to Rome for the process.

images.alt_text: Priests decked out in choir dress and others in cassocks made up the long procession, some with candles in their hands, as groups of nuns followed behind.
The Vatican on Tuesday released photographs of Francis lying in the chapel of the Santa Marta residence.
Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (second from left) meeting with business and government leaders on Monday.
Pope Francis was 88, and had suffered various ailments in his 12 year papacy.

site_title: Sats appoints new group CFO as part of leadership renewal
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based in-flight caterer and ground handler, has appointed Timothy Tang as its new group CFO-designate, effective May 2. The 46-year-old will replace incumbent Manfred Seah, who will transition to a special adviser role in July. Seah, who joined Sats in 2017, played a key role in the acquisition of WFS in 2023, which helped expand the company's global operations. The appointment is part of Sats' leadership renewal and succession plans.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck

UOB Kay Hian analyst said Sats derived 50 per cent of its group revenue from its global air cargo handling business, with the United States market being its top market accounting for 25 per cent of group revenue.

site_title: Trump considers reducing Chinese car part tariffs: FT
summary: The Trump administration is considering reducing tariffs on auto parts ahead of a May 3 deadline, potentially easing concerns from global carmakers. The proposal would exempt car parts from tariffs imposed to stop fentanyl production and allow parts makers to avoid tariffs on steel and aluminum. However, a 25% tariff on foreign-made cars would remain in place. The move is seen as a positive for US automakers, with General Motors, Ford, and Stellantis' US shares rising after the news.

site_title: Beijing says claims of ongoing US-China trade talks ‘groundless’
summary: Beijing denies US claims of ongoing trade talks, calling them "groundless" and "without factual basis". The US and China are locked in a trade battle triggered by US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods, which have reached 145% on many products. China has responded with new 125% duties on imports from the US, and Beijing urges the US to correct its "wrong practices" and return to equal dialogue and consultation. The IMF has revised down its forecast for global growth and China's economic expansion this year, citing an uncertain economic outlook.

images.alt_text: There are “no winners in trade wars” and China will remain open to the outside world and firmly support free trade and the multilateral trading system,  People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Pan Gongsheng said.
A 25 per cent tariff on all imports of foreign-made cars would remain in place and a 25 per cent tariff on car parts will still be imposed on May 3, the report says.
Scott Bessent says talks with other countries were continuing, and that a deal with India was “very close”.
Hapag-Lloyd was using smaller vessels on the route to the US in some cases, while keeping the number of passages unchanged.
The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.

site_title: Keppel posts more than 25% jump in Q1 net profit, expects limited direct tariff impact
summary: Keppel's Q1 net profit rose 25% to S$347 million, driven by stronger recurring income from its real estate and asset management arms. The company reported asset monetisations of S$347 million, mostly from divestments in China and Vietnam, and secured S$2 billion in capital commitments for new private funds. Despite tariff volatility, Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua remains optimistic, citing the company's stronger recurring income as a key factor in navigating volatility.

images.alt_text: Keppel
Keppel said the partial divestment of its stake in Tianjin Fulong Property Development is part of its asset monetisation programme.

site_title: Teo Hock Seng’s Good-Class Bungalow in Old Holland Road sold by private treaty
summary: Teo Hock Seng's 23,148 square foot Good-Class Bungalow in Old Holland Road has been sold by private treaty after an auction on Wednesday drew up to 30 attendees. The bidding process lasted over half an hour, with a counteroffer of S$33 million being accepted by the auction managing partner. The property was sold to one of the interested parties at an undisclosed price, with the buyer and seller reportedly satisfied with the sale.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Singapore GCB market sees interest picking up amid global uncertainty
A bungalow, owned by Komoco Holdings executive chairman Teo Hock Seng, will go under the hammer for at least S$36 million.
Late pioneer architect Alfred Wong’s bungalow in Bin Tong Park fetches S$45 million

site_title: Las Vegas Sands drops out of contest to develop New York City area casino
summary: Las Vegas Sands has dropped its bid to develop a New York City area casino, citing concerns over the impact of online betting on land-based gaming. The decision comes as the state considers three new casino proposals, with applications due in June and a final decision expected by December. The company, which operates resorts in Macau and Singapore, had proposed a $5 billion project at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Long Island. Its decision follows similar concerns in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, where online gaming has hurt land-based casino results.

site_title: Luxury brands cut price of exclusivity as Chinese spending drops
summary: Luxury brands are adapting to China's cooling luxury market by cutting prices and offering exclusive experiences to attract remaining high-end consumers. With Chinese luxury spending down 7% from last year, brands are shifting focus to emerging lower-tier markets, where affluent residents have stronger purchasing power. To compete, brands are experimenting with new tactics, such as expanding into smaller cities, adding hybrid experiences, and innovating digitally. Despite the challenges, luxury brands like Hermes and Chanel are weathering the storm better due to their strong brand discipline and focus on exclusivity.

images.alt_text: About 48 per cent of employees worked in China’s services industry by 2023 and the sector contributed 56.7 per cent to total GDP last year.

A person inside a casino in the Philippines. Seven South-east Asian nations – Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos – have already legalised gambling to varying degrees.
Chinese investors sent US$173 billion overseas, while foreign investors only channelled US$4.5 billion into the country, the lowest amount since 1992.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat on Thursday; markets across Asia end mixed
summary: Singapore's stock market ended flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing 0.4 points at 3,831.92. Local banks, which rose 8.2% in the last two weeks, ended lower, with DBS down 1.3%, OCBC down 0.3%, and UOB down 0.9%. The broader market saw decliners outnumbering gainers 271 to 260, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$1.6 billion traded.

images.alt_text: Generic shots of SGX

Tokyo rose more than 1 per cent, while Sydney added 0.6 per cent and Shanghai 0.3 per cent.

Keppel's increase in net profit is driven by strong performance in its infrastructure, real estate and asset management segments.

site_title: China kicks off special bond sale as tariffs threaten economy
summary: China has kicked off a special bond sale worth 500 billion yuan to defend its economy from the impact of 145% US tariffs on Chinese goods. The bond sale, which includes 286 billion yuan of five-year bonds, 50 billion yuan of 20-year bonds, and 71 billion yuan of 30-year bonds, aims to fund a fiscal package approved in March. The sale is seen as a response to Beijing's 5% growth target for 2025, which may be challenging due to the tariff shock.

images.alt_text: A string of global investment banks have lowered their projections for China’s economic growth this year and expected more monetary easing measures to underpin the economy.
Chinese demand has been shored up by a pilot programme that allows insurance funds to invest in gold, as part of efforts to optimise their asset allocations.
The PBOC has been pushing for lower borrowing costs for businesses and households.

site_title: Boeing ready to resell jets as tariffs hit China trade
summary: Boeing is considering reselling dozens of jets locked out of China due to tariffs, citing a tight jet market and lack of buyers. The move comes as the planemaker seeks to save cash and pay off debt by selling off part of its services business. Boeing had planned to deliver around 50 new planes to China this year but will instead study options to re-market 41 already built or in production. The company's CFO noted that customers are calling for additional airplanes, and potential new customers include India and other fast-growing markets.

Air India’s growth is also set to slow because of a retrofit programme that will temporarily remove some jets from its fleet, and a plan to phase out some Airbus models.
Malaysia Airlines is wholly owned by the country’s sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional.

site_title: Finding relief from irritable bowel syndrome: Effective strategies for a better life
summary: One in five Singaporeans suffer from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a condition often misunderstood and dismissed by healthcare providers. Characterized by chronic abdominal discomfort and changes in bowel habits, IBS is a functional gastrointestinal disorder, not caused by structural damage or inflammation. A holistic approach, including dietary changes, probiotics, and stress management, can help manage the condition. Understanding the complex interaction between gut microbiome, nervous system, and emotions is crucial in addressing IBS, and patients should work with healthcare providers to identify and eliminate triggers.

images.alt_text: Regular physical activity stimulates the digestive system, helping to promote more regular and efficient bowel movements.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as Trump soothes Fed fears
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as US President Donald Trump made conciliatory comments on his trade war with China, easing fears of a Federal Reserve firing and easing tariff concerns. Tokyo, Sydney, and Shanghai rose over 1%, 0.6%, and 0.3% respectively. However, Seoul fell after South Korea's economy contracted unexpectedly. The rally may be short-lived due to Trump's volatile rhetoric, and trade tensions remain a concern.

images.alt_text: Investors welcomed the comments with open arms, pushing Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul and Wellington more than one per cent higher.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield falls to 2.38%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced the latest six-month Treasury bill auction results, with a cut-off yield of 2.38%, the lowest level in the year to date. Demand for the auction decreased, receiving S$16.6 billion in applications for the S$7.4 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.24. The median yield stood at 2.32%, and average yield rose marginally to 2.16%. The lower cut-off yield is in line with market expectations, with analysts noting that Singapore dollar liquidity remains high.

“I don’t think we’re seeing dysfunction – in the sense of liquidity completely drying up in the markets – but a pattern suggestive of a loss of confidence in US economic policy,” Yellen said on CNBC on Monday.

site_title: Trump tariffs intensify European exporters’ Asean focus, say business chambers in Singapore
summary: European exporters, particularly those in the food and beverage, automotive, and machinery industries, are shifting their focus to Southeast Asia, or the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), amid US tariffs. The region's growth potential and free trade agreements are driving engagement, with many companies seeking opportunities for investment and expansion. European business chambers in Singapore report renewed interest from companies facing challenges in accessing the US market, with Singapore remaining a top hub destination for firms. Other Asean countries, such as Indonesia and Vietnam, are also attracting attention due to their consumer markets and manufacturing bases.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands Q1 revenue holds steady at US$1.2 billion amid strong operating environment
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) reported steady Q1 revenue of US$1.2 billion, unchanged from the previous quarter, despite a 1.3% increase in adjusted property Ebitda to US$605 million. The integrated resort has substantially completed its US$1.8 billion redevelopment program, featuring 1,844 rooms and 775 suites. Hotel occupancy increased to 95.6% and average daily room rate rose to US$925, resulting in revenue per available room of US$884.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

An artist's impression of what Marina Bay Sands IR2 will look like. The expansion is on the left of this photo, featuring a fourth tower and an entertainment area. Next to it is the existing MBS and its three hotel towers.

site_title: Nokia posts quarterly profit miss, flags disruption from Trump's tariffs
summary: Nokia reported a first-quarter profit that fell short of market expectations, with comparable operating profit reaching 156 million euros. The company attributed the miss to a one-time charge and a potential disruption from US tariffs, which could impact second-quarter profits. Despite losing market share to Ericsson, Nokia's sales in North America have been growing steadily. Nokia confirmed its acquisition of Infinera, but now expects more challenges in achieving its operating profit target. The company also announced a multi-year extension of its partnership with T-Mobile in the US to expand its 5G network coverage.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will allow Nokia to sell more equipment to big tech companies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Capitaland China Trust, Digital Core Reit, Sinarmas Land
summary: Keppel's net profit increased by 25% year-over-year, driven by strong performance in its infrastructure, real estate, and asset management segments. The company also announced a joint venture with Tianjin Shunhua Real Estate Construction Management to develop 19 plots of land in China. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust's distribution per unit fell 11.6% due to lower revenue contribution from China and weak regional currencies.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber decliners 385 to 178, after 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.68 billion changed hands.

site_title: ‘Made in Malaysia’: Sellers bombarded with ways to evade tariffs
summary: Unscrupulous logistics firms in China are offering tariff-busting services to online merchants, including fake value declarations and diversion of shipments through countries with lower tariffs, such as Malaysia. The offers have increased since US President Donald Trump imposed steep tariffs on China. Online merchants, including those interviewed, have declined the offers, but worry that some may try to cheat the system. US Customs and Border Protection has not increased enforcement, and businesses may weigh the risks of fines against losing their livelihoods due to the steep increase in tariffs.

images.alt_text: A parcel is scanned at the Russian Post logistics centre in Novosibirsk, Russia, November 15, 2024. REUTERS/Vladislav Nekrasov

site_title: Indonesia 2025 growth seen around 5% despite trade tensions, finance minister says
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, says the country's economic growth this year is expected to remain around 5% despite trade tensions, aligning with last year's 5.03% growth. The government's target is 5.2% this year, and President Prabowo Subianto aims to lift growth to 8% by 2029. A delegation is currently negotiating with the US to avoid reciprocal tariffs, which have led to capital outflows in Indonesia's financial markets.

images.alt_text: An employee shows Indonesian Rupiah banknotes at a money changer in Jakarta on April 10, 2025. Indonesia's benchmark stock index rallied nearly five percent higher at the open on April 10, after President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause on the harshest tariffs against US trading partners. (Photo by BAY ISMOYO / AFP)
Exports from the resource-rich country have rebounded from lows reached after the end of a commodity boom in 2022.
Indonesia has proposed increasing its imports from the US by up to US$19 billion, including around US$10 billion of energy imports.

site_title: GE2025: Highlights from Day 2 of campaigning
summary: Singapore General Election 2025: On the second day of campaigning, teams from various political parties made their rounds in constituencies across the island, engaging with residents and distributing flyers. The People's Action Party (PAP) and Workers' Party (WP) were active, with notable appearances by Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, and WP leader Pritam Singh. The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and Progress Singapore Party (PSP) also held rallies, while the National Solidarity Party (NSP) and People's Power Party (PPP) launched their campaigns. The general election is scheduled for May 3.

images.alt_text: Singapore General Election 2025

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust proposes US$11.8 million divestment of US data centre
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust is selling its US data centre in Georgia for US$11.8 million, with proceeds to be used for debt reduction or other growth opportunities. The data centre, which contributes 0.1% to the trust's revenue, has a net lettable area of 32,740 sq ft and a freehold land area of 140,341 sq ft. The sale price represents an 18.6% premium above an independent valuation of US$9.95 million. The trust plans to redeploy capital into other growth opportunities, focusing on portfolio rejuvenation efforts.

site_title: Robotaxi maker Pony.ai sees Trump’s trade war hitting sentiment, overseas expansion plans
summary: Pony.ai, a Toyota-backed robotaxi developer, expects US President Donald Trump's trade war with China to dampen its international expansion plans, despite anticipating little direct impact on its supply chain. The company has been exploring deployment in South Korea, Luxembourg, and other countries, but may reassess its plans sentimentally. Pony.ai's CEO, James Peng, stated that the company has alternatives and backups, and will likely use Nvidia's Drive Thor chips, which are not restricted from being sold in China. The company plans to launch its robotaxi services in Hong Kong and aims to produce 1,000 vehicles this year, with plans for rapid expansion in the coming years.

images.alt_text: The two-year pilot will allow ComfortDelGro to refine its autonomous vehicle (AV) capabilities for future large-scale development across China and other markets.  AV technology is critical for future-proofing the transport industry as a shortage of drivers persists, said ComfortDelGro chief executive Cheng Siak Kian (pictured).
The company will also focus its operations on international markets outside of the US, such as South Korea, Singapore and the Middle East, Peng says.

site_title: Tepid Q1 shophouse sales, but market remains resilient amid volatility: PropNex
summary: Singapore's shophouse market experienced a decline in Q1, with 19 caveated deals worth S$100 million, down 43% in value from the previous quarter. Sales volume dropped 17% year-on-year, and leasing demand slowed, with 836 rental contracts signed. Despite this, PropNex believes the market remains resilient amid macroeconomic volatility, with shophouses potentially offering a defensive asset due to their scarcity and heritage value. The market is expected to weather the storm, with a resurgence in shophouse hotel investments sales market predicted for Q2.

site_title: Sinarmas Land loses free float; trading to be suspended
summary: Sinarmas Land's shares have lost their free float after Lyon Investments' offer received valid acceptances, bringing its ownership to 92.3% of shares. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) requires companies to maintain at least 10% of their shares in public hands. The offer, made by the Widjaja family-controlled Lyon Investments, was made to purchase shares at S$0.31 apiece. The company's shares may be suspended by the exchange due to the loss of free float, and the offer will remain open for acceptance until May 14.

images.alt_text: In a bourse filing on Apr 15, property developer Sinarmas Land noted that its board has declared no dividend for FY2024.
The cash offer of S$0.31 per share to take Sinarmas Land private represents a 12.7 per cent premium over the company's last traded price.

site_title: Musk drives Tesla calmly through investors’ red lights
summary: Tesla's shares rose modestly after CEO Elon Musk stated he will be mostly back to his day job from next month, devoting only a couple of days a week to the Department of Government Efficiency. Musk's time-sapping role has weighed on Tesla's stock, with the company's value propped up by investors' faith in his ability to work magic. Despite a 20% decline in vehicle revenue, Musk remains unconcerned, citing his vision for the future and the company's significant cash pile.

images.alt_text: The company retreated from its 2025 guidance, citing unpredictability over trade policy and demand.
A Wuling Motors car is transported to the National Exhibition and Convention Center to be displayed for Shanghai auto show this week.

site_title: Malaysia’s stock market faces bleak outlook as foreign outflows hammer sentiment
summary: Malaysia's stock market faces a bleak outlook due to foreign outflows triggered by global trade tensions, delayed IPOs, and investor unease over US President Trump's second term. The FBM KLCI dropped 7.3% in the first quarter of 2025, with a total of RM10 billion pulled out of the market. This marks the largest quarterly outflow since the 2018 general election, affecting the country's economic outlook and making it one of the worst performers in South-east Asia.

The listing is now anticipated to be completed by Jun 24, Cuckoo Malaysia says.

site_title: China to allow overseas investors access to more sectors
summary: China has relaxed barriers to foreign investors, reducing the number of restricted industries on its "negative list" to 106 from 117. The move aims to boost market access and business vitality, particularly for private investment and innovation. Areas such as television production, telecommunication services, and freight forwarding services have been partially liberalized. The relaxation comes as US tariffs threaten pressure on China's economy, which is reeling from weak domestic consumption and a debt crisis in the property sector.

images.alt_text: With the US ramping up tariffs on Chinese goods and global demand weakening, the export engine helping power China’s recovery may be at risk of stalling.
Several major banks have downgraded their forecast on China’s expansion this year to 4% or lower, well below the government’s goal of around 5%.
A string of recent data has pointed to an uneven economic recovery, with bank lending beating expectations and factory activity picking up speed.
Exports to the US are expected to fall by two-thirds in the coming quarters and total overseas shipments may drop by 10 per cent in US dollar terms this year, the economists say.

site_title: Europe: Shares at near three-week highs as US-China trade tiff appears to ease
summary: European shares rose 1.8% to a near three-week high on April 23, driven by strong earnings from SAP and easing US-China trade tensions. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index outperformed, with the basic resources sub-index soaring 3.3% as base metals prices climbed. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent hinted at potential tariff cuts, while Amelie Derambure, a senior portfolio manager, attributed the market's optimism to the possibility of negotiations and reduced tariffs.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.2 per cent higher, well off session lows, with L’Oreal jumping 6.3 per cent for its best single-day gain in nearly seven months.

site_title: Malaysia’s ZUS Coffee to add 200 new South-east Asia stores, including six in Singapore
summary: ZUS Coffee, Malaysia's largest coffee chain, plans to open nearly 200 new stores in South-east Asia this year, including six in Singapore. The company surpassed Starbucks as Malaysia's largest coffee chain in 2024, with 743 stores in the country. ZUS finds success in tailor-made flavors and operates about 70% of its sales online. The company's rapid growth is attributed to its financials, with net income rising three times to RM37 million in 2024, and its technology-focused business model.

images.alt_text: ZUS Coffee Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
ZUS Coffee says it will debut in Singapore and Brunei this year and is in talks with potential partners in other countries to build new stores there in 2025.

site_title: US: Stocks rise again on more benign Trump tone on China
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 1.1% to 39,606.57, and the S&P 500 rising 1.7% to 5,375.86. The rally followed Trump's more conciliatory tone on trade negotiations with China, as well as statements that he has no plans to fire Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell. Despite the Federal Reserve's Beige Book indicating worsening economic conditions due to uncertainty about tariffs, markets are rallying on less negative headlines.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 22, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust Q1 NPI slips 6.6% to 292.5 million yuan amid lower revenue
summary: CapitaLand China Trust reported a net property income (NPI) of 292.5 million yuan, down 6.6% from the previous quarter, due to lower revenue from retail and business park portfolios. Gross revenue fell 6.1% to 439.7 million yuan. Tenant sales at CLCT malls were down 2.4%, despite a 2.4% increase in shopper traffic. The manager attributed the decline to lower rents at CapitaMall Xinnan and savings in operating expenses.

images.alt_text: CapitaMall Yuhuating in Changsha. Along with CapitaMall SKY+ in Guangzhou, CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit will have a combined value of about 2.8 billion yuan (S$499 million).

The fall in revenue was partially offset by improved performance in CapitaMall Grand Canyon, Rock Square (pictured) and CapitaMall Yuhuating, following the completion of asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Louis Vuitton raises price on popular US bag following new Trump tariffs
summary: Louis Vuitton has increased the price of its popular Neverfull GM bag in the US by 4.8% to $2,200 following the implementation of 10% US tariffs on EU goods. The price hike is the latest move by luxury brands to offset the tariffs, with LVMH's CEO stating that prices will vary by brand and product category. The US generates 24% of LVMH's sales, making it a key market for the company.

images.alt_text: Hermes has weathered the downturn in demand for luxury goods better than rivals by catering to the wealthiest and by cultivating a finely calibrated sense of exclusivity and managed scarcity.
Louis Vuitton owner LVMH is the first European luxury group to release its first-quarter results.

site_title: GE2025: Multi-cornered fights to be expected in elections, will not deter WP from fielding candidates: Pritam Singh
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh expects a multi-cornered fight in the upcoming General Election, but believes the party should still field candidates in key constituencies. WP has fielded a five-member team in Tampines GRC, a first for a Group Representation Constituency, and will compete against the National Solidarity Party and People's Power Party. In contrast, Ang Mo Kio GRC faces a three-cornered fight, despite consistently performing well in elections. WP's strategy focuses on the East, unlike the ruling party's nationwide presence, and the party emphasizes its contributions to Parliament and Sengkang town.

site_title: Thai exports rise 17.8% in March to three-year high
summary: Thailand's exports rose 17.8% in March, the highest level in three years, driven by a 34.3% increase in US-bound shipments. Despite this, steep US tariffs remain a concern, and the country's trade deficit with the US stands at $45.6 billion. The commerce ministry forecasts exports will rise 2-3% this year, with imports also increasing 10.2% year-over-year. Thailand faces a 36% tariff if US tariffs are not reduced before a global moratorium expires in July, posing a challenge to the global economy.

images.alt_text: “As the situation changes, we have to adjust,” Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira says.
Thailand has offered to step up imports of US commodities besides reducing import duties and removing non-tariff barriers to secure a deal.
Thailand’s trade surplus with the US more than doubled to US$46 billion last year from about US$17 billion at the beginning of Donald Trump’s first term.

site_title: DBS, OCBC and UOB’s recent rally a remarkable recovery, but are the risks fully priced in?
summary: DBS, OCBC, and UOB shares have rebounded 8.2% on average since April 7, driven by promises to return capital to shareholders. The banks' respective promises, announced in February, include capital returns, special dividends, and share buybacks. Despite market volatility and economic uncertainty, the banks' yields are attractive, with dividend yields ranging from 6-8.5%. However, investors should exercise caution as the banks still underperform the benchmark Straits Times Index and face risks such as asset quality and fees slowdowns.

site_title: Malaysia will need to revise down growth forecast, central bank governor says
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour says the country will likely need to revise its growth forecast due to trade and tariff uncertainties, particularly the 24% tariff rate on its goods exported to the US in July. However, the bank is not in a rush to make the change and will monitor the global trade situation. Malaysia's current growth forecast is between 4.5 to 5.5% for the year, with a strong domestic demand and increased investment activities.

Malaysia’s government and central bank have forecast the economy to expand between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent in 2025, following 5.1 per cent growth in 2024.

site_title: Nvidia supplier SK Hynix’s profit soars 158% on AI demand boost
summary: SK Hynix's operating profit soared 158% in the March quarter, driven by strong demand for artificial intelligence (AI) and stockpiling ahead of US tariffs on advanced chips and memory. The company expects its high-bandwidth memory (HBM) sales to double in 2025, with 12-layer HBM3E sales expected to account for more than half of total HBM revenues in the second quarter. Despite global uncertainty and potential slowdowns in demand, SK Hynix's results highlight the growing importance of AI in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Dram, or dynamic random access memory, is a type of memory most commonly used to process data in computers and servers.

It is the first time that SK Hynix’s quarterly operating profit beat Samsung’s total operating profit, analysts said, as its rival lags in supplying high-end HBM chips to Nvidia.

site_title: Chinese exporters retreat from US as tariffs erode profitability
summary: Chinese exporters are withdrawing from the US market due to the high tariffs, which have reached 145% on Chinese imports. Factories have halted shipments and idled assembly lines, leading to a potential shortage of crucial goods for US consumers. Some exporters, such as a Guangzhou-based retailer, are stopping shipments and raising prices by up to 30% to generate cash. The US could face rising prices and shortages, while China will endure substantial economic pain, including factory closures and worker layoffs, as the largest market is put on hold.

images.alt_text: The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.

site_title: Boeing reports small quarterly loss, confirms 2025 plane output targets
summary: Boeing reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss of $123 million in Q1, down from $343 million in the year-ago period. The company confirmed its 2025 plane production targets and reaffirmed plans to deliver the 777-9 in 2026. CEO Kelly Ortberg said the results show Boeing is "moving in the right direction," amid efforts to bolster safety following major incidents. Boeing also announced plans to sell its digital aviation solutions business for $10.55 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen displays the logo for Boeing on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 2, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust’s Q4 DPU falls 11.6%; manager warns trade tensions could weigh on performance
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 11.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for its fourth quarter, with a full-year DPU falling 10.6%. The trust's gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also fell, due to challenges in the China market and weak regional currencies. Despite this, the portfolio saw stable occupancy and positive rental reversions, with occupancy rates stable at 96.2%. The manager warned that trade tensions could weigh on performance, and will focus on tenant retention and cost management.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
The property is being sold to an unrelated third party.

site_title: Chinese AI’s secret to withstanding the trade war
summary: China's AI sector remains resilient despite the US trade war, thanks to domestic focus and government support. The country has set up a 60 billion yuan investment fund to bolster the sector, and President Xi Jinping has publicly backed the industry. China's widespread adoption of AI tools, including in agriculture and healthcare, has given it an edge over the US. While access to cutting-edge chips remains a concern, analysts believe the US restrictions could ultimately benefit the sector by reducing oversupply. China's AI ambitions are unlikely to be slowed by the trade war, with the country expected to continue to close the performance gap with the US.

images.alt_text: Fewer Chinese companies have listed in the US since Didi Global’s ill-fated share sale in 2021.

The emergence of Deepseek, the DBS team noted, is optimising chip performance, lowering the energy and computational costs of AI model training and inference.
China remained a very important market for Nvidia, which will optimise its chip products to comply with US export controls, Jensen Huang says.

site_title: Thailand may need US$15 billion of stimulus to cope with US tariffs
summary: Thailand may need a US$15 billion economic stimulus package to address the impact of US tariffs, Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said. The measures will focus on boosting domestic consumption and investment, and providing soft loans. The country is under a 36% tariff if a reduction can't be negotiated before July, and has been delayed in negotiations due to US requests to review key issues. The government is closely monitoring the situation and is prepared to implement measures to maintain growth levels, which grew just 2.5% last year.

images.alt_text: Thailand has offered to step up imports of US commodities besides reducing import duties and removing non-tariff barriers to secure a deal.

site_title: Gold prices bounce back from one-week low on dip buying
summary: Gold prices rebounded from a one-week low after US President Donald Trump's comments on not firing Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and his remarks on China trade talks. Spot gold rose 1.1% to $3,324.27 an ounce, while US gold futures gained 1.3% to $3,335.60. The US dollar index fell, making gold cheaper for overseas buyers. Trump's comments suggested a potential de-escalation of the US-China trade war, which had raised recession fears.

images.alt_text: The US dollar regained some ground after hitting a three-year low, making gold more expensive for other currency holders.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open as Trump says he has no plans to fire Powell
summary: US stocks surged at the open on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones rising 628.0 points, or 1.60%, to 39,815.01, as President Donald Trump hinted at no plans to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, driven by hopes for a trade deal with China. Trump's comments raised market expectations, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: Global roundtable sees rising debt risks for low-income countries as uncertainty mounts
summary: A global roundtable co-chaired by the IMF, World Bank, and South Africa has released a new playbook to aid countries facing mounting debt service challenges. The playbook aims to improve the sovereign debt restructuring process and address the high debt service burden facing many countries. The IMF projects global public debt to reach 99.6% of global GDP by 2030, citing rising trade tensions, declining commodity prices, and tightening financial conditions as key factors. The co-chairs emphasized the need for enhanced transparency and information sharing regarding restructuring agreements, as well as accelerated timelines and improved data-sharing.

images.alt_text: The IMF projects global growth in 2025 will slow to 2.8 per cent – its poorest showing since the Covid-19 pandemic – from 3.3 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Malaysia’s March inflation slows to 1.4% on softer consumer prices
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate slowed to 1.4% in March 2025, according to the Department of Statistics Malaysia. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased to 134.1 points, driven by modest increases in personal care, social protection, and miscellaneous goods and services. Inflation rates varied by state, with 12 states recording rates below the national average. When compared to neighboring countries, Malaysia's inflation rate was lower than Vietnam's and the Philippines' but higher than Indonesia's and Thailand's.

site_title: Driving ‘zero waste’ in Bali
summary: Desa Potato Head in Bali, a luxury eco-resort, has become a model for sustainable hospitality with a strong focus on waste management. The resort produces only 0.5% landfill waste and operates a zero-waste restaurant, making it one of the few hotels to achieve this feat. Its commitment to sustainability has earned it a spot in the World's 50 Best Hotels annual list. The resort's eco-friendly practices demonstrate that style, nightlife, and serious waste management can coexist and thrive.

site_title: Forest City special financial zone lands first family offices as Johor courts investors
summary: Forest City in southern Malaysia's Johor state has secured its first two family offices, CMY Capital Family Office and Yow Kee Family Office, to operate within its Special Financial Zone. This move aims to attract high-value investors through its economic corridor with Singapore. Another 30 companies have expressed interest in setting up operations in the zone, with the Johor Investment, Trade, Consumer Affairs and Human Resources Committee chairman Lee Ting Han stating that the zone will enhance Forest City's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng

CMG20250421-KwongKC01/邝启聪/陈紫筠 /JOHOR-SINGAPORE SPECIAL ECONOMIC ZONE (JS-SEZ) JOINT BUSINESS AND INVESTMENT FORUM IN JOHOR, MALAYSIA/ YB Senator Tengku Datuk Seri Utama Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party delivers series of surprises on Nomination Day
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) delivered a series of surprises on Nomination Day for the 2025 Singapore General Election, fielding 26 candidates across five GRCs and three single-seat wards. Senior Counsel Harpreet Singh was unexpectedly fielded in Punggol GRC, while the party defended Aljunied and Sengkang GRCs and faces the PAP in East Coast and Punggol GRCs. The WP's lineup includes 12 newcomers and 12 returning candidates, with a four-cornered fight expected in Tampines GRC. The PAP also made surprise moves, with Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong switching to Punggol GRC.
