site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 23)
summary: Singapore's core inflation slowed to 0.5% in March, its lowest in four years. The main car premium rose to nearly S$100,000, while commercial vehicle and motorcycle categories fell over 5%. PAP's candidates for Marine Parade-Braddell Heights gave their thank you speeches after winning the GE2025 election. A new centre for sustainable aviation was set up in Apac, and FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries.

images.alt_text: With GE2025 looming, Singapore’s hottest GRCs could face nomination day curveballs. Which teams and candidates might upend the election narrative?

site_title: Digital Core Reit’s Q1 distributable income rises 9.9% to US$11.7 million
summary: Digital Core Reit reported a 9.9% increase in distributable income to US$11.7 million for Q1, driven by a 79.9% jump in revenue to US$44.2 million and a 41.8% rise in net property income to US$22.4 million. Occupancy at its data centers in Northern Virginia and Silicon Valley remained full at 100%. Despite higher tax expenses, the Reit's units rose 1.06%.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck

site_title: Keppel enters joint venture to develop 19 plots of land in Tianjin
summary: Keppel Ltd has entered a joint venture with Tianjin Shunhua Real Estate Construction Management to develop 19 plots of land in Tianjin, China. As part of the agreement, Keppel divested 30% of its stake in Tianjin Fulong Property Development for approximately S$92.8 million. The move is part of Keppel's asset monetization programme and aims to collaborate with an experienced real estate partner for large-scale projects.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Keppel

site_title: US business activity moderates in April
summary: US business activity slowed to a 16-month low in April, with the S&P Global Composite PMI Output Index dropping to 51.2, the lowest level since December 2023. The decline was attributed to concerns over the economic outlook, rising costs, and labor availability due to President Trump's protectionist trade policy. Prices charged for goods and services soared to a 13-month high, driven by manufacturers, and a gauge of employment slipped to 50.8. Economists believe economic growth braked sharply in the first quarter, with GDP estimates converging below a 0.5% annualized rate.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York City, on April 16, 2025. Global stock markets mostly retreated Wednesday after the US government imposed restrictions on exports of a key Nvidia chip to China, the latest trade war salvo between the world's biggest economies. Nvidia late on April 15 notified regulators that it expects a $5.5 billion hit this quarter owing to a new US licensing requirement on the chip it can legally sell in the Asian country. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)
The reiteration from Beijing comes after US President Donald Trump acknowledged that 145 per cent was a “very high” level and that will “come down substantially”.

site_title: Time for EU bonds to shine as US Treasuries flounder
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff war has led to investors fleeing US Treasuries and the dollar, instead seeking safe assets like gold, Swiss francs, and euros. This shift undermines trust in US government bonds and the dollar, a key component of the global financial system. The European Union sees an opportunity to issue common EU bonds, which could strengthen Europe's economy, security, and policymaking autonomy, while also satisfying growing investor demand for alternative safe assets. This crisis of confidence in the US may have far-reaching consequences for the global economy.

images.alt_text: US
Gold has hit multiple record highs and gained more than 30 per cent so far this year.
China’s status as the second-largest overseas holder of Treasuries has come into focus in recent weeks as analysts debate the nation’s role in the recent turmoil.

site_title: PropNex Realty faces second lawsuit over 99-1 deals
summary: PropNex Realty is facing a second lawsuit over its 99-to-1 deals, with an Indonesian couple claiming S$850,000. The couple, Kevin Rahim and Jessica Tjitra, allege that salesperson Amos Koh misled them about the tax implications of the arrangement, which they claim was illegal. The couple paid S$849,287 to the taxman, and the lawsuit also accuses PropNex Realty of breaching its duty of care to the claimants. The case is set to be heard on April 30, while another lawsuit against PropNex Realty for S$1.2 million is believed to be going to mediation.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

Li is suing PropNex Realty, its agent Ian Sng and City Law for about S$1.2 million after he was made to top up the ABSD and pay surcharges imposed by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore for his property transactions.
Melvin Li is suing the property agency PropNex Realty, its agent Ian Sng and City Law over his 99-to-1 deals.

site_title: GE2025: Campaigning kicks into high gear following suspenseful Nomination Day
summary: Singapore's general election, GE2025, has kicked into high gear after a suspenseful Nomination Day. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) will contest 92 out of 97 seats, with 206 candidates vying for office. The PAP's strategy of redeploying ministers at the last minute, including Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong taking over in Punggol GRC, has sparked surprise and speculation. The Workers' Party (WP) has decided not to contest in Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC, but will field 26 candidates in eight constituencies. A historic four-cornered fight is taking shape in Tampines GRC, involving the PAP, WP, National Solidarity Party (NSP), and People's Power Party. The nine-day campaign has begun, with physical rallies set to resume after a decade-long hiatus.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says that while GE2025 is not the first general election amid challenging circumstances, with pandemic-era GE2020 being similar, today’s challenges are more severe.

PAP's elected candidates for Marine Parade-Braddell Heights giving their thank you speeches.

site_title: China says ‘door open’ to trade talks after Trump signals tariffs will fall
summary: US President Donald Trump has signaled a potential reduction in tariffs on China, stating that the 145% tariff rate is "very high" and will "come down substantially". China has welcomed the move, saying the door is "wide open" for trade talks. Trump also assured that he has no intention of firing Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, bringing relief to global markets. The comments have led to a surge in stock markets, with Asian markets rallying and gold prices falling.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has no free trade deal with the United States.

site_title: Kering sales drop more than expected in first quarter as Gucci crisis deepens
summary: Kering's first-quarter sales fell 14% annually and 25% at Gucci, exceeding analyst expectations and signaling a tough year for the luxury sector. The crisis at Gucci deepened, with 25 stores closed so far this year, as part of a push to shed underperforming boutiques. Kering's shares have lost over 60% since March 2024, and the company plans to reduce redundancies and cut costs amid macroeconomic headwinds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of fashion house Gucci is seen outside a store in Cannes, France, May 16, 2024. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Revenue at Gucci fell 24 per cent on a comparable basis in the fourth quarter, Kering said.
Kering has remained largely dependent on Gucci, whose success in the cutthroat fashion industry has ebbed and flowed over the years.
Comparable sales at Gucci, which makes up the bulk of Kering’s profit, slumped 25 per cent in the third quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: Oil falls 2% after sources say Opec+ to mull accelerating output
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on April 23 as Opec+ considered accelerating oil output increases in June, despite recent tensions among members over compliance with production quotas. Brent crude futures settled at $66.12 a barrel, down $1.32, after US President Donald Trump may cut tariffs on Chinese imports. However, losses were curbed by news of new sanctions targeting an Iranian shipping magnate. US crude stockpiles rose unexpectedly, and government data showed a decline in petrol and distillate inventories, supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1.18, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$67.44 per barrel.

site_title: Investors relieved Musk will refocus on Tesla, but worry about brand damage
summary: Tesla investors breathed a sigh of relief after CEO Elon Musk committed to refocusing on the electric automaker, but concerns about brand damage persist. Musk will cut back his work for US President Donald Trump to a day or two per week, but experts warn that the damage to Tesla's image may be irreparable. The company's shares rose 6.5% after Musk's announcement, but analysts say the brand faces a long road to recovery, especially with ongoing political controversy weighing on its image.

images.alt_text: The company retreated from its 2025 guidance, citing unpredictability over trade policy and demand.
A Wuling Motors car is transported to the National Exhibition and Convention Center to be displayed for Shanghai auto show this week.

Analysts expect sales to fall again this year for several reasons, including damage to the brand reputation by chief executive Elon Musk’s (above) close work with US President Donald Trump and support of far-right European politicians.

site_title: US, China tariffs both need to fall for trade talks to start, US Treasury Secretary Bessent says
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated that both US and China tariffs need to fall before trade talks can proceed. He believes that the current 145% US tariffs on Chinese goods and 125% tariffs on US goods are unsustainable and equivalent to an embargo. Bessent said there are no plans for US President Donald Trump to unilaterally cut tariffs, and a mutual reduction is possible. The US is working on restoring tariff certainty through negotiations with dozens of countries, with a goal of achieving clarity on Trump's tariffs by the third quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent takes questions from reporters at the Institute of International Finance (IIF) Global Outlook Forum on sidelines of the IMF and World Bank’s 2025 annual Spring Meetings in Washington, D.C., U.S., April 23, 2025. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: World leaders from China to EU hold climate meeting without US
summary: World leaders from China, the EU, and other countries held a virtual meeting on climate action, aiming to refocus global efforts despite trade and military conflicts. Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized China's commitment to combating climate change, stating that efforts will not slow down. The meeting was a response to the US' withdrawal from the Paris Agreement and its increasing unilateralism. The gathering resulted in agreements to present new emissions cutting plans by September, which will set the tone for the COP30 summit in November, aiming to mobilize $1.3 trillion in climate funding for developing countries.

images.alt_text: Icebergs and ice sheet in the Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland on July 19, 2022. Global sea ice cover reached a historic low in February 2025, Europe's climate monitor said, with temperatures spiking up to 11 deg C above average near the North Pole as the world continued its persistent heat streak.

site_title: ECB expects wage growth to ease considerably this year
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) expects wage growth in the eurozone to ease considerably this year, slowing to 3.1% in 2025 after 4.8% in 2024. This follows a recent cut in interest rates to support the economy amid concerns over erratic US trade policy. Excluding one-off payments, wage growth is expected to be 3.8% this year. The ECB's wage tracker provides key insights into inflation, which has fallen to 2.2% in March.

images.alt_text: The ECB has been easing borrowing costs rapidly as undue price pressures are disappearing, and recent turmoil on global markets is likely to bolster the bank’s conviction.

site_title: GE2025: PAP rejects call to debate with PSP’s West Coast-Jurong West GRC team
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has invited the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to a debate during the upcoming Singapore general election, citing the need for voters to decide who has better policies. However, PAP's National Development Minister Desmond Lee rejected the invitation, stating that there are platforms for political parties to debate policies during the election, and the PSP should publish its local plans for residents to study. The PSP has issued a manifesto with policy recommendations, and its candidates are open to debating the PAP team on any topic.

site_title: Weighing the cost of health cover in one’s senior years
summary: Singaporeans worry about high medical expenses in their senior years, with insurance being a major tool to alleviate out-of-pocket costs. The Central Provident Fund Board's Health Insurance Planner projects long-term medical expenses and funding shortfalls for individuals. The planner provides detailed comparisons of MediShield Life and Integrated Shield Plan (IP) coverage and premiums. With rising medical technologies and longevity, policyholders and insurers face significant challenges, emphasizing the importance of considering affordability and funding shortfalls in future premiums. The planner aims to help individuals make informed decisions about their health insurance.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

In Integrated Shield Plans, a pro-ration factor is applied if a policyholder consumes healthcare at a higher class ward than his plan entitlement. This prevents cross-subsidisation which would eventually raise plan premiums.
Starting in April, claim limits for Medishield Life will be increased, and coverage will also be expanded to include additional outpatient treatments and new therapies.

site_title: thrive clinches silver for Best Newsletter at Wan-Ifra Digital Media Awards Asia
summary: thrive, a young audience initiative by The Business Times, won the silver award for Best Newsletter at the Wan-Ifra Digital Media Awards Asia 2025. This marks a significant milestone for thrive, which was launched in 2022 to provide relevant, actionable insights for Gen Zs and millennials navigating their adulting journey. The award recognizes editorial newsletters that stand out for innovative content, fresh formats, and strong audience engagement, and is a testament to thrive's vision of reimagining quality journalism for a new audience.

site_title: Bank Indonesia keeps rate at 5.75%, downgrades growth outlook amid tariff tension
summary: Bank Indonesia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 5.75% for the third month in a row amid ongoing trade tensions and a weakening rupiah, which has fallen 4.6% against the US dollar this year. The central bank downgraded its economic growth outlook to 5.1% from 5.5% due to lingering uncertainty from the US-China tariff war. Governor Perry Warjiyo said the bank will intervene in the offshore market to stabilize the rupiah and attract foreign inflows.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Exports from the resource-rich country have rebounded from lows reached after the end of a commodity boom in 2022.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Wednesday amid potential easing of trade tensions; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1% on Wednesday, driven by optimism over potential easing of US-China trade tensions and remarks from US President Donald Trump signaling no plans to dismiss Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell. The Straits Times Index gained 36.91 points to 3,832.32, with Mapletree Logistics Trust being the top gainer. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also closed in positive territory. The positive sentiment was further boosted by data showing Singapore's core inflation slowed more than expected in March.

site_title: Netflix raises prices in Singapore as analysts remain ‘neutral’ on counter
summary: Netflix has raised its subscription prices in Singapore by S$2 to S$4, effective from April 18, with the priciest tier costing S$29.98. The price hike follows increases in large markets that have performed in line with expectations. Despite analysts remaining neutral on the counter, Netflix's Q1 revenue in Asia-Pacific grew 25% year on year to US$1.3 billion. The company is guiding for Q2 revenue of US$11 billion and net income to be US$3.1 billion.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd says 30% of China’s US bound shipments have been cancelled
summary: Hapag-Lloyd reports 30% cancellation of US-bound shipments from China due to the trade conflict between the US and China, with 145% US duties on Chinese goods and 125% Chinese duties on US goods. In contrast, demand for consignments from Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam has surged. The shipping company is using smaller vessels to maintain passage numbers. This shift is attributed to the steep tariffs introduced by US President Donald Trump, which are expected to slow global economic output.

site_title: GE2025: Teo Chee Hean, Heng Swee Keat among 20 PAP MPs who have stepped down
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has announced the departure of 20 PAP MPs, including Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, from the party's ticket for the upcoming General Election. The pair, who have served 33 and 14 years respectively, will step down to make way for 32 new candidates as part of the party's ongoing renewal process. The departures also include other senior ministers and MPs, with many praising their contributions to public service and Singapore's development.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says that while GE2025 is not the first general election amid challenging circumstances, with pandemic-era GE2020 being similar, today’s challenges are more severe.

site_title: US new home sales jump in March; supply still rising
summary: US new home sales rose 7.4% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 724,000 units, the highest level since September 2024. The increase was driven by a decline in mortgage rates, but a gloomy economic outlook poses a challenge to the housing market recovery. Despite a 0.6% increase in inventory, it would take 8.3 months to clear the supply of new houses on the market. Economists are cautious, citing President Trump's tariff policy and its impact on inflation and employment.

images.alt_text: New residential construction decreased 11.4 per cent to an annualised rate of 1.32 million last month, restrained largely by single-family homes.
A gauge of overall conditions from the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) and Wells Fargo rose one point to 40 in April, hovering near some of the lowest levels since late 2023.
The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index dropped three points to 39 this month, the lowest level since August

site_title: Cross-border renminbi use by Chinese climbs to record as US dollar sags
summary: Chinese yuan usage in cross-border transactions surged to a record 54.3% in March, with a total of $724.9 billion, as the US dollar's global appeal waned amid escalating trade tensions. This marks progress in Beijing's efforts to boost global renminbi adoption. The trend is also driven by mainland Chinese investors buying Hong Kong stocks, which has increased the renminbi's use in securities accounts. However, the renminbi still has a long way to go to challenge the US dollar's global status.

site_title: Grade-A office rents to stay flat in 2025: Savills Singapore
summary: Office rents in Singapore's CBD Grade-A buildings are expected to remain flat in 2025, with super-premier buildings outperforming amid US trade tariffs. Rents of overall CBD Grade-A offices rose 0.4% to S$9.83 per square foot in the first quarter of 2025, with super-premier buildings seeing a 1.1% increase to S$13.05 per square foot. The vacancy rate fell to 7.7% in Q1, with net demand remaining in the positive territory, albeit at a smaller 83,000 square feet.

Punggol Digital District (PDD) was built on an Open Digital Platform (ODP) that connects different smart technologies, and also provides a digital twin to allow tech firms to test-bed solutions.

The freehold Upper Serangoon Shopping Centre will be on the market at a reserve price of S$260 million.

site_title: GE2025: DPM Gan Kim Yong surprises by leading PAP Punggol GRC team against WP; SDA runs in Pasir Ris-Changi GRC
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong has unexpectedly led the People's Action Party's (PAP) team in Punggol GRC, a surprise move that replaces the original anchor minister. Gan, who was previously set to lead the team in Chua Chu Kang GRC, now faces off against a Workers' Party (WP) team led by "star catch" Harpreet Singh. This swap came at the last minute, with Gan citing the "situation and availability of candidates" as the reason.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, April 23, 2025
summary: Asian markets rallied as US President Trump's comments eased concerns about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and China trade tensions. Trump stated he has no intention of firing Fed Chief Powell, calming market fears. Meanwhile, PSA weighed selling a 20% stake in CK Hutchison's ports business, further weighing on the market. Despite these factors, Asian markets saw a significant rebound, driven by Trump's comments.

site_title: Bali’s first ‘zero-waste’ eco-luxury hotel: Desa Potato Head
summary: Desa Potato Head, a luxury resort in Bali, Indonesia, has achieved the distinction of being the world's first zero-waste hotel. By implementing sustainable practices, the resort reduces its waste to 0.5% of its total output, with 99% of waste being reused, recycled, or composted. The hotel's "upcycled menus" feature dishes made from hotel by-products, such as ginger pulp and egg whites. Additionally, the resort's architecture and design showcase sustainable materials and reuse of waste, inspiring guests to rethink luxury hospitality in a climate-conscious world.

site_title: PSA weighs selling 20% stake in CK Hutchison’s ports business: sources
summary: PSA International, a Singaporean ports operator, is exploring the sale of its 20% stake in CK Hutchison's ports business, which includes two ports along the Panama Canal. The deal, announced by CK Hutchison last month, would be sold to a BlackRock-led consortium for US$14.2 billion. The sale's outcome depends on whether CK Hutchison goes ahead with the transaction. The deal, valued at US$22.8 billion, encompasses 43 ports in 23 countries, and PSA has owned its 20% stake since 2006.

images.alt_text: The sell-off underscores how the company stands in the middle of a US-China tiff over its canal facilities in the Central American country.

site_title: Mainstream car COE premium rises to just under S$100,000; most other categories fall
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for mainstream cars in Singapore rose to nearly S$100,000, while most other categories fell in April. Category A premiums increased 1.8% to S$99,500, with Category B remaining steady at S$117,003. Category C commercial vehicles and buses decreased 5.5%, and Category D motorcycles dipped 5.9%. The rise in Category A premium is attributed to strong demand for electric vehicles (EVs), with some dealers speculating that buyers are buying now due to uncertainty about EV incentives set to expire at the end of 2025.

The motorcycle category saw a 4 per cent increase to S$9,889.

site_title: GE2025: New-ish kid on the block Red Dot United fields second-largest opposition slate
summary: Singapore's General Election 2025 is underway, with the Workers' Party fielding the highest number of opposition candidates at 26. Red Dot United (RDU), a relatively young party, is fielding 15 candidates, the second-largest opposition slate. RDU's candidates are contesting three Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and a single Single Member Constituency (SMC). The election sees a total of 92 out of 97 seats contested, with several parties, including the National Solidarity Party and People's Power Party, contesting multiple seats.

site_title: GE2025: PAP facing off against Red Dot United in newly formed Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC
summary: The Singapore General Election (GE2025) is approaching, with the People's Action Party (PAP) facing off against the opposition Red Dot United (RDU) in the newly formed Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC. PAP's Grace Fu will lead her five-member team, while RDU's Kala Manickam, a last-minute switch from Emily Woo, will contest the Jurong Central SMC. Both parties have new teams and will campaign in the newly formed GRC. The election is set to take place on May 3.

site_title: UK homebuilders say planning headaches starting to ease
summary: UK housebuilders report a decrease in planning delays as a significant barrier to delivering new homes, with 61% citing it as a barrier down 27 percentage points from last year. The Office for Budget Responsibility expects 1.3 million more homes by the end of the decade, despite government measures and policy changes aimed at unblocking the planning system. Labour Party's planning reforms are also seen as a positive factor, but labour shortages, higher inflation, and development costs remain major challenges to increasing housing delivery.

site_title: Two women entrepreneurs on how they tackled tradition and gender biases to transform their businesses
summary: Two Singaporean women entrepreneurs, Jenny Tay and Clare Leighton, share their stories of transforming their businesses, Direct Funeral Services and fileAI, respectively. Tay overcame resistance from industry veterans to professionalize her team, introducing personalized memorial biographies and AI-powered tools, which have increased revenue by 15 times since 2013. Leighton, co-founder of fileAI, faced biases in the tech industry, but her approach to leadership emphasizes merit-based evaluations, removing the "gender lens" that typically frames women's stories. Both women have achieved significant growth and success in their respective industries.

images.alt_text: Joe Stevens, CEO, Little Farms.
The quarterly index, which tracks the business health and performance of SMEs, fell slightly from 50.7 to 49.9.

site_title: GE2025: PAP serves Singaporeans ‘as a combined team’, PM Wong says after surprise swops
summary: Singapore is gearing up for the 2025 general election, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizing the need for voters to consider the stakes and the future of the country. The People's Action Party (PAP) has seen surprise candidate swaps, with Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong leading the PAP team in Punggol GRC. PM Wong assured voters that the PAP team will serve them effectively, despite the changes. The election comes amid challenging circumstances, including the impact of US tariffs and rising geopolitical tensions, with PM Wong warning that today's challenges are more severe than the pandemic-era GE2020.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

DPM Gan’s arrival at Yusof Ishak Secondary School on Wednesday (Apr 23) morning came as a surprise, as it was not the nomination centre for Chua Chu Kang GRC, where he was earlier introduced as the PAP team’s anchor minister.

site_title: Xiaomi delays release of first SUV after fatal road accident
summary: Xiaomi has delayed the release of its first SUV, the YU7 electric vehicle, after a fatal accident involving its electric car on March 29. The accident, which killed three women, led to an investigation and calls for stricter rules on autonomous driving systems. The delay sets back Xiaomi's $10 billion EV project, which was seen as a key driver of the company's business growth. The company has scrapped its Shanghai auto show unveiling and rescheduled its investor day to June.

images.alt_text: Huawei’s insistence on maintaining control over its intelligent driving ecosystem also means that it’s unlikely to be able to sign up customers overseas.
The move follows a fatal accident involving Xiaomi’s best-selling SU7 sedan in March that triggered widespread concerns over vehicle safety.
The rules set out stricter mandatory tests which will require companies to ensure their batteries won’t catch fire or explode in tests with a specified time period.
Down for a fifth straight session, Xiaomi's share price is now more than 20 per cent below a record high last month.

site_title: GE2025: PAP’s Ng Chee Meng to face WP’s Andre Low in Jalan Kayu SMC
summary: Singapore's general election, GE2025, will see a three-cornered fight in Ang Mo Kio GRC as the PAP faces the Singapore United Party (SUP) and People's Power Party (PPP). Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong will lead the PAP, while Labour chief Ng Chee Meng of the PAP will face Workers' Party newcomer Andre Low in the newly formed Jalan Kayu SMC. Ng Chee Meng has returned to politics after the PAP's Sengkang GRC lost to the WP in GE2020. The election marks a significant shift in Singapore's politics, with younger candidates like Andre Low vying for seats.

Red Dot United secretary-general Ravi Philemon said the decision was made after talks with WP which has also expressed interest in contesting the single-seat ward.

site_title: Apple fined 500 million euros and Meta 200 million euros for breach of EU law
summary: The European Union has fined Apple 500 million euros and Meta 200 million euros for breaching EU antitrust law. The fines follow a year-long investigation into whether the companies comply with the Digital Markets Act, which aims to allow smaller rivals into markets dominated by Big Tech. Apple has threatened to challenge the fine, while Meta has criticized the EU decision, calling it an attempt to handicap successful American businesses. The EU regulator has ordered the companies to remove technical and commercial restrictions that prevent app developers from steering users to cheaper deals outside the App Store.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms said on Thursday (Feb 13) that it will allow classified ad firms in Europe to pay to place their listings on Facebook Marketplace. The cost will be based on the number of times a user clicks on a button within the listing.
FILE PHOTO: A keyboard is placed in front of a displayed Facebook logo in this illustration taken February 21, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Apple could face an investigation if regulators subsequently find that it has not followed through on the order that could lead to a fine as much as 10 per cent of its global annual sales.
The lawsuit alleged Apple violated antitrust law by coercing customers to use the company’s iCloud service to back up core data and device setting files.

site_title: MAS to evaluate need to review asset managers’ liquidity risk management framework: Chia Der Jiun
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to review the liquidity risk management framework for asset managers, amid global calls for consistency between investment strategy and fund assets. MAS Managing Director Chia Der Jiun emphasized the need for asset managers to stress-test portfolio risks and ensure fair marketing practices. The review aims to enhance market resilience in normal and stressed market conditions, and MAS will engage with the industry when it is ready. The move follows global regulatory bodies' calls to reinforce consistency and promote diversity among market participants.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong says: “While there have been suggestions to channel sovereign monies into our equities market, it is not practical to rely on sovereign monies alone to sustain these funds and to support the equity market.”

site_title: Perromart’s Malaysian owner wants to make it the ‘Amazon of pet care services’
summary: Petico, a Singapore-based pet retailer, has acquired Perromart, a Malaysian online pet retailer, as part of its strategy to become South-east Asia's premier pet care platform. The acquisition allows Petico to expand its services to Singapore, a market with a higher appetite for premium brands and products. Petico aims to offer a one-stop platform with pet products, boarding, grooming, and veterinary services, as well as pet insurance. The company plans to launch a customer reward program for affected customers and aims to break even by the end of the year, with sales expected to reach 50-60% of pre-insolvency levels within the next year.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
With more pet owners switching to less-processed meals for their cats and dogs, it's "meow or never" for industry players to meet the demand.
Rising pet ownership means growing demand for pet products and services – but not all parts of the industry are experiencing the same boom, as high costs, price wars and space limitations bite.
Paws-perous business: The booming pets trade that's also feeding an illicit market
The vet council will be a welcome addition to the local scene, says Singapore Veterinary Association president Chow Haoting.

site_title: Chinese buyout firm is said to consider sale of chip tester UTAC
summary: Wise Road Capital, a Beijing-based private equity firm, is considering selling semiconductor assembly and testing company UTAC Holdings for approximately $3 billion. The sale is still in its early stages, and Wise Road may decide not to proceed. UTAC, acquired by Wise Road in 2020, has production facilities in Singapore, China, Indonesia, and Thailand, and a sales network focused on the US, Europe, and Asia. Wise Road focuses on investments in semiconductors and high-tech industries, with investors including tech firms, financial institutions, and family offices.

site_title: Interactive: Get to know your GE2025 candidates
summary: Singapore's electoral boundaries review committee has been formed, marking the beginning of the road to the 2025 General Elections. The committee's aim is to review and potentially adjust the country's electoral boundaries. Meanwhile, FedEx has partnered with a Singapore startup, QuikBot, to deploy robots for commercial area deliveries. In other news, the country is setting up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Gan Kim Khong, is set to visit the US for trade talks, with a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs.

site_title: London rents surge, but why are landlords miserable?
summary: London's rental market has seen a surge in rents, with prices rising 9.1% over the past year, despite a 1.7% increase in house prices. The landlord exodus, driven by new environmental rules requiring minimum EPC ratings of C, has reduced the supply of rental properties, exacerbating the issue. Only 40% of rental properties meet or exceed this threshold, and the cost of upgrading to the required standard can be prohibitively expensive for landlords. This has led to a shortage of rentals, with the volume of properties available to let decreasing by 16% in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A row of residential houses is seen with the financial district in the distance in South London, Britain, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
Some 61 per cent of housebuilders described planning delays as a “significant barrier” to delivering new homes between January and March, down 27 percentage points from a year ago.

site_title: GE2025: West Coast sees repeat battle, with PSP’s Tan Cheng Bock leading team against PAP
summary: Singapore's West Coast-Jurong West GRC will be a closely watched battleground in the upcoming GE2025, with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) facing off against the Progress Singapore Party (PSP). PSP chairman Dr. Tan Cheng Bock, 85, is leading the party's team, while PAP's National Development Minister Desmond Lee will defend the constituency. The PSP also nominated first-time candidates Sumarleki Amjah and Sani Ismail. Meanwhile, PSP labour unionist Patrick Tay will defend his Pioneer seat against PSP candidate Stephanie Tan.

summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh will lead a team defending Aljunied GRC against the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in the May 3 general election. Singh's team includes two new faces, Fadli Fawzi and Kenneth Tiong, alongside incumbents Sylvia Lim and Gerald Giam. The PAP's team, led by Chan Hui Yuh, consists of four first-timers. Aljunied GRC is one of WP's strongholds, having been won by the party in 2011 and again in 2020.

site_title: Pope Francis' coffin carried to Saint Peter's Basilica
summary: Pope Francis' open coffin began a procession to Saint Peter's Basilica in Vatican City, accompanied by dozens of cardinals, Swiss Guards, and clergy. The Argentine pontiff, 88, died on Monday after suffering a stroke, coma, and heart failure. His funeral is set for Saturday, expected to draw huge crowds and leaders from across the globe. The procession passed through St. Peter's Square, where tens of thousands of onlookers gathered to pay their respects.

images.alt_text: The Vatican on Tuesday released photographs of Francis lying in the chapel of the Santa Marta residence.

site_title: Indonesia says US$9.8 billion EV battery project to continue with China’s Huayou after LG’s exit
summary: Indonesia's US$9.8 billion electric vehicle (EV) battery project, known as the Titan Project, will continue with China's Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt Co as the new strategic investor following LG Energy Solution's (LGES) withdrawal. The project, which was set to produce 10 GWh of battery cells annually, will proceed as scheduled with Huayou teaming up with Indonesia's state-owned mining companies to produce EV batteries. Despite LGES' pullout, Indonesian officials remain committed to positioning the country as a global hub for the EV industry, leveraging its abundant nickel reserves.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
“Taking into account various factors, including market conditions and investment environment, we have agreed to formally withdraw from the Indonesia GP (Grand Package) project,” LGES said.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party team led by He Ting Ru to defend Sengkang GRC, will face PAP team of mostly newcomers
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) team in Sengkang GRC, led by He Ting Ru, will defend against a People's Action Party (PAP) team of mostly newcomers in the 2025 general election. The WP candidates include Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik, who replaces former MP Raeesah Khan, and Associate Professor Jamus Lim. The PAP team, led by Lam Pin Min, includes first-time candidates Theodora Lai and Dr Elmie Nekmat. The WP aims to retain Sengkang GRC, which they won in 2020 with 52.13% of the vote.

site_title: GE2025: Edwin Tong heads PAP team in East Coast GRC; former NCMP Yee Jenn Jong makes comeback for WP
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will not contest the upcoming Singapore general election, instead opting not to file nomination papers for any constituency. Culture, Community and Youth Minister Edwin Tong will lead the People's Action Party's East Coast GRC team, while the Workers' Party's team will be led by former Non-Constituency MP Yee Jenn Jong. The election is scheduled for May 3, and both parties have announced their candidates.

site_title: Intel to announce plans this week to cut over 20% of staff
summary: Intel plans to cut over 20% of its staff, aiming to eliminate bureaucracy and rebuild an engineering-driven culture, according to a source. This is the first major restructuring under new CEO Tan Lip-Bu, who took the helm last month. The move follows an effort last year to slash 15,000 jobs and comes as the company struggles to catch up with rivals like Nvidia in AI computing. Intel's revenue declines are expected to continue, with analysts not projecting a return to previous sales levels for years.

images.alt_text: The news comes a day after Nvidia warned of a US$5.5 billion hit as Washington restricted exports of its AI processor tailored for China.
The leadership changes are the first major move under Lip-Bu Tan, who took the top job last month.
TSMC, the world’s largest contract chipmaker, will take a 20 per cent stake in the new company, the report says

site_title: SK Hynix likely unseated Samsung as Dram leader with AI boost
summary: SK Hynix is expected to replace Samsung as the world's top dynamic random access memory (Dram) vendor for the first time in decades, driven by demand for artificial intelligence (AI). SK Hynix captured 36% of the Dram market in the March quarter, surpassing Samsung's 34%. The company's lead in high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, crucial for AI, is expected to boost its operating profit. Despite the market facing challenges from US tariffs and recession fears, analysts predict SK Hynix's growth will continue, with the company forecast to hold over half of the HBM market in 2025.

images.alt_text: In January, SK Hynix forecast sales of its HBM chips would more than double this year.
SBI aims to collaborate with SK Hynix on back-end DRAM processes and with UMC on chips for vehicles, according to the report, which did not cite sources.
It is the first time that SK Hynix’s quarterly operating profit beat Samsung’s total operating profit, analysts said, as its rival lags in supplying high-end HBM chips to Nvidia.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust undergoes strategic review
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) is undergoing a strategic review, following a failed privatisation bid in 2022 and a surge in trading activity in November and December 2024. The manager has considered various options, including exploring options with the sponsor, but notes that there is no certainty or assurance that any transactions will arise. The manager will make announcements in due course if material developments warrant disclosure, urging investors to exercise caution and refrain from taking action that may be prejudicial to their interests.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
InterContinental Singapore (above) is a hotel parked in the Singapore portfolio of Frasers Hospitality Trust, which had a portfolio valuation of around S$2 billion as at Sep 30, 2024.
The superior bedroom in Capri by Fraser China Square. Only 74.88 per cent of shareholder votes were cast in favour of the take-private resolution; 75 per cent is required.

site_title: Economists see higher chance of MAS easing in July, as core inflation falls to four-year low in March
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) economists predict a higher chance of easing monetary policy in July due to core inflation falling to a four-year low of 0.5% in March. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, was marginally below February's 0.6% figure. Economists, including OCBC's Selena Ling and Barclays' Brian Tan, expect the MAS to loosen policy again, lowering the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band to neutral. The MAS maintains its official forecast ranges for core and headline inflation at 0.5-1.5% and 0.9%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Economists note the dovish tone of MAS' latest monetary policy statement.

site_title: Vietnam seeks more free trade deals to drive growth as Trump tariff looms
summary: Vietnam is seeking to negotiate new free trade agreements with countries such as India, Brazil, and Pakistan to mitigate the impact of US tariffs, which could undermine its export-reliant economy. The country has already signed 17 free trade agreements but has no deal with the US. In response to the looming tariffs, Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has urged the trade ministry to accelerate negotiations and implement measures to boost domestic consumption, investment in digital transformation, and infrastructure development to achieve a 8% GDP growth target for 2025.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh reiterated that Vietnamese goods do not compete with those of the US and that “bilateral trade relations so far have ultimately benefited US consumers while driving Vietnam’s export growth.”
Vietnam has been slapped by the Trump administration with 46 per cent “reciprocal” tariffs, currently paused until July.
Vietnam is a major exporter of footwear and apparel to the United States, manufactured by dozens of suppliers to large multinationals, such as Nike, Adidas and Gap.

site_title: GE2025: Three-way fight set for Potong Pasir’s single seat between PAP, PAR and SPP
summary: In the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2025), a three-way contest is expected for Potong Pasir's single seat between the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), the opposition coalition People's Alliance for Reform (PAR), and the Singapore People's Party (SPP). PAR's Lim Tean will face off against SPP's treasurer Williamson Lee and PAP's Alex Yeo. Meanwhile, PAR will contest the Jalan Besar Group Representation Constituency, while the PAP will maintain a strong presence in Mountbatten and Jalan Besar. The election is set to take place on May 3.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
PM Lawrence Wong (front) leads the PAP's team for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC, which comprises Senior Minister of State for Defence and Manpower Zaqy Mohamad, Alex Yam, and Hany Soh.

site_title: GE2025: PAP walkover at Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC; first since 2011
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) secured a walkover in the Marine Parade-Braddell Heights Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in Singapore's 2025 General Election, with its team elected unopposed. The PAP team, led by Goh Pei Ming, a former Singapore Armed Forces chief of staff, includes incumbent MPs and Minister of State Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim. The Workers' Party (WP) initially planned to contest the GRC but ultimately decided not to due to limited resources, citing demographic shifts. This is the first walkover for the PAP since 2011.

Yusof Ishak Secondary School will be where the candidates for three hot GRCs – East Coast, Sengkang and Punggol – will gather.
WP chief Pritam Singh (fourth from right) with the party's other elected MPs (from left) Dennis Tan, He Ting Ru, Faisal Manap, Gerald Giam, Jamus Lim, Sylvia Lim and Louis Chua.

Minister of State for Home Affairs and for National Development Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, Manpower Minister and Marine Parade GRC MP Tan See Leng, business development director Diana Pang and South East District Mayor Mohd Fahmi Aliman speaking to ST near Eunos Crescent Market and Food Centre on March 30.

site_title: GE2025 live updates: Who’s running in your constituency?
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong attended Nomination Day at Jurong Pioneer JC. It's Nomination Day for the upcoming general election in Singapore. The Business Times is providing live updates on the election.

site_title: 70% of lawyers believe they will fall behind if they do not start using gen-AI tools
summary: A survey of over 400 lawyers and legal professionals in Malaysia and Singapore reveals that 70% believe they will fall behind if they don't adopt generative AI tools. The survey found that 48% are confident in their understanding of the tools, and 66% are already using them, with law firms showing higher acceptance. Generative AI is seen as transformative, with 56% considering its impact to be significant. Lexis+ AI, a new offering, features conversational search, intelligent drafting, and document summarization capabilities.

site_title: GE2025: No surprises as PAP, SPP repeat Bishan-Toa Payoh face off
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) and Singapore People's Party (SPP) will face off in the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC in Singapore's general election, with the PAP team led by Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat and the SPP team led by Secretary-General Steve Chia. The PAP team includes fresh faces Cai Yinzhou and Elysa Chen, while the SPP team features new faces Muhammad Norhakim and Lim Rui Xian. The constituency, one of nine unchanged from the previous election, is expected to be a closely contested battle between the two parties.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat (centre) introduced two new faces Cai Yinzhou (second from left) and Elysa Chen (second from right) who will join his team with incumbent Saktiandi Supaat at the upcoming polls. Minister of State for Education and Manpower Gan Siow Huang will defend her seat in Marymount SMC.

site_title: ‘No coincidence’ that PAP reserved areas WP was interested in contesting to the end: Pritam Singh
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh says the ruling People's Action Party's (PAP) last-minute changes to its lineup are not a coincidence, as WP was expected to contest areas the PAP reserved for the end. The PAP switched Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong to Punggol GRC and Manpower Minister Tan See Leng to Chua Chu Kang GRC, while Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean was not fielded anywhere. WP will contest Tampines GRC, where it faces a four-cornered fight, while Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC will have a walkover due to the WP's decision not to contest.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

CMG20250423-HoKJ01 / 何家俊 / 林弘谕、张鹤杨、谢慧平、林煇智、陈紫筠、魏瑜嶙 / 大选提名日 [ Poi Ching School ] Aljunied GRC is led by Mr Singh, 48, and includes WP chair Sylvia Lim, 60, and Mr Gerald Giam, 47; new faces are Kenneth Tiong, 36, and Mr Fadli Fawzi
PAP's elected candidates for Marine Parade-Braddell Heights giving their thank you speeches.

site_title: GE2025: RDU takes on PAP incumbents in Holland-Bukit Timah GRC debut
summary: The opposition party Red Dot United (RDU) is set to challenge the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in the Holland-Bukit Timah Group Representation Constituency (GRC) for the first time. RDU's team, led by music teacher Emily Woo, includes assistant engineer Sharad Kumar, operations manager Nizar Subair, and financial consultant Fazli Talip. The team will face off against the incumbent PAP team, which includes Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs and National Development Sim Ann, lawyer Christopher de Souza, and businessman Edward Chia. The Bukit Panjang single-seat ward, a neighboring constituency, will also see a rematch between RDU's Paul Tambyah and four-term MP Liang Eng Hwa.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
With GE2025 looming, Singapore’s hottest GRCs could face nomination day curveballs. Which teams and candidates might upend the election narrative?
PAP's Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC slate featuring (from left) Cai Yinzhou,  Elysa Chen, Saktiandi Supaat and Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong arrives at Jurong Pioneer JC.
PAP's Grace Fu with the party's Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC candidates.

DPM Gan’s arrival at Yusof Ishak Secondary School on Wednesday (Apr 23) morning came as a surprise, as it was not the nomination centre for Chua Chu Kang GRC, where he was earlier introduced as the PAP team’s anchor minister.
Workers' Party Sengkang GRC candidates (from left) Jamus Lim, Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik, He Ting Ru, Louis Chua at Yusof Ishak Secondary School on Apr 23.
Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong (centre) helms the PAP's E

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Keppel Reit, Paragon Reit, BRC Asia, Frasers Hospitality Trust
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singapore companies saw new developments affecting trading of their securities on Wednesday. City Developments Limited (CDL) increased its offer to buy Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand shares to NZ$2.80 apiece, a 60% premium. Keppel Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported 13.3% year-on-year net property income growth to S$54.6 million. Paragon Reit's unitholders approved a privatization scheme, with the trust expected to delist on June 6. BRC Asia entered into a conditional share purchase agreement to buy a 55% stake in Southern Steel Mesh. Frasers Hospitality Trust's managers are reviewing the company's strategy.

site_title: GE2025 daily roundup: Nomination Day surprise moves, multi-cornered fights, election rally sites and more
summary: Singapore's GE2025 Nomination Day saw surprise moves, including the Workers' Party (WP) pulling out of Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC and Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong switching to Punggol GRC. Five multi-cornered fights will take place, including a four-way contest in Tampines GRC. Other notable decisions include the withdrawal of Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, former anchor minister for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, and the non-re-election of Senior Ministers of State Amy Khor and Heng Chee How. The police have released a list of designated sites for election meetings, with rallies set to take place from April 24 to May 1.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Therese Soh

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 distributable income falls 3.5% to S$48.4 million
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 3.5% decline in distributable income to S$48.4 million in Q1 2025, primarily due to higher borrowing costs. Despite this, net property income grew 13.3% to S$54.6 million, driven by better performance from Singapore and Australian properties. The Reit's portfolio occupancy remains at 96%, and its sustainability-focused funding accounts for 82% of total debt. The company's diversified portfolio is expected to enhance long-term growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Despite higher net property income, Keppel Reit's distributable income fell due to higher management fees and borrowing costs.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as Trump comments ease Fed, China trade fears
summary: Asian markets rallied as US President Donald Trump eased concerns about the Federal Reserve, stating he has no intention of firing Jerome Powell. Trump also indicated a willingness to slash tariffs on China, which had been causing fears of a global economic crisis. The comments boosted Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul, while Taipei and Singapore rose significantly. Gold prices retreated, and the dollar recovered against major currencies, following a surge in markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo led the gains even as data showed Japanese inflation accelerated last month as rice prices more than doubled.

site_title: GE2025: PAR fields Tanjong Pagar GRC team with former independent Han Hui Hui; Radin Mas sees three-way fight
summary: In the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2025), the People's Action Party (PAP) has fielded a five-member team for Tanjong Pagar GRC, led by Education Minister Chan Chun Sing as the sole full minister. The PAP faces a challenge from the People's Alliance for Reform (PAR) team, which includes former independent candidate Han Hui Hui. Meanwhile, a three-way contest is expected in Radin Mas SMC, with PAP incumbent Melvin Yong and PAR's Kumar Appavoo facing off against independent candidate Darryl Lo.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
With GE2025 looming, Singapore’s hottest GRCs could face nomination day curveballs. Which teams and candidates might upend the election narrative?

site_title: Tesla says profits plunge 71%, warns of ‘changing political sentiment’
summary: Tesla reported a 71% drop in first-quarter profits to $409 million, citing a 9% decline in revenues to $19.3 billion. The company attributed the decline to "changing political sentiment" and uncertainty over trade policy, which may impact demand for its products. Tesla also retreated from its 2025 guidance, citing unpredictability in the market. Despite this, the company remains on track to launch new, more affordable vehicles in the first half of 2025 and its robotaxi launch is still scheduled for June.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect sales to fall again this year for several reasons, including damage to the brand reputation by chief executive Elon Musk’s (above) close work with US President Donald Trump and support of far-right European politicians.
Tesla’s Shanghai factory only makes Model 3 and Model Y cars and most of them are either sold in China or exported to other parts of Asia.
Tesla’s entry into Saudi Arabia is a fresh signal Musk has mended relations with the kingdom after a spat with Yasir Al Rumayyan, head of the US$925 billion PIF.

(FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. Tesla reported a 13 percent drop in first quarter auto sales April 2, 2025, amid lower production during factory upgrades and blowback over CEO Elon Musk's work for President Donald Trump's administration. Musk's electric vehicle company delivered 336,681 autos in the quarter ending March 31, missing analyst expectations, as it pointed to the "loss of several weeks of production" while it ramps up upgrades for its Model Y output. (Photo by Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo / AFP)

site_title: IMF slashes global outlook as White House says trade talks pick up pace
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has slashed its global growth outlook for 2025 to 2.8%, its poorest showing since the Covid-19 pandemic, due to US President Donald Trump's steep tariffs on trading partners. The IMF projects US growth to drop to 1.8% in 2025 and China's growth to 4% this year and next. The White House says trade talks with countries are picking up pace, with 18 countries offering proposals to lower tariffs. Trump expressed optimism about a trade deal with China that could substantially lower tariffs, lifting markets.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - An aerial view shows cargo containers stacked at a port in Shanghai on April 20, 2025. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Many participants in the meetings have questions over the Trump administration’s support for the IMF and the World Bank.

IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says the current tariff tensions would likely have three major consequences for the global economy, with smaller advanced economies and most emerging markets likely to be more heavily affected due to their reliance on trade for growth.

site_title: US stocks soar on White House optimism on China trade deal
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.7% to 39,186.98, as Trump administration officials expressed optimism about a potential US-China trade deal. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and White House spokesperson Karoline Leavitt stated that the tit-for-tat tariff war would de-escalate soon. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 2.5% and 2.7%, respectively. However, the International Monetary Fund reduced its forecast for global growth due to US President Donald Trump's new tariff policies.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: South Korea to seek speedy solution on auto tariffs in US trade talks
summary: South Korea will hold trade talks in Washington on Thursday to address US-imposed auto tariffs, which have been paused for 90 days. The US introduced 10% blanket tariffs and 25% auto and steel tariffs, affecting South Korea's $34.7 billion auto exports to the US. Industry Minister Ahn Duk-geun plans to seek a speedy solution for the auto tariffs, while also preparing for discussions on defense costs related to US troops in South Korea. The talks aim to find a mutually beneficial solution to the trade tensions between the two countries.

images.alt_text: The Korea Customs Service has launched a special task force to prevent illegal export attempts and plans to come up with more specific response measures to protect domestic companies.
South Korea is the US’s sixth-biggest trading partner, with the Asian country’s surplus jumping about 25 per cent in 2024 from the previous year to about US$55.7 billion.

“There are concerns about some companies struggling with liquidity difficulties due to the global trade conflict sparked by US tariffs and a delayed recovery in domestic demand,” Acting President Han Duck-soo says.

site_title: Public-private partnerships are the key to unlocking sovereign AI in Asia-Pacific
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is witnessing a surge in sovereign AI initiatives, with 33% of AI investments allocated to these efforts. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) are crucial in unlocking the potential of AI, enabling collaborative frameworks for combining government resources and private sector innovation. Three models of sovereign AI have emerged, with "government with industry" holding the greatest promise for accelerating AI adoption. However, existing inequalities will be exacerbated as major economies build sovereign AI capabilities, and targeted support is needed to address challenges such as infrastructure, talent, and skill sets.

images.alt_text: Huawei Atlas 800 inference server is displayed at InnoEX Fair, in Hong Kong, China April 15, 2025. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: German software maker SAP beats operating profit estimates for first quarter
summary: German software maker SAP reported an adjusted operating profit of 2.5 billion euros for the first quarter, beating analysts' estimates of 2.22 billion euros. SAP continues to expect cloud revenues between 21.6 billion and 21.9 billion euros for the year, driven by a boom in artificial intelligence. The company's shares have roughly doubled in value over the past two years, and SAP expects restructuring costs of around three billion euros due to the era of AI.

images.alt_text: NUS and SAP Labs will collaborate in training new AI researchers in Singapore.
SAP has prospered even as Germany’s economy stalls, with gross domestic product forecast to contract for a consecutive second year in 2024.
SAP named Christian Klein as chairman of the executive board and extended his contract as CEO.
SAP has been seeking to migrate customers from its legacy on-premise software to the cloud, where it is offering business AI services to sweeten the deal.

site_title: More nominee shareholders, accounts could be detrimental to investor protection
summary: Dasin Retail Trust (DRT) has seen significant losses due to a regulatory clampdown in China and Covid-19 challenges. The trust's large unitholders have been wrangling with the trustee-manager over the management of nominee accounts, which has hindered the company's ability to hold shareholder meetings and pass resolutions. The issue highlights the challenge for listed issuers operating with stakes held through nominee accounts, potentially compromising investor protection and the company's ability to operate effectively. The Singaporean government may need to address this issue through legislation to make the stock market more vibrant.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan

site_title: US Treasury chief expects China tariff impasse to de-escalate
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent expects a de-escalation in the US-China trade standoff, citing a need for fair trade and a reciprocal trade embargo. The US has imposed 145% tariffs on Chinese imports since Donald Trump's White House return in January, while China has retaliated with 125% tariffs on US goods. Trump predicts the tariffs will "come down substantially," but not to zero. The de-escalation is seen as a relief to markets, which have been affected by the ongoing trade tensions.

images.alt_text: In a series of moves, Washington has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 per cent, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125 per cent on US goods.

epa12038805 A Chinese flag is seen on the Shanghai Container Terminal, in Shanghai, China, 18 April 2025. China announced 125 percent tariffs on US goods effective 12 April, raising its previous rate of 84 percent, in response to the latest US tariffs, which effectively total 145 percent.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI
The spat over ocean shipping is the latest conflict in an intensifying trade war between China and the US that has pushed levies on each other’s imports beyond 100 per cent.

The trade war has all but frozen the mammoth trade between the world’s two largest economies, with tariffs over 100 per cent in each direction and a suite of trade, investment and cultural restrictions.

site_title: Europe: Shares close higher as financials, L’Oreal rise; Fed spat still a worry
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, driven by a 6.3% gain in L'Oreal, its best single-day gain in nearly seven months. Financials and post-earnings gains also contributed to the increase. However, investor concerns over US President Donald Trump's criticism of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell and heightened global trade tensions remained. The International Monetary Fund slashed its growth forecasts, citing the impact of US tariffs. Despite this, the ECB's Survey of Professional Forecasters indicated euro zone inflation could be slightly higher this year than earlier thought, stabilizing at the 2% target.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended 0.1 per cent lower, though clocked a more than 4 per cent weekly jump in a holiday-shortened week.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after selloff
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, April 22, following a sharp selloff in the previous session due to President Donald Trump's criticism of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones rose 345.8 points, or 0.91%, to 38,516.23, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, driven by investors focusing on corporate earnings.

site_title: CEOs haven’t been this gloomy about the US economy since the financial crisis
summary: US CEOs have expressed pessimism about the economy, with 27% of S&P 500 firms cutting their 2025 guidance, the lowest since the financial crisis. The shift in sentiment is attributed to uncertainty from the White House's rapidly changing policies, including trade war implications. Executives struggle to gauge the impact, leading to reduced forecasts for carmakers and transports, and lower profit expectations for Kimberly-Clark. The market is expected to remain volatile until the tariff negotiations are resolved.

images.alt_text: According to a weekly sales survey by industry association Footwear Distributors and Retailers of America, in the eleven weeks since Donald Trump’s inauguration, shoe sales in stores are down 9.5 per cent from the same period last year.
Walmart is prepping for a worsening economy by using its massive footprint to keep prices low and hunt for ways to take market share as tariff-spooked shoppers begin pulling back on spending.
Inflation is likely to be elevated, Larry Fink says, casting doubt on the Federal Reserve cutting rates multiple times this year.

site_title: US dollar close to multi-year lows vs euro, Swiss franc as Trump attacks the Fed
summary: The US dollar is near multi-year lows against the euro and Swiss franc due to President Donald Trump's attacks on the Federal Reserve, which has raised concerns about the central bank's independence. The dollar fell 0.40% against the yen, while the euro and Swiss franc rose against it. Analysts believe the dollar's value as a reserve currency is under threat, with possible divestments from US assets. Market concerns also surround the US administration's tariffs, which could trigger a global trade war.

images.alt_text: The dollar sank to a decade-low against the Swiss franc, the euro broke above US$1.15 while the New Zealand dollar reclaimed the US$0.6000 level for the first time in more than five months.

site_title: Trump floats cutting China tariffs ‘substantially’ in trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced plans to cut China tariffs "substantially" in a trade deal, signaling a potential shift in his tough stance on Beijing amid market volatility. Trump said he will be "very nice" to China and that tariffs will drop if a deal is reached, following comments from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent that the standoff was unsustainable. China has not officially responded, but optimism over the possibility of softened tensions has boosted Chinese stocks and the offshore yuan.

images.alt_text: That de-escalation will come in the very near future, Bessent says.
In a series of moves, Washington has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 per cent, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125 per cent on US goods.

epa12038805 A Chinese flag is seen on the Shanghai Container Terminal, in Shanghai, China, 18 April 2025. China announced 125 percent tariffs on US goods effective 12 April, raising its previous rate of 84 percent, in response to the latest US tariffs, which effectively total 145 percent.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI
The spat over ocean shipping is the latest conflict in an intensifying trade war between China and the US that has pushed levies on each other’s imports beyond 100 per cent.

site_title: Gold eases as Trump backs off from threats to fire Fed chair
summary: US President Donald Trump backed off threats to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, easing gold prices. Spot gold fell 1.2% to $3,340.92 an ounce, while US gold futures declined 2% to $3,349.20. Trump expressed optimism about a trade deal with China, potentially reducing tariffs. The US dollar regained ground after hitting a three-year low, making gold more expensive for other currency holders.

images.alt_text: Gold has hit multiple record highs and gained more than 30 per cent so far this year.

site_title: Boeing to sell Jeppesen unit to Thoma Bravo for US$10.55 billion
summary: Boeing is selling its navigation unit Jeppesen to private equity firm Thoma Bravo for $10.55 billion, part of CEO Kelly Ortberg's plan to reduce debt by offloading non-core assets. Thoma Bravo edged out rival firms in the auction, valuing Jeppesen at over $8 billion. Boeing will retain core digital capabilities, including fleet maintenance and diagnostics services. The deal is one of the largest carve-out transactions in recent years, following similar sales by Ball Corp and British Airways. The transaction is expected to close by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Boeing model is seen at the second China International Import Expo (CIIE) in Shanghai, China November 6, 2019. Aly Song/File Photo
Air India’s growth is also set to slow because of a retrofit programme that will temporarily remove some jets from its fleet, and a plan to phase out some Airbus models.

site_title: US punishing tariffs put South-east Asian solar exporters’ China Plus One strategy in a bind
summary: The US has imposed tariffs as high as 3,500% on solar imports from Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, potentially disrupting the region's role as a key manufacturing hub for Chinese energy giants. The tariffs, set in response to US manufacturers' complaints of unfair trade, are expected to slow the expansion of South-east Asia's solar manufacturing sector. However, some experts see a silver lining, with closer China-Asean ties and a glut of solar panel supply potentially lowering costs and accelerating the region's low-carbon transition.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The new solar levies will be in addition to new widespread tariffs imposed by Trump that have upended global supply chains and markets.

Generic photos of solar panels on the roof of Blk 965 & Blk 964 Hougang Ave 9 taken on June 4, 2021. 

Can be use for solar energy, clean energy, climate change stories 

Generics shot on June 4, 2021, of property, solar panels, cars on the road for COE stories.

site_title: GE2025: Tampines GRC to see first four-cornered fight since 1992
summary: The 2025 Singapore general election will feature a four-cornered contest in Tampines GRC, the first since 1992. The People's Action Party (PAP) will face opposition from the Workers' Party (WP), the People's Power Party (PPP), and the National Solidarity Party (NSP). WP has fielded four new faces, while NSP and PPP have also introduced new candidates. Tampines GRC has 148,119 registered voters and is the fifth-largest constituency. The election will take place on May 3, with party political broadcasts scheduled for April 25 and May 1.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
With GE2025 looming, Singapore’s hottest GRCs could face nomination day curveballs. Which teams and candidates might upend the election narrative?
In GE2020, labour chief Ng Chee Meng contested Sengkang GRC, but lost to the Workers' Party.
Singapore election 2025: Changes to Singapore’s electoral divisions with more MPs, new GRCs and SMCs
(From left) Former chief of army David Neo and Social and Family Development Minister Masagos Zulkifli posing for photos with a resident at Our Tampines Hub on April 12.

site_title: Trump says he has no intention of firing Fed chief Powell
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he has no intention of firing Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, despite criticism over the central bank's interest rate decisions. Trump expressed frustration with the Fed's slow pace in cutting interest rates, but emphasized that he has no intention of firing Powell. The news comes after a series of public comments and social media posts by Trump criticizing the Fed, which rattled markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell attends a press conference, following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy, in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard/File Photo
“I strongly hope that we do not move ourselves into an environment where monetary independence is in question,” Goolsbee says.
Trump insists he has the power to oust Powell (R) if he wanted to, despite the Fed’s status as an independent agency.
“Our independence is a matter of law,” Fed chair Powell said at the Economic Club of Chicago.

site_title: BRC Asia signs pact to buy majority stake in Southern Steel Mesh for RM61 million
summary: BRC Asia has signed a pact to buy a 55% controlling stake in Southern Steel Mesh for RM61 million (S$18.2 million). The acquisition aligns with BRC's strategy to tap regional markets and diversify revenue streams, leveraging Southern Steel's established market presence in Malaysia. Southern Steel Mesh owns four manufacturing plants in Malaysia, with a book value of RM106.5 million as of Sep 30, 2024. The deal is conditional on passing an ordinary resolution by Southern Steel's shareholders by Jul 31.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
BRC Asia said that its sales order book stood at approximately S$1.5 billion as at Dec 31, 2024.

site_title: GE2025: PAP faces SDP, NSP in three-corner fight for Sembawang GRC
summary: The 2025 Singapore General Election (GE2025) will feature a three-way fight in Sembawang GRC, with the People's Action Party (PAP) facing off against teams from the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and National Solidarity Party (NSP). SDP's Chee Soon Juan will contest Sembawang West SMC against incumbent PAP MP Poh Li San, while PAP and NSP contest Nee Soon GRC. The NSP team will be led by Minister for Law K Shanmugam, and SDP's team will be led by Bryan Lim.

site_title: Tokyo’s newest art star: one-year-old Thumbelina
summary: One-year-old Thumbelina, a toddler from Ukraine, has gained attention as a talented artist with vibrant and abstract paintings on sale for 33,000 yen (S$305) at her debut show in Tokyo. Gallery director Dan Isomura describes her style as "babyish but mysteriously dexterous," and credits her mother for assisting with the creative process. Thumbelina's unique style and seemingly intentional brushstrokes have drawn admiration from art enthusiasts, who see her as a refreshing example of a young creative mind.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Lucie Chang Fine Arts' booth at Art Basel Hong Kong 2023.
Angela Tan, executive director of Art:Dis, emphasises the importance of accessibility and showcasing diverse voices in the arts.
"The Lighthouse at Casquets" by French author Victor Hugo; the exhibition of about 70 drawings seeks to address the relationship between his artistic and literary work.

site_title: IMF slashes China growth forecasts as trade war deepens
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised down its forecast for China's economic growth, predicting a 4% expansion this year, slower than the 4.6% predicted in January. The downward pressure is attributed to a persistent crisis in the property sector, local government debt, and sluggish consumer spending. The US-China trade war, which has sparked global recession fears, is also a major contributor to the slowdown. The IMF's revised forecast is below Beijing's official target of 5% annual growth, and reflects doubts about the ability of the Chinese economy to withstand mounting domestic pressures and export hurdles.

images.alt_text: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says the current tariff tensions would likely have three major consequences for the global economy, with smaller advanced economies and most emerging markets likely to be more heavily affected due to their reliance on trade for growth.

site_title: Trump Media pushes forward with pivot to crypto, ETF plans
summary: US President Donald Trump's social media firm, Trump Media & Technology Group, has reached a binding agreement to launch a series of retail investment products, including crypto and exchange-traded funds (ETFs), in its bid to diversify into financial services. The plan, aligned with Trump's America First policies, is expected to launch later this year, subject to regulatory approval. This follows a preliminary agreement reached between Trump Media and Crypto.com, a digital asset platform, and Yorkville America Digital, an affiliate of Yorkville Advisors.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks on tariff woes, services perk up: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank for the 10th consecutive month in April due to declining manufacturer confidence, largely influenced by US President Donald Trump's tariff policies. However, the service sector showed signs of improvement, with the services PMI expanding to 52.2 in April, driven by customer demand and sales growth. The combined composite PMI also returned to growth, standing at 51.1.

images.alt_text: Price gains are still high by Japan’s standards after more than a decade of deflation.
US trade tariffs are shaking up Japan’s industrial supply chains, particularly for automobiles, the country’s biggest export item.

Tourists walk past shops and restaurants up the hill leading to Kiyomizu-dera Temple in the city of Kyoto on January 13, 2025. Japan on January 15 will announce tourist figures for the year 2024, widely expected to break the record set in 2019. (Photo by PAUL MILLER / AFP)

site_title: How to forecast a recession
summary: US recession forecast is uncertain due to Trump's trade tariffs, making traditional indicators ineffective. The inverted yield curve, a common recession predictor, is no longer reliable as the 10-year bond rate and 3-month Treasury rate are now at the same level. The yield curve primarily reflects financial-market expectations of a potential rate cut by the US Federal Reserve, rather than actual economic activity. This ambiguity leaves investors and policymakers uncertain about the likelihood of a recession, making it challenging to navigate the economic landscape.
