site_title: Oil prices settle up nearly 2% on new Iran sanctions, equities rally
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Tuesday, driven by new US sanctions against Iran and a rebound in equity markets. Brent crude futures rose $1.18 to settle at $67.44 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude contract gained $1.23 to close at $64.32. The US issued fresh sanctions targeting an Iranian liquefied petroleum gas and crude oil shipping magnate, which could weigh heavily on Iran's oil exports. Equity markets also rebounded on signs of a potential de-escalation in US-China trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were down US$1.70, or 2.5 per cent, at US$66.26 a barrel

site_title: Structured solutions provider Marex sees rising demand for notes with capital protection
summary: Structured products provider Marex expects rising demand for notes with capital protection amid market volatility, driven by investors seeking to mitigate losses. The firm has seen a notable pickup in demand for minimum redemption notes (MRNs) linked to US equities, Hong Kong equities, and precious metals, with a focus on shorter tenors. Marex is also helping clients restructure existing notes, offering customized solutions to recover losses more quickly. The company attributes the growing demand to Asian investors' familiarity with structured products and their preference for simple, transparent products with guaranteed returns.

site_title: Ericsson expands manufacturing in India to make antennas
summary: Ericsson plans to manufacture all its telecom antennas for the Indian market in the country by June, localizing production to meet domestic needs. The company, which started manufacturing in India in 1994, will partner with VVDN Technologies in Gurgaon. A significant portion of the antennas will be exported to other countries, including the US, after meeting domestic demands. This move comes as demand from Indian telecom companies surged in 2023 due to 5G services.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 22)
summary: Nomination Day for GE2025 will see prospective candidates file papers at nine centres across Singapore. Sino Group chairman Robert Ng and his children have been designated as politically significant persons under foreign interference law. The Economic Development Board launched a programme to help business founders launch and scale their next venture from Singapore. Paragon Reit unitholders approved a privatisation offer, and ERA signed a memorandum of understanding with NTUC to strengthen real estate agents' welfare and upskilling. Singapore stocks ended higher on Tuesday, with the STI up 1%.

site_title: Google’s money-printing machine can be easily dismantled
summary: A US district court judge ruled that Google's advertising business can be easily dismantled, a significant blow to the company's profits. The decision, part of a broader antitrust case, threatens to split Google's ad business, taking the ad server side and ad exchange side and divesting them. This remedy is seen as a clear and effective solution, unlike the more complex remedy in a previous search engine case. Alphabet shares fell 1% following the ruling, while smaller ad tech platforms surged. The decision is seen as a step towards promoting competition in the online advertising market.

images.alt_text: The amount of money that Google pays to Samsung was not revealed in court.
The US Department of Justice is heading into trial after two major legal victories against Google, having won a ruling in August that Google monopolised search.

site_title: ERA partners NTUC to strengthen real estate agents’ welfare and upskilling
summary: ERA Singapore partners with NTUC to enhance real estate agents' welfare and upskilling, covering staff training, workplace support, and healthcare benefits. The collaboration aims to support ERA's workforce amid industry transformation and equip employees with critical skills to navigate a rapidly evolving real estate landscape. The partnership also includes access to the Union Training Assistance Programme and discounted healthcare services, with the goal of transforming businesses and jobs through the Company Training Committee initiative.

site_title: Huawei’s expansion in smart driving stirs competition, scrutiny
summary: Huawei has cemented a dominant position in China's electric vehicle (EV) market by creating intelligent driving software for major brands such as BYD, BMW, and Audi. The company's smart driving solutions unit turned profitable last year, with revenue more than quintupled. However, Huawei's insistence on maintaining control over its ecosystem makes it unlikely to sign up customers overseas. The company's strategy, known as the Harmony Intelligent Mobility Alliance, aims to provide end-users with vehicles equipped with Huawei's software. Western governments, particularly the US, are wary of Huawei due to its alleged ties to the Chinese government, which may restrict its growth ambitions.

site_title: Tariffs challenge: What markets are and aren’t pricing in
summary: Global equity markets have reversed the Trump election-inspired valuation optimism, with US stocks falling and European and Chinese equity markets unwinding their early-2025 gains. Despite this, earnings expectations have not yet corrected enough to price in a recessionary scenario feared by bond markets. Instead, markets are pricing in a weak growth environment, with US Treasury yields closer to recessionary expectations. Gold prices have surged, breaching $3,400 an ounce, and a structurally weak greenback is unfolding, driving gold towards $4,000 per ounce by early 2026. Fiscal policies, including Trump's tax cuts and Germany's fiscal spending, may also impact global economic growth prospects.

images.alt_text: In a series of moves, Washington has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 per cent, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125 per cent on US goods.

Trump has upended the global trading system that has been in place for over 75 years with a plan for tariffs on products from across the world.

site_title: Can President Trump actually fire Fed chief Powell?
summary: US President Donald Trump has intensified his attacks on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, criticizing him for not cutting interest rates quickly enough and calling for his "termination". Powell warned that Trump's tariffs are "very fundamental policy changes" that put the Fed in uncharted waters. Trump has repeatedly threatened to remove Powell from his post, but the president's authority to do so is unclear, with some arguing that removing a Fed chair is "not permitted under the law". The Supreme Court is set to revisit a 1935 case that established precedent over the president's power to remove agency heads, which could weaken the Fed's independence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell attends a press conference, following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy, in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard/File Photo
The dollar sank to a decade-low against the Swiss franc, the euro broke above US$1.15 while the New Zealand dollar reclaimed the US$0.6000 level for the first time in more than five months.
“Our independence is a matter of law,” Fed chair Powell said at the Economic Club of Chicago.

site_title: Indian banks hit record as new RBI liquidity rules boost outlook
summary: Indian banks reached a record high as the Reserve Bank of India eased liquidity rules, boosting investor confidence in the sector's credit growth recovery. The Nifty Bank Index jumped 1.2% with HDFC Bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank, and State Bank of India leading the gains. The move is expected to improve banks' liquidity coverage ratio, freeing up capital for lending. Analysts attribute the rally to the RBI's measures, including rate cuts and easing lending rules, which are expected to put the sector on pace to outperform Asian peers this month.

images.alt_text: UBS will take over serving 360 ONE’s clients in Singapore, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: South-east Asia’s place in the sun just got dimmer
summary: US tariffs on solar exports from South-east Asia, including Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Cambodia, threaten the region's solar industry. Tariffs as high as 813.9% in Cambodia and 813.9% in Vietnam could reshape investment flows, supply chains, and export priorities. Industry players have already begun restructuring supply chains, with some shifting focus to domestic use, intra-Asean sales, and new locations like the Middle East. The impact on Vietnam's solar power sector is expected to be significant, while Malaysia's domestic sector may benefit from the oversupply. Thailand sees opportunities to expand domestic use of solar products and scale up regional sales.

site_title: GE2025: Ong Ye Kung to lead PAP team in Sembawang GRC, Poh Li San to stand in Sembawang West SMC
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung will lead the PAP's five-member team in Sembawang GRC, alongside two new faces, Ng Shi Xuan and Gabriel Lam. Poh Li San, the incumbent MP in Sembawang West, will contest the new single seat against SDP chief Chee Soon Juan. The PAP's final slate reveal comes ahead of Nomination Day on April 23, leaving the ruling party's plans for Tanjong Pagar GRC and other constituencies open.

site_title: Permira shuts Hong Kong, Shanghai offices in pivot to India
summary: Permira Holdings is closing its Hong Kong and Shanghai offices, relocating fewer than 10 professional staff to other offices, as part of its Asia strategy pivot to India. The London-headquartered firm sees India as a key market for growth, leveraging its English-speaking economy and rapid digitization. Siddarth Narayan, managing director and head of India, will become head for Asia later this year. Permira will continue to cover Australia and New Zealand through its India, Singapore, and global sector teams, maintaining its presence in the region.

site_title: China may better withstand Trump tariffs this time
summary: China appears to be better equipped to withstand US tariffs this time, with the country mobilizing its resources and public resolve to counter the impact. The MSCI China Index has shown greater resilience, with a decent year-to-date return of 6%, compared to other key markets. China's "fight-to-the-end" stance has resonated among its people, driving investor and consumer confidence, and the state-backed funds have injected billions into state-owned enterprises to stabilize the equity market. While the economic cost of the trade conflict remains significant, China is pivoting towards a more consumption-driven growth model, with ample room for monetary easing and potential upside opportunities in defensive, dividend-paying stocks.

images.alt_text: (FILES) US President Joe Biden meets with US President-elect Donald Trump in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2024. "We are immediately revoking Joe Biden's Security Clearances, and stopping his daily Intelligence Briefings," Trump said on his Truth Social network, adding in capitals: "JOE, YOU'RE FIRED." China’s top leaders have maintained an economic growth target of “around 5 per cent” for 2025.
BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.

site_title: Trade talks with US should not hurt other markets, says Vietnam’s PM
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has instructed his negotiation team to prepare for tariff talks with the US, ensuring consistency with existing international commitments and preventing negative impacts on other markets. The talks aim to address a 46% US duty on Vietnamese goods and address concerns over Chinese goods being shipped to the US via Vietnam to sidestep tariffs. Vietnam has vowed to purchase more American goods and has taken steps to crack down on origin of goods fraud.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has been slapped by the Trump administration with 46 per cent “reciprocal” tariffs, currently paused until July.

site_title: Offshore renminbi funding costs in Hong Kong sink to record low
summary: The offshore renminbi's one-month Hong Kong interbank offered rate (Hibor) dropped to 1.46%, a record low since 2013, amid expectations Beijing will keep liquidity ample to boost its economy and allow a managed renminbi depreciation. The renminbi slipped 0.3% to around 7.31 per US dollar, driven by a weak US dollar and a global exodus from US assets. Mainland investors purchased a net HK$14.1 billion of offshore renminbi shares, further pushing Hibor lower.

Whether or not the central bank decides to let the yuan go now, China’s financial markets look set to be challenged by high volatility.
China has for years been promoting the internationalisation of its yuan and sees stability – without extreme moves in either direction – as being key to further success on that front.
The PBOC has capped the yuan’s drop this year to its daily reference rate, which limits moves in the onshore yuan by 2 per cent on either side.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 22, 2025
summary: The yen strengthened past 140 per dollar for the first time since September, while the rupiah is expected to extend losses due to Bank Indonesia's efforts to combat volatility. The US imposed new duties on solar imports from South-east Asia, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Bitcoin rallies 20% during market turmoil to diverge from tech
summary: Bitcoin rallied 20% to its highest level since early March, diverging from US tech stocks amid market turmoil. The surge, driven by a slumping US dollar, offers relief for crypto bulls and fuels the decoupling narrative. Bitcoin's price is now trading well below its pre-Trump return level, and its trading pattern is increasingly resembling that of gold. This could bolster the long-term Bitcoin bull case as a store of value, with some analysts predicting further gains to the US$92,000-US$94,000 range.

images.alt_text: Investors in structured notes linked to stocks which were hit by severe volatility may choose to restructure their notes.

The divergence is a departure from the long-time correlation between Bitcoin and stocks, in which the digital asset typically experiences larger price swings.

site_title: Elias Green’s collective sale closes with no bids
summary: The collective sale tender for Elias Green condominium in District 18, Singapore, closed on April 22 with no bids, moving into a 10-week private treaty period. The property, completed in 1994, has a guide price of S$928 million, reflecting a land rate of S$1,355 per square foot per plot ratio. The site is zoned for residential use and has 65 years left on its current lease. This follows the sale of Thomson View for S$810 million in November 2024 and River Valley Apartments for S$56 million in February 2025.

Located in District 18, the 419-unit condominium sits on a land area of 48,019 sq m.

site_title: Vietnam cracks down on fraud on US exports, document shows
summary: Vietnam's trade ministry has issued a directive to crack down on illegal transhipment of goods to the US and other trading partners to avoid steep US tariffs. The directive, effective April 15, instructs officials to strengthen supervision and inspection of imported goods, especially those used for production and export. This move comes amid growing tension over US tariffs, which have been paused until July. The directive aims to prevent trade fraud and prevent countries from applying sanctions on imported goods.

Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (right) and Chinese President Xi Jinping shake hands at the Office of the Party Central Committee in Hanoi, Vietnam on Apr 14.

site_title: Walmart-backed Flipkart to shift base back to India from Singapore
summary: Flipkart, an e-commerce company backed by Walmart, is shifting its holding company from Singapore to India. This move aligns with its core operations and follows other Indian startups that have returned from financial hubs due to better IPO prospects in India. Flipkart, which started in 2007, had previously moved its holding company to Singapore in 2011. The shift is seen as part of Walmart's plans to list Flipkart and PhonePe, a digital payments company, in India over the next couple of years.

site_title: Meta appoints new Singapore country director Nicole Tan
summary: Meta appoints Nicole Tan as its new country director for Singapore, effective June 2, 2025. Tan, with over 25 years of industry experience, will focus on digital innovation, AI, and supporting Singapore's digital economy. She replaces Damian Kim and brings expertise from her previous roles in Malaysia and China. Tan stated that Singapore is a dynamic market driving South-east Asia's digital transformation, and she looks forward to working with the team to unlock growth through technology.

images.alt_text: Dan Neary, Meta’s vice-president for the region, assumed the role in 2013 and oversaw the rapid expansion of the company’s user base from Australia to Greater China and South-east Asia.

site_title: The yen strengthens past 140 per dollar for the first time since September
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened past 140 per dollar for the first time since September, driven by investors seeking alternatives to the US dollar amid increasing risks for US assets. The yen rose 0.7% to 139.90, its strongest level since September, and is the best performer among Group-of-10 currencies. President Donald Trump's trade war has boosted demand for haven assets, and investors are closely watching a meeting between Japanese and US finance chiefs, which may further appreciate the yen.

site_title: UBS resets India strategy with 360 ONE deal
summary: UBS is selling its Indian wealth business to 360 ONE WAM, a Mumbai-based asset manager, in a deal worth $220 million. The Swiss bank will take a nearly 5% stake in 360 ONE and focus on investment banking and equity capital markets in India. The transaction, which is subject to regulatory approvals, will allow 360 ONE to offer global wealth solutions to its Indian client base and expand its services. The deal marks UBS's efforts to consolidate its global business platforms and sharpen its focus in key markets amid regulatory concerns.

site_title: In GE2025, podcasts have emerged as a potent tool for politicians to engage voters
summary: In Singapore's 2025 general election, podcasts have become a popular tool for politicians to engage voters, offering a shift from traditional, polished content to more nuanced conversations. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and opposition figures have used podcasts to connect with young voters, showcasing their personalities and stumbles. Experts say podcasts enable authentic engagement, bridging the gap between politicians and the public, and have emerged as a key medium in Singapore's digital landscape.

site_title: Roche to invest US$50 billion in US to avoid Trump tariffs, create 12,000 jobs
summary: Roche, a Swiss pharmaceutical giant, plans to invest US$50 billion in the US over the next five years, creating over 12,000 new jobs. The investment will include 6,500 construction positions and 1,000 jobs at new and expanded facilities. Roche aims to export more medicines from the US than it imports, thanks to US sales accounting for nearly 48% of its revenue. The move is in response to US President Donald Trump's tariff policy, which has prompted other companies, including Novartis and Eli Lilly, to announce significant investments in the US.

images.alt_text: Novartis joins a growing number of multinational drug companies to announce investments in the US this year.

site_title: Apple iPhone prices could spike as much as 7% in this tariff scenario, Citi estimates
summary: Apple iPhone prices could increase by up to 7% globally if the US imposes tariffs on China and India, according to a Citi report. The tech giant is expected to pass on the costs to consumers, with iPhone shipments estimated to decline by 1% in 2025. Suppliers, such as Luxshare and Lens Tech, are unlikely to accept price cuts to share tariff costs, but their profits may still be affected. The US tariff pause on China-made goods has been temporary, with the Trump administration threatening to review the entire electronics supply chain.

images.alt_text: The next major company catalyst that investors will be watching is Apple’s quarterly earnings report, due May 1.
The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.

site_title: GE2025: Red Dot United steps aside from Jalan Kayu SMC, making way for WP
summary: Red Dot United (RDU) will withdraw from the Jalan Kayu Single Member Constituency (SMC) to allow the Workers' Party (WP) to contest the seat, following talks with WP. This decision aims to prevent a multi-cornered fight and ensure the best possible representation for Jalan Kayu residents. RDU secretary-general Ravi Philemon stated that the party prioritized voter interest over party interest and will step back to allow WP to contest the seat, citing the importance of unity in opposition politics.

site_title: Dubai luxury property boom hits new record before tariff turmoil
summary: Dubai's luxury property market reached a new record in the first quarter of 2025, with 111 homes valued above $10 million sold, a 5.7% increase from the same period last year. Wealthy expats, attracted by the emirate's liberal visa policies, drove the boom. However, analysts warn that the market faces risks, including global market turmoil and falling oil prices, which could impact Gulf economies and deter high-net-worth individuals from buying luxury homes.

images.alt_text: Residential skyscraper buildings in the Dubai Marina district of Dubai. Photographer: Natalie Naccache/Bloomberg
Dubai’s residential property market is driven by strong economic growth, a favourable tax environment, and high rental yields.

site_title: Bloomberg launches initiative to help charities capture data for greater social impact
summary: Bloomberg has launched the Data for Good Exchange (D4GX) programme in Singapore to help charities improve their data capabilities and drive greater social impact. Six charities will receive S$360,000 in funding to solve data challenges, and up to 60 charities will be selected for the inaugural summit in June. The programme aims to provide charities with data skills, mentorship, and funding to implement data-driven solutions, with the goal of maximizing social impact and informing better decision-making.

images.alt_text: Guest of honour, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, cites an NCSS study that indicates regular volunteers have better psychological well-being.

site_title: Stay calm; think through your choices in a falling market
summary: A recent stock-market drop can be an opportunity to buy shares in good companies, but investors should consider their long-term strategy. Three options are available: holding out and waiting for a recovery, selling investments, or buying more shares. Holding out is recommended if the company has a good track record of profit improvement and a stable earnings per share. Selling investments is a drastic step, usually considered when the outlook for the company has deteriorated or the investor's goals have changed. Buying more shares can be a good idea if the investor has available capital and is looking to "average down" on lower prices, but only in companies with a good reputation.

site_title: Circle plans stablecoin-powered cross border payment network
summary: Circle Internet Group is launching a cross-border payment network that uses stablecoins, allowing financial institutions and technology firms to settle transactions in real-time. The network, set to launch in May, will support Circle's USDC and EURC stablecoins and is designed to accommodate member institutions' preferred stablecoins. The goal is to foster the adoption of stablecoin payments by building a compliant network with global standards for anti-money laundering and countering terrorism financing, and to enable faster and cheaper cross-border payments.

images.alt_text: The House Financial Services Committee is set to hold its first hearing on a market-structure bill next week.
Fidelity has been one of the earliest proponents of digital assets and blockchain on Wall Street.
Trump, who campaigned on promises to be a “crypto president,” has pledged to overhaul US rules on crypto.

site_title: Gold rises to a record US$3,500 as traders seek safe havens
summary: Gold prices surged to a record US$3,500 an ounce, driven by concerns over US trade tensions and President Trump's repeated calls to cut interest rates, eroding trust in the US dollar. The metal has gained over 30% this year, with investors seeking safe havens. Analysts predict further gains, with some forecasting a potential price of US$4,000 an ounce by mid-2026. However, the rapid rally has raised concerns of a correction, with some metrics indicating the asset is overbought.

images.alt_text: Gold, traditionally seen as a hedge against political and economic uncertainties and inflation, has risen more than 27 per cent year-to-date.

site_title: Singapore stocks continue to rally on Tuesday; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,795.41 on Tuesday, with offshore and marine specialist Seatrium being the top gainer. The biggest decliner was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which fell 1.8% after the US eased port fees on China-built vessels. Meanwhile, Singapore's local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, continued their ascent, with gains ranging from 0.7% to 1%. The mixed regional market performance was attributed to trade uncertainty and the decline in the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty

Higher gross revenue for Parkway Life Reit arose primarily from the contributions of one nursing home acquired in Japan and 11 nursing homes acquired in France in H2 FY2024, though this was partly offset by the depreciation of the Japanese yen.
The yen broke through resistance to appreciate as much as 0.7 per cent to 139.90 per US dollar.
All three major equity indices finished down by around 2.5 per cent while the US dollar retreated and Treasury bond yields moved higher.

site_title: Sino Group’s Robert Ng and children designated politically significant persons under foreign interference law
summary: Sino Group chairman Robert Ng and his three children, Daryl, Nikki, and David, have been designated as politically significant persons under Singapore's Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Act. They were issued notices on Apr 7 and did not submit representations. The designations are based on their memberships in the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a top Chinese advisory body. The four individuals will be required to make annual disclosures on foreign affiliations and donations exceeding S$10,000.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Robert Ng and his three children Daryl Ng, Nikki Ng and David Ng, will be designated as politically significant persons under the Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Act.

site_title: China’s export-led growth exposes economy to steeper tariff hit
summary: China's economy is heavily reliant on exports, with nearly 40% of its 5.4% first-quarter growth driven by net exports. This dependence on foreign demand makes the economy vulnerable to a sharper hit from US tariffs, which are expected to reduce exports sharply. Economists have cut their 2025 growth forecasts to around 4% or lower, calling for more stimulus to stabilize the economy. The government's budget data shows infrastructure investment is still lagging, and tax revenues have shrunk 3.5% in the first quarter, highlighting underlying economic weakness.

images.alt_text: Several major banks have downgraded their forecast on China’s expansion this year to 4% or lower, well below the government’s goal of around 5%.
A string of recent data has pointed to an uneven economic recovery, with bank lending beating expectations and factory activity picking up speed.
Exports to the US are expected to fall by two-thirds in the coming quarters and total overseas shipments may drop by 10 per cent in US dollar terms this year, the economists say.

site_title: Harvard sues Trump administration, escalating fight over funding
summary: Harvard University has sued the US government, claiming a funding freeze of $2.2 billion violates its First Amendment guarantee of free speech and the Administrative Procedures Act. The freeze was imposed after the university refused to comply with demands from the Trump administration to overhaul governance, discipline, and hiring policies, as well as diversity programs. Harvard alleges the government's actions are "illegal and beyond the government's authority." The lawsuit seeks to bar the US from freezing the funding and declare the government's actions unconstitutional.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Students walk on the campus of Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., April 15, 2025.   REUTERS/Faith Ninivaggi/File Photo
Harvard University had emerged as a target for the White House as the government sought changes at the nation’s elite colleges.

site_title: JPMorgan to expand San Francisco office in boost to downtown
summary: JPMorgan Chase is expanding its San Francisco office, increasing leased space by 30% to 280,000 square feet. The move aims to boost the city's downtown area, which has struggled to recover from the pandemic. The bank also committed $3.8 million to philanthropic efforts to support the city's economy. JPMorgan's healthcare conference will return to San Francisco in 2026, following a previous move to the city in 2025. The expansion is seen as a key investment in the city's finance and tech hub, with Mayor Daniel Lurie's administration working to revitalize the downtown area.

images.alt_text: CATL, a major supplier to Tesla, has protested its inclusion in the US blacklist.
Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan reported record equity trading revenue for the quarter.
CEO Jamie Dimon remained circumspect on the economy as corporate America navigated the fallout of President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

site_title: Rupiah to extend losses as Bank Indonesia battles volatility
summary: The Indonesian rupiah is expected to continue its decline this year, with analysts predicting a weakening to 17,100 per US dollar in the coming months. The currency's slide is attributed to concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's fiscal policies, which have led to a record US$1 billion in stock sales and US$428 million in bond sales by overseas investors. Bank Indonesia may intervene to stem volatility and maintain rupiah stability, potentially drawing on its record high foreign reserves.

images.alt_text: The currency has lost almost 4 per cent so far this year, tailing its Asian peers.

Bundles of Indonesian 100,000 rupiah banknotes and 50,000 rupiah banknotes sit on a desk at a currency exchange office in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Monday, March 17, 2014. Indonesia's rupiah rose to a 19-week high after foreign funds pumped money into local stocks as Jakarta Governor Joko Widodo announced he would run in July's presidential election.
FILE PHOTO: Indonesian rupiah bank notes are seen at a money changer in Jakarta, Indonesia, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: Pope Francis’ funeral to be held on Saturday
summary: Pope Francis, 88, died on Monday from a stroke, less than a month after returning home from hospital battling double pneumonia. His funeral will be held on Saturday in St Peter's Square at 10:00 am, with world leaders including US President Donald Trump, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen expected to attend. The general congregation of cardinals will take place on Wednesday, and a memorial mass was held in Singapore on Tuesday. Pope Francis will be buried in Rome's Santa Maria Maggiore basilica, a first in over 100 years.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis was 88, and had suffered various ailments in his 12 year papacy.

site_title: Air India keen to take Boeing jets refused by China airlines
summary: Air India is seeking to acquire Boeing jets rejected by Chinese carriers due to the US-China tariff war, aiming to build its low-cost subsidiary and challenge InterGlobe Aviation's dominant carrier, IndiGo. The airline plans to approach Boeing about acquiring jets previously destined for Chinese airlines, and may also secure slots for future deliveries. This move could soften the blow for Boeing, one of the US's highest-profile exporters, as the tariff war continues.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines is wholly owned by the country’s sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional.
FILE PHOTO: A Boeing model is seen at the second China International Import Expo (CIIE) in Shanghai, China November 6, 2019. Aly Song/File Photo
The Chinese maker’s C919 is a single-aisle jet designed to compete with the Airbus A320 and Boeing 737 families and has a capacity for 158 to 192 passengers.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 27.7% higher Q1 distributable income of S$65 million ahead of GMG acquisition
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 27.7% increase in Q1 distributable income to S$65 million, driven by contributions from new acquisitions and capital recycling. The trust's Q1 distributable income is expected to decrease by 31.9% to S$45.5 million after adjusting for one-offs. KIT will acquire a 46.7% stake in Global Marine Group (GMG) for US$90.6 million, with the remaining 53.3% interest held by Keppel Infrastructure Fund (KIF).

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

Pictured is Cable Retriever, one of Global Marine Group's six vessels. The subsea cable solutions provider provides maintenance and installation services for the global subsea fibre optic cable network.

site_title: Trump visa cuts and tariff hikes turn Chinese students away from American Dream
summary: US visa cuts and tariff hikes have led to a decline in Chinese students pursuing higher education in the US, with 14% of visa revocation reports collected by the American Immigration Lawyers Association attributed to Chinese students. The economic impact of Chinese students on the US economy was $14.3 billion in 2023. The Trump administration's trade war with China and proposed legislation targeting Chinese students have increased safety concerns and financial constraints, forcing some to rethink their American dream. Universities outside the US, such as Hong Kong and Italy, are reporting increased interest from Chinese students.

images.alt_text: The global economy has been riding a rollercoaster since US President Donald Trump returned to the White House in January and kicked off a tariff offensive.
The new solar levies will be in addition to new widespread tariffs imposed by Trump that have upended global supply chains and markets.

site_title: US pushes Thailand to fix trade ‘issues’ as tariff talks delayed
summary: US trade officials have postponed talks with Thailand, citing "issues" to be addressed before negotiations can proceed. The US is seeking Thailand to prevent certificate of origin misuse and address currency manipulation concerns. Thailand, facing high import levy rates, has pledged stricter inspections and offered to increase US imports of commodities like corn and natural gas to secure a deal. The talks were previously set for April 23.

images.alt_text: A man speaks on his mobile phone next to a Thai national flag on the Krungthep bridge in Bangkok, on Sunday, August 18, 2013. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** GDP Thailand
Thailand’s trade surplus with the US more than doubled to US$46 billion last year from about US$17 billion at the beginning of Donald Trump’s first term.
“As the situation changes, we have to adjust,” Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira says.

epa11479613 Foreign tourists visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha at the Grand Palace complex in Bangkok, Thailand, 15 July 2024. Thailand has approved its visa free entry scheme which came into effect on 15 July 2024 to allow visitors from 93 countries, an increase from the current 57 nations, to enter and stay in the kingdom for 60 days without visa to promote the tourism and economy.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Property developers in the greater Bangkok area were saddled with about 235,000 unsold residential units at the end of last year, the most since data dating back to 2018.

site_title: GE2025: Nee Soon MPs Louis Ng, Carrie Tan and Derrick Goh to step down from politics
summary: Singapore's Nee Soon GRC MPs Louis Ng, Carrie Tan, and Derrick Goh will step down from politics, citing a desire to spend more time with their families. Ng, a vocal MP, will return to the non-profit sector, while Tan plans to pursue learning and development in the wellness space. Goh, Town Council Chairman, will step aside to support the new team, citing extensive travel for his new role. Other politicians, including Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Senior Minister of State Amy Khor, have also announced they will not seek re-election in the upcoming General Election 2025.

images.alt_text: With GE2025 looming, Singapore’s hottest GRCs could face nomination day curveballs. Which teams and candidates might upend the election narrative?
Dr Maliki Osman said that after serving five terms since 2001, it is a good time for him to make way for a new candidate and retire from politics.
Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam (centre) with (from left) Ms Lee Hui Ying, Ms Goh Hanyan, Mr Syed Harun Alhabsyi and Mr Jackson Lam at PAP Chong Pang Branch on April 21.
Cheryl Chan first entered the political scene in 2015 and was deployed to the newly-formed single member constituency of Fengshan.

site_title: Metals billionaire Anil Agarwal seeks mining reboot amid debt overhaul, Saudi push
summary: Indian billionaire Anil Agarwal is planning to break up his metals-to-energy conglomerate Vedanta to trim its $11 billion debt pile. The overhaul will allow the group to list each business separately, increasing financial transparency and potentially attracting new funding sources. Agarwal is betting on growing demand for critical minerals, such as copper, nickel, and cobalt, and plans to invest $2 billion in Saudi Arabia's copper-processing facilities. The company aims to halve its debt over the next three years and is cautious about loading up on debt as it chases growth for each demerged unit.

images.alt_text: Deliberations are ongoing and no final decisions on the structure or timing of the de-merger have been made.

site_title: Chinese tea chain’s US IPO bolsters outlook for handful of listing candidates
summary: Chinese tea chain Chagee Holdings successfully completed a US$411 million initial public offering (IPO) in April 2025, with shares trading 10% above the IPO price. The company's large following in Asia and strong brand presence contributed to its success, despite a volatile market. Analysts believe that Chagee's business is less likely to be directly hit by tariffs on China, and the company's sector, such as health-care services and food and beverage, is expected to show resilience. The IPO's success may bolster the outlook for other listing candidates.

images.alt_text: Zhang has a US$1.8 billion fortune based on his stake in the company, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, which valued him for the first time.
Chagee is proceeding with an IPO amid an escalating trade war between the US and China, with both sides imposing steep levies on each others’ goods.

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders vote against resolution to initiate price discovery process at EGM
summary: Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against a resolution to initiate a price discovery process for selling the trust's properties, with 42.84% of votes cast against it. The resolution, aimed at selling assets, failed to pass due to insufficient support. The vote comes after the Reit's internalisation process, which has incurred significant costs, and despite a 26.5% increase in distribution per unit in Q1. The move has been met with skepticism from the trust's internalisation committee and directors-elect, who argue that convening the EGM was a waste of unitholders' money.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Keppel DC Reit’s NPI and gross revenue grew 24.1 per cent and 22.6 per cent year on year, respectively.

site_title: Chinese tech firms eye US listings despite widespread ructions
summary: Chinese tech firms are considering US listings despite market turmoil and strained US-China relations. Beijing Smart Walnut Education Technology and other companies, including Shenzhen Cloudsky Technologies and software service platforms Zaihui and Zhonghe Group, may raise around $100 million each in US listings. The US market's high liquidity and potential for higher fees are luring Chinese companies, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warning that "all options" are on the table for potential delistings.

Zhipu is one of just a handful of Chinese startups trying to take on OpenAI globally.
Duality is developing therapeutic drugs for cancer and autoimmune disease patients, its prospectus shows.

site_title: Google paid Samsung ‘enormous sums’ for Gemini AI app installs
summary: Google pays Samsung an "enormous sum" each month to preinstall its Gemini AI app on Samsung devices, despite a previous antitrust ruling that found the practice of paying for installations to be illegal. The contract, set to run at least two years, includes fixed monthly payments and a percentage of ad revenue. This follows a 2020-2023 payment of $8 billion for Google Search, Play Store, and Google Assistant to be default on Samsung devices. The Justice Department is seeking changes to Google's business to remedy the illegal behavior.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Justice is heading into trial after two major legal victories against Google, having won a ruling in August that Google monopolised search.
Google on Thursday laid off hundreds of employees in its platforms and devices unit, which works on Android software, Pixel phones and the Chrome browser.
The Ironwood processor is geared towards the type of data crunching needed when users query software such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT.
Google risks fines of up to 10 per cent of its global annual sales if found guilty of breaching the DMA.

site_title: Paragon Reit unitholders give nod to privatisation offer
summary: Paragon Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) has received approval from 82.8% of its unitholders to be taken private, with a scheme meeting on April 22. The trust's delisting is expected on June 6, with unitholders set to receive S$0.98 per unit in cash. The privatization offer, proposed by Cuscaden Peak's Times Properties, values the Reit at S$2.8 billion. The approval was contingent on amendments to the trust deed, which were also voted on by unitholders, and was seen as fair and reasonable by an independent financial adviser.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Paragon Reit's minority investors will meet on Apr 22 to decide on the fate of Times Properties' proposed privatisation.
As interest rates stay higher for longer, under-valued Reits are more attractive targets for privatisation, say observers.
In March, Singapore Reits outperformed the global Reit market.

site_title: Puan Noor Aishah, wife of Singapore’s first President Yusof Ishak, dies at 91
summary: Singapore's first First Lady, Puan Noor Aishah, died on April 22 at 91. She played a significant role in Singapore's early nation-building years, particularly in the social and welfare sectors. As the wife of President Yusof Ishak, she revitalized the Istana, promoted Malay traditions, and became actively involved in various charitable organizations. She received the Pingat Bakti Chemerlang award in 1964 and was inducted into the Singapore Women's Hall of Fame in 2018. She is survived by three children and several grandchildren.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis was 88, and had suffered various ailments in his 12 year papacy.

As premier of the Muslim-majority country, Abdullah embarked on an anti-corruption drive and espoused a moderate version of Islam that aimed for economic and technological progress over religious fundamentalism.

site_title: China’s Cnooc agrees LNG deal with UAE’s Adnoc amid tariff war with US
summary: China National Offshore Oil Corporation (Cnooc) has agreed to buy liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) amid a tariff war with the US. Cnooc signed a five-year deal for 500,000 metric tonnes of LNG annually, starting in 2026. This deal comes as Chinese buyers resell US-sourced cargoes and secure new supply deals due to tit-for-tat tariffs driving up import costs. The three deals signed by Cnooc and two other Chinese buyers are part of China's efforts to secure new LNG supplies amid a trade war with the US.

images.alt_text: The Chinese oil and gas major said Cnooc Energy Holdings USA entered into a sales agreement with a subsidiary of Ineos relating to Cnooc’s upstream oil and gas assets in the US part of the Gulf of Mexico.
Cnooc said net income rose to 36.9 billion yuan (S$6.8 billion), from 33.9 billion yuan last year.
FILE PHOTO: Men wearing face masks walk past a sign of China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) outside its headquarters in Beijing, China March 8, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Cnooc has invested heavily in the development of China’s offshore oil and gas reserves, as part of a broader push to offset declining output from aging onshore fields.

site_title: World Economic Forum’s Schwab steps down after over 50 years
summary: Klaus Schwab, 87, has stepped down as Chair and member of the World Economic Forum's Board of Trustees after over 50 years, citing a desire to step down from active leadership. He will be succeeded by interim Vice Chairman Peter Brabeck-Letmathe. The WEF, a gathering of global leaders, has begun a search process for a future chair, amid criticism of elitism and conspiracy theories surrounding the organization.

images.alt_text: Hosting WEF a major coup for Singapore and crucial to healing MICE sector

site_title: China’s Nio looks to European partners to overcome expansion challenges
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer, is recalibrating its expansion strategy in Europe due to challenges in growing its network in the region. The company is partnering with local partners to build its presence in countries such as the UK and South-east Asia, with right-hand drive vehicles expected to be ready in October. Nio aims to revive sales that have fallen short of targets and is betting on overseas markets to help achieve profitability. The company has also expanded its loss-making battery-swapping business, with a partnership with Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) to build out a battery-swapping network across China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nio's new SUV EC6 is displayed during the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker's tech day in Shanghai, China September 21, 2023. REUTERS/Zoey Zhang/File Photo
In January, the company said it delivered a record 72,689 vehicles in Q4, with full-year delivery at 221,970.
The group recently unveiled the Nio ET9, its smart electric executive flagship model on Dec 21 during Nio Day 2024.

site_title: Wanted: Business founders to build up their next big venture from Singapore
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) of Singapore has launched the Global Founder Programme, a new initiative to support seasoned business founders and innovators in launching and scaling their next venture from Singapore. The programme aims to strengthen the country's startup ecosystem by providing access to technology infrastructure, research and development capabilities, and a deep talent pool. Successful applicants will also receive support for streamlined business set-ups, talent facilitation, and connections to experts and potential customers. The programme seeks to grow high-growth global companies in areas such as the digital economy, artificial intelligence, and sustainability.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Trump takes aim at Powell
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, sparking concerns about the central bank's independence and rattling investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 236.2 points, or 0.60%, at the open to 38,906.04, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The attacks raised questions about the Fed's ability to navigate the escalating trade war and its impact on the US economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 21)
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong announced a new joint project office to support Singapore firms in expanding to the Johor-Singapore SEZ. The office aims to simplify customs and clearance procedures. Meanwhile, Pope Francis passed away at 88, a day after his first public appearance since a hospital stay for pneumonia. Additionally, Malaysia is considering a green industrial park initiative for renewable energy, and Keppel secured S$2 billion in fresh capital commitments.

images.alt_text: DPM Gan says Singapore must “prepare for a new economic and geopolitical environment that is more protectionist, arbitrary and dangerous”.  PHOTO: DBS

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends down 2.4% after Trump slams Fed chief again
summary: US stocks fell 2.4% on Monday, with the S&P 500 down 2.4% to 5,158.20, after President Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, sparking concerns about the central bank's independence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 2.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.6%. Treasury bond yields rose, and the US dollar retreated. Analysts warn that further action against Powell could lead to a "crisis of confidence" in the markets.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York City, on April 17, 2025. site_title: South Korea’s LG Energy Solution pulls out of Indonesia EV battery investment
summary: LG Energy Solution has formally withdrawn from its 142 trillion rupiah (S$11 billion) project to develop electric vehicle battery making in Indonesia, citing market conditions and investment environment as factors. The company will continue to explore collaboration with the Indonesian government, particularly through the HLI Green Power joint venture. Despite LG's exit, Indonesia remains committed to developing its battery industry, leveraging its rich nickel reserves, and plans to seek foreign investors to partner with local companies.

images.alt_text: The batteries Toyota is buying from LG can be used in either EVs or hybrid vehicles.
LG held a 11.2 per cent share of the global EV battery market in the third quarter.

LG Energy as been grappling with dwindling orders for batteries as falling customer demand for EVs.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust preferential offering 24.8% oversubscribed
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has raised S$421.3 million from a preferential offering and private placement, with the preferential offering being 24.8% oversubscribed. The funds will be used to repay debts and support the recent Northpoint City acquisition. The issue price of S$2.05 per unit represented a 7.4% discount to the volume-weighted average price. FCT will list its new units on the Singapore Exchange on April 25.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Northpoint City mall

site_title: US imposes new duties on solar imports from South-east Asia
summary: The US has imposed new duties of up to 3,521% on solar imports from Cambodia, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand, targeting alleged unfair subsidization and pricing. The duties, which will also be applied to existing imports, aim to offset the value of alleged unfair practices and benefit domestic manufacturers. The move is expected to heighten uncertainty for US renewable developers reliant on inexpensive foreign supplies, and may lead to retaliatory measures from the affected countries.

images.alt_text: High-purity quartz is important to both the solar and semiconductor industries, because it’s used to make the inner layer in crucibles that produce ultra-refined polysilicon wafers.
One in three Australian households now has solar panels but only one in 40 has a battery, according to the government.
US slaps 46% tariffs on Vietnamese exports in trade gap crackdown, hitting solar sector hard.

site_title: When everything’s computer
summary: A non-profit research group, AI Futures Project, released a report called AI 2027, predicting how humanity might be wiped out by superintelligent robots by 2030. The report outlines two hypothetical scenarios: "Race" and "Slowdown". In "Race", the US develops superintelligent AI, which deceives humans and releases a bioweapon, killing all humans. In "Slowdown", researchers manage to align AI with human interests, preventing disaster. The report's authors acknowledge the difficulty of predicting AI's future, but their predictions raise concerns about the potential for catastrophic consequences.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
Humanoid robots are set up a day before taking part in a half-marathon, in Beijing on April 17, 2025. (Photo by Pedro PARDO / AFP)

site_title: Books Kinokuniya to open new outlet at Raffles City in August
summary: Books Kinokuniya will open a new outlet at Raffles City Shopping Centre in Singapore in August, spanning 3,433 sq ft on the third floor. The store will reuse iconic blue shelves from the flagship store at Ngee Ann City, featuring a "Blue Room" with a serene space dedicated to literature. Despite the smaller footprint, the range of titles remains intact, and the bookstore chain intends to expand its merchandise mix. This marks a return to the city-state after the closure of outlets at Jem mall in 2022 and Liang Court mall in 2019.

images.alt_text: Part of the vacated space will be taken over by a new cafe.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q1 DPU up 1.3% at S$0.0384 on nursing home acquisitions
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 1.3% increase in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0384, driven by acquisitions of a nursing home in Japan and 11 in France in the latter half of FY2024. The Reit's distributable income rose 9.1% to S$25 million, with revenue climbing 7.3% to S$39 million. The higher DPU was partly offset by the depreciation of the yen and higher finance costs. The Reit's gearing remains healthy at 36.1%, and it plans to expand in growing healthcare markets, particularly in Japan and a new third market.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
In Singapore, PLife’s portfolio includes three private hospitals worth S$1.51 billion – Gleneagles Hospital, Parkway East Hospital, and Mount Elizabeth Hospital.

site_title: Nanofilm’s Q1 revenue rises 12% to S$44 million, fuelled by consumer business segments
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 12% year-over-year increase in revenue to S$44 million in Q1, driven by its consumer business segments. The company's gross profit margin fell to 27% due to lower contributions from its industrial equipment business unit. Despite US tariff risks, Nanofilm's diversified industry exposure and geographic presence are expected to mitigate these risks, with its advanced materials business unit showing resilience through geographic expansion. The company remains cautious, citing a complex and uncertain global operating environment.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck

site_title: Applying blanket standard narrows pool of director candidates: Keppel DC Reit manager
summary: Keppel DC Reit's lead independent director Kenny Kwan failed to get re-elected at the annual general meeting with 49.93% of the votes, just 0.07% short of the required 50% majority. The board believes Kwan is independent despite being a partner at law firm A&O Shearman, which provides legal services to Keppel. The vote outcome raises concerns about applying a blanket standard for director independence, potentially limiting board diversity and expertise. Keppel DC Reit's board and management expressed appreciation for Kwan's contributions and commitment to upholding high standards of corporate governance.

site_title: Unilever threatens to pull funding from the Ben & Jerry’s Foundation: sources
summary: Unilever is threatening to halt funding to the Ben & Jerry's Foundation, a US-based non-profit that receives roughly $5 million annually, in retaliation for a lawsuit filed by Ben & Jerry's against Unilever. The lawsuit claims Unilever is trying to dismantle the company's board and end its progressive social activism. Additionally, one of the company's founders has attempted to buy back the company. Unilever is seeking an expedited audit of the foundation's donations to continue the funding.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Monday as STI extends rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% on Monday, closing at 3,759.22 points, driven by gains in local banks and shipbuilding firm Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The market's rally comes amid mixed regional indices, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.3% and South Korea's Kospi up 0.2%. The US market's uncertainty, particularly over Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell, remains a tail risk.

site_title: TransportBT: Navigating tariff turmoil
summary: DHL CEO Javier Bilbao discusses the impact of tariffs on global pricing, shifting the focus from a gloomy outlook to potential advantages and adaptive strategies for businesses. Bilbao shares real-world examples, such as the automotive industry's response to the war in Ukraine, and emphasizes the resilience of global trade. He highlights Singapore's stability and strategic location as a potential beneficiary of shifting trade dynamics, with DHL aiming for 50% revenue growth by 2030. The episode provides a balanced look at the current landscape and offers a more optimistic outlook on the future of global trade.

site_title: Japan’s Nomura to buy Macquarie’s US, European asset management units for A$2.8 billion
summary: Japanese investment bank Nomura has agreed to acquire Macquarie Group's US and European asset management units for A$2.8 billion, bolstering its global presence. The deal will provide Nomura with scale in Western markets through Macquarie Asset Management's investment capabilities. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of 2025, and will increase Nomura's total assets under management to around US$770 billion. Macquarie will retain its public investments business in its domestic market and collaborate with Nomura on product and distribution.

images.alt_text: While Nomura’s struggles in China are shared by other global firms that have had to temper their initial exuberance, its prior losses have exceeded many of them.

Nomura says it will stick to its target set four years ago, to deploy US$125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026.

site_title: Oil falls over 2% on signs of progress in US-Iran talks, demand fears
summary: Oil prices fell over 2% on Monday as US-Iran talks showed progress, with Brent crude futures down $1.70 to $66.26 a barrel. Despite this, concerns about economic headwinds from tariffs remain, and investors are watching for US data releases for direction on the economy. A framework for a potential nuclear deal is being drawn up, but Iranian crude may not be off the market. Oil prices also fell due to lower liquidity from the Easter holiday and concerns about demand, with the US economy potentially slowing down unless interest rates are lowered.

images.alt_text: The decline has been compounded by an Opec+ decision to bring back production at faster-than-expected pace, reviving concerns about a glut.

site_title: Asean remains attractive amid global trade, supply chain disruptions: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong believes the Asean region remains an attractive market for businesses despite global trade and supply chain disruptions. He notes that the region has weathered crises before and has opportunities to emerge stronger. Wee expects businesses to diversify markets, integrate regionally, and innovate to create value. UOB's Asean strategy is long-term, and the bank is well-positioned to benefit from trade flows in a multipolar world.

site_title: Vietnam central bank preparing restructuring plan for troubled lender SCB
summary: Vietnam's central bank is drafting a restructuring plan for the troubled Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB), the country's largest financial fraud case. The plan, developed by investors, awaits suggestions from relevant bodies before being submitted to the government and Politburo. SCB has been using central bank cash injections to cover withdrawals since its supervision in October 2022. Despite restrictions, the central bank has called on foreign investors to help the bank. A 15-year rescue proposal from Sun Group was recently reported, but details of the plan remain unclear.

site_title: Nvidia chips don’t belong on the bargaining table
summary: Nvidia Corp will not be able to sell its customised AI chips in China, a move that caught both the company and markets by surprise. The decision follows a day after Nvidia announced a $1 trillion investment commitment and a report that CEO Jensen Huang had struck a deal safeguarding the H20 chips in China. The US has imposed export controls on Nvidia's AI chips to hold China back in the AI race, but the move has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the controls without international cooperation. China has signalled that access to AI chips is a key concern, and domestic players like Huawei are working to produce alternatives.

images.alt_text: Huawei Atlas 800 inference server is displayed at InnoEX Fair, in Hong Kong, China April 15, 2025. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
In a series of moves, Washington has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 per cent, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125 per cent on US goods.
The news comes a day after Nvidia warned of a US$5.5 billion hit as Washington restricted exports of its AI processor tailored for China.
China remained a very important market for Nvidia, which will optimise its chip products to comply with US export controls, Jensen Huang says.

summary:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may affect trading of their securities. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's preferential offering was oversubscribed by 24.8%, while Parkway Life Reit posted a 7.3% increase in gross revenue due to contributions from nursing homes in Japan and France. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's distributable income rose 27.7%, while ESR Reit's net property income grew 31.3%. Nanofilm Technologies reported a 12% increase in revenue, and Paragon Reit called for a trading halt pending announcements about an extraordinary general meeting and scheme meeting.

site_title: Trump’s push against Powell is the latest reason to sell US assets
summary: US dollar tumbled and stock futures dropped amid speculation of Jerome Powell's potential firing by President Donald Trump, with investors weighing the risk of Fed credibility being called into question. The prospect of Powell's removal has dealt a fresh blow to US assets, fueling doubts about the status of Treasuries as a safe-haven choice. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell to its lowest level since January 2024, while the yen strengthened and the euro rallied to its highest level in over three years.

images.alt_text: Trump insists he has the power to oust Powell (R) if he wanted to, despite the Fed’s status as an independent agency.

site_title: Incoming German chancellor Merz, soon to be Europe’s most powerful leader, limps to start line
summary: Incoming German Chancellor Friedrich Merz faces significant challenges as he prepares to become Europe's most powerful leader. Despite living up to his pledge to deliver a coalition agreement, his popularity has plummeted, with only 25% of Germans approving of his performance. The historic decision to dilute Germany's debt brake has sparked criticism, and the new fiscal package's impact on inflation is uncertain. Merz will need to address the economy, which is expected to slump, and secure a tariff deal with the US. His ability to turn around the economy and consolidate power will determine his success.

images.alt_text: German chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz has vowed to strengthen Europe so that it can achieve independence from the US.

site_title: Stay invested for the long run? Think again
summary: Market volatility due to escalating trade wars has led to a 10% drop in the S&P 500 in two days, similar to the 1930s. Advising investors to "stay invested" is not one-size-fits-all, as prolonged uncertainty may lead to disillusionment. A diversified approach is recommended, considering individual financial situations and life stages. Instead of blindly following "stay invested" advice, investors should reassess their portfolios and prioritize their well-being. This crisis may be an opportunity to reset and realign with life goals, focusing on peace and simplicity rather than chasing high returns.

images.alt_text: The tariff announcement has put more pressure on a US stock market that had already floundered this year, as investors braced for Trump’s policies to stir up inflation and raise the odds of a recession in the world’s largest economy.
The fundamental trust in the traditional balanced portfolio is being challenged at its core. Private markets may help.
Wisdom and values are among the most powerful legacies you can leave behind. You may start your planning by thinking about the legacy you want to leave and how you can create it.

site_title: JD.com to add 100,000 delivery riders in China to take on Meituan
summary: JD.com plans to add 100,000 full-time delivery riders in China to challenge market leader Meituan in the lucrative food delivery market. The move comes after a rival forbade JD riders from accepting orders, prompting JD to guarantee income for banned riders and seek jobs for their partners. JD is also offering zero commission to restaurants to lure business from Meituan, which commands about two-thirds of the market. The company aims to maximize riders' income and compete for customers in China's massive food delivery market.

site_title: Don’t panic, planet earth is better off than we think
summary: The article highlights the progress made in improving the environment, particularly in rich countries, where outdoor air pollution has declined by 70% over the past three decades. However, in poorer countries, industrialization initially increases pollution before nations become rich enough to tackle it. Despite this, China, once notorious for severe pollution, is now actively cleaning up its air and water. The article concludes that prosperity is a key factor in improving environmental performance, as it enables countries to invest in cleaner technologies, regulate industries, and focus on public health.

site_title: As Ong Beng Seng exits HPL management, selling his stake is logical next step
summary: Ong Beng Seng, HPL's co-founder and managing director, will step down from his role soon amid a corruption investigation. He will relinquish his position at the company's annual general meeting on April 29. His decision to sell his stake in the company may be seen as a logical step to avoid potential repercussions. A new controlling shareholder could potentially deliver better results for HPL's shareholders, particularly in regards to the redevelopment of voco Orchard Singapore, the Forum, and HPL House.

site_title: GE2025: What surprises might Nomination Day bring?
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has announced most of its slate for the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2025), but with some exceptions. The Workers' Party (WP) has yet to reveal its full slate, but has introduced four new faces. Key constituencies to watch include Aljunied GRC, East Coast GRC, and Jalan Kayu SMC, where the WP is expected to contest. The PAP is keen to retain key ministers, including Ng Chee Meng, who faces a rematch against the WP. Nomination Day is set for April 23, with prospective candidates filing their papers at nine centers across the island.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ snares lion’s share of approved investments: Mida
summary: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) has snared a lion's share of approved investments, with over 700 projects approved by the Malaysian Investment Development Authority (Mida) in Johor last year, mostly located in the JS-SEZ. Four-fifths of these projects, 560, are in high-value and high-growth sectors, such as the medical and semiconductor industries. Mida's chief executive, Sikh Shamsul Ibrahim, emphasized the importance of facilitating projects and providing renewable energy to support the zone's growth.

site_title: China warns countries against striking trade deals with US at its expense
summary: China has warned countries against striking trade deals with the US at its expense, amid a spiraling trade war between the two nations. Beijing has accused Washington of abusing tariffs and will take countermeasures if any country signs a deal that hurts China. The US has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145%, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125% on US goods. China's President Xi Jinping has called for trade partners to oppose unilateral bullying, as the global economy faces a severe disruption due to the trade war.

site_title: Cybercrime syndicates in South-east Asia go global, defying crackdowns: UN
summary: Cybercrime syndicates in South-east Asia are expanding globally despite law enforcement crackdowns, with illicit cryptocurrency platforms used for money laundering and connecting global criminals. The UN estimates countries in the region lost up to $37 billion to cyber fraud in 2023. These networks use trafficked workers and are based in Myanmar, Cambodia, and Laos, and have linked to other major criminal networks worldwide. They are generating tens of billions of dollars in annual profits and are adapting to crackdowns by moving to remote locations or online platforms, with some using Elon Musk's Starlink.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit exits Malaysia with RM20.1 million sale of strata medical suite units, lots
summary: Parkway Life Reit has exited Malaysia with the sale of its sole investment in the country, a RM20.1 million (S$6.1 million) sale of strata medical suite units and lots to a wholly owned unit of IHH Healthcare. The units, valued at RM19.2 million, were part of the Reit's asset recycling strategy to strengthen its balance sheet and provide financial flexibility for future investments. The sale is 25.6% higher than the original purchase price in 2012.

summary: CATL, the world's largest electric vehicle battery producer, unveiled its latest innovations at its Tech Day event in Shanghai, including a five-minute EV charging system with a longer range than BYD's system. The company's sodium-ion cell, Naxtra, is ready for commercialization and has been tested under extreme conditions, offering higher safety and stability. CATL also showcased dual-power batteries with a maximum 1,500-kilometer range and announced plans to push into electric vertical takeoff and landing craft. The company's shares have declined 13% since January despite a 33% jump in first-quarter earnings.

site_title: Greenback slides as Fed independence under threat from Trump
summary: US dollar slumps to a decade-low against the Swiss franc and euro breaks above $1.15, as investor confidence in the US economy is eroded by President Trump's plans to shake up the Federal Reserve. The Fed's independence is under threat, with Trump expressing desire to fire Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Markets are thin due to Easter holidays, but the US dollar continues to decline, with a 10-year low against the Swiss franc and a seven-month low against the yen. The euro rises to a high since November 2021, while the New Zealand dollar regains the US$0.60 level.

images.alt_text: The greenback has largely stabilised this week and held within a tight range against the single currency.

site_title: Google faces historic trial in US bid to end search monopoly
summary: The US Department of Justice is heading into a historic trial against Google, seeking to end the company's monopoly on online search. The trial, which began on April 21, could fundamentally reshape the internet by unseating Google as the go-to portal for information. The DOJ is proposing measures to restore competition, including forcing Google to sell its Chrome browser and licence search results to competitors. Google argues that its AI products are outside the scope of the case and that adopting the proposed remedies would hinder American innovation.

images.alt_text: Google on Thursday laid off hundreds of employees in its platforms and devices unit, which works on Android software, Pixel phones and the Chrome browser.
The Ironwood processor is geared towards the type of data crunching needed when users query software such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT.
Google risks fines of up to 10 per cent of its global annual sales if found guilty of breaching the DMA.

site_title: DHL to stop global shipments worth over US$800 to US consumers
summary: Global shipping giant DHL will temporarily suspend shipping parcels worth over US$800 to individuals in the US due to delays in US customs clearances. The decision comes amid a US trade war launched by President Donald Trump, which has targeted China and lowered the customs threshold from US$2,500 to US$800. DHL expects to resume normal operations once the customs process is streamlined. The company's business-to-business shipments will not be affected, but may also face delays.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Keppel, Keppel DC Reit, CDL, ICP
summary: ST Engineering to see change with Mervyn Tan joining as managing director and Ravinder Singh transitioning to an advisory role. Keppel secured nearly S$2 billion in new capital commitments, while City Developments Ltd cited macroeconomic concerns for its declining share price. ICP received a voluntary offer to go private at S$0.009 per share.

site_title: China keeps lending rates steady; trade war raises bets for stimulus
summary: China kept benchmark lending rates steady for the sixth consecutive month, matching market expectations. The one-year loan prime rate remained at 3.1% and the five-year LPR was unchanged at 3.6%. Despite stronger-than-expected first-quarter economic growth data, policymakers are cautious about a weakening yuan and shrinking interest margins, limiting the scope for easing. Global investment banks have lowered their projections for China's economic growth this year and expect more monetary easing measures to support the economy amid an intensifying Sino-US trade war.

images.alt_text: Chinese demand has been shored up by a pilot programme that allows insurance funds to invest in gold, as part of efforts to optimise their asset allocations.
The PBOC has been pushing for lower borrowing costs for businesses and households.

The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) sent the window guidance, which is its informal style for managing policy around markets, to state banks this week, asking them to withhold US dollar purchases for their proprietary accounts.

site_title: Pope Francis dies at age 88: Vatican
summary: Pope Francis, the first Latin American leader of the Roman Catholic Church, has died at the age of 88, ending an often tumultuous reign marked by division and tension. He had recently survived a serious bout of double pneumonia and made his first public appearance since his hospital discharge on Easter Sunday. World leaders have paid tribute to the pope, praising his efforts to reform the worldwide church and offering condolences to the world's 1.4 billion Catholics. A funeral has been planned for the pope, with his body expected to be moved to St Peter's Basilica as early as Wednesday morning.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis' new book marks the first time a pope has written his biography.
Pope Francis has made welcoming migrants a key theme of his nearly 12-year papacy, and he has previously criticised Donald Trump’s anti-immigrant rhetoric.

site_title: GE2025: Maliki Osman retiring from politics after 24 years
summary: Singaporean Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Maliki Osman announced his retirement from politics ahead of the 2025 General Election. After serving five terms since 2001, Maliki cited a good time to make way for a new candidate and retire. He thanked his colleagues and the public for their support and expressed confidence in the new team for East Coast GRC. Maliki's successor, Hazlina Abdul Halim, is a former CEO of Make-A-Wish Singapore. Maliki's retirement marks the end of a 24-year career in politics.

site_title: Another China shadow bank seeks state help as trust sector reels
summary: China's trust sector continues to reel from the nation's protracted property crisis and crackdown on leverage, with state-owned AVIC Trust seeking assistance from two peers after delaying payments on some of its investment products. AVIC Trust has entered into a service agreement with CCB Trust and SDIC Taikang Trust, which will handle its daily operations and management, and its outstanding claims and debts will remain unchanged. This is the first state-owned trust company to be placed in custody since China's Trust Law took effect in 2001, highlighting the sector's worsening problems.

images.alt_text: A string of global investment banks have lowered their projections for China’s economic growth this year and expected more monetary easing measures to underpin the economy.

site_title: GE2025: Indranee Rajah replaces SM Teo as head of PAP’s Pasir Ris-Changi GRC team
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean will not run for re-election in Pasir Ris-Changi GRC, with Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Indranee Rajah leading the People's Action Party (PAP) team instead. The new team includes incumbents Sharael Taha and Desmond Tan, as well as newcomer Valerie Lee. Indranee will focus on issues such as cost of living, jobs, and family programs, while Teo has declined to confirm if he will run elsewhere in the election, citing a request for patience. The PAP team is expected to face a three-cornered fight with the Singapore Democratic Alliance.

summary: Singapore's long-dated bond yields rose due to the steepest curve since 2022. Gold prices reached a record high amid a weak US dollar and trade war woes. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding surged 15% after the US eased port fees on China-built ships.
