site_title: Amid ageing woes, China bets on AI to power long-term growth: DBS
summary: China's economy is expected to slow to 2.5% growth rate by 2040, but productivity gains from artificial intelligence (AI) and automation may mitigate the slowdown, according to a report by DBS. The country's ageing demographic is a major obstacle to growth, with the working population shrinking by 0.8% a year. To address this, the government is investing in AI infrastructure, including humanoid robotics and automation in agriculture. The report also predicts that domestic consumption will rise to 50-55% of GDP by 2040, driven by a shift towards sustainable urbanization and a stronger social security system.

images.alt_text: The true winner of the AI race, however, may not be the country that invents the best models. It is more likely to be the country where governments, businesses and ordinary people use AI at scale every day.

site_title: New joint project office to support Singapore firms in expanding to Johor-Singapore SEZ: DPM Gan
summary: Singapore has launched a joint project office to support local companies expanding into the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). The office, set up by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, Enterprise Singapore, and the Singapore Economic Development Board, aims to simplify customs and clearance procedures, improve the business ecosystem, and deepen economic partnerships. Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the importance of collaboration among like-minded countries, citing rising US-China trade tensions and the need for businesses to strengthen supply chains.

site_title: South Korea’s early trade data show exports shrank after tariffs
summary: South Korea's early trade data shows exports shrank 5.2% in the first 20 days of April after US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on auto imports and other shipments. The move highlights the risks to South Korea's export-driven economy from Trump's protectionist policies. Unadjusted exports also fell 5.2%, resulting in a trade shortfall of $100 million. Industry officials are set to travel to Washington to kick-start trade negotiations, as South Korea seeks to cut a "big" deal.

images.alt_text: “There are concerns about some companies struggling with liquidity difficulties due to the global trade conflict sparked by US tariffs and a delayed recovery in domestic demand,” Acting President Han Duck-soo says.
Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said that all six members of the board are open to a rate cut over the next three months.
South Korea’s decision to pump more money into its key chips sector is designed to help companies cope with heavier costs as they compete globally, it says.

site_title: Staying open is how Singapore can compete, grow and stay relevant
summary: Singapore must remain open to foreign workers to support its shrinking local workforce and address concerns over job security, social integration, and infrastructure strain. The country's aging population and declining birth rates have led to a support ratio of 3.5 working-age residents per elderly resident in 2024, up from 6 in 2014. Foreign workers have played a crucial role in augmenting the local workforce, with their inclusion raising the support ratio to 5.2. To stay competitive, Singapore must strike a balance between attracting foreign talent and addressing concerns over its economic and social impact.

images.alt_text: Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says the government’s partnership with enterprises will become increasingly important for Singapore’s growth as the world faces a more dangerous, turbulent and volatile external environment.
Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng said the changes to the updates to the policy governing work permit holders will allow firms to build a more skilled and resilient workforce.
Office workers in Singapore. From May 1 this year, the Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme’s support duration will be extended to three years.
The higher qualifying salaries will apply to new applicants from Sep 1, 2025, and renewals for expiring passes from Sep 1, 2026.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding soars 9% as US eases port fees on China-built ships
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares surged 9.2% to close at S$2.25 after the US eased port fees on China-built ships, a move seen as a positive step by analysts. The US had initially proposed fees of up to $1.5 million per port call, but softened its stance following industry pushback. The new fees will take effect after 180 days and exempt domestic exporters and vessel owners from the fees. The company has also conducted recent share buybacks, but its counter is still short of its 52-week high of S$3.32.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding’s management had reportedly told analysts a week after the United States port fees proposal that it had not received any order abortions or delays.

site_title: GE2025: PAP’s Sengkang candidate Bernadette Giam wants to bring F&B experience to politics
summary: Bernadette Giam, a 38-year-old mother of two, has been introduced as the People's Action Party (PAP) candidate for the Workers' Party-held Sengkang GRC. A former Brownie chief commissioner and entrepreneur, Giam has volunteered for the PAP since the 2020 General Election and is now chairperson of the PAP Sengkang East branch. She aims to bring her F&B experience to politics, focusing on creating memorable dining experiences and advocating for the needs of residents. Giam also plans to speak up for women entrepreneurs and working parents, if elected.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Newcomer Kenneth Tiong has been walking in the Serangoon division vacated by former MP Leon Perera.
The 30-plus new candidates that the PAP will field is the largest slate in recent history, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
PAP new face Jeffrey Siow’s last position was second permanent secretary for the Ministry of Manpower and the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Sias urges Sin Heng Heavy Machinery shareholders to reject Tal United’s offer, citing 41% discount to NAV
summary: Sias urges Sin Heng Heavy Machinery shareholders to reject Tal United's offer of S$0.58 per share, citing a 41% discount to the estimated net asset value (NAV) of S$0.98 per share. The independent financial adviser considers the offer "not fair and not reasonable." Sin Heng has demonstrated positive performance, with net profits increasing from S$3.65 million to S$6.27 million in the past three financial years. The offer closes on April 30, and Sias advises shareholders to collectively reject the offer to send a message to Tal United.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

The offeror noted that in maintaining its listed status, Sin Heng has incurred “considerable” listing and associated costs, which includes compliance costs and time dedicated to regulatory and reporting obligations.

site_title: China plastic plants face closure risk as tariffs hit US ethane
summary: China's plastics factories face the risk of shutdowns due to tariffs on US ethane, a crucial feedstock. China imports almost all its ethane from the US, and with 125% tariffs in place, factories have lost $184 per tonne of ethane processed. This is another blow to China's plastics sector, already struggling with a glut due to excessive production capacity. Domestic ethane production cannot meet the demand, and long-term contracts make it difficult for Chinese companies to obtain alternative supplies from non-US sources.

images.alt_text: epa12038805 A Chinese flag is seen on the Shanghai Container Terminal, in Shanghai, China, 18 April 2025. China announced 125 percent tariffs on US goods effective 12 April, raising its previous rate of 84 percent, in response to the latest US tariffs, which effectively total 145 percent.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI
The spat over ocean shipping is the latest conflict in an intensifying trade war between China and the US that has pushed levies on each other’s imports beyond 100 per cent.

The trade war has all but frozen the mammoth trade between the world’s two largest economies, with tariffs over 100 per cent in each direction and a suite of trade, investment and cultural restrictions.
Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam capture just 8 to 25 per cent of plastic waste for recycling in major urban areas.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines eyes new Boeing jets should China reject them
summary: Malaysia Airlines is in talks with Boeing to acquire new jets if Chinese airlines stop taking deliveries due to the US-China tariff war. Boeing is returning some 737 MAX jets from China to the US, potentially making delivery slots available. Malaysia Airlines aims to operate a fleet of 55 new generation 737 MAX aircraft by 2030 and may secure earlier deliveries if Boeing slots become available. The airline's managing director, Izham Ismail, discussed the possibility of taking over Boeing's delivery slots with the company.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines has struggled to recover from two deadly disasters in 2014.

site_title: Johor has RM23 billion in investment pipeline in April alone: chief minister
summary: Johor, Malaysia, has secured RM23 billion in investment pipeline for April, bringing the total for the first quarter to RM27.4 billion. This growth is attributed to the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, with Chief Minister Onn Hafiz Ghazi calling it a "powerful early signal of the momentum" behind the zone. The state has also launched an Invest Malaysia Facilitation Centre to streamline investment processes, with 42 "high-impact" projects undergoing accelerated processing. Onn Hafiz proposed two new initiatives to strengthen the JS-SEZ, including a regulatory sandbox and an Asean industrial park.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (second from left) meeting with business and government leaders on Monday.

site_title: Indonesia books larger-than-expected US$4.3 billion trade surplus in March
summary: Indonesia recorded a trade surplus of $4.3 billion in March, its highest in four months, driven by a 3.2% year-on-year increase in exports and a 11.8% annual increase in iron and steel exports. The surplus nearly doubled the forecast by analysts and provides a welcome boost to foreign-exchange reserves. However, analysts warn that maintaining such surpluses may be challenging, particularly with ongoing pressure on the rupiah, and that US President Trump's tariff policies could reshape Indonesia's trade dynamics.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesia's local content policy gained renewed attention after the government blocked Apple’s iPhone 16 launch.
Indonesia has proposed increasing its imports from the US by up to US$19 billion, including around US$10 billion of energy imports.
The levies for underground coal mining will be lower by comparison.
Indonesia Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the ministry recommended increasing the LPG import quota for the US, as well as importing more US crude, to help reach the target.

site_title: Keppel secures S$2 billion in fresh capital commitments across flagship funds
summary: Keppel secures approximately S$2 billion in fresh capital commitments across its flagship funds, including US$580 million for its third data centre fund, bringing its funds under management to around S$4.9 billion. The new capital brings the company closer to its interim FUM target of S$100 billion by 2026, and ultimately aims to reach S$200 billion by 2030. The funds will be invested in sustainable data centres, education-related assets, and value-added real estate opportunities.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Tailwinds from energy transition, digitisation and AI as well as real estate demand is expected to keep pushing the Keppel forward said CEO Loh Chin Hua

site_title: Upgraded Asean, Australia and New Zealand FTA enters into force
summary: The upgraded Asean-Australia-New Zealand Free Trade Area (AANZFTA) entered into force on April 21, 2025, marking a significant milestone in strengthening regional economic resilience and cooperation. The agreement, which covers over 703 million people and a combined GDP of over $5.6 trillion, aims to promote an open, inclusive, and rules-based multilateral trading system. Key benefits include streamlined processes, reduced tariffs, and improved digital connectivity, with the goal of enabling businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, to better seize opportunities in the region.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
DPM Gan says Singapore must “prepare for a new economic and geopolitical environment that is more protectionist, arbitrary and dangerous”.  PHOTO: DBS
DPM Gan said Singapore is also reaching out to its trading partners to share information and explore different ways of working together
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world

site_title: China’s Cosco warns US levies risk upsetting global shipping
summary: China's Cosco Shipping Corporation warns that US levies on Chinese-built and -owned ships risk eroding global trade and supply chain stability. The proposal, watered down from an earlier version, still puts pressure on Chinese ship operators and shipbuilders. Cosco risks losing market share and analysts predict it will not significantly impact global shipping prices. China's foreign ministry has vowed to defend its lawful rights and interests, while the US has imposed restrictions on Cosco in the past, including sanctions and blacklisting.

site_title: GE2025: Shanmugam to lead fresh PAP team to contest Nee Soon GRC
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam will lead a refreshed PAP team in the May 3 general election, contesting Nee Soon GRC with four new faces. The team includes former Nominated MP Syed Harun Alhabsyi, Jackson Lam, Lee Hui Ying, and Goh Hanyan. Shanmugam said the new team brings a range of experience and has potential office-holders, citing Lam's deep networks in Yishun and Dr Syed Harun's work in handling Malay-Muslim community issues as valuable additions. The PAP team will face off against Red Dot United's team in the constituency.

images.alt_text: Cheryl Chan first entered the political scene in 2015 and was deployed to the newly-formed single member constituency of Fengshan.
Minister Desmond Lee (third from left) at the e2i event held  at Boon Lay Community Club. Next to him (wearing white) is Hamid Razak, a fellow member of the PAP's West Coast-Jurong West GRC team.

SDP chairman Paul Tambyah led the party’s manifesto announcement alongside vice-chairman Bryan Lim and Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC candidates Jufri Salim and Dr Gigene Wong.

site_title: At Shanghai auto show, EV makers to grapple with autonomous-tech crackdown, launch Tesla ‘killers’
summary: Chinese automakers, including BYD and Geely, are showcasing models at the Shanghai auto show amid a government crackdown on marketing claims for autonomous-driving features. The crackdown follows a fatal crash of the Xiaomi SU7, which killed three people, shortly after the driver tried to take over from the car's assisted-driving system. As a result, automakers are revising their marketing presentations to focus on driver caution rather than boasts about automated-driving capabilities. Several Chinese manufacturers, including BYD and Zeekr, are launching rivals to Tesla's Model Y, including electric crossovers priced to compete directly with the US EV maker.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect sales to fall again this year for several reasons, including damage to the brand reputation by chief executive Elon Musk’s (above) close work with US President Donald Trump and support of far-right European politicians.
The move follows a fatal accident involving Xiaomi’s best-selling SU7 sedan in March that triggered widespread concerns over vehicle safety.
Xpeng has designed its own AI chip that will be fitted into Xpeng vehicles, starting in mainland China, from the second quarter of this year.
From left to right: Mercedes-Benz eVito, eCitan and eSprinter, in front of the Mercedes-Benz Centre at Alexandra in Singapore.
The rules set out stricter mandatory tests which will require companies to ensure their batteries won’t catch fire or explode in tests with a specified time period.
Tesla’s Shanghai factory only makes Model 3 and Model Y cars and most of them are either sold in China or exported to other parts of Asia.
The EU has increased tariffs on Chinese-built EVs to as much as 45.3 per cent last October.
Li Sheng, MG’s overseas brand and marketing director, with the MG S5 electric vehicle that launches in Singapore on Wednesday (Apr 9).
BYD set up shop in Shenzhen as a battery maker in 1995, before establishing an auto arm in 2003 and releasing its first car two years later.

site_title: Caribbean group says US exemptions on Chinese ships ‘acceptable’
summary: The Caribbean Private Sector Organization welcomed a US decision to exempt certain Chinese ships from millions of dollars in fees proposed by the Trump administration. The fees, aimed at reviving the US shipbuilding industry, would have imposed at least $1 million on Chinese-made vessels using US ports. The exemption applies to three categories of cargo ships that load and unload goods at Caribbean ports, avoiding "crippling consequences" such as inflation and supply-chain disruptions.

site_title: Oil fell with Ukraine-Russia truce, US-Iran talks in focus
summary: Oil prices declined by over 1% as traders worried about the impact of US-led trade wars on energy demand. The decline was compounded by an Opec+ decision to increase production faster than expected, raising concerns about a global glut. The US and Iran are in talks over Tehran's nuclear program, which may affect Iranian crude supplies. Trading volumes may be lower due to Easter holidays.

site_title: Singapore’s long-dated bond yields get boost from steepest curve since 2022
summary: Singapore's long-dated bond yields have seen a significant boost due to the steepest yield curve in about three years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is set to auction S$1.8 billion in debt on Apr 28, with yields near the highest since March 2022. This outperformance is adding to the appeal of local-currency bonds, which have gained 3.5% in the past three months, beating other major developed markets. Despite yields still being lower than US Treasuries, experts expect Singapore's rates to underperform their US counterparts this year.

images.alt_text: The growing tension between increasing demand for access and the need for proper safeguards makes the MAS proposal both timely and necessary, the writer says.
新加坡金融管理局（Monetary Authority of Singapore，MAS）外观。
Economists note the dovish tone of MAS' latest monetary policy statement.
In a Bloomberg survey, all 14 economists forecast that MAS would reduce the S$NEER slope. Meanwhile, nine out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters expected this move.

site_title: Gold hits record high on weak US dollar, trade war woes
summary: Gold has reached a record high, rising 1% to $3,361.53 an ounce, amid a weak US dollar and trade war concerns. The US dollar index hit a three-year low, making gold more attractive for investors. The move follows US President Donald Trump's escalation of trade tensions with China and other countries, fueling recession fears. Gold has risen over 27% year-to-date, traditionally seen as a hedge against economic uncertainties and inflation.

images.alt_text: Gold has hit multiple record highs this year.

site_title: Tariff deal talks to dominate IMF-World Bank meetings this week
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is the lead negotiator for tariff deals, as the IMF-World Bank meetings focus on minimizing the impact of President Donald Trump's steep import taxes. The Trump administration's support for the IMF and World Bank has raised questions, with some critics arguing that withdrawing from these institutions would be in the US's interest. Japanese and South Korean finance ministers are expected to meet with Bessent to discuss tariffs, while the IMF's economic forecasts are set to be released, which may put pressure on developing countries' debt burdens.

images.alt_text: In a series of moves, Washington has raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 per cent, prompting Beijing to slap retaliatory duties of 125 per cent on US goods.

site_title: NTUC ‘closely monitoring’ impact of US tariffs, will ensure workers continue to receive support
summary: Singapore's NTUC is closely monitoring the impact of US tariffs and will work with tripartite partners to enhance job security for workers amid growing uncertainty. The labour movement has exceeded 1.4 million union members, with nearly two-thirds being professionals and managers. NTUC will strengthen efforts to support workers and attract foreign investments, and will continue to work with the Economic Resilience Taskforce, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
DPM Gan Kim Yong (left) and SBF vice-chairman Mark Lee (standing in for SBF chairman) at the Economic Resilience Task Force press conference.
In GE2020, labour chief Ng Chee Meng contested Sengkang GRC, but lost to the Workers' Party.

site_title: East Coast GRC MP Cheryl Chan retires from politics, will not contest in GE 2025
summary: Singaporean PAP MP Cheryl Chan, a 48-year-old East Coast GRC representative, has announced her retirement from politics after two terms. Chan cited her father's illness and subsequent passing as reasons for her decision, which was made after careful consideration. She is the seventh PAP MP to announce retirement ahead of the polls on May 3. Chan's retirement comes as the East Coast GRC is expected to see another close battle with the Workers' Party, with the PAP's slate still largely unconfirmed.

images.alt_text: Minister Desmond Lee (third from left) at the e2i event held  at Boon Lay Community Club. Next to him (wearing white) is Hamid Razak, a fellow member of the PAP's West Coast-Jurong West GRC team.

PSP chairman Tan Cheng Bock introduces the candidates for West Coast-Jurong West GRC and Pioneer SMC.

site_title: DHL banks on burgeoning markets like South-east Asia as it aims for 50% revenue growth by 2030
summary: DHL, a logistics giant, remains optimistic about its revenue growth target of 50% by 2030 despite the impact of US tariffs on global supply chains. The company is focusing on high-growth regions like South-east Asia, life sciences, and e-commerce, and has set aside billions for expansion. DHL CEO Javier Bilbao sees the tariff situation as manageable and believes that healthy global trade will continue to fuel long-term growth. The company has invested heavily in Asia-Pacific, with plans to double its business in the region by 2030.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Corporations and manufacturers are weighing where to place production or worrying about product launches, Tobias Meyer says.
The companies have also agreed to a strategic partnership to strengthen their supply chain service offerings for the global life sciences and healthcare sector.
John Pearson says that in spite of the on-again, off-again tariff announcements from Trump, he expects demand for express shipping to grow this year.

site_title: Senior Fed official warns against curbing central bank independence
summary: Austan Goolsbee, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago president, warned against curbing the US central bank's independence, citing the importance of monetary independence in maintaining credibility and avoiding higher inflation rates and slower growth. This comes amid President Donald Trump's expressed frustration with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell, who has stated he will not retire before his term ends, and Trump's suggestion that Powell's termination could be imminent. The legal basis for firing the Fed chairman is questionable, and Trump's comments signal a push for more control over the US government.

images.alt_text: Trump insists he has the power to oust Powell (R) if he wanted to, despite the Fed’s status as an independent agency.
“Our independence is a matter of law,” Fed chair Powell said at the Economic Club of Chicago.
The Fed has announced in December that it would begin making several changes to the annual exams of big bank health.

US President Donald Trump in his social media post said Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell was “always too late and wrong”, and critiqued the speech Powell made on Wednesday, calling it “another, and typical, complete mess!”

site_title: Beijing slams ‘appeasement’ of US in trade deals that hurt China
summary: China has vowed to fight a trade war "to the end" and has warned other countries against making deals with the US at its expense, promising countermeasures. China has imposed duties of 125% on US goods, while the US has slapped a 10% tariff blanket on Chinese products. The US and China are engaged in negotiations to lower tariffs, but Beijing has warned nations not to compromise its interests, stating that "appeasement will not bring peace" and that any deal that harms China will be met with reciprocal countermeasures.

images.alt_text: The spat over ocean shipping is the latest conflict in an intensifying trade war between China and the US that has pushed levies on each other’s imports beyond 100 per cent.

The trade war has all but frozen the mammoth trade between the world’s two largest economies, with tariffs over 100 per cent in each direction and a suite of trade, investment and cultural restrictions.
Li Qiang’ comments come days before a closely watched gathering of the Politburo this month.

site_title: Volvo to cut up to 800 US jobs as Trump’s tariffs bite
summary: Volvo Group plans to lay off 550-800 US workers at three facilities due to market uncertainty and demand concerns caused by US President Donald Trump's tariffs. The company, which employs nearly 20,000 people in North America, cited "heavy-duty truck orders" as a factor in the layoffs. Volvo's move is the latest response from the car and truck industry reeling from the Republican president's tariffs on certain parts, which are expected to increase manufacturing costs.

site_title: CDL’s AGM: Minority support for five IDs seeking re-election a litmus test of governance perceptions
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is set to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) on Apr 23, where five independent directors (IDs) are seeking re-election. The appointments of Jennifer Duong Young and Wong Su-Yen, who are on opposite sides of the conflict, have raised concerns about governance perceptions. Minority shareholders may view CDL differently, and investors are questioning whether an overhaul of the board is necessary to boost shareholder returns. The outcome will also test the level of support for the Kwek family, which controls nearly half of CDL's shares.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
The pall of uncertainty hanging over CDL could begin to clear when it holds its AGM on Apr 23.
What can CDL do to restore the confidence of investors?

Sector-specific headwinds have also affected others, CDL says.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Balanced investing in volatile times
summary: Analysts are questioning the relevance of the 60/40 portfolio in the current volatile market, following President Trump's tariffs. The classic balanced investing strategy, comprising 60% equities and 40% bonds, has shown resilience since 2023, but its effectiveness is threatened when both markets move together positively. Experts suggest diversification, incorporating asset classes less correlated with traditional assets, and limiting exposure to highly volatile digital assets. Investors should assess their risk tolerance, stay informed, and consider professional advice to balance their portfolios effectively.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 at crossroads, signals cautious near-term outlook
summary: The Nasdaq 100 Index is navigating a challenging phase, with recent price action suggesting neither a clear bullish nor bearish trend. The index has failed to breach a key resistance zone and is currently trading around 18,490, near key support levels. Investors are advised to approach the index with caution due to ongoing US-China trade tensions and market volatility. A decisive move above 19,400 could open the path for a rally, while sustained selling pressure may push the index lower.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. US stocks powered higher on the back of optimism over the technology giants, signaling that Wall Street is set to rebound from the four-day slump that marked the end of 2024. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 1.3 per cent at 39,142.23.

site_title: Taiwan short-selling curbs extended again amid tariff uncertainty
summary: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission extended temporary curbs on short-selling shares to ensure stock market stability amid tariff uncertainty. The curbs, first imposed on April 6, will continue indefinitely without a set end date. The move aims to maintain market stability and investors' interests, with the regulator to adjust measures if significant market changes occur. The curbs were initially imposed after the US imposed sweeping import tariffs, prompting global market turmoil. The US tariff policy and negotiations with other countries remain uncertain, leading to ongoing market fluctuations.

site_title: From Valencia to Los Angeles, Asian billionaires own football clubs around the world
summary: Asian billionaires have invested heavily in football clubs worldwide, transforming teams and injecting substantial funds into English and Spanish teams. Notable owners include Peter Lim (Valencia), Vincent Tan (Cardiff City), Ruben Emir Gnanalingam (Los Angeles FC), Dai Yongge (Reading), Dejphon Chansiri (Sheffield Wednesday), Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha (Leicester City), Forrest Li (Lion City Sailors), Guo Guangchang (Wolverhampton Wanderers), and Venky's (Blackburn Rovers). These investors have brought significant financial backing and strategic direction to their respective teams, with varying degrees of success.

images.alt_text: Tech billionaire Forrest Li (standing) watching the Lion City Sailors at Jalan Besar Stadium. on Mar 12.
Peter Lim and his wife Cherie Lim before Spanish La Liga match between Valencia CF v Sevilla FC at Mestalla Stadium in 2018.

site_title: Indonesia may rework tech rules that delayed Apple, shut out Google devices
summary: Indonesia is reviewing its local content rules, which have delayed the launch of Apple's iPhone 16 and banned Google's Pixel phones, in an effort to appease the US amid a tariff crisis. The rules, introduced in the 1950s, mandate the use of locally sourced goods and services in certain sectors, including tech. Indonesia's government is considering easing these rules to attract foreign investment and boost domestic industries. The move could pave the way for Apple and Google to sell their devices in the country, but some experts warn it could also harm the domestic tech industry.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta

epa12006889 People walk past a Nike shop at a street in Hanoi, Vietnam, 03 April 2025. EPA-EFE/LUONG THAI LINH

site_title: ICP receives S$0.009 per share exit offer from major shareholder Aw Cheok Huat
summary: Major shareholder Aw Cheok Huat has launched a voluntary offer to take hospitality company ICP private at S$0.009 per share, citing low trading liquidity. The offer represents a 16.9% premium over ICP's one-month VWAP and a 20% premium over its three-month VWAP. The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval, with delisting requiring a 75% majority vote. Aw owns 57.16% of ICP and plans to use the delisting to save on compliance costs and gain more control over the business.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Food processing company Wilmar International maintained its innocence in a 2022 corruption case  revolving around the approval of export permits that did not meet requirements.

site_title: Singapore GCB market sees interest picking up amid global uncertainty
summary: The Singapore Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market has seen a resurgence in interest, with 22 deals totaling S$1 billion in 2024, according to Knight Frank data. Despite global uncertainty caused by US President Donald Trump's tariffs, analysts believe the market may weather the storm better than expected. High-net-worth individuals are tightening their purse strings, but some are putting down roots in Singapore for stability and purchasing luxury homes. GCB prices remain supported, with a record S$93.9 million sale of a Tanglin Hill GCB in 2024. Experts predict steady demand and limited supply will keep prices stable, with potential for modest appreciation.

site_title: China shipbuilders rip Trump’s ‘short-sighted’ US port fees
summary: China's shipbuilders have strongly protested US port fees, calling them "short-sighted" and "discriminatory", amid a trade war between the two nations. The fees, aimed at reviving US shipbuilding, shield domestic exporters and vessel owners, sparking opposition from China's government and shipowners. The China Association of the National Shipbuilding Industry warned that the measures would disrupt the global maritime system, lead to soaring shipping costs, and harm the US people, urging the international industry to resist the US behavior. China has vowed to take necessary measures to safeguard its interests.

images.alt_text: The trade war has all but frozen the mammoth trade between the world’s two largest economies, with tariffs over 100 per cent in each direction and a suite of trade, investment and cultural restrictions.
Li Qiang’ comments come days before a closely watched gathering of the Politburo this month.
Trump has long argued that China’s dominant role in the maritime industry has made the US overly dependent on the Asian nation, echoing the concerns of some shipbuilders.

site_title: Life sentence cut to 30 years in prison for Vietnam’s death-row property mogul Truong My Lan
summary: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan's life sentence for embezzlement and money laundering has been reduced to 30 years in prison, while her death penalty for laundering $22.6 billion remains upheld. Lan, 68, was found guilty of misappropriating funds from nearly 36,000 investors and bribing government officials. She had claimed the severe consequences of the case were unexpected and that she was working with foreign partners to repay debts within two to five years. The reduced sentence is part of Vietnam's largest fraud case on record, which has seen numerous high-ranking politicians and business leaders detained.

images.alt_text: The court ruled in April that Truong My Lan must compensate Saigon Commercial Bank a total of 674 trillion dong – an amount Lan appealed against but still committed to repay “at all costs”.
Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan (in blue) looks on at a court in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, March 25, 2025.
Truong My Lan has become the most high-profile case of the ruling Communist Party’s corruption crackdown.

Judges on Tuesday upheld the death sentence of property developer Truong My Lan, who was convicted this year of embezzling vast sums from the Saigon Commercial Bank, which she controlled, having borrowed from tens of thousands of small investors.

Truong My Lan (centre), the chairwoman of real estate developer Van Thinh Phat Holdings Group, was sentenced to death in April for her role in a financial fraud worth more than US$12 billion, Vietnam’s biggest on record.

site_title: Candy maker YLF cites market souring on US tariffs as reason to withdraw Singapore IPO
summary: YLF Group, a Singapore-based candy manufacturer, is withdrawing its initial public offering (IPO) due to unfavorable market conditions created by US tariffs. The company cited the uncertainty as a major factor, with its chief executive Lee Tee Wei stating that market sentiment has been "badly shaken". YLF had lodged its preliminary prospectus in March, but withdrew it on April 14, citing plans to expand its product mix and overseas distribution network. The company's net profit fell 42.1% to $2 million in the nine-month period ended September 2024.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Car dealer, candy maker could be first listings on SGX this year

site_title: GE2025: Tan See Leng to helm PAP’s Marine Parade-Braddell Heights team, which includes new face
summary: The PAP has announced its team for the upcoming Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC, led by Manpower Minister Tan See Leng and including new face business development director Diana Pang. The team also includes Minister of State Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, incumbent MPs Seah Kian Peng and Tin Pei Ling, and former MP Mohd Fahmi Aliman will not be part of the team. The PAP aims to improve infrastructure and intergenerational connectivity in the constituency, seeking a strong mandate from residents.

images.alt_text: SM Lee Hsien Loong (second from right) said on Saturday: "When we field somebody as a candidate, we must make sure that we are completely convinced he is going to do his best for the residents, and is the right candidate for that place."

site_title: South Korea finds ‘Made in Korea’ breaches intended to avoid US tariffs
summary: South Korea's customs agency has found a significant increase in attempts to disguise foreign products as Korean exports, mostly from China, to avoid US President Donald Trump's tariffs. The Korea Customs Service discovered 29.5 billion won (S$27.3 million) worth of country-of-origin violations in the first quarter, with 97% of the total going to the US. This is a significant rise from 34.8 billion won in 2024, with 62% of the total going to the US. The agency plans to launch a special task force to prevent such attempts and protect domestic companies.

images.alt_text: South Korea is the US’s sixth-biggest trading partner, with the Asian country’s surplus jumping about 25 per cent in 2024 from the previous year to about US$55.7 billion.

“There are concerns about some companies struggling with liquidity difficulties due to the global trade conflict sparked by US tariffs and a delayed recovery in domestic demand,” Acting President Han Duck-soo says.
Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said that all six members of the board are open to a rate cut over the next three months.
South Korea’s decision to pump more money into its key chips sector is designed to help companies cope with heavier costs as they compete globally, it says.

site_title: MAS’ private market proposal spells a new era for retail investing in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed a private market regulatory framework to provide retail investors with a safe and structured way to access private market investment funds. The proposed long-term investment fund (LIF) framework aims to adapt existing fund requirements, offering retail investors regulated access to private equity, private credit, and infrastructure investments. If implemented thoughtfully, the framework could signal the beginning of a more accessible and equitable investment landscape in Singapore, offering retail investors exposure to private markets through diversified, professionally managed funds in a regulated environment.

images.alt_text: MAS seeks feedback on proposals giving retail investors access to private market assets
While private market assets can help retail investors diversify their portfolios, experts say such investors need to understand the key differences from publicly-listed investments.

Retail investors need to assess their cashflow needs and risk appetite more carefully when considering private market assets, which are less liquid and transparent than publicly-traded instruments, experts say.
Real estate signs advertise new homes for sale in the US. Savills says it projects global real estate investments to jump 27% in 2025 to US$952 billion.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party unveils three more new faces, including Senior Counsel Harpreet Singh
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has unveiled three new candidates for the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2025), including Senior Counsel Harpreet Singh, 59, a seasoned lawyer with a storied career; Sufyan Mikhail Putra Mohd Kamil, 33, a former associate director at Abdul Rahman Law Corporation; and Jasper Kuan, 46, a digital strategist in the financial services and payment sector. The trio, along with 16 other new candidates, will contest about 31 out of 97 parliamentary seats, bringing the total number of WP candidates to 19.

images.alt_text: Dr Chee Soon Juan is set to contest in the newly carved out Sembawang West SMC.

site_title: SGX’s venture into crypto derivatives could give it an edge over other bourses
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to launch Bitcoin perpetual futures in the second half of 2025, targeting institutional and professional investors. This move aims to reinforce the institutionalization of digital assets and keep SGX competitive in the growing cryptocurrency market. Industry experts see the launch as a step towards mainstreaming Bitcoin as an investment asset, with some predicting it will attract new investors and pressure other exchanges to offer similar products. The move is expected to benefit both institutional and retail investors, providing a regulated venue for trading.

SGX hopes to act as a bridge between regulated financial markets and the freewheeling world of cryptocurrency trading.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party introduces final 3 new faces, taking first-timer slate to 14
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has introduced three new candidates for the upcoming Singapore general election, bringing its slate of first-timers to 14. The new faces include Michael Thng, a Harvard graduate and start-up founder, Jackson Au, a former London Stock Exchange Group executive, and Paris Parameswari, a former US Navy security administrator. WP chief Pritam Singh said the party is prepared to deploy spare candidates if needed and has a broad range of individuals with different backgrounds and experiences. The WP's newcomer slate is seen as a significant addition to the party's efforts to improve the political system in Singapore.

site_title: Vampire thriller ‘Sinners’ scoops up US$45.6 million in ticket sales on Easter weekend
summary: Warner Bros' vampire thriller 'Sinners' debuted to an estimated US$45.6 million in ticket sales over the Easter holiday weekend, outperforming another Warner Bros blockbuster 'A Minecraft Movie' which took in US$41.3 million. Analysts say 'Minecraft' could be the year's first billion-dollar blockbuster, following its US$344.6 million domestic ticket sales in just three weeks.

images.alt_text: A Working Man starring Jason Statham as a military veteran who comes out of retirement to seek the kidnappers of his boss’ daughter.

site_title: Greater Asean integration could prevent tariff-induced slowdown in energy transition: observers
summary: The recent US tariffs on Asean clean energy exports, particularly solar cells and panels, could hinder the region's energy transition. However, some observers believe that these tariffs could spur Asean companies to diversify their customer base, potentially accelerating the transition. Analysts estimate that Asean companies could benefit from developing their domestic clean energy sectors, which could lead to greater integration within the region. Greater Asean integration, including the development of a regional power grid, could also play a crucial role in supporting the energy transition.

site_title: Play ball: Rising valuations and private equity inflows signal a new era in sports investment
summary: Standard Chartered and DBS Private Bank have launched sports investment funds for wealthy clients, signaling a new era in sports investment. The growing interest in sports investing is driven by rising valuations and private equity inflows, as major sports leagues and teams seek alternative capital financing options. The global sports industry is expected to expand at a 7% compound annual growth rate to reach $862 billion by 2033, with football making up a significant portion of this growth. Private equity firms see sports assets as a hedge against traditional market cycles, offering diversification and uncorrelated returns.

images.alt_text: Billionaires and corporations from countries throughout Asia have injected hefty funds into well known teams around the world
Peter Lim and his wife Cherie Lim before Spanish La Liga match between Valencia CF v Sevilla FC at Mestalla Stadium in 2018.

site_title: China’s US envoy urges end to trade war, but warns Beijing ready to fight
summary: China's US envoy, Xie Feng, urged Washington to seek common ground and pursue peaceful coexistence, warning that China is ready to retaliate in the escalating trade war. Tariffs have all but frozen mammoth trade between the two economies, with over 100% tariffs in each direction. Xie drew parallels between the Great Depression and US tariffs in 1930, emphasizing the need for harmony in relations. China opposes the trade war and will retaliate to any country imposing tariffs on it.

images.alt_text: Several major banks have downgraded their forecast on China’s expansion this year to 4% or lower, well below the government’s goal of around 5%.

A 2025 Ford Mustang Mach-E GT electric sport utility vehicle (SUV) during the 2025 New York International Auto Show (NYIAS) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. site_title: South-east Asia is binging on snacks, and investors are buying in
summary: South-east Asia's snack market is booming, driven by a "snackification" trend where meals are being replaced by quick, indulgent, and functional bites. Investors are taking notice, with Temasek's US$1 billion investment in India's Haldiram's and Affinity Equity Partners' US$1.2 billion acquisition of Indonesia's Yupi Indo Jelly Gum. The sector's growth is fueled by a young and growing population, with a compound annual growth rate of 7.4%. Key factors driving this trend include better-for-you products, local flavors, and digital-first strategies. Successful snack brands must balance operational discipline with brand agility to capitalize on the region's export potential and rising incomes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows packets of snacks on the shelves inside a Haldiram's restaurant in Mumbai, India, September 6, 2023. REUTERS/M. Sriram/File Photo

In Indonesia's underdeveloped credit system with high NPL risk, many micro, small, and medium enterprises and consumers turn to informal lending sources, which charge exorbitant interest rates and exacerbate financial instability.

The discipline and the rigour that founders place in undertaking a financial modelling exercise can also better prepare them for variables and enhance their sense of confidence in dealing with uncertainties ahead of them.

site_title: InnoTek conducts buybacks following robust FY2024
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Institutional investors were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with a net outflow of S$14 million over the five trading sessions from Apr 17 to 24. The highest net institutional outflow was seen in UOB, DBS, and Venture Corporation. In contrast, Singtel, Singapore Exchange, and ST Engineering led the net institutional inflow. Fourteen primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$20.7 million. InnoTek, a company that achieved significant progress in FY2024, conducted its first buyback since May 2013, with OCBC being the largest buyer.

images.alt_text: Over the four trading sessions from Mar 28 to Apr 3, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional inflow of S$76 million.

site_title: Fidelity, Goldman find tariff haven in Asian consumer stocks
summary: Asian consumer stocks have outperformed peers in the US and Europe during market turmoil, driven by prompt policy support from governments. Fidelity International and Goldman Sachs recommended Asian consumer staples, citing government stimulus and a shift in investor mindset from growth stocks to domestic demand resilience. The MSCI Asia-Pacific Consumer Staples Index has risen 5% since April 2, while some companies have seen significant gains, such as Yonghui Superstores in China and Kobe Bussan in Japan. Fiscal stimulus plans in China, South Korea, and India are expected to further support consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Tokyo led the gains even as data showed Japanese inflation accelerated last month as rice prices more than doubled.

site_title: China accelerates budget spending to counter tariff woes
summary: China accelerated government spending in the first quarter, with combined expenditure reaching 9.3 trillion yuan, a 5.6% increase from the same period last year. This is the strongest gain for the first quarter in three years, accounting for nearly 22% of the year's planned outlays. The move aims to shield the economy from US tariffs, a housing market downturn, and deflation, which are expected to slow China's growth. Several major banks have downgraded their forecast to 4% or lower, below the government's goal of 5%.

images.alt_text: A string of recent data has pointed to an uneven economic recovery, with bank lending beating expectations and factory activity picking up speed.

site_title: GE2025: SDP launches campaign slogan ‘Thrive, not just Survive’
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has launched its campaign slogan "Thrive, not just Survive" ahead of the upcoming General Election 2025. The party, led by Dr. Chee Soon Juan, proposes a reduction of the GST to 5%, scrapping it for everyday essentials, and introducing a minimum wage act. The SDP will contest in four constituencies, including Sembawang West SMC and Bukit Panjang SMC, and has unveiled its four-member slate for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC.

site_title: GE2025: Not a ‘consolation prize’ to field former PAP opposition-ward candidates in other constituencies: SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the People's Action Party's (PAP) decision to field candidates in various constituencies is based on overall political calculations, not "consolation prizes." The party will deploy candidates who are convinced to do their best for residents and are the right fit for each area. New candidates, including Jasmin Lau and Victor Lye, will be fielded in Ang Mo Kio GRC and Jalan Kayu ward, respectively, as they bring valuable experience and a desire to make a difference. The PAP aims to field a high-quality slate of candidates to provide a competent government.

site_title: ST Engineering group COO Ravinder Singh to retire; Vertex Holdings’ managing director Mervyn Tan to take his place
summary: ST Engineering's COO Ravinder Singh will retire on May 31, taking on an advisory role, while Mervyn Tan, managing director of Vertex Holdings, will join the group as COO for technology and innovation, effective June 1. Tan brings experience from DSTA, Mindef, and SAF, and has been instrumental in shaping the company's defence and public security segment. The move comes after 11 years of Singh's leadership, during which the DPS segment grew over 20% in revenue, and the group secured over S$2.2 billion in new orders internationally.

ST Engineering’s subsidiary will hold a 60 per cent stake in the joint venture company.

site_title: GE2025: SPP launches manifesto, proposes distributing government surpluses as CDC vouchers
summary: The Singapore People's Party (SPP) has launched its 2025 General Election manifesto, titled "It is Time", proposing various policies to address economic stability, fairness, and sustainable public transport. Key proposals include distributing government surpluses as CDC vouchers, progressive taxation, and reviewing the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement to address labor inflow concerns. The party will field five candidates in the 2025 election, with secretary-general Steve Chia set to contest in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC.

site_title: A third of German firms plan job cuts in 2025
summary: A third of German firms plan job cuts in 2025 due to the strain caused by the ongoing tariff war. Despite a slight improvement in business sentiment, the construction and manufacturing sectors remain pessimistic, with optimists outnumbered by pessimists. The German Economic Institute attributes the bleak outlook to the lingering effects of the energy crisis and weak global demand for German manufactured goods, with the US tariff war being a significant contributor. The government is urged to take countermeasures to provide stability for companies.

images.alt_text: China’s status as the second-largest overseas holder of Treasuries has come into focus in recent weeks as analysts debate the nation’s role in the recent turmoil.

site_title: Ex-offenders find community and ‘family’ at The Caffeine Experience
summary: The Caffeine Experience (TCE) is a social enterprise in Singapore that provides jobs and a supportive community for ex-offenders. Founded by Matthew Poh, an ex-offender himself, the company employs individuals with a prison sentence and offers training and counseling to help them turn their lives around. With a focus on building a "family" atmosphere, TCE has seen a 20% employee retention rate, despite high turnover rates in the F&B industry. The company turns over $1 million annually and employs 20 people across its five outlets, with Poh aiming to help 30-50 ex-offenders start a new life through his work.

Ng, 56, previously led the PAP's four-member team in Sengkang GRC, where they lost to the Workers' Party. He vows to improve transport connectivity and sports facilities in Jalan Kayu. The PAP has also introduced two new faces, Jasmin Lau and Victor Lye, to the Ang Mo Kio GRC team, which will face a three-cornered fight with the Singapore United Party (SUP) and People's Power Party (PPP).

site_title: Dubai real estate firms explore Islamic bonds amid boom
summary: Dubai-based real estate firms Sobha Realty and Omniyat are exploring Islamic debt markets, aiming to capitalize on strong demand for property in the city. Sobha is reportedly gauging investor interest in a dollar-denominated sukuk to buy land, while Omniyat considers a debut dollar sukuk to fund upcoming projects. Despite prices cooling, developers say buyer appetite remains strong, with available inventory selling quickly. The firms' moves come as the US President's tariffs have rattled global markets and Dubai's property boom faces growing headwinds.

images.alt_text: Dubai’s residential property market is driven by strong economic growth, a favourable tax environment, and high rental yields.

site_title: GE2025: SDP unveils ‘Thrive’ manifesto with proposals from tax to immigration and housing
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has unveiled its "Thrive" manifesto for the 2025 General Election, focusing on six key areas: taxes, healthcare, respect for the environment and people, immigration, housing, and education. The party proposes cutting the goods and services tax (GST), replacing current healthcare schemes with a single national insurance system, and implementing a "Singaporeans first" immigration policy. Additionally, the SDP suggests its own public housing model, guide prices for new Housing Board flats, and reforms to the education system to address inequality.

site_title: S-Reits rebound from early April sell-off
summary: Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) have rebounded strongly over the past two weeks, with the iEdge S-Reit index climbing 5.9% since April 11. S-Reits with international exposure and hospitality assets were among the top performers. Despite institutional and retail investors net selling S-Reits, retail investors remain net buyers, with total net inflows of $261.9 million for the year-to-date. Key S-Reits such as Mapletree Logistics Trust, CapitaLand China Trust, and Suntec Reit recorded positive rental reversions and improved distributable income, with their units rebounding 7.4% over the same period.

images.alt_text: In March, Singapore Reits outperformed the global Reit market.

site_title: Deepal S07 review: Friendly, but competitive
summary: The Deepal S07 is a Chinese electric SUV designed in Turin, Italy, with a focus on style and comfort. It features a sleek design, frameless windows, and a 15.6-inch touchscreen. The car has a 218 horsepower motor, a 475km range, and a smooth ride. While it lacks advanced features like parking assistance, the S07 excels in its cabin space and refinement. With a competitive price tag of S$199,999, the S07 is a promising entry in the fast-growing Chinese EV market.

images.alt_text: Visually, the MGS5 plays it fairly safe. Some lines are so smooth it’s like the car has had its skin pulled tight, but there are no crazy light shows, nor a giant phony grille screaming for attention.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit lead independent director Kenny Kwan fails to get re-elected at AGM
summary: Keppel DC Reit's lead independent director Kenny Kwan failed to get re-elected at the annual general meeting, with 49.9% of votes in favor of his reappointment. Low Huan Ping was appointed as a director, while other resolutions were passed with over 90% support. The trust's manager was authorized to issue units and make convertible instruments, and the auditor's remuneration was fixed. The AGM occurred before the release of the trust's first-quarter results, which showed a 14.2% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit.

site_title: China’s murky bankruptcies expose hazards for foreign investors
summary: China's bankruptcy laws are being exploited by companies to evade payment obligations, leaving foreign investors vulnerable. A pork producer, Dalian Chuming Meat Processing, filed for bankruptcy in 2019 but continued to operate, with some investors alleging the company violated regulations and failed to provide financial information. Similar cases have been reported, with Chinese courts often favoring local interests over foreign shareholders. The lack of transparency and enforcement of insolvency laws poses significant risks for investors, with some reporting losses of hundreds of millions of dollars.

site_title: Toyota meets ‘aggressive’ Apac entry of China carmakers with more EVs – and combustion engines
summary: Toyota is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific market with a "multi-pathway strategy" that includes both electric vehicles (EVs) and combustion engines. Despite being slow to pivot to EVs, Toyota aims to introduce more EV models to the region "soon" and reach 15 EV models by 2027. The company's approach is varied, with hybrids also playing a key role, particularly in Asia where infrastructure and market readiness vary widely. Toyota's goal is to have 1 million EVs produced annually, with EVs expected to form 30% of the global car market at most.

site_title: Capital One, Discover deal gets US bank regulators’ nod
summary: US banking regulators approved Capital One's $35.3 billion purchase of Discover Financial Services, creating the nation's eighth-largest bank. The combined entity will have assets of $637.8 billion and become the largest US credit card issuer by balances. The deal is expected to increase competition in payment networks and offer customers a wider range of products. However, critics argue that the combination will reduce competition and lead to higher fees and costs for consumers.

images.alt_text: The Fed has announced in December that it would begin making several changes to the annual exams of big bank health.

site_title: Bankers get creative to sign M&A deals in Trump's trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war has led bankers to get creative in signing multibillion-dollar deals, with some adding clauses to protect investors or sweetening terms to secure deals. Despite a market slump and unpredictable tariffs, deals like Prada's $1.38 billion acquisition of Versace and Silver Lake's purchase of Intel's Altera business are moving forward. To mitigate risk, companies are modifying terms, such as deferring payments or recalculating valuations. Dealmakers say some companies are rethinking deals, cutting them slightly, or using creative financing structures to bridge valuation gaps.

images.alt_text: Tumult in global financial markets is hitting private assets as exit activity that was expected to be led by IPOs and mergers has  ground to a halt, said Nitin Gupta, managing partner at Flexstone Partners.

site_title: Why sustainable equity investors should pay attention to Singapore
summary: Singapore has identified the green economy as a key area for growth and is leveraging its position as a regional hub. The Straits Times Index's green revenues exposure stands at 10.9% of market capitalization, surpassing the global average and exceeding that of China, Hong Kong, and other Asian countries. The Singapore Green Plan 2030 aims to achieve 80% of buildings being green, 80% of new developments being super low-energy, and best-in-class green buildings achieving 80% energy efficiency improvement by 2030. Singapore's strong climate disclosure and adoption of green activities position it as a competitive player in the green economy.

images.alt_text: BMI expects electricity prices in the region to rise modestly over 2025 for various reasons.
Net Zero Banking Alliance members have more than doubled their targets in carbon-intensive sectors since 2022.

site_title: Fixed income is no longer a hedge – unless it’s active
summary: Fixed income markets are no longer a reliable hedge against stocks, as the negative correlation between the two asset classes is no longer assured. Recent tariff-fueled volatility has shown that the asset class can be volatile, with yields on 10-year US Treasuries experiencing wild swings. To get true diversification, investors should adopt an active management strategy that includes high-quality fixed income assets, flexible duration, and low volatility. A passive approach may provide unpleasant surprises, and investors should consider strategies that balance probabilities, such as flexible liquid fixed income strategies, to make fixed income a useful addition to their portfolios.

A Vietnamese garment factory. Export-oriented Asia is caught in the crosshairs of the US-China contest for economic hegemony.

“I don’t think we’re seeing dysfunction – in the sense of liquidity completely drying up in the markets – but a pattern suggestive of a loss of confidence in US economic policy,” Yellen said on CNBC on Monday.

site_title: China pits humanoid robots against humans in half-marathon
summary: China hosted the first-ever half-marathon featuring humanoid robots, with 21 robots competing alongside thousands of human runners in Beijing. The robots, designed by Chinese manufacturers, showcased their agility and endurance over a 21-km course. However, experts question the significance of the event, with some arguing that it does not demonstrate the robots' industrial potential or basic intelligence. The event is seen as a demonstration of hardware capabilities rather than AI breakthroughs, with some experts suggesting that the technology has been developed for over five years.

images.alt_text: The true winner of the AI race, however, may not be the country that invents the best models. It is more likely to be the country where governments, businesses and ordinary people use AI at scale every day.

site_title: A smarter, faster future in wealth management with AI
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming wealth management by generating valuable insights for client portfolio reviews, optimizing portfolio performance, and improving operational efficiency. Agentic AI frameworks collect, process, and interpret data, providing actionable insights for financial professionals. The Swiss Financial Innovation Desk has highlighted AI's role as the "brain of tomorrow's financial systems" in its 2035 report, and the industry's adoption of AI is expected to drive growth and innovation in wealth management, ultimately leading to increased productivity and wealth creation.

images.alt_text: A passive approach may provide unpleasant surprises. Executed carefully, however, an investment in fixed income now could be a timely move – if buyers adopt a strategy that is anchored in the active management of high quality fixed income assets, a flexible approach to duration, and low volatility.

site_title: Q&M Dental seeks secondary listing on Bursa; demands 72.3 million yuan from Aoxin Q&M CEO
summary: Q&M Dental Group has proposed a secondary listing on Bursa Malaysia, aiming to broaden its investor reach and increase liquidity. The move requires extensive preparatory work and is subject to approvals. Meanwhile, the company has issued a letter of demand to Dr. Shao Yongxin, CEO of 32.8%-owned unit Aoxin Q&M, demanding 72.3 million yuan (S$13 million) owed by Dr. Shao. Q&M holds 32.8% of Aoxin's shares, secured by an escrow arrangement, and reserves the right to withdraw the deficit amount if there is a shortfall in the profit guarantee.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Q&M operates 106 dental clinics in Singapore.

site_title: Ford ‘adjusts’ some exports to China due to tariffs
summary: Ford has "adjusted" its exports to China due to US tariffs, citing the ongoing trade conflict between the US and China. The company halted shipments of US-made vehicles, including the F-150 Raptor, Mustang, and Bronco, to China. Ford sold 442,000 vehicles in China in 2024, comprising 1.6% of the market. The move is a response to China's 125% tariffs on US exports, including cars, and the US's 145% tariffs on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Ford F-150 pickup truck is seen on the assembly line at Dearborn Truck Plant in Dearborn, Michigan, U.S.  April 11, 2024.  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: Volkswagen floats making Audis in US to swerve Trump tariffs
summary: Volkswagen's CEO Oliver Blume said the company is in "constructive discussions" with the US administration to relocate Audi production to the US to avoid US tariffs. The move aims to maintain the company's investment and partnership with the US. Despite initial plans to consider relocation, Blume ruled out American manufacturing for Porsche due to low volumes. The US tariffs, announced by President Trump, have impacted Volkswagen's first-quarter operating profit, with the company seeking to minimize the financial impact.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen, Europe’s largest auto manufacturer, said its operating profit in the first three months of 2025 fell to 2.8 billion euros (S$4.2 billion) from 4.6 billion euros in the same period last year.

site_title: Hertz wins over Ackman in a bet tariffs will boost value of cars
summary: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management has a nearly 20% stake in Hertz Global, betting that the rental car company's turnaround plan and tariffs on US auto imports will boost its vehicle value. Ackman sees a potential rise in used-car prices and a 10% increase in used car prices could equate to a $1.2 billion gain on Hertz's auto assets. Ackman aims to reach $30 a share by 2029, with CEO Gil West's targets to reach $1,500 in revenue per unit and daily per-vehicle operating expenses in the low $30-range.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 1.3 per cent at 39,142.23.
The company has said it plans to sell 30,000 EVs by the end of this year and get to a number that its customers want to rent.

site_title: Thailand kicks off process to pick new central bank governor
summary: Thailand has begun the process of selecting a new central bank governor, with a seven-member panel chaired by former bureaucrat Sathit Limpongpan. The panel will invite applications, hold interviews, and shortlist at least two candidates for Finance Minister consideration. The selection process is closely watched by investors, who are concerned about Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's administration pushing its own nominee to tighten control over the central bank. The current governor, Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, will step down in September.

images.alt_text: Thailand is among South-east Asian nations hardest hit by US President Donald Trump’s proposed measures, facing a 36 per cent tariff if a reduction can’t be negotiated before a global moratorium expires in July.
The central bank estimates that the trade war could dock as much as half a percentage point from gross domestic product growth of slightly above 2.5 per cent this year.
The central bank has said the bar would be high for a further cut as the level is consistent with the current economic outlook.
Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput says: “We believe 2 per cent is a good, robust rate suitable for a wide range of outcomes, and we don’t plan to move rates frequently.”

site_title: GE2025: PAP, WP gear up in East Coast GRC ahead of Polling Day
summary: In the final weeks before Singapore's 2025 General Election, both the People's Action Party (PAP) and the Workers' Party (WP) are intensifying efforts to reach out to residents in the East Coast Group Representation Constituency (GRC). PAP has confirmed its lineup, including Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong, while Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's participation remains uncertain. The WP has also introduced new faces, including potential candidates Kenneth Foo and Ang Boon Yaw, but its full slate has not been confirmed. Residents are expressing interest in the election and welcoming the parties' efforts.

images.alt_text: WP potential candidate Kenneth Foo (centre) speaking to residents at Block 16 food centre in East Coast GRC.
Dr Chee Soon Juan is set to contest in the newly carved out Sembawang West SMC.
Lawrence Pek (centre) mingling with a resident at the Plantation Plaza in Tengah on Mar 29.
Singapore People's Party launches its manifesto during a walkabout at 210 Toa Payoh Lor 8 Market & Hawker on Apr 19.

SM Lee Hsien Loong (second from right) said on Saturday: "When we field somebody as a candidate, we must make sure that we are completely convinced he is going to do his best for the residents, and is the right candidate for that place."
In GE2020, labour chief Ng Chee Meng contested Sengkang GRC, but lost to the Workers' Party.
WP new faces (from left) Dr Ong Lue Ping; Jimmy Tan; Andre Low; and Alexis Dang.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sees more China clients moving out of US assets
summary: Deutsche Bank reports that Chinese clients are reducing their US Treasury holdings and diversifying into European debt, particularly in Germany, Spain, and Italy, amid US President Trump's tariff deluge. This shift is driven by attractive yields and cautious investors seeking stable alternatives to Treasuries. The improved outlook for European markets, fueled by Germany's spending package and interest-rate cuts by the European Central Bank, is seen as a favorable environment for Chinese investors to reallocate into more investable countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Christian Sewing, Chief Executive Officer of Deutsche Bank, speaks at Banking Day, a gathering of bankers hosted by Germany's Banks' Association, in Berlin, Germany, April 23, 2024. REUTERS/Liesa Johannssen/File Photo

site_title: How to give Chinese tech a British accent
summary: MG, a British car brand now owned by China's SAIC, is navigating its heritage with a restrained and international approach under advanced design director Carl Gotham. The brand is launching new models with distinct designs, including the MGS5, which balances classic British lines with a more mature and serious tone. Gotham's goal is to create a coherent family of cars while honoring MG's British roots, with the help of international designers and a global perspective.

images.alt_text: Visually, the MGS5 plays it fairly safe. Some lines are so smooth it’s like the car has had its skin pulled tight, but there are no crazy light shows, nor a giant phony grille screaming for attention.

site_title: Now is the time to ask: How much market risk can you take?
summary: Investors are being urged to reassess their risk tolerance as the stock market has stabilized after President Trump's tariffs. Despite the market's recent stability, investors may be surprised by the depth of declines during a crisis, as seen during the 2008 financial crisis and the Covid pandemic. To better prepare for drawdowns, investors should consider building portfolios with specific drawdowns in mind, rather than relying on standard measures of volatility. A simple rule of thumb is to multiply the first number of the percentage allocation to stocks by four and five to estimate the range of likely decline in a severe downturn.
