Shares in Tokyo rose along with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Wellington, though Taipei edged down.
Buying a stock with a growth catalyst and at a good value point can help mitigate risk.

site_title: The hunt for dark matter lands in Singapore
summary: Singapore has joined the Global Network of Optical Magnetometers to Search for Exotic Physics (Gnome), a global network searching for dark matter, a mysterious substance making up 95% of the universe. The city-state's station, under construction in one-north, is expected to be operational by the end of this year. Scientists believe dark matter could explain how the cosmos came to be and that it may interact with atoms, causing tiny shifts in atomic clocks. Local experts have developed cutting-edge instruments, including quantum magnetometers and atomic clocks, to detect dark matter, which could help narrow down its existence.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
While efforts to understand butterflies are challenging, that’s “also the more interesting part", says Khew Sin Khoon.

site_title: Xi’s No 2 signals openness to policy shift as tariffs hit
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang signals a potential shift in economic policy as he urges officials to ensure market confidence with prompt and proactive measures. His comments come amid a worsening US-China trade dispute and lower economic forecasts for China's 2025 growth, now expected to be around 4% or lower. Li emphasized the need for a well-coordinated policy mix to positively shape market expectations and mitigate the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Trump has long argued that China’s dominant role in the maritime industry has made the US overly dependent on the Asian nation, echoing the concerns of some shipbuilders.
Trump has previously said that China’s objections to his new tariffs stalled a deal to sell off TikTok and keep the popular video sharing app operating in the US.

China has long been a target of Trump and his predecessors over its trade imbalance, alleged intellectual property theft and government subsidies, the US says undercut competition with American companies.

site_title: Of state and society: Does Singapore have social capital?
summary: Singapore's high level of social trust and safety is attributed to a balance between state-imposed laws and society-driven norms. The country's ranking in the World Happiness Report and benevolence indicators suggests that its level of social capital is consistent with its overall level of happiness. Informal experiments with dictator games, conducted with 881 NUS students, found that most students were willing to share money, but when given the option to steal, they became more stingy. This finding supports the idea that Singapore's social capital is largely consistent with international benchmarks, indicating a strong bottom-up development of social norms.

images.alt_text: It has been well-established that using gross domestic product, which values goods and services produced in an economy, as a metric to measure quality of life is woefully inadequate.

site_title: Time meets poetry, passion and play
summary: Women's haute horlogerie stole the spotlight at Watches & Wonders Geneva 2025 with Bvlgari's minimalist Serpenti Aeterna, Chanel's lipstick-inspired "Kiss Me" Secret Watch, and Van Cleef & Arpels' poetic Lady Arpels Bal des Amoureux Automate. The Serpenti Aeterna features a fluid, sculptural bangle design with diamonds, while the "Kiss Me" Secret Watch combines beauty and jewelry with a lacquered black dial and golden beryls. Van Cleef & Arpels' Lady Arpels Bal des Amoureux Automate features an in-house automaton movement with a new, four-year-developed mechanism that simulates a tender kiss between two lovers.

images.alt_text: The Black Bay 68 arrives in two distinct dial variations: a classic silver and a signature Tudor Blue.

site_title: Teo Hock Seng’s Old Holland Road bungalow up for auction with S$36 million opening price
summary: Teo Hock Seng, Komoco Holdings executive chairman, has listed his freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore's Brizay Park GCB Area for at least S$36 million, with an estimated land rate of S$1,555 psf. The 23,148 sq ft bungalow features six en suite bedrooms, a swimming pool, and a car porch. This is the second time the property has been put on the market, with a previous asking price of S$66.7 million in March 2024. The auction is expected to take place on April 23, with a defined timeline and no option to purchase.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Derryn Wong
The guide price for the redevelopment plot translates to a land rate of about S$2,800 per square foot.
A house on Gallop Park Road is being sold by Lily Yeo, the wife of the late Alan Yeo of Yeo Hiap Seng. The price is understood to be in the low-S$40 million range.
The Singapore Land Authority requires the purchaser of landed residential properties, including GCBs, to declare their identity and citizenship.

site_title: Intel will need license to export AI chips to Chinese clients: FT
summary: Intel will require a license to export its advanced AI processors to Chinese clients if they exceed certain bandwidth requirements. The chipmaker, under new CEO Lip-Bu Tan, informed clients that chips with 1,400 GB/s DRam bandwidth, 1,100 GB/s I/O bandwidth, or both exceeding 1,700 GB/s will need a license. This decision comes amid a two-year decline in the AI chip trade due to tariff threats and concerns over Big Tech spending.

images.alt_text: The leadership changes are the first major move under Lip-Bu Tan, who took the top job last month.
The tariffs exclude companies that design chips but don’t manufacture them in the US, resulting in shares of some chipmakers to outperform on the day.
TSMC, the world’s largest contract chipmaker, will take a 20 per cent stake in the new company, the report says
Intel needs to replace the engineering talent it has lost, improve its balance sheet and better attune manufacturing processes to meet the needs of potential customers, CEO Ten Lip-Bu said.

site_title: Tesla to delay US launch of affordable EV, a lower-cost Model Y: sources
summary: Tesla plans to delay the US launch of its affordable Model Y, a lower-cost version of its best-selling electric SUV, due to production and target revisions. The vehicle, codenamed E41, was expected to begin production in the US in the first half of the year but will now start at least a few months later than initially planned. The delay is attributed to various factors, including damage to the brand's reputation and supply chain disruptions. Tesla aims to produce 250,000 of the cheaper Model Ys in the US in 2026, with plans for eventual production in China and Europe.

images.alt_text: In Q1 2025, BYD outsold Tesla in pure battery EVs for the second straight quarter. And years of being shut out of the US forced BYD to redirect its focus to every other major market, including in Europe where it now has factories.
Tesla’s Shanghai factory only makes Model 3 and Model Y cars and most of them are either sold in China or exported to other parts of Asia.
Tesla’s entry into Saudi Arabia is a fresh signal Musk has mended relations with the kingdom after a spat with Yasir Al Rumayyan, head of the US$925 billion PIF.

site_title: Rudderless America
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision-making process is erratic and unstructured, making it impossible for anyone to speak on his behalf. Eight years after abandoning the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), Trump's second-term Treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, wants to renegotiate the agreement to form a united front against China. However, resurrecting Barack Obama's strategy of using the TPP to assemble a coalition against China is no longer feasible. The article concludes that Trump's unpredictable nature and lack of a coherent policy process pose a significant threat to the US and the world.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders track tariff talks
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, April 18, amid uncertainty over US-China tariff talks. Tokyo led gains despite Japanese inflation accelerating, with rice prices more than doubling. The White House and governments worldwide are negotiating to reduce tariffs imposed by the US on China, with a second round of talks set for April. US President Trump expressed optimism about the talks, citing a good relationship with Chinese President Xi Jinping. However, new tariffs on Chinese-built ships and a probe into Chinese dominance in the shipbuilding industry have raised tensions.

images.alt_text: Shares in Tokyo rose along with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Wellington, though Taipei edged down.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher; UnitedHealth weighs on Dow
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Thursday, driven by US-Japan tariff talks, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.17% due to a slump in UnitedHealth's shares. UnitedHealth's shares dropped 18% after the company lowered its forecast for the year. The S&P 500 rose 0.56% and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.57% at the open.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party introduces another batch of new faces, including ex-IMH director
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has introduced four new faces for the upcoming Singapore general election, including Dr Ong Lue Ping, a former IMH director, and Andre Low, a former disputes lawyer. WP party chief Pritam Singh declined to disclose where they will be fielded. The new candidates aim to address structural mental health issues and policy gaps affecting vulnerable families. Alexis Dang, a media company executive, and Jimmy Tan, an entrepreneur, are also part of the new lineup, with Tan citing the need for a more balanced political system with opposition representation.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Newcomer Kenneth Tiong has been walking in the Serangoon division vacated by former MP Leon Perera.
Alongside the launch of its manifesto, the Workers' Party introduced four new faces: (from left) Kenneth Tiong, Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik, Eileen Chong and Siti Alia Abdul Rahim Mattar.
From left: WP MPs Jamus Lim, Gerald Giam and He Ting Ru introduced the party's manifesto, "Working for Singapore".

site_title: Powell shows why Fed independence matters in a turbulent America
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell asserted the importance of Fed independence in a speech at the Economic Club of Chicago, defending the central bank's commitment to its goals of maximum employment and stable prices. Powell stated that the Fed's independence is a matter of law and that it will not be influenced by political pressure. He also criticized President Trump's trade policies, which could harm the economy, and warned that tariffs could lead to higher unemployment and inflation. Powell's comments came as concerns about Fed independence are rising, and he demonstrated his focus on the central bank's core goals, refusing to be swayed by external forces.

images.alt_text: The Fed has announced in December that it would begin making several changes to the annual exams of big bank health.

site_title: Issue 144: Banks lower climate ambitions; the trouble with carbon credit certification
summary: Banks have watered down their climate goals, reducing targets in carbon-intensive sectors by more than doubling since 2022. The Net Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA) now requires banks to limit warming to "well below" 2°C and "striving" for 1.5°C, rather than aligning with 1.5°C pathways. The changes give banks more flexibility to determine their own pace of decarbonization, but also raise concerns about the need for better policy support and disclosures. Additionally, researchers are calling for better resolution and quality grades for carbon credits, citing the need for more detailed project-level data and risk ratings.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.
The levies for underground coal mining will be lower by comparison.
The rules set out stricter mandatory tests which will require companies to ensure their batteries won’t catch fire or explode in tests with a specified time period.
One solution gaining attention is direct-to-chip immersion cooling, a method which significantly enhances thermal dissipation.

site_title: Boeing jet returns to US from China amid tariff war
summary: A Boeing jet has returned to the US from China, potentially halting deliveries to Chinese airlines amid the ongoing US-China tariff war. The move follows reports of a Chinese ban on Boeing imports, although the status remains unclear. Boeing has not commented on the situation, but industry sources suggest the company is preparing for a halt in deliveries due to tariffs. The US planemaker has seen deliveries to China disrupted in the past, with a significant number of unfilled orders for Chinese airlines and lessors, including 96 737 MAX orders.

images.alt_text: The Chinese maker’s C919 is a single-aisle jet designed to compete with the Airbus A320 and Boeing 737 families and has a capacity for 158 to 192 passengers.
Guangzhou-based China Southern Group is one of the world’s largest carrier groups, with stakes in 10 airlines and operating 932 commercial jets.
FILE PHOTO: A screen displays the logo for Boeing on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 2, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
The budding trade war represents the latest setback for Boeing in a market forecast to make up 20% of global aircraft demand over the next two decades.

site_title: GE2025: Former Singapore Manufacturing Federation sec-gen among PSP’s Chua Chu Kang GRC slate
summary: The opposition Party Supremo (PSP) has unveiled its slate of candidates for the upcoming Singapore General Election (GE2025), including former Singapore Manufacturing Federation secretary-general Lawrence Pek. Pek, along with technology lawyer Wendy Low, business consultant A'bas Kasmani, and investment specialist S Nallakaruppan, will contest the Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency (GRC). The PSP team faces off against the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) MPs, led by Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, in the constituency. This is the second time the PSP contests Chua Chu Kang GRC, after winning 48.32% of the vote share in 2020.

images.alt_text: Singapore People's Party launches its manifesto during a walkabout at 210 Toa Payoh Lor 8 Market & Hawker on Apr 19.
WP new faces (from left) Dr Ong Lue Ping; Jimmy Tan; Andre Low; and Alexis Dang.

Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat (centre) introduced two new faces Cai Yinzhou (second from left) and Elysa Chen (second from right) who will join his team with incumbent Saktiandi Supaat at the upcoming polls. Minister of State for Education and Manpower Gan Siow Huang will defend her seat in Marymount SMC.

site_title: US mortgage rates surge by most in a year as tariffs hit markets
summary: US mortgage rates surged by the largest weekly jump in a year, with the average 30-year loan rate reaching 6.83%, up from 6.62% last week. Higher rates risk stifling spring market sales due to economic uncertainty and tariff battles. Demand is slowing, with contracts down 0.8% from a year ago, and some economists are cutting forecasts for home-price growth this year. The impact of the trade war is already affecting the housing market, with homebuilders expecting weaker demand and higher costs.

images.alt_text: New residential construction decreased 11.4 per cent to an annualised rate of 1.32 million last month, restrained largely by single-family homes.

site_title: Trump moves to levy Chinese vessels in shipping shakeup
summary: The Trump administration has proposed levying fees on Chinese vessels docking in US ports, aiming to reduce US dependence on Chinese shipbuilding and boost the domestic industry. The plan, set to take effect in six months, would charge a fee based on the volume of goods carried, with funds used to support US shipbuilding. Opponents argue the move would raise prices, disrupt trade, and threaten US ports, while US importers see it as a de-facto tariff that would compound existing duties.

images.alt_text: Trump has previously said that China’s objections to his new tariffs stalled a deal to sell off TikTok and keep the popular video sharing app operating in the US.

China has long been a target of Trump and his predecessors over its trade imbalance, alleged intellectual property theft and government subsidies, the US says undercut competition with American companies.

A Boeing 737-800 of China United Airlines prepares to land at Shanghai Pudong International Airport in Shanghai on April 16, 2025. Donald Trump believes it is up to China to come to the negotiating table on trade, the White House said on April 15, after the US president accused Beijing of reneging on a major Boeing deal. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)
Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.

site_title: China bans ‘smart’ and ‘autonomous’ driving terms from vehicle ads
summary: China has banned the use of "smart driving" and "autonomous driving" terms in vehicle ads and tightened rules on remote software updates for driving assistance systems (ADAS) without approval. The move follows a fatal accident involving Xiaomi's best-selling sedan in March, which raised concerns over vehicle safety. Automakers must now obtain approval from authorities before upgrading ADAS via remote software updates, and face fines or have their business license revoked for misleading advertising.

images.alt_text: The rules set out stricter mandatory tests which will require companies to ensure their batteries won’t catch fire or explode in tests with a specified time period.
Down for a fifth straight session, Xiaomi's share price is now more than 20 per cent below a record high last month.
The driver assistance systems offered by Xiaomi and peers such as Xpeng and Huawei-backed EVs in China are similar to the technology that Tesla markets as Full Self-Driving.

site_title: GE2025: Ng Eng Hen steps down, Chee Hong Tat to lead PAP team for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC with 2 new faces
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen will not contest the May 3 general election, stepping down after five terms. Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat will lead the People's Action Party's team for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, introducing new candidates Cai Yinzhou and Elysa Chen. Minister of State for Education and Manpower Gan Siow Huang will defend her seat in Marymount SMC. Incumbent MPs, including Chong Kee Hiong, also announced they will not seek re-election.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The world is changing profoundly, and how Singapore navigates these turbulent times will determine its future, said Prime Minister and People’s Action Party secretary-general Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Trump raises Powell firing as ire toward Fed chair explodes
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed frustration with Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, calling him "terrible" and "too slow" to cut interest rates. Trump mused about dismissing Powell, despite the Fed's independent status, and claimed he has the power to oust the central banker. The move could have significant economic implications, potentially destabilizing markets. Economists warn that removing Powell would be a drastic step, potentially leading to a prolonged economic downturn.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump looks on as Jerome Powell, his nominee to become chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve, speaks at the White House in Washington, U.S., November 2, 2017. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
“Our independence is a matter of law,” Fed chair Powell said at the Economic Club of Chicago.
The Fed has announced in December that it would begin making several changes to the annual exams of big bank health.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei notches best week in 3 months on trade deal hopes
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 1% on Friday to its best week in three months, driven by hopes of US trade deals with Japan and other top trading partners. The Nikkei touched a two-week high of 34,758.97 before ending the day up 1.03% at 34,730.28. US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about resolving trade tensions, including with China, and Japan's economy minister Ryosei Akazawa said Trump had a "top priority" to get a deal with Japan. The Nikkei climbed 3.41% for the week, snapping a three-week losing run.

images.alt_text: Tokyo led the gains even as data showed Japanese inflation accelerated last month as rice prices more than doubled.

site_title: Why fengshui still matters in modern Singapore
summary: Fengshui, an ancient Chinese practice of arranging objects to optimize energy flows, remains relevant in modern Singapore, with its business evolving to meet the needs of a younger generation. The iconic Marina Bay Sands resort, designed with fengshui principles, continues to thrive, with revenue hitting a new high of US$4.2 billion in 2024. Many other buildings in Singapore incorporate fengshui consultants, with some companies using it as a cultural homage. Despite lacking scientific basis, fengshui is widely practiced and used as a tool for decision-making, with consultants citing its ability to create balance and harmony. As the industry adapts to modern times, fengshui is becoming more subtle and natural, with clients preferring elements like water features and crystals.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The design of this semi-detached house overcomes the tricky issue of a triangular plot, while maximising gross floor area.
The tech way to fengshui
Fengshui, the contemporary way

site_title: Liverpool poised for English Premier League coronation on Sunday
summary: Liverpool is poised to become the record-equalling 20th English league champion if they beat Leicester City on Sunday and other results go in their favor. Liverpool captain Virgil Van Dijk's team is 13 points clear of second-placed Arsenal, who face Ipswich Town, and a win for the Gunners would also see 18th-placed Ipswich relegated. The title race may end before Easter Sunday if Ipswich inflict Arsenal's first league defeat since February, while Leicester City and Ipswich are on track to be relegated with just five games left in the season.

images.alt_text: Flag off for the riders participating in the 20 kilometers Straits Times Ride at the OCBC Cycle at the National Stadium, 12 May 2024.
The 2024 edition of SCSM attracted more than 55,000 runners from Singapore and around the world.
“This is an exciting chapter for me, as I look ahead to new ventures in business,” Ronaldo said.

site_title: Netflix logs record profit in quarter, withholds user data
summary: Netflix reported a record profit in the first quarter, with earnings rising 25% to $6.61 per share, beating analyst estimates. Sales grew 13% to $10.5 billion, and operating income increased by 27% to $3.3 billion. This is the first time Netflix has reported financial results without disclosing subscriber growth, instead focusing on traditional financial metrics. The company is seeking to increase revenue from existing customers by selling advertising and raising prices, and projects strong results for the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Netflix has long used AI and machine learning for certain purposes.
Netflix paid “approximately US$44 million” for a show’s production between 2018 and 2019 helmed by Hollywood filmmaker Carl Rinsch.
Netflix will stop reporting subscriber figures after a surge in new customers from its crackdown on password sharing.

site_title: Trump signals tit-for-tat China tariffs may be near end; TikTok deal on ice
summary: US President Donald Trump signaled a potential end to the tit-for-tat tariff hikes between the US and China, saying he may not want to impose higher tariffs. Trump expressed optimism about reaching a deal with China, citing recent high-level exchanges, but noted that a deal over TikTok's fate may have to wait. The tariffs on Chinese imports, currently at 145%, are expected to remain in place, while Trump delayed implementing higher levies on other countries. A deal for TikTok's US assets, currently pending, may be put on hold until the trade issue is resolved.

images.alt_text: Trump has long argued that China’s dominant role in the maritime industry has made the US overly dependent on the Asian nation, echoing the concerns of some shipbuilders.

site_title: Intel CEO Tan Lip-Bu flattens leadership structure, names new AI chief: memo
summary: Intel CEO Tan Lip-Bu has flattened the company's leadership structure, naming Sachin Katti as new AI chief and chief technology officer. Katti will lead Intel's AI strategy and oversee the company's AI product roadmap. The changes aim to turn around the struggling chipmaker, which has faced years of manufacturing and product missteps. Tan's goal is to make Intel more engineering-focused and reduce bureaucratic processes to boost innovation.

images.alt_text: The tariffs exclude companies that design chips but don’t manufacture them in the US, resulting in shares of some chipmakers to outperform on the day.
TSMC, the world’s largest contract chipmaker, will take a 20 per cent stake in the new company, the report says
Intel needs to replace the engineering talent it has lost, improve its balance sheet and better attune manufacturing processes to meet the needs of potential customers, CEO Ten Lip-Bu said.

site_title: US House committee calls on JPMorgan, BOA to drop roles in mega HK listing of battery maker CATL
summary: US House committee chairman John Moolenaar is calling on JPMorgan and Bank of America to withdraw from the Hong Kong listing of battery maker CATL due to the company's inclusion in a Pentagon blacklist. The committee cites "significant regulatory, financial and reputational risks" and urges the banks to provide detailed responses on their risk assessments. CATL, a major supplier to Tesla, has protested its inclusion and claims the designation is a mistake. The move comes amid uncertainty over the US-China trade war and the banks' year-over-year declines in revenue from equity underwriting.

images.alt_text: CATL’s scale means it’s often able to spread costs out and deliver greater efficiencies.
The approval comes weeks after China’s securities regulator cleared CATL’s plans for the Hong Kong listing.
CATL’s listing also comes against the background of rising geopolitical tensions, which may endanger the battery maker’s global expansion.

site_title: Apple’s China smartphone shipments slide 9% in first quarter
summary: Apple's smartphone shipments in China declined 9% in the first quarter to 9.8 million units, falling to fifth place in the market with a 13.7% market share. This marks Apple's seventh consecutive quarter of decline, largely due to its premium pricing structure preventing it from capitalizing on new government subsidies introduced in January. In contrast, market leader Xiaomi saw a 40% surge in shipments to 13.3 million units, while industry-wide shipments grew 3.3%.

site_title: Trump says he is reluctant to keep raising tariffs on China
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed reluctance to continue raising tariffs on China, citing concerns it could stall trade between the two countries. Trump stated that Chinese officials, including those believed to represent President Xi Jinping, have reached out to broker a deal. However, Trump sidestepped direct questions about direct contact between him and Xi. The US has imposed 145% tariffs on Chinese goods, while China has retaliated with 125% tariffs on US goods. Trump hinted at potentially lowering tariffs and expressed confidence in a deal that would include trade concessions and a deal for the sale of TikTok's US assets.

images.alt_text: China has long been a target of Trump and his predecessors over its trade imbalance, alleged intellectual property theft and government subsidies, the US says undercut competition with American companies.

A Boeing 737-800 of China United Airlines prepares to land at Shanghai Pudong International Airport in Shanghai on April 16, 2025. Donald Trump believes it is up to China to come to the negotiating table on trade, the White House said on April 15, after the US president accused Beijing of reneging on a major Boeing deal. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)
Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.

site_title: Nvidia CEO visits Beijing after US bars chip sales to China
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang visited Beijing after the US barred the company from selling its H20 AI chip to China, a move that will impact Nvidia's product line for Chinese customers. Despite US export controls, Huang expressed optimism about China's economic outlook and reaffirmed Nvidia's commitment to the local market. The company will optimize its chip products to comply with US regulations, and Huang met with Chinese officials to discuss cooperation and investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Jensen HuangPhotographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
The latest rules for Nvidia are a sign that the Trump administration will stay the course on the US government’s approach to Chinese tech development.
Manufacturing AI chips and supercomputers in the US will create hundreds of thousands of jobs in the coming decades, Nvidia said.

site_title: Malaysia trade minister to head to US next week for tariff talks
summary: Malaysia's Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz will visit the US on April 24 to discuss US tariffs imposed on the country. Zafrul stated that the goal of the trip is to demonstrate Malaysia's ability to support US industries rather than posing a threat. He will also explain Asean's stance on the tariffs, which have had a significant impact on South-east Asian countries. The visit aims to correct "wrong views" and prevent retaliatory tariffs, with Malaysia having ruled out imposing its own tariffs.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping’s comments come after US President Donald Trump, who took office in January, shocked markets by imposing sweeping tariffs on countries across the world.
EPF, one of the world’s biggest pension funds, in common with other major investors is grappling with the uncertainty triggered by US President Donald Trump’s tariffs and policy orders.

The preliminary agreements ranged from cooperation in artificial intelligence to mutual visa exemptions and global security, as Chinese President Xi Jinping met Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim on Wednesday (Apr 16) in Putrajaya.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim greets Chinese President Xi Jinping at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Apr 15, during Xi's visit to Malaysia.
Malaysia's Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said major foreign investors remain committed to their expansion plans in Malaysia despite the evolving trade landscape.
Chinese President Xi Jinping makes a three-country tour of South-east Asia from Apr 14 to 18 amid an escalating trade tensions with the US. He arrived Hanoi on Monday for a two-day state visit.

Malaysia will host a special Asean Economic Ministers meeting on Thursday (Apr 10), seek to align the positions of member states to present a unified response during negotiations with the US as a single bloc.
Asean member states are pursuing amendments to their trade agreement with the United States in response to recently implemented US tariffs.

site_title: US Fed proposes averaging large bank stress test results to reduce volatility
summary: The US Federal Reserve has proposed averaging large bank stress test results over two years to reduce volatility, and giving banks three extra months to adjust capital plans. Under the new proposal, banks receiving test results in June would have until January to adjust capital plans, rather than the current October deadline. The changes aim to make the stress tests more transparent and less volatile, but some Fed governors have expressed concerns about the potential impact on the tests' effectiveness.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump in his social media post said Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell was “always too late and wrong”, and critiqued the speech Powell made on Wednesday, calling it “another, and typical, complete mess!”
“Despite heightened uncertainty and downside risks, the US economy is still in a solid position,” Powell says.
What businesses and workers anticipate will happen to prices, economists say, can play a key role in determining what actually does happen.
A dose of humility will help the Jerome Powell-led Fed reduce the risk of another bout of slippages in analysis, forecasts, communication and policy design.

site_title: Expert panel urges Singapore’s financial institutions to prepare for post-quantum threats and supply chain risks
summary: A newly formed expert panel, convened by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, has urged financial institutions to prepare for post-quantum threats and supply chain risks. The Cyber and Technology Resilience Experts Panel recommends four strategies: adopting a service-centric approach, re-examining IT supply chains, preparing for a post-quantum world, and implementing a multi-layered approach to detect and counter emerging digital financial scams. The panel, comprising 13 global experts, aims to strengthen cyber and operational resilience across the financial sector. MAS will work with financial institutions to implement these strategies and enhance their overall resilience.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The new panel replaces the Cyber Security Advisory Panel, which was set up in 2017.

site_title: EU weighs export restrictions on US if trade negotiations fail
summary: The European Union is considering introducing export restrictions on the US as a possible retaliatory tactic if trade negotiations fail. The restrictions, which could target critical goods, would be used as a deterrent and implemented if talks don't produce a satisfactory outcome. The EU and US have made little progress in talks, and the EU is also exploring additional measures, including tariffs and limiting public procurement for American companies.

images.alt_text: Stacked shipping containers at Aarhus Havn in Aarhus, Denmark. Photographer: Carsten Snejbjerg/Bloomberg
European policymakers must also resist the temptation to react to the “flood” of cheap Chinese goods that are diverted from the US market to Europe.
The EU has increased tariffs on Chinese-built EVs to as much as 45.3 per cent last October.

China is ready to deepen trade, investment and industrial cooperation with the European Union, China’s Commerce Minister Wang Wentao (pictured) told European trade and economic security commissioner Maros Sefcovic in a video call.

site_title: Malaysia’s Q1 growth expected to come in below expectations at 4.4% as US tariffs cast shadow over outlook
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to grow at 4.4% in the first quarter of 2025, below expectations, due to ongoing global headwinds. Despite robust domestic activity, the growth is a third straight quarter of slower growth. The services sector drove quarterly growth, expanding 5.2%, while manufacturing and construction posted double-digit growth. Policymakers are reviewing the 2025 growth forecast, currently set at 4.5-5.5%, amid global trade uncertainties, including US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia's Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz says: “Negotiation takes time, right? So, it is more to talk about how Malaysia can play an important role in the supply chain between Asia and the US.”
UOB views the tariff implication on consumer price inflation in Malaysia as small, with supply-driven factors and potential excess supply dumping activities neutralising the effects.
Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said the Bill would help the country address climate change, while strengthening its position as a “regional frontrunner in low-carbon technologies.”
Malaysia’s government and central bank have forecast the economy to expand between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent in 2025, following 5.1 per cent growth in 2024.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as Trump eyes trade deal, rips Powell
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.3% at 39,142.23, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.1% and declined 0.1% respectively. US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about a trade deal, stating "there will be a trade deal, 100 per cent," but also criticized Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, saying his "termination... cannot come fast enough." The comments led to market volatility, with individual stocks such as UnitedHealth and Eli Lilly affected.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - APRIL 15: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on April 15, 2025 in New York City. U.S. stocks climbed early Tuesday as investors weighed recent updates on President Trump's tariffs, including a possible reprieve for the auto industry and a definitive move toward new duties on semiconductors and pharmaceuticals.   Adam Gray/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Adam Gray / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: OpenAI’s US$500 billion Stargate venture weighs future UK investment: FT
summary: OpenAI's Stargate, a $500 billion data-centre project, is considering a future investment in the UK as it explores locations for its artificial intelligence infrastructure. The project, backed by SoftBank, Oracle, and OpenAI, aims to make the UK an "AI superpower" through pro-innovation regulation, public data availability, and data centre zones. The UK, along with Germany and France, is among the top contenders, following OpenAI's expansion to European offices in London, Paris, Brussels, and Munich.

images.alt_text: The family of models also operate at a “much lower cost” compared to GPT-4.5, OpenAI says.
OpenAI faces pressure from investors to change its structure.
Microsoft-backed OpenAI said it looks to deliver increasingly powerful tools for the 500 million people who use ChatGPT every week.
SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman attend an event to pitch AI for businesses in Tokyo, Japan, Feb 3, 2025.

site_title: South Korea proposes 12.2 trillion won extra budget to underpin growth amid tariff turmoil
summary: South Korea's government proposed a 12.2 trillion won (S$11.3 billion) extra budget to counter economic growth risks amid a global trade war and domestic uncertainty. The budget plan includes measures to support the auto and chip sectors, artificial intelligence, small businesses, and natural disaster responses. The proposal aims to boost growth by 0.1 percentage point and finance the budget through additional government bonds. The move comes as the country faces a high downside risk to its growth forecast of 1.5% and a possibility of an economic contraction in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s decision to pump more money into its key chips sector is designed to help companies cope with heavier costs as they compete globally, it says.
South Korea’s acting President Han Duck-soo had explained in detail South Korea’s stance on tariff negotiations to Trump, and the US president had been satisfied.
South Korean Trade Minister Cheong In Kyo (pictured) met US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer about lowering tariff rates slapped on the country.

site_title: Nickel scam accused’s buying spree extends to S$8 million on semi-detached house, S$2 million on art pieces: witnesses
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, accused of swindling nearly 1,000 victims of about S$1.5 billion, spent S$8 million on a semi-detached house and S$2 million on 41 works of art, allegedly using ill-gotten gains from his nickel trading. Prosecution witnesses testified that Ng purchased the property and art pieces on trust for his children, but the funds used were from the criminal benefits he obtained from fraudulent nickel trading through his company Envy Global Trading. The prosecution seeks to prove Ng's money-laundering charges.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
In total, Ng Yu Zhi is said to have spent more than S$21 million on about 20 luxury cars.

site_title: Adani to sell Australian terminal to his port firm in stock deal
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani's Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone will acquire Abbot Point Port Holdings from Carmichael Rail and Port Singapore Holdings in a $2.5 billion deal. The acquisition includes the North Queensland Export Terminal, which handles 30 million tonnes of thermal and metallurgical coal annually. The deal aims to expand Adani's global footprint and achieve an annual capacity target of one billion tonnes by 2030, with operating profit growth targeting $400 million in four years. This is Adani's fourth international port asset, following acquisitions in Israel, Sri Lanka, and Tanzania.

images.alt_text: The latest win is the second boost for the Adani Group as it is in the process of redeveloping Mumbai’s Dharavi slum, which is also the largest in Asia.
The India investment plans of Adani come amid legal challenges it faces in the US, and a string of project setbacks in countries including Kenya and Sri Lanka.

President Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s administration opened probes into the company’s local projects after billionaire founder Gautam Adani (top) was charged with bribery in the United States late last year.
This is the first phase of Adani Group’s exit from the joint venture in which it holds 44 per cent.

site_title: SIA, ANA tie up for Singapore-Japan flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and All Nippon Airways (ANA) have agreed to operate revenue-sharing flights between Singapore and Japan starting in September 2025, expanding joint venture efforts to improve connectivity and offer customers more options. The joint venture will also enable better coordination of flight schedules and reciprocal benefits for frequent flyers. The airlines aim to expand the partnership to Australia, India, Indonesia, and Malaysia, subject to regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: People viewing cherry blossoms in Tokyo. Singapore's competition regulator notes that the main competitors on the routes between the two cities are Singapore Airlines and All Nippon Airways.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party’s manifesto offers 125 ideas, from redundancy insurance to prioritising local talent
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has launched its manifesto for the upcoming Singapore general election, featuring 125 policy proposals across five broad areas. The manifesto, titled "Working for Singapore", aims to create a more "resilient, inclusive and democratic" Singapore. Key proposals include redundancy insurance, housing affordability measures, and a new "fixed-term" work pass for local hiring in specific industries. The party also emphasizes the importance of supporting families and enhancing security and geopolitics. WP's manifesto builds upon previous proposals, with some still pending implementation from the previous government.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Navene Elangovan
The 30-plus new candidates that the PAP will field is the largest slate in recent history, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.

site_title: Temu, Shein see US sales surge ahead of small parcel tariff
summary: US online shopping giants Temu and Shein saw significant sales growth in March and April as American consumers stockpiled products ahead of tariff-led price increases. Temu recorded 46% and 60% growth, while Shein saw 29% and 38% growth in revenue. The companies plan to raise prices starting April 25 due to increased operating expenses. Chinese suppliers are prioritizing securing new production locations outside China to offset expected US sales decline once prices rise.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shein and Temu app icons are seen in this illustration taken August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Shein is also investing 10 billion yuan in industrial projects in South China, including a US$500 million supply chain hub in Guangzhou’s Zengcheng District.
Shein ships the majority of its products directly to shoppers by air in individually addressed packages.
Shein and Temu have for years surfed on that practice to send tens of billions of US dollars worth of product into the US from their network of Chinese factories.

site_title: Europe: Shares clock marginal losses after ECB eases rates as expected
summary: European shares closed 0.1% lower on Thursday, despite a 4% weekly gain, after the European Central Bank eased borrowing rates for the seventh time in a year. The move aims to boost confidence in the struggling economy amid trade tariffs and uncertainty. European earnings season saw mixed results, with Hermes and LVMH reporting sales below expectations. The Stoxx 600 index is down 10% from its March record closing high, and tech stocks and euro zone banks were the top sub-sector laggards.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.2 per cent, though it was well off intraday lows by the close.

site_title: ‘Fallacy’ to say OCBC does not know insurance business: board chairman
summary: OCBC's board chairman, Andrew Lee, addressed shareholder concerns about the bank's acquisition of Great Eastern Holdings, saying it's a "fallacy" to say OCBC doesn't know the insurance business. OCBC has owned a majority of GEH's shares since 2004, and executives have "criss-crossed" between the two companies. Lee emphasized that the acquisition will bring synergistic benefits, such as cross-selling capabilities and profit contributions, and that the offer price is fair for OCBC shareholders. He also rejected suggestions to raise the offer price, citing governance and process constraints.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

GEH chairman Soon Tit Koon says that the board recognises that the current trading suspension is "not a satisfactory situation". Shares of Great Eastern have been suspended from trading since July 2024.
Helen Wong says: “We know a balanced portfolio can help us to overcome, in particular, the uncertainty and the volatility in the market over the next decade.”
SGX has no objection to granting the extension, the insurer says.
Dissident minority investor calls on OCBC to unlock value by distributing Great Eastern stake

site_title: Japan’s inflation quickens as rice prices gain most in 50 years
summary: Japan's inflation accelerated to a 3.2% year-over-year increase in March, driven by a 92.1% surge in rice prices, the fastest pace in 50 years. Consumer confidence has dropped to a two-year low, while households' price expectations continue to rise. The Bank of Japan is likely to maintain its rate-hike stance, despite US tariff measures that may cloud the economic outlook. The elevated cost of living has raised debate among lawmakers on cash handouts or tax rebates ahead of Japan's election in July.

images.alt_text: US trade tariffs are shaking up Japan’s industrial supply chains, particularly for automobiles, the country’s biggest export item.

Tourists walk past shops and restaurants up the hill leading to Kiyomizu-dera Temple in the city of Kyoto on January 13, 2025. Japan on January 15 will announce tourist figures for the year 2024, widely expected to break the record set in 2019. (Photo by PAUL MILLER / AFP)
Stubbornly high food costs and rising wages have kept consumer inflation above the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for nearly three years.

site_title: ‘Resist protectionism’, Xi Jinping tells Cambodia amid US tariff standoff
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged Cambodia to resist protectionism during his visit, amid US tariffs threatening the economies of both countries. The two nations signed 37 agreements, including water resources and education, and Cambodia's largest creditor, China, pledged to continue supporting its development. Xi also urged Cambodia to crack down on online frauds, targeting Chinese gangs. The visit was seen as a charm offensive in South-east Asia, following US tariffs that have hit the region hard.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping’s comments come after US President Donald Trump, who took office in January, shocked markets by imposing sweeping tariffs on countries across the world.

site_title: Women went to space, but men still want to own it
summary: A recent all-female spaceflight by Blue Origin sparked debate about feminism and publicity stunts, but the true focus of billionaire men in space exploration remains unclear. Despite the attention drawn to women's achievements, billionaires like Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk, and Richard Branson are pushing for space colonization and tourism. They claim to aim for a new frontier to escape Earth's limitations, but critics argue that their true motivations are driven by a desire for power, wealth, and control. The pursuit of space exploration by the wealthy may be a distraction from addressing pressing issues on Earth, such as climate change and inequality.

images.alt_text: The TeLEOS-1 system is the first Singapore-made commercial earth observation satellite.
Jeff Bezos, who started Amazon.com and is the world’s third-richest person, founded Blue Origin in 2000.

site_title: Indonesia says to increase US imports, lower orders from other countries
summary: Indonesia plans to increase US imports by up to $19 billion, including $10 billion in energy imports, to eliminate its trade surplus and avoid US tariffs. The country will also reduce imports from other countries and work on critical minerals. Additionally, Indonesia will simplify procedures for American horticultural products imports and facilitate US companies operating in the country. The move follows talks with the US, where a 32% tariff on Indonesian exports was paused for 90 days. Negotiations between the two countries are set to be completed within the next 60 days.

images.alt_text: The levies for underground coal mining will be lower by comparison.
Indonesia Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the ministry recommended increasing the LPG import quota for the US, as well as importing more US crude, to help reach the target.
Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto says: “Indonesia is one of the countries that had the first opportunity to be invited to Washington.”

site_title: Malaysia’s electrical, electronics exports on shaky ground as global headwinds intensify
summary: Malaysia's electrical and electronics exports face uncertainty due to renewed US tariffs, which could impact RM64 billion worth of non-semiconductor shipments. The country's 13% share in global semiconductor assembly, testing, and packaging (ATP) market may not provide a significant buffer against the threat. A proposed 24% tariff on non-semiconductor exports to the US could deter foreign investment and negatively impact businesses, with 74% of companies surveyed fearing potential tariffs. The semiconductor sector, exempt for now, remains vulnerable to a reciprocal US tariff exceeding 20%.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Trump’s politics is about casting America as a victim and himself as its fearless saviour, prepared to take action nobody else will in order to defeat its “enemies”
Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit Vietnam, Malaysia and Cambodia in his first overseas trip of the year, says China’s foreign ministry.

In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.
An industrial Park in Bac Giang, Vietnam.  In Asia, Vietnam holds the largest share of exports to the US and has the widest trade deficit
Malaysia's Petronas Twin Towers (C) are pictured with others commercial buildings from the KL Tower in Kuala Lumpur on February 21, 2025. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: ECB cuts rates again to help economy weather erratic US trade policy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates for the seventh time in a year, lowering the deposit rate to 2.25% to help the eurozone economy weather erratic US trade policy. The move aims to prop up an already struggling economy, with ECB president Christine Lagarde citing the need to be "agile" in the face of uncertainty. The cut was expected by most economists, who predict further policy easing due to increased uncertainty and volatile market response to trade tensions.

images.alt_text: The ECB has been easing borrowing costs rapidly as undue price pressures are disappearing, and recent turmoil on global markets is likely to bolster the bank’s conviction.

site_title: Oil posts weekly gain on trade deal hopes, new Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose 3.2% to $67.96 a barrel, with Brent crude futures gaining $2.11, or 3.2%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude gaining $2.21, or 3.54%, on hopes for a US-EU trade deal and new US sanctions targeting Iranian oil exports. The deal and sanctions, including those against a China-based oil refinery, could limit oil demand destruction from US tariffs and increase supply concerns. Oil prices gained 5% for the week, their first weekly gain in three weeks.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.18, or 1.8 per cent, to US$65.85 a barrel.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 17)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong warned Singapore must prepare for a more protectionist, arbitrary, and dangerous economic and geopolitical environment. The country plans to expand trade ties, forge new alliances, and push for WTO reform amid escalating US-China tensions. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Investment launched its first retail Reit in China with assets worth 2.8 billion yuan. Singapore's March exports eased to analysts' surprise, and the country's key exports are forecasted for a downgrade.

site_title: Chinese tea chain Chagee CEO becomes a billionaire after US$411 million US IPO
summary: Chinese entrepreneur Junjie Zhang, 30, has become a billionaire after his US-based tea chain Chagee Holdings went public with a $411 million IPO. Zhang now has a $1.8 billion fortune, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Chagee specializes in premium, milk-based teas using traditional Chinese blends and has a network of over 6,400 shops globally. The company's IPO comes as tensions between the US and China continue, with some analysts questioning the viability of Chinese stocks on American exchanges.

images.alt_text: Chagee is proceeding with an IPO amid an escalating trade war between the US and China, with both sides imposing steep levies on each others’ goods.

site_title: Trump moves towards deal with Iran on nuclear programme
summary: US President Donald Trump has initiated indirect talks with Iran on its nuclear program, with American negotiator Steven Witkoff meeting Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi in Muscat, Oman. The talks aim to reach a deal where Iran dismantles its nuclear program in exchange for economic sanctions relief. Trump has warned that if the talks fail, the US will use "bombing" tactics, but has also expressed a desire for a deal that would allow Iran to "get on with its lives." The negotiations come as Iran's economy is struggling and its allies in the region are weakened, but face challenges in securing concessions from the US amid a changing global balance of power.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.18, or 1.8 per cent, to US$65.85 a barrel.

site_title: DBS CEO Tan Su Shan sees ‘silver linings’ for Asia amid trade upheaval
summary: DBS CEO Tan Su Shan sees opportunities for Asia amidst US trade upheaval, citing the region's 18 of 20 fastest-growing trade corridors and 60% of its trade occurring within the region. She advises businesses to remain nimble and resilient, with a focus on strategic planning, supply chain agility, and diversification. Tan also highlights the need for alternative financial and payment systems, as the US dollar's dominance may be waning. The US tariffs may lead to a dual-track model of global trade, with companies manufacturing in the US for the American market while operating under separate rules and agreements elsewhere.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
DPM Gan says Singapore must “prepare for a new economic and geopolitical environment that is more protectionist, arbitrary and dangerous”.  PHOTO: DBS
DPM Gan Kim Yong (left) and SBF vice-chairman Mark Lee (standing in for SBF chairman) at the Economic Resilience Task Force press conference.
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong delivering his opening remarks at a NTUC dialogue session with labour movement leaders and union leaders at the NTUC Centre on Apr 14.

While Singapore may not be targeted by higher tariffs, the real risk for the trade-reliant city-state is how politicised and inconsistent US trade actions are reshaping the global environment, said participants in a webinar by the Iseas-Yusof Ishak Institute. PHOTO: AFP

site_title: German home building permits decline in February, halting recovery
summary: Germany's home building permits declined 2.3% in February, dropping to 17,900, after two consecutive months of increases. This setback marks the nation's property sector, which began shrinking in 2022, as its most severe slump in decades. The country's goal of building 400,000 apartments per year remains unmet, and experts, including the head of the Central Association of the German Construction Industry, are calling for decisive action, including tax cuts and reduced bureaucracy, to spark a turnaround.

site_title: Thai economic growth to see hit from US tariffs, central bank says
summary: Thailand's economic growth is expected to be impacted by US tariffs on its exports, with a 36% tariff looming if negotiations fail by July. The effect will be seen in the second half of the year, according to Bank of Thailand assistant governor Sakkapop Panyanukul. Thailand's GDP growth is likely to be less than 2.5% this year, down from a previous forecast, due to higher US imports and delayed investment decisions. The economy is expected to grow, but at a slower pace than expected, with inflation likely to fall due to supply-side factors.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s trade surplus with the US more than doubled to US$46 billion last year from about US$17 billion at the beginning of Donald Trump’s first term.

site_title: Trump’s clash with universities risks US innovation, scientists warn
summary: US President Donald Trump's funding freeze on Harvard University and other top colleges risks US innovation, scientists warn. The freeze, which affects over $2.3 billion in funding, comes after the schools rejected government-mandated reforms aimed at combating antisemitism and "radical left" ideologies. Experts say the move will harm the country's competitiveness and hinder groundbreaking research, with China potentially benefiting from the loss. Dr. Donald Ingber, a Harvard scientist, warns that the freeze will "kill the Golden Goose of innovation" and has seen two government contracts halted, including one worth over $20 million.

images.alt_text: Harvard University had emerged as a target for the White House as the government sought changes at the nation’s elite colleges.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, April 17, 2025
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by "Big Progress" in Japan's tariff talks. The Bank of Korea held its interest rate steady, citing increased downside risks, while Singapore plans to expand trade pacts and push for WTO reform amid escalating US-China tensions.

images.alt_text: DPM Gan says Singapore must “prepare for a new economic and geopolitical environment that is more protectionist, arbitrary and dangerous”.  PHOTO: DBS
Shares in Tokyo rose along with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Wellington, though Taipei edged down.

site_title: OCBC Centre is ‘anchor’ for the bank; no plans to sell heritage site: board chairman
summary: OCBC Centre, a heritage site and anchor for the bank, will not be sold, according to board chairman Andrew Lee. The lender has enough space for its operations and redevelopment plans are untimely due to elevated construction costs (S$4-5 billion). Lee emphasized the historical significance of the building, which was founded in 1932, and the board is not considering selling its other properties, including the nearby Bank of Singapore and Great Eastern buildings.

site_title: GE2025: PSP unveils first election candidates in Marymount and Kebun Baru SMCs
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has announced its first two candidates for the 2025 General Election: Jeffrey Khoo in Marymount SMC and Tony Tan, husband of PSP's Non-Constituency Member of Parliament Hazel Poa, in Kebun Baru SMC. PSP chairman Dr Tan Cheng Bock also hinted at his intention to contest in the election, despite being 85 years old. Khoo, a former West Coast GRC candidate, aims to address concerns over cost of living and employment, while Tan, a former National Solidarity Party candidate, has a background in engineering and business.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
PSP's West Coast-Jurong West team greeting a resident. From left: Leong Mun Wai, Sumarleki Amjah, Tan Cheng Bock, Sani Ismail and Hazel Poa.

site_title: GE2025: ‘Don’t fly back to the same old answers’ – Workers’ Party newcomer Kenneth Tiong wants to offer fresh ideas
summary: Kenneth Tiong, a 36-year-old tech executive, joins the Workers' Party (WP) for the 2025 Singapore General Election (GE2025). Tiong, who has been volunteering for the WP, aims to bring fresh ideas to tackle Singapore's challenges, including economic and social issues. He suggests reforms in research and development, startup funding, and enterprise development, calling for more authority to scientists and centralised efforts to support promising startups. Tiong also plans to advocate for young families and those affected by long-term visit passes or permanent residency for foreign spouses.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
WP chief Pritam Singh (fourth from right) with the party's other elected MPs (from left) Dennis Tan, He Ting Ru, Faisal Manap, Gerald Giam, Jamus Lim, Sylvia Lim and Louis Chua.
The date of Nomination Day was suggested by PM Wong, to which President Tharman agreed, a statement from the Prime Minister’s Office said.
Global inflation rose sharply in 2022 following the outbreak of the war in Ukraine.
This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.
The question is whether the economic uncertainty will prompt a “flight to safety” response among voters.

site_title: AmEx profit rises on resilient card spending
summary: American Express reported a 6% rise in first-quarter profit to $2.58 billion, or $3.64 per share, driven by resilient card spending. The company's provisions for credit losses decreased to $1.2 billion, down from $1.3 billion a year earlier. Despite US President Donald Trump's tariff rhetoric, AmEx's focus on affluent customers and rewards strategy helped mitigate the impact. The company maintains its full-year forecasts, with revenue expected to grow 8-10% and profit between $15-$15.50 per share.

images.alt_text: Concerns about higher inflation and personal finances have since continued to mount due to US President Donald Trump’s tariffs push.

site_title: Singapore shares settle higher on Thursday; STI extends rally, up 1.6%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.6% on Thursday, closing at 3,720.33, following regional indices such as the Kospi and Nikkei 225. DFI Retail Group led the gains, increasing 7.6% to US$2.41, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also saw significant gains. The biggest loser was Wilmar, shedding 1%. Market analysts attribute the rally to forced dichotomies amid trade uncertainties, with the potential for geoeconomic stress and diplomatic triggers.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
CapitaMall Yuhuating in Changsha, which will be under CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit's initial portfolio

site_title: Trump says Fed chair Powell’s termination can’t ‘come fast enough’
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed support for terminating Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's term, stating that Powell's termination "cannot come fast enough". Powell warned that Trump's tariff policies could push inflation and employment further from the Fed's goals, prompting Trump to call for interest rate cuts. Powell's term expires in May 2026, and it is unclear whether Trump's comments signal a wait-and-see approach or an attempt to remove Powell sooner.

images.alt_text: “Despite heightened uncertainty and downside risks, the US economy is still in a solid position,” Powell says.
“While tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation, it is also possible that the effects could be more persistent,” Powell says.

U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell speaks at a press conference, following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy, in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard

Over the years, Fed policymakers and economists have made a range of suggestions about how to improve the dot plot, which has been published in its current form since well before Powell became chair in 2018.

site_title: GE2025: With ‘far greater stakes’ this election, PAP manifesto provides ‘road map to navigate a changed world’
summary: Singapore is set to hold its general election, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizing the "far greater stakes" at play due to the changing global landscape. The People's Action Party (PAP) has launched its manifesto, titled "Changed World, Fresh Team, New Resolve - Securing a Brighter Future for You," which outlines plans to navigate the turbulent times, secure lives and livelihoods, and keep Singapore going. The party will field 32 new candidates, including 13 women, and promises to defend Singapore's interests on the global stage, grow a vibrant economy, and ensure affordable housing, sustainability, and a society where all are respected.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
PM Wong notes that the Republic is already plugged into major frameworks such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, but it must go further to reinforce the multilateral trading system.

site_title: Temasek’s Chia Song Hwee to succeed Tan Chong Meng as JTC chairman from July
summary: Temasek's Chia Song Hwee will succeed Tan Chong Meng as JTC chairman from July 1, succeeding him on June 30. Chia, deputy chief executive officer of Temasek International, has joined Temasek in 2011 and previously served as president and CEO of Chartered Semiconductor. Tan, who oversaw the development of the Jurong Innovation District and Punggol Digital District, will step down after six years in the role. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has expressed appreciation for Tan's leadership and confidence in Chia's ability to build on his work.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
JTC will introduce a scheme to allow companies to extend their leases in shorter periods, for incremental business investments.
One-north

site_title: Blackstone's Q1 profit beats on robust private equity, credit performance
summary: Blackstone reported a higher-than-expected Q1 profit of $1.41 billion, driven by asset sales in private equity and credit businesses. Distributable earnings grew 11% year-over-year, beating analyst estimates. The company's assets under management rose 10% to $1.17 trillion, with private equity segment earnings rising 13% to $564.6 million. Despite a 25% decline in shares this year, Blackstone CEO Stephen Schwarzman said the company is well-positioned to navigate the current environment.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has already begun investing the fund, targeting warehouses, residential properties, data centres and hotels while also beginning to explore deals for offices again after a long hiatus.

site_title: China’s Xi calls on Asian nations to resist confrontation and protectionism
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged Asian nations to resist geopolitical confrontation and protectionism, calling for unity among regional countries to safeguard development prospects. He made the comments during a three-nation trip to Southeast Asia, where China has been Malaysia's largest trading partner since 2009, with total trade valued at RM484.1 billion last year. Xi emphasized the need for cooperation and openness in areas such as trade, tourism, and infrastructure development, as well as cutting-edge fields like artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: A Boeing 737-800 of China United Airlines prepares to land at Shanghai Pudong International Airport in Shanghai on April 16, 2025. Donald Trump believes it is up to China to come to the negotiating table on trade, the White House said on April 15, after the US president accused Beijing of reneging on a major Boeing deal. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)
Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.
Hundreds of billions of US dollars in Chinese goods will still face an extra tariff of 145 per cent if companies continue to ship to the US.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds rate steady while citing big rise in downside risks
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) maintained its benchmark interest rate steady at 2.75% as it cited a significant increase in downside risks to growth since February, including the impacts of US trade policy and domestic political uncertainty. The decision was seen as dovish, with Governor Rhee Chang-yong stating that all six board members are open to a rate cut over the next three months. The won remained volatile after the decision, with economists predicting a potential rate cut in May to support the economy, which could see negative growth in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The BOK has so far cut its benchmark interest rate three times since its pivot in October, after confirming inflationary trends were largely in line with its views.

Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said market expectations of two to three cuts this year were in line with views at the central bank, his first indication of the long-term outlook for the latest easing cycle.
Higher US tariffs on imports would likely shrink demand for items from key trading partners such as South Korea.

site_title: India’s IDFC First Bank to raise 75 billion rupees from Warburg Pincus, Adia
summary: IDFC First Bank, India's ninth-largest private bank, has approved a plan to raise 75 billion rupees (S$1.2 billion) from US-based private equity firm Warburg Pincus and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (Adia). The bank will issue 1.25 billion preference shares to the investors, with Warburg Pincus investing US$570 million and Adia investing US$307 million. The fundraising will improve the bank's capital adequacy ratio to 18.9% from 16.1% in December 2024.

site_title: GE2025: Workers’ Party introduces four new faces, including candidates for Sengkang, Aljunied GRCs
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) introduced four new faces in Singapore for the 2025 General Election (GE2025), including candidates for Sengkang and Aljunied GRCs. The new team members include Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik, Kenneth Tiong, Eileen Chong, and Siti Alia Abdul Rahim Mattar, who are former civil servants and property manager. WP party chief Pritam Singh confirmed that the party will not aim for a third of the seats and will not field more than 32 candidates, with a focus on finding the "best people" to serve Singapore.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

Each party stands for different approaches to fiscal policy, cost of living, foreign talent and housing.

site_title: China's youth jobless rate dips in March to 16.5%
summary: China's youth jobless rate fell to 16.5% in March, reversing a two-month rise, as the country pledges to boost youth employment. The rate for 25-29-year-olds dropped to 7.2% and for 30-59-year-olds to 4.1%, compared to 7.3% and 4.3% respectively in February. This marks a slight decrease from February's 16.9% for 16-24-year-olds, excluding students. China's nationwide survey-based urban jobless rate stood at 5.2%, down from a two-year high of 5.4% in the previous month.

images.alt_text: Commuters at a subway station near the Zhongguancun tech hub, during morning rush hour in Beijing.  China has a long average working week – at 46.1 hours in 2024, according to the ILO.

site_title: OCBC Cycle, planned for May 3-4, switches to virtual event due to lack of security personnel
summary: The OCBC Cycle, Singapore's largest mass cycling event, has switched to a virtual event due to a lack of security personnel. Originally scheduled for May 3-4, the event will now take place on a virtual ride format for 7,000 participants. Full refunds will be given to all participants. The event was initially moved due to the dissolution of Parliament and a public holiday on May 3, and no other suitable venue was found to accommodate the event.

images.alt_text: Flag off for the riders participating in the 20 kilometers Straits Times Ride at the OCBC Cycle at the National Stadium, 12 May 2024.
Lee U-Wen

Minister Ong (4th from right), OCBC CEO Helen Wong (6th from right) and its head of global consumer financial services Sunny Quek (1st from left) with seniors at the launch of OCBC SeniorCare programme.
This year's OCBC Cycle features a new virtual ride for cyclists to complete a minimum 120 km in a single round-island journey.
OCBC Cycle 2020 called off, replaced with free virtual ride event

site_title: Tariff-fuelled volatility killing private equity optimism as deal flows squeezed
summary: Global private equity markets are experiencing turmoil due to US President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, leading to a halt in exit activity such as initial public offerings (IPOs) and mergers and acquisitions (M&As). In response, private equity firms are turning to alternative exit options, including the secondary market, private debt, real estate, and renewable infrastructure. Despite the uncertainty, some sectors are seen as opportunities, such as smaller and mid-sized companies and infrastructure investments in renewable energy. Private credit is also expected to benefit from the current market turmoil.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Private equity in South-east Asia still face a difficult exit environment despite an uptick in 2024.

site_title: A Lange & Sohne steals the show with trio of exquisite novelties at Watches and Wonders 2025
summary: A Lange & Sohne unveiled three exceptional timepieces at Watches and Wonders 2025, showcasing its commitment to horological artistry and technical innovation. The trio includes a Minute Repeater Perpetual, a refined 1815, and the Odysseus Honeygold, each featuring intricate mechanics, exceptional craftsmanship, and innovative use of materials. The Minute Repeater Perpetual boasts a manually wound movement with a perpetual calendar and minute repeater, while the 1815 offers a refined take on classic design with a 72-hour power reserve. The Odysseus Honeygold introduces a new level of luxurious sportiness with its honey-gold alloy and matching bracelet.

site_title: Frasers Property Industrial in capital partnership for A$600 million Aussie industrial assets
summary: Frasers Property Industrial has entered into a 50:50 joint venture with Morgan Stanley Real Estate Investing for an A$600 million portfolio of eight industrial assets in Sydney and Brisbane. The assets, valued at about S$501 million, are fully leased to 11 tenants, including supply chain solutions provider Primary Connect. The weighted average lease expiry is 7.7 years, and the assets have an average age of five years. The joint venture aims to leverage strong demand for premium industrial estates in key logistics hubs, part of Frasers Property's strategy to form long-term, strategic capital partnerships.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Anthony Boyd, Frasers Property group chief operating officer, will be stepping down from his role, effective Jul 4.

site_title: World economy likely to avoid recession despite tariffs, IMF chief says
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva expects the global economy to avoid a recession despite US President Donald Trump's tariff rollout, citing "notable" markdowns to growth but no recession. The current tariff tensions will likely have three major consequences: uncertainty is costly, rising trade barriers hit growth upfront, and protectionism erodes productivity over the long run. Georgieva calls on countries to put their own houses in order, tackle internal and external macroeconomic imbalances, and prioritize open trade policies to secure a settlement among the largest players.

images.alt_text: The ECB has been lowering borrowing costs as post-pandemic price pressures retreat, and recent trade-related turmoil on global markets is adding to the case for further policy easing.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines parent reports lower profit in 2024
summary: Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG) reported a net profit of RM54 million (S$16 million) for 2024, down 93% from the previous year due to lower airfares and capacity cuts. The company's parent, Malaysia Airlines, has struggled to recover from 2014 disasters and has temporarily reduced flight capacity by 18% due to safety and maintenance issues. Despite this, passenger traffic remained robust in the premium segment, with a 9.6% decline in average passenger yield. MAG aims to operate a narrow-body fleet of 55 new-generation Boeing MAX aircraft by 2030.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photo taken on March 7, 2015 shows Indian sand artist Sudarsan Pattnaik creating a sand sculpture of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 on Puri beach in eastern Odisha state. Malaysia's cabinet has agreed to a proposal to launch a new search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which disappeared mysteriously 10 years ago, the transport minister said on December 20, 2024. (Photo by J .K. Jagdev / AFP)
