Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 carrying 239 people disappeared from radar screens on Mar 8, 2014 while en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.
The airline has suffered several setbacks this year, with reduced routes and manpower issues.

site_title: ‘Compelling yields’: DBS flags opportunity in hotel S-Reits on Mice, concert hub status
summary: DBS analysts suggest a short-term opportunity in Singapore's hotel sector, driven by the country's efforts to establish itself as a regional Mice (meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions) hub and concert destination. The Orchard redevelopment site owned by HPL is identified as a "strong venue contender" for a new convention center, which could drive city traffic. Hotel Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) offer "compelling yields" of around 6.7%, with CapitaLand Ascott Trust, CDLHT, and FEHT offering yields of 7% or higher, presenting tactical entry opportunities into the sector.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift fans hang around the outdoor area of Kallang Wave Mall, which generally sees high footfall  during the concert periods.
One pillar of STB's Tourism 2040 roadmap is boosting Singapore’s attractiveness to leisure travellers, not just as a transit hub or a business destination.
An artist impression of the downtown Mice hub. The new venue will cater to the rising demand for events and serve delegates' changing needs.

site_title: Olam to sell whole stake in port operator for US$175 million
summary: Olam, a Singapore-based agribusiness company, plans to sell its entire stake in port operator Arise P&L for US$175 million, subject to completion by Dec 31, 2025. The sale aligns with Olam's updated reorganisation plan, which includes injecting US$500 million into its Olam Food Ingredients unit and focusing on its delayed initial public offering. The disposal is part of Olam's efforts to monetise its assets and businesses, with the company considering factors such as future earnings and cash flow when deciding on the use of the divestment monies.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Olam to inject US$500 million into ofi, liquidate remaining assets over time

site_title: Perplexity in talks to integrate assistant into Samsung, Motorola phones
summary: Perplexity AI, a startup rivaling Google and OpenAI, is in talks to integrate its virtual assistant into Samsung and Motorola phones. The company has an agreement with Motorola, set to be announced April 24, and is in discussions with Samsung, with potential terms including offering Perplexity as a default AI assistant option or preloading its app. A deal with Samsung could be complicated by the company's existing partnership with Alphabet, but the South Korean company's investment arm has backed Perplexity in the past.

images.alt_text: smartphone holding phone Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg
A US law has ordered TikTok to divest from its Chinese owner ByteDance or be banned in the United States.
Perplexity offers several services in addition to the paid and free versions of its search tool.

site_title: Singapore to expand trade pacts, push WTO reform amid escalating US-China tensions: DPM Gan
summary: Singapore plans to expand trade ties, forge new alliances, and reform the World Trade Organization (WTO) in response to escalating US-China trade tensions. Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong warned that US President Donald Trump's "reciprocal tariffs" have shaken the rules-based trading order, potentially undermining Singapore's ability to attract investments and create jobs. Singapore will work with like-minded countries to strengthen economic ties, including the Pacific Alliance, and reform the WTO to achieve a more rules-based order. The government has also formed a new economic resilience task force to address the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

While Singapore may not be targeted by higher tariffs, the real risk for the trade-reliant city-state is how politicised and inconsistent US trade actions are reshaping the global environment, said participants in a webinar by the Iseas-Yusof Ishak Institute. PHOTO: AFP
DPM Gan Kim Yong (left) and SBF vice-chairman Mark Lee (standing in for SBF chairman) at the Economic Resilience Task Force press conference.
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong delivering his opening remarks at a NTUC dialogue session with labour movement leaders and union leaders at the NTUC Centre on Apr 14.
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world
DPM Gan said Singapore is also reaching out to its trading partners to share information and explore different ways of working together

site_title: Gold continues record rally as trade war woes fuel safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices continued their record rally, rising 0.1% to $3,346.20 an ounce as investors sought safe-haven assets amid escalating global trade tensions. The US dollar slipped against rivals, making gold more attractive for other currency holders. The intensifying trade conflict between the US and its trading partners, including China, has fueled demand for gold, which has risen 27% this year. The US Federal Reserve has cautioned that Trump's tariff policies risk pushing inflation and employment further from the central bank's goals.

images.alt_text: Gold has hit multiple record highs this year.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit Q1 distributable income continues slide, tumbling 19.3% to US$9.6 million
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported a 19.3% decline in distributable income to US$9.6 million in Q1, mainly due to lower adjusted net property income. The decline was attributed to lower rental income from higher free rents and a negative 3.6% rental reversion. Revenue slipped 0.5% to US$36.9 million, and the Reit's average leverage stood at 43.7%. No distribution was declared, as previously announced plans to suspend distributions for two years were still in effect.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Its gross revenue slipped 3.7 per cent to US$72.1 million from US$74.8 million while its net property income declined 14.1 per cent to US$36.3 million from US$42.2 million.

site_title: Return of the legendary Ingenieur
summary: IWC Schaffhausen unveiled new watch models at Watches and Wonders 2025, including the Ingenieur Perpetual Calendar 41, a tribute to watch legends Gerald Genta and Kurt Klaus. The watch features a Gerald Genta-inspired design, a perpetual calendar, and an automatic movement with a 60-hour power reserve. Another model, the Ingenieur Automatic 42, is made of ceramic and has a 60-hour power reserve. The brand also introduced the Big Pilot's Watch Shock Absorber Tourbillon Skeleton XPL, a flying minute tourbillon watch with a patented shock absorber system. Prices range from S$27,700 to S$273,600.

site_title: New watches, fresh fascinations
summary: Several luxury watch brands unveiled new models at recent events. Czapek & Cie introduced the Antarctique Tourbillon, a 50-piece limited edition featuring a hand-polished open-worked flying tourbillon and a "vortex-style" guilloche pattern. FP Journe released the Chronometre Furtif, a sporty timepiece with a grey-black tone and minute tracks on a mirror-polished dial. Franck Muller showcased the Round Triple Mystery, a watch with three rotating discs displaying hours, minutes, and seconds. Other notable releases include Armin Strom's Dual Time GMT Resonance Manufacture Edition, Ulysse Nardin's Diver (Air), and Roger Dubuis' Excalibur Grande Complication, each featuring innovative designs and complications.

site_title: AMD says US rule on chips to China could cost it US$800 million
summary: AMD expects new US licensing requirements for exported semiconductors to China to cost around $800 million due to export controls on MI308 GPUs. The measure, which applies to high-performance applications like gaming and AI, may limit AMD's ability to export chips to China. Despite this, AMD CEO Jensen Huang plans to balance compliance with technological advancements, stating that AI development will continue globally.

images.alt_text: Tightening US export curbs have in recent years made it harder for American chipmakers to tap the Chinese market, but the country remains a key source of revenue.
In addition to AMD, both Apple and Nvidia have said that some of their chips are being produced at TSMC’s Arizona plant.
AMD is trying to persuade some of the biggest companies in the world to include its AI products in their data centre expansion plans.
Dell’s embrace of AMD for corporate PCs is another blow for Intel as the company struggles to hang on to its eroding dominance over chips for PCs.

site_title: China stares down Boeing parts shortage as Comac stockpiles
summary: China is navigating a Boeing parts shortage due to the ongoing trade war, with local airlines relying on stockpiled spare parts and Comac, the Chinese aircraft manufacturer, building up a buffer of engines to meet production needs. Despite this, Comac's reliance on US-made components poses a vulnerability to China's economy, and analysts suggest that the shortage may be a negotiating tactic. China's retaliatory tariffs on US goods have reached 145%, and the country may seek alternative suppliers, such as Singapore, to access US aircraft parts.

images.alt_text: China Eastern’s Comac C919 aircraft. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Guangzhou-based China Southern Group is one of the world’s largest carrier groups, with stakes in 10 airlines and operating 932 commercial jets.
FILE PHOTO: A screen displays the logo for Boeing on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 2, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
The budding trade war represents the latest setback for Boeing in a market forecast to make up 20% of global aircraft demand over the next two decades.

site_title: PGIM to invest US$2 billion in Asia property, unfazed by tariffs
summary: PGIM Real Estate plans to invest approximately US$2 billion in Asia-Pacific properties this year despite US tariffs potentially impacting economic growth and real estate investment. The firm has already invested about US$900 million in the region, with most of that in Japan, where it expects to meet its total target. PGIM's deputy head, David Fassbender, notes that the uncertainty in the market may slow down transaction activity, but the firm remains on track for its investment goals, with a focus on sectors like hospitality and data centers.

images.alt_text: The search for higher returns has intensified due to rivalry between traditional life insurers like Prudential Financial and private equity-owned counterparts.

site_title: New Zealand inflation accelerates more than expected to 2.5%
summary: New Zealand's inflation accelerated to 2.5% in the first quarter, exceeding expectations, but still within the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's 1-3% target. Despite a modest economy recovering from a 2.1% contraction, confidence and investment remain weak. The central bank has scope to cut interest rates further, with forecasts predicting a potential rate cut to 2.5% by October. Economists warn that the fragile recovery may be at risk, emphasizing the need for monetary stimulus to maintain target inflation.

images.alt_text: Official New Zealand GDP data is released only quarterly and has been subject to significant revisions in the last year.
The RBNZ may need to take the OCR below the 3 per cent floor it signalled in February as US President Donald Trump’s tariffs threaten to damp global growth and sap demand for New Zealand exports.
The central bank is expected to cut interest rates on Wednesday.
The RBNZ has reduced the Official Cash Rate by 175 basis points since August to 3.75 per cent, and is expected to deliver another cut to 3.5 per cent next week.

site_title: ECB to cut rates again to help economy overcome trade turmoil
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to cut interest rates for the seventh time in a year, aiming to support the struggling economy amid US tariffs and global market turmoil. The decision is largely seen as a done deal, with the ECB citing decreasing price pressures and bolstering conviction that euro zone inflation is under control. The rate cut is likely to bolster the euro and help the ECB get inflation back to its 2% target sooner, with Morgan Stanley arguing that inflation could fall below the target soon.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, March 6, 2025. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch//File Photo
The commission is set to publish a report next year on the banking system in the single market, including on its competitiveness.
BlackRock highlighted high-quality segments of the European securitised market such as collateralized loan obligations as offering attractive risk-adjusted returns.
The ECB cut rates earlier this month, but traders have pared bets on more action and are now almost equally torn between a cut and a pause at the Apr 16 to 17 gathering.

site_title: Jay Chou visits Tudor at Watches and Wonders 2025
summary: Tudor unveiled its 2025 novelties at Watches and Wonders Geneva, showcasing a thoughtful evolution of its core collections. The Black Bay 58 Burgundy and Black Bay 68 feature refined designs with Metas Master Chronometer certification, offering exceptional precision and water resistance. The Pelagos Ultra boasts 1,000 m water resistance and a helium escape valve, making it a professional dive watch. The Black Bay Chrono received an update with enhanced versatility, including a five-link bracelet with the practical "T-fit" clasp. Prices start from S$6,070 for the Black Bay 58 Burgundy and S$8,230 for the Black Bay Chrono.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Keppel DC Reit, Nam Cheong, Kore
summary: CapitaLand Investment is set to launch its first real estate investment trust (Reit) in China, CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit, with a combined value of about 2.8 billion yuan (S$499.2 million). Keppel DC Reit posted a higher first-quarter distribution and gross revenue, while Nam Cheong secured vessel charter contracts worth up to RM317.1 million. In contrast, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) saw a decline in distributable income due to lower rental income.

site_title: Exceptional novelties from Patek Philippe
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled 14 novelties at the Watches and Wonders fair, including a one-of-a-kind complicated desk clock, the Ref 27000M, which took seven years to develop and features a perpetual calendar, week-number indication, and a hand-wound movement with 31 days of power reserve. The desk clock is part of the Rare Handcrafts collection and is inspired by two similar clocks made in 1923 and 1927. Other notable watches include the Ref 5308G-001 Minute Repeater with a quadruple complication, the Ref 5328G 8-Day Power Reserve with an instantaneous day and date display, and the Ref 7340/1R Perpetual Calendar, the first high complication for Patek Philippe's Twenty~4 women's collection, priced at S$1,706,400.

site_title: The new faces of Omega’s Seamaster
summary: Omega introduces four new Seamaster watches, each redefining adventure, elegance, and precision. The Planet Ocean Worldtimer features a globe-trotting design, while the Milano Cortina 2026 channels Olympic heritage in 18-karat Moonshine gold. The Diver 300M in bronze gold boasts a unique alloy that resists time, and the Aqua Terra 150M offers a vibrant turquoise dial. All four watches are built with Omega's Master Chronometer Calibre 8938 and feature water resistance up to 600 meters. Prices range from S$9,600 to S$40,600, with the Milano Cortina 2026 available for S$28,000.

site_title: Hyundai to suspend EV production in South Korea due to slow demand, US tariffs
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to suspend production of some electric vehicles in South Korea from April 24 to April 30 due to slow demand and US tariffs. The move comes as EV orders from major markets have fallen sharply in April following the removal of government EV subsidies and US tariffs on imported vehicles. The suspension affects production lines for Ioniq five and Kona electric vehicles at the Ulsan complex. Hyundai aims to maintain sticker prices on its current model lineup for the next two months to ease customer concerns.

images.alt_text: Hyundai signage is seen at the New York International Auto Show Press Preview in New York City, U.S., April 16, 2025. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon
The impact of the tariff costs could fall disproportionately on high-end models, Jose  Munoz says.
BYD introduced its Seal mid-sized sedan at Seoul Mobility Show, with a price starting from 47,500,000 won (S$43,570), excluding subsidies.
Hyundai Steel shares initially jumped more than 5 per cent on the news but reversed early gains to drop 4.4 per cent later in the session as US President Donald Trump praised the company’s plan.
The official confirmed Hyundai's investment would include a US$5 billion new steel plant in Louisiana
The new X3 is a striking car in the flesh, with its smooth creases and origami-like boxiness lending it plenty of gravitas, and playing up its size.
The N Line packs the same 1.6-litre turbo hybrid, all-wheel drive powertrain as the regular Tucson, and puts plenty of emphasis on making life sweet for occupants.
Hyundai Motor Group, including Hyundai Motor and Kia, ranks third in global vehicle sales behind Toyota Motor and Volkswagen.

site_title: Industry players see room for private credit market to grow in South-east Asia
summary: Private credit funds, where investors pool capital to enable loans to companies, are gaining interest in South-east Asia, with regional governments also supporting the market. Singapore has launched a S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, while sovereign wealth and pension funds are considering building private credit platforms. Industry players note that the private credit market remains nascent and fragmented compared to Western markets, with ad-hoc lending and local expertise required. Despite this, investor interest in private credit has persisted, driven by diversification and the appeal of opaque nature of private credit funds.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Small and medium enterprises are often underserved by traditional banks. Private credit has an important role to play in filling this gap.
Singapore Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong says

site_title: Singapore’s March exports ease, missing analysts’ expectations; forecast tipped for downgrade
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 5.4% year-on-year in March, missing analyst expectations of double-digit growth. This brings NODX growth in the first quarter to 3.3%. Economists expect the export outlook to worsen in the months ahead due to US tariffs and rising uncertainty. Enterprise Singapore may lower its full-year NODX forecast, with some economists trimming their forecasts to minus 4% or lower.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Overall, total trade climbed 4.6 per cent year on year in February, slowing from the 6.6 per cent growth in the preceding month.

site_title: Europe: Shares close lower as ASML warns US tariffs cloud outlook
summary: European shares closed lower on Wednesday, weighed down by semiconductor-related stocks after ASML warned US tariffs increased uncertainty around its 2025 and 2026 outlook. The Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.2%, with ASML shares down 5.2%. Nvidia also reported a $5.5 billion charge related to its Chinese chip sales. The trade war has driven investors to overreact, making investment decisions difficult, according to analysts. The outlook for European corporate earnings has worsened, with analysts expecting a 3% drop in first-quarter profit.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 gained 1.6 per cent, with most regional indexes in positive territory.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q1 DPU up by 14.2% at S$0.02503 on acquisitions, strong portfolio performance
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 14.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02503 for the first quarter, driven by acquisitions and strong portfolio performance. DPU rose 59.4% to S$61.8 million, while revenue climbed 22.6% to S$102.2 million. Net property income grew 24.1% to S$88.1 million, primarily due to acquisitions and contract renewals. The Reit's debt profile remains favorable, with aggregate leverage at 30.2% and an interest coverage ratio of 5.8 times. The company expects AI trends to drive growth in data centre demand globally, with a projected compound annual growth rate of 39% until 2030.

images.alt_text: Keppel Data Centre Campus (Singapore).jpg - Keppel DC Singapore 7 and 8, Keppel’s latest AI-ready data centre assets in Singapore, are situated within the Keppel Data Centre Campus at 82 Genting Lane.
Therese Soh
Digital Core Reit's data centre in Osaka.  UOB Kay Hian believes the advent of new reasoning AI models will drive the next wave of demand for data centres.
More potential acquisitions, exclusive deals for Keppel DC Reit

site_title: Trump tariffs provoke growing economic uncertainty
summary: US President Donald Trump's global tariffs have sparked growing economic uncertainty, with the US Federal Reserve warning of higher inflation and stock markets tumbling. China faces levies of up to 145% on many products, while the US has imposed a blanket 10% tariff. The trade tensions are expected to have a significant impact on global growth, with the World Trade Organization warning of severe negative consequences for vulnerable economies. Trump remains optimistic about his strategy, but economists warn that the tariffs will lead to widespread disruption and economic chaos.

images.alt_text: Tightening US export curbs have in recent years made it harder for American chipmakers to tap the Chinese market, but the country remains a key source of revenue.
China is a top global producer of 30 of the 50 minerals considered critical by the US Geological Survey, for example, and has been curtailing exports in recent months.
The US export controls have spurred China to invest in its domestic chip equipment industry.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment launches its first retail Reit in China with assets worth 2.8 billion yuan
summary: CapitaLand Investment has launched its first retail Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) in China, CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit, with assets valued at 2.8 billion yuan (S$499 million). The listing on the Shanghai Stock Exchange marks the first retail Reit sponsored by an international company. The Reit will be seeded with CapitaMall Yuhuating in Changsha and CapitaMall SKY+ in Guangzhou, offering a strategic entry into China's expanding Reit market.

images.alt_text: CapitaMall Yuhuating in Changsha, which will be under CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit's initial portfolio

site_title: Cut shifts or ramp up output? Vietnam’s exporters face dilemma amid tariff chaos
summary: Vietnam's exporters, particularly in the footwear and apparel sectors, are facing a dilemma amid the ongoing tariff chaos with the US. Some factory workers have been told to increase output, while others have had their shifts cut to three days a week due to postponed or cancelled US orders. The chaotic reaction is largely due to the Trump administration's 46% tariffs on Vietnam, which were paused until July. Companies such as Nike, Adidas, and Gap are among the major multinationals affected, and some have taken measures to cut costs, including workforce reduction and downsizing operations.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (right) and Chinese President Xi Jinping shake hands at the Office of the Party Central Committee in Hanoi, Vietnam on Apr 14.
Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary To Lam and China's President Xi Jinping wave during a meeting at the office of the Party Central Committee in Hanoi on Apr 14.
Vietnam has for weeks been offering sweeteners that it hoped would persuade the US President Donald Trump’s administration to take a benign view of its huge trade surplus with America.

site_title: US looks to box in China by recruiting other trading partners
summary: The US is pressuring other nations to limit trade with China in response to its historic import taxes, aiming to encircle Beijing and raise pressure on its economic practices. Dozens of countries are seeking reductions or exemptions from US tariffs, and the US is considering secondary tariffs on imports from countries with close China ties. The US also wants trading partners to refrain from absorbing excess goods from China, with some nations, like Mexico, expected to face increased tariffs on electric vehicle imports from China.

images.alt_text: A Boeing 737-800 of China United Airlines prepares to land at Shanghai Pudong International Airport in Shanghai on April 16, 2025. Donald Trump believes it is up to China to come to the negotiating table on trade, the White House said on April 15, after the US president accused Beijing of reneging on a major Boeing deal. (Photo by HECTOR RETAMAL / AFP)
Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.
Hundreds of billions of US dollars in Chinese goods will still face an extra tariff of 145 per cent if companies continue to ship to the US.

site_title: Sentosa’s hotels are redefining eco-luxury
summary: Sentosa's luxury hotels, Equarius and Capella, are redefining eco-luxury hospitality. Equarius Hotel, a wellness-first retreat, boasts sustainable technologies and a biodiversity reserve, earning the WELL V2 Gold Certification. Capella Singapore, an eco-leader, has achieved gold certification from EarthCheck and is committed to reducing its impact through renewable energy and biodiversity protection. Both hotels demonstrate that sustainability and regenerative tourism must be woven into the guest experience, setting a new standard for responsible travel in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The 23-storey Pan Pacific Orchard has 14,000 square metres of foliage, cascading water features, mirrored ceilings and towering green columns.
Enjoy handcrafted farm-to-bar drinks at Portman’s Bar.
Damai Spa is a portal to a multitude of innovative wellness offerings.
The swimming pool at Raffles Sentosa.

site_title: How South-east Asian growth enterprises should adapt to US tariffs
summary: US tariffs have been imposed on South-east Asian countries, particularly Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos, with rates ranging from 36% to 49%. The tariffs are expected to raise costs and weaken demand, prompting companies to review their strategies and forecasts. To stay attractive to investors, businesses need to realign their business models, focusing on scalable, non-US markets such as Europe, South-east Asia, and Asia-Pacific. Over 80% of business leaders surveyed said the tariffs will directly affect their top and bottom lines, with many needing to reassess and refine their approaches to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Vietnam has for weeks been offering sweeteners that it hoped would persuade the US President Donald Trump’s administration to take a benign view of its huge trade surplus with America.

In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.

site_title: EV maker Xpeng charts steady global expansion despite tariff war
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Xpeng is expanding globally despite a trade war and punitive EU tariffs, hosting its first global launch of a flagship vehicle in Hong Kong. The company plans to localise production for Indonesia and set up an R&D centre in Germany, with CEO He Xiaopeng stating that localisation is key to becoming truly international-facing. Xpeng is also developing AI-powered products, including robotaxis, flying cars, and humanoid robots, with its own AI chip set to be fitted into vehicles starting this year.

images.alt_text: XPENG Motors (Guangzou Xiaopeng Motors Technology) logo is seen in this illustration taken January 16, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
At home, Xpeng continues to develop smart-driving features, which have emerged as the latest front line in the cutthroat Chinese market.
Zeekr, Xpeng and GAC will need regulatory approval before drivers will be able to use the level three features in their cars.
Interest in Xpeng has also been helped by strong order momentum for its new battery EV models on the back of competitive pricing and autonomous driving features.

site_title: Australia jobs rebound in March, markets still stuck on rate cuts
summary: Australia's jobless rate ticked up to 4.1% in March, but remained under forecasts of 4.2%. Employment rebounded, with net jobs rising 32,200, and hours worked fell 0.3% due to bad weather. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter-point in May, with some risk of a half-point move, amid global recession fears.

images.alt_text: The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment slid 6.0 per cent in April from March, more than erasing the previous month’s 4 per cent gain.
Exports to the United States are less than 5 per cent of Australia’s total goods exports, compared to one in four export dollars coming from trade with China.
Reserve Bank of Australia governor Michelle Bullock speaks during a news conference at the bank’s head office in Sydney, Australia, April 1, 2025.

site_title: Data centres in Asia must rethink cooling for a more responsible future
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is poised to become a global leader in data centre expansion, driven by the growing adoption of AI, cloud computing, and digital transformation. However, this rapid growth poses significant environmental challenges, including high energy consumption and carbon emissions. To mitigate these concerns, data centres must adopt more innovative and efficient cooling solutions, such as liquid cooling, chilled water systems, and hybrid cooling ecosystems, to reduce their environmental impact. By prioritizing long-term sustainability, the industry can balance growth with environmental responsibility and lead the global energy transition.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit's data centre in Osaka.  UOB Kay Hian believes the advent of new reasoning AI models will drive the next wave of demand for data centres.

site_title: A vertical oasis of graceful luxury
summary: The Pan Pacific Orchard, a 23-storey hotel in Singapore, has received numerous awards for its design, luxury, and sustainability. Named one of the top Instagrammable hotels in Singapore and awarded Best Tall Building Worldwide, the hotel features four signature open-air terraces and over 14,000 square meters of foliage. The property has achieved Green Mark Platinum rating and GSTC Multi-Site Certification, showcasing its commitment to eco-conscious efforts. With a focus on "graceful luxury" and a guest-first mindset, Pan Pacific Orchard has set a new standard for high-rise tropical hospitality.

Damai Spa is a portal to a multitude of innovative wellness offerings.

site_title: Japan’s exports expand in March ahead of US tariffs
summary: Japan's exports rose 3.9% year-over-year in March, driven by increased shipments of cars and electronic parts ahead of US tariffs, which were introduced by President Donald Trump. Shipments to the US rose 3.1% and those to China fell 4.8%. Japan ran a trade surplus of 544.1 billion yen, exceeding forecasts. Automakers are scrambling to mitigate the impact, with Nissan planning to cut Japanese production of its US model.

images.alt_text: Cargo containers are seen at the Aomi Container Terminal in Tokyo on February 5, 2025. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

Tourists walk past shops and restaurants up the hill leading to Kiyomizu-dera Temple in the city of Kyoto on January 13, 2025. Japan on January 15 will announce tourist figures for the year 2024, widely expected to break the record set in 2019. (Photo by PAUL MILLER / AFP)
Stubbornly high food costs and rising wages have kept consumer inflation above the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for nearly three years.
Nominal cash earnings for workers climbed 3.1 per cent in February from a year earlier, with the pace accelerating from a revised 1.8 per cent in January, Japan's labour ministry said on Monday.
Inflation has stayed at or above the BOJ’s price target for almost three years, sapping spending power, and the latest tariffs from the US are now expected to weaken the economy further.

site_title: Vacheron Constantin unveils limited editions to celebrate its 270th year
summary: Vacheron Constantin celebrates its 270th year with eight limited-edition watches from its Traditionnelle and Patrimony collections. The new timepieces blend heritage with modern twists, featuring subtle geometric motifs and reworked details. The Traditionnelle models include a time-only watch, moon phase watch, and tourbillon perpetual calendar, while the Patrimony models include a moon phase watch, retrograde date watch, and self-winding watch. Each watch is paired with an alligator leather strap and a 18-karat gold pin buckle, with prices ranging from $37,600 to $69,500.

site_title: Orchid Country Club’s Alain Lee impresses with 40 points, 308-yard longest drive in BT Golf League
summary: Alain Lee of Orchid Country Club shot a one-over 73 to secure 40 points, the maximum stableford total, in the third leg of the BT Corporate Golf League. Lee also claimed the Longest Drive prize with a 308-yard drive. Team Boss won the day's team honours on countback, while Singapore Global Trust retained the top spot in the standings with 108 points, tied with Orchid Country Club. The standings are now a four-way battle for the overall championship, with only 14 points separating Singapore Global Trust from fourth-placed Gayatri.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends down 3.1% on Nvidia drop, economic angst
summary: US stocks tumbled on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 3.1% to 16,307.16, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.7%. The decline was sparked by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's warning that President Trump's tariffs could lead to a challenging scenario, sparking stagflation concerns. Nvidia sank 7% after disclosing a $5.5 billion hit from US export licenses, while Advanced Micro Devices fell 7.4%. The market's drop was despite solid retail sales data, as investors weigh the impact of Trump's trade agenda on the economy.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 14, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: A day in the life: Christian Westbeld at Raffles Hotel Singapore
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore, Singapore's "Grande Dame," continues to maintain its status as a luxury beacon while embracing sustainability and social responsibility under the leadership of managing director Christian Westbeld. Westbeld, with over 20 years of experience, prioritizes traditional luxury hospitality while incorporating modern elements, such as rigorous training for staff and eco-friendly practices. The hotel's dedication to community development and partnerships with local schools and organizations reflects its commitment to preserving Singapore's heritage while making a positive social impact. Westbeld's vision for Raffles balances heritage and innovation, ensuring the hotel remains a timeless experience and destination.

images.alt_text: Equarius Hotel’s eco-pond is one of six water catchment areas in the resort and is a designated biodiversity reserve.

site_title: New Trump-branded luxury residential project launched in India
summary: US President Donald Trump's real estate firm, Trump Organization, has launched a new luxury residential project, Trump Residences Gurgaon, in India, as the country's population continues to drive demand for luxury homes. The twin-tower project, valued at 35 billion rupees, will feature 298 residences and is the fifth Trump-branded residential project in India. The project comes as the US and India are in talks for a bilateral trade deal, and luxury house sales in India's top seven cities surged 28% in the first quarter.

site_title: Jaeger-LeCoultre’s Reverso line gets an epic glow-up
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre has unveiled nine new Reverso models in 2025, marking a significant expansion of the iconic collection. The new additions include the Reverso Tribute Minute Repeater, Reverso Tribute Geographic, Reverso Hybris Artistica Calibre 179, and Reverso Tribute Enamel "Shahnameh", among others. These models feature intricate complications, artistic engravings, and luxurious materials such as pink gold and diamonds. The Reverso collection's focus on heritage and timeless design aligns with the current luxury market trend, and the new models are expected to appeal to collectors and watch enthusiasts.

site_title: Temu, Shein slash digital ads as tariffs end cheap shipping from China, data show
summary: Chinese online retailers Temu and Shein are cutting digital ad spending in the US, with Temu's ad spend declining 31% and Shein's declining 19% in two weeks, due to the removal of a "de minimis" exemption on import tariffs that increases costs for the companies. As a result, Temu and Shein plan to raise product prices next week. The move is a blow to tech companies such as Meta's Facebook and YouTube, which rely on these retailers as major advertisers.

images.alt_text: Temu is grappling with elevated US tariffs on Chinese products and the potential closure of a tax loophole for small-value parcels.

site_title: Louis Vuitton debuts at LVMH Watch Week
summary: Louis Vuitton has unveiled its latest watch creations, the Tambour Taiko Spin Time and Tambour Convergence, at LVMH Watch Week. The new collection includes six limited-edition models, featuring innovative designs such as a flying tourbillon and a world-time complication. The Tambour Convergence, with its satin-finished case and precious plate, showcases Louis Vuitton's in-house mastery of movement design. The Tambour Taiko Spin Time Air Tourbillon and Spin Time Air models also feature new movements and designs. Prices range from $49,000 to $750,000, with the most expensive model being the Louis Vuitton X Kari Voutilainen LVKV02 GMR 6.

site_title: Pity American firms in China. Xi Jinping is hitting back
summary: China's aviation regulator has instructed airlines to stop taking deliveries of aircraft from Boeing, posing a significant challenge for American firms operating in China. This move follows Donald Trump's use of tariffs, which has rendered American supply chains untenable. The decision threatens to unwind years of commercial success for companies such as Apple, Boeing, Nike, and Starbucks in China. The move is seen as a retaliation by the Chinese government against the US government's trade policies.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has framed Malaysia’s chairmanship of Asean as an opportunity to revive the bloc's economic relevance.
Wealthy Chinese buyers are shifting away from Singapore as more prioritise lifestyle needs.

In Q1 2025, BYD outsold Tesla in pure battery EVs for the second straight quarter. And years of being shut out of the US forced BYD to redirect its focus to every other major market, including in Europe where it now has factories.
A string of recent data has pointed to an uneven economic recovery, with bank lending beating expectations and factory activity picking up speed.

site_title: Malaysia’s CIMB tilts towards Singapore and Indonesia as regional bets deliver stronger returns
summary: CIMB, Malaysia's second-largest lender, is shifting its growth focus towards higher-yield markets, particularly Singapore and Indonesia, as part of a strategic pivot towards capital optimization. The bank's CEO, Novan Amirudin, aims to double down on segments with strong returns, such as Islamic finance, corporate banking, and wealth management. CIMB's Indonesian arm, Bank CIMB Niaga, is targeting the burgeoning Islamic banking sector, while Singapore is expanding as a "challenger bank" with a growing demand from small and medium-sized enterprises. The bank's six-year roadmap aims to achieve a top-quartile return on equity by 2030.

Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said heightened external uncertainties that could lead to a more moderate expansion of exports.

site_title: Rolex shines with bold new models and updates
summary: Rolex unveiled four bold new models and updates at Watches and Wonders 2025, showcasing its commitment to innovation and aesthetics. The Oyster Perpetual Land-Dweller 40 boasts a new Flat Jubilee bracelet and high-frequency movement, while the GMT-Master II receives a striking green ceramic dial. The Perpetual 1908 features a new Settimo bracelet, and the Oyster Perpetual offers vibrant new dial colours. The collection solidifies Rolex's dominance in luxury watchmaking, blending heritage and modernity to create desirable and significant timepieces.

site_title: Nickel scam accused Ng Yu Zhi splurged on 20-carat diamond ring, and had ‘five families’: witness
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, accused of 42 charges of fraudulent trading, cheating, forgery, and money laundering, allegedly spent US$965,000 on a 20.25-carat diamond ring. A former employee, Shen Xuhuai, testified that Ng had "five families" - his wife, ex-wife, and three girlfriends - and that he asked her to help him buy the diamond ring. Shen also prepared tables showing estimated profits and percentage returns for Ng's nickel trading business, which prosecutors claim was a Ponzi scheme that attracted nearly S$1.5 billion from 947 investors.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: India’s golden hour
summary: A luxury travel operator, Abercrombie & Kent, organized a bespoke journey through India, weaving together history, culture, and personal discovery. The trip began in Delhi, where visitors marveled at the Red Fort and Humayun's Tomb, before heading to Agra to witness the breathtaking Taj Mahal. In Jaipur, the "Pink City," guests indulged in royal treatment at the Leela Palace and explored the astronomical observatory Jantar Mantar. A cruise on Crystal Symphony followed, offering a relaxing getaway with fine dining and exceptional service. The journey concluded in Goa, where local cuisine and hospitality were savored.

images.alt_text: Satoyama Jujo is enveloped in snow during winter.

site_title: Nam Cheong bags RM317.1 million in regional vessel charter deals
summary: Nam Cheong secured RM317.1 million in regional vessel charter deals from oil majors, with a 56.8% of its fleet already under long-term charter. The seven anchor handling tug supply vessels will support offshore operations in Malaysian and Thai waters. CEO Leong Seng Keat said the deals enhance the group's earnings visibility and long-term value, putting Nam Cheong on track to reach its 70% goal. The company's shares rose 2.9% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Global chipmakers feel the pinch of Trump’s shifting trade policy
summary: US President Donald Trump's shifting trade policy has hit global chipmakers, including Nvidia and AMD, with export restrictions on their products. Nvidia warned of a $5.5 billion hit after the US restricted exports of its AI processor tailored for China, while AMD warned of an $800 million loss. The restrictions have complicated the outlook for semiconductor and computing giants, causing stock prices to drop. The move has also raised concerns about the impact on chip demand from big cloud companies and the potential for sector-specific tariffs to be announced.

images.alt_text: ASML’s net bookings, the most closely watched figure in the industry, missed estimates in the first quarter at 3.9 billion euros (S$5.8 billion).
In addition to AMD, both Apple and Nvidia have said that some of their chips are being produced at TSMC’s Arizona plant.
The latest rules for Nvidia are a sign that the Trump administration will stay the course on the US government’s approach to Chinese tech development.
Manufacturing AI chips and supercomputers in the US will create hundreds of thousands of jobs in the coming decades, Nvidia said.

site_title: Greenback under pressure; safe havens outperform
summary: The US dollar experienced a decline, losing 0.7% against the Swiss franc and 0.4% against the Japanese yen, as market nerves grew due to tariff-induced uncertainty. The franc has appreciated, potentially pushing the Swiss National Bank to lower interest rates, while the euro gained 5% since tariffs were announced. The Canadian dollar strengthened, with a 40% chance of a rate cut, and the pound held steady despite cooler-than-expected inflation data.

site_title: Asean’s moment of truth may have finally arrived
summary: Malaysia, as this year's Asean chair, faces a defining moment as US tariffs threaten to upend South-east Asia's economic lynchpin, its exports. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has framed the opportunity to revive the bloc's economic relevance, positioning Asean as a stabilising force amid US-China rivalry. However, the US tariffs have already rattled the export engines of regional bloc members, putting pressure on Malaysia to act as a middleman and find a solution to mitigate the impact on the region's economy.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls, Nvidia drops after new US chip export curbs
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones down 189.5 points, the Nasdaq down 323.5 points, and the S&P 500 down 60.9 points. Nvidia's shares dropped 6.5% after the company warned of steep charges from new US controls on chip exports to China, contributing to the declines. The losses were part of an escalating global trade war, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Chanel rewrites the rules of luxury watchmaking
summary: Chanel has unveiled three standout collections at Watches and Wonders 2025, showcasing its creative muscle in luxury watchmaking. The J12 Bleu line features a sophisticated midnight blue hue, achieved after five years of research and experimentation. The collection includes the J12 Bleu Sapphire, which boasts a stunning baguette-cut sapphire bezel, and the J12 Bleu X-Ray, a one-off creation with a synthetic sapphire case and a price tag of S$1.6 million. Other notable pieces include the Blush Watch Capsule Collection, the Mademoiselle Prive Pincushion "Beauty Art," and the Diamonds Astroclock, a one-off creation featuring a majestic white gold lion set with 5,037 diamonds.

site_title: Powell says Fed remains in wait-and-see mode; markets processing policy shifts
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said the Fed will wait for more data on the economy's direction before changing interest rates, despite heightened uncertainty and downside risks. Powell cautioned that President Donald Trump's tariff policies risked pushing inflation and employment further from the central bank's goals of 2% inflation and maximum employment. The Fed's benchmark interest rate is currently 4.25-4.5%, where it has been since December, and Powell warned that tariffs could reverse some of the gains made since then.

images.alt_text: What businesses and workers anticipate will happen to prices, economists say, can play a key role in determining what actually does happen.
A dose of humility will help the Jerome Powell-led Fed reduce the risk of another bout of slippages in analysis, forecasts, communication and policy design.
Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Austan Goolsbee said that current anxiety could change consumer and business spending, which in turn might require the Fed to respond.
“While tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation, it is also possible that the effects could be more persistent,” Powell says.

site_title: Chan Soo Khian: Going back home
summary: Chan Soo Khian, founder of SCDA Architects and Soori hospitality brand, is opening a new heritage hotel, Soori Heritage Penang, in his hometown of George Town, Penang, Malaysia. The 15-suite hotel is set to open in July and features customised, high-quality finishes, including bespoke onyx bathroom sinks and handcrafted furniture. Chan, who has designed luxury hotels and condominiums worldwide, aims to revive interest in Penang and showcase its Southern China traditions. The hotel's narrative is deeply personal, drawing from Chan's childhood memories of living in a shophouse next to the Leong San Tong Khoo Kongsi, Malaysia's largest Hokkien clan house.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks drop on trade war anxiety, China inches higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.9% on Wednesday, snapping a six-day winning streak, amid concerns of an intensifying trade war after the US restricted Nvidia chip sales to China. China's shares rose marginally, driven by better-than-expected economic growth data and reports of state-backed investors buying shares. The US trade war uncertainty weighed on sentiment, with Nomura cutting its annual China GDP growth forecast to 4% from 4.5%.

images.alt_text: Chinese suppliers and manufacturers are taking to TikTok to share videos aimed at showing foreigners the “source of good goods”.

Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.
Import prices dipped 0.1 per cent last month, the first decline since September, after a downwardly revised 0.2 per cent gain in February.

site_title: ASML warns of tariff risks, maintains forecast as AI race accelerates
summary: ASML, the world's largest chip-making equipment supplier, warned of tariff risks but maintained its annual forecast due to strong AI demand. The company's net bookings missed estimates, but CEO Christophe Fouquet said growth years are expected in 2025 and 2026. ASML is ready to pass most of the tariff costs to customers, with US operations seen as an asset due to talent, not tariffs. Industry calculations suggest US semiconductor equipment makers could face over $1 billion in annual tariff costs.

images.alt_text: The ASML Lego is only intended to be “a fun item for employees” in celebration of the manufacturer’s 40th anniversary.
ASML CEO Christophe Fouquet said that much of ASML’s business with China is focused on mature technology that is less relevant to national security concerns.
The semiconductor business is often viewed as a barometer for the global economy since chips are vital for a range of products, from data centre servers to dishwashers.

site_title: US retail sales surge in March due to motor vehicle buying ahead of tariffs
summary: US retail sales rose 1.4% in March, driven by a surge in motor vehicle purchases ahead of tariffs, which came into effect in early April. This boost in sales contrasts with concerns about the economic outlook, including stagnant growth estimates and low consumer sentiment. Motor vehicle manufacturers reported a significant jump in auto sales, attributed to a "rush by buyers to beat the tariffs." Despite this, discretionary spending remains a concern, with high-income households struggling to maintain investment portfolio values.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen, Europe’s largest auto manufacturer, said its operating profit in the first three months of 2025 fell to 2.8 billion euros (S$4.2 billion) from 4.6 billion euros in the same period last year.

site_title: Oil up 2% to a two-week high as new US sanctions target Iran’s exports
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a two-week high on April 16, driven by concerns over global supplies after the US issued new sanctions targeting Chinese importers of Iranian oil. Brent crude futures settled at $65.85 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude ended at $62.47 a barrel, both at their highest levels since April 3. The US sanctions aim to reduce Iranian oil exports to zero, while the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries plans further oil output cuts to compensate for pumping above agreed quotas.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 21 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to settle at US$64.67 per barrel.

site_title: Tech players in healthcare, finance sectors should have no excuses for falling foul of regulators
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has stripped MaNaDr of its clinic license after investigations found short teleconsultations and sparse case notes, prompting the tech startup to close its clinic on December 24, 2024. The move highlights the need for tech companies in regulated sectors such as healthcare and finance to adhere to regulatory standards, with no room for excuses or uncertainty. MaNaDr is now focusing on its role as a tech platform, but the incident serves as a warning to other companies operating in similar industries.

site_title: India trade deficit with China widens to record US$99.2b amid dumping concerns
summary: India's trade deficit with China widened to a record US$99.2 billion in the 2024/25 fiscal year, driven by a surge in imports of electronics goods and consumer durables. In March alone, imports from China jumped 25% year-on-year to US$9.7 billion. India's exports to China fell 14.5% to US$1.5 billion in March, with total exports dropping to US$14.3 billion in the 12-month period. The widening deficit is attributed to India's heavy dependence on imported components for its growing electronics industry.

images.alt_text: India's diamond processing hub of Surat employs at least a million workers to cut, polish and set the gem. The country, which ships more than a third of its exports to the US, is expected to be among the worst-hit sectors.

site_title: Singapore SMEs enter contraction territory in Q1 2025 amid global uncertainty: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) entered contractionary territory in Q1 2025, marking the first time since Q1 2024, according to OCBC's SME Index report. The quarterly index fell to 49.9, down from 50.7 in Q4 2024, due to weakening global trade flows and tariff-driven uncertainties. Outward-oriented sectors such as ICT, transport, and logistics experienced contractions, while domestic-facing sectors like healthcare and education also saw declines. Despite this, the majority of SME owners surveyed by OCBC did not report a worsened outlook, with 41% feeling business conditions remained the same.

images.alt_text: Singapore SMEs sustain expansionary momentum in Q4, led by trade-related sectors: OCBC

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment ticks up but tariffs weigh on outlook
summary: US homebuilder confidence rose one point to 40 in April, near its lowest levels since late 2023, due to a pickup in current sales but lower demand expectations. The median estimate of economists predicted a reading of 38. Builder expectations for sales in the next six months slipped to 43, its lowest level since November 2023, while present sales and traffic of prospective buyers ticked up slightly. Higher construction material costs, including tariffs, and mortgage rates are expected to continue restraining new-home construction.

images.alt_text: The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index dropped three points to 39 this month, the lowest level since August
Donald Trump’s tariff wars with Mexico, Canada and China have the potential to drive interest rates higher by reheating inflation – or push them lower if the economy instead is tipped into recession.

site_title: TSMC upbeat on outlook as robust AI demand offsets tariff uncertainty
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) has expressed optimism for its annual outlook despite US trade policies and tariff threats, citing robust demand for artificial intelligence (AI) applications. The company forecasts AI chip revenue to double and expects revenue growth of 20-30% for the year. TSMC's shares jumped 5% in morning trade after the announcement, which comes as the company stands by its forecast despite uncertainty over US tariffs. The company's planned US investment of $165 billion is seen as a key factor in its resilience to tariff-related price increases.

images.alt_text: In addition to AMD, both Apple and Nvidia have said that some of their chips are being produced at TSMC’s Arizona plant.

site_title: STI gains ground on Wednesday, bucking regional indices
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,662.45, despite regional peers closing lower. The top gainer was DFI Retail Group, adding 4.2%, while Venture was the biggest loser, falling 0.7%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, with DBS increasing 0.4%, OCBC 0.6%, and UOB 0.6%. The decline in regional indices, such as the Kospi and Nikkei 225, was attributed to volatile Asian bond markets and an uncertain economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Sats’ subsidiary Worldwide Flight Services has been awarded a new five-year cargo handling contract with Emirates SkyCargo, the cargo arm of Emirates, at Frankfurt Airport.

site_title: Navigating the international residential market map in shifting economic sands
summary: International residential property markets are expected to remain attractive despite global economic uncertainties, driven by strong economic fundamentals and stable governance. Cities with growing populations and supply-demand imbalances, such as the UK, Australia, and Dubai, are likely to see continued price appreciation. Investors are turning to suburban markets and properties with ESG features, while rental markets are expected to remain strong, particularly in cities with constrained housing supply. As interest rates stabilize, affordability is expected to improve, supporting renewed buyer confidence and transaction volumes.

images.alt_text: Upheaval in financial markets and prospects of recession could draw investors towards stability, while the interest rate environment could turn more conducive for institutional grade asset transactions.

site_title: A snowy adventure in Furano
summary: Furano, a city in Hokkaido, Japan, is known for its powdery snow, rivaling Niseko, but offers more to discover beyond its slopes. The city boasts a range of activities, including ice fishing, snowshoe treks, and harvesting cabbage to heighten its sweetness and freshness. Visitors can also explore the picturesque countryside, spotting wild deer and foxes, and witness the iconic sakura tree bloom in late April. Furano's culinary scene reflects its farm-to-table culture, with must-try dishes like soup curry and ramen. The Nozo Hotel, a 78-key boutique retreat, offers a cosy refuge for skiers and a tranquil spa experience.

images.alt_text: Satoyama Jujo is enveloped in snow during winter.
At the palatial Oberoi Amarvilas, every room comes with a private panorama of the Taj Mahal.

site_title: Dining and wellness at St Regis Bangkok
summary: The St Regis Bangkok's one-Michelin-starred restaurant, IGNIV, is led by Swiss-born chef Arne Riehn, who incorporates Thai ingredients into his dishes, including a unique Thai olive, into his menu. Riehn sources ingredients from local farms and uses a local organisation to find organic produce. IGNIV's dining room offers a fine-casual vibe, and the hotel also features an all-day dining restaurant, VIU, and the Longevity Hub by Clinique La Prairie, offering wellness and beauty treatments. The hotel's dining and beauty options showcase its luxury offerings beyond five-star accommodation.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas secures extra gas supply after hit from Putra Heights pipeline fire
summary: Malaysia's Petronas has secured an additional 155 million standard cubic feet per day of gas supplies after a pipeline fire at Putra Heights in early April, boosting its total supply to 400 MMSCFD. The increased supply has helped stabilize gas supply to the northern region of Peninsular Malaysia, including Bestari Jaya, Meru, and Kapar, and has enabled four power plants to resume operations. Petronas expects the restoration of the Putra Heights pipeline by July 1 at the earliest.

images.alt_text: The blast at Putra Heights in nearby Selangor earlier this week hit gas provision, MSC said.

site_title: Donald Trump has given BYD the edge over Tesla
summary: Donald Trump's latest tariff push has unexpectedly benefited Chinese carmaker BYD, which outsold Tesla in pure battery EVs for the second consecutive quarter in Q1 2025. BYD's absence from the US market, due to steep tariffs, has insulated it from the chaos unleashed by the tariffs. This has allowed BYD to redirect its focus to other major markets, where it has gained a strategic advantage. BYD's sales have expanded globally, including in Europe, while Tesla faces challenges from potential Chinese retaliation and regulatory uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s Shanghai factory only makes Model 3 and Model Y cars and most of them are either sold in China or exported to other parts of Asia.
BYD set up shop in Shenzhen as a battery maker in 1995, before establishing an auto arm in 2003 and releasing its first car two years later.

(FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. Tesla reported a 13 percent drop in first quarter auto sales April 2, 2025, amid lower production during factory upgrades and blowback over CEO Elon Musk's work for President Donald Trump's administration. Musk's electric vehicle company delivered 336,681 autos in the quarter ending March 31, missing analyst expectations, as it pointed to the "loss of several weeks of production" while it ramps up upgrades for its Model Y output. (Photo by Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 16)
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that as the global order changes, a new one will emerge, and the country cannot be a passive bystander. He emphasized Singapore's commitment to an open and stable global system. The country plans to double down on international partnerships and open new diplomatic missions in Latin America and Africa. Additionally, Mercedes-Benz introduced new electric commercial vehicles in Singapore, while Royal Sporting House is reportedly closing after 50 years.

images.alt_text: The date of Nomination Day was suggested by PM Wong, to which President Tharman agreed, a statement from the Prime Minister’s Office said.

site_title: WTO slashes 2025 trade growth forecast, warns of deeper slump
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has slashed its forecast for global merchandise trade growth to a decline of 0.2% in 2025, citing US tariffs and spillover effects that could lead to the heaviest slump since the Covid pandemic. The new estimate is 0.6 percentage points lower than its previous forecast and 0.8 points lower than expected spillover effects. The WTO also expects a 1.5% decline in trade growth, the steepest drop since 2020, and a modest recovery of 2.5% in 2026.

images.alt_text: WTO director general Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala warned that the world economy risked breaking into two blocs, one centred around the United States and the other China.

site_title: Nature’s bounty in Niigata
summary: Satoyama Jujo, a 150-year-old inn in Niigata's mountain ranges, has been transformed into a luxury retreat by chef Toru Iwasa and his business partner, Keiko Kuwakino. The property, which costs upwards of $1,000 per night, features minimalist rooms, artworks by Japanese artists, and a Michelin-starred restaurant serving local mountain cuisine. Kuwakino's menu showcases fermented and preserved mountain vegetables, which are central to her cuisine. The restaurant's focus on holistic living and slow-cooked meals has earned Kuwakino the title of "best female vegetable chef on earth." Satoyama Jujo offers a tranquil getaway from city life, with activities such as hiking and exploring the surrounding snow-covered landscape.

site_title: Latest Singapore 1-year T-bill cut-off yield falls to 2.29%
summary: Singapore's latest one-year Treasury bill tranche yielded 2.29%, 0.66 percentage points lower than the previous January tranche. The auction received S$11.2 billion in applications for the S$5.3 billion on offer, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.11. Market interest rates have fallen, with analysts attributing the decrease to increasing liquidity in the Singapore dollar market.

site_title: Singapore may be small but is not without agency; committed to open, stable and rules-based global system: PM Wong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizes the country's commitment to a stable and rules-based global system, despite its small size. He outlines three key thrusts to strengthen Singapore's role: actively contributing to global commons, championing deeper regional cohesion and integration, and strengthening its global network of partnerships. The country will open new diplomatic missions in Africa and Latin America, while continuing to engage with major frameworks such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. Wong also cautions against getting caught in the crossfire between the US and China, advocating for agility, vigilance, and skilful diplomacy to maintain Singapore's credibility as an interlocutor.

site_title: COE quota rises 6.4% to 18,232 for May to July
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced an increase of 6.4% in the number of certificates of entitlement (COEs) available for bidding from May to July 2025, totaling 18,232 certificates. This is due to vehicle deregistrations, adjustments for changes in the taxi population, and the injection of additional COEs. Category A COEs for smaller cars will increase by 10%, while Category B COEs for larger cars will rise by 5.02%.

site_title: World of well-craft
summary: Grand Hyatt Singapore is pioneering a holistic approach to wellness in the hospitality industry under the guidance of its well-being director, Thea Wong. Wong, who holds three master's degrees, aims to foster self-awareness and personal agency through innovative wellness programs, including the state-of-the-art Damai Spa and fitness facilities. The hotel also prioritizes employee well-being with a dedicated social space and wellness initiatives. Wong's vision is to integrate wellness into every touchpoint, creating a human-centric experience that acknowledges and empowers each individual's unique wellness journey.

images.alt_text: The swimming pool at Raffles Sentosa.

site_title: John Lim: Unlikely ascent from lab coats to luxury suites
summary: John Lim, 47, the founder and CEO of the Manor Group, has built a luxury hotel brand from scratch after a decade in the civil service. Initially working in various roles, including a laboratory and immigration authority, Lim's father, an electrical consultant, gave him permission to upgrade properties and start a hotel business in 2011. Lim founded the Manor Group with a $10 million investment and expanded to 11 hotels under management, including boutique hotels and serviced accommodations. He aims to have 10 Amanor hotels across Asia within the next three years and is the first Singaporean to join the Small Luxury Hotels of the World board.

site_title: Sean Lim: From dishwasher to luxury hotel co-owner
summary: Sean Lim, a Singaporean entrepreneur, is behind Penang's luxury hotel project, Radisson Blu Hotel and Apartments Penang. Lim, who grew up in a modest flat and washed dishes as a teenager, overcame his struggles with anxiety and obesity to become a successful investor and property owner. He co-founded a cafe and restaurant, and later joined an investment group, NWD Holdings, where he brokered a sale and earned his first windfall. Lim partnered with NWD to develop the 700-key beachfront development, which promises sunset cocktails, sleek architectural lines, and a Bali-style beach bar. The project, slated for a 2028 opening, will feature serviced apartments starting from US$250,000 and guaranteed rental yields of 6-7%.
