site_title: Mindful in the metropolis
summary: Urban resorts, such as Parkroyal Collection Marina Bay, are emerging as popular destinations for wellness and relaxation in city centers. These luxurious havens, like Banyan Tree and Aman Resorts, offer tranquil escapes from urban jungle life, featuring biophilic design, urban farms, and spa treatments. To promote holistic well-being, the hotel is launching three room packages: "Mindful Nourishment," "Mindful Restoration," and "Mindful Movement," focusing on intentional eating, deep relaxation, and fitness with joy. This trend reflects a growing desire for calmness, balance, and connection to oneself and the world, driven by the blurring of work and leisure lines and a focus on wellness in society.

images.alt_text: Damai Spa is a portal to a multitude of innovative wellness offerings.
The swimming pool at Raffles Sentosa.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz revamps commercial EV lineup in Singapore
summary: Mercedes-Benz launched its revamped electric commercial vehicle range in Singapore, introducing its first large electric van, the eSprinter, alongside new versions of its eCitan and eVito models. The eSprinter offers a range of 267 km and can carry up to 10.5 cubic meters of cargo. The company is targeting the growing demand for electric commercial vehicles in Singapore, with prices starting at S$213,888, excluding incentives. The launch marks Mercedes-Benz's largest commercial vehicle product offensive since 2022, with the company aiming to support businesses and reduce emissions.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
A Volvo FL Electric, a heavy duty commercial truck.
Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme is for registrations of electric heavy vehicles with a maximum laden weight of more than 3,500 kilogrammes.
FedEx Singapore's Mercedes-Benz eVito 112 fully-electric delivery van can travel up to 321 kilometres on a full charge.
Farizon Supervan launches in Singapore on Feb 18 2025 by distributor Hong Seh Motors.
The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.
The Mercedes-Benz eActros made its South-east Asian debut in Singapore on Nov 21, 2023.

site_title: Japan crosses 10 million visitors through March at fastest ever pace
summary: Japan has reached 10 million visitors through March at the fastest ever pace, surpassing last year's level of 36.87 million. Foreign arrivals for business and leisure reached 3.5 million last month, bringing the total to 10.54 million. The nation's economy is benefiting from the tourism boom, with spending by foreign visitors reaching 2.3 trillion yen (S$20.89 billion) in the first quarter, up 28.4% from last year. This marks a significant boost to Japan's economy, making tourism its second-largest export sector after autos and electronics.

site_title: China Southern is said to mull Hong Kong IPO of cargo unit
summary: China Southern Airlines is exploring a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) for its cargo business, which could raise at least several hundred million US dollars. The move comes as the company's cargo unit faces declining fortunes due to the Chinese economy and US tariffs. China Southern had previously shelved plans to list the cargo unit in Shanghai, citing changes in the market environment. The IPO could be a strategic move for the company, which relies on Chinese exports under threat from the trade war with the US.

images.alt_text: A man looks up as a China Southern Airlines passengers jet flies over head as it approaches Hongqiao Airport for landing in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Oct. 23, 2015. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Guangzhou-based China Southern Group is one of the world’s largest carrier groups, with stakes in 10 airlines and operating 932 commercial jets.

site_title: PwC exits more than a dozen countries to avoid scandals: FT
summary: PwC has closed operations in over a dozen countries due to mounting differences with local partners, amid a desire to prevent repeats of scandals that have affected the firm. The decision comes after a decline in business and layoffs since last year. China fined PwC's mainland unit $62 million for audit failures, while Britain's Financial Reporting Council fined the firm £4.5 million for its audit of Wyelands Bank. The firm is also working to mend relations with Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund after a suspension of activities.

images.alt_text: From left: Musa Fazal, chief policy officer, SBF; Kok Ping Soon, chief executive officer, SBF; Marcus Lam, executive chairman, PwC Singapore; and Lennon Lee, tax leader, PwC Singapore.
PwC Australia has overhauled its leadership and sold its government services unit

site_title: China, Malaysia seek deals as Xi deepens South-east Asia ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's state visit to Malaysia resulted in 31 cooperation agreements, including cooperation in artificial intelligence, mutual visa exemptions, and global security. The agreements aim to deepen ties between China and Malaysia, a move to counter US pressure on South-east Asian economies. Xi's visit comes amid rising trade tensions and the imposition of US tariffs on Chinese exports. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim welcomed Xi, saying Malaysia values their relationship and seeks to boost cooperation in various fields, including economy, trade, and investment.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping (L) and Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim shake hands after attending an agreement exchange session at the official residence of the prime minister in Putrajaya, outside Kuala Lumpur, on April 16, 2025. (Photo by FAZRY ISMAIL / POOL / AFP)
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim greets Chinese President Xi Jinping at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Apr 15, during Xi's visit to Malaysia.
Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (right) and Chinese President Xi Jinping shake hands at the Office of the Party Central Committee in Hanoi, Vietnam on Apr 14.
Vietnam's Communist Party General Secretary To Lam and China's President Xi Jinping wave during a meeting at the office of the Party Central Committee in Hanoi on Apr 14.
Chinese President Xi Jinping's tour of South-east Asia will last from Monday until Friday, a foreign ministry spokesperson said.
The Malaysian leader’s trip comes as the Muslim-majority country draws closer to Beijing, with Anwar openly criticising the US over its support of Israel.

site_title: GE2025: Adrian Ang hopes to put infrastructure expertise to use in Aljunied GRC – if voters give PAP a mandate
summary: Adrian Ang, a PAP candidate for Aljunied GRC, hopes to utilize his infrastructure expertise to improve the constituency's amenities. With a PhD in engineering and experience in the built environment sector, he aims to tackle municipal issues such as cleanliness and rodent problems. Ang also plans to contribute to the debate on sustainability reporting, a topic he is passionate about, having worked on green projects in the past. If elected, he will work to improve infrastructure, including playgrounds and barrier-free access, and ensure that the town council is run efficiently.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
PAP new face Jeffrey Siow’s last position was second permanent secretary for the Ministry of Manpower and the Ministry of Trade and Industry.
The 30-plus new candidates that the PAP will field is the largest slate in recent history, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, on his first visit to Aljunied GRC since taking over Singapore’s top job, with ukulele players at the community event for seniors in Kovan Hub.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggle again as Nvidia chip curb warning pops calm
summary: Asian stocks declined on Wednesday, April 16, 2025, as Nvidia's announcement of new US licensing rules on shipments of its chips to China sparked investor concern. Hong Kong led losses, dropping 1.8%, while Shanghai, Tokyo, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, and Jakarta also fell. In contrast, Sydney, Singapore, and Wellington rose. The move by US officials to require licenses for Nvidia's H20 semiconductors to be shipped to China has heightened tensions between the US and China, with China's economy expanding more than expected in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also rose. Hong Kong and Shanghai dipped with Wellington.

site_title: Trump orders tariff probe on all US critical mineral imports
summary: US President Donald Trump ordered a probe into potential new tariffs on all US critical mineral imports, escalating his dispute with China and highlighting the US reliance on Beijing for processed minerals critical to its economy. China is a top global producer of 30 of the 50 minerals considered critical by the US Geological Survey, and has been curtailing exports in recent months. The review will assess US vulnerabilities for the processing of critical minerals, including cobalt, nickel, and rare earths, and determine whether to impose tariffs on foreign suppliers.

images.alt_text: The US export controls have spurred China to invest in its domestic chip equipment industry.
Trump has slapped new tariffs on friend and foe since returning to the presidency this year, but has reserved his heaviest blows for China.
Import prices dipped 0.1 per cent last month, the first decline since September, after a downwardly revised 0.2 per cent gain in February.
Hundreds of billions of US dollars in Chinese goods will still face an extra tariff of 145 per cent if companies continue to ship to the US.
Pharmaceuticals and semiconductors are exempt from those duties, but Trump has said they will face separate tariffs.

site_title: Rene Vijay Shrestha Einhaus: Advocate of Nepal’s luxury credentials
summary: Nepalese hotelier Rene Vijay Shrestha Einhaus left his European life to follow his family's unorthodox beginnings in hospitality. His grandfather, Dwarika Das Shrestha, was out jogging when he saw carpenters sawing off a carved pillar from an old Newar house to use as firewood, inspiring Einhaus to collect and preserve Newar architecture. Einhaus now runs Dwarika's Hotel, Nepal's first luxury hotel and a living museum, with his family's combined efforts. Despite facing challenges in overcoming Nepal's backpacker image, Einhaus envisions spreading Dwarika's wings to establish the country as a luxury destination, with plans for a boutique hotel in Dhampus and a focus on preserving cultural heritage.

images.alt_text: John Lim spent 10 years in the civil service before starting his entrepreneurial journey.
Sean Lim rose from being a lowly-paid cook to a successful investor, car lover and property owner.
Boucheron seek to represent nature in its imperfect and realistic form.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, April 16, 2025
summary: Asian stocks struggle on Wednesday, April 16, 2025, as Nvidia's chip curb warning calms investors. Hong Kong's postal service halts US parcels due to tariff 'bullying', while China orders airlines to suspend Boeing jet deliveries amid trade tensions. Meanwhile, CNMC Goldmine shares spike 7% as gold hits a record high.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led losses, dropping 1.8 per cent, while Shanghai, Tokyo, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also down. Sydney, Singapore and Wellington rose.
Postal items containing only documents will not be affected.
Guangzhou-based China Southern Group is one of the world’s largest carrier groups, with stakes in 10 airlines and operating 932 commercial jets.
Shares of CNMC Goldmine spiked over 7 per cent on Wednesday (Apr 16), as spot gold climbed 1.9 per cent to record highs of over US$3,270 per ounce.

site_title: Singtel Innov8 joins US$7.3 million Series A funding round of AI startup viAct
summary: Singapore-based construction safety startup viAct has raised US$7.3 million in Series A funding led by Venturewave Capital and Singtel Innov8. The funding will be used to develop more sophisticated models for hazard prediction, environmental compliance, and workforce safety. The platform, built by viAct, uses AI to detect risks, ensure compliance, and improve efficiency across construction projects and other industries. The startup plans to expand its team and strengthen its presence in the Middle East, where demand for AI-driven safety solutions is growing.

images.alt_text: Workers are seen at a construction site on a street at the central business district (CBD) in Sydney on April 8, 2025. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)
Benjamin Cher
Singtel has upped its capital commitment to CVC arm Innov8 from US$250 million to US$350 million

site_title: Wealthy Chinese lose interest in US and Singapore homes
summary: Chinese ultra-wealthy buyers have shifted their focus from US and Singapore homes to other destinations, with Thailand emerging as the top destination in 2024, overtaking the US. Interest in Singapore homes priced above US$5 million fell to 9th place, while buyer enquiries rose in Australia, Canada, and Malaysia. The decline in US and Singapore interest is attributed to a focus on lifestyle needs over citizenship, with buyers prioritizing homes for personal use and proximity to top schools.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

Investors said recent positive signs, from improving home prices in top cities to industry leader China Vanke’s recapitalisation plan, suggest this year will be the turning point for the real estate market.
Hong Kong’s housing market has long had an are-you-kidding-me feel to it.
Hong Kong’s government is trying to prop up the struggling residential property market by lifting all additional stamp duties for foreign and second home buyers in February.
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
Shanghai’s luxury real estate market is a bright spot in China’s bleak property sector.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index plunged 13 per cent on Monday (Apr 7), the most since 1997, triggering forced selling.

site_title: Heineken's Q1 sales slightly beat forecasts
summary: Heineken reported a 0.9% increase in first-quarter organic net revenues, exceeding analysts' expectations for a decline. The company attributed the result to the sale of pricier labels, offsetting a 2.1% decline in beer volumes due to fewer trading days. CEO Dolf van den Brink stated that Heineken is performing within expectations despite volatile trends. The company maintained its full-year guidance for 4-8% profit growth, unchanged from February.

site_title: Younger shoppers help power Little Farms’ islandwide expansion
summary: Little Farms, a gourmet grocery chain, is expanding islandwide in Singapore, aiming to double its seven existing stores by 2030. The company has gained popularity among young, health-conscious, affluent Singaporeans, particularly during the pandemic, with revenue increasing by 63.3% in 2020. Little Farms now has six outlets, with a seventh opening in Sentosa, and plans to enter the regional market with high growth opportunities in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. The company prioritizes getting closer to its regular customers, focusing on younger neighbourhoods, and sources high-quality produce directly from farmers, including those in Australia, France, and Spain.

images.alt_text: Kevin Chee, founder of Matchaya, has plans to open an outlet in India and another in the Philippines
Jesher Loi, director of branding and market development at Ya Kun International.

site_title: American shoppers flock to Chinese apps on tariff fears
summary: US consumers are turning to Chinese e-commerce apps like DHgate, Taobao, and Shein to avoid higher prices due to tariffs. Viral TikTok videos showcase high-quality and affordable products, leading to a surge in downloads and sales. Chinese suppliers are using TikTok to promote their products and provide direct links to customers, with some selling counterfeit versions of luxury brands. In response, DHgate has launched a "Tariff Escort Plan" to support merchants and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s algorithm is one of the main driving forces behind US government efforts to force its Chinese owner, ByteDance, to relinquish control of its international operations.
One of ByteDance’s biggest challenges in 2025 remains securing a US deal that appeases both Washington and Beijing.
The link to the piece on the ABC News website now says “page unavailable”.
Trump has said he would be willing to reduce tariffs on China to get a deal done with ByteDance to sell the app used by 170 million Americans.

site_title: Singapore task force tackles US tariff impact with communication, support, long-term strategies
summary: Singapore has established an Economic Resilience Task Force to help companies navigate the impact of US tariffs, particularly those with manufacturing operations in China. The task force, led by Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, will focus on three areas: "sense-making" and communication, immediate support measures, and long-term strategies. The task force aims to provide support to companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and workers, particularly those in affected sectors such as manufacturing and finance. The government will also engage with like-minded nations to strengthen partnerships and inform external engagements.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
DPM Gan said Singapore is also reaching out to its trading partners to share information and explore different ways of working together
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong delivering his opening remarks at a NTUC dialogue session with labour movement leaders and union leaders at the NTUC Centre on Apr 14.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Sats, Sinarmas Land, Japfa, Aztech, Sabana Reit, LHN, Oiltek
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its low-cost arm Scoot reported a 0.8% year-on-year drop in combined passenger traffic in March due to the Easter holiday shift. SIA's shares rose 1.4% to S$6.30. Sats' subsidiary Worldwide Flight Services secured a new five-year cargo handling contract with Emirates SkyCargo at Frankfurt Airport, boosting shares by 0.8% to S$2.67.

images.alt_text: The recent IPO of Aztech Global might trigger some nostalgia among long-time participants of Singapore's capital markets.

site_title: Indonesia hikes mining royalties to fund Prabowo policies
summary: Indonesia has increased mining royalties for nickel, tin, and other metals to fund President Prabowo Subianto's policies, with rates rising from 10% to 19% depending on commodity prices. The changes come as the government seeks to finance flagship policies, including a new state investment fund and free school lunches, amidst trade turbulence and low metal prices. The increases will affect major mining companies, with shares of coal producers rallying on the news.

images.alt_text: Indonesia Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the ministry recommended increasing the LPG import quota for the US, as well as importing more US crude, to help reach the target.
Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto says: “Indonesia is one of the countries that had the first opportunity to be invited to Washington.”
Danantara is slated to eventually manage more than US$900 billion worth of assets.

site_title: Candy maker YLF scraps plan to list on SGX
summary: YLF Group Marketing, a Singapore-based candy maker, has withdrawn its plan to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) less than three weeks after lodging its preliminary offer document. The decision comes amid the US tariffs' impact on the financial markets, which has seen Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fall 9% since March 27. No reason was given for the withdrawal, which would have been the second company to go public on the SGX this year, following Parallel-car importer Vin’s Holdings.

images.alt_text: Singaporean automotive group Vin's Holdings began trading at 9am on Tuesday (15 Apr) at S$0.315.
Vin's Holdings is expected to on SGX Catalist board on Apr 15, with a market capitalisation of S$39.3 million
Singaporean automotive group Vin's Holdings seeks a Catalist IPO on Apr 15, 2025.
Car dealer, candy maker could be first listings on SGX this year

site_title: CNMC Goldmine shares spike 7% as gold hits record high
summary: CNMC Goldmine shares surged 7% on Wednesday, driven by record-high gold prices above US$3,275 per ounce. The company's spot gold field in Kelantan, Malaysia, operates 10 sq km, with recent capacity expansion and firm metals prices fueling revenue and earnings growth. CNMC's carbon-in-leach facility now has 300 tonnes per day of ore-processing capacity, providing greater operational flexibility. The company's shares traded at S$0.455, up S$0.03 or 7.1%, amid global economic uncertainty and investors seeking safe-haven assets.

images.alt_text: Gold is currently trading above US$3,200 per ounce, up from US$2,624.5 per ounce at the end of last year

site_title: Hermes’ market value surpasses that of former suitor LVMH
summary: Hermes' market capitalization surpassed that of rival LVMH, reaching almost 249 billion euros, making it the most valuable company on France's CAC40 index and the third-largest listed company in Europe. Hermes' supply-constrained business model, catering to the wealthiest and cultivating exclusivity, has helped it weather the downturn in demand for luxury goods better than rivals. The company's strong pricing power and waiting lists for its products, such as the Birkin and Kelly handbags, have contributed to its success.

images.alt_text: The Hermes fortune derives from its namesake firm Hermes International, known for selling pricey Birkin handbags.

An Hermes luxury boutique in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024. Hermes has held steady as its leather-goods unit benefits from long waiting lists and price increases, according to Exane, and has had a neutral rating since 2018. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg
The company is experiencing softer demand for its more affordable goods such as silk scarves, reflecting a curb in spending by aspirational customers, Dumas says.

site_title: GE2025: Josephine Teo continues to helm PAP’s Jalan Besar GRC slate
summary: Minister for Digital Development and Information Josephine Teo will continue to lead the People's Action Party (PAP) team in Jalan Besar GRC, a Singaporean electoral constituency, in the 2025 General Election. The team includes newcomer Shawn Loh, a 38-year-old former director at the Ministry of Finance, who has experience in both public and private sectors. The election is taking place during Singapore's 60th year of independence, known as SG60.

images.alt_text: Party chief Leong Mun Wai said that PSP has been hard at work to prepare for GE2025 despite the short time to engage new residents.
Yusof Ishak Secondary School will be where the candidates for three hot GRCs – East Coast, Sengkang and Punggol – will gather.

The date of Nomination Day was suggested by PM Wong, to which President Tharman agreed, a statement from the Prime Minister’s Office said.

site_title: Apple to rejig sales division with departure of enterprise chief
summary: Apple's top executive overseeing enterprise sales and the western European market, Mark Rogers, is leaving the company later this year after 27 years of service. Rogers will split his responsibilities, with Juan Castellanos taking over western Europe and Vivek Thakkar handling global enterprise sales. The changes follow recent reorganizations, including the departure of co-sales chief Doug Beck in 2023. Rogers' departure marks the latest exit of a long-tenured manager, following executives such as Dan Riccio and Carol Surface.

images.alt_text: Apple, these days, sells about 220 million to 230 million iPhones annually, with about a third of those going to the US.
Apple has a nearly 8 per cent market share in India’s smartphone market, where its sales – a bulk of those from iPhones – reached almost US$8 billion in fiscal 2024.
The estimate comes as US President Donald Trump zeros in on China for his trade fight.
The details of the push provide an insight into Apple’s private strategy to navigate around the Trump tariffs and build up inventory of its popular iPhones in the US.

site_title: Shein’s tariff-busting shift hits home in Chinese factory hub
summary: Shein, the ultra-fast fashion retailer, is shifting production from China to Vietnam in response to rising US tariffs, which could help maintain lower tariff rates for US-bound shipments under the "de minimis" exemption. However, this move may lead to a Catch-22 situation for the company, as diversifying its sourcing base and changing its business model could increase costs and turnaround times. The shift may also harm factory owners in China, who have seen a 50% decline in orders from Shein this year, with some considering bankruptcy or relocation to Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Shein ships the majority of its products directly to shoppers by air in individually addressed packages.
Shein and Temu have for years surfed on that practice to send tens of billions of US dollars worth of product into the US from their network of Chinese factories.
Shein’s net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: China Q1 GDP growth beats expectations, but US tariff shock dims outlook
summary: China's first-quarter GDP growth exceeded expectations at 5.4% year-over-year, driven by solid consumption and industrial output. However, analysts warn that the US tariff shock poses a significant risk to the Asian powerhouse's economy, with exports expected to sharply reverse in the months ahead. China's Premier Li Qiang has vowed to support domestic consumption, while policymakers have repeatedly stated they have ample room to implement stimulus measures. The country's growth momentum is expected to cool sharply in the next few quarters, with economists forecasting a 4.5% growth pace for 2025.

images.alt_text: Gantry cranes stand near shipping containers at Yangshan Port outside of Shanghai, China, April 15, 2025.  REUTERS/Go Nakamura
Chinese demand has been shored up by a pilot programme that allows insurance funds to invest in gold, as part of efforts to optimise their asset allocations.
The export surge supported the economy in the first quarter, but that boost may dissipate after the US threw global trade into chaos.
The Citi economists expect more US tariff rollbacks could emerge due to supply chain disruption, inflationary pressure, American business interests.
China has also vowed to boost domestic consumption as tariffs threaten exports, which contributed to nearly a third of the country’s economic expansion in 2024. T

site_title: If Japan can’t get a good trade deal, can anyone?
summary: Japan's delegation, led by Minister Ryosei Akazawa, is set to meet with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent for tariff talks. The stakes are high, as a good deal for Japan could set a precedent for other countries. Japan is a key security ally and has a history of championing free trade, but the US has imposed tariffs on Japanese autos, sparking concerns. Despite the challenges, Akazawa is seeking a win-win deal that boosts both countries' interests, particularly in areas such as currency and defense trade. The outcome of the talks will be closely watched, with the US and other countries, including the UK, Australia, and South Korea, waiting to see if Japan can secure a positive deal.

images.alt_text: The US was Honda’s biggest market last year, accounting for nearly 40 per cent of global sales.

epa12002151 Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba speaks during a press conference at the Prime Minister’s office (Kantei) in Tokyo, Japan, 01 April 2025. Ishiba stated that Japan will continue to seek an exemption from US tariffs for Japanese automobiles.  EPA-EFE/Nicolas Datiche / POOL

site_title: Tariff chaos casts shadow over Singapore’s residential rental market
summary: Singapore's residential rental market is expected to pick up in 2025, driven by improved leasing volumes and easing rents. Private condo rents eased 1.9% in 2024, while HDB flat rents rose 3.6%. The market saw increased interest in suburban and prime areas, with one-bedroom and two-bedroom units leading the demand. Ultra-high-net-worth individuals may choose to relocate to Singapore, boosting the market. However, global uncertainties, including US tariffs, may impact the market, with the government revising down its economic growth forecast and reducing the pace of the Singapore dollar's appreciation.

images.alt_text: Upheaval in financial markets and prospects of recession could draw investors towards stability, while the interest rate environment could turn more conducive for institutional grade asset transactions.

The “cluster effect” is particularly pronounced in the Lentor Hills estate cluster, which has seen six launches to date and one more to come in 2026. Despite initial concerns about a potential supply glut in an untested area, each successive launch in the Lentor Hills cluster saw healthy take-up rates and higher home prices.

site_title: China’s new home prices flat in March, investment remains weak
summary: China's new home prices remained flat in March, a slight improvement from February's 0.1% decline, according to National Bureau of Statistics data. This marks a 4.5% year-over-year decline, with property values, sales, and investment continuing to slump. Policymakers have pledged to stabilize the debt-stricken property market, but efforts have yet to yield significant results, with property sales down 3% in the first quarter and investment in the sector falling 9.9%. Premier Li Qiang emphasized the need for further policy responses to promote the market's potential.

images.alt_text: A string of recent data has pointed to an uneven economic recovery, with bank lending beating expectations and factory activity picking up speed.
The export surge supported the economy in the first quarter, but that boost may dissipate after the US threw global trade into chaos.

site_title: Sinarmas Land’s H2 net profit drops 5.5% to S$154 million on lower revenue, higher costs
summary: Sinarmas Land, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 5.5% drop in half-year net profit to S$154 million due to lower revenue and higher costs. For the full year, net profit fell 10.8% to S$243.1 million, driven by a 97.7% increase in non-controlling interests. The company declared no dividend for the financial year, citing cash conservation for working capital needs.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Over the four trading sessions from Mar 28 to Apr 3, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional inflow of S$76 million.
The cash offer of S$0.31 per share to take Sinarmas Land private represents a 12.7 per cent premium over the company's last traded price.
The offeror, Lyon Investments, currently holds about 70.3 per cent of the total number of issued shares in Sinarmas Land.

site_title: Is the curtain coming down on Royal Sporting House in Singapore after 50 years?
summary: Royal Sporting House, a 50-year-old Singaporean sports retailer, may be closing its remaining six outlets after four are set to shut down in the coming months. The company, acquired by Dubai-based GMG in 2020, has seen a significant decline in sales, with storewide discounts of up to 70% offered. This follows the closure of outlets at Northpoint and Causeway Point in March. GMG, which operates more than 200 stores in South-east Asia, has plans to consolidate its sport retail portfolio around its SSS brand.

images.alt_text: Royal Sporting House at Northpoint. It has been closed down and all the merchandise have been moved out of the shop.
Goh Ruoxue

site_title: Who needs facts when you want to remake the world order?
summary: US Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran proposes a radical economy-wide overhaul to bring back well-paid factory jobs. He argues that the US dollar's overvaluation and constant demand for US financial assets erode America's industrial base. Miran suggests converting foreign central banks' US Treasury assets to 100-year bonds, which would likely lead to a default on US debt. The plan has sparked a trade war with China, with goods trade between the two countries effectively ending. Critics argue that the plan is ahistorical and ignores the 1974 oil-for-dollars deal that created the demand for US financial assets.

images.alt_text: Mohan Kuppusamy
European policymakers must also resist the temptation to react to the “flood” of cheap Chinese goods that are diverted from the US market to Europe.
Chinese President Xi Jinping makes a three-country tour of South-east Asia from Apr 14 to 18 amid an escalating trade tensions with the US. He arrived Hanoi on Monday for a two-day state visit.
'Trump whisper' Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s Prime Minister, plans to talk next steps with the US President this week and eyes a trade deal with the US.

site_title: Hyundai CEO sees gradual rise in car prices easing tariff shock
summary: Hyundai CEO Jose Munoz expects car prices to remain relatively steady despite added costs from the escalating global trade war, citing the market's ability to decide on prices. The company plans a record $21 billion investment in the US, aiming to maintain stability and keep customers coming to dealer lots. Munoz acknowledged the added stress on parts manufacturers due to tariffs, but emphasized the company's commitment to supporting the US market, where it considers Hyundai's US operations to be the most important.

site_title: Oiltek bags RM61.9 million in new contracts across South-east Asia and other global markets
summary: Oiltek International has secured new contracts worth RM61.9 million across South-east Asia and other global markets, bringing its current order book to RM402.4 million. The contracts involve the design, fabrication, delivery, testing, and commissioning of various plants and refinery complexes in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Africa, and the Americas. The company expects these contracts to be fulfilled over the next 18-24 months, with a positive impact on its financial performance this year.

site_title: A stock that offers shelter from Trump’s mayhem
summary: CNMC Goldmine, a small-cap miner in Malaysia, is riding the soaring price of gold, with its shares climbing 73.5% this year. The company has expanded its processing capacity by 300 tonnes per day, providing greater operational flexibility and supporting increased extraction of higher-grade gold ores. Analysts forecast a 46.6% increase in CNMC's earnings for 2025, driven by rising gold prices and increased production. The company's market capitalization has reached S$172.2 million, with a projected dividend yield of 4.5%.

site_title: US import prices muted, but tariffs loom over inflation
summary: US import prices dropped 0.1% in March, the first decline since September, following a downwardly revised 0.2% gain in February. This decrease, attributed to lower energy product costs, suggests inflation is subsiding before President Trump's sweeping tariffs take effect. Economists expect tame inflation readings, but warn of a painful transition for the US economy as tariffs are implemented, potentially leading to stagflation and a recession. The US dollar has weakened, increasing the cost of imported goods, and further increases are likely.

site_title: A$2.7 billion plan to build Australia’s tallest tower falters
summary: A$2.7 billion plan to build Australia's tallest tower, STH BNK, in Melbourne's Southbank district has stalled due to soaring construction costs and financial difficulties. The project, which was set to feature a 365-meter-tall skyscraper, a vertical garden, and luxury apartments, has been plagued by delays and uncertainty since its inception in 2020. The developer, Beulah, has engaged Jones Lang LaSalle and KPMG to scout for new investors or a potential buyer, but the project's future remains uncertain. The development's failure highlights the challenges facing Australia's housing market, which has been accelerated by the pandemic.

The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment slid 6.0 per cent in April from March, more than erasing the previous month’s 4 per cent gain.

summary: Singapore and Asean exporters should diversify away from US reliance in the wake of Trump tariffs, according to panellists. The real risk for the trade-reliant city-state is the politicised and unpredictable nature of US trade actions. Regional exporters should seek non-US export markets, leveraging the region's consumer base to reduce exposure to the US market. Diversifying export markets is a strategic opportunity to reduce reliance on the US, as seen in China's efforts to diversify beyond the US.

site_title: GE2025: Academic Charlene Chen, former army chief David Neo join PAP Tampines GRC team
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its slate for Tampines Group Representation Constituency (GRC) for the 2025 General Election. The five-member team includes former army chief David Neo and academic Charlene Chen, who will join Minister for Social and Family Development Masagos Zulkifli and three incumbent members. The team's focus will be on sustainable living, with Masagos emphasizing the importance of Tampines as an eco-town. The newly carved-out Tampines Changkat ward will be contested by incumbent Desmond Choo, who faces a potential four-way fight against the Workers' Party (WP), National Solidarity Party (NSP), and the newly formed People's Power Party (PPP).

site_title: US tariffs may cost chip equipment makers more than US$1 billion, industry estimates
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on the chip industry could cost US semiconductor equipment makers over $1 billion annually, according to industry estimates. The three largest US chip equipment makers - Applied Materials, Lam Research, and KLA - may suffer losses of around $350 million per year, while smaller rivals may face tens of millions of dollars in extra spending. The Trump administration has paused the reciprocal tariffs but is considering further duties on the industry. The estimated costs include lost revenue, tariff compliance costs, and the costs of finding alternative suppliers.

site_title: Indonesia to propose US$10 billion US energy imports increase in tariff talks
summary: Indonesia plans to propose a $10 billion increase in US energy imports as part of its tariff negotiations with the US. The country aims to cut its trade surplus and avoid a threatened 32% tariff on its exports. To achieve this, Indonesia will need to reduce its LPG imports from non-US sources by 20-30%. The country will also increase its imports of US crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas to reach its target.

summary: US President Donald Trump says it's up to China to negotiate a trade deal, stating "the ball is in China's court" after China allegedly reneged on a Boeing deal. Trump has imposed steep duties on Chinese imports, with many still facing a 145% tariff, and has vowed to protect US farmers. The US and China have been locked in a trade war since the start of the year, with both sides imposing tariffs on each other's goods.

site_title: China’s Xi begins Malaysia visit in shadow of Trump tariffs
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Malaysia on April 15 for a state visit amid escalating trade tensions with the US. Xi emphasized the importance of traditional friendship between China and Malaysia, while also calling for a stable multilateral trade regime to counter US President Donald Trump's punitive tariff regime. The visit comes as China seeks to position itself as a stable alternative to US trade policies, with Xi stating that both countries should "oppose hegemony and power politics" and "unilateralism in all forms."

The move comes after the US eliminated duty-free treatment for postal items from China, including Hong Kong, and Hong Kong leader John Lee criticized the US measures, accusing Washington of "wanton suppression". Postal items containing only documents will not be affected. This decision follows Beijing's similar move, and the US has signaled readiness to talks to reduce tariffs.

summary: LHN Group plans to spin off and list its co-living business, Coliwoo Group, on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard. The move, expected to continue holding a majority stake in Coliwoo, aims to consolidate the business segment. Coliwoo's shares closed 1.2% higher on the news, and the company's listing application is pending with the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The proposal does not constitute a chain listing, meeting Singapore Exchange requirements.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly higher as investors assess possible tariff exemptions
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday as investors assessed the possibility of tariff exemptions for the auto sector. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 3 points, the S&P 500 increased 6 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 10.9 points. The move comes after President Donald Trump floated the idea of more exemptions, which could ease trade tensions and boost the auto industry. The market reaction suggests investors are cautiously optimistic about the potential relief.

site_title: China orders airlines to suspend Boeing jet deliveries amid trade war
summary: China has ordered its airlines to suspend deliveries of Boeing jets, citing US tariffs on Chinese goods. The country has also asked carriers to halt purchases of aircraft-related equipment and parts from US companies. This move comes in response to the US decision to impose 145% tariffs on Chinese goods. The halt in deliveries is expected to raise maintenance costs for the jets flying in China, and the Chinese government is considering ways to provide assistance to airlines that lease Boeing jets.

site_title: Nvidia says new limits on China exports to cost US$5.5 billion
summary: Nvidia faces new US restrictions on exporting its H20 chip to China, a move that will cost the company approximately $5.5 billion. The restrictions follow concerns that the chip could be used in a supercomputer in China, and are seen as part of the Trump administration's efforts to strengthen the US government's approach to Chinese tech development. The new rules will require a license for the H20 chip to be exported to China "for the indefinite future", and come as Nvidia prepares to build up to $500 billion worth of AI infrastructure in the US over the next four years.

site_title: China Southern halts sale of Boeing jets on US new-plane freeze

The airline cited "events impacting transactions" as the reason for the halt, following Beijing's announcement of retaliatory tariffs on US goods. This move illustrates a knock-on effect from the trade standoff, affecting the secondary trade in used aircraft and impacting China Southern's long-haul network.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as markets monitor trade war fallout
summary: US stocks finished lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average declining 0.4% to 40,368.96, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also falling 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Investors are monitoring the US-China trade war, with a White House spokesperson saying the ball is in China's court. Solid bank earnings and a calmer US Treasury market provided some relief, but uncertainty remains among market participants. Companies like Boeing and Netflix also saw significant price movements, with Boeing dropping 2.4% and Netflix surging 4.8%.

site_title: Can a global trade war be avoided?
summary: US President Donald Trump proposed sweeping tariffs on nearly all trading partners, sparking a global trade war. The US imports account for less than one-sixth of the global total, and the EU is crucial in avoiding damage. The EU should respond pragmatically, not react impulsively, to the US's actions. By rallying like-minded countries to uphold the open, rules-based global trading system, the EU can avoid the economic fallout of a global tariff war. The EU's key role in making this outcome possible could lead to a benign outcome for the global economy.

summary: European shares rose 1.6% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over potential US tariff relief on auto imports. The pan-European Stoxx 600 gained ground, with the Italian bourse outperforming others. However, luxury stocks slumped after LVMH missed sales estimates, with shares of Christian Dior and Puig also declining. Investors await the European Central Bank's policy meeting, expecting a 25-basis-point rate cut.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Explaining GE2025 from boundaries to ballots
summary: In a recent podcast episode, experts Dr Gillian Koh and Professor Walid Jumblatt bin Abdullah break down Singapore's electoral system, shedding light on recent changes and expectations leading up to GE2025. They discuss electoral boundaries, the function of Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs), and the roles of Members of Parliament (MPs). The experts provide insights into the historical development of the electoral system, its contemporary relevance, and the nuances of campaigning rules, opposition parties, and post-election preparations.

site_title: Oil prices steady as market considers latest US tariff changes
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures settling at $64.67 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude at $61.33 per barrel. The latest US tariff changes have created uncertainty, prompting the International Energy Agency to lower its global oil demand forecast for 2025. Several banks, including UBS and HSBC, have cut their crude price forecasts, citing the risk of a deeper US recession and a hard landing in China.

site_title: Ex-G7 chair Meloni faces mission impossible with Team Trump
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni is set to visit the White House this week to discuss trade tariffs and Ukraine with President Donald Trump. Despite being called the "Trump whisperer," Meloni's ability to influence the Trump team is facing its toughest test yet. Italy's trade surplus with the US and its strong economic ties to the EU make it difficult for Meloni to achieve significant gains. The visit comes at a challenging time for Meloni's fragile coalition, with critics accusing her of being too subservient to Trump. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, but preserving her coalition's stability is Meloni's top priority.

summary: Global wine consumption fell 3.3% in 2024 to 214.2 million hectolitres, the lowest level in over 60 years, according to the International Organisation of Vine and Wine. Production also dropped 4.8% to 225.8 million hectolitres, with sales in China remaining below pre-Covid-19 levels despite a rebound. The US wine market saw a 5.8% decline, while Europe's consumption fell 2.8%. The wine industry faces long-term structural factors and economic disruptions, with some players predicting a "generational" decline in drinking habits.

site_title: Asean+3’s potential growth could nearly halve by 2050: Amro
summary: Asean+3 economies, including South-east Asia, face a nearly halved growth potential by 2050 due to weaker capital accumulation and slower labour-force expansion. The region's growth rate is projected to decline from around 4% in 2023 to 2.8% by 2050, and potentially 2.3% if geoeconomic fragmentation deepens. Middle-stage economies like Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand are expected to struggle with stagnant industrialization and weak productivity growth, while non-Asean economies will be impacted by demographic constraints. site_title: FedEx launches Singapore-US direct cargo flight
summary: FedEx has launched a direct cargo flight from Singapore to the US, reducing cargo transit times by up to a day. The flight reduces transit time by not having to pass through Japan, and shipments can arrive in the US on the following Monday, instead of Tuesday.

site_title: India’s inflation at near six-year low, boosts rate cut bets
summary: India's inflation eased to 3.34% in March, the lowest in nearly six years, validating the Reserve Bank of India's interest rate cuts and boosting bets for further rate reductions. Banks expect the repo rate to drop to 5% in this easing cycle, implying 100 basis points more in cuts, as easing food inflation and lower oil prices allow the RBI to maintain looser policy settings. This supports growth in Asia's third-largest economy.

images.alt_text: India's diamond processing hub of Surat employs at least a million workers to cut, polish and set the gem. The country, which ships more than a third of its exports to the US, is expected to be among the worst-hit sectors.

site_title: Addressing Singapore employers’ hopes and fears for flexible work arrangements
summary: Singapore employers are cautiously optimistic about flexible work arrangements (FWAs), with 70% of respondents indicating they are ready to adopt FWAs. However, concerns persist, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises. The main advantages of FWAs include attracting and retaining a larger talent pool, as well as improving work-life balance. Despite the benefits, many employers are hesitant to adopt FWAs due to concerns over productivity and employee motivation. The research collaboration aims to provide guidance and support for employers to implement FWAs effectively.

images.alt_text: Office workers at Raffles Place, 23 January 2025. PMET, CBD, manpower, wages, income, salary, employment, foreign talent, job security
Many modern-day workmen operate advanced machinery and sophisticated digital systems in highly automated environments.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as stability returns, autos lifted by exemption hope
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday as stability returned to markets after last week's rollercoaster ride, with auto firms boosted by potential compromise over tariffs. The US-China trade tensions continued to fuel uncertainty, with speculation over new levies on high-end technology and pharmaceuticals dampening sentiment. Despite Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent's remarks suggesting a possible China-US deal, investors remained cautious, with Tokyo and Seoul rising due to a rally in autos.

images.alt_text: Tech firms helped push Hong Kong stocks more than two per cent higher on Monday, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei and Manila share were all higher.

site_title: Honda considers switching some car production to US from Mexico, Canada, Nikkei reports
summary: Honda is considering shifting some car production from Mexico and Canada to the US to comply with new US auto tariffs, aiming to produce 90% of cars sold in the country locally. The automaker plans to increase US vehicle production by up to 30% over two to three years, with production of the CR-V SUV and HR-V SUV moving to the US. This move aims to reduce reliance on imported vehicles and capitalize on the US market, which accounted for nearly 40% of global sales last year.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 15, 2025
summary: Asian stocks experienced mixed movements on Tuesday, with stability returning to the market. Vin's Holdings, an automotive group, debuted 16.6% higher in SGX's first listing of 2025. Meanwhile, UOBKH stated that data centers are "sheltered" from reciprocal tariffs and named its top Reit picks. The news comes as investors look for stability in the market.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Tuesday.
Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also rose. Hong Kong and Shanghai dipped with Wellington.
Singaporean automotive group Vin's Holdings began trading at 9am on Tuesday (15 Apr) at S$0.315.
Digital Core Reit's data centre in Osaka.  UOB Kay Hian believes the advent of new reasoning AI models will drive the next wave of demand for data centres.

site_title: Court hears of more luxury-car purchases by alleged nickel fraudster
summary: Alleged nickel fraudster Ng Yu Zhi, 37, is standing trial for 42 charges related to fraudulent trading, cheating, and money laundering. He spent over S$21 million on about 20 luxury cars, including a vintage Mercedes Benz for his girlfriend Qian Yijun for S$288,000. Ng's purchases came from various dealers, including Autobahn Motors and Motor-Way Credit, and included luxury cars such as Bentleys, Aston Martins, and Lamborghinis. He is accused of swindling 947 victims of nearly S$1.5 billion.

He was taking the stand in the ongoing trial of Ng, 37, who is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted $1.45 billion from hundreds of investors over six years.

site_title: Tech’s ‘zombie unicorns’ reach the end of the road
summary: Silicon Valley is facing a "zombie unicorn" crisis, where many startups that reached $1 billion valuations have dwindling prospects and little hope of justifying their status. The last two years of AI hype fueled bubbly tech valuations, but now startups are struggling to raise capital and venture firms are expressing "Covid-level fear." The economic uncertainty caused by Trump's tariff tantrum could offer a healthy correction to the ecosystem, forcing startups to focus on financial fundamentals and potentially leading to a more sustainable tech industry.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump’s announcement on Wednesday of major tariffs on US trading partners around the world sent the S&P 500 index of US stocks to its lowest level in 11 months.

site_title: Frasers Property COO Anthony Boyd leaving amid senior management changes
summary: Frasers Property is undergoing significant senior management changes, including the departure of COO Anthony Boyd on July 4, after two decades with the company, and Group Chief Digital Officer Samuel Tan on May 5. Boyd's role will not be replaced immediately, while Tan's responsibilities will be redistributed. Frasers Property UK CEO Ilaria del Beato will transition to an advisory role on July 1 after seven years at the helm. The company attributes the changes to normal business course and remains focused on its strategic goals, including increasing development exposure and boosting recurring income.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

The more adventurous investors would believe it is now time to “buy the dip”. But it might not be the wisest thing to do.
As interest rates stay higher for longer, under-valued Reits are more attractive targets for privatisation, say observers.

site_title: Multibillion dollar exodus hits China ETFs amid Trump tariff war
summary: US-listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tracking Chinese stocks have seen a record outflow of $5.57 billion in the week ending April 11, with $3.69 billion of that coming from China. The outflows, largely driven by the escalating trade war between the US and China, have raised concerns over global growth. China's retaliatory tariffs and White House's 145% levies on Chinese goods have sparked fears of negative economic impact, prompting investors to dump China-specific ETFs.

images.alt_text: Gold is traditionally bought as jewellery for its cultural significance in China, but investors have increasingly favoured the precious metal as a hedge against uncertainty.

The world’s largest digital asset has come under pressure this week, with its price sinking to its lowest level since mid-November after hitting an all-time high earlier this year.

site_title: Japfa shareholders approve privatisation offer
summary: Japfa shareholders approved a privatisation offer by family members of the company's founder, with 151 shareholders (about 75.1% of scheme shareholders) voting in favor. The offer price is S$0.62 per share, representing a 34.8% premium to the last "undisturbed" price. The company's delisting is expected to occur on or around June 3, subject to regulatory approval, with shareholders receiving the scheme consideration on or around May 30.

site_title: Taiwan shipping tycoon buys HK$260 million luxury home in Hong Kong
summary: A Taiwanese shipping family, the Chen family of TS Lines, purchased a luxury mansion in Hong Kong for HK$260 million, marking the second-largest new home sale in the Asian financial hub this year. The 5,329 square foot house, with five suites and a private elevator, is located at the One Stanley project on the southern coast of Hong Kong Island. The sale is the latest in a series of high-profile transactions in Hong Kong's luxury housing market, which has seen improving sentiment despite recent property curbs.

images.alt_text: Victoria Dockside, which houses luxury mall K11 Musea, is worth about HK$88 billion (S$15.2 billion) based on an assumed price of about HK$30,000 per square foot.
Home prices in Hong Kong have tumbled nearly 30 per cent from a 2021 peak.
China’s commercial real estate sector has been suffering from a lengthy downturn, but there have been some signs of recovery.

site_title: Sabana Reit reports 26.5% higher Q1 DPU at S$0.0086 on 22% higher NPI
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 26.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0086 in Q1 2025, driven by a 22% rise in net property income (NPI) to S$16 million. Revenue grew 4.6% to S$29.1 million, with higher occupancy and rental reversions contributing to the increase. The Reit's CEO, Donald Han, expects 2025 performance to be challenged by economic uncertainties, but believes the group's financial position remains adequate to meet funding requirements.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Analysts expect Frasers Centrepoint Trust, which counts Northpoint City as its asset, to post a higher DPU in its upcoming financial results.
Lin Duanliang engaged in contempt of court on three occasions, according to an affidavit seen by The Business Times.

site_title: Asean’s China trade play: buy less, sell more amid US tensions
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's three-country tour of South-east Asia aims to strengthen economic ties with the region amid shifting trade dynamics and US tensions. China is extending its offer as a major import market and key supply chain node for Asean's 10 member states, while some countries weigh barriers on Chinese trade. The region is caught between its two largest trading partners, the US and China, while trying to preserve its appeal as a stable, open trade hub. China is expected to roll out major stimulus soon to spur domestic consumption, potentially offering export opportunities to South-east Asian producers.

images.alt_text: In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.

Movements in the broad US dollar and yuan have for some time now been critical in determining Asian foreign exchange moves, MUFG Bank’s senior currency analyst Michael Wan noted that even more domestic-oriented economies, such as Indonesia, are increasingly responding more to the yuan
US President Donald Trump’s latest tariff torpedo means South-east Asian countries have their work cut out for them as they face one of their biggest tests in recent times.
Unlike during Trump's first presidency, South-east Asia is now directly in the firing line for aggressive and high levies, says an analyst.
The first phase of Vietnam SuperPort, located in the northern province of Vinh Phuc, has been operational since Jan 2023.

site_title: AMD set to produce its CPU chip at TSMC plant in Arizona
summary: AMD plans to produce its CPU chip at TSMC's Arizona plant, marking the first time its products will be manufactured in the US. The move comes as the Trump administration investigates whether imports of semiconductors threaten national security, potentially leading to tariffs. AMD CEO Lisa Su said the company's new fifth-generation EPYC CPU is doing well and is ready for production. The move expands AMD's US footprint, following similar announcements from Apple and Nvidia, which also produce chips at the Arizona plant.

images.alt_text: AMD is trying to persuade some of the biggest companies in the world to include its AI products in their data centre expansion plans.
Dell’s embrace of AMD for corporate PCs is another blow for Intel as the company struggles to hang on to its eroding dominance over chips for PCs.

site_title: Crypto firm Bitdeer prioritises mining to weather tariff turmoil
summary: Bitdeer Technologies Group, a Singapore-based Bitcoin mining firm, is prioritizing self-mining operations amid a cooling crypto market and US trade policy uncertainty. The company will focus on using its rigs to mine Bitcoin for itself, rather than selling them to other miners, due to faltering demand and disrupted supply chains caused by US President Donald Trump's tariff programme. Bitdeer plans to take advantage of a 90-day tariff pause to ship rigs to the US and is also preparing to launch US-based manufacturing in the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: Crypto has been said to be a potential challenger to the yellow metal’s role as a store of value, but US President Donald Trump’s tariffs are highlighting their key differences.
The divergence is a departure from the long-time correlation between Bitcoin and stocks, in which the digital asset typically experiences larger price swings.
Virtually every global financial hub vies to be crypto’s capital. But the writer asks: can you stomach the volatility?
Beijing-based Bitmain Technologies, by far the largest manufacturer of Bitcoin mining equipment, has production lines in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.
Coinbase's exchange draws revenue not only from Bitcoin, but also from alternative tokens like Ether that have sold off even faster.
The agreement marks a major step forward for Tether in its plan to become a major Bitcoin miner.

site_title: BT Luxe Spring: Of hospitality and time
summary: Three independent hoteliers, Rene Vijay Shrestha Einhaus, John Lim, and Sean Lim, are featured in BT Luxe Spring. Einhaus runs a luxury resort in Kathmandu, while Lim, a former scientist, built a hotel in Chiang Mai despite having no hospitality experience. The youngest hotelier, Sean Lim, shares his journey from dishwasher to co-owner of a hotel-residence complex in Penang. The article also highlights other hoteliers, including Chan Soo Khian, and showcases various travel destinations and luxury watch launches.

images.alt_text: Siam Motors Group's scion Pranai Phornprapha, CEO of Kaleido Lifestyle, is boldly innovating Thai food and beverages.

site_title: GE2025: Singapore set to go to the polls on May 3, after Nomination Day on Apr 23
summary: Singapore is set to go to the polls on May 3 for the 2025 general election, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's first electoral outing since taking office last year. Nomination Day is on Apr 23, and the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced over 30 new candidates, the largest slate in recent history. The opposition Workers' Party and Progress Singapore Party have also announced their candidates, with the Workers' Party focusing on unity in diversity and the Progress Singapore Party on addressing pressing concerns such as rising costs and income inequality.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Nomination Day and Polling Day shall be held within three months after Apr 15, President Tharman said in a notice in a Government Gazette that was published at 3pm.
This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

Singapore election 2025: GE2025 could feature several new GRCs and Single Member Constituencies (SMC) due to population shifts and the emergence of new estates since the last boundary delineation exercise.

site_title: New private home sales creep up in March; record number of ECs sold for S$2 million or more
summary: Singapore private home sales rose 1.5% in March to 729 units, driven by strong demand for executive condominiums (ECs) and new launches. ECs sold for at least S$2 million reached a record 162 units, surpassing the previous peak in August 2023. This brought the total number of unsold ECs to around 70 units. The majority of EC sales were at Aurelle of Tampines, with 148 units sold at over S$1,800 psf. The number of private homes sold in the first quarter reached 3,400 units, the highest since 2021.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
One Marina Gardens is the first residential development in Marina South.
Some five projects in Singapore's Core Central Region, yielding over 2,500 private homes, are expected to launch in the remainder of 2025.
The three sites were launched under the confirmed list.

site_title: Be long-term overweight on Singapore equities and property as the US’ tailwind becomes a headwind
summary: Singapore is poised for long-term economic growth despite the US' shift towards protectionism, driven by President Trump's "Make America Great Again" agenda. The country's pragmatic policymaking and strong ties with the US and China will help it navigate the challenges. Singapore's exceptionalism, strategic location, fiscal strength, and strong education system will make it an attractive destination for investors, boosting its growth as a wealth management centre. The country's property and equities markets are expected to perform well, making it a good bet for investors looking to diversify their dollar-denominated investments.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.

site_title: GE2025: WP kickstarts campaign with slogan ‘Working for Singapore’
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has launched its campaign for the 2025 Singapore general election with the slogan "Working for Singapore." The party, led by Pritam Singh, released a teaser video featuring its eight elected MPs, highlighting the need for balance in the political system and the importance of diverse voices in Parliament. WP is expected to field a large slate of candidates, with at least 30 candidates in eight constituencies and 17 new faces. The party aims to win one-third of the seats in Parliament, building on its success in the 2020 general election where it won 10 seats.

images.alt_text: (From left) Claressa Monteiro, Prof Walid Jumblatt Bin Abdullah and Dr Gillian Koh break down the unique traits of Singapore’s electoral system.
