site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 15)
summary: Singapore is set to hold its general election on May 3, with Nomination Day scheduled for Apr 23. New private home sales increased 1.5% in March, and 729 units were sold. Automotive group Vin's Holdings debuted higher on the SGX, while alleged nickel fraudster Ng Yu Zhi purchased luxury cars for his girlfriend. Frasers Property saw senior management changes amid industry challenges. The Straits Times Index rallied 2.1% on Tuesday, and Singapore ranked as the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

site_title: Gold hits record high on economic growth concerns
summary: Gold prices hit a record high, reaching US$3,266.65 per ounce, due to a weaker US dollar, trade war tensions, and concerns over global economic growth. The US dollar index eased 0.3% against rivals, making gold more attractive. Investors expect US retail sales data for insights into the economy and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy plans. Analysts predict gold will remain strong due to increasing recession risks, geopolitical uncertainty, and supply chain disruptions, with forecasts set at US$3,600 per ounce by year-end and US$3,500 per ounce for the next six months.

images.alt_text: Non-yielding gold, a traditional hedge against global uncertainties and inflation, also tends to thrive in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon returns on Dec 6-7 with new format
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon (SCSM) is returning on Dec 6-7 with a new format, featuring separate half-marathon and marathon days for the first time. The event, which attracted over 55,000 runners in 2024, aims to improve the overall race experience and allow more runners to participate. The new format, which will be held over two days, is expected to increase participation, with 31% and 46% growth in marathon and half-marathon categories, respectively, from 2022 to 2024.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Thousands of runners of the Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon taking off at the start line of the Marathon category on Dec 1, 2024.
Over 12,000 runners from 400 companies took part in this year's Corporate Challenge.

site_title: SIA, Scoot passenger traffic down 0.8% in March on Easter holiday shift
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its low-cost arm Scoot reported a 0.8% year-on-year drop in combined passenger traffic in March, despite a 2.7% growth in passenger capacity. The two airlines carried 3.3 million passengers, with Scoot's passenger traffic falling 5.5% and SIA's increasing 0.5%. The group's cargo carriage increased by 7.6% year-on-year, while its passenger load factor was 84.7%, down 3 percentage points on the year.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Cargo carriage, the weight of cargo and mail carried, was up 2.6 per cent year on year, largely due to increased cargo flow within East Asia, the group noted.
The airline aims to maintain its strong performance in passenger numbers by expanding and optimising routes said its CEO, Leslie Thng.
Elite frequent flyers get to enjoy airport lounge before their flight.

site_title: Seven steps to invest more safely amid tariff turmoil
summary: The article advises investors to take a cautious approach amid tariff turmoil by focusing on buying stocks of great businesses with growth catalysts at good value points. This can help mitigate risk. The current market volatility, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 17% from its peak, presents a potential buying opportunity. However, there is no simple answer to this question, and investors should consider their own risk tolerance and investment goals before proceeding.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms' stock fell from US$187 per share in March 2022 to US$88 in November 2022. Today it is trading at above US$265. By investing between March and November 2022, investors would have made substantial gains even if they missed the lowest entry price.
DeepSeek's competitive pricing a critical question - is massive spending the only path to AI supremacy?

site_title: Harvard hit with US$2.2 billion freeze after defying Trump
summary: The US government has frozen $2.2 billion in federal grants to Harvard University after the school refused to agree to government demands to address antisemitism on campus. The Trump administration had previously threatened to pull funding from the nation's elite colleges, and Harvard's president Alan Garber stated that the school would not "surrender its independence or constitutional rights." The demands included reforms to governance, diversity programs, and admissions, which the school deemed unacceptable. Harvard has agreed to work with the administration to combat antisemitism, but the school's defiance has reinforced concerns about federal investment and civil rights laws.

images.alt_text: A shortage of global AI talent is becoming a bottleneck as industries and enterprises speed up adoption of artificial intelligence.

Harvard president Claudine Gay resigned from her post after she was accused of plagiarism and for her widely criticised testimony about antisemitism at the college at a congressional hearing in December.

site_title: Singapore shares and STI continue to rally on Tuesday, tracking regional indices
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.1% on Tuesday, tracking regional indices, with 1.2 billion shares worth S$1.4 billion traded. The STI closed at 3,624.72. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also gained, while Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust was the top gainer. Optimism is rising ahead of the US retail sales report, with investors buying tech, treasuries, and commodities, driven by the White House's softer stance on electronic imports from China.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Food processing company Wilmar International maintained its innocence in a 2022 corruption case  revolving around the approval of export permits that did not meet requirements.

site_title: Can emerging markets thrive in ‘Trumplandia’?
summary: Emerging markets (EMs) face uncertainty in the US-led "Trumplandia," with the Trump administration's tariffs and trade policies threatening global growth. However, some EMs, such as India, Brazil, and Turkey, have the potential to thrive by diversifying trade and financial flows. Countries with cheaper labor and less integration into existing supply chains may fare better, while smaller, highly indebted countries risk higher vulnerabilities. Despite the uncertainty, EM debt has performed relatively well, and yields remain attractive, particularly for high-quality issuers.

images.alt_text: Cars waiting to be loaded onto a ship for export in Lianyungang. China has the fiscal capacity to cushion the blow from tariffs and is pivoting towards domestic demand as a primary growth driver.
"Made in China" labels on packages at an Amazon Fulfillment center in New Jersey. Photographer: Bing Guan/Bloomberg
Prabowo’s government is in the middle of negotiating a reversal to US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes, which could have major ramifications on the economy.

site_title: UOB, Wee Foundation commit S$110 million to NTU for new educational initiatives
summary: UOB and the Wee Foundation have committed S$110 million to Nanyang Technological University (NTU) for new educational initiatives. The funding supports up to 1,200 NTU students and 1,500 individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds. The initiatives include the NTU Opportunity Grant, Uplift@NTU, and the NTU Venture Creation Programme, aiming to foster a spirit of giving back to the community through projects and services that benefit the community. The combined donation will provide up to S$275 million to the university, supporting education and research advancement.

images.alt_text: Sajida Khatun (2nd from left) from Bartley Secondary School with her teammates. The group came up with the idea of Ching Ching Bank, which allows consumers to compartmentalise their spending..

site_title: Alibaba-backed AI startup Zhipu targets IPO as soon as 2025
summary: Zhipu, a Chinese AI startup backed by Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings, is targeting an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as 2025. The six-year-old firm has enlisted China International Capital Corporation to spearhead the debut and could formally apply to list by October. Zhipu aims to become the first of several prominent ChatGPT-competitors to tap public markets, following the emergence of DeepSeek, a low-cost AI model that has disrupted the market.

images.alt_text: Duality is developing therapeutic drugs for cancer and autoimmune disease patients, its prospectus shows.
Chagee is proceeding with an IPO amid an escalating trade war between the US and China, with both sides imposing steep levies on each others’ goods.

site_title: China’s Duality Biotherapeutics shares rise 130% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Duality Biotherapeutics' Hong Kong debut saw its stock rise 130.4% to HK$218, more than doubling, after raising $213 million in an initial public offering (IPO). The majority of its products are unlikely to be subject to US import tariffs due to licensing agreements, contributing to the stock's popularity. The IPO attracted 11 cornerstone investors, strong interest from retail and institutional investors, and is seen as a positive sign for international investors returning to China amidst market volatility.

images.alt_text: The approval comes weeks after China’s securities regulator cleared CATL’s plans for the Hong Kong listing.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index plunged 13 per cent on Monday (Apr 7), the most since 1997, triggering forced selling.

site_title: Global real estate recovery to speed up growth in MSCI’s private-market indices
summary: MSCI forecasts global real estate recovery to drive growth in its private-market indices, with Savills predicting a 27% increase in global real estate investments to $952 billion in 2025. The company expects its private-markets business to grow by high-teens percent annually for the next few years. MSCI is also capitalizing on the growing appetite for private markets, with institutional investors increasing allocations to private assets. However, the private markets business still lags behind the public assets segment in terms of earnings contribution, with a "couple of decades" expected before they match.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck

An electronic board shows the Nikkei 225. CEOs of asset managers in Europe or the US would find Asia to be the region to generate marginal investment and revenue, says Bill Maldonado, CEO of Eastspring Investments.

site_title: Star Entertainment posts loss, says revenue continues to fall
summary: Star Entertainment Group posted a A$136 million loss in the first half of the year, with revenue falling 25% to A$650 million. The company's shares have been suspended since February due to unmet accounting deadlines. Trading conditions continue to deteriorate, with cash limits at its Sydney complex and challenging conditions at its Gold Coast casino. Star needs to complete a A$300 million funding deal with Bally's and finalize several other deals to avoid material uncertainty about its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Nike set to build out new Shanghai studio in China push
summary: Nike is opening a new creative studio in Shanghai, China, as part of its efforts to get closer to Chinese shoppers and recapture a significant portion of the market's annual revenue of $7.5 billion. The in-house production division, Icon Studios, will produce content including digital videos, product photography, and e-commerce projects. This move follows recent investments in China, including a technology centre in Shenzhen and a sports research lab in Shanghai. The new studio will be led by former Apple marketing executive Jason King, with plans to add around 20 new employees.

images.alt_text: Nike works with over 100 apparel factories, footwear plants and equipment makers in Vietnam, the company has disclosed.
The Adidas Samba has been the hottest sneakers for the past couple of years.
Nike is in the midst of clearing out stale inventory through heavy discounting, a consequence of fading demand for some of its biggest sneaker franchises, including Air Force 1s and Dunks.
Nike is attempting to end a sales slump after a tumultuous year of corporate layoffs and the CEO change.

site_title: GE2025: Parliament dissolved, Nomination Day on Apr 23; Polling Day set for May 3
summary: Singapore's Parliament was dissolved on Apr 15, 2025, with the Writ of Election issued shortly after. Nomination Day is set for Apr 23, and Polling Day will be on May 3 if multiple candidates are nominated. The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced over 30 new candidates, while the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee has recommended widespread changes to electoral boundaries. The general election, GE2025, is expected to feature significant changes, including the introduction of new GRCs and a larger slate of new candidates.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

Speaking at an evening dialogue with Indian youth that was organised by Tamil Murasu at Huone Singapore, PM Wong acknowledged the community’s outsized contributions to Singapore in areas from business to government, and promised that new PAP candidates in the upcoming general election will include those from the Indian community.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong taking a wefie with young people. In a social media on Apr 13, he addressed Gen Z voters directly, affirming their wish for change.

Singapore election 2025: GE2025 could feature several new GRCs and Single Member Constituencies (SMC) due to population shifts and the emergence of new estates since the last boundary delineation exercise.

site_title: Malaysia telco U Mobile to partner with China’s Huawei and ZTE for 5G network
summary: Malaysia's U Mobile has partnered with Huawei and ZTE to roll out the country's second 5G network, following a government contract secured last month. The deal will see Huawei handle 5G networks in Peninsular Malaysia and ZTE oversee East Malaysia. The selection of Huawei and ZTE was based on their "proven global deployment track record," according to U Mobile chairman Vincent Tan. The move aims to balance Western and Eastern technology, despite security concerns from some Western countries.

site_title: New Zealand central banker says inflation hit from higher tariffs ‘more ambiguous’
summary: New Zealand central banker Paul Conway warns of ambiguous inflation impacts from higher tariffs, citing downside risks to growth and inflation. The US' on-off import tariffs have led to global market volatility and recession concerns. Conway also announces the launch of KiwiGDP, a live GDP growth nowcast, to address the challenges of quarterly GDP data revisions. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand may lower interest rates if necessary, depending on the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ may need to take the OCR below the 3 per cent floor it signalled in February as US President Donald Trump’s tariffs threaten to damp global growth and sap demand for New Zealand exports.
The central bank is expected to cut interest rates on Wednesday.
The RBNZ has reduced the Official Cash Rate by 175 basis points since August to 3.75 per cent, and is expected to deliver another cut to 3.5 per cent next week.
Risks to growth this year have risen as US President Donald Trump’s policies have raised fears about a broader economic downturn globally.

site_title: China’s sea cargo flow starts to slow after tariffs take effect
summary: China's sea cargo volume slowed last week, dropping 10% from a week earlier and 4% from the same period in 2024, according to Ministry of Transport data. This marks the first decline since the Chinese New Year holiday. The decline is attributed to the new US tariffs on Chinese goods, which prompted China to retaliate. Despite some exemptions, hundreds of billions of US dollars in Chinese goods will still face a 145% tariff if shipped to the US, potentially undercutting export value.

site_title: Nomura scales back China wealth unit, seeks new securities CEO
summary: Nomura Holdings has scaled back its China wealth unit, trimming staffing by about two-thirds over the past two years, in an effort to focus on brokerage and asset management. The move comes as the venture struggles to revive performance after posting consecutive years of losses since 2019. A new CEO is being sought for the securities business, which will prioritize asset management and research, and invest in sales and trading. The entity's losses narrowed to 184.5 million yuan in 2023, but it had previously targeted raising its headcount to 500 by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: Nomura has been on the hunt for new offices in Manhattan with plans to downsize its footprint.

Japan’s financial institutions have sought to develop their asset and wealth management businesses to generate income from the mammoth savings held by Japanese households, of which around half is currently held in cash and deposits.
Nomura says it will stick to its target set four years ago, to deploy US$125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026.
Nomura is making a big push in private banking as part of its efforts to diversify revenue beyond investment banking and global markets.

site_title: Vin’s Holdings closes 16.6% above IPO price in SGX’s first listing of 2025
summary: Vin's Holdings, a Singaporean automotive group, listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 15, 2025, raising S$4 million. The company's shares opened at S$0.315 and closed at S$0.35, a 16.6% gain above the IPO price. The funds will be used to enhance IT and services, showroom expansions, and after-sales services. The company also plans to distribute 75% of its FY2024 net profit to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Singaporean automotive group Vin's Holdings seeks a Catalist IPO on Apr 15, 2025.
Vin's Holdings is expected to on SGX Catalist board on Apr 15, with a market capitalisation of S$39.3 million
Car dealer, candy maker could be first listings on SGX this year

site_title: Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan lead US$16.5 billion bank borrowing spree
summary: Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, two of the largest US banks, are raising a combined $16.5 billion in new debt, with Morgan Stanley offering $8 billion and JPMorgan selling $6 billion. The banks reported record equity trading revenue in the first quarter and are capitalizing on a sense of calm in risk assets to sell new debt. The moves come as companies prepare for a potentially weaker economic environment, with some analysts predicting $32 billion of new issuance from the biggest banks post-earnings.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings’s market value has dropped by almost US$30 billion on fears that its Asia-focused operations will bear the brunt of the conflict.

Morgan Stanley is the latest global asset manager to set its sights on Japanese real estate, an asset class that has come back into favour after years of stop-start economic growth, flat wages and zero inflation.
Chinese stocks have gained momentum this year, with the MSCI China Index rising about 16 per cent so far, outperforming global peers.
Morgan Stanley’s cuts add to a series of workforce reductions across Wall Street as bosses navigate an uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: Prompt payments by Singapore companies up in Q1, but credit bureau urges vigilance
summary: Singapore companies made 41.18% of prompt payments in the first quarter of 2025, up 0.11 percentage points from the previous year. Partial payments decreased by 0.02 percentage points to 14.78%, while slow payments rose by 0.01 percentage points to 44.04%. The construction, manufacturing, and wholesale trade sectors saw increases in slow payments, while the retail and services sectors experienced improvements. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau urged vigilance in ensuring healthy cash flows amidst global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Slow payments inch up 0.1 percentage point to 44.1 per cent in Q4, from 44 per cent in Q3.

site_title: Trump administration sued over tariffs in US Court of International Trade
summary: The US Court of International Trade has been asked to block President Donald Trump's tariffs on foreign trading partners, arguing the president overstepped his authority. The lawsuit, filed by a nonpartisan advocacy group, challenges the "Liberation Day" tariffs and duties imposed against China, citing the Constitution's power to set tax rates as belonging to Congress, not the President. The Trump administration faces a similar lawsuit in Florida federal court.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s algorithm is one of the main driving forces behind US government efforts to force its Chinese owner, ByteDance, to relinquish control of its international operations.
Pharmaceuticals and semiconductors are exempt from those duties, but Trump has said they will face separate tariffs.
Assuming that the trade war sees no near-term improvements, Singapore’s economy may contract again sequentially in Q2, after it shrank 0.8% in Q1, based on advance estimates.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, ICP
summary: Wilmar International maintained its innocence in a 2022 corruption case after four judges who cleared it were reportedly arrested. The company stated its actions were intended to increase palm oil supply and reduce prices. ICP requested a trading halt on Tuesday pending an announcement. The Singapore stock market rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: SIA investing S$45 million to spiff up SilverKris, KrisFlyer Gold lounges at Changi Airport T2
summary: Singapore Airlines is investing S$45 million to upgrade its SilverKris and KrisFlyer Gold lounges at Changi Airport Terminal 2. The upgrades, set to be completed by mid-2027, will feature expanded spaces, new amenities, and enhanced dining experiences. The first-class SilverKris lounge will offer more space and live cooking stations, while the business class lounge will include a larger rest area and full-service bar. The KrisFlyer Gold lounge will double in capacity and introduce in-lounge restrooms and shower suites. The upgrades aim to elevate the end-to-end travel experience for discerning customers.

images.alt_text: Travellers at Jewel Changi Airport. Singapore's Changi Airport has been named the World’s Best Airport 2025 at the World Airport Awards.

site_title: China gets worst 2025 growth forecast yet with downgrade by UBS
summary: UBS has downgraded its growth forecast for China to 3.4% in 2025, the lowest among major banks, citing the impact of US tariffs on exports. Exports to the US are expected to fall by two-thirds, and total overseas shipments may drop by 10% in US dollar terms this year. The bank expects China's GDP to be dragged down by more than two percentage points despite additional stimulus from the government. Analysts predict a prolonged tariff shock will set forth major adjustments in the domestic economy.

images.alt_text: Retail sales are predicted to have increased 4.3 per cent in March from a year ago.
The export surge supported the economy in the first quarter, but that boost may dissipate after the US threw global trade into chaos.
The Citi economists expect more US tariff rollbacks could emerge due to supply chain disruption, inflationary pressure, American business interests.
China has also vowed to boost domestic consumption as tariffs threaten exports, which contributed to nearly a third of the country’s economic expansion in 2024. T

site_title: Movie and TV filming in Los Angeles tumbles 22%
summary: Movie and TV filming in Los Angeles declined 22% in the first quarter, with TV production falling 31% and feature film production down 29%, according to FilmLA. The decline reflects a worldwide slump and California's loss of business to other areas. This marks a significant decrease from 2021, when TV production peaked at 18,560 annual shoot days. The industry has suffered from multiple setbacks, including Covid-19 shutdowns and labour disputes, leading major media companies to cut production and jobs to boost profitability.

images.alt_text: The Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said films released in 2027 will be eligible for an Oscar for Achievement in Stunt Design.

site_title: GE2025: PAP new faces Cassandra Lee, Hamid Razak to contest West Coast-Jurong West GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its team for the West Coast-Jurong West Group Representation Constituency (GRC) for the 2025 general election. Led by Minister for National Development Desmond Lee, the five-member team includes lawyer Cassandra Lee and orthopaedic surgeon Hamid Razak. The team will contest the newly formed GRC, which combines most of West Coast GRC with estates from Jurong GRC. The PAP aims to address housing concerns, with Desmond Lee highlighting increased supply and initiatives to support first-time young couples. The team will face competition from the Progress Singapore Party (PSP).

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
National Development Minister Desmond Lee and trade unionist Natasha Choy at an event held in Jalan Mas Kuning on April 2.
Progress Singapore Party NCMP Leong Mun Wai will take over as party chief from Ms Hazel Poa, who will be the party's vice-chair.

site_title: Opec cuts 2025 oil demand forecast over US tariffs
summary: OPEC has lowered its 2025 oil demand forecast, citing the impact of US tariffs on the global economy. The organization now expects demand to grow by 1.3 million barrels per day, down from a previous forecast of 1.4 million bpd. Global demand is forecasted to reach 105.05 million bpd this year. The slight adjustment was due to first-quarter data and the expected impact of US tariffs, which also led to a slight lowering of global economic growth forecast to 3%.

images.alt_text: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell US$2.28, or 3.7 per cent, to settle at US$60.07 per barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Australia central bank to reconsider policy at May meeting, move not predetermined
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is considering cutting interest rates at its May meeting, contrary to market expectations, due to global uncertainty over US tariffs. The board judged it premature to cut rates in response to US President Donald Trump's tariff plans, but will reassess the outlook at the May meeting. The RBA's cash rate is currently 4.1% and is expected to be cut by a quarter point, matching a first easing in February, if data shows core inflation slowed back into the target band of 2-3%.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of Australia governor Michelle Bullock speaks during a news conference at the bank’s head office in Sydney, Australia, April 1, 2025.
The Aussie has risen 1.3 per cent this year after declining almost 10 per cent in 2024.
RBA Governor Michele Bullock (pictured) and her deputy Andrew Hauser have both said in recent weeks that the bank does not believe a series of rate cuts will be required.

site_title: What might it mean for the PAP to affirm the younger generation’s desire for change?
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong addressed Gen Z voters directly in a social media video, affirming their desire for change and acknowledging their high standards. Born between 1997 and the early 2010s, Gen Z voters are seen as having a new desire to not settle for the status quo, and PM Wong expressed a wish to work with them to improve the country. The video comes ahead of the 2025 general election, which will be the first for many Gen Z voters and PM Wong's first as prime minister.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

Speaking at an evening dialogue with Indian youth that was organised by Tamil Murasu at Huone Singapore, PM Wong acknowledged the community’s outsized contributions to Singapore in areas from business to government, and promised that new PAP candidates in the upcoming general election will include those from the Indian community.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's TikTok account has helped him reach out to a younger generation of Singaporeans.

site_title: Income Insurance: From unmet needs to thriving ecosystem
summary: Income Insurance, a leading composite insurer in Singapore, has transformed into a digital ecosystem pioneer by identifying and catering to overlooked customers. The company uses collaborative partnerships and data-driven strategies to create "ecosystems" that fulfill diverse consumer needs. By targeting gig workers, digital-first consumers, and underserved populations, Income Insurance has grown its business and expanded its reach. Its ecosystem strategy has also attracted partnerships with tech giants and global insurers, enabling the company to deliver agile, hyper-personalised solutions. Income Insurance's approach shows that companies that convert overlooked opportunities into scalable growth can thrive in disruption and define the future of their industries.

images.alt_text: Income should put aside hunt for a strategic partner, and focus on an organic growth plan
Income Insurance has a special place in Singaporeans' hearts. This is evident in the outcry that Allianz's offer for Income and its proposed capital reduction plan evoked.

site_title: A ransomware attack hit a vendor to DBS. What is a ransomware attack and how does it affect companies?
summary: A ransomware attack on a printing vendor hit DBS and Bank of China's Singapore branch, compromising customer data from 8,200 DBS customers and 3,000 BOC customers. DBS and BOC reported no login information was stolen. The attack is part of Singapore's 21 million cyberattacks in 2024, making it the country's top victim. Ransomware can be spread through social engineering, zero-day vulnerabilities, or brute force hacking, and its impact can be devastating, including data exfiltration, reputational damage, and regulatory fines. Companies are advised to adopt a layered cybersecurity approach and follow international standards to mitigate such threats.

images.alt_text: DBS says its systems are not compromised by the ransomware attack and that customers’ deposit and monies “remain safe”.

site_title: Singapore kicks off points-based relief scheme for eligible jobless
summary: Singapore has launched the SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme, offering up to S$6,000 over six months to eligible jobless individuals aged 21 and above with an average monthly salary of no more than S$5,000. Jobseekers must score activity points by participating in 13 qualifying activities, such as registering with an employment agency or attending a course listed on MySkillsFuture. The points-based system is flexible, allowing jobseekers to choose their own activities. The scheme will be extended to permanent residents starting from the first quarter of 2026, and applicants can apply online or receive help from various centers.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
To receive support under the new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, workers must go for training, career coaching and job-matching services.
The qualifying job activities were “carefully curated” based on research with jobseekers, said Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon.
The SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme marks a "paradigm shift" for the government, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng said during a visit to the Employment and Employability Institute on Aug 27.

site_title: China suppliers mock tariffs with Nike, Lululemon deals on TikTok
summary: US TikTok users are being encouraged to buy directly from Chinese suppliers to circumvent punitive Trump tariffs, with influencers sharing videos of factories supposedly supplying top brands like Lululemon and Nike. The videos claim to expose the low prices and quality of goods made in China, with some creators providing website URLs and contact details for viewers to order directly. This trend reflects the ongoing global reaction to Trump's tariffs and TikTok's algorithm, which is influencing what information millions of US users see.

images.alt_text: The Citi economists expect more US tariff rollbacks could emerge due to supply chain disruption, inflationary pressure, American business interests.
The tit-for-tat could reduce US-China trade in goods by 80%, the World Trade Organization says.
Given the highly specialised and multi-country nature of chip supply chains, there was uncertainty within the industry about how tariffs would be applied to chip imports.

site_title: CATL reports 33% jump in net income even as battery prices fall
summary: CATL, a Chinese battery maker, reported a 33% jump in first-quarter net income to 14 billion yuan, despite a slowdown in EV demand and falling battery prices. The company's scale allows it to spread costs and deliver efficiencies. CATL is investing in overseas production facilities, including in Germany and Hungary, to localise manufacturing. The company faces geopolitical risks, including US tariffs on Chinese goods, but remains in a comfortable position with a global market share of 38.2%.

images.alt_text: The approval comes weeks after China’s securities regulator cleared CATL’s plans for the Hong Kong listing.
CATL’s listing also comes against the background of rising geopolitical tensions, which may endanger the battery maker’s global expansion.
As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.

site_title: Gold edges higher as markets grapple with tariff uncertainty
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $3,211.49 per ounce, amid uncertainty over US President Trump's tariff plans and their impact on the global economy. Spot silver lost 0.3% and platinum fell 0.3% as well, while palladium eased 0.6%. Traders expect around 86 basis points of interest rate cuts by the end of 2025, while investment flows into Chinese gold exchange-traded funds exceeded those for US-listed funds this month. The Trump administration is set to announce tariff rates on imported semiconductors, keeping markets on edge.

images.alt_text: Non-yielding gold, a traditional hedge against global uncertainties and inflation, also tends to thrive in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Indonesia research startup Populix raises US$4.3 million in Series B funding
summary: Indonesia-based research startup Populix has raised US$4.3 million in its first close of Series B funding, led by MSW V Asia Fund X and existing investors. The funding will be used to develop and train artificial intelligence models to automate research processes and generate more reliable insights. Despite recent market challenges, Populix has kept growing, doubling the number of projects since last year and expanding its market to Southeast Asia. The company aims to leverage technology to innovate and deliver strategic advantages with unprecedented speed, accuracy, and actionability.

From L-R; Jonathan Benhi, Eileen Kamtawijoyo and Timothy Astandu, founders of Populix

site_title: US: Stocks gain as markets hope trade deals more likely
summary: US stocks rose 0.8% on Monday, driven by conciliatory signs from the Trump administration on trade, including exemptions for key electronics. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 40,524.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. Shares of Apple and US auto companies gained, while Goldman Sachs jumped 1.9% after reporting better earnings. Despite Trump's insistence on no country getting "off the hook" on tariffs, market optimism grew as investors awaited potential trade accords.

images.alt_text: Trader Peter Michael Tuchman reacts as he works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the closing bell in New York City, on April 11, 2025.  (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong’s efforts to attract ultra rich scrutinised by family offices
summary: Hong Kong aims to attract 200 new large family offices by 2025, on top of its existing 2,700, as part of its efforts to position itself as a global gateway for ultra-wealthy individuals. The government is easing capital investment visa rules and offering tax perks to lure family offices. However, controversy over an announced family office launch last year and US President Donald Trump's tariffs pose challenges to Hong Kong's wealthiest families. Family offices praise Hong Kong's lifestyle advantages, collaborative environment, and unique positioning in the global investment landscape, but caution that tax incentives alone are not enough to attract them.

images.alt_text: The increasing number of ultra-high-net-worth families has spurred the need for modernised approaches to wealth management.
A judge upheld a worldwide order to freeze the assets of the employees, who were based in Singapore, along with a British Virgin Islands entity controlled by them.
The changes announced by MAS are still seen as a step in the right direction to boost the local stock market.

site_title: Women’s health supplement brand Moom Health bags S$3.5 million funding
summary: Women's health supplement brand Moom Health secured S$3.5 million in pre-series A funding from investors including Wipro Consumer Care Ventures, DSG Consumer Partners, Racer Ventures, and HPRY Holdings. The funding will be used to invest in product innovation, strengthen supply chains, expand to new markets, and increase digital and retail presence. Moom Health aims to be the "premier supplement brand for women's health in South-east Asia and beyond" with a strong presence in Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong.

site_title: UOBKH says data centres are ‘sheltered’ from reciprocal tariffs, names its top Reit picks
summary: UOB Kay Hian predicts continued growth in demand for data centres over the next five years, driven by the onset of next-generation reasoning AI models and a potential supply shortage. Despite tariff volatility, data centre Reits are expected to perform well, with top picks including Digital Core Reit, Keppel Data Centre Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust, all assigned a "buy" rating. The analyst cites McKinsey data showing global data centre capacity demand will expand by 22% from 2023 to 2030, driven by demand for AI-ready data centres.

site_title: Wilmar maintains innocence after Indonesian judges who acquitted it arrested on corruption charges
summary: Wilmar International maintained its innocence after four judges who acquitted it in a corruption case related to obtaining export permits were reportedly arrested. The company stated it has "zero tolerance for corrupt practices" and was not involved in the bribery scheme. The arrest of judges and court employees follows a court's acquittal of Wilmar and two other palm oil companies in the 2022 case. Prosecutors allege the bribes were paid to secure a favorable verdict, with some $1.07 million paid to the judges.

site_title: GE2025: General election must provide Singapore with a competent govt to lead country in crises, says SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of a capable and effective government in Singapore's next general election. He stated that the government must be united domestically to be effective internationally, and that a competent leadership is necessary to defend Singapore's place in the world and lead the country safely through crises. Lee acknowledged that Singaporeans want more opposition MPs as a stronger check and balance to the PAP, but also emphasized the need for an effective system of government led by a good and capable ruling party. The election comes amid global uncertainties, including an ongoing trade war between the US and China, and rising concerns about the cost of living.

site_title: China’s economy likely grew 5.2% in months before big US tariffs
summary: China's economy is expected to show solid growth for the start of 2025, with a predicted 5.2% expansion in the first quarter, driven by government subsidies, industrial production, and investment. Retail sales are forecast to increase 4.3% in March, while industrial output is expected to maintain a steady pace. However, the US tariffs imposed earlier this month are forecast to hurt China's exports and knock several percentage points off the economy's expansion this year. Policymakers are expected to provide stimulus, possibly through interest rate cuts or reserve requirement ratio adjustments, but this may be too late to boost business and household confidence.

site_title: GE2025: PAP to field unchanged line-up in Holland-Bukit Timah; Liang Eng Hwa to defend Bukit Panjang
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) will contest the upcoming General Election (GE2025) with an unchanged line-up, including Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan in the Holland-Bukit Timah GRC and four-term MP Liang Eng Hwa in the Bukit Panjang SMC. The PAP team in Holland-Bukit Timah remains unchanged, with a focus on experience and youth, while Liang will defend the single seat against the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP). The election is seen as a critical test for the PAP to boost its ranks of 4G leaders and prepare for the challenges of a changing world.

site_title: GE2025: From policymaker to politician – PAP new face Jeffrey Siow wants to take public service ‘to the last mile’
summary: Jeffrey Siow, a former second permanent secretary for the Ministry of Manpower and the Ministry of Trade and Industry, is joining the People's Action Party (PAP) team for Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituency. He aims to extend public service to the last mile, bringing government policies closer to individuals. Siow believes that foreign workers are necessary to complement Singaporeans in talent and numbers, but acknowledges concerns about job security and population density. He emphasizes the need to create good jobs, increase housing, and improve public transport to alleviate anxiety about the city-state's future.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

(Clockwise from top left) Mr Jeffrey Siow, Mr Dinesh Vasu Dash, Ms Jasmin Lau, Mr Shawn Loh, Ms Goh Hanyan and Mr Foo Cexiang.
Jeffrey Siow is the fourth and most senior civil servant to resign ahead of the upcoming general election.

site_title: Tariffs, tensions and turbulence – it’s not business as usual
summary: US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on "Liberation Day" has sent financial markets into turmoil, upending long-standing trade relations among major trading nations. The proposed tariffs could lead to stagflation, with US gross domestic product growth forecasts lowered from 2.2% to 1.5%. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are watching for clarity before considering interest rate shifts. Export-oriented Asia is caught in the crosshairs of the US-China contest for economic hegemony, with some countries facing tariffs of up to 46%. Long-term investors are advised to stick to a long-term investment horizon and diversify risk-aware portfolios.

images.alt_text: Assuming that the trade war sees no near-term improvements, Singapore’s economy may contract again sequentially in Q2, after it shrank 0.8% in Q1, based on advance estimates.
Elon Musk has continually expressed his dissatisfaction with the White House's trade policy.
Bridgewater Associates founder Ray Dalio said that US President Donald Trump's trade war has been “very disruptive” and the tariffs’ impact was “like throwing rocks into the production system.”

site_title: Singaporean households to get S$500 in CDC vouchers from May 13, valid until Dec 31
summary: Singaporean households will receive S$500 in CDC vouchers starting May 13, 2025, to alleviate daily expenses. The vouchers can be used at supermarkets (S$250) and participating hawker stalls and heartland merchants (S$250), valid until Dec 31, 2025. This is the seventh tranche, with another S$300 voucher to be issued in January 2026. Over 1.28 million households (97% of 1.33 million) have claimed the vouchers, with close to S$300 million spent so far.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, on his first visit to Aljunied GRC since taking over Singapore’s top job, with ukulele players at the community event for seniors in Kovan Hub.
PM Wong taking pictures with residents at the Chingay@Heartlands celebration on Feb 22.

site_title: Apple takes top spot for first-quarter smartphone sales, data shows
summary: Apple took the top spot for global smartphone sales in the first quarter with 19% market share, followed by Samsung with 18%. Global smartphone shipments rose 1.5% despite US President Donald Trump's tariffs, with Apple stockpiling units from India to avoid tariffs. Trump's exemption of smartphones from tariffs has provided temporary relief for US companies, but the global tech market remains uncertain due to ongoing tariff volatility.

images.alt_text: Apple, these days, sells about 220 million to 230 million iPhones annually, with about a third of those going to the US.

site_title: UK consumer spending remains strong in boost for growth hopes
summary: UK consumer spending increased by 1.1% year-on-year in March, despite rising household bills, according to the British Retail Consortium and Barclays. The pick-up in spending has raised hopes for economic growth, with a 0.5% GDP growth in February and signs of underlying strengthening of demand. However, US President Donald Trump's global trade war and weak sentiment among businesses threaten to undermine the positive momentum.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Rachel Reeves called the data “encouraging” but markets are far more focused on US President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
The raft of tariffs unveiled by US President Donald Trump boosted expectations that the Bank of England will stick with a once-a-quarter easing pace that only a few weeks ago looked to be in doubt.

Make UK said its gauge of manufacturers’ confidence about the economic outlook over the next 12 months in its quarterly outlook survey dropped to 5.8 in the fourth quarter of 2024 from 6.8 three months earlier.

site_title: OpenAI launches new GPT-4.1 models with improved coding, long context comprehension
summary: OpenAI launched its new GPT-4.1 models, offering improved coding, long context comprehension, and lower costs compared to GPT-4.5. The models outperform GPT-4o and show significant improvements in instruction following and token processing, with the ability to support up to one million tokens. CEO Sam Altman stated that benchmarks are strong, but the focus is on real-world utility, with developers expressing satisfaction. The new models will replace GPT-4.5 preview in the API in July.

images.alt_text: OpenAI faces pressure from investors to change its structure.
Altman has said OpenAI is not for sale, rejected a US$97.4 billion unsolicited takeover bid earlier this year from a Musk-led consortium with a “no thank you”.
Microsoft-backed OpenAI said it looks to deliver increasingly powerful tools for the 500 million people who use ChatGPT every week.
SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman attend an event to pitch AI for businesses in Tokyo, Japan, Feb 3, 2025.

site_title: Malaysia rolls out moves to soften US tariff impact, eyes market diversification: minister
summary: Malaysia is implementing measures to mitigate the impact of US tariffs, including enforcing anti-dumping duties and countervailing taxes to shield domestic industries. The government is also intensifying market diversification efforts, targeting new markets in the Brics grouping, South America, and Africa. Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz stated that Malaysia remains economically stable, but is taking proactive steps to protect its strategic economic interests. The country will not impose reciprocal tariffs on US imports and instead prefers engagement and negotiation to lower tariff rates and broaden exemptions for Malaysian exports.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Trump’s politics is about casting America as a victim and himself as its fearless saviour, prepared to take action nobody else will in order to defeat its “enemies”
China will impose 125 per cent tariffs on US goods from Saturday, up from the 84% previously announced.

In a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting chaired by Malaysia’s Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (middle) has reached an unified voice to ruled out retaliation and pressing for “frank and constructive dialogue” with the United States to address trade-related concerns.
Governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour says Bank Negara expects continued ringgit volatility and that it is ready to curb any excessive fluctuation.

site_title: Trade tensions can lead to stock market crashes, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that trade tensions can trigger large corrections in stock prices, leading to market volatility and potential financial stability threats. Since 2022, news-based measures of risk, including conflicts, wars, and trade restrictions, have increased sharply. The IMF urges financial institutions to hold enough capital and liquidity to deal with potential losses from geopolitical risks, citing research that shows significant drops in stock prices following major risk events, such as wars and diplomatic tensions.

images.alt_text: The tariffs “clearly represent a significant risk to the global outlook at a time of sluggish growth,” IMF chief  Kristalina Georgieva said in a statement.

site_title: Bruised dollar languishes near three-year lows on tariff anxiety
summary: The US dollar slipped to a three-year low of 99.4 against a basket of currencies on Monday, amid ongoing tariff-related uncertainty from US President Donald Trump. Investors are seeking refuge in other currencies, such as the euro, which rose 0.3% against the dollar. The dollar's weakness is attributed to contradictory statements from the US administration, fueling market uncertainty and causing investors to dump US assets. The euro, yen, and sterling all rose against the dollar, while the New Zealand dollar reached a four-month high.

images.alt_text: The decline in the US dollar comes amid wild swings in stocks.

site_title: LVMH sales fall as shoppers curb spending on luxury goods
summary: LVMH, the luxury goods conglomerate, reported a 5% decline in first-quarter sales, exceeding expectations, due to weak demand in China and the US. The decline was attributed to Chinese shoppers reining in purchases and US tariffs on European imports. The company's American depositary receipts slid 9.4% as investors expressed concerns about underlying demand recovery. LVMH's chief financial officer said the company may consider price increases and adjust marketing costs to offset the impact of the tariffs.

images.alt_text: A series of management reshuffles had fuelled speculation that Bernard Arnault, who has five children, was preparing his succession plans – especially as all of them now have key positions in the conglomerate.
In mainland China, Sephora has incurred millions of US dollars in losses in its efforts to win customers.
Bernard Arnault says 2025 has started relatively well, with Louis Vuitton posting double-digit growth so far this year.

site_title: Elon Musk’s public spat with Trump’s trade tsar points to crack in camp Maga
summary: Elon Musk publicly criticized Peter Navarro, the architect of US President Donald Trump's trade approach, calling him a "moron" and "dumber than a sack of bricks". The spat reflects a potential rift between Trump's trade policies and the libertarian wing of the Maga movement, led by Musk. Navarro's hawkish stance on tariffs has been at odds with some Republicans, including Senator Ted Cruz and Senator Rand Paul, who oppose Trump's tariffs. The controversy has led to Navarro being relegated to the sidelines of the trade team, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick taking on more prominent roles.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s acting President Han Duck-soo had explained in detail South Korea’s stance on tariff negotiations to Trump, and the US president had been satisfied.
In this volatile environment where anti-American, anti-bullying sentiment runs high, it won’t take much for the PBOC to smash the safe-haven status of the US dollar and bonds.
Assuming that the trade war sees no near-term improvements, Singapore’s economy may contract again sequentially in Q2, after it shrank 0.8% in Q1, based on advance estimates.

site_title: Singapore no longer operating in stable external environment; current uncertainty unprecedented: SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that Singapore is no longer operating in a stable external environment due to US-imposed tariffs, which he described as unprecedented and lasting. The tariffs, which include a 10% flat duty on goods from all foreign countries, have disrupted the global financial system and trade. Lee emphasized the need for Singapore to be strong domestically and internationally, citing its stable politics and effective system of government. He also expressed concern about the impact on jobs and growth, predicting a recession and urging the government to devise strategies to address the economic uncertainties.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 14)
summary: Singapore's economy may contract again in Q2, with a 0.8% decline in Q1, unless trade war improvements are seen. The country's official 2025 GDP forecast has been downgraded to 0-2%. Late architect Alfred Wong's bungalow sold for S$45 million, while property tycoon Ong Beng Seng steps down as HPL managing director to manage cancer treatment. Olam invests US$500 million in ofi, aiming to pursue profitable growth. Singapore remains the world's top port for a 12th consecutive year.

site_title: South Korea unveils 33 trillion won support package for chips amid US tariff uncertainty
summary: South Korea has unveiled a 33 trillion won (S$30.6 billion) support package for its semiconductor industry, aiming to help companies cope with increased costs amid US tariff uncertainty. The move comes as the country seeks to boost its key chip makers, Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which face rising competition from Chinese rivals. The package includes financial assistance and tax cuts to support the industry and help expand markets, amid growing policy uncertainty under the current US administration.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a circuit board of a computer in this illustration picture taken February 25, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
South Korea’s acting President Han Duck-soo had explained in detail South Korea’s stance on tariff negotiations to Trump, and the US president had been satisfied.
South Korean Trade Minister Cheong In Kyo (pictured) met US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer about lowering tariff rates slapped on the country.
South Korea’s auto-related exports to the US totalled US$42.9 billion last year, according to officials.

site_title: HPL jumps 5.5% after announcing that Ong Beng Seng will step down as managing director
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) shares rose 5.5% after founder Ong Beng Seng, 79, announced he will step down as managing director due to health reasons, specifically receiving treatment for white blood cell cancer. Ong will relinquish his position and not seek re-election as a director at the company's annual general meeting on April 29. The company has not named a successor, but his departure may alleviate some uncertainty for HPL.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Property tycoon, hotelier and Singapore GP head Ong Beng Seng  at State Courts on Oct 30, 2024. Ong will step down as managing director for Hotel Properties Limited to manage his medical condition.

site_title: Singapore shares and STI close higher on Monday, mirroring regional indices
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1% higher on Monday, mirroring regional indices, after 1.1 billion shares worth S$1.4 billion changed hands. The STI rose 36.38 points to 3,548.91. Major banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also gained, while SGX was the top gainer. The US's tariff rollbacks have boosted market optimism, but recession risks remain elevated.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Olam Group will sell its Olam Agri stake to Saudi Agricultural and Livestock Investment Company for US$2.6 billion over two tranches, with the first tranche set to complete in Q4 of 2025.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, April 14, 2025
summary: Asian stocks rose on news that the US has exempted electronics from its tariffs, boosting sales in the region. Singapore slashed its 2025 growth forecast to 0-2%, citing the impact of Trump tariffs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased its policy slightly, lowering inflation forecasts after the tariffs threatened growth.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.
Tech firms helped push Hong Kong stocks more than two per cent higher on Monday, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei and Manila share were all higher.
Generic photos for Budget 2024
In a Bloomberg survey, all 14 economists forecast that MAS would reduce the S$NEER slope. Meanwhile, nine out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters expected this move.

site_title: US steps up probes into pharmaceutical, chip imports, setting stage for tariffs
summary: The US is conducting probes into pharmaceutical and semiconductor imports as part of a bid to impose tariffs on both sectors, citing national security threats. The investigations, initiated on April 1, will include pharmaceuticals and pharmaceutical ingredients, with separate tariffs planned for both sectors. The move is part of President Trump's economic and national security policies, which have led to a surge in tariffs and economic uncertainty. The probes must be completed within 270 days, and economists predict higher joblessness and inflation as a result.

images.alt_text: Assuming that the trade war sees no near-term improvements, Singapore’s economy may contract again sequentially in Q2, after it shrank 0.8% in Q1, based on advance estimates.
The Citi economists expect more US tariff rollbacks could emerge due to supply chain disruption, inflationary pressure, American business interests.
Trump’s latest exemptions cover almost US$390 billion in US imports based on official US 2024 trade statistics, including more than US$101 billion from China.

site_title: Former Malaysia PM Abdullah Badawi dies aged 85
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi has died at 85, according to his family and medical authorities. He served as the country's fifth prime minister from 2003 to 2009, implementing an anti-corruption drive and promoting a moderate form of Islam. Despite criticism, Badawi's tenure was marked by economic progress. He died peacefully at the National Heart Institute in Kuala Lumpur on April 14, 2025, after experiencing breathing difficulties.

site_title: Thailand finalises US trade strategy ahead of talks next week
summary: Thailand finalizes its US trade strategy ahead of talks next week, aiming to secure relief from a planned 36% reciprocal tariff on its goods. The country's trade surplus with the US more than doubled to $46 billion last year, with officials pledging to cut the surplus and step up imports of US farm goods. Thailand's negotiation stance will be based on a strategy approved by Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, with a focus on creating a trade balance and strengthening a sustainable economic partnership.

images.alt_text: “As the situation changes, we have to adjust,” Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira says.
Property developers in the greater Bangkok area were saddled with about 235,000 unsold residential units at the end of last year, the most since data dating back to 2018.

Stock Exchange of Thailand said that the ban on short selling of all securities, except for market makers, and a narrower band for stock movements will be effective from Tuesday (Apr 8) and no longer than Apr 11.

site_title: Oil rises marginally on tariff exemption, Chinese crude imports
summary: Oil prices rose marginally on Monday, with Brent crude futures closing 12 US cents higher at US$64.88 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settling 3 US cents higher at US$61.53. The gains were driven by exemptions for some electronics from US tariffs and a sharp rebound in China's crude imports in March. However, concerns about the trade war weakening global economic growth and fuel demand limited gains. Oil demand forecasts were also revised downward, with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) cutting its global demand forecast due to US tariffs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) during the United Nations climate change conference COP29, in Baku, Azerbaijan November 13, 2024. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov/File Photo
There were volatile price swings this week as US President Donald Trump’s new tariff regime forced traders to reassess the geopolitical risks facing the crude market.

site_title: Great Eastern chairman declines to speculate on potential delisting at AGM
summary: Great Eastern Holdings chairman Soon Tit Koon declined to speculate on the potential delisting of the insurer, citing ongoing discussions with its financial adviser to explore options for complying with the Singapore Exchange's free-float requirements. Shareholders expressed dissatisfaction with the offer of S$25.60 per share, citing a 30% discount to the insurer's embedded value per share. The re-election of OCBC's CEO Helen Wong to the GEH board was also debated, with some shareholders citing potential conflicts of interest and integrity concerns. The board assured shareholders that GEH is working towards meeting the deadline to explore options and maintain its solvency position.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Starting in April, claim limits for Medishield Life will be increased, and coverage will also be expanded to include additional outpatient treatments and new therapies.
Helen Wong says: “We know a balanced portfolio can help us to overcome, in particular, the uncertainty and the volatility in the market over the next decade.”
The insurer's total weighted new sales in Q4 fell 16% to S$432.7 million from S$514.1 million.

site_title: These China sectors and stocks are bucking the trend amid market volatility
summary: China stocks bucked the trend of global market volatility, with the Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Shenzhen CSI 300 Index rising 2.2% and 2.7% respectively last week. The tech sector led the gains, with Xiaomi, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, and Sunny Optical surging 4.6%, 23%, and 18.3% week to date. The consumer staples and healthcare sectors also performed well, with gains of 3.6% and 3.6% week to date. China's state-backed funds plan to buy local stocks, and companies have announced share buybacks to support the market.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Fixed income funds has seen more interest from investors of late, though some analyst believe some Asian equities are up and coming.

site_title: Too many cooks: Singapore’s F&B sector at risk of oversupply as openings outpace closures
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector is at risk of oversupply due to a surge in new openings outpacing closures. In 2024, 3,047 F&B businesses closed, while 3,793 new brands entered the market. Knight Frank suggests regulatory controls, such as limiting licences and capping shop sizes, may be needed to stabilize the market. The consultancy warns that the sector's high churn and rapid expansion could lead to financial losses for operators and diners, and that measures should be taken to ensure sustainability for local and international brands.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Benjamin Boh, managing director of Mcdonald’s Singapore, has been appointed the new president of the Restaurant Association of Singapore.
Sushi Oshino will be rebranded as Sushi Ishizawa after chef-owner Koichiro Oshino decided to leave after the restaurant lease expired.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.

site_title: Temasek-backed ABC Impact finishes final close of second fund with more than US$600 million
summary: ABC Impact, backed by Temasek, has completed the final close of its second fund at over US$600 million, doubling the size of its first fund. The fund, launched in August 2023, focuses on sectors like clean energy, climate resilience, and healthcare, and has received support from investors including Temasek Trust, Asian Development Bank, and ultra-high-net-worth individuals. The fund's investments have included companies in India, Japan, and the US, aiming to shape a more sustainable and inclusive future in Asia.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
GIC says that the fresh funds will help Novotech pursue organic growth, as well as merger and acquisition opportunities.
65 Equity manages about US$3.3 billion and typically writes cheques of US$50 million to US$150 million to back family-owned and founder-led companies.
The fund receives support from existing investors such as Temasek and Temasek Trust.

site_title: Indonesia’s Fore Coffee surges in IPO debut, defying market turmoil
summary: Indonesia's Fore Coffee, a homegrown coffee chain, made a successful debut on the local bourse, with its shares opening 34% above the offering price. The IPO, which raised 353.4 billion rupiah, signals robust demand despite global market uncertainty. Fore plans to use 76% of the fresh capital to expand its retail footprint, aiming for 600 locations across Indonesia within four years. The company's strong debut marks a milestone in Indonesia's fast-growing coffee industry, which is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 11% through 2030.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Fore Coffee in Jakarta

site_title: Free AI workshops, resources for SMEs at new AI Centre of Excellence
summary: A new AI Centre of Excellence, launched by the Association of SMEs (Asme) and the Institute of Technical Education (ITE), aims to provide free workshops and resources to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, focusing on AI adoption and skills development. The centre will collect data on real-world AI use cases and user challenges to shape future AI initiatives and policies. Additionally, students will gain exposure to AI-driven business solutions through internships and industrial attachments with participating SMEs.

images.alt_text: The GenAI Playbook aims to make AI adoption more accessible for enterprises across different stages of digital maturity.
Asme president Ang Yuit making the opening address at the AI Festival 2025.

site_title: Late pioneer architect Alfred Wong’s bungalow in Bin Tong Park fetches S$45 million
summary: A late pioneer architect Alfred Wong's bungalow in Bin Tong Park, a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area, has been sold for S$45 million, or S$2,283 per square foot. The property features a two-storey bungalow designed by Wong himself in the late 1960s. A separate bungalow in White House Park is also in the early stages of a sale, with an option to purchase granted at S$40 million, or S$2,636 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
A house on Gallop Park Road is being sold by Lily Yeo, the wife of the late Alan Yeo of Yeo Hiap Seng. The price is understood to be in the low-S$40 million range.
The Leedon Park bungalow was developed by George Lim, who completed the property in 2011.
The conservation house in Nassim Road has an expansion garden in front.

site_title: Invest like you shop: Take advantage of market discounts
summary: Investors can improve their returns by investing regularly and taking advantage of market discounts. Research by Morningstar found that the average investor returns are 0.3-0.7% lower than the funds' performance over 10 years, resulting in a 70% gap from the initial investment. By diversifying investments across asset classes and geographies, investors can reduce losses and recoup them quickly. The optimal approach is to invest regularly, accelerate investments during market weakness, and mentally prepare for potential losses to avoid emotional decision-making.

images.alt_text: Brokerages reported a surge in trading volume days amid heightened market volatility after US President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs on Wednesday (Apr 2).
Markets have crashed in the days following the April 2 tariff announcement amid fears of a global economic slowdown.
Trader Peter Michael Tuchman reacts as he works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the closing bell in New York City, on April 11, 2025.  (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

site_title: Hyatt Hotels to double India capacity in 5 years
summary: Hyatt Hotels plans to double its properties in India over the next five years, adding 50 new hotels to its existing 50, as the country's tourism sector is expected to grow to $131 billion by 2030. Domestic travel has driven this growth, making India the fourth-largest hospitality market, with affluent residents splurging on events, pilgrimage, and weddings. The company will continue its asset-light model, partnering with existing owners to manage and promote hotels, and is targeting local travelers seeking high-end experiences.

images.alt_text: Hyatt, which has roughly 325 of its more than 1,400 hotels in Asia Pacific, is looking to expand in the region, and “India is a big part of that,” says Carina Chorengel, a senior executive.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as Trump eases tariffs on electronics from China
summary: European shares rose 2.7% on Monday, marking the third consecutive week of gains, after US President Donald Trump granted tariff exclusions on electronics from China. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed higher, with financials and chip-related companies leading the gains. Despite this, the benchmark index remains 7% away from its pre-Tariff announcement levels. The European Central Bank is set to hold its policy meeting later this week, with markets anticipating a 25-basis-point rate cut.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, April 14, 2025.   REUTERS/staff
The Stoxx 600 falls 1.8% on a weekly basis, its third straight week in the red.

site_title: OCI is said to put brakes on Malaysia IPO plan on market turmoil
summary: OCI Holdings' financial advisers have paused work on its Malaysian polysilicon business's initial public offering (IPO) due to market volatility, despite not officially cancelling the plan. The polysilicon industry is struggling with a huge surplus, leading to a 80% price drop over the past two years. OCI Malaysia, which produces polysilicon for semiconductors and solar panels, may revisit the IPO plan later, but no final decisions have been made. The company is still weighing options, including an IPO that could raise up to RM1.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Robust trading in the securities market has contributed significantly to Bursa Malaysia's financial performance in the first six months of 2024.
Malaysian tycoon Syed Mokhtar Al-Bukhary's conglomerate MMC may sell a stake of up to 30 per cent in MMC Ports.

site_title: Citi transformation is paying off amid tariff troubles, with room for optimism
summary: Citi's transformation is yielding positive results, despite US President Donald Trump's imposition of hefty tariffs. The bank's head of international, Ernesto Torres Cantu, remains optimistic, citing Singapore as part of the Asia South region, which is experiencing rapid growth. Citi's simplified business structure, with a country-agnostic and product-agnostic view, allows for faster decision-making and improved client service. The bank's presence in Singapore, with around 8,000 employees, is critical for its global operations, and it expects the region to continue growing and benefiting from increased investments and trade flows.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
Citi’s profit beat Wall Street expectations in the second quarter, lifted by revenue in investment banking, markets and services.
Vietnam Airlines is working to move ahead with a US$10 billion 2023 commitment to buy 50 Boeing 737 Max aircraft, Le Duc Canh says.

site_title: With ‘major challenges’ ahead, Singapore is ready to do more to help businesses transform: DPM Gan
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong stated that the government is prepared to provide additional support to companies to transform and become more resilient in the face of major challenges. He cited Samwoh Corporation as an example of a company that has invested in innovation, sustainability, and talent development, providing numerous opportunities for staff to grow. The government will continue to provide necessary support, with significant support already provided in Budget 2025.

images.alt_text: PM Wong said the government will provide short-term support to businesses “without blunting the incentive for them to restructure”.

All companies that have at least three resident employees will receive a fresh S$10,000 in the redesigned SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit, which will be available from the second half of 2026 and last for three years.

site_title: Why wouldn’t China weaponise its US$760 billion Treasury holdings?
summary: China, the US' second-largest foreign creditor, is not expected to retaliate against US President Donald Trump's tariffs, having already called the administration's actions a "joke". However, China's $760 billion Treasury holdings pose a potential threat, and experts speculate that Beijing may sell these holdings to disrupt the US bond market. The move could undermine the dollar's safe-haven status and weaken Trump's economic agenda, as the US needs to issue $2 trillion in new debt this year.

images.alt_text: The export surge supported the economy in the first quarter, but that boost may dissipate after the US threw global trade into chaos.
Traders are not only losing confidence in the US dollar’s long-term prospects – they’re doing so at the fastest pace on record.
The late-night exclusion provides welcome relief to major technology firms such as Apple (above), Dell Technologies and many other importers.
The escalating US-China trade war will hurt both sides.

site_title: Japan sees record population drop in 2024
summary: Japan's population fell to 120.3 million as of October 2024, marking a record drop of 898,000 people from the previous year, according to the internal affairs ministry. This is the largest fall on record since data collection began in 1950. The country's low birth rate and shrinking workforce are major concerns, with the government offering assistance to young families and increasing wages for young people. The population has declined for the 14th consecutive year, with a total fall of 1.43 million since 2022.

images.alt_text: As society moved from being predominantly agricultural to urban, there was less need to have large families.

site_title: Impact of Trump tariffs could push Singapore into technical recession, after Q1 growth disappoints: economists
summary: Singapore's economy may contract again sequentially in Q2, potentially pushing the country into a technical recession, according to private-sector economists. The country's GDP forecast for 2025 has been downgraded to 0-2% due to the escalating US-China trade war, which is expected to weigh heavily on global growth. Economists have cut their full-year growth forecasts for 2025, with some expecting a mild three-quarter technical recession. This comes after Singapore's Q1 GDP shrank 0.8% year-on-year, slower than the 5% growth in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Generic photos for Budget 2024
In a Bloomberg survey, all 14 economists forecast that MAS would reduce the S$NEER slope. Meanwhile, nine out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters expected this move.
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world

site_title: Economists split on likelihood of third monetary policy easing in 2025 as Trump tariffs loom
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has announced a slight reduction in the slope of its monetary policy band, with no change to the width of the band or its level. Economists are divided on whether this move signals further easing in July, with some predicting a 50 basis point reduction to zero, while others expect MAS to hold steady. The move comes amid concerns over the impact of US tariffs on global trade and growth, with MAS forecasting a negative output gap and lower-than-expected inflation. The central bank's dovish tone has sparked expectations of potential adjustments to the policy band, but some economists believe MAS may pause for now.

site_title: Goldman Sachs’ profit jumps as traders deliver gains
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 15% rise in first-quarter profit to $4.74 billion, driven by record revenue in equities trading and boosted fixed income results. The bank's equities trading revenue rose 27% to $4.2 billion, while fixed income revenue increased 2% to $4.4 billion. However, the company's investment banking fees fell 8% to $1.9 billion. Despite the strong earnings, investors are cautious due to uncertainty over tariffs and potential recession, which may limit growth in the coming months.

images.alt_text: CEO Jamie Dimon remained circumspect on the economy as corporate America navigated the fallout of President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

The planned cuts are in line with the bank’s typical approach as it seeks to keep a lid on costs and make room to enlist new talent.

site_title: GE2025: PAP new faces Jeffrey Siow, Choo Pei Ling in Chua Chu Kang team; Amy Khor to step down
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its team for the upcoming Chua Chu Kang group representation constituency (GRC) in Singapore's General Election 2025. New faces Jeffrey Siow and Choo Pei Ling will join Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong and incumbent MP Zhulkarnain Abdul Rahim. Siow, a former senior civil servant, will bring experience in supporting small and medium enterprises, while Dr Choo, a neuroscientist, aims to be a "community builder" in the area. The PAP will contest the GRC against the Progress Singapore Party (PSP).
