The 30-plus new candidates that the PAP will field is the largest slate in recent history, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: US: Nasdaq leads Wall Street higher at open after tariff break for electronics
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, with the Nasdaq leading the way, up over 2% after the White House exempted smartphones and computers from US tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 333.4 points, or 0.83%, to 40,546.15, while the S&P 500 gained 78.6 points, or 1.47%, to 5,441.96. The exemption is seen as a positive move for tech companies, boosting investor confidence and driving market gains.

site_title: Yellen says treasuries show US confidence loss, not dysfunction
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the recent selloff in Treasuries indicates a loss of confidence in American policymaking, rather than a dysfunctional event. She noted the unusual rise in Treasury yields and decline in the dollar, suggesting investors are shunning dollar-based assets. Yellen expressed concern but said the US Federal Reserve has the capacity to intervene if necessary. She also downplayed the risk of China selling its Treasuries, citing it would harm China's interests. The risk of recession has increased, but Yellen is cautious about forecasting one.

images.alt_text: Outgoing Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urges lawmakers once more to take steps to increase or suspend the statutory ceiling.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on electronics tariffs exemption, gold hits new high
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday as the US announced tariff exemptions for electronics, boosting tech firms and lifting Hong Kong stocks over 2%. However, the dollar weakened and gold hit a record high amid concerns the relief would be short-lived. US President Donald Trump later tempered the remarks, saying exemptions had been misconstrued and new tariffs on semiconductors would be announced. Despite this, markets remained relatively stable, with the US stock market also rising, and investors looking to safe-haven assets like gold.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda warns of heightened uncertainty from US tariff policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda warned of heightened economic uncertainty due to US tariff policy, stating it will likely put downward pressure on global and Japanese economies through various channels. The Bank of Japan will guide monetary policy to sustainably achieve its 2% inflation target, while monitoring economic developments without preconceptions.

site_title: Aberdeen committed to Asia as it stages profit turnaround
summary: UK-listed asset management firm Aberdeen Group reported pre-tax profits of £251 million for fiscal 2024, a significant turnaround from a loss of £6 million in 2023. The firm's investments business saw "good momentum" from Asian institutional investors, contributing to the profit. Aberdeen's restructuring efforts, including a cost-cutting program, are bearing fruit, and the firm has restored its original name. Net outflows decreased to £6 billion, down from £13.9 billion previously, as the firm seeks to capitalize on dollar asset diversification driven by Asian investors.

site_title: Gold dips as Trump eases trade tensions with tariff exemptions
summary: US President Donald Trump granted tariff exemptions on smartphones, computers, and other electronics, easing trade tensions with China. Gold prices dropped 0.4% to $3,223.67 an ounce, despite reaching a record high on Friday. The exemptions were announced after intensifying US-China trade tensions rattled global markets. Despite this, traders expect around 80 basis points of interest rate cuts by the end of 2025, which could support gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold’s rally this year has also been fuelled by strong demand from central banks.

site_title: Indonesia to lift US imports as part of tariffs talks: minister
summary: Indonesia is considering boosting US imports as part of trade negotiations with the US, aiming to narrow its trade surplus of $17.9 billion in 2024. Indonesia's 32% tariffs imposed by the US have hurt the country's economy. Chief Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto announced plans to purchase US goods, including liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas, and adjust import taxes on certain commodities. Indonesian officials will meet with their US counterparts from April 16 to April 23 to discuss trade agreements.

site_title: Malaysia asset manager Permodalan Nasional says US, China will remain important
summary: Malaysia's largest asset manager, Permodalan Nasional Bhd (PNB), stated that US and China assets will remain a significant part of its portfolio despite volatile global markets. The firm, which manages RM337 billion in assets, prioritizes investment diversification and has a majority of its portfolio in public equities, both local and international. PNB believes that the US and China's assets will remain an important component of its portfolio in the long term due to their size and economic influence.

site_title: South Korea sees Trump starting tariff talks with Seoul, Japan and India
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to initiate tariff talks with South Korea, Japan, and India, following a video meeting with South Korea's acting President Han Duck-soo. Han reported that Trump was satisfied with South Korea's stance on tariff negotiations. The two countries are also set to discuss the proposed Alaska LNG project. This comes after South Korea's trade and industry minister highlighted the potential for cooperation in shipbuilding as a key card in negotiations over tariffs.

images.alt_text: South Korean Trade Minister Cheong In Kyo (pictured) met US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer about lowering tariff rates slapped on the country.

site_title: GXS acquires fintech Validus’ Singapore business to boost business banking offerings
summary: GXS Bank, a digital bank backed by Grab and Singtel, has acquired Validus Capital's Singapore business for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition will allow GXS to offer short and medium-term working capital loans, trade finance, and boost its lending capabilities. Validus Capital has disbursed over $1 billion in loans to SMEs since its inception in 2015. The deal is expected to be completed by April 15 and will enable GXS to target a full launch of its business banking services in the third quarter of 2025.

Validus co-founder Nikhilesh Goel is seeking to leverage Batumbu's "unique position" as Indonesia's largest and only profitable SME financing platform.

site_title: Trump’s tariff exemption to trim GDP impact on China, Citi says
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff exemptions on consumer electronics and semiconductors could reduce the negative impact on China's economy by 0.4 percentage point, according to Citigroup. The exemptions cover $100 billion of goods and could bring US tariff rates on Beijing down to 127.5%. The move is seen as a potential sign of a de-escalation in the US-China tariff dispute, with economists expecting more US tariff rollbacks due to supply chain disruption and inflationary pressure.

site_title: London property faces worst hit from trade war: Rightmove
summary: London house prices are expected to suffer the most from US President Donald Trump's trade war, with asking prices rising only 0.5% on average in April to £699,200. The city's already struggling market is vulnerable to global demand slowdowns and geopolitical tensions, with foreign buyers increasingly reliant on top locations. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors has reported the lowest buyer demand gauge since September 2023, but property experts predict a stable market in the first half of the year due to expected interest-rate cuts.

site_title: Savills Singapore cuts 2025 investment sales value forecast on US tariffs impact
summary: Savills Singapore has downgraded its 2025 investment sales forecast to S$20 billion due to subdued activity in the private sector, largely driven by economic uncertainties caused by US tariffs and ongoing geopolitical tensions. In Q1 2025, industrial investment value fell 90.3% due to lower activity from S-Reits and lackluster response to industrial GLS tenders. The residential sector remained the top contributor, with private residential sales growing 47.4% qoq to S$3.77 billion, while commercial and hospitality sectors saw growth, albeit with volatile transaction volumes.

site_title: Japan says no plan for big concessions in talks on US tariffs
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba stated that his country does not plan to make significant concessions in upcoming tariff negotiations with the US, amid 24% levies on its exports. Ishiba emphasized the need to understand US President Donald Trump's argument, both logically and emotionally, to negotiate effectively. The two countries will begin trade talks in Washington, covering tariffs, non-tariff barriers, and exchange rates, with a focus on mitigating the impact of US tariffs on Japan's economy.

site_title: China, Vietnam ink deals as Xi visits Hanoi amid US tariff tensions
summary: China's President Xi Jinping visited Vietnam, signing dozens of cooperation agreements with the country amid US tariff tensions. Xi called for stronger ties on trade and supply chains, urging cooperation in production and supply chains, artificial intelligence, and the green economy. Vietnam, under pressure from the US, has tightened controls on trade with China to ensure goods exported to the US have sufficient added value. The visit aims to consolidate relations and boost bilateral trade, with agreements on enhancing supply chains, railways, and the use of Chinese-made planes.

site_title: Qatar to invest US$2 billion in Indonesia sovereign wealth fund
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto announced that Qatar will invest US$2 billion in the Danantara Indonesia sovereign wealth fund, a move aimed at boosting economic growth. The investment is part of a larger plan to ramp up annual growth from 5% to 8%. The Danantara fund, launched in February, will take control of government holdings in state companies with an initial budget of US$20 billion.

images.alt_text: Danantara is slated to eventually manage more than US$900 billion worth of assets.

site_title: Olam to inject US$500 million into ofi, liquidate remaining assets over time
summary: Olam Group is investing US$500 million in its food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients (ofi), as part of a reorganization plan. The investment, funded by internal resources, aims to position ofi for profitable growth and resume its delayed initial public offering plans. Olam will also de-leverage its remaining assets over time, with the goal of liquidating them progressively.

Olam will now focus on seeking strategic options to unlock value for its remaining businesses and ofi.

site_title: Chinese exports swell ahead of US tariffs that will snarl trade
summary: China's exports rebounded 12.4% in March, exceeding forecasts and surpassing pre-tariff levels, before the US imposed tariffs. The surge was driven by companies frontloading orders and diverting shipments to South-east Asian countries. Imports shrank 4.3% and China's trade surplus reached $103 billion. The export rebound may be short-lived as the US tariffs take effect, potentially disrupting global trade and putting pressure on China's export engine.

site_title: Battered dollar steadies but investors brace for more tariff volatility
summary: The US dollar found some stability on Monday, but remains near a three-year low against a basket of currencies, following a volatile week sparked by US President Donald Trump's tariff plans. Investors braced for more volatility, with the euro expected to reach $1.20 by end of July, driven by a crisis of confidence in the dollar. The dollar's structural attractiveness as the world's reserve currency is being re-assessed, with some analysts predicting a process of "rapid de-dollarisation."

site_title: Property tycoon Ong Beng Seng to step down as HPL managing director to manage cancer treatment
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) announced that managing director Ong Beng Seng, 79, will step down to devote time to managing his medical condition, specifically multiple myeloma. Ong, a controlling shareholder, will continue to provide strategic oversight but will no longer hold both positions. Board members Christopher Lim and Stephen Lau will manage the company as executive directors. Ong's departure comes after he received treatment for cancer in February. He will not seek re-election as a director following the annual general meeting on April 29.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, EC World Reit, Hotel Properties Limited
summary: Olam Group plans to sell its 64.6% stake in Olam Agri to Saudi Agricultural and Livestock Investment Company for US$2.6 billion in two tranches. The divestment will help fund the reorganisation of Olam Group's business. Meanwhile, EC World Reit's mortgage of three properties has been deemed lawful and valid by a PRC Court, resolving a dispute that had led to the suspension of its units from trading.

site_title: Wise aims for faster, cheaper transactions amid Asia-Pacific expansion
summary: Wise, a London-listed fintech firm, is expanding its services in the Asia-Pacific region, aiming to make international transactions cheaper and faster. The company has established partnerships with major banks and has over 90 banking partners, including Morgan Stanley and Standard Chartered. Wise's cross-border volumes grew 24% to £37.8 billion, and its account balances increased by 26% to £16.2 billion. The company is pushing for pricing transparency in cross-border wire transactions, which it believes will increase competition among banks and make the service more competitive.

site_title: Singapore businesses must move strategically to get on winning side of tariff war
summary: Singapore businesses must adapt to the complex and uncertain global trade landscape following the US's latest tariff announcements. While the country's reliance on trade may put it at a disadvantage, its strategic location, competitive tax environment, and strong legal framework make it an attractive hub for high-value trade activities. To stay ahead, businesses should assess their exposure and risk, then act to ensure supply chains remain competitive. They can do this by adjusting supply chain capacities, rethinking growth strategies, and adopting technology-enabled operating models. The government has also announced initiatives to strengthen the enterprise ecosystem, providing businesses with opportunities to seize.

site_title: Companies getting ‘a bit tired’ of tariff chaos, DHL CEO says
summary: US companies are growing tired of the constantly shifting US tariffs, according to DHL CEO Tobias Meyer. The tariffs have caused uncertainty, with companies struggling to navigate changing announcements. US officials estimate raising $300 billion to $600 billion from the tariffs, while President Trump has pledged tax cuts. The tariffs have led to fatigue among manufacturers and distributors, with some opting to wait until Trump's decisions are finalized. The whipsawing of trade policies is affecting companies like DHL, which is carrying parcels subject to US duties.

site_title: Queasy investors are calling Trump’s tariff bluff, and it looks like he will eventually fold
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has paused individualized tariffs on countries running trade deficits with the US, but a baseline tariff of 10% remains in effect. Global investors, who initially showed little concern, have expressed discomfort with the tariffs, prompting Trump to reconsider. The move could lead to further de-escalation of tensions between the US and China, with China having vowed to ignore further US tariffs. The 90-day pause may create opportunities for trade-dependent economies in Asia to negotiate better deals, while investors should remain cautious due to the potential impact on economic growth and corporate earnings.

site_title: UK rushes to find materials to keep British Steel plant running
summary: UK officials are racing to secure raw materials to keep Britain's last primary steel manufacturer, British Steel, running. The government is working with suppliers and workers to ensure they are paid, and a shipment of coking coal is being held in the port of Immingham. The government is considering a nationalization of British Steel, with the Business Secretary saying it is the "likely option" due to the company's £233 million loss. The move is seen as crucial to the country's economic security, as allowing the plant to close would leave Britain unable to produce virgin steel.

site_title: Goldman cuts targets on China stocks for second time this month
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut its targets for Chinese stocks for the second time this month, citing heightened US-China trade tensions. The firm lowered its 12-month target for the MSCI China Index to 75 from 81 and for the CSI 300 Index to 4,300 from 4,500. The cuts imply potential upsides of 12% and 15% respectively, as concerns over a global recession and decoupling risks weigh on investor sentiment. Despite being bullish on Chinese stocks, Goldman Sachs trimmed its targets after US tariffs on China were increased.

images.alt_text: China’s economy may suffer broadly from Trump’s aggressive hike in tariffs to 145 per cent and the decoupling of the two nations.

site_title: Can Paragon Reit upgrade crown jewel Paragon without unitholders’ distribution taking a big hit?
summary: Paragon Reit's minority investors will meet on April 22 to decide on the proposed privatisation of Times Properties, a subsidiary of the Reit's sponsor. If approved, the scheme would lead to Paragon Reit's delisting, as Cuscaden Peak Investments, which owns 61.5% of the Reit's units, will abstain from voting. Minority investors will decide the fate of the privatisation, which could impact unitholders' distribution. The outcome will determine the future of Paragon Reit, a 12-year-old Reit that has been on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Australia’s PM approval rises as Trump looms over May election
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's net approval rating has reached its highest point in 11 months ahead of the May 3 election, with a 52-48% lead over the Liberal-National Coalition opposition. The election campaign has been influenced by US President Donald Trump's trade war, with Australian markets experiencing similar fluctuations. Albanese is seeking to become the first in over two decades to win consecutive elections in Australia, while his government has tied the opposition's leader, Peter Dutton, to Trump, accusing them of copying policies from overseas.

images.alt_text: Australia’s defence minister Richard Marles was quick to dispel notions of Canberra and Beijing uniting in “common cause”.

One in three Australian households now has solar panels but only one in 40 has a battery, according to the government.

site_title: Insights and strategies to help investors hold their nerve
summary: Global markets have experienced unprecedented volatility amid concerns over recession and inflation risks. The S&P 500 ended last week up 5%, but US Treasuries are pricing in higher risks. A disciplined investing approach through dollar-cost averaging, as advocated by experts, can help investors tune out emotions and impulses. Historical data shows that even in times of great pessimism, markets have shown resilience, and diversification across asset classes can mitigate risk. Investors are advised to consider low-volatility funds, options strategies, and structured products with downside protection to navigate the current market uncertainty.

site_title: Asia, Europe, gold, private markets: Where investors can seek refuge as US exceptionalism is cast into doubt
summary: Global investors are shifting their focus from US markets, citing concerns over American exceptionalism and the impact of President Trump's tariffs. Experts recommend diversifying into Asia, Europe, and private markets, such as gold, to hedge bets. Investment managers like Eastspring and Natixis prefer to maintain a balanced view between the US and Europe, while Standard Chartered upgraded China equities to "overweight" and downgraded US equities to "neutral". Investors are advised to be cautious and consider asset classes like investment-grade bonds, gold, and private markets to mitigate volatility.

summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) is launching a US$8 billion expansion project, IR2, set to open in January 2031. The luxury resort will feature a fourth tower, 570 suites, a new casino area, entertainment space, and high-end restaurants. Construction begins in June 2025, and a ground-breaking ceremony is planned for mid-2025. MBS is recruiting thousands of employees to work at the new development, with the company already one of Singapore's largest employers. The expansion comes as the company enjoys exceptional financial performance, with adjusted property earnings exceeding US$2 billion in 2024.

Even though integrated resorts in other parts of the world might not be fully rebranding or repositioning themselves, they are certainly reinvesting and elevating," says MBS COO Paul Town.
Marina Bay Sands’ expansion plans come as Singapore’s tourism industry has staged a sharp rebound since the pandemic.
Ron Reese (left), senior vice-president of global communications and corporate affairs at Las Vegas Sands, and one of Food Bank Singapore's co-founders Nichol Ng.
Occupancy at MBS is largely stable for the quarter.

site_title: Singapore slashes 2025 growth forecast to 0-2%; Q1 GDP up 3.8% year on year
summary: Singapore's official growth forecast for 2025 has been downgraded to 0-2% due to the impact of US President Donald Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs. The country's Q1 GDP grew 3.8% year on year, below economists' expectations of 4.5%. The manufacturing sector is expected to be affected by weaker global demand, while the finance and insurance sector may see weaker trade activity due to risk-off sentiments. The government will closely monitor global and domestic developments and make further adjustments to its forecast if necessary.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Generic photos for Budget 2024
Geopolitical tensions, including from higher tariffs, remained the most-cited downside risk to the domestic outlook, flagged by all respondents.
Under Singapore's free trade agreement with the US, Singapore has recourse to take countermeasures and seek dispute resolution – but has decided not to do so.
In a Bloomberg survey, all 14 economists forecast that MAS would reduce the S$NEER slope. Meanwhile, nine out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters expected this move.

site_title: Impact of Trump’s tariffs, interest costs in focus as S-Reits report Q1 earnings
summary: Analysts expect Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) to report a slight increase in Q1 distributions per unit (DPU) due to lower interest rates. US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on global goods have impacted S-Reits, with some expecting higher vacancy rates and lower rental growth. S-Reits under the Frasers and Mapletree groups will report their half-year and full-year results, respectively. Analysts are also tracking S-Reits' guidance on their average cost of debt, with interest rates expected to remain low. Overall, most S-Reits are expected to report a slight increase in DPU, despite potential challenges.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Trump tariffs spark S-Reits sell-off but analysts say sector remains ‘safe haven’
In March, Singapore Reits outperformed the global Reit market.

site_title: MAS’ private-market proposal for retail investors may boost appeal of semi-liquid funds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes allowing retail investors to access private markets through authorized long-term investment funds (LIFs), which may be listed or unlisted. Semi-liquid funds, offering periodic redemption opportunities, are expected to gain appeal among retail investors. However, experts warn that these funds are not without risks, including illiquidity and limited redemption windows. To mitigate risks, investors must evaluate their liquidity needs and risk profile, assess the track record of fund managers, and consider diversifying their portfolios. MAS's proposal aims to increase investor confidence and provide more options for retail investors.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Private-market funds are expected to offer diversification benefits and higher risk-adjusted returns. Liquidity, however, is relatively infrequent and fees are higher.

site_title: Indonesia arrests judge after palm oil companies cleared of graft charges
summary: Indonesia's Attorney General's Office arrested a chief judge, Muhammad Arif Nuryanta, on charges of bribery related to the acquittal of three palm oil companies, Wilmar Group, Musim Mas Group, and Permata Hijau Group, in a corruption case. The companies were cleared of misconduct charges in obtaining export permits in 2022. Two lawyers of the companies allegedly paid the judge 60 billion rupiah (S$4.7 million) to secure a favorable verdict. A court clerk and two lawyers have also been apprehended. Charges against the companies are unclear.

Indonesia launched an effort this year to improve governance of its forest and palm oil cultivation after facing criticism that the plantations are a major driver of deforestation.

site_title: One Marina Gardens moves 38% of project at S$2,953 psf average amid cautious sentiment
summary: Singapore's One Marina Gardens and Bloomsbury Residences sold 38% and 25.1% of their units, respectively, with average selling prices of S$2,953psf and S$2,474psf, despite market concerns over a trade war and recession. The projects, launched on the same weekend, have done reasonably well, with some buyers choosing to wait before committing to purchases. The sales percentage and prices are lower than those of other major residential projects launched in the first quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The new condo is located in District 5 and is conveniently accessible to the Central Business District and Orchard Road.
The 99-year leasehold development is close to the upcoming Marina South MRT station, shopping malls and schools.

site_title: Trump warns tariffs are coming for electronics after reprieve
summary: US President Donald Trump has warned that tariffs on electronics, including phones and computers, are coming despite a temporary reprieve from tariffs on China and other countries. The reprieve, which covers nearly $390 billion in US imports, including $101 billion from China, is a procedural step towards applying a specific levy to the electronics sector. Trump has doubled down on the plan, saying the exempted products will be moved to a different "tariff bucket" and will face a lower tariff rate than the 125% rate on China. Semiconductor tariffs are also expected to come, with a notice to be published this week.

images.alt_text: Larry Fink, CEO of BlackRock says: “The market downturn impacts millions of ordinary people’s retirement savings.”
Cars waiting to be loaded onto a ship for export in Lianyungang. China has the fiscal capacity to cushion the blow from tariffs and is pivoting towards domestic demand as a primary growth driver.
Given the highly specialised and multi-country nature of chip supply chains, there was uncertainty within the industry about how tariffs would be applied to chip imports.
Markets are expected to remain volatile over the next many weeks as information unfolds.

site_title: Indonesia’s foreign reserves hit record high despite rupiah rout
summary: Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves reached a record high of $157.1 billion in March, gaining $2.6 billion despite the country's currency, the rupiah, experiencing a 4% decline this year. The increase in reserves is attributed to tax and service revenues, as well as the withdrawal of foreign loans. The move provides support for Bank Indonesia to defend the rupiah, which has been hit by multiple factors, including US President Donald Trump's tariffs. Domestic concerns, such as a slowing economy and fiscal outlook, also weigh on market sentiment.

site_title: Buyout firms get creative on Gulf trips in bid for bigger checks
summary: Buyout firms are intensifying efforts to secure investments from Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds amid a global economic downturn. In response to US President Donald Trump's trade war, asset managers such as Carlyle Group and BlackRock are relocating executives and launching training programs to build relationships with Gulf wealth funds. The move is driven by the need for liquidity in a market where tariffs have wiped out trillions of US dollars from stock markets. By establishing connections in the region, buyout firms aim to secure funding and capitalize on the Gulf's history of stepping in during economic downturns.

images.alt_text: KKR stands out for leaning into private equity at a time when many of its peers, including Apollo Global Management, have lowered expectations for buyouts.
A recent internal probe into the startup alleged that eFishery inflated its revenue and profit over several years.

site_title: Global funds hit pause on Indonesia after Prabowo policy changes
summary: Global investors are hesitant to invest in Indonesia due to sweeping policy changes under President Prabowo Subianto's administration, which led to the country's largest stock market decline since 2011. The government's attempts to manage state finances and push forward with high-priority projects have raised concerns among investors. The recent sell-off of foreign assets, with a total of $1.8 billion in the first quarter, has weakened investor confidence. Despite some pockets of value, investors are cautious about loading up on Indonesian assets, citing governance concerns and a lack of conviction in the government's direction.

images.alt_text: The nation’s currency and stock markets are also suffering due to concerns that Prabowo’s policy spending spree could eat into the country’s fiscal discipline built under previous administrations.
During deliberations with lawmakers, the government and the budget committee approve most of the budget assumptions in the original proposal.
The surplus for South-east Asia’s biggest economy was US$3.12 billion.

site_title: Stripe’s banking push comes as fintechs dive deeper into finance
summary: Stripe, a payments unicorn, has applied for a Merchant Acquirer Limited Purpose Bank (MALPB) charter in Georgia, a move to reduce reliance on banking partners and gain more control over its business. The charter would allow Stripe to directly access payment-card networks Visa and Mastercard, reducing the risk of service disruptions if its bank partners exit the fintech sector. Fiserv, a bank technology provider, has also received a MALPB charter in Georgia, and other fintechs are expected to follow, driven by the Trump administration's support for innovative bank charters.

images.alt_text: Stripe, one of the largest startups in the US and a closely watched candidate for an initial public offering, has said that it’s not in a rush to list publicly.
Stablecoins are typically designed to track the value of currencies or assets such as US dollars one-for-one.
While Stripe has long been perceived as a top fintech IPO contender, the company’s founders have emphasised that they are in no rush to go public.

site_title: Fed’s deepest tariff fear is a price shock that won’t fade away
summary: The US Federal Reserve is concerned about the potential impact of President Donald Trump's tariffs on inflation, as consumer and business estimates of future inflation suggest a loss of faith in the central bank's ability to control prices. The benchmark long-run expectations gauge has soared to a 30-year high, indicating a persistent inflationary impulse. This could lead to higher interest rates and a decrease in the Fed's credibility, making its job harder in controlling inflation. Economists warn that a trade war could turn a one-time price hit into a more persistent inflationary impulse, and that the Fed needs to take swift action to address the issue.

images.alt_text: US consumer sentiment tumbled to the second-lowest level on record in a University of Michigan survey, as inflation expectations soared to multi-decades highs.

site_title: MoneyHero faces potential delisting as shares dip below US$1
summary: MoneyHero, a Nasdaq-listed financial comparison site, may be delisted due to its shares falling below US$1 per share for 31 consecutive business days, failing to meet the minimum bid price requirement. The company has seen an exodus of senior executives since its initial public offering. Its full year results are set to be released on April 29, amid uncertainty surrounding its listing status.

images.alt_text: Generic photo people at shenton way traffic crossing. For stories related to Labour, Employment, Wages and Productivity.

site_title: GE2025: Jasmin Lau and Victor Lye spotted at Ang Mo Kio GRC along with SM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Former senior civil servant Jasmin Lau and PAP veteran Victor Lye have been spotted with Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong at Ang Mo Kio GRC, sparking speculation about their potential involvement in the upcoming general election. Lau, a former deputy secretary at the Ministry of Health, and Lye, a former MP for Aljunied GRC, have expressed their willingness to join the PAP team. SM Lee has hinted that both could be part of his team, citing their diverse experiences and potential contributions to the constituency.

images.alt_text: This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

site_title: Apple India produces US$22b of iPhones in shift from China
summary: Apple has increased iPhone production in India by nearly 60% to $22 billion in the past year, accounting for 20% of its global production. This shift away from China is driven by the COVID-19 lockdowns that affected production in the country. Apple's India production is now valued at $8 billion in sales, with exports to the US reaching $23 billion. The move is seen as a strategic diversification for the company, but it may take years to fully replace China as a major manufacturing hub.

images.alt_text: While the ban was in place, the government had allowed iPhone 16 models to be brought into the country, provided they were not being traded commercially.

site_title: China credit expansion beats forecast on bond sale deluge
summary: China's credit expansion exceeded expectations in March, driven by a surge in bond sales to offset the impact of US tariffs on Chinese goods. Aggregate financing rose 5.89 trillion yuan, surpassing forecasts, as financial institutions offered 3.64 trillion yuan in new loans. The government's fiscal spending was also boosted, with net sovereign and local bond financing reaching nearly 1.5 trillion yuan. Despite this, the economy likely held up in the first quarter before trade tensions escalated, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) sent the window guidance, which is its informal style for managing policy around markets, to state banks this week, asking them to withhold US dollar purchases for their proprietary accounts.
Aside from using yuan to counter a growth slowdown, another long-term agenda may impact China’s currency policy.
Whether or not the central bank decides to let the yuan go now, China’s financial markets look set to be challenged by high volatility.
Looking ahead, cash conditions in China are set to remain tight without further liquidity support from the PBOC.

site_title: Bullish outlook for EURUSD
summary: The EURUSD FX pair has experienced heightened volatility, moving from 1.02 to 1.09, a 700 pip movement, driven by market sensitivity to geopolitical and economic developments. The euro's bull run in 2024, underpinned by positive GDP growth, is expected to continue, with the current uptrend indicated by the Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicator. However, the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on inflation and the European Central Bank's interest rate cut create uncertainty, disrupting the eurozone economy and volatility in the EURUSD.

images.alt_text: Traders are not only losing confidence in the US dollar’s long-term prospects – they’re doing so at the fastest pace on record.

site_title: UOB, CIMB vote for 1.5 deg C climate target  to be replaced with below 2
summary: Banks in South-east Asia, including UOB and CIMB, are voting to replace the 1.5°C climate target with a commitment to keep global warming to "well below 2°C". The move comes as the Net-Zero Banking Alliance faces increasing pressure after high-profile departures, including JPMorgan Chase and several Japanese banks. The proposal offers greater flexibility to target decarbonisation targets to the markets in which banks operate, rather than aligning with the 1.5°C threshold. DBS has also expressed support for a region-specific decarbonisation pathway, emphasizing the need for Asia to craft its own ambitious and socio-economically grounded climate plan.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: China no longer welcome in UK steel sector, minister says
summary: The UK government has effectively closed its doors to Chinese investment in the steel sector following the refusal of China's Jingye Group to accept a £500 million aid package. The decision comes after the closure of blast furnaces at the British Steel plant in Scunthorpe, which would have left Britain as the only major economy unable to produce virgin steel. Business minister Jonathan Reynolds stated that Chinese companies linked to the Chinese Communist Party pose a risk to national security, and the steel sector is deemed too sensitive for Chinese investment.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump’s administration excluded smartphones, computers and other electronics from the increased import duties on Friday (Apr 11), narrowing the scope of his tariffs of 125 per cent on goods from China and a baseline 10% on imports from most other countries.

site_title: Apple was on brink of crisis before Trump tariff concession
summary: US President Donald Trump has exempted Apple from 125% tariffs on Chinese goods, including iPhones, iPads, and Macs, in a move that marks a major relief for the company. The exemptions, announced on Friday, also include a 10% flat rate tariff on consumer electronics imported from other countries. However, the US Commerce Secretary warned that the reprieve is temporary, and the company may still face a sectoral tariff on semiconductors. The move could have significant implications for Apple's supply chain and manufacturing operations, particularly if the company were to shift production from China to India.

images.alt_text: Apple has a nearly 8 per cent market share in India’s smartphone market, where its sales – a bulk of those from iPhones – reached almost US$8 billion in fiscal 2024.
The estimate comes as US President Donald Trump zeros in on China for his trade fight.
The details of the push provide an insight into Apple’s private strategy to navigate around the Trump tariffs and build up inventory of its popular iPhones in the US.
The next major company catalyst that investors will be watching is Apple’s quarterly earnings report, due May 1.

site_title: MAS eases policy slightly, lowers inflation forecasts after Trump tariffs threaten growth
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased monetary policy slightly, lowering inflation forecasts after US tariffs raised recession fears. The central bank reduced the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band by 50 basis points to an estimated 0.5% per annum. MAS also lowered its full-year inflation forecasts, expecting core inflation to range between 0.5 and 1.5% and headline inflation to average between 0.5 and 1.5%. The move follows January's loosening and is in line with market expectations, with economists expecting further easing in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Most economists expect a “slight” slope reduction of 50 basis points, including Citi, HSBC, Maybank, Standard Chartered and UOB. PHOTO: BT FILE
A risk analyst at Fitch Solutions unit, BMI, expects the MAS to ease policy given the mounting risks to growth, including the imposition of tariffs by US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Muted momentum, stable demand in luxury homes in wake of ABSD hikes
summary: Singapore's luxury condominium market is showing signs of a slight recovery, driven by improved market confidence. Core Central Region (CCR) sales have plunged since April 2023, but recent data indicates a slight increase in transactions and caveats lodged, with 84 transactions valued at S$676.1 million in Q1 2025. Analysts attribute this to moderation in interest rates and healthy balance sheets, as well as a shift in buying behavior from foreign ultra-high-net-worth individuals to local wealthy buyers.

site_title: Singapore’s prime residential market gears up with 2,500 new homes to be launched in 2025
summary: Singapore's prime residential market is expected to see a boost with 2,500 new homes to be launched in 2025 in five projects in the Core Central Region. This represents a significant increase from 680 units launched last year and 630 units in 2023. The new supply is a result of developers resuming launches after a two-year hiatus due to declining demand following steep stamp duty hikes. The increase in supply may test the demand for high-end and luxury homes in prime districts 9, 10, and 11.

site_title: Japan policymaker wants stronger yen; against selling Treasuries
summary: Japan's policymaker Itsunori Onodera wants to strengthen the yen, citing its weakness as a factor in accelerating inflation, and opposes intentionally selling US Treasury holdings in retaliation to US tariffs. Onodera believes boosting Japanese companies' competitiveness is key to strengthening the currency. The move comes ahead of trade talks with the US, which may include discussions on currency policy. The Bank of Japan's slow interest rate hikes may also be criticized, with Washington potentially calling for Tokyo to prop up the yen.

images.alt_text: Of the total households surveyed between Feb 6 and March 4, 83.5 per cent expect prices to rise five years from now, up from 82.5 per cent in the December survey.

site_title: “A Minecraft Movie” holds on to the top spot in North American theatres
summary: "A Minecraft Movie" starring Jack Black and Jason Momoa holds the top spot in North American theatres with estimated ticket sales of US$80.6 million, bringing its total domestic sales to US$281 million and international sales to US$269 million. The film is the most successful video game adaptation to date, boosting the box office performance similar to the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Movie still: A Minecraft Movie starring (from left) Jack Black, Danielle Brooks and Jason Momoa
Netflix has long used AI and machine learning for certain purposes.
The Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said films released in 2027 will be eligible for an Oscar for Achievement in Stunt Design.
Now, US films account for only 5 per cent of the overall box office receipts in China’s market.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Smart cash moves for money mastery
summary: Host Howie Lim discusses the benefits of investing in money market funds for excess cash, citing higher yields, safety of principal, and liquidity. Experts Michele Ferrario and Willie Keng explain how these funds invest in low-risk, short-term fixed income securities, and highlight the importance of diversification in a long-term investment portfolio. They also debunk common myths about fixed income products and emphasize the need for informed investment decisions.

site_title: Bridgewater’s Ray Dalio says Trump trade war has put US ‘close to a recession’
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, says US President Donald Trump's trade war has brought the country near to recession. He described the tariffs' impact as "very disruptive" and likened it to throwing rocks into the production system. Dalio expressed worry about the combined impact of US debt, budget deficit, and global political tension, warning that the situation could produce a more severe outcome than a recession.

images.alt_text: Trump’s politics is about casting America as a victim and himself as its fearless saviour, prepared to take action nobody else will in order to defeat its “enemies”
Trader Peter Michael Tuchman reacts as he works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the closing bell in New York City, on April 11, 2025.  (Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY / AFP)

Apple, these days, sells about 220 million to 230 million iPhones annually, with about a third of those going to the US.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly shipping market report (Apr 11, 2025) highlights headwinds in the tanker and dry bulk market due to macroeconomic pressures, particularly escalating US-China tariff tensions. The Capesize market saw significant drops, with the BCI 5TC down from $16,728 to $14,952. Panamax, Ultramax, and Supramax markets also faced challenges, with rates declining across various regions. Handysize and MR freight markets experienced downward pressure, while the Suezmax market showed resilience. The LNG market softened, with rates falling across most routes, and the LPG market plummeted amid US tariffs.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Apr 4, 2025).

site_title: Taiwan extends short-selling curbs after US tariffs bring market turmoil
summary: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission has extended short-selling curbs for another week to ensure market stability amid US tariff-induced turmoil. The measures had "indeed had the expected effect of effectively curbing speculative selling," according to the regulator. Taiwan's stock market saw significant fluctuations last week, with the benchmark index dropping 15% this year, prompting the regulator to activate its $15-billion stock stabilisation fund. Global market uncertainties remain, with investor confidence still fragile.

images.alt_text: Cars waiting to be loaded onto a ship for export in Lianyungang. China has the fiscal capacity to cushion the blow from tariffs and is pivoting towards domestic demand as a primary growth driver.

site_title: GE2025: ‘We hear you, I hear you’: PM Wong’s message to young S’poreans, first-time voters
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has addressed young Singaporeans and first-time voters in a social media post, acknowledging their high standards and desire for change. He promised that the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) will include candidates from diverse backgrounds, including the Indian community, in the upcoming general election. Wong also emphasized the importance of diversity and minority representation, calling on the Indian community to build a distinctive Singaporean Indian identity. The PAP has announced its largest number of new candidates in recent history, with over 30 faces set to contest opposition-held areas.

images.alt_text: This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

site_title: EU to probe use of personal data by X's AI chatbot
summary: Ireland's Data Protection Commission, acting on behalf of the European Union, launched an inquiry into X's use of personal data to train its AI chatbot, Grok, developed by Elon Musk. The probe focuses on the processing of personal data from publicly-accessible posts on X's social media platform. This follows a previous court case and agreement between X and the DPC to suspend the use of data. The commission will examine compliance with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation, specifically regarding lawfulness and transparency.

images.alt_text: Altman has said OpenAI is not for sale, rejected a US$97.4 billion unsolicited takeover bid earlier this year from a Musk-led consortium with a “no thank you”.

site_title: China says US tariff break a ‘small step’ to fixing mistake
summary: China's government views US tariff exemptions as a small step towards rectifying its wrongdoings, urging the US to revoke the levies. The exemptions cover almost $390 billion in US imports, including over $101 billion from China, and exclude products like semiconductors and electronics. The move does not extend to a separate 20% duty on China, and other levies appear unaffected. China's Ministry of Commerce calls for the US to "take a big stride in completely abolishing the wrongful action" and return to resolving differences through dialogue.

images.alt_text: The late-night exclusion provides welcome relief to major technology firms such as Apple (above), Dell Technologies and many other importers.

site_title: China March new bank loans rise to 3.6 trillion yuan, beating expectations
summary: China's new bank loans rose to 3.6 trillion yuan in March, beating expectations, with outstanding loans increasing 7.4% year-over-year. This rebound offers relief to policymakers as the country prepares for an escalating trade war with the US. Total new loans for the first quarter rose to 9.8 trillion yuan, with growth forecasts remaining steady despite deepening trade frictions. China's economic growth target of "around 5 per cent" this year may be supported by potential monetary policy adjustments, including reserve requirement ratio cuts and interest rate reductions.

images.alt_text: The tit-for-tat could reduce US-China trade in goods by 80%, the World Trade Organization says.

site_title: Singapore education provider RVi Group shelters students amid Myanmar earthquake recovery
summary: Singapore-based education provider RVi Group is sheltering students and working to rebuild operations in Myanmar after a 7.7-magnitude earthquake struck on March 28. The company, which manages seven schools across the country, has been ensuring the safety of staff and students while contributing to relief efforts. RVi Group has partnered with structural engineers to assess and restore school buildings, and is providing aid to the local community. The company has also set up a plan for contingency learning arrangements to address concerns about access to resources and psychological trauma.

images.alt_text: OUE Healthcare holds a 40 per cent stake in the joint venture companies that own, operate and manage Pun Hlaing Hospitals located in the Myanmar cities of Yangon, Mandalay and Taunggyi.
Specialists, including members of Russia's emergencies ministry, take part in a search operation following a massive earthquake in Mandalay, Myanmar, April 1, 2025.

site_title: Scottish rowing brothers aim for record-breaking Pacific crossing
summary: Three Scottish brothers, Ewan, Jamie, and Lachlan MacLean, have embarked on a record-breaking attempt to row across the Pacific Ocean from Peru to Sydney in Australia. The brothers, who previously rowed across the Atlantic Ocean, aim to raise over $1 million for clean water projects in Madagascar and complete the 14,500 km journey in approximately four months. The trio will row non-stop with no outside support, facing challenges such as sleep deprivation and relentless rowing.

images.alt_text: Over 12,000 runners from 400 companies took part in this year's Corporate Challenge.

site_title: US dollar emerges as latest victim of last week’s markets mayhem
summary: The US dollar has plummeted to a six-month low due to a worsening global trade war and rising tariffs on US goods, which is expected to derail US economic growth. Traders have lost confidence in the dollar at the fastest pace on record, with a Bloomberg gauge tumbling 12% in a week. Haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc, and gold, have benefited from the outflows, while the euro has risen to its strongest level in three years. Investors are shifting towards European and Asian assets, and the US dollar's long-term prospects have become increasingly negative.

images.alt_text: Crypto has been said to be a potential challenger to the yellow metal’s role as a store of value, but US President Donald Trump’s tariffs are highlighting their key differences.

site_title: Netflix tests new AI search engine to recommend shows, movies
summary: Netflix is testing a new AI-powered search engine to recommend TV shows and movies, expanding its use of the technology. The search engine, powered by OpenAI, allows customers to search for content using specific terms, including their mood, and provides recommendations from Netflix's catalog. The feature is currently available in Australia and New Zealand on iOS devices and will soon expand to the US. The test aims to improve user experience and provide more personalized recommendations, but management is sensitive to potential criticism about the use of AI technology.

images.alt_text: Netflix paid “approximately US$44 million” for a show’s production between 2018 and 2019 helmed by Hollywood filmmaker Carl Rinsch.

site_title: France wants to make one-off wealth tax permanent
summary: France's economy minister Eric Lombard plans to make a one-off wealth tax permanent, aiming to raise 40 billion euros (S$60 billion) in 2025 to reduce the public deficit to 4.6% of GDP in 2026. The tax, initially introduced as a temporary measure, will target high earners and companies, with a minimum 20% income tax for individuals earning over 250,000 euros and couples with joint incomes over 500,000 euros. The measure aims to make government financing "more equitable" and combat tax over-optimisation.

images.alt_text: The French government had forecast annual growth of 0.9 per cent when presenting its 2025 budget, but Economy Minister Eric Lombard told TF1 television that it would be trimmed to 0.7 per cent.
National Rally leader Marine Le Pen speaks during a demonstration at Place Vauban in Paris, France, April 6, 2025.

site_title: Top European banks launch task force to boost defence investment
summary: Top European banks, including BNP Paribas, UniCredit, and ING, have formed a task force to boost defence investment in the region. The task force, set up by the European Banking Federation, aims to address regulatory issues that prevent banks from lending to defence projects and companies. The banks are exploring ways to ease the way for them to support Europe's higher defence spending, which has been encouraged by finance ministers meeting in Warsaw. The task force will also coordinate how the finance industry communicates around its defence activities and consider incentives to encourage greater levels of activity.

images.alt_text: In her strongest comments yet, European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen indicated that she was ready to step up her threats of retaliation and target American services if negotiations fall short.

site_title: GE2025: Parties start to show their hand with formal introductions of candidates
summary: Singapore's general election (GE2025) kicked off with opposition parties formally introducing their candidates on April 12, 2025. The People's Action Party (PAP) announced its slate of over 30 new candidates, the largest in recent history, while the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) confirmed its team for Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC. The PAP also unveiled its teams for opposition-held Aljunied and Sengkang GRCs. The election season will continue with the nomination period set to begin on a date yet to be announced.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
PAP veteran Victor Lye and former senior civil servant Jasmin Lau arriving with Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong at Hougang Village on April 13.

SDP secretary-general Chee Soon Juan (centre) with candidates (from left) Alec Tok, Jufri Salim, Gigene Wong and Ariffin Iskandar Sha Ali Akbar at a press conference which followed the walkabout on Sunday.
This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

site_title: China’s Xi courts South-east Asia as Trump tariffs bite
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is embarking on a five-day, three-nation South-east Asia tour, visiting Vietnam, Malaysia, and Cambodia, to strengthen regional trade ties and counter US President Donald Trump's tariffs. The trip aims to present China as a stable alternative to the US, which has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, causing anxiety among developing Asian nations. China is the largest recipient of exports to the 10-member Asean bloc, with Vietnam and Malaysia among its biggest buyers. The visit is seen as a bid to offset the impact of the closed US market and cement China's influence in the region.

images.alt_text: For the first quarter, total new loans rose to 9.78 trillion yuan from 9.46 trillion yuan in the same period last year. Outstanding yuan loans rose 7.4 per cent in March from a year earlier, up from a 7.3 per cent pace in February.

site_title: Trump wants to halt climate research by key agency: reports
summary: The Trump administration plans to cut 75% of funding for NOAA's research branch, potentially eliminating hundreds of jobs and drastically reducing the agency's climate research capabilities. The move, part of the administration's broader assault on climate-related resources, could have significant global consequences, including impacts on weather forecasting, fisheries conservation, and the US economy. Critics warn that the cuts will "eviscerate" the agency's weather forecasting capabilities and undermine essential services.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump speaks in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on March 3, 2025. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

US President Donald Trump is moving to expand mining and the use of coal in the US in a bid to power the boom in energy-hungry data centres while seeking to revive a declining US fossil fuel industry.

site_title: Classical music at Coachella? LA Philharmonic makes desert debut
summary: The Los Angeles Philharmonic made its Coachella debut on April 12, led by Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel, in a unique collaboration with various artists, including vocalists Laufey, Becky G, and Maren Morris. The performance featured classical pieces, such as Johann Sebastian Bach's "Toccata and Fugue in D Minor," alongside popular songs like Zedd's "Clarity" and LL Cool J's "Mama Said Knock You Out." The event marked the first time a major orchestra performed at Coachella, aiming to reach new audiences and expand the festival's musical scope.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong - then the Acting Minister for Culture, Community and Youth - surprised the audience at the ChildAid 2012 charity concert with an impromptu performance.

site_title: Punch-drunk traders across Asia ready for another week of drama
summary: Asian traders are bracing for another week of market volatility as US President Donald Trump's trade policy decisions continue to disrupt the region. The past week saw extreme market reactions, with stocks posting their biggest-ever plunge and largest one-day gain since 2008. Japanese government bonds, credit spreads, and currency values were also significantly impacted. Investors are on edge due to the potential for quick turnarounds in Trump's policy, which has led to a "recession genie" being let out of the bottle. Traders are taking a cautious approach, with many shifting to short-term trades and being reactive rather than fundamental long-term.

images.alt_text: Taiwan’s Financial Supervisory Commission said the market stabilisation measures on short-selling of shares had “indeed had the expected effect of effectively curbing speculative selling”.

site_title: Improving carbon credit frameworks to enhance carbon project quality and financing
summary: Singapore and other countries are procuring carbon credits to meet their climate goals, but current frameworks and certifications fall short in addressing reputational risks and cash flow risks. New research from the Sustainable and Green Finance Institute (SGFIN) proposes a set of principles and requirements for carbon credit frameworks to ensure high-quality projects. Standardized project-level disclosures are crucial for increasing confidence in valuation results, facilitating external verification, and overcoming quality concerns in the voluntary carbon market. Countries like Singapore are accelerating their procurement strategies, and standardized disclosures can support the quality of credits selected for use in sector-specific carbon credits trading mechanisms.

images.alt_text: India accounts for about half of Sembcorp’s installed and upcoming solar and wind capacity.

Containers on a Cosco Shipping cargo ship to be unloaded at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2025. site_title: Britain makes £20b export finance support available amid tariff turmoil
summary: Britain is increasing its export finance support by £20 billion, raising its lending capacity to £80 billion, to help exporters affected by US tariffs. The move aims to provide stability and certainty for UK businesses amid global trade uncertainty. Up to £10 billion will be set aside to support those most affected by the tariffs in the short term. Finance Minister Rachel Reeves stated that the announcement will benefit thousands of businesses across the country, supporting them to navigate the challenges ahead in the new era of global trade.

site_title: Chinese manufacturers in fighting spirits despite scrapped US orders
summary: Chinese manufacturers are bracing for the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs, which have increased to 145% on Chinese goods. The World Trade Organization estimates the tit-for-tat could reduce US-China trade in goods by 80%. Despite the uncertainty, many Chinese factory owners, such as those in Zhejiang province, say they are united and willing to weather the storm, having diversified their client bases and developed new markets. Some companies are redirecting US products to other countries or domestically, while others are focusing on developing new products for international markets.

images.alt_text: Trump’s comments cap a tumultuous week for equity and bond markets and threaten to inject more uncertainty for countries, investors and businesses grappling with his trade policies.

site_title: Hundreds of flights cancelled as strong winds sweep northern China
summary: Strong winds swept northern China on Saturday, causing 413 flight cancellations at Beijing's Capital International Airport, with over 300 trees toppled and 19 vehicles damaged. The powerful winds, part of a cold vortex system from Mongolia, also suspended train services and closed several tourist attractions. No injuries were reported, but the incident is a reminder of China's vulnerability to extreme weather due to climate change.

images.alt_text: A boy looks on as forensic investigators comb the ground for DNA evidence near a pile of twisted airplane debris at the crash site of an Ethiopian airways operated Boeing 737 MAX aircraft at Hama Quntushele village in Oromia, Ethiopia, March 16, 2019.

site_title: GE2025: Ex-army chief David Neo joins PAP’s Tampines GRC team in run-up to election
summary: Former Singapore Army Chief David Neo has joined the People's Action Party (PAP) in the Tampines Group Representation Constituency (GRC) ahead of the 2025 General Election. Neo, 47, has been introduced to various parts of Tampines and will be working with the team at events. The PAP has been refreshing its team with over 30 new candidates, and Tampines is expected to be a hotly contested constituency with up to three opposition parties vying for the five-member GRC and the Tampines Changkat single seat.

images.alt_text: This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.
Former MOF director Shawn Loh greets residents in Jalan Besar GRC at an event on Sunday together with the constituency's current MPs.

site_title: S-Reits rebound from early April sell-off
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have rebounded strongly over the past two weeks, with the iEdge S-Reit index rising 5.9% since April 11. Top performers include S-Reits with international exposure and those holding hospitality assets. Mapletree Logistics Trust and CapitaLand China Trust saw significant gains, with units rising 7.4% and 11% respectively. Despite institutional investors net selling S-Reits, retail investors remain net buyers, with total net inflows of S$261.9 million for the year-to-date. The rebound is attributed to the broader recovery in the Singapore market and the sector's weak correlation with US and global equities.

images.alt_text: In March, Singapore Reits outperformed the global Reit market.

site_title: Brent, WTI prices climb more than US$1 on possible Iran crude restriction
summary: US Energy Secretary Chris Wright suggests the US could end Iran's oil exports as part of negotiations over its nuclear program, sparking a surge in Brent and WTI crude prices by over $1. Global supply would be reduced, and China is expected to continue buying oil from Iran. The US tariff regime, including a new 125% tariff on Chinese goods, is weighing on global economic growth and reducing demand for oil, leading to volatile price swings and potential economic disruption.

images.alt_text: China will impose 125 per cent tariffs on US goods from Saturday, up from the 84% previously announced.

site_title: Chinese airline delays Boeing jet delivery as tariffs surge
summary: China's Juneyao Airlines is delaying the delivery of a Boeing 787-9 Dreamliner valued at $120 million due to US President Donald Trump's tariffs on China, which have driven up the price of big-ticket goods. The delay is the latest setback for Boeing, which is forecast to make up 20% of global aircraft demand over the next two decades. The trade war has led to companies on both sides suspending the exchange of goods, with Tesla stopping orders for US-made Model S sedans and Model X vehicles in China.

site_title: GE2025: News site founder Ariffin Sha, ex-PSP candidate Gigene Wong in SDP’s Marsiling-Yew Tee slate
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has announced its slate for the Marsiling-Yew Tee Group Representation Constituency (GRC) for the upcoming 2025 General Election. The four candidates are Gigene Wong, a former PSP candidate; Ariffin Sha, founder of alternative news site Wake Up, Singapore; Alec Tok, theatre director; and Jufri Salim, SDP's organising secretary. They will face off against a team led by Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. The SDP is emphasizing the need for a mature and civilised election campaign, focusing on issues rather than personal attacks, and promising to bring about better policies and welfare if elected.

images.alt_text: This is the largest slate of new faces in recent history, says PM Wong.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 11)
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has unveiled its Tourism 2040 road map, focusing on boosting the country's attractiveness to leisure travelers beyond its status as a transit hub and business destination. The plan aims to increase tourism receipts to S$40 billion by 2040. This move follows a record-breaking S$29.8 billion in tourism receipts in 2024.

site_title: GE2025: NSP, SDP fail in talks to avoid three-cornered fight in Sembawang GRC
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and the National Solidarity Party (NSP) failed to reach an agreement to avoid a multi-cornered fight in Sembawang GRC. SDP had proposed NSP contest in Holland-Bukit Timah GRC, but NSP rejected the proposal, citing party integrity and value of work done in Sembawang GRC. NSP will contest both Sembawang GRC and the newly formed Sembawang West SMC, while SDP's Chee Soon Juan is eyeing Sembawang West SMC.

images.alt_text: RDU secretary-general Ravi Philemon said it cannot support NSP’s intention to enter a three-way contest against the opposition Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and the PAP in Sembawang GRC.

Gabriel Lam (left), chief operating officer of Shalom International Movers, and Ng Shi Xuan, director of battery company Powermark Battery and Hardware, at the OCBC SeniorCare event at Bukit Canberra.

SDP chief Chee Soon Juan addressing reporters in Sembawang West. In February, he announced his intention to run in Bukit Batok SMC, which has since been absorbed into the new Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as markets assess tariff risks
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Friday as markets assessed the latest escalation in the US-China trade war, with China increasing tariffs on US imports to 125%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 100.2 points, or 0.25%, to 39,493.42, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The move is seen as a response to the US's latest tariff hike, putting pressure on policymakers and potentially slowing China's GDP growth.

site_title: GE2025: RDU withdraws from opposition coalition over NSP’s refusal to back down from 3-way fight
summary: Red Dot United (RDU) has withdrawn from an opposition coalition due to the National Solidarity Party's (NSP) refusal to back down from a three-way contest against the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) and the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in the Sembawang GRC. RDU secretary-general Ravi Philemon cited the need for a clean two-way fight against the PAP, citing SDP's positive position in the constituency. The decision undermines a core belief of the coalition to prioritize voters' interests.

images.alt_text: (From left) NSP members Raiyian Chia, Spencer Ng – who is the party’s secretary-general, Kevryn Lim and Zee Phay speaking to the media at Woodlands Mart on April 12.
RDU secretary-general Ravi Philemon (centre) introduced potential candidates on the evening of April 10 at Senja Hawker Centre.

site_title: Imports at busiest US port set to drop next month as tariffs hit
summary: Imports at the Port of Los Angeles are expected to decline as punitive tariffs on Chinese goods take effect, with a 10% drop predicted in the second half of the year. The port, which handles 40% of US imports from China, saw a 1.6% increase in imports last month, but tariffs now in place may lead to a sharp decline starting in May. The tariffs, imposed after China increased duties on US goods, have already started to impact US exports, with a 15% drop in loaded exports reported.

site_title: US economists say recession risk is still high after Trump pivot
summary: US economists maintain recession risk remains high at 45% despite President Trump's pause on major tariffs, citing a sharp slowdown in US economic growth and higher unemployment. Forecasts predict 0.1-0.6% growth in 2025 and 0.5-1.5% in 2026, with inflation expected to rise. The average US tariff rate remains high, and economists warn that uncertainty could lead to a recession if tariffs persist. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley issue similar forecasts, with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York predicting real GDP growth will slow to below 1%.

images.alt_text: Larry Fink, CEO of BlackRock says: “The market downturn impacts millions of ordinary people’s retirement savings.”

site_title: GE2025: ‘Integrity, empathy, purpose’, says Maliki Osman on East Coast successor Hazlina Abdul Halim
summary: Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Maliki Osman has formally endorsed Hazlina Abdul Halim as his successor in East Coast GRC, citing her qualities of integrity, empathy, and purpose. Hazlina, a 40-year-old former chief executive of Make-A-Wish Singapore, will take over the five-member group representation constituency's Siglap ward. Dr. Maliki also vouched for her ability to understand the needs of Singaporeans, drawing from her experience as a journalist and non-profit sector leader.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean (foreground, centre) leading a PAP team comprising party newcomer Valerie Lee, Senior Minister of State in the Prime Minister’s Office Desmond Tan (behind Ms Lee), Senior Minister of State (Digital Development and Information and Health) Janil Puthucheary and Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC MP Sharael Taha (behind SM Teo, partially hidden) during a visit to Pulau Ubin on Apr 11.

site_title: Trump spares smartphones, computers, other electronics from China tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has granted exclusions from tariffs on smartphones, computers, and other electronics imported largely from China, providing relief to major technology firms like Apple. The exclusions, announced late at night, apply to 20 product categories, including computers and semiconductor devices. The move aims to ease import costs for semiconductors from Taiwan and Apple iPhones produced in India. Analysts have welcomed the news, calling it "bullish" and predicting a sigh of relief for big tech firms.

images.alt_text: US consumer sentiment tumbled to the second-lowest level on record in a University of Michigan survey, as inflation expectations soared to multi-decades highs.

site_title: Group of ex-OpenAI employees back Musk's lawsuit to halt OpenAI restructure
summary: A dozen former OpenAI employees have filed a legal brief backing Elon Musk's lawsuit to halt the company's restructuring, which aims to give investors control. The former employees claim the change would "fundamentally violate" OpenAI's mission to develop AI for humanity, not corporate profit. They argue the non-profit's oversight is crucial to its strategy and mission. OpenAI denies the allegations, stating the transition won't affect its mission, but must complete the change by the end of the year to secure a $40 billion fundraising round.

images.alt_text: The Ironwood processor is geared towards the type of data crunching needed when users query software such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

site_title: UK finance minister eyes closer EU ties, warns of ‘profound’ tariff impact
summary: British finance minister Rachel Reeves plans to advocate for a "more balanced global economic and trading system" at the International Monetary Fund meeting, aiming to achieve a closer relationship with the European Union while negotiating a trade deal with the US. Reeves warns of a "profound" tariff impact, citing the US President Donald Trump's tariffs as a potential threat to Britain's economy. The UK economy has returned to growth, beating expectations, but Reeves acknowledges the challenges ahead and emphasizes the importance of international collaboration and free trade.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Rachel Reeves called the data “encouraging” but markets are far more focused on US President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

site_title: Treasury yields see biggest weekly jump since 2001 as cash flees
summary: US Treasury yields surged to their largest weekly jump in over two decades, rising 0.5 percentage points to 4.49% amid investor pullback from US assets. The sell-off, triggered by President Donald Trump's trade war, threatens to deal another blow to the US economy by pushing up borrowing costs. Investors are fleeing to other assets, such as the Swiss franc, gold, and yen, casting doubt on Treasuries' status as a safe haven. The move has sparked calls for the Federal Reserve to intervene, with some strategists suggesting quantitative easing or liquidity injections to stabilize markets.

images.alt_text: The losses came in the four trading days between Apr 3 and Apr 8, following US Trump’s announcement on global tariffs.

site_title: American consumers are getting rattled by Trump’s tariff chaos
summary: US consumer sentiment plummeted to the second-lowest level on record in a University of Michigan survey, driven by soaring inflation expectations. President Trump's tariff chaos has created uncertainty, causing financial markets to descend into chaos and China to unleash retaliatory measures. The average US tariff rate remains high, nearly 24 percentage points higher than when Trump took office. Consumers, businesses, and economists are bracing for the long-term impact, with some predicting a drag on spending and investing due to the unpredictability of Trump's trade policy.

images.alt_text: Trump’s latest 125 per cent tariff has placed the ball in Beijing’s court, as the world waits to see if China will continue to reciprocate in a tit-for-tat manner.

site_title: GE2025: PAP to refresh team with over 30 new candidates; ‘no target vote share’
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) will field over 30 new candidates in the upcoming general election, the largest slate of new faces in recent history, according to Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. The election comes in a time of global uncertainty and turbulence, with PM Wong emphasizing that "who you have in the cockpit matters." The PAP will not have a target vote share and will focus on presenting its report card on the last five years and future plans. The election will feature 18 GRCs and 15 SMCs, with the PAP's team in the Marsiling-Yew-Tee GRC remaining unchanged.

site_title: China’s retail giants pledge to help exporters go domestic amid trade war
summary: China's retail giants, including JD.com, have launched initiatives to help exporters sell products domestically amid a US-China trade war. JD.com will launch a 200 billion yuan (S$36.2 billion) fund to support domestic sales over the next year. Meanwhile, Beijing increased tariffs on US imports to 125% in response to US President Donald Trump's decision to hike duties on Chinese goods to 145%. The moves aim to reduce reliance on exports and mitigate the impact of the trade war.

site_title: Beyond Adolescence
summary: A Netflix series "Adolescence" has sparked debate on how to counter the toxic influences of social media on young males. However, the problem of male entitlement and violence is broader, fueled by older men's online content that promotes a grievance culture. This culture is evident in Donald Trump's base, who feel threatened by women's rights and anti-racist initiatives. Trump's "might is right" approach to international relations appeals to similar sentiments, highlighting the need for a more comprehensive solution to address the root causes of this issue.

site_title: Running for fitness, camaraderie and a good cause
summary: Over 12,000 participants from over 400 companies, including Amazon and Microsoft, ran the 20th edition of the JP Morgan Corporate Challenge Singapore, held on April 10 at the F1 Pit Building. The event, which started in 1977 in New York's Central Park, aims to promote teamwork, resilience, and health while supporting a local charity. This year, the event raised money for HWA, a non-profit organization enhancing the quality of life for the elderly and persons with disabilities.
