site_title: Balancing protections and flexibility during economic uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Employment Act is due for review to balance protections for employees with business flexibility during economic uncertainty. The review should aim to safeguard employees' interests while supporting businesses to thrive, without overly progressive measures that could limit workforce flexibility and undermine business competitiveness. Key proposed reforms include requiring employers to justify contract terminations, establishing a minimum essential minimum for statutory leave entitlements, and leveraging tripartism to shape workplace norms through market forces and promotion efforts.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower will conduct a review of the Employment Act with its tripartite partners.

site_title: GE2025: PSP confirms it will contest Marymount, Kebun Baru, Pioneer SMCs again
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has confirmed it will contest the Marymount, Kebun Baru, and Pioneer Single Member Constituencies (SMCs) in the upcoming general election. PSP leaders met with potential candidates and residents in the constituencies, with the party's secretary-general Leong Mun Wai saying they are looking forward to a breakthrough in Marymount. PSP has also announced its intention to contest the West Coast-Jurong West and Chua Chu Kang GRCs, with the party's founder and chairman Tan Cheng Bock confirming its return to Pioneer SMC.

site_title: US is either very close to a recession or already in one, says BlackRock CEO Larry Fink
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink says the US is either near or already in a recession due to the market downturn, particularly the impact on ordinary people's retirement savings. He attributes the shock to President Trump's tariffs, which sparked a global sell-off and the S&P 500's steepest two-day plunge since the pandemic. Fink notes that investors have put a record $950 billion in cash accounts, but sees transformative investment opportunities in AI and infrastructure demand.

site_title: InnoTek conducts buybacks following robust FY2024
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a net institutional outflow of S$14 million from Apr 17 to 24, with institutions selling stocks in the financial services and Reits sectors. Meanwhile, the telecommunications and industrials sectors saw the highest net institutional inflow. 14 primary-listed companies conducted buybacks totaling S$20.7 million, with OCBC leading the consideration tally. InnoTek, which made significant progress in FY2024, conducted its first buyback since May 2013. Net institutional outflow for the 2025 year to Apr 24 reached S$1.79 billion.

images.alt_text: Over the four trading sessions from Mar 28 to Apr 3, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional inflow of S$76 million.

site_title: US chipmakers outsourcing manufacturing will escape China’s retaliatory tariffs
summary: US chipmakers outsourcing manufacturing to countries other than China, such as Taiwan, will be exempt from China's retaliatory tariffs on US imports. China classifies US-designed chips' place of origin as Taiwan if made by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC). This exemption applies to all integrated circuits, regardless of packaging. The move aims to mitigate the impact of tariffs on the global chip supply chain, which is highly specialized and multi-country.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends whipsaw week higher as Fed comments soothe market
summary: Wall Street ended a turbulent week on a high note, with the S&P 500 and Dow notching their largest weekly percentage gains since November 2023, and the Nasdaq registering its biggest weekly percentage advance since November 2022. The gains came after Federal Reserve President Susan Collins reassured investors that the Fed is prepared to keep financial markets functioning in case of uncertainty. The week's volatility was driven by the US-China trade war and the recent hike of tariffs to an effective rate of 145%.

site_title: Russian oil shipments shift to western tankers as prices slump
summary: Russian oil shipments are shifting to western tankers as oil prices slump below the US$60 threshold, allowing for the use of western-owned or insured tankers for the first time since the US price cap was introduced in December 2022. This shift has tightened the market for western tankers in the Atlantic basin, driving up rates to ship US crude to Europe by 50% to around US$4.60 per barrel. The increased use of western ships is also boosting demand for tankers, with shipments reaching 1.7 million barrels per day in February and March.

images.alt_text: There were volatile price swings this week as US President Donald Trump’s new tariff regime forced traders to reassess the geopolitical risks facing the crude market.

site_title: More Japan households expect prices to rise: BOJ survey
summary: Japan households expect prices to rise, with 83.5% anticipating a five-year increase, up from 82.5% in the previous survey. A year ahead, 86.7% expect price rises, a quarterly increase. The Bank of Japan's survey shows rising inflation concerns among Japanese households.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, April 11, 2025
summary: Asian stocks and the US dollar sink as Trump tariff uncertainty continues to roil markets. The Singapore dollar strengthens against the US dollar, while blue-chip companies in Singapore scoop up more shares amid market volatility. The US dollar slumps against the Singapore dollar due to ongoing tariff uncertainty, causing Asian stocks to decline.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei sank more than four per cent on Friday - a day after surging more than nine per cent.
The decline in the US dollar comes amid wild swings in stocks.
Generic photos of SGX

site_title: JPMorgan Q1 profit tops estimates
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a Q1 profit of $14.6 billion, exceeding estimates, driven by record equities trading and higher fees from debt underwriting and merger advisory. CEO Jamie Dimon remained cautious on the economy amid President Trump's tariffs, citing increased market volatility and geopolitical tensions. The bank increased provisions for credit losses to $3.3 billion, warning of potential loan defaults if inflation and economic growth slow.

images.alt_text: Economic sentiment is darkening as money managers and corporate executives struggle to cope with the volatility created by US President Donald Trump’s escalating trade war.

site_title: Antitrust chiefs counter proposed cuts as tech cases advance
summary: US antitrust enforcers are pushing back against the Justice Department's proposed restructuring plan, which would cut funding for key tech cases and limit enforcement in the sector. The plan, proposed by Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche, includes closing antitrust field offices and folding teams into a centralized policy office. Antitrust division head Gail Slater has the trust of White House leadership, and her deputy, Roger Alford, is urging officials to reconsider the proposal, citing the importance of landmark cases against tech companies like Apple and Google.

images.alt_text: Copilot, Microsoft’s AI assistant, is gaining a host of new features to make it more proactive.

site_title: In face of high F&B churn, Singapore brands can learn from China peers: association chief
summary: Singapore's high food and beverage (F&B) churn rate, with 3,047 closures in 2024, is unsustainable, according to Restaurant Association of Singapore (RAS) president Benjamin Boh. Local operators can learn from Chinese peers, who are "very strong" in attracting and retaining customers. To address this, RAS is organizing an immersion trip to China and shortlisting vendors for customer-relationship management systems. The association aims to improve customer retention, tackle labor shortages, and drive cost efficiencies through technology adoption. A more diverse F&B association and greater representation of segments are also needed to address industry challenges.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Sushi Oshino will be rebranded as Sushi Ishizawa after chef-owner Koichiro Oshino decided to leave after the restaurant lease expired.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Shares down for third week after tariff whiplash
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 fell 1.8% for its third straight week, as shares lost ground due to US tariff volatility. China raised tariffs on US goods to 125% from 84%, escalating trade tensions between the two largest economies. The 90-day tariff pause shifts focus to individual trade deals, and the European Union will hold talks with US officials. Analysts expect tariffs to be used as a negotiation tool rather than a permanent source of income.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 leapt 3.7 per cent to 487.28 points on Thursday.

site_title: Snowflake continues investing in growth in an AI revolution
summary: Snowflake, a high-growth data-management platform, reported a loss of $1.3 billion in FY2025 despite a 29% revenue increase to $3.6 billion. Co-founder Benoit Dageville attributes the losses to investing in the future, stating that the company's growth will stop if it stops investing. Snowflake is focusing on free cash flow and expanding into markets like South-east Asia. The company is also working on automation to keep costs down, and is researching ways to efficiently leverage graphic processing units to improve AI model performance.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The main chipmaker for Apple and Nvidia reported revenue of NT$839.25 billion (S$34 billion) in the first three months of 2025.
Elon Musk says in a post on X that the combined company would be valued at US$80 billion.

site_title: The modern family office: Balancing legacy, innovation, and risk
summary: Family offices, once closely held structures for wealth management, have evolved into complex organizations facing various challenges and opportunities. To address these, modernized approaches emphasizing digital presence, privacy, and robust risk management strategies are crucial. Emerging models include transitioning into full-fledged asset management firms with diversified investment strategies and adopting traditional endowment-style approaches. Key advantages of these models include flexibility, cost efficiency, and strategic growth. Next-generation family members are increasingly involved in wealth management, driving innovation and diversification. To preserve wealth, family offices must prioritize risk management through cultural, structural, and legal safeguards, as well as adopt robust cybersecurity measures.

images.alt_text: Fernando Silva
Sameer Somal
S-Reits could lose out from family office investment scheme exclusion.
In March, the private banking arm of Citi launched new philanthropy advisory solutions in Asia, beginning with Singapore, amid rising client demand for such services.
The evolving co-investment environment gives ultra-high-net-worth investors greater control of their strategies.

site_title: Indonesia’s US$48 billion social security fund eyes doubling equities exposure
summary: Indonesia's US$48 billion social security fund BPJS Ketenagakerjaan aims to double its equities exposure to 20% within three years, with current exposure at around 10%. The fund has been increasing investments in big-market-cap stocks in sectors like banking, telecoms, and consumer goods, citing undervalued shares following the global turmoil. The agency targets a 13% year-on-year return in 2025 and is seeking government approval to invest in overseas markets.

images.alt_text: The nation’s currency and stock markets are also suffering due to concerns that Prabowo’s policy spending spree could eat into the country’s fiscal discipline built under previous administrations.

FILE PHOTO: Indonesian Minister of Finance Sri Mulyani Indrawati speaks before signing with U.S. Secretary of Treasury Janet Yellen a $649 million Indonesian Infrastructure and Finance Compact - a five year grant between the U.S. government's Millennium Challenge Corporation and the Government of Indonesia at the International Monetary Fund Building in Washington, D.C., U.S. April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Ken Cedeno/File Photo
Indonesia plans to buy US liquefied petroleum gas, liquefied natural gas and soybeans as part of the negotiation efforts, said chief economic minister Airlangga Hartarto.
Sri Mulyani Indrawati Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

Inflation has been very low at the start of 2025, with Indonesia recording its first annual deflation reading in more than two decades in February, as the government offered hefty discounts on some electricity prices.

Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: South-east Asia’s key garment and footwear trade dodges tariff bullet – for now
summary: US President Donald Trump has granted a 90-day reprieve to South-east Asia's key garment and footwear trade, dodging tariff hikes for Vietnam, Indonesia, and Cambodia. The three countries, which rely heavily on the US market, are bracing for steep tariff hikes, but the delay gives them time to negotiate for a win-win outcome. Analysts say the outcome of negotiations could be pivotal in determining the region's ability to maintain its appeal as a manufacturing hub and long-term investment magnet.

images.alt_text: Vietnam vows to tackle US non-tariff concerns as it seeks 45-day delay of Trump’s levy

site_title: Revolut to roll out UK stock trading amid market chaos
summary: Revolut plans to launch UK stock trading in the coming days, offering British blue-chips such as Rolls Royce and Marks & Spencer Group. The move comes amid market chaos following US President Donald Trump's plans to raise tariffs on trading partners. Revolut's UK trading customers have shown interest in diversifying their portfolios, with the firm's data showing that most opted to hold their positions during recent market volatility. The launch is expected to provide a boost to the UK government's efforts to increase interest in domestic equities.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England lowered rates to 4.5 per cent and halved its growth forecast for this year to 0.75 per cent.

site_title: Singapore shares settle lower on Friday; STI down 1.8%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 1.8% or 65.3 points to 3,512.53 on Friday, April 11. The biggest gainer was Mapletree Logistics Trust, up 0.9%. Local banks, including DBS, lost ground, with DBS settling 3.9% lower at S$38.13. The decline was part of a broader market trend, with decliners outnumbering advancers 257 to 241, and 1.5 billion shares worth S$1.9 billion transacting.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
ST20240422_202439334845 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at the SGX Centre 1, located in Shenton Way, on April 22, 2024.
Brokerages reported a surge in trading volume days amid heightened market volatility after US President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs on Wednesday (Apr 2).

site_title: Apple's iPhone 16 hits Indonesia stores after months long ban
summary: Apple's iPhone 16 has hit Indonesian stores after a months-long ban, following a deal with the government to invest $150 million in local production. The ban was imposed due to Apple's failure to meet a 40% local parts requirement. The sale of iPhone 16 models was initially prohibited, but the government allowed them to be brought into the country for personal use. This move marks a win for Apple and highlights the economic importance of Indonesia, with the country being one of the biggest markets for Apple in the Asian region.

images.alt_text: The estimate comes as US President Donald Trump zeros in on China for his trade fight.

site_title: Gold versus Bitcoin – a battle for portfolio diversification
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs have highlighted the differences between gold and cryptocurrencies as potential store of value assets. Gold recorded a new high of $3,132.43 per ounce, while Bitcoin sank 28% lower than its January peak. Despite crypto's potential to rival gold, its high correlation with the equity market and limited supply make it less attractive. Crypto's recent plunge shows its high-risk nature, and investors are shifting towards gold-backed ETFs as a safer alternative. While some believe crypto has the potential to replace gold, others argue that its superficial similarities and high-risk nature make it less suitable.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The divergence is a departure from the long-time correlation between Bitcoin and stocks, in which the digital asset typically experiences larger price swings.
Virtually every global financial hub vies to be crypto’s capital. But the writer asks: can you stomach the volatility?
Rising material costs ultimately put pressure on profit margins in the sector, which have already been traditionally thin, says SK Jewellery's spokesperson.
BMI expects gold prices to range between US$3,000 to US$3,400 per ounce over the second and third quarters of 2025.

site_title: Trump floats possible exceptions to 10% baseline tariff
summary: US President Donald Trump hinted at possible exceptions to his 10% baseline tariff on most trading partners, despite maintaining the rate as a "floor" for nations seeking trade deals. The comments came amid a tumultuous week for markets, with stocks and bond yields experiencing significant fluctuations. Trump downplayed concerns about the impact of his trade policies, saying the US dollar will remain the "currency of choice" and markets are "in great shape."

images.alt_text: The tariffs exclude companies that design chips but don’t manufacture them in the US, resulting in shares of some chipmakers to outperform on the day.

site_title: US tariffs threaten troubled Sri Lanka's recovery: IMF
summary: The US has threatened to resume 44% tariffs on Sri Lanka's merchandise exports, which could undermine the country's recovery from its worst economic meltdown. The tariffs were initially imposed before being put on hold for 90 days. Sri Lanka's exports to the US account for almost a quarter of its $12 billion in merchandise exports, making the US its largest single market. The IMF warns that resuming the tariffs would increase trade uncertainty and hinder Sri Lanka's economic recovery.

site_title: UK economy grows a robust 0.5% in February, beating expectations
summary: The UK economy expanded 0.5% in February, beating expectations, with services output growing 0.3% and manufacturing output leaping 2.2%. However, markets are focused on the potential impact of US President Trump's tariffs, which could have a "chilling effect" on output. Finance minister Rachel Reeves described the data as "encouraging," but economists warn that underlying momentum in the private sector remains feeble.

images.alt_text: A pensioner walks along a street of residential housing in Sandwich, UK, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves defended her controversial decision to cut the winter fuel allowance for most pensioners, saying it was needed to help restore order to the UK’s public finances. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei slumps on trade war worries, stronger yen
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average plummeted 2.96% to 33,585.58 on Friday, ending a volatile week as investors worried about the US-China trade war and a strong yen. The Nikkei had surged 9% on Thursday, its largest one-day gain since August, but declined as much as 5% earlier in the session. Japanese companies will announce their fiscal year outlooks starting this month, raising concerns about the market's prospects. A stronger yen tends to hurt exporter shares, with Uniqlo-owner Fast Retailing and chip-testing equipment maker Advantest losing 2.04% and 4.59%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 index of shares closed up 9.12 per cent, or 2,894.97 points, at 34,609.00 yen.

site_title: US dollar slumps against Singdollar as tariff uncertainty continues to roil markets
summary: The US dollar has fallen to its weakest point against the Singapore dollar since November 2024, weakening 0.3% to S$1.3210. The decline is amid wild stock swings and global trade uncertainty. Analysts attribute the drop to US President Donald Trump's tariff announcements, which have weakened the US dollar index by 3.5% since April 2. However, a potential policy slope easing by the Monetary Authority of Singapore may support the US dollar against the Singapore dollar, according to analysts at OCBC.

images.alt_text: The greenback dropped 1.05 per cent against the safe-haven yen to 144.70 and 0.90 per cent versus the Swiss franc after hitting a fresh six-month low at 0.8379.

site_title: Shein gains UK approval for London IPO, awaits China nod: sources
summary: Shein, a Chinese online fast-fashion retailer, has secured approval from Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) for its planned initial public offering (IPO) in London. The company, valued at $66 billion, must still secure approval from Chinese regulators, particularly the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), before the London float. The IPO is contingent on the removal of US tariffs on Chinese goods and tighter rules on duty-free shipments, which could delay the IPO schedule to the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Shein and Temu have for years surfed on that practice to send tens of billions of US dollars worth of product into the US from their network of Chinese factories.
Shein’s executive chairman Donald Tang said in an interview that a listing would help the company earn public trust and increase transparency.
Shein’s net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.
Shein shareholders are suggesting that an adjustment is needed to help get its potential initial public offering in the UK over the line.

site_title: TikTok drives ByteDance’s 29% growth while China business slows
summary: ByteDance's revenue jumped 29% to $155 billion in 2024, driven by TikTok's 63% growth to $39 billion, which accounts for a quarter of the company's topline. Net profit edged up to $33 billion. Despite international growth, ByteDance's overall growth slowed due to economic downturn in China. The company faces uncertainty over its US deal, with Amazon and AppLovin reportedly seeking to acquire it. A US ban on TikTok looms unless a deal is secured by Saturday.

images.alt_text: Trump has said he would be willing to reduce tariffs on China to get a deal done with ByteDance to sell the app used by 170 million Americans.
The president also suggested TikTok could even be part of a broader deal with China to ease the stinging tariffs he imposed on Beijing as part of a worldwide blitz of levies.
Bidders for the short video social media company are piling up, as the weekend deadline for TikTok to find a buyer approaches.
US President Donald Trump has downplayed risks that TikTok is in danger of being banned in the United States, saying he remains confident of finding a buyer for the app’s US business.

site_title: Google lays off hundreds of employees in Android, Pixel Group: The Information
summary: Google has laid off hundreds of employees in its Android, Pixel Group and Chrome browser unit, following January buyout offers to employees. The company cited a focus on becoming more nimble and operating effectively as the reason for the job reductions. This move comes after Alphabet announced plans to cut 12,000 jobs in January 2023, impacting 6% of its global workforce. The exact number of layoffs is not specified.

site_title: Facing Trump tariffs, Vietnam eyes crackdown on some China trade
summary: Vietnam is cracking down on Chinese goods being shipped to the US via its territory, in an effort to avoid punishing US tariffs. The country has agreed to start trade talks with the US, which had imposed a 46% tariff on Vietnamese goods, and is hoping to reduce the duties to 22-28%. Vietnam's government has also tightened controls on sensitive exports to China, including dual-use goods like semiconductors, and has approved US companies like Elon Musk's Starlink satellite service. The move is seen as a bid to preserve trade with the US, Vietnam's largest export market, while also avoiding antagonizing China, a top source of investment.

images.alt_text: The escalating US-China trade war will hurt both sides.
Chinese President Xi Jinping's tour of South-east Asia will last from Monday until Friday, a foreign ministry spokesperson said.
China’s economy may suffer broadly from Trump’s aggressive hike in tariffs to 145 per cent and the decoupling of the two nations.
US President Donald Trump’s latest order promises further disruptions to imports of popular low-cost imports from China, which can cover clothing and small appliances.

site_title: MG MGS5 review: A flameproof plan to rule
summary: The MG MGS5 is a family-oriented electric SUV that aims to outperform the popular BYD Atto 3 in Singapore. With a spacious cabin, sharper steering, and a tighter turning radius, the MGS5 delivers a surprisingly sporty drive. Its battery design, which pairs cells flat and lays them flat, results in a thinner battery pack, providing more space for headroom and making the car genuinely roomy in the back. The MGS5 is priced at S$165,888 and offers a range of 425km on a single charge.

images.alt_text:
steering5 - BMW 116



Credit, source: Big Fish Publishing

site_title: BlackRock misses long-term flow expectations amid Asia outflows
summary: BlackRock reported a less-than-expected $83 billion in client money to its investment funds in the first quarter, missing the $105 billion average estimate. Despite this, the firm's adjusted net income per share rose 15% to $11.30, beating analyst estimates. The company saw $4 billion in outflows from Asia-Pacific investors, its only region to decline, as investors added $107 billion to exchange-traded funds and $38 billion to fixed income.

images.alt_text: The additional pay perks reflect BlackRock’s commitment to private markets, as does a trio of recent acquisitions.
Celia Yan will remain at the firm till the middle of June, ensuring an orderly transition of her responsibilities.
The iShares Bitcoin ETP will debut with a temporary fee waiver of 10 basis points – reducing its expense ratio to 0.15 per cent until the end of the year.
BlackRock highlighted high-quality segments of the European securitised market such as collateralized loan obligations as offering attractive risk-adjusted returns.
The potential transaction shows how local investors are scooping up bargains amid the unprecedented property downturn in China, while foreign funds and companies pare exposure.
Port of Balboa at the Panama Canal; CK Hutchison will sell 43 ports in 23 countries, while keeping facilities in mainland China and Hong Kong.
CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.

site_title: Australia reveals US$460 million property splurge tied to fugitives
summary: Australia's financial crimes watchdog, Austrac, has linked a $460 million property splurge to international fugitives, with family members on Interpol's priority wanted list. The acquisition spree, detected in one week, highlights the attractiveness of Australian real estate for international criminals. Austrac's powers are expanding to oversee real estate agents, lawyers, and accountants to combat money laundering and terrorism financing, which cost Australia $69 billion annually. The watchdog aims to shut down avenues for organised crime groups, warning entities that will be subject to its new remit.

images.alt_text: The pursuit of the “Great Australian Dream” of home ownership is hurting families saddled with high mortgage payments, as Australia’s Reserve Bank had raised interest rates 13 times since 2022 before last month’s rate cut.

site_title: China hits back at Trump tariff hike, raises duties on US goods to 125%
summary: China has raised tariffs on US goods to 125% in retaliation to President Trump's tariff hike, effectively canceling out further US levies. Beijing claims the tariffs no longer make economic sense for importers to buy from America, and will ignore further US action. The move has triggered market turmoil, with Asian markets plummeting and oil and the US dollar sliding. China also announced plans to file a lawsuit with the World Trade Organization over the latest round of levies, while Trump warned that tariffs could return after the 90-day freeze.

site_title: Nickel scam accused paid S$7 million for 8 luxury cars and S$1 million for vintage car plate: dealer
summary: Alleged nickel scammer Ng Yu Zhi spent around S$7 million on eight luxury cars, including two Mercedes Benzes, two Rolls-Royce Phantoms, and one Ferrari, purchased between June 2020 and January 2021. Five of the cars were transferred to his wife and girlfriends. Ng also bought two vehicle registration plate numbers, one for S$1.1 million, for a vintage "S11T" and another for S$91,000. The luxury cars and plate numbers were purchased using cheques or bank transfers. Ng is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted about S$1.5 billion from 947 investors from 2016 to 2021.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

Finian Tan at the Supreme Court, on April 4, 2025.
Well-known venture capitalist Finian Tan told the High Court on April 3 that he was impressed by alleged fraudster Ng Yu Zhi, who was introduced to him as a successful nickel trader when they first met in August 2020.
He was taking the stand in the ongoing trial of Ng, 37, who is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted $1.45 billion from hundreds of investors over six years.
Ng is accused of cheating Dr Tan by getting him to deliver US$19.2 million (S$25.7 million) in fresh funds to Ng’s company, Envy Global Trading (EGT).
Dr Finian Tan gave evidence as a prosecution witness and alleged victim in the trial of Ng Yu Zhi.
Finian Tan (above), the founder and chairman of Vickers Venture Partners, was impressed with Ng Yu Zhi after their first meeting.

site_title: Bain seeks to raise at least US$7 billion for new Asia PE fund
summary: Bain Capital, a US private equity firm, is seeking to raise at least $7 billion for its Asia fund and $2.1 billion for a special situation fund. The company plans to focus on private equity and credit deals in countries such as Japan and India, following a slowdown in private equity fundraising in Asia due to the global economic outlook. Bain has backed companies in the consumer care and healthcare sectors in China and is bolstering its presence in Japan and India. The firm's fundraising efforts come as investors reassess their dealmaking pace amid uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Bain Capital and Seven & i are hammering out details of a transaction that could be announced as soon as this week.

Bain’s deliberations come as the artificial intelligence boom is forcing large corporations to increase their technology spending to upgrade outdated business software and automate more routine tasks.
Bain had said last week it might withdraw its proposal for Fuji Soft, after KKR raised its offer above Bain’s in a months-long bidding war.

site_title: US producer inflation falls in March
summary: US producer prices declined 0.4% in March, a significant drop from the revised 0.1% increase in February. This follows the March consumer price index's 0.1% decline, suggesting a decrease in demand for goods due to imposed tariffs. The 11.1% drop in gasoline prices contributed to the decline. The producer price index is 0.4% below the pre-tariff levels, and the US president's decision to roll back tariffs for most countries leaves in place higher levies on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Engines arrive on the assembly line at the General Motors (GM) manufacturing plant in Spring Hill, Tennessee, U.S., August 22, 2019. Picture taken August 22, 2019. REUTERS/Harrison McClary/File Photo

site_title: GE2025: SM Teo leads walkabout on Pulau Ubin with MPs and newcomer Valerie Lee
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean led a PAP team, including newcomer Valerie Lee, to Pulau Ubin on April 11, visiting the island ahead of the upcoming General Election. The island will be subsumed under the new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC, which will combine parts of Pasir Ris and East Coast GRCs. The team aimed to reach out to residents, with about 70 homes retaining its kampung charm and over 30 residents living there.

images.alt_text: RDU secretary-general Ravi Philemon (centre) introduced potential candidates on the evening of April 10 at Senja Hawker Centre.
SUP secretary-general Andy Zhu said his party is adamant about contesting the ward despite the presence of a “third party”. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI
The question is whether the economic uncertainty will prompt a “flight to safety” response among voters.

Former MDDI director Goh Hanyan (centre), accompanied by former Nee Soon South MP Lee Bee Wah (right), greeting residents before a Meet-the-People session at the PAP’s Nee Soon Central branch on April 7.
Former MOF director Shawn Loh greets residents in Jalan Besar GRC at an event on Sunday together with the constituency's current MPs.
From mid-2025, singles applying for BTO flats will get priority access when they buy a home near or with their parents.
Global inflation rose sharply in 2022 following the outbreak of the war in Ukraine.
Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.
Each party stands for different approaches to fiscal policy, cost of living, foreign talent and housing.
Dr Ong Lue Ping served as IMH’s head of psychology for six years between 2015 and 2021, and director of allied health from 2022 to 2024.

site_title: China won’t blink first in its fight with the US
summary: The US-China trade war is escalating, with China refusing to back down, despite US President Donald Trump's increased tariffs. China has retaliated with 84% tariffs, while Trump's latest move raises the effective tariff rate to 145% on Chinese goods. China's President Xi Jinping can withstand more economic pain than Trump, indicating Beijing is determined to "fight to the end". The trade war is expected to hurt both sides, with no clear resolution in sight.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping's tour of South-east Asia will last from Monday until Friday, a foreign ministry spokesperson said.
China’s economy may suffer broadly from Trump’s aggressive hike in tariffs to 145 per cent and the decoupling of the two nations.
Gold’s rally this year has also been fuelled by strong demand from central banks.
US President Donald Trump’s latest order promises further disruptions to imports of popular low-cost imports from China, which can cover clothing and small appliances.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment ready to cash in on growing need for healthcare-related real estate
summary: CapitaLand Investment's S$350 million wellness fund has invested around S$190 million in two luxury wellness resorts and an orthopaedic hospital in Thailand. The fund aims to capitalize on the growing need for healthcare-related real estate in South-east Asia as the region's population ages. CEO Patricia Goh notes that preventative healthcare treatment and wellness activities require physical real estate, presenting a significant opportunity for real estate players. The fund has a target equity size of S$500 million and aims to achieve an asset value of S$2.9 billion when fully deployed.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The project will be built in two phases, with construction on the hospital block and the central lift core to start by the end of the year or the first quarter of 2026.
Trump tariffs spark S-Reits sell-off but analysts say sector remains ‘safe haven’
What's next for the travel industry?

site_title: TI and Intel shares sink as China tariffs hit US-made chips
summary: China has imposed new tariffs on US-made semiconductor imports, excluding companies that design chips but don't manufacture them in the US. This has led to a decline in shares of chipmakers with US manufacturing plants, including Texas Instruments (-6.8%), Intel (-3.7%), and GlobalFoundries (-2.4%). However, companies like Nvidia (+2.2%) and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (+3.3%) have seen gains, as the tariffs are expected to benefit these companies. Analysts believe the US-China trade deal is the key factor for semi stocks, with few expecting a deal to be struck soon.

images.alt_text: China’s economy may suffer broadly from Trump’s aggressive hike in tariffs to 145 per cent and the decoupling of the two nations.

site_title: Singapore targets Mice demand, leisure travellers in Tourism 2040 road map
summary: Singapore aims to boost tourism receipts to S$47 billion to S$50 billion by 2040, driven by increased demand for Mice (meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions) and leisure travel. The country's tourism board, STB, has outlined three pillars for its Tourism 2040 road map: capturing demand from high-potential areas, strengthening Singapore's attractiveness as a leisure destination, and developing the industry. Mice receipts are expected to treble by 2040, while leisure visitors will remain a dominant contributor to overall arrivals.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
An artist impression of the downtown Mice hub. The new venue will cater to the rising demand for events and serve delegates' changing needs.
Sats JV to upgrade Marina Bay Cruise Centre, gets extension for terminal operator agreement
Singapore is hoping the new ship will help cement its place as a tourist beacon in South-east Asia and reinvigorate its post-Covid recovery.
Singapore’s 2025 tourism receipts to exceed pre-Covid levels, but arrivals still playing catch up

site_title: Top US pension funds suffer US$169 billion blow from tariffs shock
summary: Top US pension funds suffered a $169 billion loss in four trading days following US President Trump's tariff announcement. The losses are estimated to be significantly higher for the entire US public retirement system. The losses came in the trading days between Apr 3 and Apr 8, with the funds losing an estimated $249 billion for the year so far. The report warns that pension funds may face tightening cash flow in the coming years if the economic recession is prolonged.

site_title: CATL gets Hong Kong approval for this year’s biggest listing
summary: CATL, China's top battery maker, secured Hong Kong's approval for its largest-ever listing, potentially raising $5 billion, and may be the world's biggest such offering this year. The approval comes weeks after China's securities regulator cleared the plan. However, CATL's global expansion is under threat due to intensifying China-US tensions, with the company added to a US Defense Department list of firms with alleged links to the Chinese military.

images.alt_text: CATL’s listing also comes against the background of rising geopolitical tensions, which may endanger the battery maker’s global expansion.
As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.
CATL’s Hong Kong listing plan comes as the city sees increased interest for second listings from Chinese A-share companies, which are seeking to tap into overseas liquidity.

site_title: Tesla China scraps ‘order now’ option for two imported EVs
summary: Tesla has removed the "order now" option for imported Model S and Model X electric vehicles on its China website, following China's retaliatory tariffs against US President Donald Trump's 125% charge. The move affects imported models, while existing inventory remains available. The decision comes as Tesla's Shanghai factory only produces Model 3 and Model Y cars, primarily sold in China or exported to Asia. The removal of the "order now" option is a result of China's response to US trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s entry into Saudi Arabia is a fresh signal Musk has mended relations with the kingdom after a spat with Yasir Al Rumayyan, head of the US$925 billion PIF.

(FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. Tesla reported a 13 percent drop in first quarter auto sales April 2, 2025, amid lower production during factory upgrades and blowback over CEO Elon Musk's work for President Donald Trump's administration. Musk's electric vehicle company delivered 336,681 autos in the quarter ending March 31, missing analyst expectations, as it pointed to the "loss of several weeks of production" while it ramps up upgrades for its Model Y output. (Photo by Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo / AFP)
Tesla delivered 336,681 vehicles in the first three months of the year, its worst quarterly total since 2022.

site_title: Berkshire yen bond deal is its smallest ever amid trade war
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sold 90 billion yen ($834 million) in bonds, its smallest yen deal ever, amid a trade war. The offering included tranches ranging from three years to 30 years and offered higher premiums than the previous sale in October. Despite market volatility, Buffett's firm pushed ahead with the deal, reflecting optimism in the Japanese equity market. The sale is part of Berkshire's efforts to boost investments in Japanese trading houses, which have boosted the nation's stock indexes in the past.

images.alt_text: The potential yen bond deal comes after Buffett’s annual letter to shareholders in February signalled plans to increase holdings in the sector.
Berkshire Hathaway chairman and CEO Warren Buffett attends the Berkshire Hathaway Inc annual shareholders' meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, US, May 3, 2024.
Berkshire has also issued fixed-rate, yen-denominated bonds, but Buffett said it seeks “currency neutrality” and has no view on future currency changes.

site_title: Exits to remain tough for South-east Asia private equity despite uptick in 2024
summary: Private equity (PE) in South-east Asia experienced a surge in deal value to US$15 billion in 2024, up from US$9 billion in 2023, despite a tough exit environment. Singapore topped the region as an investment destination, with US$5.2 billion in deal value and 30% rise in exit values. However, investors are not exiting the amount they need to exit to meet returns expectations, citing challenging macroeconomic conditions and geopolitical tensions. Trade sales and secondary sales are expected to be the top exit routes, with investors more optimistic about returns in the next three to five years.

site_title: Alibaba’s Jack Ma wants AI to serve, not lord over, humans
summary: Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma emphasized the responsibility of technologists to ensure AI serves humanity, not lords over it. Ma, who has pivoted Alibaba into AI, stated AI should be tailored to meet people's needs, protect livelihoods, and understand humans. He also expressed the company's primary objective is artificial general intelligence, a goal to build AI systems with human-level intellectual capabilities. Ma's comments come after Alibaba's aggressive AI pivot, which has helped the company recover from years of turmoil and signal Beijing's support for a revived private sector.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma Photographer: Marlene Awaad/Bloomberg

Alibaba Cloud is expanding its platform-as-a-service options and updating its AI capabilities with the addition of its latest proprietary large language models, including its Qwen-Max and DeepSeek-like QwQ-Plus reasoning model.
Alibaba has been releasing AI products at a frenetic pace since going all-in on the technology this year.
Alibaba envisions becoming a key partner to companies developing and applying AI to the real world as models evolve.
Alibaba has been aggressively pivoting its focus to AI over the past few months, pledging to invest more than 380 billion yuan on AI infrastructure over the next three years.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, dollar sink as Trump tariff panic returns
summary: Stocks in Asia plummeted, with the Nikkei sinking over 4% on Friday, following US President Donald Trump's admission that his global tariff blitz could result in a "transition cost". The move sparked a market panic, with shares and the dollar tumbling. Gold prices reached a fresh record high amidst the uncertainty. Despite initial gains, investors remained cautious, with some markets closing at a day's low. The realisation that Trump's decision did not resolve the issue fueled further selling, leaving markets in a state of flux.

images.alt_text: The decline in the US dollar comes amid wild swings in stocks.

site_title: Issue 143: Sembcorp’s spin-off speculation; shipping’s green fuel rules
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is reportedly undertaking a strategic review of its business amid speculation about a potential spin-off of its Indian assets. The company's chairman and CEO have expressed optimism about the growth of renewable power in South-east Asia, China, and India, with capacity expected to double by 2028. Sembcorp's Indian renewables space is seen as a prime candidate for securitization, with analysts citing the country's large operational portfolio and pipeline of projects. However, the company has not ruled out the possibility of recycling capital in China, where the market is undergoing turbulence.

site_title: UN trade chief warns against tariff pain for countries
summary: UN Conference on Trade and Development head Rebeca Grynspan warned against the potential pain of tariffs for countries, particularly vulnerable ones, as the US and China consider a possible global trade war. The current uncertainty is weighing down the global economy, and Grynspan urged the US to spare poor countries from tariffs. The US has paused tariffs on most countries but raised levies on China to 145%, affecting smaller, vulnerable nations.

site_title: Hotel chain Hyatt bets on India's population boom to fuel growth
summary: Hyatt Hotels plans to open six hotels in India, targeting the country's growing population and consumer spending power. With 1.4 billion people, India is a key market for the US hotel chain, which aims to double its hotel count in the country to 100 within five years. The company expects revenue growth in the double-digit percentage range in India in fiscal 2026. This expansion follows rival Hilton Worldwide's plan to quadruple hotel rooms in India's pipeline in the same timeframe.

site_title: China trade tensions lift safe-haven gold to record high
summary: Gold prices reached an all-time high on April 11, 2025, as recession concerns and escalating US-China trade tensions fueled demand for safe-haven assets. Spot gold rose 1% to $3,205.53 an ounce, with US gold futures gaining 1.5%. The rally has seen gold gain over 21% this year, driven by strong demand from central banks.

images.alt_text: Gold, traditionally seen as a hedge against economic and political uncertainty, often thrives in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Indonesian coffee chain Fore says its IPO oversubscribed by 200 times
summary: Indonesian coffee chain Fore's initial public offering (IPO) has been oversubscribed 200 times, raising approximately $28 million in fresh funds. The company plans to use the funds to expand 140 shops across Indonesia. Fore is the first domestic coffee chain to list on the Indonesian stock exchange, and its listing is seen as a positive for the country's stock market, which fell 9% on Tuesday. The company's debut could provide a boost to Indonesia's economy, which is affected by a record-low rupiah.

site_title: Japan’s ruling camp to call for sales tax cut: Yomiuri
summary: Japan's ruling coalition is considering a temporary sales tax cut, targeting food items, to ease the economic impact of rising living costs and US tariffs. The proposed tax cut aims to cushion the blow and stabilize the economy. The measure is expected to be announced in the coming weeks.

site_title: Londoners spend less than other Brits due to pricey housing
summary: Londoners earn nearly 40% more than the UK average but spend 7% less after removing housing costs due to the city's high rent and house prices. The average home in London costs the equivalent of 11 years of earnings, exceeding the affordability threshold. This results in Londoners having less disposable income to spend on goods and services, challenging the conventional wisdom that London households enjoy higher living standards.

images.alt_text: A pensioner walks along a street of residential housing in Sandwich, UK, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
The share of overseas buyers registering with an estate agency in Britain fell to 1 per cent between January and March, the lowest level since at least 2008, according to data from broker Hamptons.

site_title: Tariff volatility to benefit SGX; Macquarie upgrades shares, lifts target price
summary: Macquarie upgraded its 12-month target price for Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares to S$13.70 from S$12.90, citing the exchange's derivatives business as a defensive option amidst tariff volatility. SGX's derivatives product offerings, including equity index futures, foreign exchange, and commodity derivatives, are expected to benefit from hedging activity. The upgrade to "outperform" from "neutral" reflects Macquarie's confidence in SGX's ability to capitalize on the current market conditions.

images.alt_text: For the January-to-March quarter, the combined turnover value of SDRs, daily leverage certificates, structured warrants and ETFs was up 13.6 per cent from the previous three-month period at S$3.6 billion.

site_title: China tech faces worry beyond tariffs after US$350 billion wipeout
summary: China's tech sector faces significant concerns beyond US tariffs, with some investors and analysts warning of potential forced delistings, restricted technology access, and sanctions from the US Department of Defense. The sector's market value has lost over $350 billion since March, despite recent gains. The US has already blacklisted Tencent Holdings and others, and the US-China trade tensions may have a broader impact on China's economy. Investors are nervous, with the cost of hedging against declines in Chinese tech giants near multi-year highs.

site_title: EU head tells FT it could tax US Big Tech if tariff talks fail
summary: European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned that the EU could tax US Big Tech if tariff talks fail, amid escalating tensions over a US-led trade war. Von der Leyen hinted at using the anti-coercion instrument, which empowers the EU to target services, including advertising revenues of digital services. The EU has insisted on a mutually beneficial agreement with the US, but von der Leyen indicated that countermeasures would be taken if negotiations fall short.

site_title: China’s Country Garden secures support from some creditors for offshore debt overhaul
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese developer, is restructuring to cut its US$16.4 billion offshore debt by 70%. The company has secured support from creditors holding 29.9% of its existing offshore bond debt. A deal is also near completion with a lender group of seven banks to reduce debt by US$3.6 billion. The restructuring aims to prevent potential liquidation and secure a reprieve until May 26.

site_title: Europe: Shares notch best day in over three years after Trump’s tariff pause
summary: European shares surged 3.7% on Thursday, their best day in over three years, after US President Donald Trump paused reciprocal tariffs on most trading partners. The pause came as the US tariffs took effect, prompting a relief rally. The Stoxx 600 index rose 487.28 points, with major regional bourses also experiencing significant gains. However, uncertainty remains, as Trump further hiked tariffs on Chinese imports and broader levies remain in effect.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 finished down 3.5 per cent at 5,268.05 on Thursday.

site_title: Big US companies went bankrupt at fastest pace since 2010: S&P
summary: Large US companies filed 188 bankruptcies in the first three months of 2025, the fastest rate in 15 years, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. This surpasses the 139 filings in the same period last year and is the highest since 2010. Companies with weaker balance sheets are facing challenges due to maturing debt at higher interest rates, leading to a surge in repeat bankruptcies over the past two years.

site_title: Novartis pledges US$23 billion US investment as tariffs loom
summary: Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis pledges a $23 billion US investment over five years to manufacture its key drugs domestically, amid US President Donald Trump's plans to impose tariffs on global drugmakers. The investment will fund seven new facilities, create 1,000 jobs, and expand three existing US facilities, with total US spending expected to reach $50 billion. This move aims to counter potential tariffs and demonstrate Novartis' focus on the US market.

site_title: Singapore eyes new Mice hub downtown as sector gets set for strong growth
summary: Singapore is planning to develop a new Mice hub in the downtown area, aiming to capture a larger share of the valuable sector. The hub will provide large-scale expo spaces that can leverage existing and upcoming amenities, including hotels and lifestyle experiences. The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) aims to treble tourism receipts contributed by the Mice sector by 2040, with the new hub expected to support this growth. The development will cater to future demand for events and serve the needs of delegates who want to engage in 'bleisure'.

site_title: China’s Xi Jinping to visit Vietnam, Malaysia and Cambodia from Apr 14 to 18
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit Vietnam, Malaysia, and Cambodia from April 14 to 18 as Beijing navigates an escalating trade war with Washington. The tour comes amid tensions between the two countries, which have been triggered by US President Donald Trump. During his visit, Xi is expected to strengthen ties with regional countries and signal a potential end to China's deflationary price wars. The trip highlights China's efforts to maintain its influence in South-east Asia amidst global trade uncertainty.

site_title: Tariffs are eating all the fun out of sushi
summary: US tariffs on Japanese ingredients, including wasabi and fish, may increase prices at high-end sushi restaurants in New York City. The tariffs, currently set at 10% but pending negotiations, could lead to significant price hikes. Restaurants like Masa and Shion 69 Leonard Street, which serve exquisite and expensive sushi, may be forced to raise prices, potentially pricing out customers. This could be an indicator of the US economy's future, as high-end sushi is a niche market that reflects the country's food preferences.

site_title: EU, China will look into setting minimum prices on electric vehicles, EU says
summary: The European Union and China have agreed to explore setting minimum prices for Chinese-made electric vehicles instead of tariffs imposed by the EU last year. EU Trade Commissioner Maros Sefcovic and Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao discussed the idea, which could potentially lift tariffs of up to 45.3% imposed on Chinese-built EVs. The talks come as the US President Donald Trump embarks on a trade war with the EU and China, and are seen as a positive step towards resolving the longstanding trade dispute.

site_title: Singapore’s STI tumbles more than 3% on Friday on continued tariff tensions
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell more than 3% on Friday due to continued tariff tensions, with the US confirming President Donald Trump's tariff hikes bring the additional rate on many Chinese products to 145%. Most STI constituents suffered losses, but some, such as the Singapore Exchange, recovered by midday. The US markets also declined, with the S&P 500 down 3.5% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 2.5%.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after sharp rally on Trump tariff reversal
summary: US stocks opened lower on April 10, 2025, after a sharp rally on President Donald Trump's move to temporarily lower tariffs on dozens of countries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 611.5 points, or 1.51%, to 39,996.93. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with losses of 103.7 and 489.5 points, respectively. The decline follows a previous day's rally, as investors adjust to the new trade policy.

site_title: Chinese tea chain Chagee launches US IPO, defying stock slump
summary: Chinese tea chain Chagee Holdings is launching a US$411 million initial public offering (IPO) despite market volatility, defying the slump. The company, which operates 6,440 tea houses with 83% year-over-year growth, will offer 14.68 million American depositary shares at $26 to $28 each. Founder Junjie Zhang will retain 89% voting power after the offering, which is being led by Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, and China International Capital. The IPO comes as other firms have paused planned listings amid market turmoil, but Chagee aims to capitalize on the growing bubble tea market forecast to reach $71 billion in three years.

site_title: YouTube star IShowSpeed woos US consumers with futuristic China tech
summary: US YouTube star IShowSpeed has sparked curiosity about Chinese technology during his recent visit to China, showcasing products from Huawei and BYD. The 20-year-old streamer, who has 38.4 million YouTube subscribers, was seen riding a luxury SUV that can float in water and buying three Huawei Mate XTs, a foldable smartphone. His unscripted manner has been praised for building trust among his audience, and his visit is expected to fuel demand for Chinese products, despite US sanctions and bans on certain technologies.

site_title: Rich Indonesians wary of Prabowo’s policies send wealth overseas
summary: Wealthy Indonesians are shifting hundreds of millions of US dollars offshore amid concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's fiscal discipline and economic stability. They are investing in gold, real estate, and cryptocurrencies, such as Tether Holdings' stablecoin USDT, to avoid scrutiny. The outflows accelerated after Prabowo came to power in October and the rupiah plunged in March. The move may have contributed to the decline in Indonesia's currency and stock markets, which are also suffering due to concerns about Prabowo's policy spending spree.

site_title: Oscars to add new award for stunts
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced plans to introduce a new Oscar award for Achievement in Stunt Design, to be presented at the 100th Academy Awards in 2027. Films released in 2027 will be eligible for the award. The move aims to recognize the technical and creative work of stunt designers, who are considered an integral part of filmmaking. The eligibility rules and voting process will be revealed in two years' time. This new category is part of the Academy's efforts to expand the Oscars to reflect the complexity of modern filmmaking.

site_title: UK recruiters report sharpest rise in job seekers since Covid-19
summary: The Recruitment and Employment Confederation reported a sharp rise in job seekers in the UK, with the pool of candidates growing at its fastest pace since December 2020. This reflects belt-tightening by firms in preparation for increased payroll taxes and the minimum wage. The jobs market may weaken further due to global uncertainty and rising employment costs. The survey suggests the Bank of England may cut interest rates again, but policymakers warn that wages are growing too quickly to meet the 2% inflation target sustainably.

summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed a 145% tariff on Chinese goods, with the additional 20% duty from earlier in the year stacking on top. The new rate targets popular low-cost imports from China, including clothing and small appliances, and also increases duties on small packages from 90 to 120%. The tariff hike, which took effect on Thursday, is part of Trump's ongoing trade tensions with China.

site_title: Buying the dip, nervous selling drive trading volumes up in Singapore amid tariff volatility
summary: Singapore's trading volumes surged amid US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement, with brokerages recording a 124% increase in trading activity and a 313% jump in trading value from Apr 1 to Apr 4. Retail investors scooped up blue-chip stocks, including local banks, while institutional investors made massive sell-offs on Apr 4. Tech stocks, including Nvidia and Tesla, were hotly traded, with "buy" orders outnumbering "sell" ones. Investors also flocked to gold ETFs as a safe-haven asset amid volatility, with trading volumes for these assets more than doubling.

site_title: The impact of US tariffs on Asian markets
summary: US tariffs on Asian markets have led to elevated volatility, with China, India, and other nations experiencing economic growth impacts. China, with fiscal capacity to cushion the blow, is pivoting towards domestic demand, while India faces near-term challenges due to a 26% tariff imposed by the US. Other Asian markets, such as Indonesia, may fare better due to reduced dependency on the US. The second-order effects on US and global demand and inflation will be critical to monitor, with potential opportunities for investors in utilities, banks, and higher dividend-yielding stocks.

Tokyo’s Nikkei surged more than eight per cent, Seoul and Singapore each piled on more than five per cent, and Sydney and Jakarta more than four per cent on Wednesday..

site_title: Osaka Expo seeks to showcase Japan’s success to the world
summary: Japan's Osaka Expo 2025 aims to showcase the country's success to the world with significant economic dividends. The event, themed "Designing Future Society for Our Lives," will run from April 13 to October 13 and is forecast to have an economic impact of around 2.75 trillion yen (S$25 billion) nationwide. The Expo will feature cutting-edge innovations, including flying car services, and will coincide with the redevelopment of Osaka's Grand Green area and the influx of upmarket hotels. To maximize its benefits, Japan must pursue a concerted national strategy that aligns its stakeholders around a single, coherent vision for its country brand.

The restrictions, announced by China's National Film Administration, will limit the number of American films imported into the country, with analysts predicting a minimal impact on the US film industry. The move comes ahead of the summer box office kickoff, potentially affecting highly anticipated releases such as "Mission Impossible – The Final Reckoning" and "The Fantastic Four".

site_title: Sats JV to upgrade Marina Bay Cruise Centre, gets extension for terminal operator agreement
summary: SATS has announced a S$40 million upgrade to Marina Bay Cruise Centre Singapore, with refurbishment works beginning in the first quarter of 2025 and expected to be completed in nine months. The upgrade is timely as the cruise centre gears up for more intensive operations, including welcoming two mega cruise ships. The Singapore Tourism Board has also extended the terminal operator agreement with SCCS by eight years, with the option to extend it for another two years. The refurbished centre will have updated amenities and facilities, increasing capacity from 6,800 to 11,700 passengers.

site_title: Singapore man accused of chip fraud wields global connections
summary: A Singaporean man, Alan Wei Zhaolun, has been charged with allegedly masking the true destinations of hundreds of millions of US dollars of American computer servers purchased by his companies, which have ties to tech leaders including Nvidia. Wei, a naturalized Singaporean, owns or helps manage at least 15 firms, including Aperia Cloud Services, and has international connections. The case highlights the global nature of the tech industry and the challenge of enforcing US export restrictions, particularly in countries like Malaysia where servers potentially containing Nvidia chips were shipped.

images.alt_text: Chinese national Li Ming was offered bail of $1 million, while Singaporeans Alan Wei Zhaolun and Aaron Woon Guo Jie were offered bail of $800,000 and $600,000, respectively.
The trio’s cases have been adjourned to Mar 7.
Shanmugam says the case is not tied directly to US export controls, and that the fraud investigation is an independent probe conducted by Singapore.

site_title: The hopeless search for Trump’s cunning plan
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs on several countries, including Cambodia (49%), Vietnam (46%), and Singapore (10%), sparking concerns about the US-China contest and potential shifts in global trade. However, experts argue that there is no coherent grand strategy behind these tariffs, contradicting Trump's goals of containing China and promoting "Liberation Day." Instead, the tariffs seem to be driven by arbitrary targets, with no clear logic or pattern. This has led to a search for a hidden plan, but ultimately, the contradictions in Trump's worldview make it difficult to attribute any grand design to him.

images.alt_text: Steel sheets are piled high at Central Steel Supply Company in Marlborough, Massachusetts. Supply-chain independence from China is a stated goal for the Trump administration.  Or, as Trump has said, “If you don’t have steel, you don’t have a country”.

A press briefing at the White House. The US desperately needs media outlets that take the trouble to discern which Trump pronouncements are backed by dedicated policymaking teams and bureaucracies, with the intent to follow through, and which are not.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats, CapitaLand Investment
summary: Sats-Creuers Cruise Services is refurbishing Marina Bay Cruise Centre Singapore to increase handling capacity and update amenities. The S$40 million upgrade will also provide new facilities. Sats shares rose 7.7% on the news. CapitaLand Investment's lodging business, Ascott, signed agreements to add 600 units to its India portfolio, growing its total portfolio to around 6,100 units. Ascott plans to increase its portfolio to 12,000 units by 2028.

site_title: Reframing social sustainability for board leadership
summary: Boards of directors play a crucial role in driving social sustainability within organizations. To effectively integrate social sustainability into their core business strategies, boards must adopt a structured approach, balancing short-term financial objectives with long-term societal goals. This includes adopting standardized reporting frameworks, prioritizing transparency and accountability, and focusing on internal governance. Innovation, such as the use of advanced technologies like AI and machine learning, can also drive social sustainability efforts. By harnessing innovation, prioritizing good governance, and demonstrating strong leadership, boards can create meaningful and lasting change, strengthening their competitive position and contributing to a more equitable and sustainable future.

images.alt_text: Regulators in major markets are starting to take a tougher stance and demand greater accountability from companies that suffer cyber lapses.
Boards need to adopt an ongoing approach to learning to adapt to emerging threats and opportunities.
Board evaluations are meant to be an exercise in self-reflection and strategic planning, providing accountability and transparency to stakeholders.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends down 3.5% as stocks resume tariff sell-off
summary: The US S&P 500 ended down 3.5% at 5,268.05 on Thursday, reversing Wednesday's 9.5% gain. Investors were disappointed by the decline, which was attributed to lingering uncertainty over President Donald Trump's trade and economic policies. Despite this, Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday. The tariff sell-off continued, with major US indices spending the day in the red.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: US consumer prices unexpectedly fall in March
summary: US consumer prices unexpectedly fell 0.1% in March, with the 12-month CPI advancing 2.4% after rising 2.8% in February. Excluding volatile food and energy components, the core CPI inflation increased 2.8% year-on-year. The decline is attributed to lower energy costs and fading price hikes. President Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods have raised inflation risks, with economists predicting a peak inflation rate of 4% this year. The Federal Reserve may resume cutting interest rates in June, citing economic risks of higher inflation and slower growth.

images.alt_text: In addition, some consumers likely tried to get ahead of future tariffs by buying products, including cars, which probably put pressure on prices.

site_title: Apple airlifts 600 tonnes of iPhones from India ‘to beat’ Trump tariffs: sources
summary: Apple chartered cargo flights to transport 600 tonnes (1.5 million) of iPhones from India to the US, bypassing President Trump's tariffs. The move is part of Apple's private strategy to build up inventory in the US market, which relies heavily on imports from China subject to the highest tariff rate of 125%. The Indian government assisted with clearing customs faster. Analysts warn that US iPhone prices could surge due to the high reliance on Chinese imports.

images.alt_text: The estimate comes as US President Donald Trump zeros in on China for his trade fight.
The next major company catalyst that investors will be watching is Apple’s quarterly earnings report, due May 1.
Apple has rapidly expanded in India after strict Covid shutdowns paralysed manufacturing at its largest iPhone plant in China.
Apple’s latest flagship iPhone currently starts at US$999 – a level that has remained constant since 2017.
The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.

site_title: Tariffs, trade and uncertainty: A perspective on US equity markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's new tariffs have sent markets into volatility, with uncertainty expected to persist in the coming weeks. While the tariffs' impact on the US economy is uncertain, the administration's goal of reshoring manufacturing and reducing the deficit through lower federal spending and new revenue sources may ultimately benefit American jobs and national security. For patient investors, there are reasons for optimism, with valuations coming down and high-quality, tariff- and recession-resistant companies available at compelling prices. Continuous innovation is seen as a durable pathway to unlocking value and sustaining growth over the long term.

images.alt_text: Fixed income funds has seen more interest from investors of late, though some analyst believe some Asian equities are up and coming.

site_title: Trump’s tariff pause leaves CEOs puzzled about what happens in 90 days
summary: US President Donald Trump temporarily lowered tariffs on dozens of countries, but kept 25% duties on aluminum, steel, and autos in place. This move, announced on Wednesday, sent global stocks soaring as investors hope for negotiations to avert a full-blown global trade war. Shoe sales in stores are down 9.5% since Trump's inauguration, and CEOs are puzzled about the 90-day timeline for the tariff pause, which may impact companies' concerns about soaring costs, falling orders, and snarled supply chains.

images.alt_text: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell US$2.28, or 3.7 per cent, to settle at US$60.07 per barrel on Thursday.
The broad-based S&P 500 finished down 3.5 per cent at 5,268.05 on Thursday.

site_title: UBS sticks to US$3 billion share buyback plan despite capital changes, global uncertainty
summary: UBS chairman Colm Kelleher reaffirmed the bank's plan to repurchase $3 billion in shares in 2025, despite looming capital rule changes and global economic uncertainty. The bank plans to buy $1 billion in the first half and up to $2 billion in the second half. Proxy adviser Ethos opposes the plan, calling it a provocation and urging the board to stop. The Swiss government is set to present new capital rules in June, which UBS chairman Kelleher warns could overregulate the bank and harm its long-term success.

images.alt_text: UBS has established offshore desks in Singapore to help cater to its clients in Australia and Japan with domestic wealth growing.

site_title: Price-friendly Hokkaido fare at new Japanese import Mare Hachikyo
summary: Mare Hachikyo, a Japanese import from Hokkaido, has opened its first outpost in Singapore at Palais Renaissance. The restaurant offers price-friendly fare, with lunch options starting from S$68 for three courses and dinner options from S$228. The food features a 90% focus on Hokkaido ingredients, including crab, uni, and ikura. Standout dishes include crab ramen with an intense, milky-thick broth and a decent spread of sashimi. The restaurant boasts a laid-back vibe and effortless hospitality, making it a wallet-friendly option for dining out in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Warm lighting and discreet interiors of Pulsii.

site_title: Regulators should encourage SGX-listed companies to conduct hybrid AGMs: NUS study
summary: A new study by the Centre for Investor Protection at NUS Business School recommends that regulators encourage Singapore Exchange-listed companies to conduct hybrid annual general meetings (AGMs), which incorporate live Q&A and real-time voting. The study found that only 17 AGMs out of 556 conducted in 2024 were held in hybrid mode, with most allowing live text chat and only a few offering live video calls. Hybrid AGMs could make meetings more accessible to shareholders and enhance participation, with the study suggesting that regulators consider recommending hybrid meetings through the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance.

site_title: Trump already slowing global trade as companies pause orders
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff plans have led to a global slowdown in trade, with companies pausing orders and cancelling shipments. Amazon has started cancelling orders from China, while Haas Automation is reducing production due to decreased demand. The uncertainty caused by Trump's tariffs is affecting business and consumer sentiment, with economists warning of a potential 1% contraction in global merchandise trade volumes this year. Despite a temporary 90-day tariff pause, the long-term impact of Trump's tariffs is expected to be significant, with average US effective tariff rates reaching 21 percentage points higher than their level at the beginning of the year.

images.alt_text: Since returning to the White House in January, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened an array of punitive measures on trading partners, only to revoke some of them at the last minute.

site_title: SC Capital Partners in talks to buy British data centre group Global Switch: sources
summary: Singapore-headquartered real estate investment manager SC Capital Partners is in talks to buy British data centre group Global Switch, valued at between US$4 billion and US$5 billion. The firm, backed by CapitaLand Investment, is the only bidder to emerge for the company, currently controlled by Chinese steelmaker Jiangsu Shagang Group. Talks are ongoing, subject to market conditions, and a deal is not guaranteed. This potential acquisition comes amid rising demand for digital infrastructure assets, driven by the growing need for artificial intelligence and cloud computing-based services.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment's group chief executive Lee Chee Koon (right) with Suchad Chiaranussati, chairman and founder of SC Capital Partners.
Ascott's Citadines Arpora Nagoa Goa, which opened in the Indian city in 2024. The expansion plans come on the back of favourable growth prospects in the Indian hospitality market, says Ascott.

site_title: Moving the needle on AI adoption
summary: Singapore has launched an S$150 million Enterprise Compute Initiative (ECI) to help businesses adopt artificial intelligence (AI) technology. The initiative aims to enable enterprises to move beyond pilot projects and adopt AI on a larger scale, driving industry-wide transformation. The ECI provides access to cloud compute credits, training programs, and grants to use consultancy services, removing implementation burdens and helping companies develop and scale AI solutions. The initiative is expected to accelerate AI adoption, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and position Singapore as a leader in AI innovation.

site_title: Automotive group Vin’s Holdings aims for greater gains in used-car space with IPO
summary: Vin's Holdings, a Singaporean automotive group, plans to list on the SGX Catalist board on April 15 with net proceeds of S$4 million. The group aims to use the funds to grow its automotive business organically and invest in IT infrastructure, including an enterprise resource planning system that integrates artificial intelligence. This follows its successful growth in the pre-owned car market from 2021 to 2023, with CEO Galvin Khong stating that the IPO will support "robust growth" for the company.

site_title: Swings in US Treasuries trigger global bond market aftershocks
summary: US Treasury yields surged and then plummeted, triggering global bond market volatility and fears of a financial dislocation reminiscent of the pandemic era. The moves led to sharp swings in markets from Australia to Japan, with policy-sensitive bonds in Australia and New Zealand plummeting and longer-tenor debt rallying. Traders are bracing for a prolonged period of negotiations on US tariffs, which may weigh on markets for months, and are looking to the world's biggest debt market for clues about borrowing costs and economic growth.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Hopes for a quick end to extreme volatility were dashed on Wall Street, with stocks and bonds staging big reversals after a White House official said the US is moving forward with tariffs on China as high as 104%.
