site_title: Football star Ronaldo creates movie studio with filmmaker Vaughn
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo and British filmmaker Matthew Vaughn have launched an independent film studio, UR•MARV, with a 50-50 joint venture. The studio will produce three action films, including two already financed and produced together. This move comes as streaming platforms like Netflix and Disney+ boost independent film producers by offering global distribution. Ronaldo, a five-time Ballon d'Or winner, has invested in various business ventures, including football clubs, hotels, and media companies. The partnership marks Ronaldo's first foray into the movie-making business.

site_title: There isn’t a practical alternative to US Treasuries
summary: US Treasuries remain the world's benchmark due to their practicality and stability. Despite market volatility, there is no viable alternative for the vast majority of investors, as the greenback holds strong demand in funding markets. Central banks report no issues with accessing the currency, and there is still a market price for securities. The current situation differs from the 2020 Treasury bond rout, but a dash to cash is evident as longer-dated US Treasuries are no longer seen as risk-free assets.

images.alt_text: After a rally in US government debt that sent the two-year yield to touch the lowest since 2022, traders are positioning for more gains and pricing in a greater chance the Federal Reserve moves most aggressively to cut interest rates to keep the economy from stalling.

site_title: Harley-Davidson explores US$1 billion-plus sale of financing arm
summary: Harley-Davidson is exploring the sale of its financing arm, Harley-Davidson Financial Services (HDFS), which could fetch at least $1 billion. The move comes as the company grapples with a lagging stock price, lacklustre sales growth, and stiff competition from rivals. HDFS could appeal to regional banks, private equity firms, and private credit players. Harley-Davidson has not made a final decision on pursuing a sale and could opt to keep the unit. A representative for the company declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: Review of the Harley Davidson Street Glide Special, Sep 21, 2023.

site_title: Euro zone consumers may be put off by inflation ‘misperception’: ECB’s Schnabel
summary: Euro zone consumers' spending may be hindered by "misperception" of inflation and income growth, according to ECB board member Isabel Schnabel. Despite real income increasing in over half of households last year, only 11% perceived this growth, leading to reluctance to spend. This "misperception" may have held back the economic recovery, as households failed to recognize their real income developments. The phenomenon was more pronounced among poorer and less financially educated households.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Isabel Schnabel, member of the German advisory board of economic experts attends the 29th Frankfurt European Banking Congress at the Old Opera house in Frankfurt, Germany November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: US allies greet Trump’s tariff U-turn with relief, and defiance
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to pause some of his most aggressive tariffs has sparked a mix of relief and bewilderment among US allies and trading partners. The move has left uncertainty about Trump's intentions and how it will affect global trade. European officials, such as Germany's chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz, are urging unity and a clear stance against protectionism, while Asian nations like South Korea and Japan are trying to navigate the changing landscape. The US tariffs remain in place, and officials are now trying to figure out how to deal with Trump's unpredictable approach, with some warning of a return to economic uncertainty and a potential spill-over into other areas.

images.alt_text: In her strongest comments yet, European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen indicated that she was ready to step up her threats of retaliation and target American services if negotiations fall short.
Rebeca Grynspan, head of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, noted that the current uncertainty was weighing down the global economy.

According to a weekly sales survey by industry association Footwear Distributors and Retailers of America, in the eleven weeks since Donald Trump’s inauguration, shoe sales in stores are down 9.5 per cent from the same period last year.

site_title: Oil settles down over 3% as investors reassess Trump’s tariff flip
summary: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 3.7% to $60.07 per barrel, settling at $2.28 lower, amid investors reassessing US President Trump's planned tariff pause. The move reverses a $2-per-barrel gain from the previous day, as investors focus on a deepening trade war between Washington and Beijing.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled up US$2.66, or 4.23 per cent, to US$65.48 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures closed US$2.77, or 4.65 per cent, higher at US$62.35 on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares rebound on Thursday, mirroring regional indices; STI up 5.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed up 5.4% on Thursday, mirroring regional indices, with the biggest gainer being Jardine Matheson, which rose 8.7%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also recovered, with DBS gaining 6.8%, OCBC 7%, and UOB 7.2%. The unexpected US tariff announcement has lifted market sentiments, with regional indices increasing, including the Kospi, Nikkei 225, and Hang Seng Index.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment’s Ascott to add 600 units to India portfolio, eyes growth in country
summary: Ascott, the lodging business of CapitaLand Investment, plans to add 600 units to its India portfolio, growing its total portfolio to around 6,100 units across 22 properties by 2028. The new units will be located in Lucknow, Thanjavur, and Goa, with three signings under its Oakwood brand. The expansion aims to increase its India portfolio to around 12,000 units by 2028, driven by favourable growth prospects in the Indian hospitality market, which is expected to double in leisure and recreation spend by 2030.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Aman Residences Tokyo boasts a spa and 25-metre pool.

site_title: 🥺 Should you take up an unpaid internship?
summary: Manpower Minister Tan See Leng advises undergraduates to take unpaid internships to gain real-world experience and improve employability in a "skills-based hiring" trend. Under this approach, companies prioritize skills over qualifications when hiring decisions are made. This trend is driven by the need for workers with adaptable skills in an uncertain job market, where Gen Zs are facing challenges in finding employment and redefining traditional roles.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 10)
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is expected to ease interest rates in its April meeting amid US President Donald Trump's tariffs, contrary to initial expectations. The Singapore stock market showed signs of recovery, with blue-chip companies buying back shares, despite US tariffs. Changi Airport was crowned the world's best airport for the 13th time, and the country's port remained the top-ranked globally for the 12th consecutive year.

images.alt_text: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 9)

site_title: Axiata seeks adviser for US$3 billion sale of tower arm
summary: Axiata Group is seeking a financial adviser to help with the potential sale of Edotco Group, a Malaysian telecommunications tower company, valued at approximately US$3 billion including debt. Axiata owns 63% of Edotco, with the remaining 37% held by a Malaysian pension fund. The sale comes after Khazanah Nasional, Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, agreed to buy Innovation Network of Japan's stake in Edotco in March, increasing its holding to 32%. Investment banks are expected to submit proposals to work on the potential sale.

images.alt_text: Khazanah is studying the impact on the economy and commodity prices, as well as possible shortages, as markets face waves of volatility following Russia's widening assault on Ukraine.

site_title: China announces quartz discovery vital to chips to rival US mine
summary: China has discovered new deposits of high-purity quartz, a crucial mineral for semiconductors and solar panels. The deposits, found in Henan and Xinjiang, aim to minimize leverage points the US has in the trade war. China's high-purity quartz production, currently dominated by US mines in North Carolina, could reduce reliance on the US. The Chinese discoveries were announced by the Ministry of Natural Resources, highlighting Beijing's efforts to secure supply lines for its high-tech industry.

site_title: Prada agrees to buy Versace for US$1.38 billion despite tariffs
summary: Prada has agreed to purchase Versace for US$1.38 billion, the largest deal in the company's 112-year history. The acquisition returns Versace to Italian ownership and aims to strengthen Prada's position as Italy's largest fashion group. The deal is expected to close in the second half of this year. This purchase could put Prada in a better position to compete with luxury rivals, while also giving Versace a chance to turn around its performance under new Italian ownership.

site_title: Volatility is set to stay. Here’s where investors can put their money amid wild market swings
summary: Global markets continue to experience volatility amid the ongoing tariff-induced tensions, with both US and global markets plummeting before rebounding. Investors are flocking to safer options such as fixed income offerings, including bonds and money market funds, with global money market funds witnessing $61.3 billion in inflows. However, some analysts see value in certain Asian equities, such as Singapore real estate investment trusts and technology stocks, as "safe-haven plays." Chinese stocks have also seen a strong rally, driven by cheap valuations and government stimulus.

PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world

site_title: Strong response to Trump tariffs likely, but China hopes to negotiate: analysts
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed a 125% tariff on Chinese goods, doubling down on his previous tariffs. China had previously responded with 34% and 84% tariff hikes on US imports. Analysts expect China to introduce fresh stimulus measures to boost its economy, potentially including fiscal and monetary measures. Beijing hopes to negotiate with the US from a position of strength, while also diversifying its trade relationships with other countries. The uncertainty caused by the tariffs is likely to cause businesses and consumers to pause their purchasing activities, and China's policymakers are expected to hold discussions on stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: WTO director general Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala warned that the world economy risked breaking into two blocs, one centred around the United States and the other China.

site_title: Going Gaga for tourism that powers Singapore’s retail real estate
summary: Singapore's tourism industry continues to drive retail real estate growth, with visitor arrivals reaching a 21% year-on-year increase in 2024 to 16.5 million. Major events like Coldplay's music video, Lady Gaga's concert, and the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix solidify the city-state's status as a global tourism hub. This has boosted retail sales, food and beverage spending, and tourism receipts, which are expected to reach an all-time high of $27.5 billion to $29 billion in 2024. The symbiotic relationship between tourism and retail continues to shape market trends, with landlords and retailers adapting to changing consumer preferences to thrive.

site_title: GE2025: Red Dot United to contest Holland-Bukit Timah GRC, introduces three potential candidates
summary: Red Dot United (RDU) has announced its plans to contest the Holland-Bukit Timah Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming Singapore General Election 2025. The party introduced three potential candidates: Fazli Talip, a 43-year-old financial consultant; Sharad Kumar, a 25-year-old assistant engineer; and Patrick Tan, a 70-year-old business owner. Two of the candidates, Talip and Kumar, are newcomers to politics. The fourth member of the team has yet to be announced.

images.alt_text: SUP secretary-general Andy Zhu said his party is adamant about contesting the ward despite the presence of a “third party”. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI

site_title: No retaliation, but deep concern: Asean decries US tariffs, upholds trade commitments
summary: Asean economic ministers have ruled out retaliation against US tariffs, affirming their commitment to trade commitments and calling for "frank and constructive" talks to prevent a deeper rupture. The 10-member bloc, representing the fifth-largest economy in the world, acknowledges the US as its largest source of foreign investment and second-biggest trading partner. Despite the escalation, Asean vowed to uphold its trade commitments, seeking "mutually acceptable solutions" to issues of common interest, including facilitating two-way trade and investment, deepening strategic trade partnerships, and enhancing supply-chain connectivity and resilience.

images.alt_text: Since returning to the White House in January, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened an array of punitive measures on trading partners, only to revoke some of them at the last minute.

site_title: Cargill’s asset network, innovation help food businesses manage market volatility
summary: Cargill, the American conglomerate, is responding to market volatility in the agribusiness sector by leveraging its asset network, innovation, and global footprint. The company is developing cocoa butter-equivalent products, such as palm oil-based alternatives, to provide affordable substitution options for food and beverage brands facing rising cocoa costs. Cargill's extensive assets, including soy crushers and palm processing facilities, also enable the company to provide supply chain resilience amid ingredients' supply crunch. This strategy is part of Cargill's broader efforts to serve regional players and grow its business in the Asia-Pacific market.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield retreats to 2.5%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a 0.18 percentage point drop in the six-month Treasury bill cut-off yield, falling to 2.5% in the latest auction. The auction received S$17.2 billion in applications for the S$7.4 billion on offer, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.32. The median yield declined to 2.4%, while the average yield fell to 2.1%. Investors are seeking to lock in returns amid concerns of potential interest rate cuts ahead.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
DBS analysts say a “wall of money” could soon flow into S-Reits, as retail investors turn away from T-bills.

site_title: Singapore biohackers turn to science to stay younger, live longer
summary: In Singapore, a growing number of "biohackers" are using advanced technologies to extend their lifespan and delay aging. They incorporate practices such as red light therapy, metabolic tracking, and supplements into their daily routines, often with promising results. Clinical tests have shown that biohackers tend to have higher metabolisms, lower inflammation, and sharper cognitive function compared to their peers. However, skeptics raise concerns about the reliability of supplements and the lack of mainstream medical oversight. Biohackers argue that they are taking a proactive approach to their health, using science-backed strategies to optimize their well-being.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
O2genes is one of the players in the longevity market, specialising in oxygen therapy.
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.

site_title: ST Engineering bags S$1.4 billion contract for Taiwan’s Taichung MRT Blue line
summary: ST Engineering secured a S$1.4 billion contract to provide turnkey rail services for Taiwan's Taichung MRT Blue line, a 24.8 km fully automated system with 20 stations. The deal, awarded by the Taichung City Government, marks ST Engineering's expansion in Taiwan's rail market. The contract scope covers 14 years and is expected to start in 2025, with ST Engineering leading project management and systems integration.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

ST Engineering announced that the Rapid Transit System Bureau of Taichung City Government has awarded a contract worth about S$1.4b to its Urban Solutions business to provide turnkey rail services for the new Taichung MRT Blue Line.

site_title: Chinese sellers on Amazon to hike prices or exit US as tariffs soar, association says
summary: Chinese sellers on Amazon are considering increasing prices or exiting the US market due to President Trump's tariff hikes, which will significantly impact China's small enterprises and manufacturers. The 125% tariff rate will overwhelm the cost structure, making it "very hard for anyone to survive in the US market," according to Shenzhen Cross-Border E-Commerce Association head Wang Xin. Some sellers may look to find new markets, while others will hike prices in the US. The tariffs will accelerate China's unemployment rate, affecting small businesses and manufacturers.

site_title: GE2025: AMK GRC heading for three-cornered fight after 2 opposition parties fail to strike deal
summary: Opposition parties in Singapore's Ang Mo Kio GRC are set for a three-cornered fight in the upcoming polls after two parties failed to reach a deal on which one would contest against the ruling PAP. The Singapore United Party (SUP) has confirmed it will contest the ward, despite the presence of the People's Power Party (PPP), which will also field a team led by party treasurer William Lim. This development is expected to make the contest more competitive.

site_title: Thailand says US tariff talks to factor in high Chinese levy
summary: Thailand is preparing for US tariff talks, considering the impact of high Chinese levies on its local manufacturing industry. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will lead a delegation to the US, aiming for a "win-win solution." The talks will focus on balancing Thailand's trade with the US and other partners, with the country offering to buy more natural gas and farm goods to reduce its trade surplus. A recent survey found 71% of Thai CEOs fear cheap Chinese imports could shut local factories, highlighting the challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: Property developers in the greater Bangkok area were saddled with about 235,000 unsold residential units at the end of last year, the most since data dating back to 2018.

Stock Exchange of Thailand said that the ban on short selling of all securities, except for market makers, and a narrower band for stock movements will be effective from Tuesday (Apr 8) and no longer than Apr 11.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei stocks index closes 9.1% higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed 9.12% higher at 34,609.00 yen on April 10, following US President Donald Trump's reversal on imposing reciprocal tariffs. The broader Topix index gained 8.09%. This upward trend was likely influenced by the reduced trade tensions between the US and other countries. The Nikkei's significant increase reflects investor optimism and a decrease in market volatility.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars stage massive rally after Trump’s tariff reversal
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged in a historic rally after US President Donald Trump paused most of his reciprocal tariffs, sparking a rebound in US stocks and a sharp pullback in Treasury yields. The Australian dollar rose 3.3% to a five-year high of US$0.6121, while the New Zealand dollar jumped 2.1% to a five-year high of US$0.5636. However, the rally was tempered by Trump's announcement that duties on China would rise to 125%, and the two countries' currencies still face near-term resistance.

images.alt_text: Australia’s defence minister Richard Marles was quick to dispel notions of Canberra and Beijing uniting in “common cause”.

The won has been one of the worst-performing emerging market currencies since then-President Yoon Suk-yeol’s short-lived martial law attempt in early December.
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment slid 6.0 per cent in April from March, more than erasing the previous month’s 4 per cent gain.

site_title: MaNaDr must ensure regulatory compliance regardless of its corporate structure: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has reiterated that MaNaDr Clinic's corporate structure does not exempt it from regulatory compliance. Despite MaNaDr's claims that its clinic operations and telemedicine platform run independently, the MOH stated that all licensees and key office holders are ultimately responsible for ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements. The MOH also emphasized that MaNaDr's use of AI tools in clinical settings raises inherent risks and ethical concerns, and the company must ensure the accuracy, confidentiality, and security of patient health records.

site_title: Citibank, Vietnam Airlines ink US$560 million loan deal to buy aircraft
summary: Vietnam Airlines has signed a US$560 million loan deal with Citibank to partially finance the purchase of Boeing 737 Max aircraft. The airline aims to buy 50 planes, with 25 to be sold and leased back. The deal is part of Vietnam's efforts to strengthen US aviation and finance ties, as the country negotiates a trade agreement with the US. The airline previously committed to spending US$10 billion on Boeing aircraft in 2023. Representatives will meet with the US Export-Import Bank to discuss loan guarantees.

images.alt_text: A Vietnam Airlines Airbus A330-200 plane prepares for landing at Noi Bai airport in Hanoi, Vietnam November 21, 2016. REUTERS/Kham

site_title: China’s consumer deflation persists as trade war poses new risks
summary: China's consumer price index declined 0.1% in March, marking the second consecutive month of deflation, as trade tensions with the US continue to pose new risks to the economy. The producer-price index also fell 2.5%, the 30th month of factory deflation. Beijing has announced plans to pump up fiscal stimulus and boost domestic consumption to counter the downward pressure on prices. The country is on track for its longest streak of economy-wide price declines since the 1960s, with the property crash yet to bottom out.

images.alt_text: About 48 per cent of employees worked in China’s services industry by 2023 and the sector contributed 56.7 per cent to total GDP last year.
Confronting persistent housing woes and deflationary pressures, Chinese policymakers unveiled a central bank-led stimulus blitz in late September.
The gain followed a 11 per cent rise in December and a 3.3 per cent decline for the whole of 2024, according to National Bureau of Statistics data.

site_title: Singapore’s RV Capital is set to join the hedge fund influx into Dubai
summary: Singapore-based RV Capital Management, a macro hedge fund managing $1 billion in assets, is set to open an office in Dubai, joining a growing number of Asian investment outfits in the UAE. The move is attributed to Dubai's tax-free status, sovereign wealth funds, and favorable time zones, making it a competitor to financial hubs like London and Hong Kong. RV Capital's CEO, Aziz Faqir, will lead the Dubai office, which is expected to be set up in the Dubai International Financial Centre.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, April 10, 2025
summary: US President Trump announces a significant shift in trade policy, lowering tariffs to 10% for most countries and raising them to 125% for China. This move has led to a surge in Asian stocks as investors react to the delay of painful tariffs. Samsung, a South Korean company, is under pressure due to the impact of US tariffs on its economy. The EU has also paused countermeasures following Trump's tariff reprieve, further boosting Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Since returning to the White House in January, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened an array of punitive measures on trading partners, only to revoke some of them at the last minute.

site_title: Philippine central bank cuts policy rate by 25 bps
summary: The Philippine central bank cut its key policy rate by 25 basis points to 5.50% to help the economy cope with global challenges, including US trade policy fallout. This move is expected to aid growth despite a more challenging external environment. The rate cut follows inflation easing to a near five-year low of 1.8% in March. The bank will continue to take a measured approach in deciding on further monetary easing. The move aims to support the country's growth target of 6.0-8.0% this year.

images.alt_text: Philippines' consumer price index rose 1.8 per cent in March, below the previous month’s 2.1 per cent rate and the 2.0 per cent median forecast in a Reuters poll.

site_title: UK housing market risks being derailed by trade war
summary: The UK housing market is at risk of being derailed by the US trade war, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. Buyer demand plunged to its lowest since September 2023, and house prices dropped 9 percentage points to 2, the lowest since August. Chief economist Simon Rubinsohn warns that price and sales expectations for the next 12 months are more positive but could be affected by the trade war's impact on the economy and the Bank of England's response.

images.alt_text: The share of overseas buyers registering with an estate agency in Britain fell to 1 per cent between January and March, the lowest level since at least 2008, according to data from broker Hamptons.

site_title: Expanding real estate options for growing businesses in Singapore
summary: Singapore is expanding its real estate options for growing businesses, offering high-spec industrial space, business parks, and suburban offices at a 44% discount to central region office rents. The government has invested S$1 billion in research infrastructure, including biosciences and medtech research, to attract life science companies. High-growth enterprises, predominantly in financial services, AI, and blockchain, are increasingly seeking cost-effective alternatives, with 36% located in industrial spaces. New developments, such as Punggol Digital District, offer green credentials and digital twin facilities for tech firms.

site_title: Gold climbs on safe-haven demand as Trump hikes China tariffs
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $3,089.17 an ounce on Thursday, driven by safe-haven demand following US President Donald Trump's decision to raise tariffs on China to 125% from 104%. The move escalated tensions between the US and China, sparking concerns about economic uncertainty. Gold is often seen as a hedge against economic and political uncertainty, typically thriving in a low-interest-rate environment. The move came despite Trump's decision to temporarily ease duties on other countries.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. site_title: Tesla’s Saudi Arabia entry puts ‘funding secured’ feud to rest
summary: Tesla has officially entered the Saudi Arabian market, marking a significant move by the company to expand its presence in the region. The move comes after a long-standing feud between Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) head Yasir Al Rumayyan appeared to have been resolved. Tesla will showcase its model lineup and prototypes at a launch event in Riyadh, facing competition from Chinese carmakers and Lucid, which has a final-assembly plant in the kingdom. The company's entry is seen as a sign of goodwill towards the Saudi government and a potential growth opportunity for Tesla.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. site_title: Focused and present: In-form Scheffler ready to conquer Augusta once more
summary: Rolex Testimonee Scottie Scheffler is set to defend his 2024 Masters title at Augusta National Golf Club, where he won by four shots last year. Scheffler, 28, credits his internal motivation and focus on the process of improvement for his success, rather than the results. He aims to continue evolving his game, particularly in his short game and putting, while maintaining a balance between his golf career and family life. Scheffler's partnership with Rolex has been a significant milestone, with a memorable advertisement featuring his 2022 Masters win.

site_title: US tariffs may cut Indonesia growth by up to 0.5 percentage points
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati says planned US tariffs could reduce the country's potential growth by 0.3-0.5 percentage points, but a 90-day pause allows time to discuss solutions. Indonesia welcomes the pause, which it believes will mitigate downside risks to economic growth. The country has set a 5.2% GDP growth target this year, with President Prabowo Subianto aiming to increase it to 8% by 2029. Indonesia's economy relies more on the domestic market, which is less affected by US tariffs.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation accelerates, signals sticky cost pressure
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation accelerated to 4.2% in March, outpacing market forecasts and highlighting persistent cost pressures. The Bank of Japan faces challenges in judging interest rate hikes amid US President Donald Trump's tariffs, which threaten to derail Japan's moderate recovery. Stubbornly high food costs and rising wages have kept consumer inflation above the 2% target for nearly three years, prompting the BOJ to consider a pause in interest rate hikes. The yen's rebound and falling commodity costs may moderate consumer inflation, but the impact of US tariffs remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Inflation has stayed at or above the BOJ’s price target for almost three years, sapping spending power, and the latest tariffs from the US are now expected to weaken the economy further.
The service sector’s slowdown is of particular concern to Japan, which counts on it to anchor growth and offset some of the drag from struggling manufacturing.

site_title: Australia rebuffs China’s appeal to ‘join hands’ in trade
summary: Australia has rebuffed China's appeal to form a "common cause" in defending trade, with Defence Minister Richard Marles stating the country will not make common cause with China. China's Ambassador to Australia, Xiao Qian, urged cooperation to counter US tariffs on Chinese goods, which have reached 125%. Australia remains a key security ally of the US and has been impacted by US tariffs on its exports. The country is instead focusing on diversifying its trade.

summary: Changi Airport was named the World's Best Airport 2025 for the 13th time at the World Airport Awards. It also won awards for World's Best Airport Dining, World's Best Airport Washrooms, and Best Airport in Asia. Doha's Hamad International Airport took second place, while Tokyo's Haneda Airport came in third. The airport's success is attributed to its customer experience, which was evaluated by travellers of over 100 nationalities. Changi Airport's CEO, Yam Kum Weng, thanked passengers for their vote of confidence, citing the airport community's commitment to service excellence.

site_title: South Korea trade envoy says Trump’s tariff pause leaves room for negotiations
summary: South Korean Trade Minister Cheong In Kyo said US President Donald Trump's tariff reprieve has created room for negotiations, as the country seeks to reduce tariffs. Cheong met US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer to discuss lowering tariff rates slapped on South Korea, following Trump's announcement of a 25% tariff on the country. The meeting aims to find a "landing zone" for trade talks, with Cheong delivering concerns about US tariffs.

site_title: Samsung under pressure as US tariffs rattle South Korean economy
summary: Samsung, the world's second-largest phone maker, is under pressure as the US threatens to impose a 46-per-cent tariff on Vietnam, where the company produces around half of its handsets. If Samsung absorbs the proposed tariff cost, it would expose approximately 33% of its smartphone operating profit, equivalent to S$3.6 billion. The company's daily operations in Vietnam remain unaffected, despite global market fluctuations.

site_title: Google launches new Ironwood chip to speed AI applications
summary: Google unveiled its seventh-generation artificial intelligence (AI) chip, Ironwood, to speed AI applications. The chip is designed for "inference" computing, performing rapid calculations to render answers in chatbots or generate responses. It boasts double the performance for the amount of energy needed compared to its Trillium chip, making it better suited for running AI applications. The Ironwood processor can work in groups of up to 9,216 chips, increasing available memory and reducing costs. This move represents a viable alternative to Nvidia's powerful AI processors, with Google's tensor processing units (TPUs) being used by its engineers and cloud service.

site_title: With Trump tariffs, economists now expect MAS easing in April meeting, with further moves ahead
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to ease monetary policy on April 14, with further moves possible in July, following US President Donald Trump's declaration of a 10% import duty on all countries. Economists now expect a "slight" slope reduction of 50 basis points, with forecasts for full-year growth ranging from 1.5% to 2.6%. The MAS's January expectation that Singapore's output for 2025 would be close to potential is now seen as unlikely, with the risk of a more sharp easing in April.

site_title: Airbus plans to buy US$2 billion worth of parts from India every year
summary: Airbus plans to increase its annual sourcing from India to $2 billion by 2030, a 43% jump from current levels. This move reflects the country's growing importance in the aviation market, with its domestic market ranked third largest. The company currently sources $1.4 billion worth of products from India, up 40% from 2022. Airbus has a pending order book of 1,800 aircraft with Indian carriers, including IndiGo and Air India. The decision is seen as a significant boost to India's aviation sector, which is expected to need 2,210 new aircraft over the next 20 years.

site_title: TSMC sales beat estimates as AI demand soars
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) reported a 42% revenue rise in the first quarter of 2025, exceeding estimates, driven by strong demand for AI servers and smartphones. The main chipmaker for Apple and Nvidia saw revenue reach NT$839.25 billion, marking its fastest growth pace since 2022. The results come ahead of US tariffs, which could disrupt electronics demand, and coincide with concerns about the impact on iPhone sales. Despite potential tariffs, TSMC remains the world's leader in advanced semiconductor production.

site_title: Billionaires score best-ever day as stocks soar on tariff pause
summary: Billionaires worldwide added a record US$304 billion to their combined net worth on Wednesday, surpassing the previous record of US$233 billion set in March 2022. The surge came after US President Donald Trump announced a pause on tariffs on some trading partners, causing the S&P 500 Index to jump its most since 2008. The largest individual gainers were Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Meta Platforms' Mark Zuckerberg, with Musk adding US$36 billion and Zuckerberg gaining almost US$26 billion.

The surge followed US President Donald Trump's announcement to delay crippling tariffs on US partners for 90 days, easing concerns of a global recession. The delay is seen as a relief for investors, with some markets experiencing their best gains on record.

summary: Singapore's healthcare spending is expected to reach S$30 billion annually by 2030, surpassing defense spending, according to Health Minister Ong Ye Kung. The majority of the funds will be allocated to building new facilities and staffing, with a significant portion going towards subsidies to keep costs down for patients. This increase is driven by an aging population, resulting in more frequent and prolonged hospital stays. Despite the rising costs, Ong assured that the quality of healthcare will not suffer, and the Government will continue to make basic healthcare affordable for Singaporeans.

site_title: Evolving Singapore’s urban planning for a world of change
summary: Singapore is shifting its urban planning approach to adapt to a rapidly changing world. The city-state's planning system, which has been successful in the past, needs to evolve to accommodate new challenges such as a slowing global economy, rising geopolitical tensions, and a changing population. The next Master Plan will prioritize relationships between people and place, government and community, and past ambition and future possibility. Key challenges include breathing new life into existing spaces, unlocking value in underutilized assets, and empowering communities. A more communicative, flexible, and collaborative approach to planning is needed to ensure Singapore's continued success.

site_title: Renminbi starts to lead the dance in Asean’s currency moves
summary: South-east Asian currencies are increasingly reacting to China's monetary moves, with the renminbi emerging as a barometer for regional currency swings. This trend is driven by deepening trade ties with China, US tariffs, and the weakening US dollar dominance. Analysts note that domestic-oriented economies such as Indonesia are now visibly reacting to the shifts in the renminbi, joining traditionally sensitive currencies like the Malaysian ringgit. This shift underscores the region's growing sensitivity to China's monetary moves.

site_title: Trump says he does not want to see US Steel go to Japan
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he does not want US Steel Corp to be sold to Japan, contradicting recent actions by his administration. The US$14 billion bid by Nippon Steel for US Steel was announced in December 2023 and has faced opposition since. Trump's comment suggests the deal's future remains uncertain, despite a national security panel reviewing the bid. Shares of US Steel fell 12% in pre-market trading following the news.

site_title: Amazon seeks partners for US$15 billion warehouse expansion plan
summary: Amazon plans to invest $15 billion in nearly 80 new logistics facilities across the US, reversing its post-pandemic construction slowdown. The facilities will serve as delivery hubs and some will include large fulfillment centers with robots. Amazon is seeking capital partners to submit proposals and is willing to lease facilities for 15-25 years. The expansion comes as the company adjusts to a softer industrial real estate market and potential trade policies.

site_title: CEOs brace for recession even after tariff reprieve boosts stocks
summary: US CEOs are bracing for a recession despite a 90-day tariff reprieve that boosted stocks. Walmart is preparing for a worsening economy by keeping prices low and taking market share from tariff-spooked shoppers. Other companies, such as Delta Air Lines, are warning of a wave of pessimism that's swamping demand and making it difficult to predict the future. This gloomy outlook is fueled by consumer expectations of higher prices and weaker spending, despite the recent tariff reprieve.

images.alt_text: Inflation is likely to be elevated, Larry Fink says, casting doubt on the Federal Reserve cutting rates multiple times this year.

site_title: Nissan taps SoftBank-backed startup Wayve for AI driving system
summary: Nissan has partnered with SoftBank-backed startup Wayve to integrate its AI driver software into the next-generation ProPilot system, set to debut in 2027. The system will be tested on Ford Mustang Mach-E and Jaguar I-Pace vehicles in the UK, US, and Germany. Wayve's technology aims to handle complex real-world driving conditions in a human-like manner, marking the first time a global automaker has announced plans to integrate its AI technology into production cars.

site_title: Cuckoo Malaysia delays IPO due to volatile global market
summary: Cuckoo Malaysia has delayed its initial public offering (IPO) by two months due to global market volatility. The IPO, initially planned for April 30, is now expected to be completed by June 24. The company had initially aimed to raise over RM470 million (S$140 million) from the offering. Cuckoo Malaysia will allow investors who have submitted their applications to withdraw from the IPO, citing the current market conditions.

site_title: How will Trump’s tariffs affect GE2025?
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs are set to significantly impact Singapore's economy, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong expressing concerns over the global trading system and world economy. The government's policy response will be crucial in steering the nation through this new economic climate. Voters are likely to judge the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) on its ability to inspire confidence amidst economic uncertainty, with a potential flight-to-safety response among voters possible, similar to the 2001 GE.

summary: China and the European Union discussed strengthening their economic and trade cooperation in response to US tariffs. In a video call, China's Commerce Minister Wang Wentao and European trade and economic security commissioner Maros Sefcovic exchanged views on trade relief and electric vehicle price commitments. The conversation occurred before US President Donald Trump's additional tariffs on China took effect, with both sides expressing readiness to deepen cooperation. The EU and China aim to negotiate and implement agreements to counter US punitive measures.

site_title: Volkswagen says first-quarter profits impacted by Trump tariffs
summary: Volkswagen, Europe's largest auto manufacturer, reported a 39% decline in first-quarter operating profit to 2.8 billion euros (S$4.2 billion) due to tariffs on car imports ordered by President Trump. The result deviates significantly from market expectations of a 4 billion euro operating profit. The tariffs, which were imposed in 2018, have had a lasting impact on Volkswagen's profits, with the company attributing the decline to increased costs and reduced sales.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 9)
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) slumped on Wednesday, with almost all counters in the red due to US tariffs. US office and China-exposed S-Reits were among the top losers. Meanwhile, COE premiums rose for most categories, with mainstream car premiums nearing S$100,000. Top economic officials from Southeast Asia will convene virtually on Thursday for talks on US tariffs' impact, but doubts linger over whether meaningful change can be achieved.

site_title: Shadow banks are too big to stay in the shadows
summary: US markets are tanking due to Trump's tariffs, risking a crisis of faith in the country's reliability as a world power and its Treasury bonds, which underpin shadow banking. Mega hedge funds, such as Citadel, have become critical to modern finance, operating with less regulation than traditional lenders. These shadow banks can invest more aggressively, taking on greater risks and earning greater rewards. As markets continue to fluctuate, there is a growing concern that the US's financial power and stability are at risk.

The evolution of finance continues to favour the biggest Wall Street banks, such as JPMorgan Chase or Goldman Sachs Group, that can spend the most on tech and have tight relationships with the biggest private-market asset managers.

site_title: France cuts its growth forecast for 2025 on tariff uncertainty
summary: France has cut its 2025 growth forecast to 0.7% due to uncertainty over world trade, following US President Donald Trump's decision to pause a massive hike in tariffs. The government initially forecast 0.9% growth, but Economy Minister Eric Lombard said the revised estimate depends on US trade negotiations. The Bank of France and French Economic Observatory also lowered their forecasts to 0.7% and 0.5% respectively. Lombard ruled out raising taxes in 2025, but warned that the US policy remains unpredictable and may have a negative impact on Europe.

images.alt_text: Co-owner Jorge Rodriguez, 50, at the Petralanda winery, Fuenmayor, Rioja region, Spain, April 1, 2025. site_title: US: Wall Street mixed at open as China raises tariffs on US goods
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, April 9, after China raised tariffs on US goods in retaliation to President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs. The Dow Jones fell 257.7 points, or 0.68%, to 37,387.91, while the S&P 500 declined 17.5 points, or 0.35%, to 4,965.28. The Nasdaq Composite rose 27.5 points, or 0.18%, to 15,295.44. The move follows Trump's tariff increase earlier in the day, which targeted Chinese goods worth $60 billion.

site_title: India approves US$7.4 billion deal to buy 26 French fighter jets
summary: India has approved a $7.4 billion deal to purchase 26 French Rafale marine fighter jets, bolstering its defense capabilities in the face of increasing Chinese assertiveness in the Indian Ocean region. The order includes four twin-seater trainer aircraft and 22 single-pilot jets, with the fleet to be based on the INS Vikrant aircraft carrier. The deal marks a shift in India's defense procurement, with France closing in on Russia as a major supplier, and is seen as a key part of India's efforts to counter China's growing influence in the region.

images.alt_text: India awards Airbus US$1.9 billion military plane order

site_title: Tight CBD supply, resilient rents could revive demand for decentralised offices
summary: Singapore's office market is expected to shift towards a tighter supply landscape from 2025 to 2027, driven by a continued decline in interest rates and steady growth of office-using employment. CBD Grade-A rents are projected to rise by 3 to 5% annually over the next five years, making decentralised offices a viable, cost-effective option for occupiers. New business park space, such as Geneo in Singapore Science Park and Punggol Digital District, could attract eligible larger tenants seeking a campus-like environment at a fraction of traditional office rental costs.

images.alt_text: Upheaval in financial markets and prospects of recession could draw investors towards stability, while the interest rate environment could turn more conducive for institutional grade asset transactions.

site_title: US inflation to show some relief ahead of tariff impact
summary: US inflation is expected to show some relief in March, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 0.1% from February, the smallest monthly gain in eight months. The drop in energy costs and moderation in food and energy categories are contributing factors. However, tariffs imposed since February on Chinese imports are expected to have an impact in the May to August period, according to economists.

site_title: Asian buyers shun US farm goods, hit by ship crunch and trade war
summary: Asian buyers are reducing purchases of US agricultural goods due to US tariffs and shipping challenges. China, the largest importer of US agricultural products, retaliated with 34% duties on US goods. Freight costs have increased, making US farm goods less attractive, and uncertainty over trade wars has discouraged imports. Benchmark Chicago soybean and wheat futures are trading near multi-month lows. Traditional buyers like Japan and South Korea may continue purchasing US wheat, but alternative suppliers in South America and the Black Sea region may fill the gap for corn and soybeans.

site_title: Singapore’s STI up around 5% as Trump takes a pause on tariffs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) surged 5% after US President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause to his reciprocal tariffs on "worst offender" countries, lowering them to 10%. The STI rallied 8.7% in morning trading, reaching 3,688.2 points, before settling at 5.09% by mid-day. This comes after eight consecutive days of losses for the index, including a 7.5% drop on Monday. The market reaction was seen as a relief rally following the US president's decision, which is expected to have a positive impact on global trade.

She claimed top executives met with Chinese officials to promote US tech and build products to appease Beijing's censors. Wynn-Williams also accused Meta of lying to Congress about its dealings with China, including deleting an account of a Chinese dissident living in the US. Meta's communications director denied the allegations, stating Wynn-Williams' testimony was "divorced from reality" and "riddled with false claims."

site_title: Malaysia to host China’s Xi from April 15 amid US tariff tensions
summary: Malaysia will host Chinese President Xi Jinping for a three-day visit from April 15 to 17, amid US tariff tensions. This marks Xi's first trip to Malaysia since Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim took office in 2022. The visit aims to boost trade relations between the two countries, with Malaysia seeking to solidify its economic and diplomatic foothold in the region amidst global trade tensions.

site_title: US asset sell-off hammers greenback against safe-haven currencies, euro
summary: The US dollar dropped 1.05% against the yen and 0.90% versus the Swiss franc after hitting a fresh six-month low due to concerns over US tariffs and their economic impact. The tariffs, including 104% duties on Chinese goods, sparked fears of a global trade war and led to a sell-off in US Treasuries. Analysts warn of a high risk of a US recession, citing a simultaneous collapse in US assets, including equities and bonds. The euro jumped 0.7% to US$1.1033, while the eurozone growth forecast was cut to 0.8% for 2025.

site_title: There is no method to Trump’s tariff madness
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade tariff policy is driven by a desire to exercise unilateral power globally, rather than addressing economic concerns. Despite promises of boosting manufacturing jobs and the economy, tariffs have led to a decline in the US dollar's value, a potential recession, and pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. The tariffs' impact on domestic workers and consumers is also uncertain, with some industries potentially losing jobs. Trump's actions appear to be driven by a desire for geopolitical influence, rather than economic benefits, with some experts drawing parallels to Nazi Germany's use of trade threats to gain power.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, April 9, 2025
summary: Asian equities experienced a selloff on Wednesday, April 9, 2025, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The US dollar reached a four-year low of US$1, while oil prices settled down. The trade-sensitive currencies in Asia, such as the Singapore dollar, were heavily impacted by the tariff turmoil. The selloff is attributed to US President Donald Trump's recent actions, which have increased tensions in the US-China trade war.

summary: UOB Kay Hian has downgraded its target price for Singapore-based air freight handler SATS to S$2.89 from S$4, citing potential risks from the US tariff war and lower global trade volumes. The analyst has cut its FY2026-2027 air cargo volume projections by 5% and reduced earnings projections by 17-18%. site_title: US exits carbon talks on shipping, urges others to follow
summary: The US has withdrawn from international talks on a proposed carbon levy for shipping, citing concerns over economic measures based on GHG emissions or fuel choice. The US rejects any efforts to impose fees on its ships and will consider "reciprocal measures" to offset any charges. The move comes as the shipping industry aims to reach net zero emissions by 2050. The US will not engage in negotiations and urges other countries to reconsider their support for the proposed GHG emissions measures.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone cost could rise 90% if it’s made in US: Bank of America report
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade fight with China could lead to a significant increase in the cost of making an iPhone if Apple moves its production to the US. A Bank of America report estimates the cost could rise 90% or more due to higher labor costs and tariffs on imported components. The report suggests Apple would need tariff waivers to make relocating manufacturing to the US viable. Apple shares have surged despite the estimate, but the stock has lost 23% this year and $479 billion in market capitalization since Trump's tariff announcement on April 2.

site_title: South Korea’s presidential front-runner Lee Jae-myung enters leadership race
summary: South Korea's opposition leader Lee Jae-myung has entered the country's presidential leadership race, vowing to drive large-scale investments in technology and talent development to stimulate economic growth. With a 34% support in a recent Gallup poll, Lee is the front-runner to become the next South Korean president, set to be held on June 3. Lee's bid aims to address economic polarisation and social conflict, following the impeachment of former president Yoon Suk Yeol for his martial law declaration.

images.alt_text: Lee Jae-myung, leader of the main opposition Democratic Party, is leading in most opinion polls, with the Gallup Poll released last Friday showing 34 per cent of respondents supporting him.

site_title: Sata CommHealth’s health and medical-care site in Bedok up for sale at S$63 million
summary: Sata CommHealth's 60-year leasehold site in Bedok, Singapore, is up for sale at S$63 million. The 60,282 sq ft site, currently occupied by the Sata CommHealth Building, will be redeveloped into a 12-storey assisted-living facility with a medical centre. The sale comes amid Singapore's ageing population and rising healthcare costs, with the site offering a rare opportunity for developers to create a new healthcare development. An expression-of-interest exercise closes on May 21.

New flats will be offered in nine estates and classified as Standard, Plus or Prime based on location.

site_title: Virgin Australia targeting June IPO despite tariff turmoil: sources
summary: Virgin Australia is moving forward with plans for an initial public offering (IPO) in June, despite market turmoil caused by US President Donald Trump's trade war. The airline's new CEO, Dave Emerson, has briefed potential domestic investors and will meet with Asian investors next week. Despite the challenges, Virgin Australia has reported successive annual profits and has a deep-pocketed cornerstone investor in Qatar Airways. The airline's IPO will be priced at a discount to Qantas, Australia's largest airline, to attract new shareholders.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways is still awaiting government approval for its purchase of a 25 per cent stake in Virgin Australia from the US private equity firm Bain Capital.

site_title: China’s central bank asks state lenders to reduce dollar purchases: sources
summary: China's central bank has asked major state-owned banks to reduce US dollar purchases and step up checks on speculative trades amid a sharp decline in the renminbi. The move aims to curb speculative trades and prevent a sharp depreciation, which could hurt market confidence. The PBOC will instead allow a modest depreciation to help exports, and is considering measures to support key enterprises. The onshore renminbi rebounded after the announcement, but the offshore renminbi still faces downward pressure due to the worsening US trade war.

site_title: South Korean presidential race in top gear as frontrunner joins
summary: South Korea's presidential election is underway after the opposition leader Lee Jae-myung indicated his intention to run, leading in most opinion polls with 34% support. The election will determine the country's next leader, who will face challenges of integrating a divided nation, shoring up an economy strained by the trade war, and countering North Korea's rising nuclear ambitions. The ruling party's former Labor Minister Kim Moon-soo also announced his candidacy, and other politicians are expected to run in the PPP primary on May 3. The election is seen as crucial for South Korea to put the country back on track after a constitutional crisis sparked by former President Yoon Suk Yeol's martial law decree.

The move is seen as a way for Amazon to reduce its exposure to tariffs, with the company buying about 40% of its products directly from vendors.

summary: Luxury travel operator Scott Dunn recommends three destinations for those seeking a deeper connection with nature, people, and culture. Latin America is ideal for nature lovers, offering breathtaking landscapes and unique wildlife encounters. The Galapagos Islands, Ecuador, and Bolivia's Salar de Uyuni are highlighted for their epic natural encounters. Grab's growth in on-demand services, financial services, and loan portfolio, as well as Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee's presence in South America, are expected to mitigate the impact of tariffs. The move sparked global economic uncertainty, with China retaliating with an 84% tariff on US goods. Trump later announced a 90-day reprieve for most tariffs, except for China, which will face the full 125% rate. The tariffs have raised concerns about trade tensions and their impact on global markets.

site_title: Europe: Shares resume selloff as trade war escalates; healthcare slumps
summary: European shares plummeted 3.5% to 469.89 points on Wednesday as the trade war between the US and China escalated, with China doubling its tariffs on US imports. Healthcare stocks fell 5.8% after US President Trump threatened more sector-specific tariffs. The Stoxx 600 is now 16% below its March high, nearing a bear market. The European Union also imposed tariffs on US imports, and rate-sensitive banks fell 3.1%.

images.alt_text: German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, February 11, 2025.    REUTERS/Staff

The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 per cent to 40,608.45 and the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 per cent to 5,456.90 on Wednesday as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect.

site_title: In China, whispers of change as some companies tell staff to work less
summary: Chinese companies, such as Midea and Haier, are implementing mandatory clock-off times for staff, with some declaring offices must be vacated by 9 pm. This shift is attributed to changes in EU labor laws, rather than social pressure, and may signal a change in the country's approach to work hours. However, analysts question whether these changes will lead to widespread adoption, citing financial insecurity and the country's long working week. The Chinese government is pushing for companies to adhere to a 44-hour weekly work limit, aiming to boost consumption and reduce reliance on exports.

images.alt_text: BYD set up shop in Shenzhen as a battery maker in 1995, before establishing an auto arm in 2003 and releasing its first car two years later.

site_title: Oil jumps 4% after Trump pauses tariffs on many countries, raises China levy
summary: US President Donald Trump paused tariffs on most countries, including Canada, while raising the tariff rate on China to 125% effective immediately. Oil prices surged 4% as a result, with Brent futures up $2.66 to $65.48 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up $2.77 to $62.35. The pause aims to encourage countries to work on a deal, but analysts say the escalating trade war continues to pressure oil prices and fuel concerns of a global recession.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled down US$1.39, or 2.16 per cent, at US$62.82 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled down US$1.12, or 1.85 per cent, at US$59.58 on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Wall Street soars on Trump tariff pause with Nasdaq up 12%
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 7.9% to 40,608.45 and the S&P 500 Index rallying 9.5% to 5,456.90. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 12.2% to 17,124.97 after US President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause in new tariffs, except for Chinese goods, which would face a 125% tariff rate. The delay lifted investor sentiment and brought the markets closer to fresh records.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange in New York City, U.S., April 8, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Silicon Valley’s loss will be China’s gain
summary: The US-China trade war is taking a toll on Silicon Valley, with President Trump's tariffs potentially hurting American tech companies more than their Chinese counterparts. China's tech sector, however, is experiencing a revitalization, driven by fresh enthusiasm for AI development and government support. While US companies struggle to navigate the uncertainty, China is poised to gain an edge in key technologies like AI and set global standards for its use. The longer-term ramifications could be far-reaching, with China's domestic tech giants emerging as winners despite initial setbacks.

images.alt_text: Russia has proved to be a tougher adversary in economic warfare for the US than Iran.
It is typical of personalistic leaders, like Trump, to pit allies (courtiers, really) against each other so that none amasses too much power.

site_title: Malaysia’s Khazanah says hard to exit private assets right now
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional is facing challenges in exiting private assets due to US President Donald Trump's global tariffs, which have roiled global markets and threatened investment returns. Managing director Amirul Feisal Wan Zahir stated that the fund is assessing its next moves amid uncertainty, with a focus on diversifying risks internationally and investing in key enablers for the Malaysian economy. Despite concerns, Amirul expressed optimism about Malaysia's economic growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Khazanah is studying the impact on the economy and commodity prices, as well as possible shortages, as markets face waves of volatility following Russia's widening assault on Ukraine.
Khazanah Nasional Berhad office which located in U.A.B building at Gat Lebuh China in George Town, Penang.
Khazanah managing director Amirul Feisal Wan Zahir was positive on Malaysia’s growth prospects due to increasing foreign direct investments, a solid domestic economy, and higher household spending.

site_title: Bank Indonesia will act boldly to maintain rupiah stability
summary: Bank Indonesia plans to intervene in the rupiah market to maintain stability, citing the recent global trade war's impact on regional currencies. The rupiah hit a record low of 16,970 per US dollar before paring losses. Despite low inflation, the central bank has limited room to cut interest rates due to its focus on stabilizing the rupiah. Indonesia's economy remains resilient, and businesses are urging the government to intervene to stabilize the exchange rate. A high-level delegation will visit the US next week to discuss tariffs and potential negotiations.

images.alt_text: Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Angel investors cite the founder as a make-or-break factor in backing startups
summary: Angel investors in Singapore cite a startup's founder as a crucial factor in deciding whether to invest in a business. Key qualities investors look for include grit, leadership, communication skills, and a willingness to listen. Great founders can turn mediocre ideas into successes, while weak founders can waste promising opportunities. According to Ashley Koh, a founder is the most important factor in early-stage startups, as they are the only constant in an unpredictable journey.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Ryan Reynolds (centre), pictured here in Disney+'s  Welcome To Wrexham, has an impressive portfolio which included a stake in Mint Mobile that was sold to a major telco for US$1.35 billion this year.

site_title: RBI cuts rates, changes stance to 'accommodative' as US tariffs add to growth risks
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut its key repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.00% for the second consecutive time, changing its monetary policy stance to "accommodative" to boost the sluggish economy amid fresh US tariffs. The tariffs have raised global growth risks and sparked financial turmoil, prompting the RBI to consider deeper rate cuts to support growth. The RBI now estimates growth at 6.5% and inflation at 4%, with economists predicting growth could be hit by 20-40 basis points due to the tariffs.

images.alt_text: The RBI says that IndusInd is well-capitalised, with a liquidity coverage ratio of 113 per cent as at Mar 9, compared with the regulatory requirement of 100 per cent.
The Reserve Bank of India had lowered its benchmark rate for the first time in almost five years last month, with rate-setters drawing comfort from softening price gains.

site_title: China-owned British car brand MG aims to double South-east Asia sales to 100,000 in next three years
summary: China-owned British car brand MG aims to double its South-east Asia sales to 100,000 in the next three years, up from around 50,000 in 2024. To support this goal, MG will add two factories in Malaysia and Vietnam, in addition to existing sites in Thailand and Indonesia. The new factories will produce MG cars, as well as vehicles from SAIC's China brands, such as Maxus and Wuling. MG will also launch three new models, including the MG S5 electric SUV, to bolster its regional sales.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The Yangwang U8 sport utility vehicle on display at the Japan Mobility Show in late 2023.

site_title: COE premiums rise for most categories; mainstream car premium nears S$100,000
summary: COE premiums rose in Singapore, with mainstream car premiums reaching S$97,724, the highest in 2025. Category A, which applies to cars with engines up to 1,600 cc, saw a 3.4% increase, while Category B, for larger and more powerful cars, rose 0.9%. The motorcycle category, D, also saw a 4% increase, driven by the introduction of popular, small-capacity models. The three-week gap between bidding rounds contributed to the price increase, with industry experts attributing it to the introduction of new EV models and increased demand.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Sky-high prices are reflective of the fact that premiums have been steadily rising over the past two decades.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei down nearly 4% on slowdown fears as US tariffs kick in
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average plummeted 3.9% to close at 31,714.03, while the broader Topix dropped 3.4% to 2,349.33, amid concerns over a potential economic slowdown and intensifying US-China trade war. The sell-off followed a 6% gain on Tuesday, marking a significant reversal. The decline reflects traders' fears of a slowdown in the global economy, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Workers walk past an electronic board showing the numbers of the Nikkei Stock Average on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo, Japan, April 8, 2025.

site_title: Nike’s 30-year gamble on Vietnam is rattled by Trump tariffs
summary: Nike's 30-year investment in Vietnam, a key supplier of 95% of its footwear production, is under threat due to US President Donald Trump's 46% tariff on goods from Vietnam. The tariff, imposed on April 9, could devastate Vietnam's manufacturing industries and force Nike to pass on costs to consumers. New CEO Elliott Hill faces a costly conundrum, with limited options to reorient the supply chain. Analysts say there's nowhere else with comparable capacity or labor costs to absorb the volume, and Vietnam's government is trying to placate Trump with offers to delay tariffs and cut tariffs on US goods.

images.alt_text: Nike is in the midst of clearing out stale inventory through heavy discounting, a consequence of fading demand for some of its biggest sneaker franchises, including Air Force 1s and Dunks.
The Adidas Samba has been the hottest sneakers for the past couple of years.
Nike is attempting to end a sales slump after a tumultuous year of corporate layoffs and the CEO change.

site_title: US considers adjusting port fee plan for Chinese vessels after pushback: sources
summary: The US is considering adjusting its proposed fee plan for Chinese vessels visiting US ports, following negative feedback from industries that claimed the idea could be economically devastating. Proposed fees could top $3 million per port call for China-built or linked vessels. Changes under consideration include delayed implementation and new fee structures to reduce costs. The US Trade Representative's proposal has sparked concerns about potential economic repercussions, leading to calls for a revised approach.

images.alt_text: The sell-off underscores how the company stands in the middle of a US-China tiff over its canal facilities in the Central American country.

US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth (second right) visits the Miraflores locks of the Panama Canal. accompanied by Panama Canal Administrator Ricaurte Vasquez (left) in Panama City, Panama, April 8, 2025.

The Port of Balboa, managed by CK Hutchison, located at the entrance to the Panama Canal in Panama City, March 12, 2025. The subsidiary of the Chinese company Hutchison Holdings has breached the contract that allows it to operate two ports in the Panama Canal, according to the result of an audit released on April 7, 2025.
China’s new curbs highlight rising US-China tensions as Trump ramps up tariffs, amid existing investment restrictions over national security and capital outflows
A view of Balboa Port after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison Holdings agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from the US.

site_title: Trump tariffs spark S-Reits sell-off but analysts say sector remains ‘safe haven’
summary: US tariffs took effect on Wednesday, sparking a sell-off in Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), with US office and China-exposed S-Reits among the top losers. Analysts attribute the decline to short-term market volatility, despite the sector being considered a "safe haven." Top decliners included Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, with declines of 10.2%, 5.9%, and 5.1%, respectively.

site_title: Global bond rout starting to sound market alarm bells
summary: A global bond rout is unfolding, with the US Treasury market experiencing intense selling pressure, driven by forced selling and a dash for cash amidst US tariffs. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose 39 basis points to 4.38%, its biggest weekly jump since 2013, and long bonds surged to 21-year highs. The rout has raised pressure on central banks and policymakers to act fast to stabilize economies facing a sharp slowdown. Hedge funds, which had borrowed to bet on small gaps between cash and futures prices, are selling, causing bond yields to soar and fall out of sync with swaps.

images.alt_text: After a rally in US government debt that sent the two-year yield to touch the lowest since 2022, traders are positioning for more gains and pricing in a greater chance the Federal Reserve moves most aggressively to cut interest rates to keep the economy from stalling.

A television station broadcasts stock market news on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Losses accelerated through world markets as trading shifted into the US on deepening concern President Donald Trump’s trade war will upend the global economy. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
The covered bonds are part of OCBC's US$10 billion global covered bond programme.

site_title: How to live longer
summary: Singapore's biohacker community is growing, with mostly men and increasingly women, focusing on optimizing their body and health through specific steps. Local biohackers share their experiences, inspiring others to adopt similar practices. The trend is popularized by figures like Bryan Johnson, who aims to live forever. Biohackers in Singapore use various methods, including diet, exercise, and technology, to enhance their well-being and potentially live longer.

site_title: Blackstone nets 9.8 billion euros for Europe property during crash
summary: Blackstone has raised 9.8 billion euros (US$10.8 billion) for its European real estate fund, Blackstone Europe Real Estate Partners VII, during a severe property market correction. This is the largest ever pool of external capital for a European real estate fund, boosting Blackstone's capital to US$47 billion across three opportunistic real estate funds. The firm has begun investing in warehouses, residential properties, data centers, and hotels, and is also exploring deals for offices again after a long hiatus.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of 70 St Mary Axe, nicknamed the 'Can of Ham', in London, Britain, October 18, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside The Blackstone Group headquarters in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
London’s office market has seen anaemic activity since interest rates started rising in 2022.
Blackstone is a major owner of commercial real estate globally and its real estate debt group manages US$77 billion of assets.

site_title: Trump says long-promised pharmaceutical tariffs due very shortly
summary: President Donald Trump announced that tariffs on pharmaceutical drugs are due to be announced "very shortly," using section 232 powers to enact levies. Trump has long complained about the lack of domestic pharmaceutical production and promised tariffs to bring more capacity into the country. He stated that the US is the "big market" and companies will "come rushing back" once the tariffs are implemented, citing the country's advantage. The exact details of the planned levy remain unclear.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s auto-related exports to the US totalled US$42.9 billion last year, according to officials.
Asia has been hit the hardest by the tariffs because of the concentration of countries that run a trade surplus with the US.

US President Donald Trump has praised trading partners for coming forward to make concessions, but also brushed aside some offers.

Co-owner Jorge Rodriguez, 50, at the Petralanda winery, Fuenmayor, Rioja region, Spain, April 1, 2025. DBS CEO Tan Su Shan says it is still too early to determine the full consequences of the trade policy shock and everyone is still digesting the tariffs' impact.

site_title: Taiwan’s AUO lowers asking price on Singapore industrial asset to S$380 million
summary: Taiwanese display maker AUO has lowered the asking price of its industrial facility in Singapore to S$380 million, down from S$400 million. The six-storey, 997,330 sq ft facility is approved for advanced flat panel display manufacturing and has a remaining land tenure of 34 years. Suitable for companies in the semiconductor, wafer fabrication, and electronics sectors, the property was first marketed last year after AUO shut down production in Singapore in December 2023.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The facility, on a massive site of 997,330 square feet, is ideally suited for semiconductor, wafer fabrication, and electronics industries.

site_title: TSMC could face US$1 billion or more fine from US probe: sources
summary: The US Department of Commerce is investigating Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) for allegedly exporting chips to China-based Sophgo, which likely ended up in Huawei's high-end AI processor, the Ascend 910B. TSMC could face a fine of $1 billion or more, twice the value of transactions that violate export control regulations. The investigation is a critical moment for US-Taiwan relations, with TSMC planning to invest $100 billion in the US and facing potential tariffs from the Trump administration.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A cargo ship full of shipping containers is seen at the port of Oakland as trade tensions escalate over U.S. tariffs, in Oakland, California, U.S., March 6, 2025. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
US President Donald Trump said he had spoken to leaders from Europe and Asia over the weekend, who hope to convince him to lower tariffs as high as 50 per cent due to take effect this week.

US National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett has denied that the tariffs were part of a strategy by US President Donald Trump to crash financial markets to pressure the US Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.
Taiwan’s stock market was closed last Thursday and Friday for a holiday and reopens on Monday, meaning investors have yet to have a chance to respond to the tariffs.
TSMC, the world’s largest contract chipmaker, will take a 20 per cent stake in the new company, the report says

site_title: Oaktree Capital puts Hong Kong commercial building on the market
summary: Oaktree Capital Management is selling a 25-storey commercial building in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district, 303 Jaffe Road, after taking ownership from real estate investor Kailong Group. The sale comes amid a tough time for commercial real estate in Hong Kong, with banks nursing losses and office vacancies at a record high. Colliers has been appointed as the sole agent to sell the property, which has retail and office space.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee said the city would feel short-term impacts from US .tariffs but would remain a free port with no plans for retaliatory measures.
Hong Kong’s Financial Secretary Paul Chan said that the imposition of reciprocal tariffs is “a bullying and unjustified act that violates WTO rules” and undermines the recovery of the global economy.
Global investors are seeing signs of improving sentiment towards China.

site_title: Singapore shares, STI continue to tumble on Wednesday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.2% or 75.78 points to 3,393.69 on Wednesday, mirroring regional indices. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB declined 2.2%, 2.6%, and 3.5% respectively. The market saw 414 decliners to 203 advancers, with 2 billion shares worth S$2.9 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
