site_title: China drives record gold ETF inflows as trade war deepens
summary: Chinese investors poured a record 7.6 billion yuan into gold-backed exchange-traded funds last week, driven by safety concerns amid escalating trade tensions. The surge comes after steep US tariffs wiped trillions off global equities, with retail investors driving the majority of recent inflows. This marks a significant increase in Chinese gold ETF inflows, four-fifths of last year's total, and could potentially rival developed-market ETFs in impact.

images.alt_text: The benchmark 10-year note yield hit a more than one-week high, making non-yielding gold less attractive.

site_title: Universal to build its first Europe theme park in the UK
summary: Universal is set to build its first European theme park in Bedford, UK, with a £50 billion investment expected to create 28,000 jobs and boost the UK economy by £50 billion by 2055. The park, which will feature rides and shows based on popular movie characters such as Shrek, Minions, and Harry Potter, is expected to attract 8.5 million visitors in its first year. Construction is expected to begin in 2025, with a planned opening in 2031.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift fans hang around the outdoor area of Kallang Wave Mall, which generally sees high footfall  during the concert periods.

A person inside a casino in the Philippines. Seven South-east Asian nations – Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos – have already legalised gambling to varying degrees.

site_title: Millennium Hotels commits S$1 million to Community Chest to support children with special needs
summary: Millennium Hotels and Resorts has committed S$1 million to Community Chest over three years, supporting over 82,000 individuals and families in need. The donation includes S$500,000 in 2025 and S$250,000 annually in 2026 and 2027, focusing on children with special needs and youth at risk. This commitment qualifies for the SG Gives matching grant, multiplying the impact of its donations.

images.alt_text: Guest of honour, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, cites an NCSS study that indicates regular volunteers have better psychological well-being.

site_title: Nearly 7 in 10 SkillsFuture learners say training has boosted work performance
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore's year-in-review found that nearly 7 in 10 learners reported improved work performance, with 64% crediting their career advancement to training. The number of participants increased to 555,000, with a 7% rise, and over 84% of respondents said course learnings were applicable to their work. The agency also reported a 35% increase in SkillsFuture Credit usage to offset course fees. To support career transitions, SSG expanded SkillsFuture Career Transition Programmes, and online learning usage jumped 9 times.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

Manpower Minister Tan See Leng (L) said he encourages  undergraduates to get work exposure during their studies. Seen beside him is KPMG Singapore's managing director Lee Sze Yeng. PHOTO: SHINTARO TAY, ST
Skills over degrees: Nearly 8 in 10 job vacancies don't require them.
Changes made to SkillsFuture schemes will ease logistical, administrative and cost burdens.
Employers are expressing concern about skills gaps hindering their business transformation, said Minister of State for Education Gan Siow Huang.

site_title: Singapore banks face nickel questions
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have pledged not to finance new coal-fired power plants, but a mining company, Harita Nickel, which primarily uses coal to power its operations, is still financed by these banks. The banks' transition finance commitments do not include nickel production, even if it is coal-powered, raising concerns about greenwashing accusations. This decision highlights the need for greater accountability in hard-to-abate sectors and the banks' potential risk of being associated with environmentally damaging activities.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Aerial view of Kawasi Village on Obi Island, where Harita Nickel's operations are located.
Harita Nickel’s Halmahera Persada Lygend processing facility on Obi Island. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: China engineers orderly yuan drop as trade war threatens growth
summary: China's central bank has guided the yuan weaker at a carefully orchestrated pace to blunt the economic impact of the trade war, but moderated the pace of its adjustment. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) weakened the yuan's daily reference rate for a fifth straight session, but state banks sold US dollars in large amounts to prop up the yuan in the onshore market. The move aims to control the pace of yuan weakness and maintain stability, despite the ongoing trade standoff with the US.

images.alt_text: Whether or not the central bank decides to let the yuan go now, China’s financial markets look set to be challenged by high volatility.
China has for years been promoting the internationalisation of its yuan and sees stability – without extreme moves in either direction – as being key to further success on that front.

site_title: Hon Hai makes case to build EVs for Japan’s automobile industry
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn, is making a case to build electric vehicles (EVs) for Japan's automobile industry. The Taiwanese manufacturer is building or refurbishing facilities in the US, Taiwan, and Thailand, and plans to expand capacity in India and the Middle East. CEO Jun Seki aims to attract Japanese carmakers to outsource their EV manufacturing, citing the company's ability to build products cheaply and effectively. Seki expects to announce partners in the near future and plans to detail its strategy at a news conference in Tokyo, with electrified cars and buses set to appear on roads in Japan and the US over the next few years.

images.alt_text: The April seminar comes shortly after two other sources said Foxconn clinched the deal to make EVs for Mitsubishi to be sold in Oceania markets, including Australia.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is pictured on top of the company's headquarters in New Taipei City, Taiwan October 31, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins/File Photo
Foxconn said in January its fourth-quarter revenue jumped 15.2 per cent to a record for that quarter on strong sales of AI servers.

site_title: RBNZ delivers fifth straight rate cut, signals more to come
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) cut interest rates for a fifth consecutive meeting, lowering the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 25 basis points to 3.5% amid global economic growth concerns. The move signals potential further reductions, citing US tariffs as a downside risk to economic activity and inflation. The RBNZ has scope to lower the OCR further if necessary, potentially below the 3% floor previously signaled in February.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) building in Wellington. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: South Korea unveils US$2 billion emergency help for carmakers after Trump tariff blow
summary: South Korea has unveiled a $2 billion emergency support package for its carmakers after US President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on auto exports. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the tariffs on South Korea's top export, with car-related exports to the US totaling $42.9 billion last year. The package includes low-cost financing, tax deferrals, and a subsidy system for electric vehicles, with the goal of maintaining the country's manufacturing base and domestic market. The government also plans to expand its support ratio from 20-80% to 30-80% to help affected companies.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators against impeached South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol gather at a rally near the Constitutional Court in Seoul, South Korea, April 4, 2025. South Korea has been effectively leaderless since December when Yoon attempted to subvert civilian rule but was quickly impeached by law.
Samsung Electronics estimated an operating profit of 6.6 trillion won (S$6.07 billion) for the January-March period, versus a 5.1 trillion won LSEG SmartEstimate.

Cargo ships are loaded with containers while docked at the port of Bangkok, in Bangkok, Thailand, April 3, 2025. Thailand, with a tariff rate of 37 per cent imposed by U.S. President Donald Trump, is one of the six countries in the Southeast Asian region slapped with much higher-than-expected traffis by the U.S. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

Cars for export at a port in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, April 2, 2025. South Korea’s exports to the United States hit a record high of US$127.8 billion in 2024, with automobiles - the top-selling product - accounting for 27 per cent of the total.

site_title: Gold eases as Treasury yields climb; trade war in focus
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $2,981.86 an ounce amid rising US Treasury yields and escalating trade tensions between the US and its key trading partners. The benchmark 10-year note yield hit a one-week high, making non-yielding gold less attractive. US Treasury yields ticked higher, while the White House confirmed country-specific tariffs of up to 50% would take effect, including steep duties on Chinese imports. The US Federal Reserve has yet to cut interest rates, and markets await the minutes of its latest policy meeting and key economic data releases.

images.alt_text: Gold, used as a safe investment during times of political and financial uncertainty, scaled an all-time peak of US$3,167.57 on Apr 3.

site_title: Johor, Singapore emerge as data centre hotspots amid Apac’s US$15.5 billion investment boom
summary: Johor, Malaysia, and Singapore are emerging as key data centre hotspots in the Asia-Pacific region, attracting record cross-border investments. Asia-Pacific received US$15.5 billion in data centre investments in 2024, with Johor expected to add 335 MW of capacity by 2027, and Singapore dominating high-margin, small-scale rack deals. The global data centre market is projected to reach US$4 trillion by 2030, with an 18% compound annual growth rate. Companies like ByteDance, Alibaba, and Sea Group are investing heavily in Johor for high-density AI infrastructure, while Singapore's data centre market remains highly competitive and valuable.

images.alt_text: Johor and Singapore are among the region’s fastest-growing markets in data centre market.
Tan Ai Leng

site_title: Will Singapore continue to attract real estate investors amid global troubles?
summary: Singapore's resilience in the global real estate market is expected to continue amid uncertainties, driven by its macroeconomic stability, pro-business environment, and supportive government policies. Despite potential trade disruptions and interest rate volatility, the country remains a top cross-border investment destination, attracting institutional and individual investors. The government's initiatives, such as the extension of the Central Business District Incentive and Strategic Development Incentive schemes, are expected to encourage redevelopment and investment in the city centre. The interest rate environment may also become more conducive for institutional grade asset transactions, benefiting investors with a long-term view.

images.alt_text: Robust sales at recent launches such as Parktown  Residence, which drew over 10,000 visitors during the first three days of public preview, reflect renewed confidence and evolving buyer demographics.

Singapore’s public housing market is well-positioned to achieve a better equilibrium between demand and supply, with price increases expected to be moderated by the upcoming influx of supply and caution among buyers.

site_title: US tariffs to significantly impact economies in Asia: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) expects US tariffs to significantly impact economies in Asia, shaving growth by a third of a percentage point in 2025 and a full percentage point in 2026. The tariffs will mainly affect countries with trade surpluses with the US, with Asia being hit the hardest. The ADB warns that countries should cooperate and engage in more trade between themselves to mitigate the impact, and governments should support their firms and workers. Permanent high tariffs may lead to unsustainable efforts to support affected industries.

images.alt_text: Australia has a large, mature electricity market with relatively few players and plenty of space for new arrivals.
Hong Kong is the world’s second-biggest market for share sales this year.

site_title: Asia’s trade-sensitive currencies whipsaw amid tariff turmoil
summary: Asia's trade-sensitive currencies experienced rapid swings amid US-China tariff turmoil, with the Korean won and Indonesian rupiah hitting multi-year lows. The Bloomberg Asia Dollar Index hovered near a record low, while the offshore Chinese yuan rebounded from a record low. Traders fear a spiraling US-China trade war will hit global growth, with South-east Asian assets bearing the brunt. Asian countries have dispatched trade delegations to the US, but a swift deal is uncertain, with the Trump administration committed to tariffs.

images.alt_text: Asia has been hit the hardest by the tariffs because of the concentration of countries that run a trade surplus with the US.
Australia has a large, mature electricity market with relatively few players and plenty of space for new arrivals.
Hong Kong is the world’s second-biggest market for share sales this year.

site_title: Asia: Equities resume selloff as Trump cranks up trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump has increased tariffs on China to over 100% amid ongoing trade tensions, causing a global selloff in equities and oil prices. Asian markets plummeted, with Tokyo's Nikkei falling over 2% and Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore losing more than 1%. The European Union is set to unveil its response next week, with France's President Emmanuel Macron calling for Washington to reconsider. The US stock market also fell, with the S&P 500 ending 1.6% lower. The market now sees a greater than 50% chance of a US recession, according to estimates.

images.alt_text: CMG20250218-LimMS01/林明顺/Caifang/预算案：拍SGX 外观 [SGX Center]
All three major indices finished firmly in the red, with the S&P 500 shedding 1.6 per cent to 4,982.77 on Tuesday, its first close below 5,000 points in nearly a year.

site_title: JPMorgan model shows recession fear in markets spiking up to 79%
summary: JPMorgan's recession indicator shows a 79% chance of an economic downturn in the US, with the small-cap Russell 2000 pricing in nearly 80% odds and the S&P 500 at 62%. The firm's strategist notes that the high probability of a recession may have lowered the bar for a rebound, but corporate bond markets have yet to price in the risk. Economists, including JPMorgan's chief US economist, forecast a 60% chance of a global recession and 0.3% real GDP growth, with many experts raising recession odds due to the escalating US trade war.

images.alt_text: A dose of humility will help the Jerome Powell-led Fed reduce the risk of another bout of slippages in analysis, forecasts, communication and policy design.

Inflation expectations play a crucial role in determining the cost of fighting actual inflation. When they remain well-anchored, as in the past five years, the Fed can manage without pushing unemployment up too high.

site_title: Malaysian glove makers will likely stay afloat in Trump tariff tsunami, but face being priced out in non-US markets
summary: Malaysian glove manufacturers are expected to weather the US tariff storm due to lower duties imposed on their exports, making Chinese-made gloves more expensive in the US. The 24% tariff on Malaysian gloves is lower than those imposed on other Asian markets, benefiting companies such as Top Glove and Riverstone. However, analysts warn that competitors could flood non-US markets, driving down average selling prices and potentially pricing out Malaysian manufacturers.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says: “Malaysia, as Asean chair, will lead efforts to present a united regional front, maintain open and resilient supply chains, and ensure Asean’s collective voice is heard clearly and firmly on the international stage.”
US President Donald Trump’s latest tariff torpedo means South-east Asian countries have their work cut out for them as they face one of their biggest tests in recent times.
Monday's slide in share prices comes amid a broader sell-off in local banking stocks.
The Straits Times index plummeted by 8.5 per cent, falling below 3,500 with a drop of more than 325 points, on Monday morning.
Semiconductors have been exempted from tariffs for now, but analysts warn that the space is hardly “immune” from future tariff threats.

site_title: Asean seeks relief at Thursday talks as US tariffs bite, but turning the tide won’t be easy
summary: Southeast Asian economic officials are convening for high-stakes talks amid mounting US tariffs, threatening the region's export-driven economies. The talks, led by Malaysia, aim to present a united front and deepen intra-regional trade ties. Analysts warn that prolonged uncertainty could weigh on capital flows and sentiment, while observers expect individual countries to avoid retaliatory measures against Washington. Negotiations are underway to lower tariffs, eliminate non-tariff barriers, and enhance rules-of-origin enforcement, but a breakthrough is unlikely, and the outcome will test Asean's institutional maturity and ability to adapt to a fragmented global economy.

An industrial Park in Bac Giang, Vietnam.  In Asia, Vietnam holds the largest share of exports to the US and has the widest trade deficit

site_title: US company resurrects the extinct dire wolf, or some version of it
summary: US company Colossal Biosciences has successfully "de-extincted" three genetically engineered wolf pups, dubbed dire wolves, created with ancient DNA from fossilized remains of the extinct species. The pups, named Romulus and Remus, and Khaleesi, were born after editing 20 genes of grey wolves to include dire wolf traits. The company claims this is the world's first successful de-extinction, but experts describe the pups as genetically modified grey wolves. The dire wolves are thriving in a secure ecological preserve and could eventually weigh up to 68 kg and stand 102 cm at the shoulder.

site_title: China retaliates with 84% tariffs on US goods as Trump tariffs kick in
summary: China has imposed 84% tariffs on US goods, effective April 10, in retaliation to US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods, which came into effect earlier on Wednesday. The European Union will also start retaliating against US tariffs on April 15. The move has sparked a global trade war, causing a significant decline in global markets, including the S&P 500, which has suffered its deepest loss since its creation in the 1950s. The US dollar has also weakened against other major currencies, and US Treasuries have extended heavy losses.

images.alt_text: Co-owner Jorge Rodriguez, 50, at the Petralanda winery, Fuenmayor, Rioja region, Spain, April 1, 2025. The Trump Administration has said it will institute a 20 per cent tariff on goods from the European Union, which would cause the price of a bottle of wine to surge past what a casual customer would usually pay.
FILE PHOTO: Nike shoes are seen displayed at a sporting goods store in New York City, New York, U.S., May 14, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar//File Photo
HSBC Holdings’s market value has dropped by almost US$30 billion on fears that its Asia-focused operations will bear the brunt of the conflict.

site_title: Malaysia central bank to look beyond interest rates amid tariff challenges
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, is shifting focus beyond interest rates to combat the impact of US tariffs, citing the country's strong investment activity and diversified trade partners. Governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour stated that monetary policy cannot resolve trade wars and emphasized the need for sustainable economic growth. Despite US levies, Bank Negara expects price stability and maintains its benchmark rate at 3% since May 2023. The central bank is also reviewing its economic growth forecast of 4.5-5.5% and assessing measures to shield the economy from tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said heightened external uncertainties that could lead to a more moderate expansion of exports.
Malaysia’s government and central bank have forecast the economy to expand between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent in 2025, following 5.1 per cent growth in 2024.

site_title: The Fed must resist repeating past mistakes
summary: The Jerome Powell-led Federal Reserve faces significant challenges as it navigates the current economic and financial volatility, including higher tariffs and a rise in inflation. The Fed's recent forecast revisions, including a predicted 5.3% unemployment rate and 4.4% inflation, have heightened the uncertainty of its policy decisions. Market participants expect the Fed to respond with looser financial conditions, but this could be counterproductive, as protracted inflation could undermine its efforts to counter rising unemployment. To mitigate these risks, the Fed needs to adopt a more humble approach, prioritizing inflation control and avoiding premature policy responses.

images.alt_text: Inflation expectations play a crucial role in determining the cost of fighting actual inflation. When they remain well-anchored, as in the past five years, the Fed can manage without pushing unemployment up too high.

"Store Closing" signs at a Forever 21 store in New York, US, on Friday, March, 21, 2025. After filing for bankruptcy, Forever 21 plans on closing its last remaining stores in the US as the brand pursues a model that is similar to its online competitors. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

site_title: Expanded tax scheme to benefit more construction companies from 2026
summary: Singapore is expanding its Land Intensification Allowance (LIA) scheme to support the development of construction facilities that use land more efficiently. The enhanced scheme will be available from January 1, 2026, and will provide tax allowances of up to 100% of qualifying capital expenditure for facilities that achieve a minimum gross plot ratio of 1.03. The scheme aims to encourage the development of construction facilities that use land more efficiently, particularly for multi-storey design for manufacturing and assembly (DfMA) facilities. The move is part of the government's effort to boost the construction sector and reduce its reliance on manpower.

images.alt_text: A significant rollout of residential projects led to higher than expected demand in 2024.

site_title: US agriculture chief says new deals may be struck over tariffs by end of week
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said new deals over trade tariffs could be struck by the end of the week, amid a backdrop of US President Donald Trump's plans to impose 10% baseline tariffs on all imports and higher duties on dozens of countries. 104% duties on imports from China will take effect shortly after midnight. Rollins stated that 70 countries have reached out for talks, and the administration has scheduled talks with South Korea and Japan, two close allies and major trading partners.

images.alt_text: A dose of humility will help the Jerome Powell-led Fed reduce the risk of another bout of slippages in analysis, forecasts, communication and policy design.

site_title: Commercial explosives firm Explomo blazes a trail in the fireworks space
summary: Explomo Corporation, a Singapore-based commercial explosives firm, is expanding its fireworks and pyrotechnics business following the acquisition of Glorious Singapore. The company aims to capitalize on the post-pandemic return of live entertainment, particularly for SG60 celebrations. Explomo's fireworks and pyrotechnics arm now accounts for half of its top line, up from 40% previously. The company has delivered pyrotechnic displays for events such as the Singapore Formula 1 Grand Prix and the inaugural Yuewen Music Festival, and has won its first overseas contract for a fireworks and special effects spectacle in Thailand.

Explomo banks on the Big Bang

site_title: Trump signs order to ‘turbocharge’ coal mining in United States
summary: US President Donald Trump signed executive orders to "turbocharge coal mining" in the US, aiming to power data centers and revive the declining US fossil fuel industry. The orders will lift regulatory barriers to coal extraction, suspend coal-fired power plant closures, and instruct the Department of Justice to fight state and local regulations harming coal miners. Critics argue that coal production is a polluting and expensive power source, while production has fallen sharply in the US over the last 15 years. The move is part of Trump's efforts to boost fossil fuels through deregulation.

images.alt_text: Investors traditionally turn to utilities during times of market upheaval thanks to their relatively stable revenue sources.

site_title: Sembcorp ties up with Indian oil and gas company for renewable energy projects
summary: Sembcorp Industries has entered a joint venture with Bharat Petroleum, a state-owned Indian oil and gas company, to support India's renewable energy and green hydrogen projects. The partnership aims to achieve net-zero Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2040 and will focus on decarbonizing "hard-to-abate sectors". Bharat Petroleum aims to build a 10-gigawatt renewable energy portfolio, and the joint venture will consider projects in green ammonia production, bunkering, and emissions reductions for port operations.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
GAIA solar farm in Long An province was Sembcorp's first utility-scale acquisition in Vietnam.
Despite near-term headwinds, China's renewables capacity is set to grow, said Sembcorp CEO Wong Kim Yin (pictured) and chairman Tow Heng Tan.
the partnership aims to support India's long-term energy transition plans, says Sembcorp.

site_title: Wall Street braces for souring corporate earnings amid trade war
summary: US stocks face a test as corporate earnings season begins amid a trade war and global economic concerns. Analysts predict a 6.7% year-over-year earnings growth for the S&P 500 in the first quarter, down from 11.1% in early November. Recession fears and tariff uncertainty threaten multinational companies' supply chains and export demand, potentially leading to zero earnings growth for S&P 500 companies this year.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York City, on April 3, 2025. site_title: Global supply chains: Navigating the ripple effects of the Trump tariffs
summary: The US has announced new import taxes, including a 10% baseline tariff on all goods and 25% on non-US manufactured cars. This shift in trade policy is expected to disrupt North American automakers and impact global supply chains. Asia, particularly Vietnam, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Taiwan, and Malaysia, will face tariffs ranging from 24% to 46%. Companies must adapt to the new tariffs, which will increase costs and potentially disrupt industries, with roughly half of all vehicles sold in the US being imported.

images.alt_text: The US tariffs would amount to the highest trade barriers in more than a century: a 10 per cent baseline tariff on all imports and higher targeted duties on some of the country’s biggest trading partners.

site_title: Hedge funds move into Asia power market with new hires
summary: Hedge funds are expanding into Asia's power markets, particularly in Australia and Japan, as they seek to offset declining profits from traditional commodities. The move is driven by the increasing volatility of power prices in these regions, with Australia's 30-day historical volatility reaching nearly 500% last year. Companies such as Jain Global, Citadel, and Balyasny Asset Management are hiring traders and portfolio managers to capitalize on the market's potential. The Australian and Japanese power markets are seen as entry points for companies to tap into the wider region, with many funds committing large base salaries to attract talent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, SGX, Sembcorp, CDL, DBS
summary: UOB Group plans to invest in a new headquarters building in Ho Chi Minh City's business district and enhance its digital banking platform in Vietnam. The bank will inject additional capital into its Vietnam subsidiary. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a 25% increase in securities market turnover value in March, with shares of SGX rising 2%. Sembcorp Industries entered into a joint venture with Bharat Petroleum to explore renewable energy and green hydrogen projects in India. DBS and UOB also announced share buybacks, with DBS buying back 500,000 shares for S$19.1 million.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of the United Overseas Bank ( UOB ) logo on OUB Plaza taken from OCBC Centre on August 4, 2023

site_title: Singapore’s STI stumbles over 2% as Trump’s 104% tariff hit on China kicks in
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.2% to 3,394.74, with the US imposing 104% tariffs on Chinese goods, including a 104% tax on many Chinese goods. Japan's Nikkei plummeted 5% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index retreated nearly 2%. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also declined, with the Nasdaq Composite Index shedding 2.2%. The impact of the tariffs, which took effect at midnight US time, led to a significant decline in Asian markets, with losers outnumbering gainers 401 to 148 on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: A US tariff idea that makes sense
summary: A US Senate bill proposes imposing sanctions on companies involved in Russian oil and gas sales, with Russia paying a per shipment fee to the US Treasury. This could pressure the Kremlin into negotiations to end the war in Ukraine. The plan aims to pressure Russia into negotiations, rather than solely relying on economic sanctions. The bill's implementation would likely burden US consumers with increased taxes and decrease manufacturing employment.

site_title: US will not let China disrupt Panama Canal: US Defence Secretary
summary: US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth warned China that the US will not allow it to disrupt the Panama Canal's operations, calling it a "wonder of the world." Hegseth's visit to Panama comes amid pressure from the Trump administration to reduce Chinese influence on the canal, seen as a threat to US national security. Panama has begun an audit of the concession contract held by Hong Kong-based Panama Ports, which operates the two ports at either end of the canal, amid reports of breaches and unpaid debts.

site_title: Xi’s No 2 says China is equipped to fight Trump’s tariff hikes
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang stated that his country has sufficient policy tools to offset any negative external shocks from US President Trump's tariff hikes. Li criticized the punitive action as a typical example of unilateralism and protectionism, and China has pledged to retaliate with tariffs of up to 104% starting April 9. Li also urged the EU to strengthen communication with Beijing and push for a new round of high-level dialogue on strategic cooperation and trade. The US has imposed tariffs on China, while the EU faces a 20% levy.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has praised trading partners for coming forward to make concessions, but also brushed aside some offers.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 25% in March, volume down 23%
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 25% year-over-year increase in securities turnover value to S$29.7 billion in March, with the Straits Times Index (STI) generating a 5% gain over the January-to-March quarter. Market volumes fell 23% to 26.8 billion shares, while derivatives traded volume increased 14% to 27.4 million contracts. The STI topped Asean stock benchmarks, and small and mid-cap stocks garnered investor interest. SGX also listed the Lion-China Merchants CSI Dividend Index ETF, bringing combined assets under management to over S$700 million.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The benchmark Straits Times Index outperforms its regional peers in February 2025.

site_title: Lee Ek Tieng, former top civil servant who drove Newater development, dies aged 91
summary: Former Singaporean civil servant Lee Ek Tieng, a pioneer in the country's clean and green movement, has died at 91. He oversaw critical infrastructure projects, including an islandwide sewage system and the transformation of Singapore's waterways. Lee led the development of Newater, a water recycling system, and was a key figure in shaping Singapore's environmental transformation. His legacy has been praised by former Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu, and other officials, who remembered him as a humble and kind leader who continued to inspire generations with his spirit of service and stewardship.

images.alt_text: Samsung co-CEO Han Jong Hee died from cardiac arrest while receiving treatment at a hospital during time off, a company spokesperson said.

site_title: CK Hutchison shares erase all gains since Panama ports deal
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings shares declined 1.4% on Wednesday, erasing all gains since the company sold its Panama Canal port assets to a BlackRock-led consortium. The move comes amid escalating trade tensions between the US and China, with Beijing accusing the US of trying to reclaim the canal. The sale is set to generate $19 billion in cash proceeds, but the deal has raised concerns about the company's precarious position in the middle of the US-China spat.

site_title: Judge orders White House to lift restrictions on AP access
summary: A US federal judge ordered the White House to restore the Associated Press's access to President Donald Trump's official events, citing a violation of the First Amendment. The AP had been barred from the Oval Office and Air Force One since February 11 due to their continued use of the term "Gulf of Mexico" instead of "Gulf of America" as decreed by Trump. The judge ruled that the "viewpoint-based denial of the AP's access" was unconstitutional and must be lifted.

Top Glove said the 24 per cent tariff is “relatively favourable” compared to peers.

site_title: China’s EV boom masks economic pain for major auto hubs
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) boom is masking economic pain for major auto hubs that rely on foreign automakers. Cities like Guangzhou, once reliant on joint ventures with Toyota and Honda, are struggling as Chinese consumers prefer domestic brands like BYD. Guangzhou's auto output plunged 20% in 2024, while Shenzhen's surged 65%. The shift to EVs is exacerbating economic woes, with joint ventures forecast to reduce capacity by another 10 million vehicles by 2030. Officials in Guangzhou are under pressure to mitigate the economic fallout, with the city investing in future-facing technologies like autonomous driving.

site_title: Rich Asian investors opt to unwind holdings amid margin calls
summary: Wealthy Asian investors are unwinding their equity holdings amid margin calls triggered by the recent global market turmoil. Some Singapore investors are cutting trades, doubting the chances of a strong market rebound, while Hong Kong-based clients are opting to liquidate assets to avoid forced selling. The uncertainty over President Donald Trump's tariff programme has kept investors on edge, with some clients expressing concerns about the impact of tariffs on their businesses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 8)
summary: PM Wong announced the government's plan to set up a task force to help businesses and workers navigate the challenges of the new economic environment amid the ongoing tariff fallout. The task force, chaired by DPM Gan, aims to address the wider implications for the global trading system. This move comes as Singapore faces concerns over the potential recession and the impact of Trump's tariffs on the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Monday's slide in share prices comes amid a broader sell-off in local banking stocks.

site_title: Oil settles down US$1 at four-year low as US-China trade war escalates
summary: Oil prices have plummeted to a four-year low due to the escalating US-China trade war. Brent futures settled down US$1.39, or 2.16%, at US$62.82 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped US$1.12, or 1.85%, to US$59.58. The decline follows US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on all US imports, which has led to a 16% slump in oil prices since April 2. The escalating trade war has investors pricing in an increasing likelihood of a recession.

site_title: US$20 million blue diamond goes on show in Abu Dhabi
summary: A 10.03-carat Mediterranean Blue Diamond valued at US$20 million went on display in Abu Dhabi, capital of the UAE, as part of a Sotheby's exhibition. The 10-carat diamond is part of a collection estimated at US$100 million, featuring the largest flawless diamond, the second-largest red diamond, and several diamonds over 100 carats. The diamond will go on sale in Geneva next month.

images.alt_text: Just  one of several magnificent necklaces from Van Cleef & Arpels' Treasure Island high jewellery collection.
Illustrations by French comic-book artist and writer David Beauchard accompany the Treasure Island collection by Van Cleef & Arpels.

site_title: Apple’s historic sell-off has bulls balking from tariff risks
summary: Apple's shares dropped 19% in response to US President Donald Trump's tariffs on China, Vietnam, and India, the worst three-day stretch since 2001. The tariffs, which could hit iPhone demand and earnings, have investors questioning the company's ability to navigate the trade uncertainty. Despite a sell-off, analysts remain positive on Apple's prospects, citing strong free cash flow and robust buyback activity, and expect the stock to rise more than 30% over the next 12 months. The company's quarterly earnings report, due May 1, is a key catalyst for estimates to change.

images.alt_text: Apple has rapidly expanded in India after strict Covid shutdowns paralysed manufacturing at its largest iPhone plant in China.
Apple’s latest flagship iPhone currently starts at US$999 – a level that has remained constant since 2017.
The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.
Despite the ban on iPhone sales in Indonesia, the government had allowed the devices to be brought in if they were not being traded commercially.

site_title: Keep it together: New condo clusters bring benefits for developers and homebuyers
summary: Singapore's "cluster effect" in new condo launches is gaining prominence, with benefits for developers and homebuyers. Concentrating projects in the same neighborhood enhances urban planning efficiency and supports prices. This approach has been successful in areas like Lentor Hills Estate, where each launch has enjoyed healthy take-up rates and higher prices. The clustering of new homes also leads to better decision-making for buyers, as they can compare features and prices across projects. Additionally, it drives developers to enhance their product offerings, resulting in more diverse and unique projects.

site_title: Real estate sector to face stricter compliance, tougher penalties to tackle money laundering
summary: Singapore is implementing stricter compliance requirements and tougher penalties for estate agents, salespersons, and developers to combat money laundering, terrorism financing, and proliferation financing. The Anti-Money Laundering and Other Matters (Estate Agents and Developers) Bill, read in Parliament, targets the real estate sector. Errant individuals will face penalties, including fines and imprisonment, under the new framework. The aim is to improve transparency and accountability in the industry, protecting the country from financial crimes.

site_title: Bitcoin turns less volatile than stocks as tariffs wreak havoc
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs have triggered a swing in the stock market, causing it to become more volatile, but Bitcoin has remained relatively stable. Unlike traditional stocks, digital tokens are not significantly impacted by tariffs, with low premiums over futures and muted options activity. Market observers attribute this resilience to moderate leverage and favorable regulatory trends in the US. Despite short-term volatility, traders remain bullish on Bitcoin's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Binance’s Zhao will guide Pakistan’s newly-formed Crypto Council on regulation, infrastructure, education and adoption as a strategic advisor.
Virtually every global financial hub vies to be crypto’s capital. But the writer asks: can you stomach the volatility?
Beijing-based Bitmain Technologies, by far the largest manufacturer of Bitcoin mining equipment, has production lines in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Europe: Shares notch best session since November 2022 after tariff-sparked pullback
summary: European shares rose 2.72% to a 14-month high, rebounding from a 12% slump in the past four sessions. The Stoxx 600 closed at 486.91 points, driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. Investors remain cautious amid escalating US-EU trade tensions, with a possible global recession on the horizon. Despite this, stocks broadly recovered some lost ground, with world stocks also rising.

images.alt_text: All three major indices finished firmly in the red, with the S&P 500 shedding 1.6 per cent to 4,982.77 on Tuesday, its first close below 5,000 points in nearly a year.

site_title: As Trump unleashes mayhem, keep calm and carry on; reading more might help
summary: DBS Group's former CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizes the importance of reading and talking to people in generating ideas. Gupta, who pioneered many initiatives during his tenure, attributes his ideas to reading and engaging in conversations with others. He advises young Singaporeans to prioritize reading to make associations and connections. This approach can help business leaders and individuals develop valuable insights and drive progress. Gupta's emphasis on reading and collaboration highlights the significance of knowledge-sharing and learning in driving innovation and growth.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
Warren Buffett, 94, is now the world’s fourth-richest person and one of only two of the top 20 people on the list have added to their wealth this year.

(FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. Tesla reported a 13 percent drop in first quarter auto sales April 2, 2025, amid lower production during factory upgrades and blowback over CEO Elon Musk's work for President Donald Trump's administration. Musk's electric vehicle company delivered 336,681 autos in the quarter ending March 31, missing analyst expectations, as it pointed to the "loss of several weeks of production" while it ramps up upgrades for its Model Y output. (Photo by Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo / AFP)

site_title: US wine sellers worry as Trump tariffs set to hit on Wednesday
summary: US wine sellers are bracing for the impact of President Trump's 20% tariff on European Union goods, set to kick in on Wednesday. The tariff is expected to surge the price of a bottle of wine past what a casual customer would usually pay, with some wines increasing by as much as $45. The tariffs are expected to cause significant financial losses for US wine sellers, with co-owner Jorge Rodriguez of Petralanda winery expressing concerns about the impact on his business.

site_title: Thai court denies bail for US academic for alleged royal insult, group says
summary: A Thai court denied bail to American academic Paul Chambers, accused of insulting the monarchy under the country's lèse-majesté law. Chambers, a lecturer at Naresuan University, was charged after making comments about the powers of the prime minister and the monarchy during an international webinar. The court deemed him a flight risk as a foreigner and opposed his bail application. Chambers faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted, and his lawyers plan to appeal the decision in the High Court.

images.alt_text: Property developers in the greater Bangkok area were saddled with about 235,000 unsold residential units at the end of last year, the most since data dating back to 2018.

site_title: Sri Lanka passes landmark law to recover stolen assets
summary: Sri Lanka's leftist government passed the Proceeds of Crime Bill unanimously in parliament, allowing for the seizure and confiscation of ill-gotten wealth without a criminal conviction. The bill paves the way for the prosecution of high-profile politicians and others from previous administrations. The legislation, which enjoys a two-thirds majority, is seen as a significant step in recovering stolen assets and promoting transparency in the country. President Anura Dissanayake's government hailed the bill as a "historic day" for Sri Lanka, marking a new era in asset recovery and corruption prosecution.

images.alt_text: A general view of the main port in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

site_title: US clothing retailers delay orders, freeze hiring as tariffs hit China, Vietnam products
summary: US clothing retailers are delaying orders and freezing hiring due to impending tariff hikes on China and Vietnam products, which take effect on April 9. The tariffs, imposed by the Trump administration, could increase costs by 40% and strain already-thin profit margins. Smaller clothing and shoemakers, reliant on Vietnam and China, face a difficult choice: raise prices or absorb the cost increase. Nike shares have dropped 14% since the tariffs were announced, and similar retailers are expected to follow suit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nike shoes are seen displayed at a sporting goods store in New York City, New York, U.S., May 14, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar//File Photo

site_title: How to invest amid a global trade storm
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy has led to a global trade storm, with tariffs imposed on around 60 countries, reaching up to 50% on China. This has hurt US consumers and businesses, potentially leading to a recession. Investors should consider alternative markets such as China, Europe's defence sector, or money market funds and short-duration bonds to reduce exposure to US equities. Selective buying of stocks with competitive advantages, diversified revenue streams, and strong balance sheets is recommended, while avoiding sectors vulnerable to tariffs, such as industrials and consumer discretionary.

images.alt_text: Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
US President Donald Trump said he had spoken to leaders from Europe and Asia over the weekend, who hope to convince him to lower tariffs as high as 50 per cent due to take effect this week.

FILE PHOTO: A cargo ship full of shipping containers is seen at the port of Oakland as trade tensions escalate over U.S. tariffs, in Oakland, California, U.S., March 6, 2025. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.
The Straits Times index plummeted by 8.5 per cent, falling below 3,500 with a drop of more than 325 points, on Monday morning.

site_title: Greenback falls as prospect of tariff talks calms global markets
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.3% on Tuesday, marking a reversal of its 0.7% drop since Trump announced tariffs on April 2. The euro rose 0.3% to $1.0936, while the Japanese yen and Swiss franc also gained. Investors are cautiously optimistic about the prospect of tariff talks, with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent expressing hope for negotiations. However, China criticized the US over Trump's threat of additional tariffs, and the European Union floated counter-tariffs.

images.alt_text: The dollar was down 0.41 per cent against the yen to 146.255, after tumbling more than 1.4 per cent earlier in the session.

site_title: Exxon faces no shareholder proposals for first time in 25 years
summary: ExxonMobil has faced no shareholder proposals for the first time in at least 25 years, following a year after the company sued climate-focused investors to remove what it described as an "extreme agenda." The US Securities and Exchange Commission agreed to discard a single proposal this year due to attempts to micromanage the company. This absence comes as the SEC released guidelines making it easier for corporations to block votes on shareholder resolutions. ExxonMobil's actions have had a chilling effect on investors raising concerns about environmental and social topics.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil indicated in an SEC filing that stronger oil refining margins will also help boost earnings by US$300 million to US$700 million compared to the fourth quarter.

site_title: Stagflation is now America’s best-case scenario
summary: The US economy is expected to face stagflation due to President Trump's tariffs on imports, with annualized inflation potentially reaching 5% and demand declining. The Fed may struggle to manage inflation without pushing unemployment up too high, and the economy's ability to grow will be impaired. A recession is likely, with the sustainable rate of real output growth cut to around 1%. The Fed's options are limited, and investors are too optimistic about central bank support, making a slower response justified due to high economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flags fly over the Federal Reserve Headquarters on a windy day in Washington, U.S., May 26, 2017. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo

site_title: Should Hong Leong Finance join Quek Leng Chan’s financial empire to boost its prospects?
summary: Hong Leong Finance, a Singapore-listed finance company, may benefit from joining Malaysia's Hong Leong Financial Group, potentially improving its prospects and serving small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in neighboring Malaysia. The company's executive chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, is also involved with Hong Leong Financial Group, and his family, including Quek Leng Chan, holds significant stakes in both companies. A potential merger could bring synergies in financial services and products, but succession issues at Hong Leong Finance and Hong Leong Financial Group may pose concerns for stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Net interest income for the half-year rose 11.5 per cent to S$112.4 million
CDL exec chairman Kwek Leng Beng is suing his son and other directors over an "attempted coup” by his son and CEO Sherman Kwek.
Second generation Kwek family members may hold the keys to Kwek Leng Beng's fate in his tussle with son Sherman at CDL.

site_title: Thailand cuts property fees to prop up industry battling glut
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a cut in property registration and transfer fees to 0.01% from 2% for condominiums, landed houses, and commercial buildings priced up to $202,000 until June 30, 2026, to revive the real estate industry. The move follows a relaxation in loan-to-value by the Bank of Thailand and aims to stimulate the sector, clear the property backlog, and boost sales. The reduced fees will become effective immediately, and are expected to help alleviate the industry's oversupply, which has resulted in about 235,000 unsold residential units in the greater Bangkok area.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba chases international AI users with new Qwen upgrades
summary: Alibaba Cloud is expanding its international AI capabilities, launching new proprietary large language models, including Qwen-Max and QwQ-Plus, through its Singapore availability zones. The move aims to lure AI users and developers globally, following the successful debut of DeepSeek in January. Alibaba is also set to release the Qwen three flagship model soon, along with new software-as-a-service products, including AI Doc and Smart Studio, targeting end-users. This expansion is part of Alibaba's aggressive campaign to boost its cloud division and compete with other AI leaders.

site_title: G7 can help create order from Trump levies
summary: The G7 could assume new relevance in setting the global economic agenda as the G20's effectiveness wanes. US President Donald Trump's tariffs announced on "Liberation Day" may be a key inflexion point for the global economy since the 1971 Nixon shock. The G7, comprised of non-US members, must find common positions to address the uncertainty. A similar approach to the 1970s, when the G7 played a key role in managing exchange rates and bringing Japan into the Western policymaking community, is needed today. The club of industrialized democracies must step up to address the challenges.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

site_title: Swiss watchdog backs UBS plan to limit investment bank amid capital rule debate
summary: Switzerland's financial watchdog, Finma, has signaled support for UBS's plan to limit its investment bank amid a debate over capital requirements. UBS has proposed capping the size of its investment bank as a proportion of risk-weighted assets, a move that could ease fears of a state bailout. The proposal may also address concerns about non-financial risks such as money laundering and sanctions. The Swiss parliament will discuss legislation that could impose up to $25 billion in fresh capital demands, but Finma's backing of UBS's plan indicates a potential way forward.

images.alt_text: UBS has established offshore desks in Singapore to help cater to its clients in Australia and Japan with domestic wealth growing.
Two years ago, UBS acquired Credit Suisse after its old rival collapsed, sparking calls for stricter regulation in the industry to prevent the risk of another banking crisis.
DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta was paid S$17.6 million, up from the S$11.2 million paycut he took in 2023

Sergio Ermotti, chief executive officer of UBS Group AG, during an interview at Bloomberg House during the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025. The move comes as UBS doubles down in a region that it has long seen as key to its wealth-management ambitions.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends 1.6% lower as tariff angst kills stocks rally
summary: US stocks fell 1.6% on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 closing below 5,000 points for the first time in nearly a year, due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's trade wars. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. Investors were disappointed by a lack of concrete progress in White House negotiations with Japan and South Korea, while massive tariffs on China were confirmed to go into effect overnight. This has led to an estimated 50% chance of a US recession, according to market analysts.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York City, on April 3, 2025. Wall Street stocks sank in early trading on April 3,2025, joining a global equity selloff after President Donald Trump's latest tariff announcement exacerbated worries about a trade war and global economic downturn. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)

site_title: Trump’s tariff chaos becomes US$700 billion storm for big banks
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war has led to a significant sell-off in financial stocks, with major banks like HSBC and JPMorgan Chase experiencing a market value drop of over $700 billion. The S&P 500 and other benchmark indexes have also been affected, with financial stocks among the hardest hit. Analysts warn that the banks' Asia-focused operations may be particularly vulnerable to the conflict, and some predict a US recession this year, which could further impact bank earnings.

images.alt_text: DBS CEO Tan Su Shan says it is still too early to determine the full consequences of the trade policy shock and everyone is still digesting the tariffs' impact.

FILE PHOTO: Bill Ackman, chief executive officer and portfolio manager at Pershing Square Capital Management, speaks during the SALT conference in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S. May 18, 2017.  REUTERS/Richard Brian/File Photo

site_title: IBM launches new mainframe in bet that some data stays local
summary: IBM unveiled its new mainframe system, z17, which can handle the computational requirements of generative AI models. Unlike cloud-based systems, mainframes store data on customer-owned servers, allowing companies to maintain control over their data. The z17 is the first new mainframe since 2022 and is expected to be a lucrative business for IBM, with its physical infrastructure unit posting $14 billion in revenue in the last fiscal year. This move aligns with growing customer demand for data ownership and control, driven by the increasing use of generative AI.

site_title: UOB to inject fresh capital of 2 trillion dong into Vietnam unit, build new headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will inject 2 trillion dong (S$104 million) into its Vietnam subsidiary, increasing its total charter capital to 10 trillion dong. This move makes UOB Vietnam the second-largest foreign-owned bank in Vietnam. The bank plans to build a new headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City's business district, solidifying its commitment to the country. UOB aims to deepen its presence in Vietnam and strengthen its digital banking capabilities, with plans to launch a new digital banking platform this year.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
UOB injects fresh capital worth 2t dong into Vietnam unit

site_title: DBS sees more trade flows in Asia, Africa post-Trump’s tariffs
summary: DBS expects increased trade flows between Asia, Africa, and the Middle East amid US President Donald Trump's tariff hikes. CEO Tan Su Shan notes that while the full consequences are still uncertain, the bank will support such business. The trade policy shock is expected to lead to more connectivity between regions, with new supply chains emerging. The impact of Trump's tariffs is being digested, and cooperation among Asean members is being emphasized.

images.alt_text: UOBKH downgrades the broader Singapore banking sector to “underweight”, with Trump’s “unprecedented” tariffs and a slowdown in global trade likely to affect Singapore’s wider economy.
DBS says its systems are not compromised by the ransomware attack and that customers’ deposit and monies “remain safe”.
Monday's slide in share prices comes amid a broader sell-off in local banking stocks.

site_title: Here are the top 15 companies in Singapore for career growth: LinkedIn
summary: LinkedIn has released its top 15 employers in Singapore for career growth, with financial institutions and tech companies dominating the list. DBS tops the list for the third year, while Bytedance and global banks Standard Chartered and JPMorgan Chase also made the cut. The ranking considers factors such as ability to advance, skills growth, and company stability. Six in 10 Singapore professionals are open to pivoting into a new role or industry this year, with a third planning to acquire new skills.

images.alt_text: LinkedIn found that artificial intelligence jobs are growing fast; more people are looking to switch jobs and are eyeing new opportunities

site_title: Apple exported 1.5 trillion rupees in iPhones from India last year, minister says
summary: Apple exported over 1.5 trillion rupees (S$23.6 billion) in iPhones from India in the last fiscal year, according to Tech Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw. This coincides with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ambition to turn India into a manufacturing hub. India shipped out over 2 trillion rupees worth of smartphones in the fiscal year, a 54% jump from the previous year. Apple's diversification drive is driven by US President Donald Trump's levies on China, but a complete shift away from China is unlikely in the short term.

images.alt_text: Apple’s latest flagship iPhone currently starts at US$999 – a level that has remained constant since 2017.
The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.
Despite the ban on iPhone sales in Indonesia, the government had allowed the devices to be brought in if they were not being traded commercially.
“Thrilled to meet the next generation of developers at Zhejiang University today,” Apple CEO Tim Cook said on Wednesday.

site_title: CDL group CEO Sherman Kwek gives up long-term incentive of S$1.35 million; total compensation for FY2024 down 15.4%
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) group CEO Sherman Kwek voluntarily forgoed his long-term incentive grant of S$1.35 million for FY2024, reducing his total compensation by 15.4% to S$2.97 million. Executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng also saw a 13.6% decrease in total compensation. The declines come as CDL reported a 36.6% drop in net profit to S$201.3 million for FY2024, driven by its property development segment's lower contributions.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
CDL posts basic earnings per share (EPS) of S$0.121, compared with an EPS of S$0.27 in the year-ago period.
Hotelier Kwek Leng Beng had his start with a single hotel on Orchard Road, before rapidly expanding into a global hospitality group with over 145 hotels worldwide.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust launches preferential offering at S$2.05 apiece
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust launched a preferential offering at S$2.05 apiece, representing a 7.4% discount to its previous volume-weighted average price. The offering, made for 54 units for every 1,000 existing units, aims to raise approximately S$421.3 million in gross proceeds.

Northpoint City mall

site_title: Indonesia announces trade concessions for US ahead of talks
summary: Indonesia has announced trade concessions for the US ahead of talks, including reducing import duties on US steel, mining products, and health equipment to 0-5% from 5-10%. The country plans to buy US liquefied petroleum gas, liquefied natural gas, and soybeans as part of the negotiations, aiming to ease the impact of a 32% tariff due to take effect on Wednesday. A high-level delegation led by Chief Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto will travel to Washington next week to secure a deal.

images.alt_text: Sri Mulyani Indrawati Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan debt deals pulled as tariffs hit deals outlook across Asia
summary: Japan's Asahi, Suntory, and Nissin have postponed the sale of 100 billion yen worth of yen-denominated bonds due to global financial market volatility induced by US President Donald Trump's tariffs. The move is expected to impact capital raising deals across Asia, as investors navigate the risk of tariffs increasing geopolitical tensions. Market volatility has led to a decline in benchmark 10-year Japanese government bonds, with investors remaining cautious despite a slight bounce back in the latest session.

images.alt_text: The 7-Eleven operator’s profit has fallen in recent quarters as domestic convenience store operations underperformed competitors and its North American arm suffered from lower consumer spending against a backdrop of accelerating inflation.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 8, 2025
summary: Asian markets staged a mild rebound on Tuesday, but uncertainty over US tariffs continued to affect the region. Singapore's STI edged down 0.4% after Monday's sell-off, with PM Wong stating that the country may face recession due to the impact of US tariffs. Indonesia's markets tumbled after resuming trading following the Eid break, amid tariff turmoil. The US-China trade tensions remain a significant concern for regional markets.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s STI edges down 0.4% after Monday’s dramatic sell-off
Tokyo's Nikkei index jumped more than six per cent on April 8 after plunging an eye-watering 7.8 per cent the previous day, as US tariffs fuel market volatility.
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world

site_title: Singapore shares settle lower on Tuesday; STI down 2%, bucks regional indices rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 2% or 71.03 points at 3,469.47 on Tuesday, bucking regional indices that rebounded. Local banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB declined 4.3%, 3.3%, and 3.3% respectively, while Sembcorp Industries rose 7.6%. The broader market saw 362 advancers and 234 decliners, with 2.4 billion shares worth S$3.5 billion changing hands. Regional markets, including the Kospi and Nikkei 225, rebounded, while Singapore's KLCI shed 0.02%.

Singapore’s STI edges down 0.4% after Monday’s dramatic sell-off

site_title: Oil prices sink to 2021 lows as tariff war fans recession fears
summary: Crude oil prices have plummeted to 2021 lows, falling 2% amid escalating US-China tariff tensions and recession fears. Brent and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reached their lowest levels since April 2021. Market strategists believe the next move in oil prices will depend on the outcome of US trade talks and how key trading partners respond. If a full-blown recession persists, oil prices could continue to decline.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Sri Mulyani Indrawati Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘I am embarrassed by this loss’: venture capitalist Finian Tan on being duped of US$33.3 million in alleged nickel scam
summary: Venture capitalist Finian Tan testified in a Singapore court that he was embarrassed by losing US$33.3 million in an alleged nickel-trading scam masterminded by Ng Yu Zhi. Ng is accused of duping 947 investors, including Dr. Tan, between 2016 and 2021 by claiming to buy and sell nickel at a profit. Dr. Tan had delivered US$19.2 million to Ng's company, Envy Global Trading, and later claimed he had done proper due diligence. However, a prosecution witness testified that the investment team had assessed the risk as low, and Dr. Tan had formally assessed Ng's credibility.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Dr Finian Tan gave evidence as a prosecution witness and alleged victim in the trial of Ng Yu Zhi.
Finian Tan (above), the founder and chairman of Vickers Venture Partners, was impressed with Ng Yu Zhi after their first meeting.

site_title: Sweden is well placed to tackle turmoil, Riksbank governor says
summary: Sweden's central bank governor, Erik Thedeen, says the country is well-positioned to handle global economic turmoil, despite US President Donald Trump's tariffs raising uncertainty about future inflation and the economy's recovery. The Swedish inflation rate remains elevated at 2.3% in March, but the Riksbank targets 2% inflation. Deputy governor Aino Bunge notes that the impact of US tariffs on inflation is uncertain, and the bank is ready to act if necessary. The Swedish economy's rebound is showing signs of weakness in household demand and the labor market, but the Riksbank is prepared to respond to any challenges.

images.alt_text: Sweden's central bank reduced its interest rate to 3.25 per cent, and outlined additional easing that is likely to take the benchmark markedly lower by the end of 2024.

site_title: Indonesia to send finance, economy ministers to US trade talks
summary: Indonesia will send a team of officials, including Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati, to US trade talks to negotiate better terms following a 32% tariff on Indonesian goods. Indonesia has ruled out retaliating against the US plan, instead seeking to boost imports of US goods and ease non-tariff barriers. The delegation will also consider relaxing rules on local content for the information and communications technology sector. This move comes as Indonesia is among the hardest hit economies globally by higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Inflation has been very low at the start of 2025, with Indonesia recording its first annual deflation reading in more than two decades in February, as the government offered hefty discounts on some electricity prices.

Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: China state firms pledge to boost share purchases to calm markets
summary: China's state firms pledged to boost share purchases to calm markets, following a 7% slump on Monday due to US tariff woes. State holding companies, including China Chengtong Holdings Group and China Reform Holdings Corp, announced plans to buy back shares to stabilize the market. Central Huijin, a state fund, also increased its share holdings to steady markets, providing direct liquidity support and sending a signal to calm market nerves. The moves came as China's stock market rebounded, with regulators encouraging state-owned companies to contribute to market stability.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.
The rapid drop suggests investors expect Beijing to speed up monetary easing to support the economy in the worsening trade spat with the US.
China has made a largely successful bid in recent years to shift the country’s dependence to other, less antagonistic, suppliers such as Brazil.
Investors traditionally turn to utilities during times of market upheaval thanks to their relatively stable revenue sources.

“If China does not withdraw its 34 per cent increase above their already long term trading abuses by tomorrow, April 8th, 2025, the US will impose ADDITIONAL Tariffs on China of 50 per cent, effective April 9th,” Trump said in a Truth Social post.
Hong Kong’s Financial Secretary Paul Chan said that the imposition of reciprocal tariffs is “a bullying and unjustified act that violates WTO rules” and undermines the recovery of the global economy.

site_title: Malaysia to send officials to US for tariff talks: PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to send officials to the US for tariff talks following the imposition of a 24% levy on Malaysian imports. The move aims to begin dialogue and adjust the policy's implementation, while acknowledging limited room for revisiting the tariffs' intent. Anwar emphasized the importance of soft diplomacy and diversifying ties with major markets, warning that the Trump tariffs are not the first challenge to multilateralism.

images.alt_text: Sri Mulyani Indrawati Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s farm sector buckles up for tariffs as trade war worsens
summary: China is set to impose tariffs on US agricultural goods, including soybeans, corn, and wheat, in response to Washington's blanket 34% levies. China has made significant progress in shifting its dependence on US suppliers to Brazil and other countries, with domestic grain output at record levels and stockpiles brimming. The move is expected to have a limited impact, as US exports have slowed down and the world production cycle is in the fourth quarter. Chinese agriculture stocks have surged in recent days, bucking the slump in equities elsewhere.

images.alt_text: The rapid drop suggests investors expect Beijing to speed up monetary easing to support the economy in the worsening trade spat with the US.
Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

“If China does not withdraw its 34 per cent increase above their already long term trading abuses by tomorrow, April 8th, 2025, the US will impose ADDITIONAL Tariffs on China of 50 per cent, effective April 9th,” Trump said in a Truth Social post.
American LPG made up around 60 per cent of China’s total imports in 2024.

site_title: Transparency a key focus of Singapore’s tariff task force; ‘no comfort’ in lower tariff rate
summary: Singapore's tariff task force focuses on transparency, gathering information from the ground and supporting local enterprises navigating trade tensions. The government aims to share information with trading partners and explore ways to work together. Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized transparency and honesty in sharing information with the public and businesses. Despite being in the lowest tariff rate in Asia, Singapore is unlikely to benefit from lower tariffs, as the country's economy is heavily reliant on trade and external markets. The government is bracing itself for a "bumpier ride" ahead, with potential challenges in supply chain reorganization and trade balance shifts.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world
Though Singapore has recourse under its free trade agreement with the US, it will instead engage its US counterparts to address their concerns, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong.
Under Singapore's free trade agreement with the US, Singapore has recourse to take countermeasures and seek dispute resolution – but has decided not to do so.

site_title: India says ‘no’ to BYD while wooing rival Tesla to invest
summary: India has restricted market access to Chinese EV maker BYD, citing concerns over strategic interests, despite courting investments from US rival Tesla. India's 100% duty on fully built vehicles makes it difficult for foreign players to enter the market. Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal stated that India will be cautious about allowing foreign investments, particularly from China, amid protectionist trade policies. This move is part of India's broader strategy to become a global hub for electric vehicle production.

images.alt_text: BYD introduced its Seal mid-sized sedan at Seoul Mobility Show, with a price starting from 47,500,000 won (S$43,570), excluding subsidies.
Shenzhen-headquartered BYD has set a goal of selling around 5.5 million vehicles this year, 800,000 of which it forecasts may be exports.
BYD’s European Union tariff is 27%, including the standard 10% import levy.
BYD founder and chairman Wang Chuanfu said the company will continue building factories overseas without partners as it has abundant funding.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens sharply higher on hopes of tariff talks
summary: US stocks opened sharply higher on Tuesday, April 8, 2025, as investors awaited potential talks on US tariffs, reversing a week of significant losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 861.5 points, or 2.27%, to 38,827.1, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground, with the S&P 500 rising 131.3 points, or 2.59%, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 577.8 points, or 3.70%. The gains were attributed to hopes of negotiations over tariffs, which have seen trillions of dollars wiped out since last week.

site_title: Asia’s economic giants should look inwards for growth
summary: Asia's economic giants, China, India, and Japan, are exploring alternative sources of growth due to rising trade uncertainties. China has diversified its supply chain and boosted domestic demand, while India's services exports and domestic consumption are expected to drive growth. Japan is experiencing a wage-inflation virtuous cycle, which could boost domestic consumption. These countries may benefit from bolder reforms, regional collaborations, and support for domestic demand, potentially offsetting the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

India's diamond processing hub of Surat employs at least a million workers to cut, polish and set the gem. The country, which ships more than a third of its exports to the US, is expected to be among the worst-hit sectors.
Asean member states are pursuing amendments to their trade agreement with the United States in response to recently implemented US tariffs.
The moves in credit mirror a selloff in stocks around the region on Monday, with equity gauges from Sydney to Tokyo plunging.

site_title: China vows to ‘fight to the end’ as Trump tariff war rages
summary: China has vowed to "fight to the end" against US tariffs, following US President Donald Trump's announcement of additional levies. If implemented, total new US duties on Chinese goods could rise to 104% by Wednesday. China has stepped up efforts to shield its economy from global market turmoil, with analysts warning that further hikes would only exacerbate the situation, squeezing Chinese exporters' margins and Washington's desire to cut China out of the world's biggest consumer market.

images.alt_text: China, meanwhile, is mulling front-loading stimulus, which may include subsidies for some exports and potentially alleviate some of the pain for Cosco Shipping, Orient Overseas and China Merchants.

“If China does not withdraw its 34 per cent increase above their already long term trading abuses by tomorrow, April 8th, 2025, the US will impose ADDITIONAL Tariffs on China of 50 per cent, effective April 9th,” Trump said in a Truth Social post.
