site_title: This time is different: More downside risks unless US reduces tariff rates
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced the highest effective tariff rate in 100 years, bringing in significant changes to US economic policy. This move is seen as a departure from the post-World War II economic order, prioritizing unilateral trade benefits for the US over non-discrimination and reciprocity. Economists warn that tariffs are likely to cause negative employment effects, as they ripple through the economy and increase input costs for other industries. The US is expected to experience a meaningful recession and lower equity markets, with global growth potentially falling to 4% in 2025.

images.alt_text: PM Wong said the government’s deeper worry is not the direct impact that business faces, but the wider implications for the global trading system and the world
Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Austan Goolsbee said that current anxiety could change consumer and business spending, which in turn might require the Fed to respond.
Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.
Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee said the city would feel short-term impacts from US .tariffs but would remain a free port with no plans for retaliatory measures.

site_title: Chinese state funds plan to buy stocks as market rout deepens
summary: Chinese state funds plan to inject 80 billion yuan (S$14.8 billion) into the market through share purchases to stabilize Chinese stocks amid a deepening market rout. The move follows record net inflow of 42 billion yuan (S$5.7 billion) into exchange-traded funds favored by the national team. This is part of Beijing's efforts to stem the equities rout, with the Hong Kong index of Chinese stocks listed sinking over 13% on Monday, entering a bear market. Consistent interventions may be needed to stabilize the market.

images.alt_text: Sovereign fund Central Huijin said it is “firmly optimistic about the development prospects of China’s capital market and fully recognises the current investment value of A-shares.”

An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Chinese stocks initially jumped last September due to optimism over additional economic stimulus.

site_title: Buffett’s 2025 wealth gains stand out amid billionaire wipeout
summary: Warren Buffett's net worth has increased by $11.5 billion to $153.5 billion this year, making him the world's fourth-richest person. This growth is unusual among the top 20 billionaires, who have seen their fortunes decline due to US President Donald Trump's tariffs. Buffett's conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, has performed relatively well, with shares dropping only 8.8% compared to the S&P 500's 10.7% decline. Only two billionaires, Buffett and L'Oreal heiress Francoise Bettencourt Meyers, have seen their wealth increase this year.

images.alt_text: So far this year, Musk has lost US$134.7 billion.
No one lost more over the two-day stretch than Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk.

Mark Zuckerberg, the Meta founder was the biggest loser in US dollar terms, with the social media company’s 9 per cent slide costing its chief executive officer US$17.9 billion, or around 9 per cent of his wealth.

site_title: Country Garden’s sales slump persists as revival proves elusive
summary: Country Garden Holdings' sales continued to slump in March, with a 25.3% drop in monthly contracted sales to 3.2 billion yuan, outpacing the broader China housing sector's 11% decline. The developer's first-quarter sales totaled 7.8 billion yuan, a significant drop from its heyday. Weak domestic demand and a fragile job market weigh on China's housing market, now in its fourth year of decline, amid a trade war escalation with the US. Country Garden continues lengthy restructuring talks and engages financial advisers to build creditor support for its debt plan.

images.alt_text: Country Garden’s next winding-up hearing is scheduled for May 26.
Despite government support, many buyers prefer second-hand homes due to concerns that developers will still struggle to finish construction on presold projects.

site_title: Lakeside Drive, Dunearn Road, Woodlands residential sites released for sale
summary: Three Singapore government land sales sites, including one in Turf City, Lakeside Drive, and Woodlands, have been released for sale, yielding approximately 1,000 new homes. The sites are expected to attract strong interest, with market watchers anticipating top bids of between S$900 and S$1,200 per square foot per plot ratio. The Woodlands executive condo site is expected to draw substantial demand, while the Lakeside Drive site is projected to receive three to 10 bids due to its proximity to the Lakeside MRT station. The sale marks the start of the long-term rejuvenation plan of Bukit Timah Turf City.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Help large families who upgrade from an HDB BTO home to a resale unit with a sizeable CPF housing grant.
Robust sales at recent launches such as Parktown  Residence, which drew over 10,000 visitors during the first three days of public preview, reflect renewed confidence and evolving buyer demographics.

In March, the first EC project launch of 2025 - Aurelle of Tampines - saw robust demand, shifting 90 per cent of its 760 units at an average price of S$1,766 per square foot over its launch weekend.

site_title: Boeing settles to avoid civil trial over Ethiopian Airlines crash
summary: Boeing has settled two civil lawsuits related to the 2019 Ethiopian Airlines crash that killed 157 people, avoiding a trial that was set to start on Monday. The settlements bring the total number of cases settled to six, including a recent agreement with the family of a woman killed in the crash. Boeing has accepted responsibility for the crashes and is facing additional lawsuits and a potential criminal trial in June. The company has made upfront commitments to compensate families and will continue to resolve claims.

images.alt_text: The Boeing plane crashed on March 10, 2019, just six minutes after takeoff from Addis Ababa on its way to Kenya, killing all 157 people on board.

site_title: Hong Kong leader vows more free trade pacts amid ‘ruthless’ US tariffs
summary: Hong Kong leader John Lee vowed to sign more free trade pacts to diversify the city's risk amid the US-led global trade war. Lee called US tariffs "ruthless" and said Hong Kong would continue to remain a free port, but would seek trade agreements in other regions, such as South-east Asia and the Middle East. Hong Kong is in negotiations for investment agreements with Saudi Arabia, Bangladesh, and Peru, aiming to attract foreign companies and capital. The city aims to mitigate the impact of US tariffs, which now stand at 54% on Hong Kong goods.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

site_title: Blue-chip listcos scoop up more shares; Singapore market faces volatility on Trump tariff uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) tanked on April 7 due to US President Donald Trump's 10% tariffs, causing major markets to collapse. However, blue-chip companies such as Singapore banks quickly recovered, with Singtel and Singapore Exchange making gains. Despite initial losses, the STI's 30 constituents are now buying back shares, indicating resilience. The market volatility is attributed to Trump's tariffs, which have raised pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesia inflation rate stays below central bank target zone in March
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate remained below the central bank's target range for the third consecutive month, coming in at 1.03% in March, according to the statistics bureau. This marks the country's first annual deflation reading in over two decades, following a government offer of hefty discounts on electricity prices in February. The inflation rate missed market expectations of 1.17%, which had been driven up by concerns over the country's economic growth. Bank Indonesia continues to target inflation within a range of 1.5-3.5%.

images.alt_text: Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: PM Lawrence Wong auctions his guitar to empower 600 young musicians
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is auctioning his prized guitar, a Paul Reed Smith 25th Anniversary Custom 24 Artist Package, to raise funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The guitar, signed by PM Wong, will be part of a charity auction in August as part of the Gift a Guitar initiative to commemorate Singapore's 60th year of independence. The auction aims to empower 600 young musicians, with proceeds going towards the charity fund.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
Portraits of artists who transcended their outsider status, showcased at National Gallery Singapore.

site_title: Risks of bad loans, slowdown in region spark cuts in banks’ target prices; DBS downgraded to ‘sell’, OCBC, UOB get ‘hold’ rating
summary: Analysts at UOBKH downgraded Singapore banks, citing risks from US President Trump's tariffs and a global trade slowdown. DBS was downgraded to "sell" with a target price cut to S$40, while OCBC and UOB maintained "hold" ratings with target price cuts to S$16.85 and S$32.70, respectively. The downgrade reflects concerns over weaker loan growth and higher credit costs, with regional operations bearing the brunt of Trump's tariffs.

images.alt_text: Cargo ships are loaded with containers while docked at the port of Bangkok, in Bangkok, Thailand, April 3, 2025. site_title: Asia: Markets stage mild rebound but Trump tariff uncertainty reigns
summary: Asian markets experienced a mild rebound on April 8, with Tokyo's Nikkei index jumping over 6% after plummeting 7.8% the previous day. US tariffs continue to fuel market volatility, with President Trump warning of more measures against China. Despite this, investors are cautiously optimistic about the possibility of Washington tempering some tariffs. The uncertainty surrounding the trade war has sparked concerns about a global recession, with company valuations taking a hit.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent lower at 37,965.60 on Monday.

site_title: Japan’s Seven & i seen booking 24% fall in Q4 profit, adding to takeover pressure
summary: Japan's Seven & i Holdings is set to record a 24% drop in quarterly profit due to underperformance of its domestic convenience store business and lower consumer spending in its North American arm. The company faces a takeover attempt by Canada's Alimentation Couche-Tard, and a management buyout led by the founding family collapsed in February. Seven & i has proposed listing its North American subsidiary by the second half of 2026 and announced a $2 billion share buyback to increase corporate value. Investors are skeptical, with its share price trading below Couche-Tard's offer.

images.alt_text: Seven & i has said it is engaging with Couche-Tard, but a core concern is that US competition authorities will not give the deal the green light given the overlap in the companies’ businesses.
Seven & i has more than 13,000 locations in the US and Canada under a variety of brands, including franchises and stores operated under license.
The Nikkei closed down 0.2 per cent at 37,608.49, while the broader Topix shed 0.5 per cent to sit at 2,790.88 after hitting an eight-month peak on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends 6% higher on market recovery hopes
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 6% to 33,012.58 on Tuesday, its sharpest daily gain since August 6, driven by investor optimism over a market recovery on Wall Street. The broader Topix also gained over 6% to 2,432.02, with chip-making equipment maker Tokyo Electron and bank shares advancing. Despite concerns about the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariff policies, investors bought back stocks, seeing signs of a market recovery.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 dropped 4.5 per cent to 474.01 points on Monday, down for the fourth straight session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent lower at 37,965.60 on Monday.
All 30 STI constituents closed lower on Monday as Trump's tariffs continue to roil markets.

site_title: China traders boost monetary easing bets as tariffs roil markets
summary: China traders are betting on faster monetary easing to support the economy amid a deepening trade spat with the US. The drop in five-year interest rate swaps, a key gauge for such bets, is the largest in five years and closest to its lowest level since 2008. Investors expect the People's Bank of China to act preemptively to cushion the economic fallout from US tariffs, with a cut in interest rates or reserve requirement ratio possible in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Beijing and Washington are already on track to raise blanket tariffs on each other this week.

“If China does not withdraw its 34 per cent increase above their already long term trading abuses by tomorrow, April 8th, 2025, the US will impose ADDITIONAL Tariffs on China of 50 per cent, effective April 9th,” Trump said in a Truth Social post.
Trump has also closed a trade loophole that had allowed low-value packages from China to enter the US duty-free.

site_title: Vietnam vows to tackle US non-tariff concerns as it seeks 45-day delay of Trump’s levy
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has directed the government to address US non-tariff concerns, including Chinese transhipment and intellectual property theft, amid a growing trade surplus of $123.5 billion. Vietnam seeks a 45-day delay of the US tariff on its goods, citing a need for negotiation and preparation for a "status transition." The government will implement measures such as strict oversight of goods origins and enhanced intellectual property enforcement to curb rebadged products.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump touted Vietnam as "great negotiator" as he announced reciprocal tariffs on the South-east Asian country in the White House Rose Garden.

US President Donald Trump’s latest tariff torpedo means South-east Asian countries have their work cut out for them as they face one of their biggest tests in recent times.
Unlike during Trump's first presidency, South-east Asia is now directly in the firing line for aggressive and high levies, says an analyst.
US President Donald Trump’s second act promises a return of the much-dreaded tariffs that put Asean smack in the crosshairs of collateral damage.

site_title: Chinese shipping earnings face ‘harder-than-expected’ tariff hit as recession risks rise
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed an additional 34% tariff on Chinese goods, bringing average US tariffs on all Chinese products to 65%, prompting concerns that transpacific volumes and shipping rates could fall. Chinese shipping companies, such as Cosco Shipping and Orient Overseas, are expected to be hit hard due to their reliance on Chinese exports. The US may also end "de minimis" tariff exemptions and impose a $1 million levy on Chinese-built ships entering US ports. China is considering front-loading stimulus, including subsidies for exports, to alleviate the impact.

images.alt_text: Semiconductors have been exempted from tariffs for now, but analysts warn that the space is hardly “immune” from future tariff threats.
At issue are proposed, stacking fees on China-built vessels that could top US$3 million per US port call.

site_title: Apple customers dash to stores to buy iPhones ahead of tariffs
summary: Apple customers are rushing to retail stores to buy iPhones ahead of tariffs set to hit Chinese-made products, which are expected to be 54% in line. The company's share price has plummeted due to the threat of tariffs, but the short-term benefit is a surge in sales at US retail stores. Employees report stores filled with customers expressing concerns about price increases, with some customers panic-buying phones. The frenzy may help bolster Apple's third-quarter results, but the impact of tariffs is not expected to be felt until the following quarter.

images.alt_text: The company still produces the majority of its US-sold devices in Chinese factories, Apple now makes its wares across a swath of nations.
Despite the ban on iPhone sales in Indonesia, the government had allowed the devices to be brought in if they were not being traded commercially.

site_title: Clean streets vs business woes: pollution charge divides Londoners
summary: Londoners have seen significant improvements in air quality since the implementation of the Ultra Low Emissions Zone, which charges polluters, in 2019. The zone, the world's largest pollution charging scheme, has been expanded to nine million residents in 2023. Campaigners and researchers hail its effectiveness, citing reduced pollution and improved health outcomes, such as reduced coughing among residents like 21-year-old Beau Boka-Batesa, who co-founded a campaign group advocating for improved air quality.

images.alt_text: The share of overseas buyers registering with an estate agency in Britain fell to 1 per cent between January and March, the lowest level since at least 2008, according to data from broker Hamptons.
UK luxury car manufacturer Jaguar Land Rover said on Saturday that it would “pause” shipments to the US in April as it addressed “the new trading terms”.

The UK has about 75,000 non-doms – spanning top City of London bankers to owners of global businesses – who contribute more than £8 billion (S$13.9 billion) in taxes a year, according to the latest official data.

site_title: Clean power offers safety to China investors rattled by tariffs
summary: China's clean power generators are attracting investors amid trade war turmoil due to low-cost, tariff-free inputs such as sunshine, wind, and water. Three firms - China Longyuan Power Group, China Yangtze Power, and Huaneng Lancang River Hydropower - are among the 20 firms on the CSI 300 index whose shares are up since the start of trading on Monday. This shift is driven by investors seeking stable revenue sources, as traditional utilities have historically been a safe haven during market upheavals.

site_title: New Zealand says economic recovery made harder by US tariffs
summary: New Zealand's economic recovery from recession has been hindered by US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, which have impacted the country's currency, stock, and bond markets. Finance Minister Nicola Willis stated that retaliatory tariffs imposed by China on US imports have exacerbated volatility, making New Zealand's recovery harder. Despite this, the government plans to stick to its fiscal strategy, aiming to return to surplus in the 2027-2028 fiscal year, and expects to cut interest rates on Wednesday. The global economic event has raised concerns about growth and demand for New Zealand's products.

site_title: South Korea to go to the polls on June 3 to elect next president
summary: South Korea will hold its 21st presidential election on June 3, following the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in December. The country has been leaderless since then, with Prime Minister Han Duck-soo acting as the interim leader. The election will be held within 60 days, with campaigning starting on May 12 and a two-day transition period after the election. Opposition leader Lee Jae Myung is the frontrunner, with a 34% support rating, and will be inaugurated as president on June 4 if he wins.

images.alt_text: South Korea is among the nations most vulnerable to protectionist policies as its economy relies heavily on earnings from abroad.
Samsung Electronics estimated an operating profit of 6.6 trillion won (S$6.07 billion) for the January-March period, versus a 5.1 trillion won LSEG SmartEstimate.

Cars for export at a port in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, April 2, 2025. South Korea’s exports to the United States hit a record high of US$127.8 billion in 2024, with automobiles - the top-selling product - accounting for 27 per cent of the total.

site_title: Australia’s April consumer confidence slammed by tariff turmoil
summary: Australia's consumer confidence index plummeted 6.0% in April, erasing a 4% gain from the previous month, due to US President Donald Trump's tariff plans. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index dropped to 90.1, 9.3% higher than last year, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. The decline was triggered by a 10% tariff on Australian goods and a sell-off in global financial markets, with further declines in sentiment expected in the months ahead.

site_title: Singapore recession not ruled out; task force to deal with tariff fallout: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's economic growth is likely to be significantly impacted by US President Donald Trump's tariffs, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. The government is reassessing its 1-3% growth forecast and may revise it downwards. Slower growth will lead to fewer job opportunities and smaller wage increases for workers. A task force, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, will be set up to help businesses and workers navigate the challenges of the new economic environment, with the government expressing "full confidence and support" for the mission to stay relevant.

site_title: Forget ‘hello world’, say ‘hello wealth’
summary: As artificial intelligence reshapes the workforce, financial literacy is becoming increasingly crucial to avoid obsolescence. A decade ago, the author's career advice to "learn to code" may have seemed relevant, but with AI tools now capable of handling most tasks, workers must adapt. Increasing financial literacy for students, regardless of education or aptitude, can help level the playing field. By the time someone joins the workforce, they should be familiar with basic financial concepts, such as compound interest and passive income, to protect themselves from the impact of automation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SGX, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Thakral, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: DBS reported a ransomware attack, compromising the data of approximately 8,200 customers, including their names, addresses, and equity details. Shares of DBS fell 9.3% on Monday. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) also experienced volatility, with its shares down 9.5% on Monday. Frasers Centrepoint Trust launched a preferential offering, while Thakral clarified rumors about its associate GemLife's potential initial public offering. Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager declared an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) invalid, citing dissenting unitholders.

site_title: DBS, Bank of China’s printing vendor hit by ransomware attack; over 11,000 customers’ data stolen
summary: DBS Bank and Bank of China's printing vendor, Toppan Next Tech, were hit by a ransomware attack, exposing data of over 11,000 customers. The attack, reported on April 5, may have compromised customer statements and letters, including names, addresses, and loan account numbers, but no transaction banking information was affected. Both banks stated that their internal systems are secure and that customers' deposits remain safe. Investigations are ongoing, with the Cyber Security Agency and Monetary Authority of Singapore aiding in the response.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Monday's slide in share prices comes amid a broader sell-off in local banking stocks.

site_title: South Korea eyes boosting energy imports to cut surplus with US
summary: South Korea plans to increase energy imports to reduce its trade surplus with the US, a move aimed at negotiating a lower tariff rate. The country's trade minister, Cheong Inkyo, will discuss this during a two-day trip to Washington, citing liquefied natural gas as a potential shipment. South Korea recorded a $55.7 billion surplus with the US in 2024, and the US has imposed 25% tariffs on South Korean auto imports, steel, and aluminum. The government will unveil a 10 trillion won extra budget plan to shore up the slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Cars for export at a port in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, April 2, 2025. South Korea’s exports to the United States hit a record high of US$127.8 billion in 2024, with automobiles - the top-selling product - accounting for 27 per cent of the total.
South Korea is among the countries hit with larger tariffs at 25 per cent, along with Japan at 24 per cent, India at 26 per cent and Cambodia at 49 per cent.
The BOK has so far cut its benchmark interest rate three times since its pivot in October, after confirming inflationary trends were largely in line with its views.

site_title: Amid 2025’s fresh uncertainties, opportunities and risks emerge in the HDB resale market
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market experienced a three-year high in resale volume in 2024, with 28,986 flats transacted, up from 26,735 units in 2023. Resale prices rose 1.5% in Q1 2025, slower than the 2.6% in the fourth quarter of 2024. The strong demand is expected to moderate with the influx of flats reaching their minimum occupation period (MOP) and coming onto the resale market. However, escalating trade tensions may slow the pace of price growth, and the government's proactive fiscal policies will keep mortgage rates manageable for buyers.

images.alt_text: In March, the first EC project launch of 2025 - Aurelle of Tampines - saw robust demand, shifting 90 per cent of its 760 units at an average price of S$1,766 per square foot over its launch weekend.
Robust sales at recent launches such as Parktown  Residence, which drew over 10,000 visitors during the first three days of public preview, reflect renewed confidence and evolving buyer demographics.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 7)
summary: Singapore's three local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, experienced a slide in share prices amid a broader market sell-off triggered by US tariffs. The sell-off led to a loss of over S$37 billion in market value for the banks. The decline in local banking stocks follows a similar trend seen in other markets globally.

site_title: Elon Musk’s net worth falls below US$300 billion for first time since November
summary: Elon Musk's net worth has fallen below US$300 billion for the first time since November due to Tesla's stock losses, which have dropped over 50% since the record high in mid-December. Musk has lost US$134.7 billion this year, taking his total fortune to US$297.8 billion. The slump in his fortune is attributed to the backlash against Trump's tariffs, which have targeted Tesla, as well as Musk's polarizing behavior and social media activity.

images.alt_text: No one lost more over the two-day stretch than Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk.
Altman has said OpenAI is not for sale, rejected a US$97.4 billion unsolicited takeover bid earlier this year from a Musk-led consortium with a “no thank you”.

site_title: Samsung sees Q1 profit beating estimates as looming tariffs spur chip sales
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a Q1 operating profit of 6.6 trillion won (S$6.07 billion), beating estimates, driven by solid memory chip sales and strong smartphone demand. The company attributed the boost to customers stockpiling chips ahead of potential US tariffs. Analysts expect a weaker Q2 due to delays in securing new customers for high-bandwidth memory chips, with some predicting a potential halving of chip division profit.

images.alt_text: Samsung co-CEO Han Jong Hee died from cardiac arrest while receiving treatment at a hospital during time off, a company spokesperson said.
Samsung co-CEO Han Jong Hee speaks at the company's annual general meeting at the Suwon Convention Centre in Suwon, South Korea, March 19, 2025.

site_title: Executive condos still a popular pick, but how high will prices go?
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market remains strong, driven by sustained demand from first-time buyers and HDB upgraders. The first EC project of 2025, Aurelle of Tampines, sold 90% of its 760 units at an average price of S$1,766 per square foot. EC prices continue to rise, but are still lower than those of new private condos. The government's release of more EC sites and improved transport infrastructure may help keep prices stable. The EC segment is expected to remain resilient, but the impact of global economic factors, including US tariffs, will be closely watched.

site_title: Tesla shares plunge below Lutnick’s ‘never this cheap’ level
summary: Tesla's shares plummeted 9.2% to $217.41, dropping below Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick's "never this cheap" level, amid a broader global equity market selloff. The decline comes after Wedbush Securities analyst Daniel Ives slashed his price target by over 40% due to Trump's trade policies and Musk's brand crisis. Tesla shares have fallen 55% from their record high in December, following weak vehicle delivery numbers and lower-than-expected estimates for sales and earnings.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A Tesla Store in Clermont, Florida, on March 29, 2025. Tesla reported a 13 percent drop in first quarter auto sales April 2, 2025, amid lower production during factory upgrades and blowback over CEO Elon Musk's work for President Donald Trump's administration. Musk's electric vehicle company delivered 336,681 autos in the quarter ending March 31, missing analyst expectations, as it pointed to the "loss of several weeks of production" while it ramps up upgrades for its Model Y output. (Photo by Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo / AFP)
Tesla delivered 336,681 vehicles in the first three months of the year, its worst quarterly total since 2022.

site_title: Businesses anxious over tariffs, Fed must look at ‘hard data’ in policy response: official
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Austan Goolsbee expressed concerns over businesses' anxiety due to President Trump's tariffs, stating that the central bank would need to look at "hard data" in its policy response. Goolsbee warned that escalating trade tensions could lead to stagflation, prompting the Fed to consider a response. However, the exact nature of the response would depend on economic trends and data, and negotiations could potentially lead to new trade agreements and avoid tariffs of over 100%. The Fed's policy response would be influenced by the outcomes of these negotiations.

site_title: Singapore’s STI edges down 0.4% after Monday’s dramatic sell-off
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged down 0.4% on Tuesday, April 8, following a 7.5% drop on Monday due to US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement. Maritime stocks rebounded, with Seatrium and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding gaining 4.2% and 3.1% respectively. Banking stocks continued to decline, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB shedding 0.9%, 1.6%, and 0.6% respectively. The market's decline follows a volatile session in Asia and Europe, with the Stoxx 600 index closing at its lowest since January 2024.

site_title: Indonesia markets tumble as trading resumes after long Eid break amid tariff turmoil
summary: Indonesia's stock market plummeted 9.2% on its reopening after a two-week Eid break, with the benchmark IDX Composite index closing down 7.9% amid escalating trade tensions triggered by US President Donald Trump's 32% tariff hike on Indonesian goods. The rupiah also fell to an all-time low, and the central bank signaled its readiness to take "aggressive" action to stabilize the currency. Analysts predict a V-shaped market rebound, but concerns over a potential trade war and its impact on Indonesia's trade surplus and exports remain.

site_title: GE2025: Former MDDI director Goh Hanyan spotted in Nee Soon GRC
summary: Former MDDI director Goh Hanyan, accompanied by former Nee Soon South MP Lee Bee Wah, attended a Meet-the-People session at the PAP's Nee Soon Central branch on April 7. Goh, who left MDDI on April 3, greeted residents before entering the branch office, accompanied by Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and PAP new face Jackson Lam. This event is seen as a potential indicator of the PAP's plans for the Nee Soon Central ward ahead of the 2025 general election.

site_title: Exxon CEO Woods compensation rose 19% in 2024
summary: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods' pay package rose 19.3% in 2024 to US$44.1 million, with his base salary at US$1.96 million and majority based on variable factors. His pay package is about 231 times the average compensation of Exxon's US$190,266 workers. This increase comes as Chevron's CEO Michael Wirth saw a 23.4% rise in total compensation to US$32.7 million in 2024.

site_title: Gold prices recover as trade war tensions lift safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices recovered, reaching a 4-week high, as trade war tensions between the US and its trading partners lifted demand for safe-haven assets. Spot gold rose 0.3% to $2,990.48 an ounce, following a near-four-week low on Monday. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes and interest rate data will be closely monitored, with futures indicating around 93 basis points of interest rate cuts by December. The global trade war and recession fears have boosted gold prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 1.9 per cent at US$2,981.09 an ounce, as of 0031 GMT, its lowest level since March 13.

site_title: Larry Fink says most CEOs he talks to think US is in a recession
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink stated that most CEOs believe the US is in a recession, citing economic weakness and elevated inflation. He warned that the US dollar may weaken and consumption will decline due to the impact of tariffs. Fink also expressed concerns about the Federal Reserve cutting rates multiple times this year. Despite the uncertainty, Fink sees potential for a buying opportunity in the long run, but acknowledges the risk of further market declines.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump holds a "Foreign Trade Barriers" document as he delivers remarks on tariffs in the Rose Garden at the White House in Washington, D.C., April 2, 2025.
Concerns about higher inflation and personal finances have since continued to mount due to US President Donald Trump’s tariffs push.

site_title: Binance founder Zhao to help Pakistan boost crypto trading bid
summary: Binance founder Zhao Changpeng has been appointed as a strategic advisor to Pakistan's newly-formed Crypto Council, guiding the country on regulation, infrastructure, education, and adoption of cryptocurrency trading. This move aims to boost the country's economy, which dodged a financial default in 2023, and develop a legal framework for cryptocurrency trading to attract foreign investors. Pakistan's 230-million population is increasingly adopting crypto trading despite the central bank's warnings about the risks. The government sees this as an opportunity to establish Pakistan as a regional powerhouse for Web3, digital finance, and blockchain-driven growth.

site_title: Thakral clarifies IPO rumours on associate GemLife; says ‘no certainty’ that any transaction will proceed
summary: Thakral Corp clarified that its associate GemLife, Australia's largest privately owned land lease developer, is not gearing up for an initial public offering (IPO) as reported by The Australian Financial Review. Despite a report suggesting introductory meetings with listed equities investors, Thakral Corp stated there is "no certainty" that any transaction will proceed, leaving the IPO plans uncertain.

Inderbethal Singh Thakral, CEO , Thakral Corporation

site_title: No shelter from the storm
summary: US President Donald Trump's return to politics has introduced a new layer of complexity to the global trade environment, with sweeping tariffs expected to impact Asean economies. The "Liberation Day" tariffs, including a 10% duty and steeper tariffs on countries with significant trade surpluses, will put pressure on local manufacturers and potentially disrupt global supply chains. Vietnam, Thailand, and Malaysia are expected to be the most affected, with tariffs of 46%, 36%, and 24%, respectively. Businesses and governments must recalibrate their strategies to address the increased protectionism, with potential implications for growth, inflation, and trade flows.

images.alt_text: Another area gaining traction is the digitisation of trade and supply chain finance.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, April 7, 2025
summary: US President Trump's newly introduced tariff 'medicine' has injected turmoil into global markets, causing Asian markets to plummet. The Hang Seng index dropped 13.2%, Nikkei 225 fell 7.8%, and the Straits Times Index declined 7.7%. Singapore banks lost over S$37 billion in market value due to the ongoing tariff sell-off. The move has triggered significant market volatility, affecting major economies worldwide.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said he had spoken to leaders from Europe and Asia over the weekend, who hope to convince him to lower tariffs as high as 50 per cent due to take effect this week.
Monday's slide in share prices comes amid a broader sell-off in local banking stocks.

site_title: The sinseh will see you now: TCM on the rise as healthcare players combine Eastern, Western medicine
summary: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) is gaining popularity in Singapore as more patients seek its benefits for a range of ailments, from common colds to chronic health conditions. Clinic chains like Pulse TCM and Oriental Remedies have seen significant increases in patients, with Thomson Medical Group reporting a 35% rise in its TCM arm over the last five years. The growing demand is attributed to increased awareness and acceptance among younger generations, who are more open to TCM due to social media and wellness trends. TCM is now being integrated with Western medicine, with some clinics offering combined treatments and referrals to Western specialists.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Eczema has been gaining in prevalence in Singapore over the last few years, as more patients become aware of the illness and look to treat the symptoms.

site_title: Bye, bye globalisation? Trump’s tariffs usher in a new economic age
summary: US President Donald Trump's imposition of trillions of dollars in tariffs on foreign imports marks a significant shift away from globalization and free trade policies. Trump believes Americans are better off producing what they need domestically, even if it leads to higher costs. He aims to create a manufacturing hub in the US, bringing back jobs and widespread prosperity. However, economists warn that this approach could lead to protectionism, trade wars, and recessions, potentially destabilizing the global economy and exacerbating international tensions. The move may also dismantle the foundations of globalization, leading to the emergence of regional trading blocs instead.

site_title: Europe: Shares close at over 14-month low as trade war volatility grips markets
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index plummeted 4.5% to 474.01 points, its lowest since January 2024, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. The drop marked the fourth consecutive session of losses, with major bourses closing between 4% to 5% down. European banks confirmed a bear market, down over 20.9% from its March record high, while defense stocks fell over 5%. Investors fear the trade war could sharply hit economic growth and increase inflation, leading to potential interest rate reductions from the ECB and US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent lower at 37,965.60 on Monday.

site_title: Investors seek refuge in US dollar, yen as tariff fallout grips markets
summary: Investors are seeking refuge in the US dollar and yen as global markets continue to plummet due to US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. The dollar fell 0.41% against the yen, while the yen rose 0.41% against the dollar. Investors are betting on a global recession and a potential cut in US interest rates as early as May, leading to a sell-off in riskier assets and a surge in safe-haven currencies. The euro also rose, but struggled for direction, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped against the US dollar.

site_title: EU spares bourbon in 25% tariffs on some US goods in metals spat
summary: The European Union has dropped plans to impose a 50% retaliatory tariff on American bourbon in response to US President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on aluminium and steel imports. Instead, the EU will impose 25% tariffs on a selection of US goods, including diamonds, motorcycles, and household appliances. The decision was made after EU member states pushed to spare European wine and champagne producers from facing higher tariffs. The tariffs will take effect on April 15, but most duties will not be collected until mid-May.

summary: A Panama audit has found that Hong Kong firm CK Hutchison breached its contract to operate two ports at the entrance of the Panama Canal. The audit revealed "many breaches" of the concession, resulting in Panama not receiving $1.2 billion owed under the contract. The firm is facing pressure to relinquish its control of the ports following US President Donald Trump's threats to reduce Chinese influence in the canal. CK Hutchison has agreed to sell the ports to BlackRock for $19 billion, but an antitrust review in China may prevent the deal from going through.

summary: Genevieve Cua, wealth editor at The Business Times, explores investment strategies for volatile times in her latest episode of WealthBT. Joined by Steve Brice, global chief investment officer at Standard Chartered Bank, they discuss ways to consider risk appetite and portfolio spread amidst market uncertainty and newly introduced tariffs. Cua and Brice provide timely insights on how to navigate the current market landscape, helping investors make informed decisions to hedge against potential market fallout.

site_title: The battle for the global payments system is underway
summary: The European Union is taking steps to counter the US push for dominance in the global payments system, with the European Central Bank (ECB) advocating for a digital euro to rival US dollar stablecoins. The US aims to promote the use of privately issued stablecoins, which could lead to "digital dollarisation" and undermine central bank control. The eurozone is already heavily dependent on American payment mechanisms, with two-thirds of card payments processed by non-European providers. The digital euro project, if successful, could create a new tech economy and give Europe autonomy in its economic affairs.

site_title: PBOC set to reveal hand on yuan as depreciation talk mounts
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is set to reveal its stance on the yuan's value amid growing concerns about depreciation. The yuan weakened to 0.03% away from 7.20 US dollars, sparking bets that China may allow the currency to weaken further to boost exports and growth. Analysts predict a sharp plunge in the yuan, with some forecasting up to a 30% deliberate depreciation. The PBOC has tools to manage volatility, but a dramatic move could worsen capital outflows and antagonize the US.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, cash conditions in China are set to remain tight without further liquidity support from the PBOC.

site_title: Levi maintains 2025 outlook in face of tariff turbulence
summary: Levi Strauss maintained its 2025 earnings outlook despite the impact of new US tariffs, which are expected to significantly raise costs for multinational apparel companies. The company expects organic revenue growth of 3.5-4.5% for the year, assuming no significant worsening of macroeconomic pressure or supply-chain disruptions. Shares rose 2.1% following the announcement, despite a 19% decline since President Trump unveiled the tariffs.

site_title: Rewriting the rules: Challenging outdated notions of luck, risk and gender
summary: A study reveals that, globally, women are expected to accumulate only 76% of the wealth of men by the end of their working lives, despite earning, inheriting, and managing more wealth than ever before. Financial success is driven by individual choices, access to resources, and informed decision-making, challenging outdated notions of luck, risk, and gender. This disparity is attributed to societal practices that reinforce outdated gender stereotypes, such as assuming men are naturally inclined to take risks while women are more cautious.

site_title: Hong Kong pledges measures to support companies in wake of tariffs
summary: Hong Kong's government has pledged measures to support companies affected by US President Donald Trump's tariffs, including export credit insurance support and assistance with branding, market expansion, and digital transformation. Financial Secretary Paul Chan described the tariffs as "a bullying and unjustified act that violates WTO rules" and undermines the global economy. The government will also strengthen support for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are expected to be impacted by the tariffs.

site_title: Oil prices slide 2% to near 4-year low as US trade conflict fuels recession fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted 2% to near a four-year low, settling at $64.21 per barrel for Brent futures and $60.70 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures, amid fears of a global recession fueled by US President Donald Trump's trade tariffs. The drop follows a 11% decline in prices last week, with volatility sparked by reports of a potential 90-day tariff pause and retaliatory measures from China and the European Commission. Analysts forecast a 45% chance of recession in the US and globally, with Goldman Sachs cutting its oil price projections.

site_title: US consumer borrowing unexpectedly declines in broad pullback
summary: US consumer borrowing unexpectedly declined in February for the first time in three months, falling nearly $810 million. This decline was driven by a sharp pullback in credit-card balances and a decrease in motor vehicle and other non-revolving loans. Outstanding credit-card debt edged up, but non-revolving debt, such as loans for vehicle purchases and school tuition, declined for the first time in nearly a year. The decline reflects growing concerns about higher inflation and personal finances.

site_title: Star Entertainment agrees to take-control offer from Bally’s: AFR
summary: Star Entertainment, Australia's second-largest casino operator, has agreed to a refinancing deal with US peer Bally's. Bally's will invest approximately A$250 million and billionaire Bruce Mathieson will provide over A$50 million. The deal aims to help Star stave off bankruptcy, which has been caused by years of regulatory scrutiny and lawsuits following money laundering allegations. Star's shares remain suspended from trading due to the lack of a refinancing proposal.

site_title: BOJ warns of heightened uncertainty as Trump tariffs batter markets
summary: The Bank of Japan warned that uncertainty over Japan's economy is heightening due to US trade uncertainty, with some firms expressing concern over the impact on output and profits from higher US duties. The BOJ maintains its assessment of a moderate economic recovery, but notes that Trump's tariffs may threaten to derail a cycle of rising wages and prices, a key prerequisite for further interest rate hikes.

site_title: Trump says EU tariff proposal ‘very, very bad to us’
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the European Union's proposal for an exemption from tariffs on industrial products, including cars, is insufficient to address the transatlantic trade deficit. Trump previously announced a 20% tariff on European goods, set to take effect on April 9, calling the EU's proposal "very, very bad" to the US.

site_title: Malaysia’s first search fund Nusatu Capital targets SME acquisition
summary: Malaysia's first search fund, Nusatu Capital, was launched by Nazrul Johari, a seasoned corporate strategist, with an undisclosed seven-figure ringgit sum in search capital from 17 investors. The fund aims to acquire an SME with annual revenue of over RM30 million by Q2 2026. Nusatu Capital seeks to grow the business further, focusing on digitalisation and professionalisation, and has already spoken to over 70 SME owners in Malaysia. Despite initial difficulties, Johari remains hopeful that search funds will become a solution for succession planning as ageing business owners look to retire, with a target internal rate of return of 35.1% similar to the Stanford Graduate School of Business 2024 Search Fund Study.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 lower after volatile session; Nasdaq ends positive
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.9% to 37,965.60. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2% to 5,062.25, while the Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.1% to 15,603.26. Recession worries persisted due to President Trump's trade wars, despite a brief surge into positive territory after a report on a possible 90-day tariff pause. Economists see the tariffs as boosting recession risk, with futures markets indicating a likely interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: China LPG buyers’ rush to replace US flows sends prices soaring
summary: China is scrambling to replace US liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) supplies due to a 34% tariff imposed on all US imports starting April 10. Middle East-origin LPG prices have surged, with a premium of over $100 per tonne, as buyers try to swap US cargoes with alternatives. The sudden demand has led to a significant price increase, affecting not only LPG but also China's imports of crude oil and liquefied natural gas.

site_title: Cybersecurity has biggest dip in salary among tech roles: NodeFlair report
summary: Cybersecurity engineers in Singapore reported the largest drop in salary, with a 4.6% decrease. Other tech roles also experienced salary declines, including data scientists (1.2%), data analysts (2.4%), and data engineers (1.5%). In contrast, traditional software engineer roles saw a 3.3% increase, while game engineers reported the highest salary growth of 28%. The NodeFlair report analyzed over 130,000 salary data points across roles and countries, highlighting a shift towards more traditional software engineers over data-related talent.

site_title: Trump gives Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel a second look
summary: US President Donald Trump has launched a review of the proposed takeover of US Steel by Japanese rival Nippon Steel, a deal previously blocked by Joe Biden on national security grounds. Trump's decision has inspired hopes that the deal may now close, with US Steel shares rising 16% on Monday. The review will be conducted by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) to determine if further action is necessary.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon warns tariffs could slow US growth, fuel inflation
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon warns that US tariffs could slow economic growth, fuel inflation, and lead to lasting negative consequences. He expressed concerns about the impact on America's long-term economic alliances and noted the potential for retaliation by other countries. Dimon raised the risk of a US and global recession to 60% from 40% due to the tariffs, and warned that the issue could lead to a stagflation-like scenario. His comments come as investors braced for more losses in global stock markets.

site_title: Thailand temporarily bans short selling to calm stock market
summary: Thailand temporarily bans short selling of all securities, except for market makers, to mitigate potential volatility and provide investors with an opportunity to assess their response to the US tariff barrage. The ban will be effective from April 8 and last no longer than April 11. The Thai Stock Exchange will also tighten other share trading rules, including cutting the ceiling and floor limits on stocks and foreign shares, and reducing the threshold of security-specific dynamic price band. The measures aim to stabilize market conditions and reinforce investor confidence.

site_title: The Hour Glass to acquire Aussie watch retailer for A$90 million
summary: The Hour Glass has signed a deal to acquire Aussie watch retailer SPV for A$90 million, expanding its presence in Australia. The acquisition will make SPV a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hour Glass (Australia) and is expected to provide an enlarged client base and operating synergies. The deal is expected to be completed in the first half of the financial year ending March 31, 2026, and will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings. This move aligns with The Hour Glass' strategy to strengthen its retail footprint in Australia.

site_title: Tariff worries continue to pummel Asian markets on Monday; Hong Kong sheds 13.2%
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday, with the Hong Kong market suffering its largest drop since the 1997 Asian financial crisis, falling 13.2% after US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement. Japan's Nikkei and Singapore's Straits Times Index also declined 7.7% and 7.5%, respectively. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 7.3%, while South Korea's Kospi index retreated 5.6%. Global markets are still reeling from the "seismic" tariff shock, with fears of more measures to come.

summary: Malaysia will chair a special Asean Economic Ministers' meeting on Thursday to address the impact of US-imposed tariffs on regional trade and investment. The move follows US President Donald Trump's announcement of reciprocal tariffs, including a 24% levy on Malaysian goods. Malaysia's Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry has set up a task force to assess the fallout and gather feedback from stakeholders. Member states are pursuing amendments to their trade agreement with the US in response to the tariffs. The meeting aims to coordinate a collective response to the US tariffs.

site_title: Credit gauges in Asia show most concern since early pandemic
summary: Global junk bond spreads in Asia have widened by the most since the early pandemic, driven by concerns over a wave of defaults that could push economies into recession. The cost to insure investment-grade debt of Asian issuers outside Japan increased by 26.5 basis points, marking the biggest single-day jump since March 2020. The US tariffs have also caused global junk bond spreads to widen by the most since 2020, with investors worried about the impact on economies, including the US, and recession.

site_title: Trump threatens further 50% tariffs on China
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose 50% tariffs on China if Beijing doesn't withdraw its 34% increase in retaliatory measures by April 8th. The tariffs, effective April 9th, would target goods from the world's second-largest economy. The move comes after Trump announced a sharp tariff hike on Chinese goods last week, prompting Beijing to issue countermeasures. The US will begin negotiations with other countries seeking to avoid the tariffs, but Trump has warned that China's refusal to back down will result in significant economic consequences.

site_title: Let large families buy new HDB 3Gen flats and enjoy priority for 4- and 5-bedder exec condos
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a Large Families Scheme to encourage couples to have three or more children, amid a low birth rate and ageing population. The scheme offers financial incentives and housing policy changes to support families. Eligible large families can receive up to S$80,000 in CPF housing grants for buying resale flats, and more HDB 3Gen flats can be built, including in prime locations. The government may also give large families priority access to buying executive condominiums and waive the resale levy when selling their HDB BTO home to buy a new EC home.

site_title: Microsoft venture Wicresoft to halt China operations, cutting 2,000 jobs: report
summary: Microsoft's joint venture Wicresoft will cease its China operations, resulting in the layoff of approximately 2,000 staff. The move follows Microsoft's decision to stop outsourcing after-sales support in China to Wicresoft amid growing political and trade tensions between the US and China. This decision is part of Microsoft's broader pullback from the China market, which is also due to stiff competition from Chinese rivals. The closure will mainly affect the 2,000-strong Microsoft outsourcing team in China.

site_title: Sino Group chairman Robert Ng and three children to be designated as politically significant persons under Singapore’s foreign interference law
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs has designated Sino Group chairman Robert Ng and his three children as politically significant persons (PSPs) under the Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Act. The designation is due to their membership in a foreign legislature or foreign political organization, but the Ministry clarified that it does not imply any wrongdoing. Robert Ng, 72, is the son of the late Ng Teng Fong, founder of Far East Organization, and his children have held various roles in the company. They have 14 days to submit representations to the registrar.

summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 7.5% or 285.36 points to 3,540.5, its worst rout since 2008. Marine stocks led the decline, with Seatrium falling 14.4%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also dropped, with DBS down 9.3%, OCBC 6.9%, and UOB 6.3%. The decline was part of a broader market downturn, with 612 decliners outnumbering 137 advancers.

site_title: Foreigners’ interest in UK homes sags to lowest level since 2008
summary: Foreigners' interest in buying homes in the UK has declined to its lowest level since 2008, with the share of overseas buyers registering with an estate agency falling to 1% between January and March, according to data from broker Hamptons. Tax changes, including increased stamp duty and plans to abolish non-domiciled residents' tax perks, are cited as major factors in the decline. US buyers have increased their share, accounting for 16% of all foreigners looking to purchase a property in Britain, while demand from Europeans has decreased.

site_title: Singapore jewellers keep their shine amid gold’s record run – even as margins thin
summary: Singapore's jewelry retailers are adapting to record-high gold prices by investing in manufacturing efficiency, launching entry-level products, and tightening supply-chain strategies. Despite thin margins, consumer confidence in gold remains strong, driving sales and supporting demand. Companies such as Aspial Lifestyle and SK Jewellery saw double-digit growth in gold sales in 2024, with some retailers introducing lower-priced gold pieces to attract younger buyers. As gold prices continue to rise, retailers are focusing on inventory planning, procurement optimization, and product mix to sustain margins and protect against falling prices.

site_title: Singapore seen easing monetary policy as tariffs threaten growth
summary: Singapore is expected to ease monetary policy at its April 14 review, with nine out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters predicting a reduction in the slope of the policy band. The move comes amid mounting risks to growth due to US tariffs, which could knock 1 percentage point off Singapore's economic growth. Trade minister Gan Kim Yong has said the country is reviewing its economic forecasts, and Maybank economists have cut their forecast for GDP growth to 2.1 per cent.

site_title: Boeing faces new civil trial over 2019 Ethiopian Airlines crash
summary: Boeing is set to face a jury trial in Chicago over the 2019 Ethiopian Airlines crash that killed 157 people. The trial, expected to last two weeks, will focus on the case of Canadian Darcy Belanger, one of the few remaining plaintiffs. A settlement was reached on Sunday, resolving two other cases, leaving 18 complaints still open against Boeing. This trial marks the first civil case related to the disaster to reach court, with Boeing accepting responsibility for the design of the MCAS flight stabilizing software implicated in both the Ethiopian Airlines and Lion Air crashes.

site_title: European shares plummet to 16-month low on trade war gloom
summary: European shares plummeted to a 16-month low on April 7, with the STOXX 600 index sliding 5.8% and Germany's benchmark index falling 6.1% due to US President Donald Trump's continued aggressive trade war with China. Investors are concerned about a potential recession, with European banks on track to confirm a bear market. The European Central Bank estimates a US tariff would lower eurozone growth by 0.3 percentage points, while EU counter-tariffs would raise the damage to half a percentage point.

site_title: Yuan devaluation market chatter grows as trade war worsens
summary: China is considering devaluing the yuan in response to US President Donald Trump's tariffs, sparking market speculation and potential capital flight. Strategists predict a 15-30% deliberate depreciation of the yuan, which could offset some of the tariff impact but also risk economic instability. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has shown a slightly looser grip on the currency, and authorities may consider rate cuts, targeted support, and a weaker currency to avoid a repeat of the 2015 devaluation shock.

summary: India's government projects 6.3-6.8% growth for the 2025/26 fiscal year despite US tariffs, with officials citing a stable oil price below $70 a barrel. Economists have lowered forecasts to 6.1% due to global trade tensions, but the government is assessing the impact on export industries, including the diamond sector, which employs over a million workers. Discussions are underway to provide support to exporters, including an interest-subsidy scheme and increased bank credit.

site_title: Sheng Siong CEO Lim Hock Chee’s compensation for FY2024 jumps 20.6% to S$7.06 million
summary: Sheng Siong's CEO Lim Hock Chee received a 20.6% increase in compensation to S$7.06 million for FY2024, driven by a 20.6% rise in variable bonus to S$6.66 million. The company reported a 1% lower year-on-year net profit of S$67.6 million for the second half, despite a 5.5% increase in revenue. Lim attributed the decline to external uncertainties and high finance and administrative expenses. The company recommended a final dividend of S$0.064 per share, marginally higher than FY2023.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end 13.22% down, worst since 1997 Asian financial crisis
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 13.22% on their worst day in nearly three decades, ending at 19,828.30, due to China's retaliation against US tariffs, fueling recession fears. The Hang Seng Index dropped 3,021.51 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 7.34%. Market turnover reached a record $80 billion, with tech giant Alibaba diving 18% and Chinese developers losing up to 15%. The decline is the heaviest since the 1997 Asian financial crisis, raising concerns about the trade war's impact on the global economy.

site_title: China sovereign fund Huijin buying domestic stocks as market slumps
summary: China's sovereign fund Central Huijin Investment increased its holdings in domestic stocks amid a 7% slump in the Shanghai Composite Index, its worst day in five years. The fund stated it's "firmly optimistic" about China's capital market and will defend market stability. Huijin's actions helped stabilize the market, with trading volumes for favored ETFs spiking to their highest in a year. The fund's support, along with potential monetary easing and consumer spending measures, may limit further market decline, but experts caution that a widening trade war could still impact the market.

China remains the largest market for US agricultural products, but imports of US farm goods dropped for the second consecutive year.
China produces around 90 per cent of the world’s rare earths, a group of 17 elements used across the defence, electric vehicle, energy and electronics industries.
Beijing also announced controls on exports of medium and heavy rare earths, including samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium, to the US, effective Apr 4.

site_title: Trump tariffs and Asean’s Plan B
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced tariffs on various countries, including Asia and Singapore, sparking uncertainty and potential retaliation. The tariffs, which range from near-50% to 10%, aim to control specific resources and goods, but their long-term impact and permanence are unclear. The US may close its market to the rest of the world or focus on making America a great manufacturer again. Asian countries, including Singapore, must adapt to the new trade landscape and consider diversifying investments and promoting domestic production to mitigate the effects of the tariffs.

site_title: Bill Ackman warns Trump is losing business leaders’ confidence
summary: Billionaire fund manager Bill Ackman warned US President Donald Trump that he's losing the confidence of business leaders and urged him to pause his trade war. Ackman called for a 90-day truce to resolve trade issues via negotiation, warning that an economic nuclear war would severely damage the US reputation and harm the economy.

site_title: Billions wiped off Singapore banks as Asia market carnage worsens; STI drops 8.5%, HK plunges 12.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 8.5% on Monday, its largest intraday decline since 2008, following US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement. The STI fell below 3,500 points, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB leading losses. The Nikkei 225 index in Japan dropped 8.6% and the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong fell 12.6%. The US dollar strengthened against the Singapore dollar, and commodities took a beating. Economists predict a significant impact on global markets and economies, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore expected to ease monetary policy.

images.alt_text: In his executive order last Wednesday (Apr 2), Trump reiterated many of the grievances about global trade he had openly expressed on his campaign trail.

site_title: Treasuries star as haven bet even as Trump fans stagflation woes
summary: US Treasuries have seen a rally as investors position for more gains and price in a greater chance the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates aggressively to keep the economy from stalling. Despite concerns about stagflation, a term referring to a slowing economy coupled with elevated prices, the two-year yield has reached its lowest level since 2022. Market analysts warn that this positioning may be warranted in the short term but ignores the risk of inflation. The Fed is in a difficult situation, and investors are betting on a possible US recession, with futures contracts pricing in nearly four Fed rate cuts by December.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump holds a "Foreign Trade Barriers" document as he delivers remarks on tariffs in the Rose Garden at the White House in Washington, D.C., April 2, 2025.
UK luxury car manufacturer Jaguar Land Rover said on Saturday that it would “pause” shipments to the US in April as it addressed “the new trading terms”.

US National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett has denied that the tariffs were part of a strategy by US President Donald Trump to crash financial markets to pressure the US Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says: “Malaysia, as Asean chair, will lead efforts to present a united regional front, maintain open and resilient supply chains, and ensure Asean’s collective voice is heard clearly and firmly on the international stage.”
World leaders have hit back and markets plummeted since US President Donald Trump unveiling sweeping tariffs on American imports last week.

site_title: US: Wall St opens sharply lower, S&P 500 nears bear market territory
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened sharply lower on Monday, with the S&P 500 losing 181.37 points, or 3.57%, to 4,892.71, marking it near bear market territory. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1,212.98 points, or 3.17%, to 37,101.88, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 623.23 points, or 4.00%, to 14,964.56. The losses were attributed to economic worries over US President Donald Trump's tariff plans. Investors sought refuge in government bonds, further exacerbating the market downturn.

site_title: Singapore banks lose over S$37 billion in market value as tariff sell-off continues
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, suffered a significant decline in market value, losing over S$37 billion, amid a broader sell-off triggered by US tariffs. The tariffs, imposed by US President Donald Trump, have raised concerns about slower growth and potential rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve, which could weigh on bank margins and earnings. Analysts expect potential rate cuts to compress net interest margins, pressuring net interest income, but also see opportunities for fee income growth in wealth management.

site_title: Upper Serangoon Shopping Centre seeking S$260 million in en bloc market
summary: The six-storey Upper Serangoon Shopping Centre in Singapore is being marketed in a collective sale with a guide price of S$260 million. The site can be rebuilt into a mixed-use development with 154 homes, 56 serviced apartments, and 12,000 sq ft of commercial space. The sale includes an adjoining 5,443.3 sq m plot of land, which can also be developed separately. The development's redevelopment potential is expected to attract strong interest from local and international buyers, with the potential for a premium of up to 50% of its existing market value.

site_title: Liverpool’s rare loss delays title march, Southampton relegated
summary: Liverpool suffered its second Premier League defeat of the season, losing 3-2 to Fulham, while Southampton was relegated after a 3-1 loss to Tottenham. The loss delays Liverpool's title march, leaving them needing 11 points to secure a record-equalling 20th English top-flight championship.

site_title: Bank Indonesia intervenes in offshore rupiah ahead of reopening
summary: Bank Indonesia intervened in the offshore rupiah market ahead of the currency's reopening on Tuesday, aiming to stabilize the Indonesian rupiah after a 2.5% weekly gain. The central bank will also aggressively intervene in the onshore markets. The rupiah closed at 16,560 against the dollar on March 27, and offshore dollar-rupiah one-month NDFs rose 0.5% on Monday to 17,101. The government has vowed not to retaliate against the US's 32% tariff on Indonesian goods. The intervention comes amid rising concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's policies and the impact on fiscal consolidation measures.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s markets have so far avoided the turmoil from US President Donald Trump’s so-called reciprocal levies as they have been closed since Mar 28 for holidays.

site_title: Trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust declares notice of upcoming EGM is ‘invalid’; any resolutions passed will be void
summary: The trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust has declared an upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM) called by several dissenting unitholders "invalid" and "ineffective", stating that any resolutions passed during the meeting will be void. The trustee-manager has recommended that unitholders do not participate in the proposed EGM, citing that it was not involved in preparing or issuing the documents and has not conducted an independent review of the documents' contents. The EGM, set to take place on April 17, was proposed to terminate FTI Consulting as adviser to Dasin Retail Trust and appoint a new adviser.

Ocean Metro Mall, one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. A group of unitholders are seeking to internalise the trust's trustee-manager as well as replace its adviser.

site_title: Trump’s tariff ‘medicine’ injects turmoil into global markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, set to take effect this week, have triggered global market turmoil, with Asian stocks plummeting and US stock market futures opening sharply lower. Trump warned foreign leaders they would have to pay "a lot of money" to lift the tariffs, which could lead to higher prices, weaker demand, and potentially a global recession. Investors and leaders are seeking to convince Trump to lower the tariffs as high as 50%, with some countries offering talks and concessions to avoid the duties.

summary: A surge in cryptocurrency is envisioned, but before investing, consider the pros and cons. The writer questions whether one can stomach the volatility. Key factors to consider include the "pro-crypto" US President Donald Trump, Bitcoin's recent surge, and the potential for a massive surge ahead. However, it's recommended to slow down and ask why one should own cryptocurrency. The article aims to provide a clear-eyed look at the pluses and minuses of investing in crypto.

site_title: JPMorgan fund firm launches 3 active ETFs in Singapore; listing here ‘not off the table’
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management has launched three active exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in Singapore, following the success of its existing funds on the London Stock Exchange. The new listings signal the firm's commitment to the active ETF segment, with total assets under management of US$3.6 trillion, including US$242 billion in active ETFs. The funds are expected to drive demand, particularly among younger self-directed investors, and the company aims to manage US$1 trillion in active ETFs by 2029.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Active ETFs seek to outperform the indexes they are benchmarked to, including the S&P 500, the Nasdaq 100 and the Russell 1000 Growth Index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, The Hour Glass, Wee Hur Holdings
summary: Sembcorp Industries aims to expand its land bank to 18,000 hectares by 2028 and scale industrial properties to 1.5 million sq m. The company's gross renewables capacity is expected to reach 25 GW by 2028, with 17 GW installed as of February. The Hour Glass plans to acquire an Australian company for A$90 million, while Wee Hur Holdings experienced a cybersecurity incident but reported no significant impact to its business operations.

site_title: Unpacking demand for Singapore’s new condo launches
summary: Singapore's private new sale market continues to thrive despite geopolitical trade tensions, with robust sales at recent launches such as Parktown Residence and Emerald of Katong. Demand is driven by shifts in affordability, evolving buyer demographics, and project-specific appeal. Easing interest rates and rising HDB resale prices have improved affordability, while intergenerational wealth transfer has fueled demand from young buyers. The market's strong momentum suggests sustained sales, with developers aligning projects with evolving buyer preferences to achieve long-term growth.

site_title: South Korea to prepare support measures as US tariffs loom
summary: South Korea's finance minister plans to prepare support measures for sectors with urgent needs ahead of the US' 25% tariff on imports, set to come into force this week. The tariff affects South Korea's top-selling automobile exports, which accounted for 27% of the country's total exports to the US in 2024, valued at $127.8 billion. The government is reviewing a response strategy, with the trade minister set to visit the US this week to request a lower tariff rate.

site_title: Taiwan announces temporary short-selling curbs after US tariffs
summary: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission announced temporary curbs on short-selling of shares to mitigate market turmoil from US President Donald Trump's new import tariffs. The curbs, starting Monday, will limit the number of shares that can be sold short and raise the minimum short-selling margin ratio to 130% from 90%. The move aims to stabilize Taiwan's capital market amid global stock market plunges since the tariffs were unveiled, with the S&P 500 losing $5 trillion in two days.

images.alt_text: Trump has also closed a trade loophole that had allowed low-value packages from China to enter the US duty-free.

site_title: US dollar recovers after Fed signals caution on future easing
summary: The US dollar recovered 0.2% against major currencies, including the euro and yen, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled caution on future easing due to the impact of larger-than-expected US tariffs. China announced additional 34% tariffs on all US goods starting April 10, adding to recession concerns and intensifying a global stock market rout. The Australian dollar hit five-year lows against the greenback, while the Swiss Franc rose 0.6% versus the euro.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s markets have so far avoided the turmoil from US President Donald Trump’s so-called reciprocal levies as they have been closed since Mar 28 for holidays.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses on fears global trade war could slow economy
summary: Oil prices declined 3-3.5% on Monday, extending losses from the previous week, amid growing concerns a global trade war could slow the global economy and weaken oil demand. Brent futures fell $2.10 to $63.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures lost $2.14 to $59.85. The decline follows China's retaliation against US President Donald Trump's tariffs, which escalated a trade war that has led investors to price in a higher probability of recession.

site_title: AI Cyberattacks Are Here. “Come with me if you want to live.”
summary: AI cyberattacks are a growing concern, with the threat level likened to a fictional AI entity from The Terminator. According to Nick Marrett, Group CEO of Bruce Security Asia, AI-enabled attacks are becoming unstoppable unless countered with AI-powered defenses. The increasing sophistication of AI attacks demands a proactive approach from leaders to treat them as business risks. Failing to act may result in devastating consequences, as the AI entity will not stop until its objectives are achieved. Effective countermeasures are necessary to protect against these evolving threats.

site_title: Gold plunges to lowest in over 3 weeks as market sell-off hits bullion
summary: Gold prices plummeted 1.9% to US$2,981.09 an ounce, its lowest level in over three weeks, amid a wider market sell-off triggered by US President Donald Trump's tariff measures. The drop, which followed a 3% decline on Friday, has raised concerns of a global recession. Investors may be selling off gold to cover losses, potentially triggering a negative feedback loop. China has struck back at the US with counter-measures, deepening the trade war between the two economies.

images.alt_text: Rising material costs ultimately put pressure on profit margins in the sector, which have already been traditionally thin, says SK Jewellery's spokesperson.
