site_title: Making the leap from HDB to private condo
summary: Singapore's public and private housing markets have evolved in tandem with the nation's growth, driven by steady economic progress and increasing wealth across the board. Resale HDB flat prices have outpaced private home prices, with the HDB Resale Price Index growing 37.2% between 2019 and 2023, while private home prices rose 29.8%. This trend suggests that HDB homeowners can sell their flats at a gain, incentivizing more to upgrade to private housing. The price gap between HDB and private resale homes narrows when comparing the upper ranges of HDB resale prices to the lower end of the private market.

site_title: France’s Le Pen slams ‘witch hunt’ as ban dominates rival rallies
summary: France's National Rally leader Marine Le Pen vowed to pursue her presidential ambitions despite being found guilty of embezzlement and banned from office. Le Pen described the court sentence as a "witch hunt" targeting her party. The National Rally is currently leading in polls ahead of the 2027 presidential election, with Le Pen expected to be the frontrunner.

President of the far-right Rassemblement National (RN) parliamentary group Marine Le Pen was convicted over a scheme to take advantage of European Parliament expenses to employ assistants who were actually working for her far-right party in France.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Flipping the script on your Q1 investment missteps
summary: Host Howie Lim discusses Q1 investment mistakes with experts David Kuo and Hugh Chung. Despite market volatility, the trio offers a different perspective, providing insights on how to turn investment missteps around. They focus on major Q1 events, including market updates, and share strategies for investors to navigate the rest of 2025, including the potential for private equity to open up to regular investors and the resurgence of gold in an uncertain world. The episode aims to empower investors with knowledge to make informed decisions and improve their investment outcomes.

site_title: Further malaise ahead for 7 tech giants
summary: The Magnificent Seven tech giants, including Apple, Microsoft, and Amazon, have experienced their worst quarterly performance since Q3 2022, with the Bloomberg Magnificent Seven Price Index declining 16% in Q1 2025. This decline is attributed to a combination of factors, including fading AI momentum, economic concerns, and valuation headwinds. The AI-driven rally that propelled these stocks in recent years has lost momentum, and investors have shifted to defensive assets, further weighing on the performance of high-growth tech stocks.

site_title: Asia’s electricity prices to be increasingly impacted by renewables: BMI
summary: Asia's electricity prices are expected to rise modestly over 2025 due to the increasing influence of renewable energy, battery storage solutions, and grid infrastructure costs. The costs of thermal coal will diminish, while renewables integration, battery energy storage systems, and grid infrastructure costs will significantly impact electricity prices. Several regulators are moving forward with reforms to adopt electricity pricing that is reflective of costs and market forces, such as Vietnam's new electricity law and China's phase-out of feed-in tariffs. Additionally, rising liquefied natural gas imports and utility companies recouping losses from the global energy crisis will also contribute to price increases.

site_title: Shipping entrepreneur buying Leedon Park Good Class Bungalow for S$45.8 million
summary: A shipping entrepreneur, Guo Ningbo, is buying a Leedon Park Good Class Bungalow in Singapore for S$45.8 million, or S$2,929 psf, based on the freehold land area. The 14-year-old bungalow was developed by George Lim in 2011 and sold in 2012 for S$33 million. Guo, 47, co-founded Pioneer Logistics Holdings, a diversified shipowner enterprise, and is a naturalised Singapore citizen. The sale price reflects a record S$2,929 psf for a GCB Area transaction.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei sinks to 1½-year low as bank shares tumble
summary: Japan's Nikkei share index plummeted 8.8% to 30,792.74, its lowest level in 1½ years, as bank stocks tumbled 17% amid concerns over a global recession. The US S&P 500 has also dropped 10.6% since US President Donald Trump's latest round of tariffs. Analysts say the market is pricing in bad news but expect a bottom if there's flexibility on trade policies or economic support measures. Banks, particularly Nomura Holdings, Mizuho Financial Group, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, were heavily hit, with nearly a quarter of their combined value lost over the past three sessions.

site_title: Singapore’s strategic response to Trump tariffs
summary: Singapore must adopt a multi-pronged strategy to mitigate the impact of Trump's tariffs, leveraging its diplomatic channels, diversifying trade, and enhancing competitiveness. The small, open economy must navigate protectionist measures to safeguard its economic interests, businesses, and livelihoods. By building alliances and resourcefully adapting to the new trade dynamics, Singapore can sustain its position as a global trade hub and minimize risks.

summary: Analysts advise against "buying the dip" amid the steepest equity sell-off in years on Wall Street. They recommend a risk-off strategy and a shift towards defensive plays instead of rushing into the market. Experts, such as Philipp Lienhardt of Julius Baer, caution against prematurely buying into market weakness, especially in the US, and suggest diversifying into other markets. This approach aims to mitigate potential losses and capitalize on potential opportunities in the midst of market uncertainty.

site_title: Markets reel, world reacts as Trump’s sweeping tariffs take effect
summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs on all American imports took effect on Sunday, sparking global trade disruptions. The 10% tariff on imports from countries such as Singapore, Australia, and Brazil has sent shockwaves through markets, with the US stock market plummeting over 5% on Friday. Higher "reciprocal" tariffs of up to 50% are set to take effect later in the week on imports from around 60 nations. Global leaders have condemned the tariffs as "fundamentally wrong" and are seeking to retaliate, raising concerns of a global trade war.

summary: Australian shares plummeted 4.2% in their worst session since the pandemic, wiping out billions in stock market value, due to US tariffs under President Donald Trump fueling recession fears. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,343.30 points. Miners, heavily exposed to Chinese commodity demand, saw significant drops, with BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue falling between 3% and 6%. The decline is attributed to concerns over the impact of US tariffs on the global economy.

site_title: Singaporeans have to work together to deal with uncertainty, says SM Lee, citing new Trump tariffs
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Singaporeans to work together to deal with uncertainty, citing US President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs. The tariffs will affect trade, economy, region, and future, Lee said, emphasizing the importance of unity and resilience. Lee also highlighted SG60 as a time for Singaporeans to prepare themselves to make the country better, ensuring safety and prosperity.

site_title: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink gets 14% compensation bump in 2024
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink received a 14% increase in compensation to $30.8 million in 2024, with President Rob Kapito and CFO Martin Small also receiving significant pay raises. The company's commitment to private markets is reflected in Fink's additional pay perks and recent acquisitions totaling $12.5 billion. Long-term incentive pay is also being used to retain top brass, with no mention of a successor to Fink.

site_title: Karin leans into Chinese tech demand to keep 47-year profit run alive
summary: Karin Technology, a 47-year-old company, has maintained its flawless financial record despite growing interest in Chinese tech amid the US-China rivalry. CEO Michael Ng attributes this to strict financial controls and discipline in accounting practices. The company is shifting its focus from public-sector mega projects to commercial ones, diversifying its revenue streams. Revenue from its IT segment fell 10.2% in the first half of 2025, but net profit remained stable. Karin remains optimistic about its prospects, with plans for regional expansion in the medium term, particularly in Singapore and South-east Asia.

DeepSeek’s models, which focus on “inference” or when an AI model produces conclusions, optimise computational efficiency rather than relying solely on raw processing power.

A photo illustration taken in Beijing on March 11, 2025 shows a mobile phone displaying an introduction screen for the AI assistant tool Manus, released by Chinese startup Butterfly Effect. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

Nvidia has been a dominant player in AI computing in recent years, with its processors powering data centres that support chatbots and other tools. The company’s shares have been a safe bet for a long time, gaining nearly 900 per cent from the start of 2023 to late January.

site_title: Snappy birthday: Germany’s Leica camera turns 100
summary: Germany's Leica camera is celebrating its 100th birthday, marking the milestone since its first commercial camera was introduced in 1925. Founded in 1869, Leica has become synonymous with high-quality photography, still assembled by hand in Wetzlar, Germany. Despite market competition from Japanese giants, Leica continues to thrive, with projected sales reaching a record 600 million euros in 2024/25. The company has diversified into watches, laser projectors, and smartphone cameras, but maintains a focus on traditional photography, with CEO Matthias Harsch insisting that the romance of the Leica camera cannot be replicated by technology.

images.alt_text: The true winner of the AI race, however, may not be the country that invents the best models. It is more likely to be the country where governments, businesses and ordinary people use AI at scale every day.

site_title: GE2025: PSP unveils manifesto focused on reducing cost of living, building new social compact
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has unveiled its manifesto for the upcoming General Election (GE2025), focusing on reducing the cost of living, building a new social compact, and addressing key issues such as housing, jobs, and education. The party proposes a quota for employment pass holders, a monthly levy on foreign professionals, and government subsidies for healthcare premiums. It also calls for reducing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from 9% to 7%. The PSP will contest in West Coast-Jurong West and Chua Chu Kang Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and field fewer candidates than in 2020.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
PSP's West Coast-Jurong West team greeting a resident. From left: Leong Mun Wai, Sumarleki Amjah, Tan Cheng Bock, Sani Ismail and Hazel Poa.

The newly elected members of the Progress Singapore Party's central executive committee: (front row, from left) Wendy Low, Leong Mun Wai, Tan Cheng Bock, Hazel Poa and A'bas Kasmani; (back row, from left) S Nallakaruppan, Jonathan Tee, Joseph Wong, Phang Yew Huat, Soh Zheng Long, Anthony Neo and Samuel Lim.
Singapore election 2025: Changes to Singapore’s electoral divisions with more MPs, new GRCs and SMCs
Singapore election 2025: The EBRC report recommended widespread changes, with only five GRCs and four SMCs untouched.

site_title: Protesters rally across Spain against housing crisis, tourist flats
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Spain marched across 40 cities to protest soaring rents and a lack of affordable homes. Average rents have doubled and house prices have swelled by 44% over the past decade, outpacing salary growth. The country's centre-left government struggles to balance attracting tourists and migrants with keeping rents affordable for average citizens. A housing deficit of 500,000 homes exists, with only 120,000 new homes built annually, exacerbating the shortage. Protests call for action to defend housing rights and address the issue.

site_title: Japan’s nominal wages rise in bright spot as outlook darkens
summary: Japan's nominal wages rose 3.1% in February from a year earlier, accelerating from a revised 1.8% in January, according to the labour ministry. This positive sign for the domestic economy contrasts with external headwinds, including trade tensions, which are clouding the outlook. The reading beat economists' estimates, while a more stable gauge showed base pay for full-time workers increasing 1.9%, the lowest rate in 18 months. The wage growth is a bright spot for Japan's economy.

images.alt_text: Japan’s automotive sector comprises 20 per cent of the country’s total exports and the majority of exports are headed to the US market.

Aside from the direct impact on global trade, Donald Trump’s tariffs, set at 24 per cent for Japanese goods, could affect corporate sentiment and market moves by heightening uncertainty over the economic outlook, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said.
Inflation has stayed at or above the BOJ’s price target for almost three years, sapping spending power, and the latest tariffs from the US are now expected to weaken the economy further.

site_title: Don’t rush to take advantage of the big sell-off
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs have triggered a global market downturn, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 falling 9.1% and 9.8% respectively. The tariffs, which include a 10% baseline rate and higher reciprocal rates for countries with trade deficits, have weakened the US dollar and weighed on global economic activity and corporate earnings. Investors are advised to remain cautious, as the situation may take several months to resolve, and the US dollar's status as a global reserve currency is under threat. Markets in South-east Asia, which are heavily reliant on trade with the US, are particularly vulnerable.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Since Trump’s inauguration, US stocks have pulled back from all-time highs amid growing fears of stagflation or even an outright recession.
It could be just a matter of time before the Fed cuts rates, which should take pressure off regional currencies
Vietnam, a major regional manufacturing base for many Western companies, posted a trade surplus of over US$123 billion with the US, its largest export destination, last year.

Protests were planned in all 50 states plus Canada and Mexico; they are expected to form the largest single day of protest against President Donald Trump and his billionaire ally Elon Musk since they launched a rapid-fire effort to overhaul government and expand presidential authority.
Vietnam exported US$44 billion in textiles last year, with the US as its largest market, according to the nation’s textile and apparel association.
Indonesia’s markets have so far avoided the turmoil from US President Donald Trump’s so-called reciprocal levies as they have been closed since Mar 28 for holidays.

site_title: Oil price in freefall reorders global energy landscape
summary: Oil prices plummeted 13% to around $66 a barrel, upending President Trump's "energy dominance" agenda. The decline, driven by OPEC's surprise production boost and US tariffs, threatens to derail US drillers' plans to increase production. Middle Eastern petrostates, including Saudi Arabia, are taking a hit, with the country pushing to triple its May production increase to punish non-compliant members. Lower oil prices will ease energy costs in Europe but squeeze Middle Eastern states, which rely on high oil prices to fund government spending.

images.alt_text: Global benchmark Brent futures settled US$4.56, or 6.5 per cent, lower at US$65.58 a barrel.

site_title: Malaysia pushes for coordinated South-east Asia tariff response
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced the country will lead efforts to coordinate a regional response to US President Donald Trump's tariffs, aiming to present a united front and maintain open supply chains. As Asean chair, Malaysia will engage with the US to find a "mutually acceptable solution" and ensure the region's collective voice is heard. The country has not retaliated against the tariffs, but may review its GDP growth targets if the tariffs come into effect on April 9. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the tariffs on the region's economies.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said it is more important than ever to cherish and to protect what people have in Singapore.

site_title: Going, going, gone: UK non-dom exits quicken after tax perk ends
summary: The UK is seeing a surge in wealthy individuals, including top bankers and business owners, leaving the country after the end of its preferential tax regime for non-domiciled residents. Approximately 75,000 non-doms, who contribute £8 billion in taxes annually, are expected to exit the UK as the tax regime is replaced with a residency-based system. The move is part of UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves' efforts to plug a £40 billion economic hole, with some experts warning of a potential £111 billion cost to the UK over the next decade, including 40,000 jobs lost.

images.alt_text: A view of the Canary Wharf financial district and residential houses in London, Britain, January 23, 2025. REUTERS/Hannah McKay

site_title: GE2025: Parties continue to introduce prospective candidates as election draws near
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and opposition parties continue to introduce prospective candidates ahead of the upcoming Singapore general election. Former senior civil servants, including Jeffrey Siow and Shawn Loh, were spotted at community events, sparking speculation about potential PAP candidates. The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) unveiled its manifesto, focusing on reducing the cost of living and building a new social compact. The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) introduced its five-member team to contest in Sembawang GRC, while the National Solidarity Party (NSP) has expressed interest in contesting the same area.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
xxx
Each party stands for different approaches to fiscal policy, cost of living, foreign talent and housing.
Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.
Global inflation rose sharply in 2022 following the outbreak of the war in Ukraine.
From mid-2025, singles applying for BTO flats will get priority access when they buy a home near or with their parents.

site_title: S-Reits record net institutional inflows in March as sector snaps 5-month losing streak
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) outperformed the global Reit market in March, with the iEdge S-Reit Index rising 1.4% following US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement. This marked the sector's first positive week in five consecutive losses. Institutional investors rotated into S-Reits, with S$26 million of net inflows during the Apr 3 session, driven by a preference for relative stability and income potential amid market volatility. S-Reits ended the first quarter with total returns of 2.8%, driven by a 5% price gain in March, their best monthly return in eight months.

images.alt_text: Sasseur Reit – which owns four outlet malls in China – reported stable EMA (entrusted management agreement) rental income and distributable income in FY2024 amid lower finance cost and tax expenses, despite a yoy reduction in sales.

site_title: Over 36,000 HDB households set to benefit from upgrading works in their neighbourhoods
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced plans to upgrade 17 HDB projects, benefiting over 36,000 households, under the Neighbourhood Renewal Programme (NRP). The programme, which has a budget of $165 million, includes new facilities such as covered walkways, drop-off porches, and senior-friendly amenities. Additionally, the Silver Upgrading Programme will be rolled out to 12 precincts, benefiting 11,000 households, with enhancements including therapeutic gardens, fitness trails, and way-finding features. The upgrades aim to improve the livability and accessibility of HDB homes for residents, particularly seniors.

images.alt_text: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong (left) was accompanied by East Coast GRC's anchor minister Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat during his first public walkabout in the constituency.
From mid-2025, singles applying for BTO flats will get priority access when they buy a home near or with their parents.

site_title: PSL becomes Uni-Asia substantial shareholder; Oceanus Group’s Peter Koh adds to stake
summary: Institutional investors increased their net buying of Singapore stocks by S$76 million from Mar 28 to Apr 3, reversing a S$170 million net outflow over the preceding 10 sessions. The top net institutional inflow stocks were Singtel, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and Yangzijiang Financial. Meanwhile, UOB, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Seatrium led the net institutional outflow. Uni-Asia Group became a substantial shareholder of itself after Unity Ventures' acquisition of 46,000 shares, increasing PSL's stake to 5.02%. Oceanus Group executive director Peter Koh acquired 10 million shares, increasing his stake to 12.07%.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of SGX logo

site_title: Growing pains of going green among local eco-conscious brands
summary: Local eco-conscious brands face challenges scaling up their sustainable businesses. .bungkus, kupaa, and Webeings, featured at the recent Boutiques Singapore fair, struggle with operational and production issues despite their commitment to sustainability. Brands are exploring alternative materials, die-cutting techniques, and online sales to streamline production and reduce costs. Design and pricing are also key factors, with high-quality products commanding higher prices. The entrepreneurs emphasize the importance of finding a niche audience and educating customers about the craftsmanship behind their products, with sustainability becoming a standard for businesses, not just niche players.

site_title: More than 50 countries have contacted White House to start trade talks, Trump adviser says
summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping new tariffs have triggered global turmoil, with over 50 countries reaching out to the White House to begin trade talks. US National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett denied that the tariffs were a strategy to crash financial markets, stating there would be no "political coercion" of the central bank. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent downplayed the stock market drop, saying there's "no reason" to anticipate a recession based on the tariffs. The tariffs have led to a 10% drop in US stocks over the past two days, with economists warning of risk of inflation and damaging economic growth.

images.alt_text: World leaders have hit back and markets plummeted since US President Donald Trump unveiling sweeping tariffs on American imports last week.

site_title: Vietnam GDP growth slowed in first quarter ahead of Trump’s tariffs
summary: Vietnam's GDP growth slowed to 6.93% in the first quarter of 2025, down from 7.55% in the previous quarter, ahead of US President Donald Trump's 46% tariff on Vietnamese exports. Industrial production increased 7.8% year-on-year, but faces challenges due to the tariffs and global uncertainty. The government aims for at least 8% growth this year, with the remaining quarters requiring a 8.2-8.4% increase. The tariff may cut GDP growth by 0.84 percentage points, particularly affecting the garment, footwear, electronics, and smartphone sectors.

images.alt_text: Vietnam, a major regional manufacturing base for many Western companies, posted a trade surplus of over US$123 billion with the US, its largest export destination, last year.

site_title: US, Vietnamese businesses ask Trump to delay 46% tariffs on Vietnam
summary: US and Vietnamese businesses have asked the Trump administration to delay a 46% tariff on Vietnamese goods, citing concerns it will hurt them and bilateral commercial relations. The Vietnam Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the American Chamber of Commerce in Hanoi expressed their concerns to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, saying the tariff is "shockingly high." Vietnam, a major manufacturing base for Western companies, posted a trade surplus of over $123 billion with the US last year. A deal to remove tariffs was agreed upon by President Trump and Vietnamese leader To Lam after a phone call.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of a container ship and shipping containers in California. In the wake of the tariffs, economists warned that Liberation Day has made a US recession more likely.

site_title: Siemens is planning sale, leaseback of headquarters in Portugal
summary: Siemens is planning to sell and leaseback its Lisbon headquarters, covering 10 football fields and employing 2,800 people. The company received non-binding offers at the end of March and real estate broker CBRE is advising on the sale. Siemens is among a handful of multinational companies with hubs in Lisbon, including Google and Mercedes-Benz. The sale is part of the company's constant review of its portfolio, but details cannot be provided. Potential bidders will soon have the chance to submit binding offers.

site_title: Opec+ stuns oil market with policy shift to drive down price
summary: Opec+ has made a surprise decision to increase oil production by three times the planned amount in May, aiming to drive down prices and punish countries that have exceeded their output limits. The move, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, is seen as a deliberate effort to counter the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariff announcements on the oil market. The increased supply is expected to turbocharge the rout in oil prices, which are already reeling from the tariffs and have fallen to an almost two-year low of US$65.21 a barrel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Wall Street fears job cuts as dealmaking fizzles in trade war
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Bank of America, are revising down internal revenue projections for their advisory businesses due to the slowdown in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) caused by the ongoing trade war. Executives are considering job cuts in the second half of the year if the environment doesn't improve. The US dollar's decline and Trump's tariffs have led to market volatility and caused companies to pause initial public offerings, resulting in reduced fees for banks and underwriters.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump’s announcement on Wednesday of major tariffs on US trading partners around the world sent the S&P 500 index of US stocks to its lowest level in 11 months.

site_title: GE2025: PAP, WP and PSP agree that Singapore needs foreign talent. But they differ on the balance
summary: Singapore's ruling party and opposition parties agree that the country needs foreign talent, but differ on the balance. The People's Action Party (PAP) and the Workers' Party (WP) support measures to attract and integrate foreign workers, while the Progressive Singapore Party (PSP) calls for greater safeguards and transparency. The PAP has introduced the Complementarity Assessment Framework to evaluate foreign workers' skills and the Fair Consideration Framework to ensure fair competition. The WP and PSP propose tracking skills-related underemployment and job displacement, and imposing diversity quotas. The government highlights the role of foreign workers in widening the tax base and supporting social spending.

site_title: Intel, TSMC recently discussed chipmaking joint venture: report
summary: Intel and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) have discussed a joint venture to operate Intel's US chip factories, with TSMC taking a 20% stake. The White House and Commerce department officials have been pushing for the deal to resolve Intel's long-running crisis. Intel's CEO, Lip-Bu Tan, appointed to revive the company's fortunes after missing the AI-driven semiconductor boom. TSMC plans to invest $100 billion in US chip facilities, and Intel reported a $18.8 billion net loss in 2024.

images.alt_text: Intel needs to replace the engineering talent it has lost, improve its balance sheet and better attune manufacturing processes to meet the needs of potential customers, CEO Ten Lip-Bu said.
DeepSeek’s focus on reasoning will increase the need for computation, helping drive demand for Nvidia chips, Jensen Huang says.
Intel will also restart plans to produce chips that power AI servers and look to areas beyond servers in several areas such as software, robotics and AI foundation models.

site_title: ‘A Minecraft Movie’ strikes gold to dominate North American box office
summary: "A Minecraft Movie" has dominated the North American box office, grossing an estimated US$157 million in its opening weekend, surpassing expectations and becoming the most successful adaptation from a video game, beating the US$146 million opening of "Super Mario Bros. Movie" in 2023. The film, made with Legendary Pictures and starring Jack Black, Jason Momoa, and Jennifer Coolidge, has a production budget of US$150 million and is expected to earn over US$301 million globally.

Director James Gunn with David Corenswet, Rachel Brosnahan and Nicholas Hoult promote the movie "Superman" at CinemaCon, the official convention of Cinema United, Las Vegas, Nevada, April 1, 2025.

site_title: Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ will go down in history – just not as he hoped
summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, unveiled on April 2, have sent the US economy into turmoil. The S&P 500 plummeted 12% in its first two sessions, marking the largest two-session loss since the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists warn that "Liberation Day" may mark the tipping point towards a US recession, as tariffs drive up prices for all American imports. The move has sparked a global trade war, with China retaliating with 34% tariffs on US goods, and many other countries likely to follow suit.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said it is more important than ever to cherish and to protect what people have in Singapore.
WP chief Pritam Singh said change and unpredictability is an ever-present reality for nations that are reliant on trade.
Trump has also closed a trade loophole that had allowed low-value packages from China to enter the US duty-free.
No one lost more over the two-day stretch than Tesla chief executive officer Elon Musk.

site_title: Anti-Trump protesters gather in Washington, other US cities
summary: Thousands of protesters gathered in Washington, DC, and across the US on April 5, part of a nationwide demonstration against President Donald Trump and his billionaire ally Elon Musk. Over 1,200 events were planned in all 50 states plus Canada and Mexico, with an expected 20,000 attendees at the National Mall rally. Protesters criticized Trump's policies on tariffs, immigration, education, and Social Security, with many expressing concerns about the impact on the economy and government institutions. Trump was not present at the rallies, instead spending the day in Florida, while Musk's Department of Government Efficiency team has eliminated over 200,000 federal jobs.

images.alt_text: At the start of the year, investment bankers around the world were hopeful that Trump would fan the flames of the nascent recovery in M&A that got underway in 2024.

site_title: MOM to make three ‘strategic shifts’ to better serve Singaporeans: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) will make three strategic shifts to better serve the country and its citizens in a rapidly changing global economy. These shifts include empowering workers to access good job opportunities, building inclusive workplaces, and strengthening trust between workers and businesses. The ministry will also roll out a new scheme, the SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, to help workers who face employment difficulties. Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the need for manpower to be an "offensive strategy" to attract talent and drive economic growth.

site_title: North Korea holds first Pyongyang International Marathon in six years
summary: North Korea held its first Pyongyang International Marathon in six years on April 6, 2025, with about 200 foreign runners from China, Romania, and other countries participating. The event, which was organized by Koryo Tours, took place in central Pyongyang, passing major landmarks and ending at a stadium filled with 50,000 spectators. This is the first major international event in the country since the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw the closure of its borders in 2020. The marathon is one of several events to celebrate the Apr 15 birthday of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's founder.

images.alt_text: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola (left) with Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim before their respective teams played each other at the Etihad Stadium in Manchester last December. United won the match, thanks to two late goals.

site_title: South-east Asia rushes to avert tariff pain by enticing Trump
summary: Countries in South-east Asia are attempting to negotiate with US President Donald Trump to avoid severe tariffs on their exports, including Vietnam, which exported $44 billion in textiles to the US last year. In response to Trump's tariffs, Vietnam has offered to drop tariffs on US goods and heighten imports, while Cambodia and Indonesia have also pledged to ease trade rules. Singapore has chosen not to retaliate, and Malaysia is coordinating with its neighbors to find a collective response. The US has indicated openness to agreements if countries offer something "phenomenal", with Trump saying the tariffs give the US "great power to negotiate".

images.alt_text: An aerial view of a container ship and shipping containers in California. In the wake of the tariffs, economists warned that Liberation Day has made a US recession more likely.

site_title: China hits back at US tariffs with export controls on key rare earths
summary: China has imposed export restrictions on rare earth elements, a group of 17 elements used in defense, electric vehicles, and electronics, in retaliation for US President Donald Trump's tariffs. The move affects exports to all countries and includes not only mined minerals but also finished products, making it difficult for the US to find alternatives. China produces 90% of the world's rare earths, and the US relies heavily on Chinese supply chains. The move is seen as a demonstration of China's ability to weaponize its dominance in the mining and processing of these critical minerals.

images.alt_text: Beijing also announced controls on exports of medium and heavy rare earths, including samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium, to the US, effective Apr 4.

summary: Singapore's ruling PAP party has proposed measures to address cost-of-living pressures, following global inflation's sharp rise in 2022 due to the Ukraine war. Despite inflation easing in 2024, Singaporeans are adjusting to new price realities. The PAP government introduced various measures in Budget 2025, including assistance for immediate cost concerns. The proposals aim to help Singaporeans cope with the ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: Honda sets up dedicated business in US to tap into space boom
summary: Honda has established a dedicated business unit in the US to tap into the growing space industry. The company, which has been expanding its space activities, will work with US startups Sierra Space and Tec-Masters to test its technology on the International Space Station. Honda aims to leverage its core technologies to support human activities and lunar development, although details on the unit's size and budget remain undisclosed. This move marks Honda's growing presence in the space sector.

site_title: US tariffs could trigger ‘full-blown global trade war’: PM Wong
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent tariffs on Singapore and other countries may trigger a global trade war, according to Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. Wong warned Singaporeans to brace for more shocks ahead as the country stands on a strong foundation. The 10% tariff on most goods imported into the US from Singapore and key partners may lead to retaliation from other countries, potentially sparking a full-blown global trade war.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump’s latest tariff torpedo means South-east Asian countries have their work cut out for them as they face one of their biggest tests in recent times.
Trade-reliant Singapore will take ‘bigger hit’ than others in US tariffs-induced slowdown: PM Wong
Under Singapore's free trade agreement with the US, Singapore has recourse to take countermeasures and seek dispute resolution – but has decided not to do so.

site_title: Bank Indonesia vows to support rupiah amid trade tariffs threat
summary: Bank Indonesia has pledged to intervene in domestic markets to ensure rupiah stability amid a global trade war surge. The central bank will provide sufficient foreign exchange liquidity to meet banks' and businesses' needs, and maintain market confidence. Markets in Indonesia have so far avoided the turmoil due to being closed since March 28 for holidays. The rupiah is expected to weaken when markets reopen, with offshore one-month dollar-rupiah forward contracts climbing 2.5% since domestic markets closed. Bank Indonesia will monitor global and domestic financial markets to mitigate potential hot money outflows.

site_title: China says ‘market has spoken’ after US tariffs spark sell-off
summary: China responded to US President Donald Trump's introduction of additional 34% tariffs on Chinese goods, calling it "the market has spoken" after global markets reacted negatively. China's foreign ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun urged Washington for "equal-footed consultation." Chinese commerce associations in various industries warned that the tariffs would worsen inflation in the US and called for unity in exploring alternative markets. The US tariffs also closed a trade loophole allowing low-value packages from China to enter the US duty-free.

images.alt_text: China remains the largest market for US agricultural products, but imports of US farm goods dropped for the second consecutive year.

site_title: US SEC says stablecoins aren’t securities that require registration
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has determined that stablecoins, as long as they are backed by a stable currency or commodity, are not securities requiring registration. This decision applies to stablecoin issuers and exchanges, providing a boost to the crypto industry. The determination is a significant shift in regulatory clarity, allowing stablecoins to operate without the need for registration, pending the passage of a stablecoin bill in the House and Senate.

images.alt_text: Fidelity has been one of the earliest proponents of digital assets and blockchain on Wall Street.
Trump, who campaigned on promises to be a “crypto president,” has pledged to overhaul US rules on crypto.
“If the President of the US says this is top priority for the US, Big Four auditing firms will have to listen, so we are very happy with that,” said Paolo Ardoino, CEO of Tether.
Dollar-backed stablecoins distributed by the biggest issuers Tether and Circle are already used in billions of US dollars of transactions a day.

site_title: US: Wall St opens sharply lower, Nasdaq heads toward bear market
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on April 4, with the Nasdaq Composite heading towards a bear market, after China imposed fresh tariffs on all US goods in response to the Trump administration's levies. The tech-heavy Nasdaq dropped over 20% from its all-time high, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also declined. The move escalates the global trade war and raises concerns about the impact on the US economy.

site_title: S’pore must be ‘nimble’ in wake of US tariffs and stay united, says WP chief Pritam Singh
summary: Singapore must remain "nimble and fleet-footed" in the wake of US-imposed tariffs, said WP chief Pritam Singh. As a country reliant on trade, Singapore must adapt to change and unpredictability. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has called for the country to stay united in the face of uncertainties. The 10% tariff imposed on Singapore's exports to the US and higher duties imposed on other countries highlight the need for Singapore to be proactive in navigating the global trade landscape.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said it is more important than ever to cherish and to protect what people have in Singapore.

site_title: Meta plans nearly US$1 billion data centre project in Wisconsin
summary: Meta Platforms plans to invest nearly $1 billion in a data centre project in central Wisconsin, expanding its cloud infrastructure and artificial intelligence efforts. This project, combined with a $65 billion investment for the year, underscores the company's focus on building AI-oriented infrastructure. Wisconsin has emerged as an attractive location for hyperscalers, with Microsoft and OpenAI also developing data centres in the state. The project is expected to provide transformative economic benefits to the community and area, according to local economic development authorities.

images.alt_text: Dan Neary, Meta’s vice-president for the region, assumed the role in 2013 and oversaw the rapid expansion of the company’s user base from Australia to Greater China and South-east Asia.

Meta is investing heavily in artificial intelligence infrastructure, seeking to better compete in a fast-moving race against the likes of OpenAI and Google as well as upstarts such as Hangzhou-based DeepSeek.
The Magnificent Seven stocks – Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Amazon.com, Tesla, Alphabet and Meta – are seen as particular beneficiaries of AI.

Both Meta and Apple have been in the European Commission’s crosshairs since last year for potential breaches of the Digital Markets Act which could cost companies as much as 10 per cent of their global annual sales.

site_title: Malaysia refutes US claim on tariffs, doesn’t expect recession
summary: Malaysia's government denies US claims of a 47% tariff on American imports, stating it will engage with Washington to find a fair solution. The country is assessing the impact of US tariffs and reviewing its economic growth forecast of 4.5-5.5%. In response to the tariffs, Malaysia plans to strengthen its supply chain and diversify trade and investment interests to mitigate the impact. The government's move aims to shield the economy from potential recession.

site_title: GE2025: How parties are dealing with concerns over housing needs
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) is introducing measures to address concerns over housing affordability. From mid-2025, singles applying for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats will receive priority access when buying a home near or with their parents. The move aims to encourage young couples to settle down and own their own homes. This initiative follows a pledge by the PAP government to launch up to 100,000 new flats by 2025 to meet pandemic-induced demand. The measures aim to keep housing accessible and affordable for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Global inflation rose sharply in 2022 following the outbreak of the war in Ukraine.
Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.
Each party stands for different approaches to fiscal policy, cost of living, foreign talent and housing.
Dr Ong Lue Ping served as IMH’s head of psychology for six years between 2015 and 2021, and director of allied health from 2022 to 2024.
National Development Minister Desmond Lee and trade unionist Natasha Choy at an event held in Jalan Mas Kuning on April 2.
Potential WP candidate Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik (in grey shirt) at a Sengkang GRC townhall meeting on March 29. He is a senior property manager at Aljunied-Hougang Town Council.

Minister for Law K Shanmugam says fellow Nee Soon GRC MP Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim is "unlikely to be here" after the associate professor was spotted at Eunos Crescent Market and Food Centre.

site_title: Australia’s Albanese pledges A$2.3b to help homeowners buy solar batteries
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese pledged A$2.3 billion to help homeowners buy solar batteries, aiming to lower energy costs. This move comes as his centre-left Labor party runs neck-and-neck in opinion polls with the opposition led by Peter Dutton, who has campaigned on lowering power bills. The proposal is expected to save households about A$4,000 or 30% on the installed cost of a typical energy-storage battery, addressing a major issue in the upcoming general election.

images.alt_text: Australian politicians are using social media including Xiaohongshu, a Chinese lifestyle app also called RedNote, and other campaign strategies to appeal to Chinese communities who will again be a crucial bloc in the upcoming election.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for April 4, 2025, provides an overview of the tanker and dry bulk market. Key highlights include:

- The Capesize market experienced a midweek rebound in the Pacific, driven by strong C5 activity, but softened later due to holidays in Hong Kong and China.
- Panamax rates stalled due to the US tariff measure uncertainty and a lack of demand, with rates now closer to mid $17,000.
- Ultramax/Supramax rates were slow, with limited activity and a lack of fresh demand.
- Handysize rates remained flat, with minimal visible activity and steady rates.
- LR2 rates leveled off, with MEG LR2s holding steady, while LR1 rates remained flat due to vessel availability.
- MR rates suffered downward pressure, with the USG MR rate dipping $5,747.
- Suezmax rates came under pressure due to problems between the US and CPC terminal operators and OPEC's "over-production" by Caspian oil fields producers.
- Aframax rates improved in the North Sea but fell in the Mediterranean.
- LNG market softened in the Atlantic basin, while the Pacific market remained relatively stable.
- LPG market maintained its positive momentum, with rates rising across key routes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The second oil tanker sold to Venezuela is seen in Bushehr coast, Iran on June 8, 2022.  PDVSA paid almost 157 million euros (about $173 million), or 63% of the 248 million euros (about $272 million) to U.S.-sanctioned Iran Marine Industrial Company (Sadra) for four tankers, according to the documents. Two of the four vessels have been delivered after payment delays, difficulties with parts supplies and problems with insurance and certifications. Sadra Company/WANA (West Asia News Agency)/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY./File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 4)
summary: Retail sales in Singapore excluding motor vehicles dropped 6.7% year-over-year in March, compared to January's 5.1% growth. This is the lowest since 2020. The decline is attributed to the impact of US tariffs on Asian economies. In other news, semiconductor and shipbuilding stocks suffered heavy losses, and the share prices of major banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also retreated. Meanwhile, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Indonesia are set to face challenges in their expansion plans due to the US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Though Singapore has recourse under its free trade agreement with the US, it will instead engage its US counterparts to address their concerns, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong.

site_title: ‘Worst-case scenario’ for tech wipes US$1.4 trillion from Nasdaq
summary: US technology companies face a "worst-case scenario" as the Nasdaq 100 index has fallen 16% in six weeks, wiping out $1.4 trillion in market capitalization. The decline is largely due to President Trump's new tariff regime, which has imposed levies of 54% on China and 32% on Taiwan. Chipmakers, including Apple, Nvidia, and Broadcom, are particularly affected, with some stocks plummeting 20% or more. Investors expect further volatility and a potential bear market, with some analysts warning that the tariffs could lead to a recession.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks on tariffs in the Rose Garden at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., April 2, 2025. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo

A television station broadcasts stock market news on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Losses accelerated through world markets as trading shifted into the US on deepening concern President Donald Trump’s trade war will upend the global economy. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

Mark Zuckerberg, the Meta founder was the biggest loser in US dollar terms, with the social media company’s 9 per cent slide costing its chief executive officer US$17.9 billion, or around 9 per cent of his wealth.

An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The US would place a 46 per cent tariff on Vietnam’s exports, 36 per cent on Thailand’s, and 32 per cent on Indonesia’s.

TOPSHOT - Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York City, on April 3, 2025. Wall Street stocks sank in early trading on April 3,2025, joining a global equity selloff after President Donald Trump's latest tariff announcement exacerbated worries about a trade war and global economic downturn. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 4.0 per cent lower at 40,545.93, a loss of more than 1,600 points on Thursday.

The tariff announcement has put more pressure on a US stock market that had already floundered this year, as investors braced for Trump’s policies to stir up inflation and raise the odds of a recession in the world’s largest economy.
Trump began speaking after Wall Street closed, and both S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures reversed gains as investors blanched at his sweeping tariff plans.

site_title: Oil dives 7% to lowest in over three years on China’s tariffs
summary: Oil prices plummeted 7% to their lowest in over three years due to China's imposition of 34% tariffs on US goods, escalating a trade war. Global benchmark Brent futures fell to $65.58 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped to $61.99. This led to a 10.9% weekly loss for Brent and a 10.6% decline for WTI, with investment bank JPMorgan now predicting a 60% chance of a global economic recession by year-end.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled at US$70.14 a barrel, down US$4.81, or 6.42 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Women and their money
summary: Women have made significant strides in financial empowerment, with a 81% increase in female billionaires from 2015 to 2024. However, they still lag behind men in terms of wealth. Despite this, more women are completing education and participating in the workforce, leading to greater income potential and financial savvy. Nevertheless, women face obstacles such as lower-paying jobs and reduced opportunities for career advancement, particularly those who take career breaks to care for family. Greater awareness of these challenges is essential for women to make informed financial decisions.

images.alt_text: Women tend to change jobs less frequently, which limits opportunities to renegotiate pay.
The more guaranteed and reliable income flows like payouts from CPF Life, retirement income insurance and fixed income can be used to meet your needs.
Although the "financial independence, retire early" movement has gained followers, there is no need to be pressured by achieving a retirement magic number or meeting a looming retirement deadline.

site_title: M&A and IPOs worth billions stalled in 24 hours by trade war
summary: Billions of US dollars in acquisitions and initial public offerings (IPOs) are on hold due to the ongoing trade war between the US and China. Companies such as StubHub, Klarna, eToro, and Medline Industries have delayed or paused their listings, citing market volatility and uncertainty. The trade war has led to a decline in global M&A activity and a widening of spreads on public transactions. Executives are revising down revenue projections and considering job cuts, and markets have extended deep losses, wiping out $5.4 trillion in market value.

images.alt_text: China produces around 90 per cent of the world’s rare earths, a group of 17 elements used across the defence, electric vehicle, energy and electronics industries.
Donald Trump’s announcement on Wednesday of major tariffs on US trading partners around the world sent the S&P 500 index of US stocks to its lowest level in 11 months.
Trump has said he would be willing to reduce tariffs on China to get a deal done with ByteDance to sell the app used by 170 million Americans.
“While tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation, it is also possible that the effects could be more persistent,” Powell says.

site_title: Fed’s Powell says larger-than-expected tariffs mean higher inflation, slower growth
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says larger-than-expected tariffs by President Donald Trump will likely lead to higher inflation and slower economic growth, citing a "highly uncertain outlook" with risks of both higher unemployment and inflation. The Fed will wait for more data to decide on monetary policy, focusing on keeping longer-term inflation expectations anchored. Powell notes that tariffs could lead to a more persistent jump in price pressures, emphasizing the need for the Fed to address this outcome. The Fed's stance may remain unchanged until it's clear which trend - slower growth or rising prices - takes hold more forcefully.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk past a restaurant, with a hiring sign outside, in Washington, DC on October 5, 2023. The US private sector added more jobs than anticipated in January, payroll firm ADP said on February 5, 2025, as consumer-facing job creation surged. Private sector employment increased by 183,000 jobs last month, ADP said in a statement, sharply above the market consensus of 155,000, according to Briefing.com. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP)

site_title: Microsoft, turning 50, dials up Copilot actions to stay in AI game
summary: Microsoft is celebrating its 50th anniversary by upgrading its AI assistant, Copilot, with new features to make it more proactive. The company aims to stay competitive in the crowded AI market, which includes Elon Musk's xAI and Anthropic. Copilot's new features include improved functionality in Excel, among others, and Microsoft's leaders believe this will bring the company into the future of artificial intelligence. The updates are part of Microsoft's efforts to strengthen its AI capabilities and remain a leader in the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Copilot logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Investor scepticism about the hefty AI spending by US tech firms has increased due to slow payoffs and the rise of Chinese startup DeepSeek.

The new cloud region will generate US$10.9 billion in new revenues and create 37,575 jobs in Malaysia by 2028, including 5,700 skilled IT positions, projects Laurence Si, managing director of Microsoft Malaysia.
Microsoft is also developing so-called reasoning models, which are designed to field more complex queries and display human-like problem-solving, the source says.
Microsoft’s results in late January underlined both why it has lately failed to excite investors, and also why few are throwing in the towel.

site_title: BT journalists recognised at annual EMTM awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) journalists won several awards at the annual EMTM (English, Malay, Tamil Media) awards, including Story of the Year for Jessie Lim's scoop on Singapore's largest money laundering case and Commentary/Feature of the Year for Tan Nai Lun's story on Malaysia as a retirement destination. BT also received Excellence Awards for various stories, including an interactive graphic and a series on Good Class Bungalow transactions. The awards recognize the best work by journalists of the EMTM group in the past year, with cash prizes and trophies given to the winners.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim (left), winner of the Young Journalist of the Year award and Wong Pei Ting, winner of the Journalist of the Year award.

site_title: Sembcorp optimistic on 2028 renewables target, China market despite headwinds
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based energy company, remains optimistic about achieving its 2028 target of 25 gigawatts of gross installed renewables capacity despite headwinds in the China market. The company's chairman and CEO, Wong Kim Yin, stated that renewables growth in South-east Asia, China, India, and the Middle East is expected to remain robust. Sembcorp's gross renewables capacity stands at 17 GW as of February, with strong momentum in greenfield tenders in India and the Middle East. The company is also exploring the import of electricity from neighboring countries to promote renewable energy development.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The proposed acquisition will be funded through Sembcorp’s internal cash resources and/ or external borrowings and is set to complete in the second quarter of 2025.

site_title: Malaysia Smelting warns of disrupted tin output after gas blast
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corp (MSC), a major tin producer, has reported disruptions to deliveries from its smelter due to a pipeline explosion at Putra Heights in Selangor, which interrupted gas supply. The blast may impact some shipments of tin, with no clear timeline for fuel supply resumption. This disruption comes as the tin market faces growing concerns around supply, exacerbated by an earthquake in Myanmar and a mine suspension in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The incident highlights the challenges facing the global tin industry.

site_title: Musk and OpenAI jury trial to begin in spring next year
summary: Elon Musk's lawsuit against OpenAI is set to go to a jury trial in spring 2026, following a federal judge's decision to expedite the trial. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman had previously rejected a $97.4 billion unsolicited takeover bid from Musk, calling it a "no thank you". The trial will focus on OpenAI's shift to a for-profit model, with the judge denying Musk's request to pause the transition. The trial is the latest turn in a public grudge match between Musk and Altman over OpenAI's business direction.

images.alt_text: Microsoft-backed OpenAI said it looks to deliver increasingly powerful tools for the 500 million people who use ChatGPT every week.
SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman attend an event to pitch AI for businesses in Tokyo, Japan, Feb 3, 2025.
While revenue is soaring, OpenAI is also confronting significant costs from the chips, data centres and talent needed to develop cutting-edge AI systems.
Stargate joins a race among leading tech companies to build up capacity of Nvidia’s latest chips.

site_title: Struggling to make sense of Trump tariffs, Singapore exporters look to diversify
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, which include a universal 10% tariff on imports and higher levies on 60 "worst offenders," may have a relatively lesser impact on Singapore exporters compared to regional peers. However, companies are still diversifying suppliers and customers to mitigate potential risks. Local companies expect cumulative tariffs across the supply chain to cause goods to lose cost competitiveness, leading to lower demand and business spending. Some firms, such as furniture makers and skincare companies, are exploring new markets and products to offset the impact of the tariffs.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Elysia Tan
Under Singapore's free trade agreement with the US, Singapore has recourse to take countermeasures and seek dispute resolution – but has decided not to do so.

Beijing also announced controls on exports of medium and heavy rare earths, including samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium and yttrium, to the US, effective Apr 4.

site_title: US: Stock market wipes out over US$5 trillion on Trump’s tariff war
summary: The US stock market experienced a significant decline, wiping out over $5 trillion in market value in two sessions, with the S&P 500 falling 6% and the Nasdaq 100 entering a bear market. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that President Donald Trump's tariffs could have a persistent impact on inflation, while China imposed new tariffs on American imports. The economic impact of the trade war is expected to be larger than initially thought, with recession fears rising.

site_title: Three Michelin-starred restaurants close; two of them to rebrand
summary: Two Michelin-starred Japanese restaurants in Singapore, Shinji by Kanesaka and Oshino, are closing and rebranding as new concepts. Shinji by Kanesaka will reopen as Keijo, a more price-accessible sushi restaurant, while Oshino will become Ishizawa, also serving fine dining sushi. Restaurant Poise, which also held a Michelin star, has closed due to high operating costs. The closures mark the latest in a string of Michelin-starred restaurant closures in Singapore, with four one-star restaurants having closed in the past year.

images.alt_text: Warm lighting and discreet interiors of Pulsii.

site_title: JPMorgan says Trump’s tariffs will send US into recession
summary: US economist JPMorgan predicts the US economy will fall into a recession this year due to the impact of President Donald Trump's tariffs. The forecast, made by chief US economist Michael Feroli, expects real GDP growth of -0.3% by the end of the year, with a potential unemployment rate of 5.3%. Other banks, including Barclays and Citi, have also revised their growth forecasts downward since the tariff announcement. Investors are betting on a full percentage point of reductions by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: “While tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation, it is also possible that the effects could be more persistent,” Powell says.

site_title: Walmart denies ABC News report it could join investor group to buy TikTok
summary: Walmart has denied a report by ABC News that it was considering joining a group of investors to buy TikTok. The report, which cited sources close to the deal, stated Walmart's interest was triggered by Amazon's involvement. However, a Walmart spokesperson said the story was incorrect and has been removed from the ABC News website. The report follows a previous consideration by Walmart to team up with Microsoft to buy TikTok in 2020. US President Donald Trump has extended a deadline for ByteDance to sell US assets of TikTok to a non-Chinese buyer.

site_title: Tesla estimates cut further on ‘unprecedented brand damage’
summary: Tesla delivered 336,681 vehicles in Q1, its worst quarterly total since 2022, amid "unprecedented brand damage" due to Elon Musk's interventions in global politics. JPMorgan analyst Ryan Brinkman cut estimates for Q1 earnings to $0.36 per share, down from $0.40, and trimmed full-year projections to $2.30 per share. Tesla shares fell over 5% before trading began, and the stock has slumped 44% since its record high in December. The company's EU sales plummeted 49% year-on-year in the first two months of 2025.

images.alt_text: Trump has tasked Musk with leading efforts to cut government funding and dismantle various US agencies as a special government employee.
The numbers will set the tone for the rest of 2025 as the company aims to return to growth after logging its first annual sales drop in over a decade last year.

Elon Musk Musk launched into a familiar pitch that Teslas will soon be capable of driving autonomously, but execution still lags.

The recall covers just over 46,000 vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27 of this year, Tesla said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and is the eighth recall for the SUV since January 2024.
Tesla has said it expects the vehicle business to return to growth this year, after a small drop in 2024.

site_title: GE2025: Where the parties stand on key issues
summary: Singapore's ruling party, PAP, has defended its decision to raise the goods and services tax (GST) from 7 to 9% as necessary to balance the budget and ensure intergenerational equity. The opposition parties, WP and PSP, have opposed the hike, citing inflationary pressures and suggesting alternative revenue sources, such as increased taxes on wealth and land sales. Experts argue that the current system of using past reserves to fund the government's finances provides discipline and ensures that the government does not rely on the largesse of previous generations. The debate highlights the divergence in fiscal policy approaches among the parties, with the PAP prioritizing long-term sustainability and the opposition parties focusing on short-term relief for voters.

images.alt_text: Some common ground appears to be emerging among the three main parties on the contentious issue.

site_title: TikTok deal put on hold after China indicated it would reject it over tariffs: sources
summary: The US deal to spin off TikTok's US assets to a non-Chinese buyer has been put on hold after China indicated it would reject the deal due to US tariffs. US President Donald Trump extended the deadline by 75 days for ByteDance to sell US assets to a non-Chinese buyer, or face a ban that was supposed to take effect in January. China has stated its opposition to the deal, citing its respect for the legitimate rights and interests of enterprises. A new mid-June deadline has been set for a deal, with Trump willing to reduce tariffs on China to get a deal done.

images.alt_text: The president also suggested TikTok could even be part of a broader deal with China to ease the stinging tariffs he imposed on Beijing as part of a worldwide blitz of levies.
Bidders for the short video social media company are piling up, as the weekend deadline for TikTok to find a buyer approaches.
US President Donald Trump has downplayed risks that TikTok is in danger of being banned in the United States, saying he remains confident of finding a buyer for the app’s US business.
US officials have raised security concerns over the app’s ties to China, which TikTok and owner ByteDance have denied

site_title: Singapore retail sales fare worse than expected, down 3.6% in February from earlier Chinese New Year
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 3.6% year on year in February, worse than expected, due to the Chinese New Year being celebrated in January this year. Excluding motor vehicles, sales dropped 6.7% year on year, with declines in department stores, supermarkets, food and alcohol, and petrol service stations. The month-on-month seasonally adjusted sales growth was 3% excluding motor vehicles.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Singapore retail sales up 4.5% in January, swinging from year-end decline

site_title: Trump unveils first US$5 million ‘gold card’ visa
summary: US President Donald Trump unveiled a new "gold card" visa, a premium green card alternative priced at US$5 million, which he claims will bring in job creators and reduce the national deficit. The special visa, available in less than two weeks, will be a route to US citizenship, with Trump as the first buyer. He hopes to sell "maybe a million" of the cards, potentially including Russian oligarchs. The move aims to attract high-net-worth investors and ease the national deficit.

site_title: Europe: Shares confirm correction in worst day since 2020 after China’s tariff response
summary: European stocks plummeted, with the Stoxx 600 index falling 5.1% to its biggest daily loss since 2020, as China retaliated against US tariffs with additional tariffs and curbs on rare earth exports. The move intensified fears of a global recession triggered by the trade war. Investors sought safe-haven assets, driving down euro zone government bond yields, and European banks led declines. The pan-European Stoxx index is now nearly 12% below its March closing high, confirming a correction.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 sank 257 per cent to 523.12 points on Thursday, falling back to its lowest since January.

site_title: Billionaires poised to lose near half-trillion US dollars in two days
summary: The world's 500 richest people suffered a collective $536 billion loss over two days due to the US President's tariff announcement, with the S&P 500 Index dropping 10.5% and the Nasdaq Composite falling 11.4%. Tesla's Elon Musk lost $31 billion, while Meta Platforms' Mark Zuckerberg lost $27 billion. Ernest Garcia III's Carvana lost $2 billion, pushing him off the list. Nike's Phil Knight was a rare winner, gaining $84 million after the US lifted a 46% tariff on Vietnam.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations in March
summary: The US economy added 228,000 jobs in March, beating expectations, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.2% from 4.1% in February. Low layoffs and solid wage gains are sustaining the economic expansion, but President Trump's sweeping import tariffs may test the labor market's resilience. Economists warn of potential job cuts, supply chain disruptions, and higher prices, which could lead to a recession in the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Imports may very well fall in the coming months – which would help to narrow the trade gap, one of Trump’s aims with his policy – as businesses try to avoid outsourcing expensive foreign goods.

site_title: Europe: Shares in the red at open
summary: European stocks fell on Friday, Apr 4, 2025, extending losses after US President Donald Trump's tariff offensive. Paris dropped 0.9%, Frankfurt fell 0.7%, and London dropped 0.7%. The global stock market rout was triggered by Trump's harsher-than-expected "Liberation Day" levies, which sent shockwaves through markets. British goods face a 10% tariff, lower than the 20% Trump is imposing on the European Union.

site_title: Taiwan unveils US$8.7 billion in help for companies to deal with US tariffs
summary: Taiwan's government has announced US$8.74 billion in financial assistance to help companies affected by US tariffs, which include a 32% duty on Taiwanese products. The tariffs, imposed by US President Donald Trump, do not apply to semiconductors, a major Taiwanese export. The government will provide export credits, trade financing, and NT$88 billion in financial aid to companies. Taiwan's Premier Cho Jung-tai reiterated that the tariffs are unreasonable, citing a skewed trade balance due to strong demand for Taiwanese technology products.

site_title: China files complaint with WTO over new US tariffs
summary: China has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) over new US tariffs, alleging they violate WTO rules. The 34% tariffs on US goods are the latest escalation in the trade war between China and the US, following China's retaliatory tariffs. The dispute settlement process is set to begin, with consultations expected to last 60 days. The move could lead to further escalation and impact global markets, with fears of a recession and stock market rout.

site_title: Global brokerages raise recession odds; JPMorgan sees 60% chance
summary: Global brokerages have revised their recession forecasts, with JPMorgan now predicting a 60% chance of a US and global recession by the end of the year. Disruptive US policies, including tariffs, are seen as the biggest risk to the global outlook. Other brokerages, including S&P Global and HSBC, have also raised their recession probabilities, citing concerns over supply-chain disruptions and a decline in US business sentiment. Some analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further to boost economic activity, but investors expect only modest rate cuts.

site_title: TikTok must find non-Chinese owner by Saturday to avert US ban
summary: US President Donald Trump is urging TikTok to find a non-Chinese owner by Saturday or face a US ban. The popular video-sharing app, with over 170 million American users, must split from its Chinese owner ByteDance or get shut down in the US due to a national security law passed last year. Trump has expressed confidence in finding a buyer, suggesting a deal could also ease tariffs imposed on China. Several investors, including Oracle and Blackstone, have expressed interest in acquiring TikTok, but uncertainty remains over the app's algorithm.

images.alt_text: Bidders for the short video social media company are piling up, as the weekend deadline for TikTok to find a buyer approaches.

site_title: Trade-reliant Singapore will take ‘bigger hit’ than others in US tariffs-induced slowdown: PM Wong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warns that the US' sweeping global tariffs will have a bigger impact on the country due to its heavy reliance on trade. He describes the tariffs as a "seismic change in the global order" and a "complete rejection of the WTO framework." Wong cautions that other countries may retaliate, leading to a "strong global response" and a likely "full-blown global trade war." He urges Singaporeans to "brace" for more shocks and assures the nation will remain vigilant and build up capabilities to stay ahead.

site_title: Vietnam goes from potential FDI darling to trade target in Trump’s trade storm
summary: Vietnam's status as a top foreign direct investment (FDI) destination is threatened by the US's 46% reciprocal tariff on the country, imposed by President Donald Trump. The tariff, which is the steepest among the Asean-6 countries, narrows Vietnam's cost advantage over China and could deter multinational corporations from investing in the country. Vietnam has just days to negotiate a reprieve, or risk losing its edge as a supply-chain hub and facing lower GDP growth projections, with some analysts expecting a 1 percentage point hit this year.

images.alt_text: Unlike during Trump's first presidency, South-east Asia is now directly in the firing line for aggressive and high levies, says an analyst.

site_title: Liberation Day for USA Ltd
summary: The US has imposed a 10% universal import duty and additional reciprocal tariffs on 60 nations, including China, in a move dubbed "Liberation Day." This marks a shift towards mercantilism, prioritizing national profit and power over trade. The tariffs could result in a $1 trillion hit to the US economy over the next decade, according to Yale University's Budget Lab. Global markets have reacted with outrage and ridicule, with China and the EU threatening retaliatory measures. The US administration believes the tariffs will redress "unfair" trade imbalances, but the consequences are uncertain and seismic.

site_title: French classics with a Japanese twist at Pulsii
summary: Pulsii, a French bistro in Tras Street, Singapore, offers refined and subtle dining with a Japanese twist. Chef Daisuke Yoshikawa's menu features dishes such as crispy chicken liver mousse, grilled yellowtail, and slow-cooked ox tongue, all made with high-quality ingredients. The restaurant's understated ambiance and attention to detail make it a pleasant dining experience. Prices are reasonable, with most dishes ranging from S$4 to S$48. Overall, Pulsii is a solid choice for those seeking a semi-fine dining experience with a focus on quality over flashy presentation.

site_title: Junk bonds suffer worst rout since 2020 with US hit hardest
summary: US junk corporate bonds suffered their worst rout since 2020, with yields widening 45 basis points to 386 basis points, marking the steepest American tariffs in a century. Investors dumped US junk bonds and leveraged loans, pulling cash from exchange-traded funds, and some traders bought put options on ETFs to hedge risk. Global high-yield spreads are widening, with yields soaring to the highest since August, and credit investors are wary of the impact of tariffs on borrowers, potentially driving spreads higher.

site_title: Car dealer Vin’s Holdings gears up to raise net proceeds of S$4 million in Catalist IPO
summary: Car dealer Vin's Holdings is set to raise S$4 million in its initial public offering (IPO), with 20 million placement shares priced at S$0.30 each, valuing the company at S$39.3 million. The IPO is expected to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Catalist board on April 15. Net proceeds will be used for digital transformation and IT integration plans, as well as general working capital, with S$2 million allocated for these purposes. The company's controlling shareholder, Vin's Capital, will hold a 76.3% stake in the company.

site_title: ‘It was an amazing act’: Finian Tan of alleged nickel trading scammer Ng Yu Zhi’s charade
summary: Finian Tan, a venture capitalist, testified in the trial of alleged scammer Ng Yu Zhi, who is accused of perpetrating a US$19.2 million nickel trading scam. Tan was sold on Ng's business and trusted him enough to invest millions, despite having done due diligence. He initially believed Ng's company was buying nickel at low prices and selling it for a profit, but later realized that Ng had never bought or sold nickel. Tan expressed regret and shock at being deceived, stating that Ng's actions destroyed many lives and resulted in significant financial losses.
