site_title: Grab’s entry into taxi sector given green light on organic growth: CCCS, LTA
summary: Grab's entry into the Singapore taxi sector has been given the green light by regulators, who believe it will increase competition in the industry. The company will start a new taxi fleet, rather than acquiring an existing one, and will be given a three-year grace period to expand its fleet to at least 800 taxis. Industry observers say the move could benefit commuters and drivers, but also raises concerns about potential anti-competitive behavior, particularly given Grab's dominant position in the ride-hail market. Regulators will closely monitor the situation to ensure fair competition.

images.alt_text: Grab out to snatch ComfortDelGro cabbies with huge discount. In a text message targeted at  ComfortDelGro cabbies on 3 September 2017 night, Grab dangled a rental discount of more than 40 per cent to those who are willing to defect to any of the other taxi companies - all of whom use the Grab hailing platform.
Derryn Wong

site_title: Sustainable fashion an opportunity for mall operators to boost green credentials
summary: Mall operators in Singapore can boost their green credentials by offering rental discounts or rebates to second-hand clothing stores. As the sustainable fashion market grows, these stores can help raise awareness among consumers about the importance of buying second-hand. Mall operators can incentivize these businesses by prioritizing them when renewing leases or offering special financing solutions. This move can align with their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) efforts and demonstrate their commitment to sustainability, despite potential financial costs.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

The inside of thrift store Un.Wastelands near Haji Lane. While second-hand fashion is not new in Singapore, the difference is that many of these new thrift shops are for-profit businesses – the pioneer players tended to be non-profit models.
A complain filed in the US District Court says Lululemon has a "significant and growing climate and environmental footprint".
Marie-Claire DAVEU_CSO Kering

site_title: Innovative financing mechanisms can ratchet up climate ambition in these times
summary: South-east Asia requires an annual investment of $171-$185 billion from 2026 to 2030 to meet climate goals. However, emerging markets face roadblocks including geopolitical tensions, investment barriers, and limited fiscal space. The US administration's shift in climate priorities may impact financial commitments and international cooperation. To meet the Paris Agreement objectives, radical collaboration is essential to mobilize climate finance, with the New Collective Quantified Goal aiming to scale up finance to $1.3 trillion by 2035.

images.alt_text: With an estimated financing gap of over US$800 billion a year in developing Asian countries for climate mitigation and adaptation, there is a critical need to mobilise private-sector capital towards climate action at scale.

site_title: OCBC to finance £10 billion in UK investments by 2030 under new partnership
summary: OCBC Bank has signed a memorandum of understanding with the UK's Office for Investment to finance £10 billion in UK investments by 2030, marking the first time a Singapore or Asian bank has secured a deal of this scale. The funds will be channeled into priority British growth sectors, including energy, transportation, and data centers. The partnership aims to promote the UK as a hub for Asian businesses and investors, and will assist UK firms expanding into Singapore and Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Minister Ong (4th from right), OCBC CEO Helen Wong (6th from right) and its head of global consumer financial services Sunny Quek (1st from left) with seniors at the launch of OCBC SeniorCare programme.
DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta was paid S$17.6 million, up from the S$11.2 million paycut he took in 2023
Let a property group create a new landmark by redeveloping the OCBC Centre cluster of buildings.

site_title: Oil prices fall into negative territory as Trump announces new tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on trading partners, including the European Union, China, and South Korea, sparking concerns that a global trade war may dampen demand for crude oil. Oil prices fell to negative territory after rising by a US dollar in post-settlement trade. Despite US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gaining 51 US cents, oil prices declined due to concerns about a potential trade war and its impact on economic growth and demand.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled down 28 cents, or 0.37 per cent, at US$74.49 a barrel on Tuesday. The session high was above US$75 a barrel.

site_title: Refreshed icons
summary: Tag Heuer's Formula 1 Solargraph collection debuts with nine models featuring solar-powered quartz movements, retro designs, and vibrant colorways. IWC introduces new sizes and complications to its Ingenieur line, including the Ingenieur Automatic 35 and Ingenieur Perpetual Calendar 41. Jaeger-LeCoultre unveils the Reverso Tribute Geographic, a limited-edition travel time watch with a double-sided case and Art Deco lines. The watches showcase innovative materials and complications, catering to a wide range of audiences and styles.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Roger Federer wears a Land-Dweller 40 in a white Rolesor version.

site_title: Enterprise 50 Awards 2025 now open for nominations
summary: Nominations are now open for the 2025 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, recognizing 50 innovative and competitive home-grown, privately owned businesses in Singapore that have contributed to the country's economic development. The awards, now in its 31st year, are jointly organized by The Business Times and KPMG in Singapore, and companies have until June 30 to submit their applications. The E50 Awards spotlight firms across various sectors, regardless of their size or industry, and are sponsored by OCBC and supported by Enterprise Singapore and other organizations.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

Richard Eu, Eu Yan Sang International group chairman (R), with moderator Dylan Tan, BT's memberships editor, during a virtual fireside chat held during the launch of the E50 2025 Awards.

PHOTO: BT

site_title: Next generation of ultra-rich to spur take-up of donor-advised funds: Citi
summary: Citi's private banking arm has launched philanthropy advisory solutions in Asia, particularly in Singapore, amid rising demand from ultra-high-net-worth individuals. The next generation of ultra-rich is expected to boost the uptake of donor-advised funds (DAFs) to meet their philanthropic needs. DAFs allow individuals to establish fund accounts for charitable donations and provide features such as legacy and succession planning. Citi expects a significant increase in demand for DAFs in Asia, driven by their simplicity and anonymity.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: One Raffles Quay inks S$1.13 billion sustainability-linked loan from DBS, other banks
summary: One Raffles Quay, a Singapore office complex, has secured a S$1.13 billion sustainability-linked loan from DBS and three other banks over five years. The loan will support efforts to reduce its carbon footprint, with targets to reduce energy and water usage by 20-29%. Proceeds will be used for debt refinancing and working capital needs. As part of the loan, One Raffles Quay must meet sustainability performance targets, differing from traditional sustainable financing.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The Reit manager said the loans are part of the Reit manager’s “proactive capital management strategy”.

site_title: TikTok bidders pile up as deadline looms with Amazon, OnlyFans founder in mix
summary: US officials are pressing TikTok to find a non-Chinese buyer by April 5, or risk being banned from the US market. Bidders include Amazon, a consortium led by OnlyFans founder Tim Stokely, and startup Zoop. The deadline follows a 2024 law requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok. US officials have raised security concerns over the app's ties to China, which TikTok has denied. A non-Chinese buyer would need to reduce Chinese ownership to below 20% to comply with US law.

images.alt_text: Trump faces an Apr 5 deadline for ByteDance to find a buyer for TikTok’s US operations or see the app banned in the country.

US President Donald Trump earlier this month said the United States was in talks with four groups interested in acquiring TikTok.
A US law has ordered TikTok to divest from its Chinese owner ByteDance or be banned in the United States.

site_title: Apple production hubs hit by tariffs, sending shares plummeting
summary: US President Donald Trump has unveiled a long list of levies, including a 34% tariff on Chinese goods, which will hit Apple's supply chain hard. The new reciprocal tariffs will also affect Apple's manufacturing centers in India, Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, and Ireland, with rates ranging from 20% to 46%. The move is expected to trigger a 7.9% stock drop in Apple shares, adding to the company's 11% decline this year. The tariffs are set to kick in on April 9, potentially squeezing Apple's margins and affecting its ability to source components from countries hit by tariffs.

images.alt_text: Despite the ban on iPhone sales in Indonesia, the government had allowed the devices to be brought in if they were not being traded commercially.
“Thrilled to meet the next generation of developers at Zhejiang University today,” Apple CEO Tim Cook said on Wednesday.

site_title: Musk will stay until he completes Doge mission, White House says
summary: The White House has confirmed that Elon Musk will stay on as a special government employee until he completes his mission to slash government spending and downsize the federal workforce. Despite reports suggesting Musk will leave his role soon, the White House said he will depart when his 130-day mandate expires around late May. Musk has been tasked by President Donald Trump to lead efforts to cut government funding and reshape the federal bureaucracy through the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge).

images.alt_text: The numbers will set the tone for the rest of 2025 as the company aims to return to growth after logging its first annual sales drop in over a decade last year.

site_title: Finding a greener route for transport refrigeration
summary: Hwee Jan, a Singapore-based transport company, prioritizes innovation, sustainability, and customer value. Founded in 1980, the company has evolved from providing automotive air-conditioning systems to transport refrigeration and special-purpose vehicles. Hwee Jan's commitment to sustainability includes zero-waste initiatives, green manufacturing practices, and reducing carbon emissions through energy-efficient systems and recycling protocols. The company has received several awards for its efforts, including the Enterprise 50 Award and the Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark Super Low Energy Award. Hwee Jan's leadership style emphasizes consultative approach, open communication, and employee welfare, contributing to its success and recognition as a leader in the industry.

images.alt_text: Hock Seng Hoe Metal managing director Sam Chee Keong (centre) and executive director Chan Lee Ying (left of centre) at the company's celebration of its 10th anniversary.
The RS Facilities Services team, led by director Michelle Yap (front row, third from left) and operations director Tay Chin Chye (front row, third from right).

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as Trump tariffs loom
summary: US stock indexes plummeted on April 2 as investors awaited details on President Donald Trump's tariffs, which could impact the global economy, corporate earnings, and inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 342.35 points, or 0.82%, to 41,647.61, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The declines were attributed to uncertainty surrounding Trump's tariffs and concerns about their potential impact on the economy.

site_title: Iata airlines chief warns aviation industry falling behind on net zero
summary: Global airlines have expressed concerns that their 2050 net-zero emissions goal is at risk due to lack of support from airports, manufacturers, air traffic control agencies, and energy firms in implementing Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). IATA Director General Willie Walsh warned that the industry is not on track and urged the sector to reevaluate its commitment. The airline industry is facing additional costs due to government mandates and carbon emissions pledges, and Walsh criticized fuel companies for not meeting their SAF supply promises, saying they must "play their part" in achieving the goal.

images.alt_text: Steel-sector financed emissions intensity rose for all three Singapore banks in their latest reports.
The OCBC Bank Holland Village branch is seen on Feb 26, 2025.
The greater challenge lies in helping high-emission industries transition while safeguarding economic priorities.
The move follows actions taken by Tokyo-based peers Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Nomura Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group to leave the climate group.
MUFG follows Tokyo-based rivals Nomura Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in quitting the climate group.
Climate change can impact portfolio assets in material and unexpected ways, both near-term and in the coming years, as the world attempts to mitigate this systemic risk.

site_title: GE 2025: Trade unionist Natasha Choy joins Desmond Lee’s team in West Coast
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee has joined forces with trade unionist Natasha Choy in West Coast GRC, which will be renamed West Coast-Jurong West GRC due to electoral boundary changes. Choy, a 30s-old trade unionist, has been seen at community events since mid-February and will focus on issues like active ageing, youth engagement, and infrastructure development. The PAP has not yet released its slate for the new constituency, but Lee is expected to be joined by Senior Parliamentary Secretary Shawn Huang and orthopaedic surgeon Hamid Razak.

images.alt_text: Potential WP candidate Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik (in grey shirt) at a Sengkang GRC townhall meeting on March 29. He is a senior property manager at Aljunied-Hougang Town Council.

site_title: Adopting Japan or South Korea’s stock market reforms in Singapore not that straightforward
summary: Singapore's listing rules are being considered for reforms similar to Japan and South Korea's, which require companies to address share price undervaluation and increase corporate value. However, Japan's experience with stricter regulations has led to a mass exodus of companies opting to delist. If similar rules were introduced in Singapore, the local market could face a significant loss of firms, potentially affecting the market's overall quality and investor confidence. Local regulators must weigh the benefits of improved listed company quality against the potential risks of losing firms to delisting.

images.alt_text: Catalist-listed SIAMH's woes illustrate perfectly the caveat emptor market that we live in, since Catalist companies need not have a proven track record of profitability when going public.

Another suggestion is to list large government-linked corporations (GLC) like PSA and Changi Airport Group based on a hope that history will repeat itself: back in October 1993, Singtel’s initial public offer had sparked a “super bull’’ run.
There have been many attempts to improve the local market’s attractiveness, but each has had only muted impact, while, collectively, there has not been any appreciable improvement.
Singapore's billionaires should support the local equities market by doing more to get their businesses listed on SGX.

site_title: SLA appoints new CEO to succeed Colin Low
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has appointed Calvin Phua, deputy secretary (policy) at the Ministry of Law, as its new CEO, replacing Colin Low, effective May 1, 2025. Phua's appointment comes after Low's departure, which was confirmed by a LinkedIn post stating he was not running for the role. Low's leadership was praised for his efforts in optimising state land and properties, driving sustainable asset management practices, and spearheading geospatial adoption across sectors.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
(Clockwise from top left) Mr Jeffrey Siow, Mr Dinesh Vasu Dash, Ms Jasmin Lau, Mr Shawn Loh, Ms Goh Hanyan and Mr Foo Cexiang.

site_title: Despite offers to go West, Ya Kun Kaya Toast would rather deepen roots in South-east Asia
summary: Ya Kun Kaya Toast, a Singaporean heritage brand, is focusing on deepening its roots in South-east Asia rather than expanding to Western markets. Despite offers to franchise in the US, Europe, and Australia, the company believes it can sustain a business model with economies of scale only in the region. The brand has seen success in its existing markets, including Cambodia, Indonesia, and the Philippines, and plans to expand its presence in these countries. Ya Kun is also investing in local improvements, such as mobile ordering and automated packaging, and collaborating with other brands to stay trendy and unique.

images.alt_text: Tan Jian Yong set up Happy Fish Swim School to teach children to swim
Kevin Chee, founder of Matchaya, has plans to open an outlet in India and another in the Philippines

site_title: Trump tariffs add polish to gold rally but full market impact yet to hit
summary: US President Donald Trump's latest move of reciprocal tariffs has sparked a surge in gold prices, with spot gold reaching a fresh high of $3,167.71 per ounce. Investors are turning to gold as a safe-haven asset amid uncertainty and recession fears, with BMI expecting gold prices to range between $3,000 and $3,400 per ounce over the second and third quarters of 2025. However, silver prices have fallen 2.9% due to its heavy industrial use, with some analysts predicting a potential price drop if the global economy slows down.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, Taipei and Manila stocks were all up, Tokyo was flat and Singapore and Seoul slipped on Wednesday.
Gold, viewed as a safeguard against economical and political uncertainties, typically flourishes in an environment of low interest rates.
Confronting persistent housing woes and deflationary pressures, Chinese policymakers unveiled a central bank-led stimulus blitz in late September.

site_title: Singapore PMI slips to 50.6 in March amid global trade tensions, US tariff risks
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector grew at a slower pace in March, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 50.6, down 0.1 point from February. Despite the decline, the sector has remained in expansion mode for 19 consecutive months. Economists attribute the slowdown to rising global trade tensions and tariff uncertainties, particularly ahead of US President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" announcements. While growth is expected to sustain in the coming months, sector-specific tariffs could weigh on Singapore's manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

SIPMM executive director Stephen Poh noted that while this was the 18th straight month of expansion for the overall manufacturing sector, there have been concerns over slowing growth in the last few months.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda says US tariffs could have big impact on global trade
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda expressed concerns that US tariffs could significantly impact global trade, particularly among nations affected by the tariffs. The tariffs, announced by US President Donald Trump, could influence household and business sentiment, affecting overall spending. Ueda's comments come ahead of the official announcement of the tariffs, which may impact Japan's economic outlook, currently aligned with the BOJ's economic projections.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, April 2, 2025
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, but uncertainty persisted ahead of US President Trump's potential tariffs. Grab, a Singapore-based taxi operator, received its operator licence. Gold prices increased due to safe-haven demand before US reciprocal tariffs. The uncertainty surrounding Trump's tariffs and the LTA's licence decision for Grab have left markets uncertain.

site_title: Goh Cheng Liang, Li Xiting, Forrest Li top Forbes’ list of richest Singaporeans
summary: Goh Cheng Liang, Li Xiting, and Forrest Li top Forbes' list of richest Singaporeans, with net worths of $13 billion, $12.8 billion, and $8.6 billion respectively. Singapore's collective net worth increased to $145.2 billion, up from $115.5 billion in 2024. The country now has 49 billionaires on the list, up from 39 in 2024.

site_title: Here are the 5 top-performing Singapore stocks in Q1 – DBS, UOB and OCBC are not among them
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached an all-time high of 4,005.18 points in the first quarter of 2025, driven by investors seeking safe havens. The index had 22 gainers and eight decliners, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC not among the top performers. The STI briefly crossed the 4,000 mark on March 28.

site_title: Volvo Cars sales fall 10% in March as fully electric sales dive
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 10% decline in sales in March, with fully electric car sales plummeting 26% to account for 19% of total sales. Sales in Europe fell 9%, while in the US and China they were down 8% and 22%, respectively. Volvo's shares dropped following the announcement of former CEO Hakan Samuelsson's return to head the company for the next two years.

site_title: Shares of Malaysia’s Petronas Gas fall as much as 38 sen after major pipeline blaze
summary: Malaysia's Petronas Gas shares fell 38 sen after a major pipeline blaze erupted on April 1 in Putra Heights, disrupting operations. The fire, which damaged 235 premises and displaced over 500 people, was extinguished around 4 pm. Despite the incident, analysts predict a limited financial impact, with shares ending the day unchanged. No fatalities were reported, and the pipeline rupture was attributed to a gas leak. The fire is currently under investigation.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Parked vehicles are seen near a massive gas pipeline fire in Putra Heights, outside Kuala Lumpur on Apr 1.
Petronas has been engaged in stalled negotiations with Petros, Sarawak’s state-run energy firm, since last year.

site_title: Goldman is opening up private equity deals to rich individuals
summary: Goldman Sachs is launching an open-ended private equity fund, G-PE, offering access to buyout, growth, secondary, and co-investment deals for wealthy individuals. The move aims to challenge larger private-market rivals and compete with traditional banking peers. The fund is part of Goldman's broader strategy to grow its alternative investments, with plans to distribute $8 billion in alternative investments through third-party wealth platforms and nearly triple its asset-management unit headcount to 60 people worldwide.

The planned cuts are in line with the bank’s typical approach as it seeks to keep a lid on costs and make room to enlist new talent.

site_title: Ford is as American as apple pie. Or is that Honda?
summary: US President Donald Trump's incoming 25% auto tariffs are expected to add thousands of dollars to the average price of a vehicle in the US. Trump's trade adviser, Peter Navarro, claims that General Motors and Ford, two of the "Big Three" US automakers, are not truly American companies, despite employing nearly 180,000 people in the US. However, data suggests that these companies have more domestic content in their vehicles than some foreign competitors, such as Honda. The tariffs' impact is expected to be felt globally, with manufacturers potentially cutting jobs to deal with the costs. The move is seen as outdated and potentially pricing cars beyond consumers' reach, with experts warning of a compliance nightmare for auto manufacturers and customs.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by 0.4 per cent to 42,299.70, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index lost 0.3 per cent to 5,693.31 on Thursday.
GM said its US sales jumped 17 per cent in the quarter from the same period a year ago, reporting 693,363 deliveries.

site_title: Inflation casts shadow over Japan’s cherry blossom season
summary: Japan's inflation has been running at its fastest rate in the Group of Seven, casting a shadow over the country's cherry blossom season. Food prices, including traditional sweets and rice balls, have surged 21.4% in the past six years, outpacing general inflation. The average budget per person for hanami gatherings is around 2,997 yen, despite recent wet weather in Tokyo. The total economic impact of hanami season could reach approximately 1.39 trillion yen, boosted by overseas tourist arrivals.

images.alt_text: Japan's headline index measuring big manufacturers’ business confidence stood at +12 in March, down from +14 in December and matching a median market forecast.
The cost of rice in Tokyo surged 92.4 per cent in March, a sign of the pain households were feeling from rising living costs.
BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank will keep raising interest rates if prospects of higher wages lead to broader price hikes, not just for goods but for services.

site_title: ECB still has a bit of work to do on prices: Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that the fight against inflation is not yet over, despite price growth approaching the 2% goal. Consumer prices in the eurozone rose 2.2% in March, and policymakers are weighing whether to continue cutting interest rates or pause at their next meeting. Lagarde emphasized the need for a medium-term approach, expecting occasional bumps but focusing on sustainable inflation control.

site_title: JPMorgan and SUTD’s programme opens students up to careers in STEM sector
summary: A program called Career Connect, run by JPMorgan and Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD), aims to encourage teenagers to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. The fourth edition of the program involved 13- to 15-year-old students from underprivileged backgrounds who were tasked with designing tech solutions to everyday problems. The students' ideas were developed through design challenges, career activities, mentoring, and workshops, with the goal of sparking interest in STEM fields and providing them with skills to compete for quality careers.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

The playbook was conceptualised by Denise Phua, Mayor of the Central Singapore District, in her volunteer capacity as president of Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) and chairman of Autism Association (Singapore).

site_title: New meets old and more at Watches and Wonders 2025
summary: Rolex unveiled its new Oyster Perpetual Land-Dweller collection at Watches and Wonders 2025, drawing inspiration from the 1969 Rolex Quartz and 1974 Datejust. The watch features a unique honeycomb motif and an innovative escapement system. Patek Philippe also showcased its Quadruple Complication Reference 5308G-001, a timepiece combining a minute repeater, chronograph, and perpetual calendar. Cartier revived its cult favorite Tank a Guichets design, with a modern update featuring a jump-hour aperture and dragging-minute display.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Gold Quartz TPT is used for the RM74-02 and the material is exclusive to Richard Mille in watchmaking.

site_title: Walmart keeps price pressure on suppliers after Beijing pushback
summary: Walmart is continuing to pressure Chinese suppliers to cut prices by up to 10% to offset US President Donald Trump's tariffs, despite Beijing's summons of the retailer's executives and warnings of potential retaliation. The world's largest retailer has shown no signs of backing down, reflecting the challenges Chinese companies face with the tariffs adding to the country's slowing domestic economy. This stance indicates tough conditions for Chinese exporters for some time to come.

images.alt_text: Walmart is also closing its office in Charlotte, North Carolina, and is cutting corporate roles as part of the process, according to the memo.
Walmart’s push shows how rising geopolitical tensions are set to reshape global supply chains and pile pressure on US consumers already grappling with cost-of-living stresses.

site_title: New US tariffs likely to hurt firms in Singapore; nearly half say they will pass on costs, survey finds
summary: US President Donald Trump's new tariffs are likely to negatively impact firms in Singapore, with nearly half (45%) planning to pass on costs to customers. Over two-thirds of respondents fear reciprocal tariffs on countries taxing US imports, and nearly seven in 10 (69%) expect significant or moderate negative impacts on their operations. Some firms plan to diversify supply chains or gain market share from competitors, but experts warn that even those with no immediate impact may still be affected by knock-on effects.

site_title: China senses an opportunity in Trump’s cultural revolution
summary: China's leaders believe the US's cultural revolution under President Donald Trump will benefit China, as it will lead to a decline in US global credibility and a shift in alliances, favoring China's rise. China's rulers prefer the chaotic world Trump is trying to create to the one he is destroying. China sees opportunities in Trump's policies, including a weaker US dollar and a potential surge in exports to Europe and other countries. China's policymakers are confident that the US can no longer block their rise, and they are focusing on domestic issues, such as addressing a demand problem in the economy and investing in consumption.

site_title: Bukit Timah condo Hillcrest Arcadia put up for en bloc sale at S$920 million
summary: Bukit Timah condominium Hillcrest Arcadia is being put up for en bloc sale at a guide price of S$920 million, with a potential 773 new homes to be built on the 4-hectare site. The 99-year leasehold property has about 50 years left on its lease and is zoned for residential use with a gross plot ratio of 1.6. Owners stand to receive between S$945,000 and over S$5.7 million if the collective sale is successful, with the tender launching on April 3 and closing on May 22.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Brokered by Edmund Tie & Co, the sale of Thomson View is the largest en bloc deal done in Singapore since the S$890 million sale of Chuan Park got the go-ahead in May 2023.

site_title: Liberal wins Wisconsin Supreme Court election in setback for Trump, Musk
summary: Wisconsin voters elected liberal Judge Susan Crawford to the state Supreme Court, maintaining a 4-3 liberal majority and a setback for President Donald Trump and his ally Elon Musk, who backed conservative candidate Brad Schimel. The election was the most expensive judicial contest in US history, with over $90 million spent. Crawford won with 55% of the vote, defeating Schimel by 178,000 votes. The outcome is seen as a significant early referendum on Trump's presidency.

images.alt_text: Increasing soft data, from surveys and other qualitative sources, have pointed to a softening US economy, Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Austan Goolsbee noted, including sharp declines in business and consumer sentiment.

The White House would not confirm reports in US media that President Donald Trump was considering across-the-board tariffs of around 20 per cent, rather than different amounts for different countries.

Residents vote at a polling station in Madison, Wisconsin, April 1, 2025. In a race that has grabbed national attention, voters in Wisconsin are being asked to choose between Dane County Judge Susan Crawford and Waukesha County Judge Brad Schimel as the state's newest Supreme Court justice in what has been the most expensive judicial campaign in the nation’s history.

site_title: Dollar dips as Trump tariff plan keeps traders on edge
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.1% to 104.08 against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, amid uncertainty over President Donald Trump's planned tariffs. Traders await a White House Rose Garden announcement that may lead to steep new duties on US imports. The euro and sterling rose slightly, while the Australian dollar gained 0.44% as investors sought out less exposed currencies. A 20% blanket tariff plan has sparked concerns about a global trade war, potentially undermining the dollar this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee of a money changer holds a stack of U.S.  Dollar notes before giving it to a customer in Jakarta, October 8, 2015. REUTERS/Beawiharta/File Photo

site_title: The coming US recession will be self-inflicted
summary: The US economy is heading towards a recession, the first directly caused by White House policy, due to contractionary policies implemented by the Trump administration, including reducing the federal government, instituting broad tariffs, and deporting workers. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's economic index has turned negative, and consumer confidence has plummeted, with steep declines reported by the Conference Board and the University of Michigan. A recession is likely unless these policies are abandoned, and it may take years for the economy to fully recover, with job losses, slow hiring, and anaemic wage growth expected.

images.alt_text: Data for January was revised slightly higher to 7.762 million vacancies instead of the previously reported 7.74 million.
While factory-order and retail-sales data have held up so far, there are signs that purchasing managers are rushing to get orders in before the price hikes begin to take effect, likely on Apr 2.

site_title: Xiaomi shares extend losses as police investigate EV accident
summary: Xiaomi shares plummet 4.2% to a 6-week low after a deadly accident involving one of its electric vehicles in China killed three people. The incident raises concerns about the company's smart driving software and has sparked broader scrutiny of the industry. Investors are waiting for police conclusions before reassessing the company, which had recently become an investor darling after duplicating its smartphone success in the EV market.

images.alt_text: The driver assistance systems offered by Xiaomi and peers such as Xpeng and Huawei-backed EVs in China are similar to the technology that Tesla markets as Full Self-Driving.
The final price was towards the bottom end of the HK$52.80 to HK$54.60 price range flagged to investors when the deal launched on Monday.
Xiaomi’s top-up placement adds to a recent rush of Chinese firms’ carrying out equity capital market deals in the first few months of 2025.
The plan comes as Xiaomi’s SU7 electric sedan and its Ultra race car version prove popular with buyers, shipping more than 200,000 units in less than a year.
Xiaomi's revenue from EVs and “other new initiatives” reached 32.8 billion yuan last year.

site_title: SAC Capital lifts Soilbuild target price on strong order book, maintains its ‘buy’ call
summary: SAC Capital has lifted Soilbuild Construction's target price to S$1.10, maintaining its "buy" call, citing strong order book, solid execution, and improving profitability. The target price represents a 37.5% upside from the current price. The group's order book is expected to remain stable, with a potential 15% increase in net profit for FY2025 for every 10% increase in order book. Soilbuild's focus on high-spec manufacturing projects and sustainability is seen as a key driver of its positive outlook, with some S$47 billion to S$53 billion in construction contracts expected to be awarded this year.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Workers are able to conduct all-weather operations more efficiently with machinery at Tiong Seng’s Advanced Precast Hub for building components that can be precast.
Soildbuild construction group chief executive officer Lim Han Ren believes that the group is well-positioned to capitalise on more opportunities in the future.

site_title: UK imposes online entry permit on European visitors
summary: The UK has introduced a digital Electronic Travel Authorisation (ETA) permit for European visitors, aiming to boost security and streamline entry processes. Starting Wednesday, travellers from Europe will need an online permit to enter the UK, with a buffer period that could last several months. This change is part of the British government's efforts to update longstanding travel rules.

images.alt_text: epa11981239 International Arrivals at Terminal 2 in Heathrow Airport in Hounslow, Britain, 22 March 2025. Flights resumed at Heathrow Airport following a power outage on 21 March 2025. A fire at a substation which supplies power to Heathrow forced its closure for most of 21 March, leading to thousands of cancelled flights and stranding passengers across the world. Heathrow is Europe's busiest Airport and the Metropolitan Police’s Counter Terrorism Command is leading the investigation into the cause of the fire at the electrical substation.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL

site_title: Thailand vows to cut US trade surplus as it sees US$8 billion hit
summary: Thailand plans to reduce its trade surplus with the US by importing more energy and food products, estimating a potential loss of around US$8 billion if US tariffs on Chinese products are raised. The country's trade surplus with the US reached US$45 billion last year, with electronics, machinery, and agricultural products being major exports. Thailand's government has prepared a strategy to cope with reciprocal tariffs, adopting a "holistic approach" to trade negotiations.

images.alt_text: Japanese tourists (in the center) visit Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn on the eve of Lunar New Year, as the high-profile alleged kidnapping of a Chinese actor and similar crimes stoked worries over tourism and security in Bangkok, Thailand January 28, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa
The earthquake, which occurred in the city of Mandalay in Myanmar, was one of the strongest in the South-east Asian nation in a century.

site_title: Singapore shares slide ahead of Trump’s tariffs; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% or 14.64 points to 3,954.21 ahead of US President Donald Trump's expected tariff announcements. The decline came despite a special dividend announcement from property player Wee Hur, which closed down 2.9% after disposing of a 37.1% stake in Australian student accommodation assets. Across the Asia-Pacific region, the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI, S&P ASX 200, Shanghai Composite Index, and Nikkei 225 ended higher, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and South Korea's Kospi slid.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
In the first quarter of 2025, the Straits Times Index had 22 gainers and eight decliners, according to data from the Singapore Exchange.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, Taipei and Manila stocks were all up, Tokyo was flat and Singapore and Seoul slipped on Wednesday.
Sembcorp Utilities signed a sale and purchase agreement that will increase its interest in Senoko Energy to as much as 70 per cent.

site_title: US manufacturing activity shrinks for first time this year
summary: US factory activity contracted in March for the first time this year, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index declining 1.3 points to 49. Consumer demand is cooling, making it difficult for producers to pass on higher costs due to the uncertainty surrounding additional tariffs. The ISM index of factory orders slumped to its lowest level since May 2023, and production shrank for the first time this year.

images.alt_text: Data for January was revised slightly higher to 7.762 million vacancies instead of the previously reported 7.74 million.
IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said the Fund may slightly downgrade its global economic forecast for this year of 3.3 per cent, adding it does not currently predict a recession.
US President Donald Trump's order establishes an office within the Department of Commerce called the United States Investment Accelerator, which will encourage companies to make large investments.

A shopper carries a Gump's San Francisco bag in the Union Square area of San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024. Fewer Americans shopped during Thanksgiving weekend this year, a sign that consumers remain selective about spending. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Bangkok’s condo oversupply problem may worsen over quake fears
summary: A deadly earthquake in Myanmar has worsened Bangkok's condominium oversupply problem, with 235,000 unsold units at the end of 2024, the most since 2018. The 7.7 magnitude quake has shaken the confidence of prospective home buyers, especially in high-rise condominiums, with sales expected to slump further. Developers, including Ananda Development and Origin Property, are facing added inspection and repair costs, while smaller developers catering to landed homes might benefit from the shift in buyer preferences. The condominium association expects a short-lived impact on demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: US lawmakers seek to rename street for Hong Kong's jailed Jimmy Lai
summary: US lawmakers have introduced a bill to rename a street in Washington's Dupont Circle area after Jimmy Lai, a pro-democracy activist and media mogul jailed in China. Lai was the founder of the Apple Daily, a now-shuttered Chinese-language newspaper that championed mass demonstrations in 2019. The proposed street sign, "Jimmy Lai Way," aims to honor Lai's efforts to safeguard democratic liberties in Hong Kong. The bill was introduced by Representative Chris Smith, who stated that the move aims to remind employees of the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office of their role in dismantling Hong Kong's freedoms.

images.alt_text: Lai, who is set to take the stand in November, is the most high-profile target in Hong Kong’s crackdown on dissent.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars exposed to collateral damage from tariff fallout
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were exposed to uncertainty due to the potential for a global trade war triggered by US tariffs. Despite having limited direct trade exposure to the US, the currencies are vulnerable to regional and global economic growth concerns. The Aussie traded flat at US$0.6278, while the kiwi dollar was a fraction firmer at US$0.5709. Markets expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates further in May due to the ongoing uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The collapsed proposal with Salter Brothers Capital is a major blow to Star, which has been struggling to stay afloat amid a growing debt crisis and regulatory investigations at the casino group.
Reserve Bank of Australia governor Michelle Bullock speaks during a news conference at the bank’s head office in Sydney, Australia, April 1, 2025.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation picks up, backing case for BOK pause
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation unexpectedly accelerated to 2.1% in March, surpassing economists' forecasts, giving the central bank an incentive to pause its monetary easing campaign. The Bank of Korea (BOK) has cut its benchmark interest rate three times since October, and policymakers will assess the impact of the February rate cut before setting policy on April 17. The government is also providing an extra budget of 10 trillion won to address trade risks and support growth, amid US President Donald Trump's tariff campaign threatening to weigh on exports.

images.alt_text: Since taking office in 2022, Financial Supervisory Service Governor Lee Bok Hyun has actively launched investigations into a number of controversial share issue plans and held a series of forums to address various issues related to stock market reforms.

The meeting between South Korea's Industry Minister Ahn Duk-geun (centre)  with Japan's Yoji Muto (left) and China's Wang Wentao takes place with the US’ 25 per cent levy on car imports set to take effect on Apr 3.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 2)
summary: BMI forecasts gold prices to range between US$3,000 and US$3,400 per ounce for the second and third quarters of 2025, indicating a bullish outlook on the metal's price growth. This prediction comes after spot prices hit fresh records.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Singapore property landscape

site_title: Maybank initiates coverage on Centurion with ‘buy’ call with construction boom in Singapore expected
summary: Maybank has initiated coverage on Centurion with a "buy" call, citing a tight supply of worker dormitory beds in Singapore and strong construction demand. The analysts set a price target of S$1.45, 19.8% above the latest closing price of S$1.21. They believe Centurion will benefit from "favourable demand-supply dynamics" in the Republic. The company's overseas student accommodation portfolio is also seen as a positive outlook.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
On Feb 26, the group reported a net profit of S$226.6 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2024, a year-on-year increase of 97 per cent.

site_title: China extends EU brandy probe, delays definitive penalties
summary: China has extended its anti-dumping investigation into European Union brandy by three months, delaying definitive penalties until July 5, amid heightened trade tensions. The probe was initiated in January 2024 and was originally due to be concluded in a year. The delay follows a visit by French Foreign Minister Jean-Noel Barrot, who offered deeper bilateral cooperation. China's measures require importers to pay nearly 40% security deposits to import brandy from the EU, making it more costly. The French cognac industry group views the delay as a "positive signal" for negotiations.

images.alt_text: The EU imposed tariffs on China-made EVs at the end of October after an anti-subsidy investigation, including 17 per cent for BYD, 18.8 per cent for Geely and 35.3 per cent for SAIC, on top of the EU’s standard car import duty of 10 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Chinese carmakers, eager to expand to major global markets, have hit resistance in Europe after being effectively shut out from the US.

The vehicle trade-in policy, which offered a subsidy payment as high as 20,000 yuan (S$3,700), was credited for record high auto production and sales in November, with many consumers rushing to buy cars before the policy ends this month.
The EU is also proposing a derogation mechanism to allow EU central securities depositories to unfreeze some of the cash they hold in the face of increased litigation in Russia.
Plans to ship cognac in containers and bottle it in China rather than France were discussed by industry body Maisons de Cognac.
Beijing’s commerce ministry said that authorities have “decided to implement temporary anti-dumping measures in the form of a cash deposit or letter of guarantee” against European brandy products.

site_title: Indonesia’s hotels suffer as Prabowo’s austerity drive hits travel and events
summary: Indonesia's hotels are struggling due to sweeping budget cuts under President Prabowo Subianto's administration, which has reduced government-related bookings from 40% to a significant decrease. This has led to a 20-40% drop in hotel occupancy rates, sparking concerns of layoffs and closures. About 60-70% of hotels, especially in major cities like Jakarta, are feeling the squeeze. The industry's reliance on public spending has made it vulnerable to the cuts, highlighting the sector's heavy dependence on government events and travel.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
A sign for Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund Danantara is seen in front of its headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, February 28, 2025. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: Trump faces first electoral test in Wisconsin, Florida votes
summary: US President Donald Trump faces his first electoral test as he campaigns for Republican candidates in Wisconsin's Supreme Court and two Florida congressional seats. Trump has sent his advisor Elon Musk to boost Republican chances in Wisconsin, with Musk handing out money to petition signers. The Wisconsin Supreme Court election has set a record for spending, with over $49.7 million spent. Trump has attacked Democratic candidate Susan Crawford, calling her a "Radical Left Liberal." The outcome could determine the balance of power on the Wisconsin Supreme Court and send a message to the country.

images.alt_text: A gauge of production at factories declined to 46, the lowest level since May 2020, from 47.9 in November.
Data for January was revised slightly higher to 7.762 million vacancies instead of the previously reported 7.74 million.

EPA-EFE/ALEXANDER DRAGO / POOL

site_title: RB Family Office markets Mosque Street asset amid increasing buzz in shophouse hotel scene
summary: RB Family Office is marketing its 138-room Hotel 1900 in Singapore's Mosque Street for a guide price of around S$170 million. The hotel was previously known as Porcelain Hotel and has been revamped. Another shophouse hotel, Duxton Reserve Singapore, has been sold to a company with Indian shareholders for S$80 million. These sales follow increasing buzz in the shophouse hotel market. CBRE and HSBC are conducting a private EOI exercise for Hotel 1900, describing it as a "generational opportunity" for buyers.

site_title: Sembcorp unit proposes to more than double stake in power supplier Senoko Energy
summary: Sembcorp Industries is proposing to acquire up to 70% of Senoko Energy, more than doubling its current 30% stake, for a maximum purchase price of $144 million. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2025, aims to expand opportunities for the two companies to contribute to the energy transition and deliver sustainable energy. The deal has been reviewed by the Energy Market Authority and has no objections, with Sembcorp committing to ensure fair market competition.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
For investors, Sembcorp’s missed target should be of little concern, the writer argues.
This will not affect Sembcorp’s energy costs or its ability to meet gas supply requirements in Singapore, says Sembcorp.
Sembcorp’s shares have climbed more than 250 per cent since the end of 2020, giving the company a market value of S$10.7 billion.
GAIA solar farm in Long An province was Sembcorp's first utility-scale acquisition in Vietnam.

site_title: PBOC seen deploying stimulus soon on tariff risks, cash shortage
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is expected to deploy monetary stimulus as early as April due to the double threat of US tariff hikes and a seasonal cash shortage. The central bank is likely to cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to unshackle hundreds of billions of yuan for lending and investing, according to economists. This move would be a shift from the PBOC's relatively hawkish approach to managing liquidity since the beginning of the year, and would signal a readiness to help the economy weather US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has also tightened liquidity to support its currency, leading to higher bond yields.
The committee of the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) suggested stepping up monetary policy adjustment and control, and improving monetary policy to be more forward-looking, targeted and effective.
A string of recent economic data, including manufacturing activity, industrial output and retail sales, provide encouraging signs for the economy’s continued recovery.

site_title: Australia’s Star Entertainment eyes Bally’s lifeline after failing to secure new debt package
summary: Australia's Star Entertainment is exploring a lifeline from US casino group Bally's Corp after a proposed A$940 million refinancing deal with Salter Brothers Capital collapsed. The collapse is a major blow to Star, which has been struggling with a growing debt crisis and regulatory investigations. Star is now considering a A$250 million recapitalisation package offered by Bally's, which would give the company control of 50.1% of Star. Star shares remain suspended from trading due to uncertainty about the company's ability to continue as a going concern, with enough cash to last one week.

images.alt_text: Distressed casino operator Star Entertainment opened its books in early March to investment group Salter Brothers for a debt refinancing proposal worth up to A$940 million (S$792 million).

site_title: Warburg purchases Tokyo rental houses, plans Japan office
summary: Warburg Pincus, a New York-based private equity firm, has acquired a portfolio of 1,195 shared rental houses in the Tokyo area from Lone Star Funds, with plans to expand its Japan office later this year. The move underscores increased foreign investor activity in Japan, drawn by the weak yen, cheap financing, and the return of inflation. Warburg's real estate investments will focus on the "new economy" sectors, including rental housing, life sciences, and data centers, with plans to invest in late-stage startups and growth companies in Japan.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Slim Eng Thiam, chairman of SRG Singapore; Warren Downey, group CEO; Collin Yap, CEO, Asia Pacific; Chua Eng Leong, chairman, Asia Pacific; Lee Anderson, deputy group CEO, at the launch event.
Justin Gabbani, chief executive officer (Investment Management) at Lendlease.

site_title: BYD enjoys yet another blockbuster quarter as Tesla flounders
summary: BYD, a Chinese carmaker, reported a 58% increase in sales for the first quarter of 2025, with 986,098 units sold, including 416,388 pure electric vehicles. The company aims to sell 5.5 million vehicles this year, with 800,000 forecasted exports. This contrasts with Tesla, which may see lower sales due to Elon Musk's involvement in politics and intense competition from home-grown competitors. BYD's shares have risen 45% this year, while Tesla's have fallen 36%.

images.alt_text: BYD founder and chairman Wang Chuanfu said the company will continue building factories overseas without partners as it has abundant funding.
BYD has risen quickly to the top of China’s car market – the world’s biggest and most competitive in terms of electric vehicles.
As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.

site_title: South Korea financial watchdog chief offers to resign after veto on shareholder interests
summary: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service Governor Lee Bok Hyun has offered to resign after the acting president vetoed a revised Commercial Act that would have broadened the duty of corporate board members to act in the interests of all shareholders. The vetoed bill aimed to resolve the "Korea discount" issue, where family-owned conglomerates' poor governance leads to depressed stock prices. Lee had expressed his intention to step down to the chairman of the Financial Services Commission, but the offer was not immediately accepted.

images.alt_text: The resumption of short selling after a 17-month ban could improve market access for international investors.
Korean brands have cornered about 22% of foreign cosmetics products in the US and about 40% in Japan.

The meeting between South Korea's Industry Minister Ahn Duk-geun (centre)  with Japan's Yoji Muto (left) and China's Wang Wentao takes place with the US’ 25 per cent levy on car imports set to take effect on Apr 3.
South Korea’s Kospi is Asia’s second-best performer among major Asian equity gauges this year so far, with a roughly 7 per cent gain.

site_title: Hong Kong's new police chief stresses national security despite US sanctions
summary: Hong Kong's new police chief, Joe Chow, emphasized national security as his top priority despite US sanctions imposed on him and other officials for Beijing's human rights crackdown. Chow described the sanctions as "barbaric acts" attempting to intimidate police officers, and vowed to continue working hard on national security. The US sanctions were imposed in response to Hong Kong's use of national security laws to "intimidate, silence and harass" activists abroad, while Hong Kong authorities have defended their use of the laws. Beijing has vowed "countermeasures" against the sanctions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong prosecutors on Tuesday filed a "seditious publications" charge against jailed media tycoon Jimmy Lai who already faces charges under a tough national security law that critics say has stifled freedoms in the Asian financial hub.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Nio, SingPost, Fu Yu
summary: Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary signed a deal to increase its stake in Senoko Energy to 70% for S$144 million, while Nio delivered 42,094 vehicles in Q1, a 40.1% year-over-year increase. Singapore Post announced leadership changes and will restructure over several months. Fu Yu plans to make claims against six individuals related to its subsidiary's acquisition and misuse of resources.

site_title: Need to redouble efforts to maintain Singapore’s social cohesion: PM Wong
summary: Singapore must work to maintain social cohesion and guard against forces that could pull society apart along racial and religious lines, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. He emphasized the importance of religious harmony, citing the presence of leaders from major religions at a dinner celebrating the Taoist Federation's 35th anniversary and Singapore's 60th year of independence. Wong noted that Singapore's progress over the past 60 years was not without challenges, but the country has thrived and become a prosperous nation, with multiculturalism being its strength.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong speaking at the REACH 40th Anniversary Launch Ceremony at Jewel Changi Airport.
He is making great effort to renew the leadership team and the party, PM Wong tells media in an interview capping of his visit to Hanoi.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says the government’s partnership with enterprises will become increasingly important for Singapore’s growth as the world faces a more dangerous, turbulent and volatile external environment.

site_title: Gold prices climb on safe-haven demand ahead of US reciprocal tariffs
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $3,120.64 an ounce, driven by safe-haven demand ahead of US reciprocal tariffs set to take effect on April 3. The tariffs, announced by Trump, could escalate the global trade war and lead to inflation. Investors also await the automobile tariffs, which will also be implemented on April 3. The uncertainty has led to a decrease in interest rates, creating a favorable environment for gold to flourish.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held steady at US$3,125.34 an ounce, as of 0023 GMT, after hitting an all-time high of US$3,128.06 in the previous session.

site_title: Warner showcases ‘Superman’ reboot, new DiCaprio film
summary: Warner Bros unveiled footage from its highly anticipated "Superman" reboot and a new Leonardo DiCaprio film, "One Battle After Another", at CinemaCon in Las Vegas. The "Superman" reboot, directed by James Gunn, features a lighter and more humorous approach, with a focus on kindness and human love. Gunn aims to reinvigorate the classic character for modern audiences. Meanwhile, "One Battle After Another" is a post-modern thriller loosely based on Thomas Pynchon's "Vineland", with DiCaprio playing a man struggling to remember a secret passcode to locate his daughter. The films are part of Warner's efforts to revitalize its superhero movies and high-budget films.

images.alt_text: The North American film industry has never recovered to pre-pandemic levels of moviegoers.
A Working Man starring Jason Statham as a military veteran who comes out of retirement to seek the kidnappers of his boss’ daughter.
The Bugis+ branch of Filmgarde Cineplexes closed in 2022 along with its Century Square outlet.

site_title: ‘World came crashing down’: Former Envy director and family invested more than S$40m in nickel scam
summary: Former Envy executive director Lau Lee Sheng testified in the trial of Ng Yu Zhi, accused of masterminding a S$1.46 billion nickel-trading scam. Lau invested S$26 million and his family members, including his mother and two sisters, also invested millions. He realized the scam was a fraud when Ng was arrested in 2021, and his mother was diagnosed with Stage 4 cancer. Lau faces potential bankruptcy if liquidators succeed in clawing back S$17 million from his earnings. The prosecution is proceeding on 42 of Ng's 108 charges, which include cheating, forgery, and money laundering.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi is accused of masterminding a nickel-trading scam that attracted S$1.46 billion from 947 investors over six years.
Prosecutors alleged that Ng Yu Zhi’s Ponzi scheme, which promised attractive profits from nickel trading, was “pure fiction” that duped 947 investors of almost $1.5 billion.

site_title: Actor Val Kilmer, star of ‘Top Gun’ and ‘Batman Forever’, dies at 65
summary: Actor Val Kilmer, known for his roles in 'Top Gun' and 'Batman Forever', has died at 65 due to pneumonia. A Juilliard-trained actor, Kilmer struggled with a reputation for being temperamental and perfectionistic, which led to clashes with directors and co-stars. Despite commercial successes like 'Heat' and 'The Doors', his career was marred by flops and personal struggles, including a diagnosis of throat cancer in 2014. Kilmer's personal life, including high-profile relationships, often overshadowed his work, leaving a lasting impact on Hollywood.

images.alt_text: He played not just in popular series but in musical theatre – he even had a brief stint as a recording artist – and took on classical stage roles, drawing surprisingly strong reviews while playing Hamlet in Birmingham, England.
Samsung co-CEO Han Jong Hee died from cardiac arrest while receiving treatment at a hospital during time off, a company spokesperson said.

site_title: Is the hit to Yangzijiang Shipbuilding share price going to be fleeting?
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's share price has plummeted nearly 30% since the US proposed US$1.5 million in fees on Chinese-built or Chinese-operated ships, as well as liners with orders for Chinese vessels. Despite analysts' calls for a buying opportunity, the share price remains unchanged. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's management reported no order abortions or delays, but the company's clients have calculated that the port fees would amount to US$100 per container, which could be passed on to shippers. The proposed levies may have a lasting impact on Chinese shipbuilders beyond Trump's term.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
On Feb 21, the USTR office proposed to hit Chinese-built vessels entering US ports with fees of up to US$1.5 million.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was one of the Singapore Exchange’s top-performing stocks in 2024.

site_title: Panin Bank a good fit for DBS’ Indonesia operations; Singapore bank’s surplus capital could fund this buy: analysts
summary: DBS is leading the bid to acquire Panin Bank, Indonesia's 12th largest lender, with analysts citing the bank's potential to generate surplus capital for DBS and enhance its earnings diversification. The acquisition could cost DBS around S$2.8 billion, which could be funded using one to two years of surplus capital generation. DBS has a strong track record of turning around unprofitable targets and could benefit from Panin's branch network, expanding consumer lending, and lowering funding costs.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta was paid S$17.6 million, up from the S$11.2 million paycut he took in 2023
DBS' AGM on Mar 28– which was attended by more than 1,500 shareholders – marked the leadership transition of South-east Asia’s largest lender.

site_title: LTA issues Grab taxi operator licence in Singapore
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) issued a street-hail service operator licence to GrabCab, a subsidiary of Grab Holdings, valid for 10 years from April 9. This makes Grab the sixth taxi company in Singapore, with a three-year grace period to expand its fleet to at least 800 taxis. The licence allows Grab to operate taxis, serving both street-hail and ride-hail rides, and aims to improve ride availability and cater to consumers' growing demand for point-to-point rides.

A licence or special decal which private-hire car drivers who must display on their windscreens. Grab Affixing Centre at Midview City in Sin Ming Lane.

site_title: RHB Singapore appoints new CEO Goh Ken-Yi
summary: RHB Singapore has appointed Goh Ken-Yi, 53, as its new CEO, effective April 1. He succeeds Danny Quah, who led the bank from 2019, and aims to expand the bank's presence in priority sectors. Goh has over 20 years of experience in investment banking and financial services, and will focus on advancing the bank's digital capabilities and delivering innovative financial solutions. Quah, who has 30 years of banking experience, has taken on a new role as managing director for group international business.

site_title: Fu Yu seeks claims against six individuals including Victor Lim in relation to probe into subsidiary
summary: Fu Yu Corp is pursuing claims against six individuals, including its largest shareholder Victor Lim, over a probe into its subsidiary FYSCS. The probe found unverifiable arrangements for a $3 million payment, and Fu Yu alleges breach of duties, misrepresentation, and conspiracy. The company is seeking claims for the acquisition of FYSCS, misuse of resources, and pre-paid commission. Lim denies wrongdoing and claims the company is trying to deflect attention from its own issues, including reduced revenues in its core manufacturing business.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Without two non-cash impairments, Fu Yu expects to record an operating profit in FY2024.
Fu Yu's largest shareholder wanted to replace two independent, non-executive directors with three proposed candidiates.
Fu Yu’s largest shareholder makes new request to table motion to oust directors at AGM

site_title: GM leads first quarter US auto sales as tariffs loom
summary: General Motors led US vehicle sales in the first quarter with a 17% increase in deliveries to 693,363 units. Fellow major automakers Toyota, Honda, Hyundai, and Kia also reported sales increases, while Ford logged a small decline. The industry is bracing for President Trump's incoming tariffs, which could cause average auto prices to surge by thousands of dollars over time. GM's sales growth outpaced other major automakers, driven by its portfolio, including electric vehicle models.

images.alt_text: The driver assistance systems offered by Xiaomi and peers such as Xpeng and Huawei-backed EVs in China are similar to the technology that Tesla markets as Full Self-Driving.
The numbers will set the tone for the rest of 2025 as the company aims to return to growth after logging its first annual sales drop in over a decade last year.
Nissan Motor incoming Chief Executive Officer Ivan Espinosa wants to cut development for the first car in a family of cars to 37 months, while the second car or third car would take just 30 months.

site_title: Trump ‘perfecting’ new tariffs as nervous world brace
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce sweeping new tariffs on Wednesday, sparking concerns of a global trade war. The tariffs, potentially around 20% across the board, are aimed at "liberating" the US economy and stopping it from being "ripped off" by other countries. The move has prompted vows of retaliation from major economies, including the European Union, Canada, and Vietnam, and could lead to a recession at home and abroad.

images.alt_text: GM said its US sales jumped 17 per cent in the quarter from the same period a year ago, reporting 693,363 deliveries.

Residents vote at a polling station in Madison, Wisconsin, April 1, 2025. In a race that has grabbed national attention, voters in Wisconsin are being asked to choose between Dane County Judge Susan Crawford and Waukesha County Judge Brad Schimel as the state's newest Supreme Court justice in what has been the most expensive judicial campaign in the nation’s history.
Brent futures settled down 28 cents, or 0.37 per cent, at US$74.49 a barrel on Tuesday. The session high was above US$75 a barrel.
A gauge of production at factories declined to 46, the lowest level since May 2020, from 47.9 in November.
Data for January was revised slightly higher to 7.762 million vacancies instead of the previously reported 7.74 million.

site_title: China’s improving profits may help soften tariff blow for stocks
summary: China's fourth-quarter earnings beat estimates by 5.1%, driven by a stimulus blitz and growing consumer spending, offering a cushion for local stocks as they prepare for US tariffs. The earnings boost fueled investor optimism, particularly in tech firms, with major consumer tech giants such as JD.com, Alibaba Group, and Tencent Holdings reporting consensus-beating results. However, tariffs imposed by US President Donald Trump on China remain a significant concern, with potential impacts on 2025 earnings growth estimated at 4-5 percentage points.

images.alt_text: State-backed Vanke reported a record 49.5 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) loss last year, its first full-year loss since 1991.

“More proactive and effective macroeconomic policies will be implemented to comprehensively expand domestic demand and stabilise foreign trade and investment,” said China's Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang.
The gain followed a 11 per cent rise in December and a 3.3 per cent decline for the whole of 2024, according to National Bureau of Statistics data.

site_title: Hong Kong considers new OTC stock market for delisted companies
summary: Hong Kong is drafting rules for an over-the-counter (OTC) market for delisted shares, which would provide an exit for investors looking to sell worthless securities. Since 2018, 224 companies have been delisted due to prolonged trading suspensions. The proposed OTC market, also referred to as a "pink sheet market," would be an "end-of-life care" platform, allowing investors to sell but not raise new funds. Regulators are considering a "buyer beware" model, restricting brokers responsible for advising investors on delisted stocks. The market is expected to be run by HKEX, but not generate profits.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong stock exchange has just closed a market consultation to limit clawbacks, hoping to keep more shares for institutional investors.

site_title: US tech giant Qualcomm acquires GenAI unit of Vietnam’s Vingroup
summary: US tech giant Qualcomm has acquired MovianAI, a generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) subsidiary of Vietnam's Vingroup, for an undisclosed amount. This follows Nvidia's earlier acquisition of VinBrain, a Hanoi-based company specializing in AI-powered healthcare solutions. The deal is expected to expedite Qualcomm's creation of advanced AI solutions for products such as smartphones, PCs, and software-defined vehicles. MovianAI's founder and CEO, Hung Bui, will join Qualcomm following the acquisition.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Nvidia Executive Vice President for Worldwide Field Operations Jay Puri, Nvidia Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang; Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, and Minister of Planning and Investment Nguyen Chi Dung
Truong Quoc Hung, chief executive at VinBrain and Kimberly Powell, vice president of healthcare at Nvidia at the headquarters of Nvidia in the US in March, 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up but uncertainty rules ahead of Trump tariffs
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday as investors braced for US President Donald Trump's announcement of new tariffs, despite uncertainty surrounding the measures. The planned 25% auto tariffs are set to come into effect on Thursday, and Trump's decision is expected to be made at 4 pm in Washington. Analysts warn that the ongoing uncertainty could spook markets, with estimates suggesting tariffs could range from a few percentage points to double-digit levels. Economists predict that the tariffs could lead to a hit in economic growth and inflation, and a global trade war.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 1.07 per cent higher at 539.64 points, recovering from the prior day’s losses.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped less than 0.1 per cent to 41,989.96 while the broad-based S&P 500 shook off a recent slump to close up 0.4 per cent at 5,633.07 on Tuesday.

site_title: Myanmar quake toll passes 2,700, nation halts to honour victims
summary: A devastating earthquake in Myanmar has killed at least 2,719 people, with over 4,500 injured and 441 still missing. The 7.7-magnitude quake struck on April 1, causing widespread destruction in the country's second-largest city, Mandalay. A minute's silence was held nationwide to honor the victims, and international aid has begun to pour in. Over 1,000 foreign rescuers have arrived to help, and nearly 650 people have been pulled alive from the rubble. The country is also grappling with a four-year civil war, which has displaced 3.5 million people.

images.alt_text: OUE Healthcare holds a 40 per cent stake in the joint venture companies that own, operate and manage Pun Hlaing Hospitals located in the Myanmar cities of Yangon, Mandalay and Taunggyi.

Scores of people were feared trapped under collapsed buildings across Mandalay but most could not be reached or pulled out without heavy machinery, a humanitarian worker and two residents say.

International tourist arrivals are expected to drop by 10-15 per cent or even more in the next two weeks as the 7.7 earthquake on Friday (Mar 28) shook buildings in Bangkok and other Thai tourist hot spots, spooking prospective travellers, the Thai Hotels Association says.

site_title: Xiaomi car with driver assistance crashes, three reported dead
summary: A Xiaomi electric vehicle crashed on a Chinese expressway, killing three people and injuring others. The accident occurred when the driver's hands were taken off the wheel despite the advanced driver assistance system being engaged. Xiaomi's Navigate on Autopilot function, which can change lanes and speed, was reportedly active at the time of the crash. The company has condemned the incident and is cooperating with the Chinese police, but the cause of the crash remains under investigation. The accident has raised concerns about the safety of smart driving technology in China.

images.alt_text: The final price was towards the bottom end of the HK$52.80 to HK$54.60 price range flagged to investors when the deal launched on Monday.

The plan comes as Xiaomi’s SU7 electric sedan and its Ultra race car version prove popular with buyers, shipping more than 200,000 units in less than a year.
Xiaomi's revenue from EVs and “other new initiatives” reached 32.8 billion yuan last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 1)
summary: Singapore's non-landed private residential property prices rose 0.6% quarter on quarter in Q1 2025, following a 3% increase in the prior quarter. This marks a slower pace of growth compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: Straits Times Index closes slightly lower after cutting intra-day losses
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed slightly lower, dipping 3.58 points or 0.1% to 3,968.85 on Tuesday. The decline followed a late-session climb on Wall Street, with SPI Asset Management's Stephen Innes warning investors not to be fooled by the gains, citing a "macro minefield" ahead due to the US' planned reciprocal tariffs on April 2.

In January, Ho Bee Land launched a non-binding indicative offer to acquire all the shares it does not indirectly own in AVJennings for A$0.70 apiece.

Japan’s Nikkei led the rout in Asia, losing an eye-watering 4.1 per cent and falling to a six-month low as automaker stocks continued to suffer fallout from Trump’s talk of 25 per cent tariffs on imported cars.

site_title: Hard data shows US economy is solid, but there is fear around tariffs: Federal Reserve’s Goolsbee
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Austan Goolsbee stated that the "hard" data show a solid US economy, with a strong labor market and low inflation, but warned that the imposition of broad new tariffs could lead to renewed inflation or an economic slowdown. The tariffs, set to be announced by President Trump, could impact prices and consumer behavior, with Goolsbee noting that imports account for only 11% of the US economy. The Fed has chosen to wait on adjusting monetary policy due to uncertainty over the tariffs' impact.

images.alt_text: The White House would not confirm reports in US media that President Donald Trump was considering across-the-board tariffs of around 20 per cent, rather than different amounts for different countries.

site_title: Bankers get boost in Asia-Pacific as M&A growth tops US, Europe
summary: The Asia-Pacific region has seen a significant boost in merger and acquisition (M&A) activity, with the region's M&A volume up 19% from the first quarter last year. The US and Europe trail behind, with volumes up 13% and down 14% respectively. Take-private deals are common in Hong Kong, where the Hang Seng Index has climbed over 15% this year. Financial sponsors are under pressure to deploy capital, and companies are increasingly pursuing M&A to achieve this goal.

site_title: Trump to weigh plans for TikTok sale at meeting on Wednesday
summary: US President Donald Trump will meet on April 2 to consider a proposal for divesting TikTok's US operations from Chinese parent company ByteDance, ahead of a deadline for a sale by April 5. The plan, led by Oracle and Blackstone, would give the company a small stake in a new American entity, but critics say it may leave unresolved concerns about China accessing sensitive data. Trump has extended the deadline once before and is considering lowering tariff rates on China to secure Beijing's support of a sale, which would keep TikTok's algorithm in Chinese hands.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
US President Donald Trump earlier this month said the United States was in talks with four groups interested in acquiring TikTok.

site_title: Intel will spin off non-core units, says CEO Tan Lip-Bu
summary: Intel CEO Tan Lip-Bu plans to spin off non-core units to restore the company's fortunes. He aims to improve Intel's balance sheet, manufacturing processes, and engineering talent. The company will focus on creating custom semiconductors to better align with customers' needs. Tan acknowledged Intel's struggles in areas like AI and data centre chips, and emphasized the need for a long-term turnaround.

images.alt_text: DeepSeek’s focus on reasoning will increase the need for computation, helping drive demand for Nvidia chips, Jensen Huang says.
Intel will also restart plans to produce chips that power AI servers and look to areas beyond servers in several areas such as software, robotics and AI foundation models.
