site_title: EU readies ‘strong plan’ against Trump’s global tariff strike
summary: The European Union is preparing a "strong plan" to retaliate against the US if President Donald Trump imposes reciprocal tariffs on the bloc, according to European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The EU aims for a "negotiated solution" and is considering using its anti-coercion instrument to restrict trade, services, and intellectual property rights. The bloc is preparing countermeasures on up to $37.7 billion of US goods, including cars, steel, and aluminum imports.

images.alt_text: With multiple rounds of tariffs already implemented against China, Canada and Mexico – plus the 25 per cent tariff on cars announced last week which is due to start on Apr 3 – he has already lifted America’s effective tariff rate to about 8 per cent, up from 2 per cent last year, the highest it has been since the 1940s.

site_title: US job openings decline in February amid rising economic uncertainty
summary: US job openings declined in February to 7.568 million, a drop of 194,000 from the previous month, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. This marks a still-low level of job openings, and a slight increase from the revised January figure of 7.762 million. Rising economic uncertainty due to tariffs on imports is believed to have contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said the Fund may slightly downgrade its global economic forecast for this year of 3.3 per cent, adding it does not currently predict a recession.

A shopper carries a Gump's San Francisco bag in the Union Square area of San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024. Fewer Americans shopped during Thanksgiving weekend this year, a sign that consumers remain selective about spending. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring, decreased 25,000 to a seasonally adjusted 1.856 million during the week ending March 15.

site_title: Oil eases off five-week highs as traders weigh impact of imminent Trump tariffs
summary: Oil prices eased off five-week highs on Tuesday as traders weighed the impact of imminent US President Donald Trump's tariffs. Brent futures fell 28 cents, or 0.37%, to US$74.49 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures declined 28 cents, or 0.39%, to US$71.20. Trump's threats to impose secondary tariffs on Russian oil and attack Iran fueled supply worries, limiting losses. The move was seen as a sign that the global trade war may intensify, but did not have a significant impact on oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent futures were up US$1.11, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$74.74 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose US$2.12, or 3.1 per cent, to settle at US$71.48.

site_title: Taiwan chipmaker UMC launches US$5 billion wafer fab facility in Singapore; 700 jobs to be created
summary: Taiwan-based chipmaker UMC has launched a US$5 billion wafer fabrication facility in Singapore, expected to create 700 jobs. The facility, set to produce over one million wafers annually by 2026, will increase UMC's production capacity in the country. The expansion is seen as a significant investment in Singapore's growing semiconductor industry, positioning the country as a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: GE2025: SAF Chief of Staff Goh Pei Ming steps down ahead of general election
summary: SAF Chief of Staff Goh Pei Ming, 42, stepped down ahead of the general election, raising speculation about his potential candidacy. Goh, who held various senior command appointments, confirmed his last day was March 31 but declined to comment on his next move or election plans. His departure has sparked interest in his possible involvement in the upcoming election, with many speculating he may be fielded as a candidate.

site_title: Ghibli-inspired viral feature drives record ChatGPT usage
summary: ChatGPT's image-generation tool sparked a viral trend of creating Ghibli-style AI art, leading to a record surge in users and in-app subscription revenue. Average weekly active users reached 150 million, a new high for the year. The trend strained ChatGPT's servers, temporarily limiting the feature's usage. The extensive usage raises questions about potential copyright violations, particularly given the inspiration from Studio Ghibli's iconic style.

site_title: US movie theatres urge 45-day ‘baseline’ before films hit streaming
summary: The US film industry's trade organization, Cinema United, has urged movie theatres to require a 45-day "baseline" exclusivity period for new films before they become available on streaming platforms. This move aims to restore the industry's health, which has struggled to recover from pre-pandemic levels of moviegoers. The proposal, made by Cinema United president Michael O'Leary, seeks to prevent the undercutting of box office profits by shorter theatrical windows.

images.alt_text: A Working Man starring Jason Statham as a military veteran who comes out of retirement to seek the kidnappers of his boss’ daughter.
The Bugis+ branch of Filmgarde Cineplexes closed in 2022 along with its Century Square outlet.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover ground as markets brace for US tariff deadline
summary: European shares recovered 1.07% on Tuesday, closing at 539.64 points, after a two-month low the previous day. The market is bracing for a US tariff deadline on April 2, with reports suggesting 20% tariffs on most US imports. Despite this, most regional bourses rose over 1% as bank and technology stocks led gains. Goldman Sachs cut its 12-month forecast for the European benchmark index to 570 points due to US tariffs. The European Central Bank is expected to consider rate cuts in the near future.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped less than 0.1 per cent to 41,989.96 while the broad-based S&P 500 shook off a recent slump to close up 0.4 per cent at 5,633.07 on Tuesday.

site_title: Should investors hang tight, sell or build defences?
summary: US investors are facing market volatility due to concerns over tariffs, prompting questions of whether to hold on, sell, or build defensive barriers. Building defensive barriers, such as hedging with warrants and ETFs, can provide a shield against market decline. Investors can also consider exposure to commodities like gold and silver, which traditionally provide protection in turbulent times. The article suggests using trade band analysis to predict price levels and recommends considering a weaker US dollar, which can be bullish for gold and silver.

images.alt_text: Gold’s role as a safe-haven asset is unique, and we believe that gold prices are supported at current levels.
Spot gold held steady at US$3,125.34 an ounce, as of 0023 GMT, after hitting an all-time high of US$3,128.06 in the previous session.

site_title: SIA, SBS Transit, PSA among 19 key transport entities to face greater controls under new law
summary: The Transport Sector (Critical Firms) Act has come into force, giving the government greater control over 19 key transport entities in Singapore, including SBS Transit, Singapore Airlines, and PSA. The law aims to prevent adverse influences and major interruptions in essential transport services. The list of designated entities was published in the government gazette on April 1, marking the start of increased regulatory scrutiny for these transport companies. The move is expected to improve the reliability and resilience of Singapore's transport system.

site_title: MTI announces board appointments for agencies, including DBS CEO Tan Su Shan for EDB
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has announced board appointments across five statutory boards, including DBS CEO Tan Su Shan for the Economic Development Board (EDB), effective April 1. Tan joins Micron Technology's Manish Bhatia and reappointed members. New appointments include Khoo Boo Hor, Cindy Lim, and Paul Santos at Enterprise Singapore; Prof Lock Kai Sang and Premod Thomas at Energy Market Authority; Saiful Saroni at JTC Corporation; and four new faces at Sentosa Development Corporation. A total of 11 board members will step down upon completing their terms.

images.alt_text: DBS' AGM on Mar 28– which was attended by more than 1,500 shareholders – marked the leadership transition of South-east Asia’s largest lender.

site_title: The predicament of economic warfare: Do sanctions work?
summary: The US has struggled to effectively use economic warfare as a tool in its geopolitical power struggles, particularly against Russia and China. Unlike Iran, which has been more vulnerable to sanctions, Russia has proven to be a tougher adversary. According to Edward Fishman's book "Chokepoints", a statement from the US government can be enough to cripple a nation's economy, rather than traditional blockades and sieges. This shift in economic warfare highlights the increasingly fragmented global economy and the US's reliance on its pre-eminence in finance and technology to achieve its objectives.

images.alt_text: So, what is globalisation's future? Long-distance interdependencies will remain a fact of life as long as humans are mobile and equipped with communication and transportation technologies.
The timing of Biden's latest oil sanctions on Russia shows the depth of rage at the way the Ukraine war has gone so far.

site_title: US dollar struggles for direction before Trump’s reciprocal tariffs, awaits data
summary: The US dollar remained relatively unchanged on Tuesday as investors await US President Donald Trump's announcement of reciprocal tariffs. The dollar index rose 0.03% to 104.19, with markets closely monitoring the US Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) and ISM manufacturing index for further insights into the impact of uncertainty in US trade policy. Trump announced new tariffs on all countries this week, although no specific details were provided.

images.alt_text: The yen strengthened to 148.7 per US dollar at one point on Monday, and was last 0.37 per cent stronger at 149.280.

site_title: Trump administration begins mass layoffs at health agencies
summary: The Trump administration has begun implementing a plan to cut 10,000 jobs at the US Department of Health and Human Services, with the first layoffs occurring at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration. Fired staff were required to present their badges and return home. This move is part of a broader plan to shrink staffing levels in federal departments and agencies, as announced by President Donald Trump and billionaire ally Elon Musk. The layoffs are expected to affect various health agencies, including the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration.

site_title: Shell completes Singapore refinery sale to Chandra Asri-Glencore joint venture
summary: Shell has completed the sale of its Singapore refinery and refining assets to a Chandra Asri-Glencore joint venture, Aster Chemicals and Energy. The deal marks the end of Shell's 1961 operations at the Bukom and Jurong islands facility. The new owners have started purchasing feedstock, with Chandra Asri making several open-spec naphtha purchases. Financial terms of the deal remain undisclosed, but staff from the site will remain with the new venture.

Shell has been buying back US$3.5 billion of shares a quarter and increasing its dividend by 4 per cent annually, reaching 34.4 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 2024.

site_title: Coinbase sees worst quarter since FTX fell as crypto slides
summary: Coinbase's stock fell 31% in the worst quarterly performance since FTX's collapse in 2022, amid growing concerns about the US economy and a global trade war. Nearly every major crypto-linked stock plummeted alongside Coinbase, with Bitcoin tumbling over 10% and Ether losing 45% of its value. Experts attribute the decline to macro reasons, including tariffs and potential trade war, rather than fundamental reasons. The industry is experiencing a risk rally, with investors fleeing risky bets, including digital assets.

Ether is the native token of the Ethereum blockchain, which underpins some of the most commercially significant decentralised finance tools in the digital assets industry.

site_title: Is diversification in equity indexes a myth?
summary: Global equity markets have become increasingly reliant on a small handful of stocks, mainly in the tech sector, with the Magnificent Seven stocks (Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Alphabet, Amazon, Meta, and Tesla) accounting for 45% of the MSCI ACWI's return in 2024. As these stocks' dominance is unlikely to last, the market is likely to rebalance, potentially benefiting actively managed portfolios over index-tracking investors. Analysis shows that the MSCI ACWI has a lower effective number of constituents and higher concentration of weightings than a thematic equity strategy, suggesting the latter is more diversified.

site_title: UOB trims interest rate on flagship One Account, joins OCBC in 360 Account cut
summary: UOB is cutting interest rates on its flagship One Account to 3.3% per annum from May 1, following similar moves by OCBC. This is the second year in a row UOB has cut rates on the account, which previously offered up to 5% per annum. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts in 2024 are expected to influence other banks, with markets anticipating further rate cuts later this year.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell says that the Fed will hold interest rates steady for now.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore does not allow fund managers to operate as banks.
The respective bank managements also shared mixed sentiments on their 2025 outlook.

site_title: Tesla sales drop to lowest since 2022 amid Musk backlash
summary: Tesla's vehicle sales dropped 13% to 336,681 units in the first quarter, the company's worst showing since 2022. This decline is attributed to disruptions in the business, including the transition to the redesigned Model Y and Elon Musk's involvement in global politics. Analysts had expected the company to sell more than 390,000 vehicles. The sales figures reflect the challenges faced by Tesla in the first quarter, amid a tumultuous period for the company.

images.alt_text: Protestors in front of a Tesla showroom in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, March 22, 2025.
A demonstrator holds an anti-Tesla poster during a protest encouraging people to boycott Tesla, outside the Tesla Centre Park Royal in London, Britain, March 15, 2025.
Elon Musk Musk launched into a familiar pitch that Teslas will soon be capable of driving autonomously, but execution still lags.

The recall covers just over 46,000 vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27 of this year, Tesla said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and is the eighth recall for the SUV since January 2024.

site_title: Factories around the world brace for Trump tariffs
summary: Factories worldwide, including Japan and Britain, saw activity slump in March due to anticipation of new US tariffs, according to global surveys. China, however, showed signs of recovery as factories rushed to deliver goods before the tariffs took effect. US President Donald Trump is set to announce a tariff proposal on "Liberation Day" on April 2, sparking concerns over its impact on the global economy, which is still recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: epa12002083 US President Donald Trump speaks during an executive order signing in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 31 March 2025. The order directs the Federal Trade Commission to work with the Department of Justice to ensure that competition laws are enforced in the concert and entertainment industry, and pushes state consumer protection authorities on enforcement.  EPA-EFE/ALEXANDER DRAGO / POOL

site_title: UOB to take legal action against former Yang Kee Logistics CEO, The Online Citizen over ‘defamatory’ remarks
summary: UOB will take legal action against former Yang Kee Logistics CEO Ken Koh and The Online Citizen editor Xu Yuanchen for "defamatory" remarks. The bank claims Koh failed to retract and apologize for baseless allegations about UOB's handling of Yang Kee Logistics' properties and confidential information. UOB had previously issued a warning letter to Koh and informed the Monetary Authority of Singapore of the issues. The bank will pursue "appropriate legal action" against both Koh and The Online Citizen.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
In an article published by The Online Citizen, former chief executive officer of Yang Kee Logistics Ken Koh (pictured) alleged that UOB had acted against its interest.

site_title: Global populists rally to France’s Le Pen
summary: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen has been barred from running for president in 2027 after being found guilty of embezzling EU funds and sentenced to five years in disqualification from public office. This ruling could destabilize French politics, potentially leading the National Rally party to target Prime Minister Francois Bayrou's government. Le Pen's party may try to capitalize on her martyrdom, undermining French stability and the EU's second-largest economy. The ruling may also impact the country's already tumultuous politics, having seen four prime ministers in 2024.

images.alt_text: President of the far-right Rassemblement National (RN) parliamentary group Marine Le Pen was convicted over a scheme to take advantage of European Parliament expenses to employ assistants who were actually working for her far-right party in France.
One way that Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni can have an outsized international impact is by encouraging a new generation of other far-right populist leaders in Europe and beyond.
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: US: Stocks close mixed before Trump tariff announcement
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Tuesday ahead of President Donald Trump's tariff announcement, dubbed "liberation day." The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped less than 0.1% to 41,989.96, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 5,633.07. The announcement, set for Wednesday at 4 pm local time, has left traders guessing, as Trump has not unveiled the details of his plan.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 154.65 points, or 0.37 per cent, to 41,845.98.

site_title: China ready to buy more goods from India as US tariffs loom
summary: China is willing to increase its purchases of Indian goods to balance trade, following US President Donald Trump's announcement of reciprocal tariffs on Wednesday. China's main exports to India include petroleum oil, iron ore, marine products, and vegetable oil, worth US$16.6 billion in 2023-2024. This move comes as bilateral trade between China and India stands at US$101.7 billion, with India running a significant deficit. China aims to strengthen practical cooperation in trade and import more Indian products suitable for the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: The gain followed a 11 per cent rise in December and a 3.3 per cent decline for the whole of 2024, according to National Bureau of Statistics data.
Banks typically remove bad debt from their balance sheets by writing them off or selling them to bad asset managers.

site_title: The number of top-ranked restaurants in France is inching up
summary: The Michelin guide has announced its 2025 restaurant rankings for France, with 31 three-star dining rooms, up from 30 last year. New three-star spots include Christopher Coutanceau's eponymous restaurant in La Rochelle and Le Coquillage in Brittany, headed by chef Hugo Roellinger. Nine new two-star restaurants and 57 new one-star restaurants were also added to the list, while 23 restaurants were downgraded, including Georges Blanc's establishment, which lost its three-star status. The ceremony was held in Metz, eastern France, and comes as the French economy slows and tourism industry faces pressure to generate revenue.

site_title: With Kid Rock at his side, Trump signs executive order targeting ticket scalping
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday (Mar 31) targeting ticket scalping in the live entertainment industry. The order, signed with Kid Rock, aims to protect fans from "exploitative" ticket practices, particularly bot sales, and directs Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Attorney General Pam Bondi to ensure compliance with tax laws. The move follows lawsuits against Live Nation Entertainment and Ticketmaster for allegedly monopolizing markets and hurting artists and fans. Experts say Ticketmaster commands over 70% market share of primary ticket services.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's order establishes an office within the Department of Commerce called the United States Investment Accelerator, which will encourage companies to make large investments.

site_title: Why China can’t sort out its property market mess
summary: China's property market has been in a downward spiral for five years, with real estate values plummeting and households in financial distress selling properties. Government-linked developer Vanke reported a record $6.8 billion annual loss in 2024, its first full-year loss since its IPO in 1991. The crisis was fueled by debt, speculation, and unaffordable housing, prompting the government to impose measures to reduce the risk of a bubble and temper inequality. Despite recent efforts to boost the market, property prices continue to fall, and the country's residential mortgage delinquency ratio has jumped to its highest in four years.

images.alt_text: State-backed Vanke reported a record 49.5 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) loss last year, its first full-year loss since 1991.
A view of Balboa Port after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison Holdings agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from the US.

site_title: Alibaba preparing for flagship AI model release as soon as April
summary: Alibaba is set to release its upgraded Qwen 3 AI model, possibly in April, as the company competes with rivals OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic. Following DeepSeek's low-cost AI model, Chinese tech leaders have flooded the market with affordable AI services, threatening to undercut premium US offerings. This move comes after OpenAI plans to release an "open" model that mimics human reasoning in the coming months, shifting its strategy in response to the rapid AI development in Asia.

site_title: Australia’s central bank holds rates as it frets over trade war risk
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held its cash rate steady at 4.1% in a decision driven by concerns over the risk of a global trade war. Policymakers emphasized the need to control core inflation before acting again, despite data showing tepid consumer demand. The RBA omitted a reference to upside risks to inflation and took a slightly dovish tone, sparking speculation of a potential rate cut in May. The decision was seen as a cautious response to global uncertainties, including US tariffs and a potential recession, and is expected to have limited impact on the upcoming Australian general election.

images.alt_text: The pursuit of the “Great Australian Dream” of home ownership is hurting families saddled with high mortgage payments, as Australia’s Reserve Bank had raised interest rates 13 times since 2022 before last month’s rate cut.
The Albanese-led Labor government has been announcing a slew of measures aimed at pleasing families and businesses grappling with high costs as it seeks to win a second term.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 1, 2025
summary: Asian markets edged back but were dampened by concerns over US President Trump's tariff plans, which sparked inflation worries. Gold prices remained steady near an all-time high, while oil prices climbed 2% to a five-week high due to supply chain concerns in Russia and Iran. Meanwhile, Australia's central bank held interest rates, and UOB and OCBC cut rates on their flagship accounts.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks, which has borne the brunt of the pain owing to hefty selling of car giants including Toyota and Honda, edged up along with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei shares.
Spot gold held steady at US$3,125.34 an ounce, as of 0023 GMT, after hitting an all-time high of US$3,128.06 in the previous session.
OCBC and UOB have announced cuts in interest rates on their flagship savings accounts in 2025.

site_title: Temasek-backed 65 Equity Partners, Inflexion to make minority investment in Kee Safety
summary: Global investment firm 65 Equity Partners and London-based private equity firm Inflexion are jointly investing in safety equipment provider Kee Safety. Both firms will have equal minority shareholdings alongside Kee Safety's management team. The investment could value Kee Safety at around £1.3 billion (S$2.3 billion) and is subject to regulatory and tax clearances. Kee Safety, which specializes in safety systems, has acquired 54 businesses and will continue to receive support from Intermediate Capital Group as a lender and minority shareholder.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Tan Chong Lee, chief executive of 65 Equity Partners, said: "Our goal is not to just focus on domestic businesses, but to open up the funnel."
From left: Adrienne Teh, managing director; Francis Woo, chief corporate officer and managing director (Singapore); chief executive Tan Chong Lee; and investment principal Timothy Wee.

site_title: Tech billionaires mired in their reality-distortion fields
summary: Tech billionaires, particularly Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, have become trapped in their own reality-distortion fields, warping their perception of the world. A new memoir by former Meta executive Sarah Wynn-Williams reveals the company's hypocrisy and Zuckerberg's fixation on developing a fanbase. Wynn-Williams' book highlights the need for limits to tech leadership tenures, as Zuckerberg has led Meta for over 20 years. The company's concentration of power has led to questionable decisions, such as expanding into China despite concerns about human rights. Experts call for term limits on tech CEOs to prevent reality distortion and ensure proportional oversight.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla CEO Elon Musk looks on next to U.S. President Donald Trump talking to the media, at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 11, 2025. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo
Any expectations that the start of Trump’s new term would continue to fuel market returns have been upended.

site_title: Stakes high for Switch 2 after Nintendo’s stock valuation surges
summary: Nintendo's shares have surged 25% in the past 12 months, surpassing Japan's Topix benchmark and briefly reaching a market capitalization of over $100 billion. The company's upcoming Switch 2 console unveil is highly anticipated, with investors expecting details on compatibility with third-party games and a potential price tag. Analysts predict the console's release could boost demand, but also warn of potential disappointment and profit-taking, given the stock's high valuation and recent hype.

images.alt_text: Attendees play Nintendo Co's Pokemon Go augmented-reality game, developed by Niantic Inc., on their smartphones during a Pikachu Outbreak event, organised by Pokemon Co., in Yokohama, Japan, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2017. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Japanese video game company Nintendo is displayed at the Nintendo Tokyo store, Japan Nov. 19, 2019. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Players have long been hungry for news on a follow-up to Nintendo’s hybrid Switch console, which can be handheld or connected to a TV screen.

site_title: Thailand says collapsed Bangkok Tower used substandard steel
summary: Thailand's investigation into the collapsed Bangkok Tower has found substandard steel bars made by a factory that was shut down since December due to safety concerns. The steel, produced by Xin Ke Yuan Steel, failed tests for mass, chemical composition, and stress resistance before breaking. The factory, which was closed after a gas tank leakage accident, had been seized by authorities and had over 2,400 tons of steel. The discovery has sparked a probe into the building's construction and the use of Thai nominees as proxy shareholders by the Chinese company involved.

images.alt_text: The building has drawn attention for being the sole building in the metropolis to entirely collapse.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, YZJ Financial, KIT, Boustead, Cordlife
summary: Yangzijiang Financial is divesting its entire treasury shareholding of 193.5 million shares at S$0.72 apiece. Keppel has divested its 42% stake in South Rach Chiec, generating S$55 million in profit. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit (Clar) has completed the redevelopment of 1 Science Park Drive, boosting its business space and life science portfolio.

site_title: OUE Healthcare says Mandalay hospital building in which it has a stake damaged by earthquake
summary: OUE Healthcare announced that its 40% stake in the Mandalay hospital in Myanmar's Pun Hlaing Hospitals was damaged by the massive earthquake on March 28. The hospital has suspended operations, with no reported casualties. The group will conduct further assessments to determine the full extent of the damage. The earthquake, with a 7.7 magnitude and 6.7 aftershock, has devastated infrastructure and caused thousands of casualties in Myanmar and neighboring countries.

site_title: Boeing slows output of 737 Max jets to 31 a month due to wing systems issues
summary: Boeing has slowed production of 737 Max jets to 31 per month due to delays in wing systems installation, a setback from a production rate of 38 planes in February. The issue persists, forcing Boeing to further slow earlier parts of its wing production to catch up. The US planemaker aims to grow production to 38 a month this year, after curbing output in 2024 following quality concerns.

site_title: Drilling down into quality of earnings and why it matters
summary: Quality of earnings analysis is crucial in evaluating a company's true financial stability, particularly in mergers and acquisitions, private equity, and strategic planning. Research shows that auditors failed to identify material uncertainties related to going-concern risks in three-quarters of significant corporate failures in the UK from 2010 to 2022. Quality of earnings analysis, which adjusts for non-recurring items, normalizes revenue streams, and establishes a reliable baseline for projections and valuations, helps surface red flags, validate financial performance, and provide a more reliable foundation for investment decisions.

site_title: US judge rejects J&J’s US$10 billion baby powder settlement
summary: A US bankruptcy judge rejected Johnson & Johnson's $10 billion proposal to settle lawsuits alleging its baby powder causes ovarian cancer. The proposal was the third attempt by the company to resolve the lawsuits through bankruptcy. Judge Christopher Lopez ruled that J&J did not belong in bankruptcy, stating that the company should instead work towards a settlement. The decision allows the lawsuits to continue, with the judge expressing hope for a resolution that benefits all parties involved.

site_title: Global deal activity disappoints, M&A revenue falls as Trump pursues tariffs
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions revenue fell 25% to $7,629 billion in the first quarter, with US deals declining 13% to $436.56 billion. Despite a surge in Asia-Pacific deals, driven by state-run acquisitions in China and a ports deal involving Trump, bankers predict a three-year slowdown in deals due to ongoing market uncertainty and a prolonged trade war. IPO activity increased, but some recent deals have failed to impress, and analysts warn of a brain drain among companies considering going public. Investment banking fees fell 4.9% to $21.47 billion, and some banks are positioning for job cuts.

site_title: UltraGreen.ai is said to mull up to S$400 million IPO in Singapore
summary: UltraGreen.ai, a Singapore-based provider of fluorescence technology for medical and surgical imaging, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) to raise up to S$400 million. The company is working with financial advisers to plan an offering that could take place in Singapore as early as this year. This would be one of the largest IPOs in Singapore in 2024, which saw a total of US$34.4 million raised from four listings.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit completes S$883 million redevelopment of Science Park project
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit has completed a S$883 million redevelopment of the 180,600 square meter Geneo cluster in Singapore Science Park, with all five buildings now operationally ready. The redeveloped property offers premium business space, wet-lab ready workspace, and retail and food and beverage amenities, and has achieved green credentials including the Green Mark Platinum rating. Around 76% of its net lettable area has been committed, with advanced negotiations for another 19%.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Geneo comprises three properties at 1,5 and 7 Science Park Drive and will offer about 180,600 square metres (sq m) of gross floor area (GFA) upon its completion in 2025.

site_title: Hooters files for bankruptcy as brand eyes turnaround plan
summary: Hooters of America has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, listing assets of $50 million to $100 million and liabilities in the same range. The casual-dining chain struggles due to high labor costs, competition from cheaper fast-food chains, and declining restaurant traffic. To turn things around, Hooters' founders plan to make the chain more family-friendly. The company seeks $40 million in debtor-in-possession financing to support operations during the restructuring process, which is expected to last until August.

images.alt_text: Hooters operator's shares soar as it joins the Beyond Meat universe

site_title: Insurers brush off impact of higher MediShield Life premiums, claim limits on Integrated Shield Plan
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life will see increased claim limits and expanded coverage starting April, with premiums rising up to 35% over three years. Insurance companies, including Great Eastern and Singlife, have made provisions for the changes and expect minimal impact on their businesses. Industry players attribute the increases to rising medical costs and consumption, citing the need for a "more mindful approach to healthcare consumption" to manage long-term costs. Despite concerns, insurers emphasize their commitment to ensuring policyholders' coverage remains unchanged and affordable.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
In the wider Asia-Pacific region, insurers are expecting medical costs will increase by 12.3 per cent next year, up from 11.9 per cent in 2024
The average cost of medical care in Singapore is expected to rise by close to 10.7 per cent in 2024, up from 10.3 per cent in 2023, data from advisory and solutions company WTW showed.
The insurer's total weighted new sales in Q4 fell 16% to S$432.7 million from S$514.1 million.
Starting in April, some MediShield Life rules will be changing, and that will also affect Integrated Shield Plans.

site_title: GlobalFoundries, Taiwanese chipmaker UMC consider merger: sources
summary: Taiwanese chipmaker UMC and US-based GlobalFoundries are considering a merger, sources say. A combined company would establish a larger US-based firm with a global manufacturing footprint spanning Asia, the US, and Europe. The potential deal comes as the US seeks to strengthen its semiconductor supply chain amid rising tensions in the Taiwan Strait and competition from China. The move could help the US reduce its dependence on Taiwan and China for chip supplies, addressing concerns over national security and supply chain resilience.

site_title: Vietnam slashes duties on range of imports to head off US tariffs
summary: Vietnam has slashed duties on a range of imports, including cars, liquefied gas, and agricultural products, in an effort to head off US tariffs. The move comes after Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh said the country was reviewing levies to encourage increased imports from the US, which has the third-highest trade deficit with Vietnam. The changes, effective March 31, 2025, aim to soften the blow of potential tariffs and maintain good relations with the US.

site_title: European private equity company Inflexion opens Singapore office
summary: Inflexion, a London-based private equity company, has opened an office in Singapore, appointing Shane Gong as managing director for investor relations focusing on the Asia-Pacific region. The move aims to deepen investor coverage in the region, following Collar Capital's expansion to Singapore earlier this year. The office will focus on mid-market transactions, typically involving companies with annual earnings of $5 million to $100 million. This strategic milestone is expected to provide Inflexion with increased access to institutional and private wealth investors in South-east Asia.

site_title: Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway mandates banks for yen bond deal
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is planning to sell yen bonds in global markets, following the company's plans to increase ownership in Japan's five main trading houses. The deal, potentially led by BofA Securities and Mizuho Securities, comes after Buffett's annual letter to shareholders in February signaled a plan to boost holdings in the sector. The move may occur in the near future, subject to market conditions, and is seen as a result of Berkshire's efforts to relax its stake ceiling, originally set below 10%.

site_title: China property pain worsens with sales slump, record Vanke loss
summary: China's property sector continues to decline, with state-backed Vanke reporting a record 49.5 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) loss in 2024, its first full-year loss since 1991. New home sales slid 11% in March, and the sector has been in decline for its fourth consecutive year. Weak domestic demand and a fragile job market are major contributors to the slump. The country's property market remains uncertain, with no clear sign of a floor for its decline.

site_title: Scores in hospital after huge fire at Petronas gas pipeline in Malaysia
summary: A huge fire broke out at a Petronas gas pipeline in Puchong, Malaysia, on April 1, 2025, causing widespread damage and forcing the evacuation of nearby residents. The blaze, which started with a towering orange flame and billowing smoke, was extinguished by mid-afternoon, but not before scores of people were treated in hospitals for burns, injuries, and respiratory problems. At least 305 people were affected, including 41 who were discharged, and 190 homes were damaged. Authorities say the cause of the fire is still unknown, but an investigation is underway.

summary: HDB resale prices rose 1.5% in Q1 2025, slower than the 2.6% in Q4 2024 and 2.3% average quarterly growth in 2024. Resale volume decreased 7.7% in tandem with slower market conditions. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will launch approximately 5,400 Build-To-Order flats in July. National Development Minister Desmond Lee noted early signs of moderation in price growth across both public and private housing markets.

The new Mount Pleasant housing estate will see 5,000 new homes across six Build-to-Order projects.
The Senior Housing Bonus scheme, which incentivises seniors to downsize to a smaller flat, will be extended to inlcude more private property owners.

site_title: Singapore's GLP closes first digital infrastructure fund at US$358 million in AUM
summary: Singapore-based GLP has successfully closed its first digital infrastructure fund, the GLP China IDC Income Fund I, with US$357.76 million in assets under management. The fund, backed by a consortium of domestic and international investors, will take over a data centre in the Greater Beijing region from another investment firm. The data centre is operational, environmentally sustainable, and fully rented to an e-commerce firm. The move comes as demand for data centres surges due to growing technology needs, with US government agencies projecting a 300% increase in demand within three years.

site_title: Vietnam’s big golf bet on Trump: Three swings, one strategy
summary: US President Donald Trump is investing in a $1.5 billion golf course and hotel project in Vietnam, part of the country's strategy to attract high-end property investors and golfers. Trump's golf ventures align with Vietnam's push to improve trade ties with Washington, despite a trade surplus of $123.5 billion in 2024. The move aims to smooth over trade tensions and draw affluent tourist golfers, with more than 80 golf courses already in operation in Vietnam. Trump's golf diplomacy is seen as a way to build rapport with Vietnamese leaders, but some observers worry it could blur the lines between personal interests and public policy.

images.alt_text: The Starlink pilot programme envisages cooperation with Vietnamese companies to distribute hardware equipment and deliver services to customers.

A man reads a Vietnamese newspaper with a front page story on the inauguration of US President Donald Trump. While Trump's earlier threats of tariffs are not off the negotiating table yet, pundits say Asean now has more leverage.
The golf course and resort business was the biggest driver of cash flow for the Trump Organization, the family business of US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.
US President Donald Trump waves after arriving at Noi Bai airport for the US-DPRK summit in Hanoi on February 26, 2019.
South-east Asian merchants scramble as TikTok ban in US looms, shifting focus back to Amazon, Etsy

site_title: Cordlife served two letters of demand from customers; any settlement likely to hit group’s finances
summary: Cordlife, a private cord-blood bank, received two letters of demand from customers claiming damages and breach of contract. The claims fall under two categories: those with unsuitable cord blood units for stem cell transplants and those with units in the "low risk" or "unaffected" band. If settled, the claims may result in a "negative impact on the financial position of the group" for the financial year ending Dec 31. Cordlife is seeking legal advice and reported a net loss of S$6.3 million in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
This is the first letter of demand received by the company from legal representatives of an affected client.

site_title: Ho Bee Land drops AVJennings bid; Australian property developer to be acquired by US fund
summary: Real estate group Ho Bee Land has dropped its non-binding indicative offer to acquire Australian property developer AVJennings for A$0.70 a share, following AVJennings' acceptance of a competing binding offer from US fund PM Nominees C. The revised offer price of A$0.655 per share represents a 98.5% premium above AVJennings' closing price prior to the announcement. AVJennings' board has decided to formally agree with the scheme, and the company will proceed with a scheme of arrangement to acquire all its shares.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Simon Cheong, chairman and CEO of SC Global, plans to launch a new concept.
Ho Bee Land's proposed transaction is not expected to have a material impact on its consolidated net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2025.

site_title: Believe Trump when he says he wants a third term
summary: President Donald Trump has expressed interest in running for a third term, stating that "a lot of people want me to do it" and that he's "not joking." Trump's comments come after his second term has already shown that democracy is fragile in the US, with the president using various methods to maintain power, including firing federal workers and using the Alien Enemies Act to deport immigrants. The 22nd Amendment limits a president to two terms, but Trump and his allies may attempt to circumvent this by exploiting loopholes or claiming that the Constitution doesn't apply.

images.alt_text: At 82 years and seven months old, Trump will already be the oldest president ever at the end of his second term in January 2029.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to buy 46.7% stake in subsea cable firm Global Marine for US$90.6 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) will acquire a 46.7% stake in subsea cable firm Global Marine Group (GMG) for US$90.6 million, with the deal expected to raise distribution per unit by 3.5% and increase net gearing by 3%. The acquisition will capitalize on Keppel's expertise in the connectivity space, following the development of the 20,000 km Bifrost Cable System. The deal is in line with KIT's strategy to tap growth opportunities in digital infrastructure driven by global digitalization efforts.

images.alt_text: Pictured is Cable Retriever, one of Global Marine Group's six vessels. The subsea cable solutions provider provides maintenance and installation services for the global subsea fibre optic cable network.

site_title: Keppel divests entire stake in Vietnam’s Palm City for 2.6 trillion dong
summary: Keppel, a global asset manager, has divested its entire 42% stake in South Rach Chiec City, the developer of Palm City in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, for 2.6 trillion dong (S$136.6 million). This results in a net divestment profit of about S$55 million for Keppel. The divestment unlocks assets valued at S$10 billion to S$12 billion, as part of Keppel's asset monetisation plan, and is expected to have no material impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Crystal Heng
Digitalisation and AI are megatrends that are here to stay, said Loh
Keppel has shown its ability to "do more with less", said Loh

site_title: Guide to help caregivers of autistic children has its pilot launch
summary: A pilot guide, "Life After Death," has been launched by Autism Network Singapore to support caregivers of autistic children in planning for their future. The guide, set to be fully online by 2025, provides a structured step-by-step approach to help caregivers focus on big-picture planning, covering topics such as financial arrangements, health matters, and housing issues. Developed in collaboration with parents, caregivers, and autism professionals, the guide aims to empower caregivers to make informed decisions and ensure their children on the autism spectrum can thrive after they are no longer around.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Outgoing chief executive of DBS Piyush Gupta says companies should take a longer-term approach to CSR.

site_title: Singapore private home prices flatten in Q1, inching up 0.6% after year-end jump
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.6% in Q1, a slower pace than the 2.3% increase in Q4 last year, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Sales volume fell 15% to 6,299 units, with non-landed properties increasing in price across the board. The government plans to release 5,030 private homes through its land sales program, aiming to maintain a strong supply and stabilize the market. Experts predict a slowdown in activity, with some forecasting a 3-4% increase in home prices for the year, down from 3.9% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
HDB resale prices rise at a slower 1.5% pace in Q1: flash data
Presently, landlords continue to prioritise building occupancies in a time of uncertainty that has been amplified by global tariffs.
Under the Planning Act, it is an offence to convert the use of a property for short-term accommodation without the approval of the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

site_title: Elon Musk vs the federal government
summary: Elon Musk, empowered by President Donald Trump, has been waging a largely unchecked war against federal bureaucrats, seeking to scale back or dismantle the federal government. Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (Doge) has made swift work of the billionaire's goal, shutting down diversity programs, shutting down agencies, and offering millions of civil servants an ultimatum to quit or face being fired. The efforts have sparked a resistance from federal worker unions, prompting lawsuits, protests, and the signing of thousands of new members, as the federal workforce faces a desperate fight to preserve their jobs and benefits.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Ellen Lipton Hollander of Maryland said Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency was intruding into “the personal affairs of millions of Americans” as part of its hunt for fraud and waste under President Donald Trump.

Union leaders and workers rally outside the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) headquarters in Washington, D.C., March 04, 2025. Workers gathered to protest recent cuts made to the department by Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).

Tech billionaire Elon Musk and his young aides at the cost-cutting Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) are in the midst of a radical downsizing of the federal bureaucracy at the behest of Trump, who views the government as bloated and corrupt.
Elon Musk’s downsizing initiative, executed by his so-called Department of government Efficiency (DOGE), has led to the layoff of more than 20,000 workers.

site_title: Several key executives exit SingPost amid restructuring retrenchment
summary: Several key executives at Singapore Post (SingPost) have exited the company amid restructuring and retrenchment efforts. The departures include Michelle Lee, chief sustainability officer, and four other executives: Lee Eng Keat, head of strategy and communications; Sehr Ahmed, group chief people officer; Noel Singgih, group chief information officer; and Audrey Teoh and Hendrik Liyuwardi, who also left their roles. The company announced the retrenchment of 45 employees in February, primarily in corporate support units.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

At the meeting,  SingPost also announced plans to invest S$30 million to install a new, fully automated e-commerce parcel sorting equipment at its regional e-commerce logistics hub in Tampines by mid-2026.
Group CEO Vincent Phang, group chief financial officer Vincent Yik and CEO of international business unit Yu Li  (left to right) were fired in December.
Singpost said that the restructuring is the result of prolonged macroeconomic challenges, such as intense competition.

site_title: YZJ Financial falls 10% on placement of treasury shares at S$0.72 each
summary: Shares of Yangzijiang Financial fell 10% after the company agreed to divest its entire treasury shareholding of 193.5 million shares at S$0.72 apiece. The net proceeds will be deployed towards the group's core maritime investments. The divestment was facilitated by two separate entities, Merlion Quay Capital and Operie Capital, each established by an investor and three senior executives of Yangzijiang Financial.

images.alt_text: In a bourse filing on Sunday (Mar 30), the financial arm of the shipbuilder said it on Friday agreed to divest its entire treasury shareholding of 193.5 million shares at S$0.72 per share.

site_title: China is days late in releasing trade data as US shipping slumps
summary: China has delayed releasing weekly trade data, marking the first time this year it has not been announced on Monday. The data typically shows China's ports processed 6.3 million standard 20-foot containers, a 10% increase from last year. The delay comes after the US imposed punitive tariffs on most Chinese exports, leading to a slump in shipping. The data is expected to be released on May 9, providing insight into China's trade with the US and other countries since the tariffs were announced.

images.alt_text: On the flip side, China’s own expansive efforts to attract foreign tourists with visa-free travel and relaxed entry for dozens of countries could pay off this year, too.
China's official purchasing managers’ index fell to 49.0 in April versus 50.5 in March, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction, and missing a median forecast of 49.8 in a Reuters poll.
China appeared to have resisted jumping into any trade negotiations with Trump.
High-technology focused manufacturers’ profit rose 3.5 per cent in the quarter, reversing a 5.8 per cent decline in the first two months of the year.
Beijing is signalling it is in no rush to be aggressive in expanding economic stimulus just a month after unveiling measures including a commitment to run a record-high budget deficit.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge back but Trump tariff fears dampen mood
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Tuesday, recouping losses from recent weeks, despite US President Donald Trump's threat to impose sweeping tariffs. Tokyo stocks, which were hit hard by heavy selling of car giants, edged up along with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, and Taipei shares. Gold prices hit a record high amid the uncertainty. Investors are bracing for Trump's "Liberation Day" announcement on Wednesday, which may impact global markets and stoke recession fears.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past an electronic board showing the Nikkei 225 index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange along a street in central Tokyo on March 28, 2025. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: China still backs overseas coal plants despite 2021 pledge, research shows
summary: China is still backing overseas coal plants, despite a 2021 pledge to stop financing coal projects, according to a US think tank. China is involved in constructing 7.7 gigawatts of new coal-fired power, mostly for nickel smelters in Indonesia. This contradicts President Xi Jinping's 2021 promise to stop financing overseas coal projects. The move has raised concerns about China's commitment to reducing climate-warming carbon dioxide emissions and its influence on other Brics countries.

images.alt_text: “This is a time for Asia to boost domestic demand, pursue sound economic policies and diversify industries and trade partners,” Masato Kanda says.
Wang Yi’s call to the international community underscores China’s attempt to portray itself as the bastion of free trade as US tariffs threaten to reshape commerce globally.
CICC aims to participate in the energy transition and infrastructure construction drive in the Gulf region by providing structured financing and services, according to Wang

site_title: Japan’s businesses signal resilience as BOJ mulls pace of hikes
summary: Japan's large manufacturers showed resilience with an index of sentiment edging lower to 12 in March, matching consensus estimates. The service sector index beat expectations, reaching its highest since 1991. The outlook for manufacturers weakened less than expected, marking a 17th consecutive quarter with a positive outlook. The data suggests the Bank of Japan should maintain a gradual pace of interest rate hikes despite global trade uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Japan's The jobs-to-applicants ratio also dipped to 1.24 in February from 1.26 in January.

Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba speaks during a press conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo on October 9, 2024. The Nikkei fell 4.05 per cent to 35,617.56, its lowest close since August 6, the day after the index posted its biggest single-day rout since the 1987 Black Monday crash.

site_title: Xi showdown with Li Ka-shing threatens China’s pro-business push
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is facing a showdown with billionaire Li Ka-shing over a $22.8 billion deal to sell 43 ports worldwide, including two in the Panama Canal. China's market regulator has launched a review of the deal, citing a need to "protect public interests." The move is seen as a test of Xi's pro-business push, and a potential bargaining chip with the US is at stake. The US had framed the deal as a way to "reclaim" the Panama Canal, fueling concerns that China is trying to expand its influence in the region.

images.alt_text: CK Hutchison Holdings might be debt-free once the controversial US$19 billion sale of most of its ports to a BlackRock-led consortium concludes.

The Panama deal is not the first time Li’s business dealings have drawn Beijing’s ire.
Cargo vessels docked at Balboa Port, operated by Panama Ports Company, at the Panama Canal, in Panama City, Panama, Feb 1, 2025.

site_title: Gold steady near all-time high as Trump’s tariff plans stir inflation woes
summary: US gold prices held steady near an all-time high at $3,125.34 an ounce, following a record high of $3,128.06 the previous session. Investors remain concerned about US President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs on all nations, which may fuel inflationary pressures and impede economic growth, impacting gold prices.

images.alt_text: The yen strengthened to 148.7 per US dollar at one point on Monday, and was last 0.37 per cent stronger at 149.280.
Gold prices have surged to record highs, eclipsing the US$3,000 per ounce mark for the first time in history.

site_title: Japan denies report citing Bessent’s push for strong yen
summary: Japan's vice-finance minister, Atsushi Mimura, denied a media report that US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told him that a weak US dollar and a strong yen are desirable during their meeting in Washington. The report sparked market expectations of pressure on Japan to strengthen the yen's value against the US dollar. Bessent said he had "very constructive talks" with Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato, but declined to comment on specific requests made to Japan. The denial follows US President Donald Trump's past remarks accusing Japan of maintaining a weak yen.

images.alt_text: The yen broke through resistance to appreciate as much as 0.7 per cent to 139.90 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore’s Q1 employment growth slows, unemployment edges up, with further softening ahead
summary: Singapore's Q1 employment growth slowed to 2,300, down from 7,700 in the previous quarter and 3,200 in the year-ago quarter. Unemployment rose slightly to 2.9% for residents and 3.1% for citizens. Despite fewer retrenchments, the Ministry of Manpower expects the labour market to soften due to external growth uncertainties, with economists predicting further softening and potential shrinkage in employment.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
Generic photos for Budget 2024
Singapore’s retrenchments grow in Q4, but job vacancies also rise.
Business reorganisation or restructuring continued to be the primary reason for lay-offs in 2024.

site_title: A home that’s lean and green
summary: Singaporean architect Lim Cheng Kooi's latest project, The Long House, is a semi-detached home that maximizes space on a long and narrow plot. The architecture amplifies the linearity of the site through strategically placed courtyards and cut-outs, creating layered internal vistas and integrating soft landscapes. The home features a rooftop pool, private screens for the facade, and 'floating' staircase, while each bathroom has a view of a small garden. The design prioritizes natural light, privacy, and seamless interaction among family members, with multiple spaces for relaxation, entertainment, and quality time.

images.alt_text: Future Impact 3: Design Nation at Milan Design Week.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed on Monday as investors eye trade talks
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Monday as investors assessed the impact of US trade tariffs and China's plans to boost consumption. Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and other Asian cities rose, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore edged down. Investors remain cautious despite a positive US market, awaiting key economic data and central bank decisions. China's top leaders discussed plans to stimulate growth, while the US and South Korea are set to hold trade talks, with a possible "understanding" to be reached this week.

images.alt_text: A group of investors recently urged a review of Australia’s listing rules, arguing it’s unfair that companies can issue shares for acquisitions without shareholder approval.
ST Engineering has secured new contracts valued at around S$4.4 billion in Q1 of 2025

site_title: Japan’s February jobless rate falls to 2.4%, job availability shrinks
summary: Japan's jobless rate fell to 2.4% in February, down from 2.5% in January, according to government data. The jobs-to-applicants ratio also decreased to 1.24 from 1.26 in January. This marks a slight improvement in the labor market, contrary to economists' median forecast of a 2.5% jobless rate.

site_title: Match Group seeks to woo more singles in Asia to swipe right on its apps
summary: Match Group, the parent company of Tinder and Hinge, is seeking to expand its presence in Asia, where the penetration rate for dating apps is 7% compared to Western markets. The company aims to target high-intent users, those seeking long-term relationships, and has seen promising results with its Japan-based app Pairs, which allows users to reflect on their profile and connect on deeper levels. Match Group plans to expand Pairs to India and focus on growing its user base in Europe, the US, and the Middle East. The company also owns the video chat app Azar, which has seen positive growth in the Middle East and Europe since its acquisition in 2021.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Entertainment company Unfiltered Presents ventured into the social events space last August with a new concept called Never Strangers.
Tinder contributed nearly US$1.7 billion to Match's total revenue of US$3 billion in 2021
Violet Lim, co-founder and CEO of Lunch Actually, and Alex Tam, CEO of Paktor Group. The two dating agencies have merged to form Lunch Actually Paktor Group.
Match Group offers dating app services including Tinder, Hinge, OkCupid and Plenty of Fish.

site_title: China ramps up cash injection as it braces for tariff impact
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is injecting 600 billion yuan (S$108 billion) of one-year medium-term lending (MLF) facility to maintain liquidity and safeguard the economy from US tariffs, which have reached as high as 145%. This is the largest MLF injection since December 2023. The move is seen as a signal of supportive monetary policy and aims to smooth over increased demand for cash during holidays in early May and support special government bond issuances.

images.alt_text: There are “no winners in trade wars” and China will remain open to the outside world and firmly support free trade and the multilateral trading system,  People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor Pan Gongsheng said.
The latest round of issuance comes as Beijing looks to ramp up spending to defend the economy from the onslaught of 145 per cent US tariffs on Chinese goods.
A string of global investment banks have lowered their projections for China’s economic growth this year and expected more monetary easing measures to underpin the economy.
The PBOC has been pushing for lower borrowing costs for businesses and households.

site_title: Vietnam’s VinFast to open India factory on Jun 30, Indonesia plant in October
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast is shifting its strategy to focus on Asian markets, bypassing North America and Europe due to high logistic fees. The company plans to open its India manufacturing plant on June 30 and an Indonesia plant in October, following a delayed opening of a factory in North Carolina to 2028. VinFast expects to deliver over 200,000 vehicles in Vietnam this year and is close to reaching a break-even point in the market by 2025, with its billionaire founder committing to invest US$2 billion in the company through 2026.

images.alt_text: Startup VinFast is pursuing an aggressive but costly expansion strategy in Vietnam, where it can rely on a growing market of nearly 100 million people.
The new VinFast VF 6 at India's auto show in New Delhi; the company not disclose pricing for the VF6 and VF7 cars that it plans to launch in India.
The automaker delivered 44,773 cars during the first nine months of this year, just over 55 per cent of its target of 80,000 units for the year.
VinFast has been bleeding cash since it shipped its first vehicles to the US in late 2022.

site_title: Starmer’s energy summit gig bumps up UK’s post-Brexit profile
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer's hosting of the International Energy Agency (IEA) conference on energy security highlights the UK's growing post-Brexit profile, particularly in its commitment to clean energy. The conference, which includes executives from major firms like Shell and Eni, aims to build a consensus on a holistic approach to energy security. The UK government's vision of becoming a "clean energy superpower" by 2030 is expected to be discussed, with a focus on accelerating clean electricity and phasing out fossil fuels. However, the US's stance on energy security, led by the Trump administration, may pose a challenge to this vision, with the US favoring energy dominance through fossil fuel production and exports.

images.alt_text: The IEA, which advises major economies, reduced projections for growth in world oil consumption this year by roughly 100,000 barrels a day to about one million a day.

site_title: Fireworks at CDL AGM, but shareholders vote strongly in favour of all resolutions
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) held its annual general meeting (AGM) on April 23, where all resolutions were passed with high support levels. The re-election of numerous independent directors, including Jennifer Young and Wong Su Yen, was approved by 99.43% and 99.33% of shareholders, respectively. The resolutions for the re-election of three retiring independent directors also received strong support. The company also renewed its share purchase mandate and IPT mandate, with 99.9% and 97.93% support, respectively. Despite lingering tensions, the boardroom tussle involving executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his son Sherman Kwek appears to have been set aside for the company's greater good.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Sector-specific headwinds have also affected others, CDL says.

CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) said he has filed court papers to deal with the attempted coup by Sherman Kwek, Philip Lee, Wong Ai Ai and a group of directors acting with them to allegedly consolidate control of the board and the group.

site_title: CDL unit raises offer for M&C New Zealand to NZ$2.80 a share
summary: City Developments Ltd's (CDL) New Zealand subsidiary has raised its offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand (MCK) shares to NZ$2.80 apiece, a 60% premium to the one-month volume weighted average share price of NZ$1.75. The offer is now unconditional and will expire on May 8. CDL had previously offered NZ$2.25 per share, but MCK rejected it due to a perceived undervaluation. The new offer represents the highest share price in five years and reflects a significant increase from the initial offer.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
The privatisation deal is not expected to materially affect CDL's net tangible assets or consolidated earnings per share for the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2025.

site_title: Intel delivers disappointing forecast, moves to slash jobs
summary: Intel delivers a disappointing forecast, citing concerns over declining consumer spending and investment in data centre infrastructure. The company plans to slash jobs, with a new round of cuts expected to bring its workforce in line with competitors. Second-quarter revenue is forecast between $11.2 billion and $12.4 billion, below analyst estimates. Intel's shares dropped 6% in late trading. The company aims to reduce operating costs to $17 billion this year and $16 billion in 2026. CEO Tan Lip-Bu plans to revamp the company's culture, focusing on core products and foundry businesses.

images.alt_text: The company is scheduled to report first-quarter results on Apr 24, giving Tan an opportunity to lay out more of his strategy.
The news comes a day after Nvidia warned of a US$5.5 billion hit as Washington restricted exports of its AI processor tailored for China.
The leadership changes are the first major move under Lip-Bu Tan, who took the top job last month.

site_title: Donald Trump is proving disastrous for Big Tech
summary: US tech giants face significant challenges under Donald Trump's presidency, with combined market value falling by $2.3 trillion since his inauguration. Trump's trade war and trustbuster efforts, led by the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice, target companies such as Google, Meta, Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft. Tariffs and restrictions on Chinese goods, including those from Nvidia and Apple, are expected to rise, potentially cooling their growth. The situation may worsen, with China's watchdogs probing American companies and the European Union considering levies against US tech giants.

images.alt_text: The stage is seen after a keynote session at the SAP Center in San Jose, California, on March 18, 2025. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP)

site_title: TSMC shows off new tech for stitching together bigger, faster chips
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) unveiled its new A14 manufacturing technology, set to arrive in 2028, which can produce faster chips with 15% more performance at the same power consumption or 30% less power at the same speed as its existing N2 chips. The technology will allow the stitching together of at least 16 large computing chips, memory chips, and optical interconnections, enabling thousands of watts of power to be delivered to the chips. TSMC plans to build two factories near its Arizona chip plants to carry out this work, as demand for massive AI chips shifts the competition between TSMC and Intel.

images.alt_text: TSMC has been spending billions of US dollars on new factories overseas, though it has said most manufacturing will remain in Taiwan.
In addition to AMD, both Apple and Nvidia have said that some of their chips are being produced at TSMC’s Arizona plant.
The main chipmaker for Apple and Nvidia reported revenue of NT$839.25 billion (S$34 billion) in the first three months of 2025.

site_title: GE2025: PAP’s unfair treatment of opposition wards is ‘negative politics’, says WP’s Pritam Singh
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh criticized the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) for its treatment of opposition wards, calling it "negative politics". Singh listed examples of how opposition wards were last to receive estate upgrades and how opposition MPs were denied access to community clubs since 1981. He accused the PAP of using these tactics to maintain power, saying "PAP only listens when it loses vote share and parliamentary seats to the Workers' Party". Singh's comments come after Prime Minister Lawrence Wong accused the WP of negative politics, sparking a heated exchange between the two parties.

site_title: GE2025: PSP’s leaders to run in West Coast-Jurong West GRC, in reprise of GE2020’s closest fight
summary: The Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has announced its candidates for the West Coast-Jurong West Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming Singapore general election (GE2025). PSP chairman Tan Cheng Bock, NCMPs Leong Mun Wai and Hazel Poa, and first-time candidates Sumarleki Amjah and Sani Ismail will run in the newly formed GRC. This is a partial reprise of the 2020 contest, where PSP narrowly lost to the PAP. The PSP team is seen as a strong contender, with Tan Cheng Bock's potential candidacy possibly marking his last election.

Leong Mun Wai (centre) of PSP meets Marymount SMC MP Gan Siow Huang (left) ahead of his walkabout on Saturday.

site_title: GE2025: PAP’s West Coast-Jurong West team offers mix of youth and experience: Desmond Lee
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its team for the West Coast-Jurong West GRC, a constituency that saw a narrow win for the PAP in 2020. The team, led by Minister Desmond Lee, includes Tan Cheng Bock, a veteran politician, and a mix of youth and experience. The opposition Progress Singapore Party (PSP) has also announced its top three leaders, including Tan Cheng Bock, who is gearing up for his final electoral outing. The election is expected to be closely fought, with the PAP and PSP vying for the seat.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Minister of State for Home Affairs and for National Development Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, Manpower Minister and Marine Parade GRC MP Tan See Leng, business development director Diana Pang and South East District Mayor Mohd Fahmi Aliman speaking to ST near Eunos Crescent Market and Food Centre on March 30.
The Workers' Party introduced three new candidates on Apr 20: (from left to right) Jackson Au, Paris Parameswari, and Michael Thng.
